text 1: Persistent pain characterizes many clinical conditions and is usually the reason that patients seek medical attention.
text 2: Persistent pain is often ignored by patients and rarely leads them to seek medical attention.

text 1: Thermal nociceptors are activated by extremes in temperature, typically greater than 45°C (115°F) or less than 5°C (41°F).
text 2: Thermal nociceptors are activated at moderate temperatures, typically between 20°C (68°F) and 30°C (86°F).

text 1: First and second pain are carried by C fibers and A delta fibers, respectively.
text 2: First and second pain are carried by A delta and C fibers, respectively.

text 1: Signals from nociceptors are conveyed to neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord.
text 2: Signals from nociceptors are conveyed to neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

text 1: Acute, temporary, or minor are terms used to describe the different types of pain experienced.
text 2: Acute, persistent, or chronic are terms used to describe the different types of pain experienced.

text 1: Morphine controls pain by activating opioid receptors.
text 2: Morphine controls pain by inhibiting opioid receptors.

text 1: Pain is the direct expression of a sensory event and requires minimal processing in the brain.
text 2: Pain is not the direct expression of a sensory event but a product of elaborate processing in the brain.

text 1: Opioid peptides hinder endogenous pain control.
text 2: Opioid peptides contribute to endogenous pain control.

text 1: Noxious insults activate only mechanical nociceptors.
text 2: Noxious insults activate thermal, mechanical, and polymodal nociceptors.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the brain intensifies pain sensation.

text 1: The hippocampus solely relays nociceptive information to the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Several thalamic nuclei relay nociceptive information to the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Pain perception is regulated by a balance of activity in nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.
text 2: Pain perception is unaffected by nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.

text 1: Tolerance to and dependence on opioids are the same phenomena.
text 2: Tolerance to and dependence on opioids are distinct phenomena.

text 1: The perception of pain arises from and can be controlled by cortical mechanisms.
text 2: The perception of pain cannot be influenced by cortical mechanisms.

text 1: Silent nociceptors are the most well-understood class of nociceptors.
text 2: Silent nociceptors are an enigmatic class of nociceptors.

text 1: The map shows that multiple brain regions are engaged by episodic memory, indicating how a single cognitive function can be associated with multiple brain regions.
text 2: The map shows that only one brain region is engaged by episodic memory, indicating how cognitive function is limited to a single brain region.

text 1: These maps show that the hippocampus is engaged by multiple cognitive functions, illustrating a many-to-one mapping.
text 2: These maps show that the hippocampus is engaged by a single cognitive function, illustrating a one-to-one mapping.

text 1: fMRI is based on the physics of gravitational waves and the biology of neural coupling.
text 2: fMRI is based on the physics of magnetic resonance and the biology of neurovascular coupling.

text 1: fMRI supports inferences about whether a brain region is necessary for a behavior.
text 2: fMRI does not support inferences about whether a brain region is necessary for a behavior.

text 1: fMRI technology is no longer undergoing development and has reached its maximum potential in temporal and spatial resolution.
text 2: fMRI technology is undergoing continual development to improve the temporal and spatial resolution of biological measurements.

text 1: Studies with fMRI suggest that some patients in a vegetative state exhibit brain activity that reflects mental processing.
text 2: Studies with fMRI suggest that patients in a vegetative state show no brain activity, having no mental processing.

text 1: The discovery of MRI in the 1970s was never recognized by the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
text 2: The discovery of MRI in the 1970s was recognized by the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2003.

text 1: Some laboratory studies have reported differential brain activity when groups of subjects are instructed to lie repeatedly.
text 2: No laboratory studies have reported differential brain activity when groups of subjects are instructed to lie repeatedly.

text 1: fMRI evidence is widely admissible in court due to its high reliability.
text 2: fMRI evidence is generally inadmissible in court due to reliability issues.

text 1: An important challenge for neuroscientists is to convey that fMRI is infallible and without limitations.
text 2: An important challenge for neuroscientists is to convey that fMRI is powerful but has limitations.

text 1: fMRI provides the opportunity to study the function of the human brain in both health and disease.
text 2: fMRI only provides the opportunity to study the function of the human brain in disease.

text 1: The ability to image the human brain with noninvasive tools has not influenced clinical diagnosis and treatment.
text 2: The ability to image the human brain with noninvasive tools has led to applications in clinical diagnosis and treatment.

text 1: Understanding the relationship between BOLD activity and other processes is not essential for scientific advancement.
text 2: A better understanding of the relationship between BOLD activity and other processes is essential for scientific alignment and divergence.

text 1: When human subjects perform cognitive tasks during fMRI, there is no way to link BOLD activity measurements to mental processes.
text 2: When human subjects perform cognitive tasks during fMRI, BOLD activity measurements can be linked to specific mental processes.

text 1: fMRI measures the EEG response to neuronal activity as part of linking biological and behavioral measures.
text 2: fMRI measures the BOLD response to neuronal activity as part of linking biological and behavioral measures.

text 1: Sections through peripheral nerve tracts are shown in the images at right.
text 2: Sections through central nerve tracts are shown in the images at right.

text 1: Transplanted cells that differentiate into astrocytes enhance remyelination and substantially improve the locomotor ability of experimental animals.
text 2: Transplanted cells that differentiate into oligodendrocytes enhance remyelination and substantially improve the locomotor ability of experimental animals.

text 1: Axons can regenerate and form new synapses following injury, but in mammals, regeneration is far more widespread and effective in central axons than in peripheral axons.
text 2: Axons can regenerate and form new synapses following injury, but in mammals, regeneration is far more widespread and effective in peripheral axons than in central axons.

text 1: A key factor in the differential response of peripheral and central axons is that the environment confronting injured central axons is rich in supporting growth.
text 2: A key factor in the differential response of peripheral and central axons is that the environment confronting injured central axons is poor at supporting growth.

text 1: Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans are inhibitory factors secreted by astrocytes.
text 2: Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans are growth-promoting factors secreted by astrocytes.

text 1: Studies have promoted regeneration of severed axons by enhancing their intrinsic growth programs and observed some restoration of function.
text 2: Studies have promoted regeneration of severed axons by inhibiting their intrinsic growth programs and observed substantial restoration of function.

text 1: The traditional view that all neurogenesis occurs during or shortly after gestation has modified by the discovery that new neurons are born throughout life in a few brain areas.
text 2: The traditional view that neurogenesis does not occur during or shortly after gestation has modified by the discovery that new neurons are born throughout life in a few brain areas.

text 1: A more useful source for neuronal replacement may be neurons derived from ES or iPS cells.
text 2: A more useful source for neuronal replacement may be neurons derived from adult differentiated cells.

text 1: Efforts to replace central neurons or enhance regeneration would still be beneficial even if axons were unable to form functional synapses with their target cells.
text 2: Efforts to replace central neurons or enhance regeneration would be of little use if axons were unable to form functional synapses with their target cells.

text 1: One method to enhance neurogenesis includes administration of growth factors to promote neuronal production from progenitors grown in culture.
text 2: One method to enhance neurogenesis includes removing growth factors to halt neuronal production from progenitors grown in culture.

text 1: Severed axons can only form synapses on distant targets following regeneration.
text 2: Severed axons can form synapses on nearby targets following regeneration.

text 1: Transcriptional reprogramming generally reduces potential of quiescent cells following injury.
text 2: Transcriptional reprogramming could harness potential of quiescent cells following injury.

text 1: Wallerian degeneration involves the degeneration of the distal segment after axons are transected.
text 2: Wallerian degeneration involves the regeneration of the distal segment after axons are transected.

text 1: Damaged axons primarily form new connections, generating adaptive circuits that can fully compensate for those lost to injury.
text 2: Intact axons can form new connections, generating adaptive circuits that can compensate to some extent for those lost to injury.

text 1: Figure 50–18 shows destroyed retinal ganglion axons in the optic nerve unable to form functional synapses.
text 2: Figure 50–18 shows regenerated retinal ganglion axons in the optic nerve forming functional synapses.

text 1: The hippocampus has no role in the binding of associations during both encoding and retrieval.
text 2: The hippocampus plays an essential role in the binding of associations during both encoding and retrieval.

text 1: Studies show that successful formation of episodic memories independently occurs within the medial temporal lobe.
text 2: Studies show that successful formation of episodic memories depends on interaction between frontoparietal networks and the medial temporal lobe.

text 1: Episodic memory processing involves only encoding and retrieval.
text 2: Episodic memory processing involves encoding, storage, retrieval, and consolidation.

text 1: Episodic memory is mediated by a single process.
text 2: Episodic memory is mediated by at least four related but distinct types of processing.

text 1: Encoding is the process by which stored information is recalled.
text 2: Encoding is the process by which new information is initially acquired and processed during the formation of a new memory.

text 1: Consolidation makes stored information less stable.
text 2: Consolidation transforms temporarily stored information into a more stable form.

text 1: Retrieval involves bringing back to mind different kinds of information that are stored.
text 2: Retrieval refers to the initial acquisition of new information.

text 1: Memory encoding is stronger when one is motivated to remember due to emotional or behavioral relevance.
text 2: Memory encoding is unaffected by one's motivation to remember.

text 1: Long-term storage of memory has an almost unlimited capacity.
text 2: Long-term storage of memory has very limited capacity.

text 1: Memory retrieval is an exact reflection of stored memory without distortion.
text 2: Memory retrieval is a constructive process and subject to distortion.

text 1: Functional MRI does not allow for identification of active brain regions during memory processes.
text 2: Functional MRI allows researchers to identify specific brain regions active during different memory processes.

text 1: Hippocampal activity during encoding is greater for remembered items than for forgotten items.
text 2: Hippocampal activity during encoding is greater for forgotten items than for remembered items.

text 1: Only the frontoparietal networks are involved in the formation of episodic memories, not the medial temporal lobe.
text 2: Frontoparietal networks and the medial temporal lobe are involved in the formation of episodic memories.

text 1: Distinct subregions within the hippocampus contribute to different aspects of memory encoding.
text 2: The hippocampus functions uniformly, with no distinct subregions contributing to different aspects of memory encoding.

text 1: The medial temporal lobe independently handles memory consolidation and retrieval without cortical interaction.
text 2: Interactions between the medial temporal lobe and cortical regions are central in memory consolidation and retrieval.

text 1: The proenkephalin precursor protein contains multiple copies of dynorphin and orphanin FQ.
text 2: The proenkephalin precursor protein contains multiple copies of methionine-enkephalin and leucine-enkephalin.

text 1: β-Endorphin is a cleavage product of prodynorphin.
text 2: β-Endorphin is a cleavage product of pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC).

text 1: Enkephalin and dynorphin are located only in the hypothalamus.
text 2: Enkephalin and dynorphin are located in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

text 1: Orphanin FQ participates in a broad range of physiological functions.
text 2: Orphanin FQ is solely involved in pain regulation.

text 1: Morphine acts by mimicking the actions of endogenous opioid peptides.
text 2: Morphine acts as an antagonist to endogenous opioid peptides.

text 1: Aδ nociceptors have more μ receptors than C-fiber nociceptors.
text 2: C-fiber nociceptors have more μ receptors than Aδ nociceptors.

text 1: Systemic morphine-induced analgesia enhances with naloxone injection.
text 2: Systemic morphine-induced analgesia can be blocked by naloxone injection.

text 1: Prodynorphin can produce dynorphin and α-neoendorphin.
text 2: Prodynorphin produces exclusively β-endorphin.

text 1: Spinal administration of morphine is commonly used in the treatment of postoperative pain.
text 2: Spinal administration of morphine is avoided in the treatment of postoperative pain.

text 1: Opioids regulate nociceptive transmission by increasing K+ conductances.
text 2: Opioids regulate nociceptive transmission by decreasing K+ conductances.

text 1: Opioid receptors in the bowel muscles lead to diarrhea as a side effect.
text 2: Opioid receptors are expressed in the bowel muscles leading to constipation as a side effect.

text 1: Activation of the orphanin receptor participates in a broad range of other physiological functions.
text 2: The orphanin receptor is only responsible for opioid peptide release.

text 1: The C-fiber nociceptors mediate fast acute pain.
text 2: The C-fiber nociceptors mediate slow persistent pain.

text 1: Naloxone induces analgesia when injected into specific brain regions.
text 2: Naloxone can block morphine-induced analgesia when injected into specific brain regions.

text 1: Morphine is more effective in the treatment of acute pain than persistent pain.
text 2: Morphine is more effective in the treatment of persistent pain than acute pain.

text 1: Progenitor cells can undergo asymmetric division to generate two neurons or two glial cells.
text 2: Progenitor cells can undergo asymmetric division to generate a neuron and a glial cell, or a neuron and another progenitor.

text 1: Radial glial cells serve as precursors to neurons in the central nervous system and provide a scaffold for radial neuronal migration.
text 2: Radial glial cells serve only as precursors to neurons without providing a scaffold for radial neuronal migration.

text 1: Figure 46–3 depicts Delta binding to Notch and determining neuronal fate.
text 2: Figure 46–3 depicts Delta binding to Notch and determining glial fate.

text 1: Notch signaling regulates the expression of two non-bHLH transcription factors, Olig1 and Olig2, essential for oligodendrocyte production.
text 2: Notch signaling regulates the expression of two bHLH transcription factors, Olig1 and Olig2, which have essential roles in the production of embryonic and postnatal oligodendrocytes.

text 1: Neurons emerge from a proneural region where only certain cells form neurons and others become epidermal support cells.
text 2: Neurons emerge from a proneural region where all cells form neurons without differentiation into support cells.

text 1: At early stages of development in the mammalian cortex, Notch signaling promotes neuronal generation by activating Hes proteins.
text 2: At early stages of development in the mammalian cortex, Notch signaling promotes the generation of radial glial cells by activating Hes proteins.

text 1: In the mammalian central nervous system, cells with high levels of Notch activation are diverted from neuronal fates.
text 2: In the mammalian central nervous system, cells with low levels of Notch activation are diverted from neuronal fates.

text 1: Numb protein plays a key role in neurogenesis by enhancing Notch signaling.
text 2: Numb protein plays a key role in neurogenesis by antagonizing Notch signaling.

text 1: Neurogenins promote astrocyte production by activating downstream proneural bHLH transcription factors.
text 2: Neurogenins promote neuronal production by activating downstream proneural bHLH transcription factors.

text 1: During cell division, radial glial cells give rise to postmitotic neurons that migrate using radial glial cells as a guide.
text 2: During cell division, radial glial cells give rise to postmitotic neurons that do not migrate using radial glial cells as a guide.

text 1: Delta binds to Notch, resulting in the full receptor being transported into the nucleus.
text 2: Delta binds to Notch, resulting in proteolytic cleavage of the Notch cytoplasmic domain that enters the nucleus.

text 1: The initial difference in Notch levels between cells may be small and stochastic, but these differences are amplified through feedback pathways.
text 2: Notch levels between cells start broadly distinct and are further minimized through feedback pathways.

text 1: At later stages of cortical development, Notch signaling activates Hes proteins which result in astrocyte differentiation.
text 2: At later stages of cortical development, Notch signaling activates Hes proteins which result in neuronal differentiation.

text 1: The radial glial cells produce independently of feedback signals from neurons.
text 2: The radial glial cells rely on feedback signals from neurons for continued production.

text 1: Numb determines the neuronal fate of daughter cells by preferential localization in neuronal daughters.
text 2: Numb determines the neuronal fate of daughter cells by being evenly distributed in all daughters.

text 1: Microglia prune synapses by engulfing weak synapses, stimulated by complement components such as C1q.
text 2: Microglia prune synapses by engulfing strong synapses, stimulated by complement components such as C1q.

text 1: Microglia secrete transforming growth factor β (TGFβ), promoting production of C1q.
text 2: Astrocytes secrete transforming growth factor β (TGFβ), promoting production of C1q.

text 1: C1q tags inactive terminals for removal involving C3 and C3R interaction.
text 2: C1q tags active terminals for removal involving C3 and C3R interaction.

text 1: Only astrocytes are involved in synapse formation and elimination.
text 2: Both astrocytes and microglia are involved in synapse formation and elimination.

text 1: Schwann cells are exclusively involved in synapse formation at the neuromuscular junction.
text 2: Schwann cells may play roles at the neuromuscular junction in synapse formation and elimination.

text 1: Synaptic specificity is guided by matching cell-surface recognition molecules.
text 2: Synaptic specificity is guided by randomly expressed recognition molecules.

text 1: Cadherins, immunoglobulins, and leucine-rich repeat proteins are involved in synaptic specificity.
text 2: Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are involved in synaptic specificity.

text 1: The basal lamina at the neuromuscular junction helps organize differentiation.
text 2: The basal lamina at the neuromuscular junction prevents differentiation.

text 1: Agrin inhibits postsynaptic differentiation.
text 2: Agrin is a key nerve-derived organizer of postsynaptic differentiation.

text 1: Central synapses develop similarly to those at the neuromuscular junction.
text 2: Central synapses develop completely differently from those at the neuromuscular junction.

text 1: Many synapses formed initially in both nervous systems are later eliminated.
text 2: All synapses formed initially in both nervous systems are maintained throughout life.

text 1: Glial cells contribute to synapse formation, maturation, maintenance, and elimination.
text 2: Glial cells only contribute to synapse maintenance.

text 1: Neuroligins and neurexins do not function as synaptic organizers.
text 2: Synaptic organizers include neuroligins and neurexins.

text 1: Activity-dependent mechanisms always reduce synaptic specificity.
text 2: Activity-dependent mechanisms can sharpen synaptic specificity.

text 1: At the neuromuscular junction, motor neurons and muscle fibers interact to form synapses.
text 2: At the neuromuscular junction, motor neurons and muscle fibers do not interact to form synapses.

text 1: The hypothalamus coordinates homeostatic regulation by linking interoceptive sensory feedback with adaptive behaviors and physiological responses.
text 2: The hypothalamus coordinates homeostatic regulation by ignoring sensory feedback and only focusing on external stimuli.

text 1: Neurons in the hypothalamus control key survival activities such as fertility, mating, and nurturing offspring.
text 2: Neurons in the hypothalamus control key survival activities such as digestion, immunity, and skin regeneration.

text 1: The neuroendocrine system secretes peptide hormones from the pituitary to control functions like water retention and somatic growth.
text 2: The neuroendocrine system secretes peptide hormones from the pituitary to control smell and taste perception.

text 1: Homeostasis allows physiological parameters to fluctuate wildly outside of a narrow range without impacting survival.
text 2: Homeostasis keeps physiological parameters within a narrow range and is essential for survival.

text 1: Sexual behavior and aggression are controlled by the cerebellum and a subarea of the amygdala.
text 2: Sexual behavior and aggression are controlled by the preoptic hypothalamic area and a subarea of the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus.

text 1: Merkel cells express Piezo2 proteins and show increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ levels when stimulated by pressure.
text 2: Merkel cells express Piezo1 proteins and show decreased cytoplasmic Ca2+ levels when stimulated by pressure.

text 1: Hairs are embedded in skin invaginations called hair follicles.
text 2: Hairs are embedded in skin projections called hair follicles.

text 1: Guard hairs are innervated by the largest-diameter and fastest-conducting sensory nerve fibers (type Aβ).
text 2: Guard hairs are innervated by the smallest-diameter and slowest-conducting sensory nerve fibers (type C).

text 1: The smallest and most numerous hairs are called guard hairs.
text 2: The smallest and most numerous hairs are called zigzag or down hairs.

text 1: Aδ and C fibers were thought to mediate only visual or auditory sensations.
text 2: Aδ and C fibers were thought to mediate only thermal or painful sensations.

text 1: Merkel cells are responsible for the initial response to dynamic touch.
text 2: Merkel cells are responsible for the sustained response to static touch.

text 1: Each sensory nerve fiber collects information from a single point of skin because its distal terminals are unbranched.
text 2: Each sensory nerve fiber collects information from a wide area of skin because its distal terminals have multiple branches.

text 1: Humans cannot perceive motion of individual hairs or localize the sensation to the base of the hair.
text 2: Humans can perceive motion of individual hairs and localize the sensation to the base of the hair.

text 1: Sensory hair fibers are insensitive to motion.
text 2: Sensory hair fibers are extremely sensitive to motion.

text 1: Sensory neurons are named slowly adapting high-threshold mechanoreceptors (SA-HTMRs) because they respond to forceful touch.
text 2: Sensory neurons are named rapidly adapting low-threshold mechanoreceptors (RA-LTMRs) because they respond to gentle touch.

text 1: Gentle touch excites only one sensory fiber at the site of contact.
text 2: Gentle touch excites many different sensory fibers at the site of contact.

text 1: Hair follicles are innervated by redundant lines of communication, rather than a single labeled line.
text 2: Hair follicles are innervated by a single labeled line, with no redundancy in nerve fibers.

text 1: Touch information is transmitted in parallel by an ensemble of sensory neurons.
text 2: Touch information is transmitted sequentially by a single sensory neuron.

text 1: Four types of hairs are found in mammalian skin: zigzag, guard, awl/auchene, and spiraled hairs.
text 2: Three types of hairs are found in mammalian skin: zigzag, guard, and awl/auchene hairs.

text 1: Hairs or sensory antennae detect sound, light, and smell.
text 2: Hairs or sensory antennae detect important object features such as texture, curvature, and rigidity.

text 1: A communication brain–machine interface can control a computer cursor using a continuous decoder based on neural activity during the preparation epoch.
text 2: A communication brain–machine interface can control a computer cursor using a discrete decoder based on neural activity during the preparation epoch.

text 1: The information transfer rate (ITR) of the brain–machine interface is approximately 6.5 bps.
text 2: The information transfer rate (ITR) of the brain–machine interface is approximately 0.5 bps.

text 1: Decoding accuracy increases with the period in which spike counts are taken because spiking noise is more easily averaged out in longer periods.
text 2: Decoding accuracy decreases with the period in which spike counts are taken because spiking noise is more difficult to manage in longer periods.

text 1: The V-KF outperformed the ReFIT-KF by producing straighter cursor movements with less deviation from a straight line to the target.
text 2: The ReFIT-KF outperformed the V-KF by producing straighter cursor movements with less deviation from a straight line to the target.

text 1: Prosthetic limbs directed by BMIs can move in three dimensions and additionally can move the hand in a grip angle dimension.
text 2: Prosthetic limbs directed by BMIs cannot move the hand in any additional dimensions beyond the basic three dimensions.

text 1: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) sends electrical signals to a set of muscle groups to restore movement in paralyzed arms.
text 2: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) sends mechanical pulses to restore movement in paralyzed arms.

text 1: The duration of the trial length was equal to the period in which spike counts were taken minus 190 ms.
text 2: The duration of the trial length was equal to the period in which spike counts were taken plus 190 ms.

text 1: Monkeys in experiments were trained to ignore central targets and only focus on peripheral targets.
text 2: Monkeys in experiments were trained to fixate on central targets and prepare to reach peripheral targets.

text 1: Decoding accuracy and information transfer rate are affected by the number of targets and trial lengths.
text 2: Decoding accuracy and information transfer rate are not affected by the number of targets and trial lengths.

text 1: V-KF is being used in clinical trials by people with paralysis.
text 2: ReFIT-KF is being used in clinical trials by people with paralysis.

text 1: The period in which spike counts are taken has no effect on decoding performance and information transfer rate.
text 2: The period in which spike counts are taken affects decoding performance and information transfer rate.

text 1: BMI-directed prosthetic arms cannot orient the hand or grasp, manipulate, and carry objects.
text 2: BMI-directed prosthetic arms can orient the hand and grasp, manipulate, and carry objects.

text 1: Trials showed that the wrist of a robotic arm can be rotated in an additional grip angle.
text 2: Trials showed that the wrist of a robotic arm cannot be rotated in any additional grip angle.

text 1: Subjects could not erase typing mistakes using a delete key while using BMI.
text 2: Subjects could erase typing mistakes using a delete key while using BMI.

text 1: The ReFIT-KF involved closing the loop of BMI control through decoder calibration to achieve straight cursor movement.
text 2: The ReFIT-KF did not involve closing the loop of BMI control through decoder calibration to achieve straight cursor movement.

text 1: The stereocilia decrease in length towards the single kinocilium, and deflection towards it causes the cell to hyperpolarize, increasing the afferent firing rate.
text 2: The stereocilia increase in length toward the single kinocilium, and deflection toward it causes the cell to depolarize, increasing the afferent firing rate.

text 1: The vestibular portion of the membranous labyrinth lies anterior to the cochlea.
text 2: The vestibular portion of the membranous labyrinth lies lateral and posterior to the cochlea.

text 1: Both of the otolith organs lie outside the central compartment of the labyrinth, surrounded by the bony cochlea.
text 2: Both of the otolith organs lie in the central compartment of the labyrinth, surrounded by the bony vestibule.

text 1: Endolymph is a K+-rich fluid filling the membranous labyrinth.
text 2: Endolymph is a Na+-rich fluid filling the bony labyrinth.

text 1: Perilymph bathes the basal surface of the receptor epithelia and nerve fibers.
text 2: Endolymph bathes the basal surface of the receptor epithelia and nerve fibers.

text 1: The posterior vestibular artery supplies the structures innervated by the superior vestibular nerve.
text 2: The anterior vestibular artery supplies the structures innervated by the superior vestibular nerve.

text 1: Stimulation of efferent fibers from the brain stem changes the sensitivity of afferent axons.
text 2: Stimulation of afferent fibers changes the sensitivity of efferent axons.

text 1: The semicircular canals detect angular acceleration and report the magnitudes and motion directions to the brain.
text 2: The semicircular canals detect linear acceleration and report the magnitudes and motion directions to the brain.

text 1: The horizontal canal is oriented approximately 30° elevated above the naso-occipital axis.
text 2: The horizontal canal is oriented approximately 60° elevated above the naso-occipital axis.

text 1: The anterior and posterior canals are oriented more vertically at approximately 45 degrees from the sagittal plane.
text 2: The anterior and posterior canals are oriented horizontally at approximately 90 degrees from the sagittal plane.

text 1: The stereocilia are arranged such that leftward rotational motion is inhibitory for the left horizontal canal.
text 2: The stereocilia are arranged such that leftward rotational motion is excitatory for the left horizontal canal.

text 1: Vestibular signals are carried from the hair cells to the brain stem by branches of the vestibulocochlear nerve.
text 2: Vestibular signals are carried from the hair cells to the spinal cord by branches of the vagus nerve.

text 1: Hair cells transduce auditory signals into visual signals.
text 2: Hair cells transduce head motion into vestibular signals.

text 1: The oval and round windows connect the endolymphatic space to the cochlear duct.
text 2: The oval and round windows connect the perilymphatic space to the middle ear cavity.

text 1: Balance between endolymph and perilymph has no impact on vestibular function.
text 2: Disruption of the balance between endolymph and perilymph can result in vestibular dysfunction.

text 1: The FM area in the mustached bat's auditory cortex is where the distance from the target is computed.
text 2: The FM area in the mustached bat's auditory cortex is where the velocity of the target is computed.

text 1: The Doppler-shifted CF area in the mustached bat is specialized for computing the distance from the target.
text 2: The Doppler-shifted CF area in the mustached bat is specialized for the identification of small fluttering objects.

text 1: The auditory cortex suppression in marmoset monkeys begins several hundred milliseconds prior to vocalization.
text 2: The auditory cortex suppression in marmoset monkeys begins several milliseconds after vocalization starts.

text 1: In humans, there is more suppression of auditory cortex if vocal feedback is altered.
text 2: In humans, there is less suppression of auditory cortex if vocal feedback is altered.

text 1: Vocalization-induced suppression is not observed in any mammalian subcortical structures.
text 2: Vocalization-induced suppression is observed in several mammalian subcortical structures.

text 1: A smaller proportion of neurons in marmoset A1 increases their responses during self-initiated vocalizations.
text 2: Most neurons in marmoset A1 increase their responses during self-initiated vocalizations.

text 1: Single-neuron recordings show suppression of cortical responses to self-initiated vocalizations in monkeys.
text 2: Single-neuron recordings show enhancement of cortical responses to self-initiated vocalizations in monkeys.

text 1: Self-generated sounds enhance the ability to monitor external sounds during speaking.
text 2: Self-generated sounds need to be masked to monitor external sounds during speaking.

text 1: Vocal feedback monitoring in the auditory cortex increases if vocal feedback is experimentally altered.
text 2: Vocal feedback monitoring in the auditory cortex decreases if vocal feedback is experimentally altered.

text 1: The enhancement of auditory responses in marmosets suggests inhibition as the cause.
text 2: The suppression of auditory responses in marmosets suggests inhibition as the cause.

text 1: Vocalization-induced suppression starts several hundred milliseconds before vocal onset in cortical areas.
text 2: Vocalization-induced suppression starts several hundred milliseconds after vocal onset in cortical areas.

text 1: The absence of vocal feedback-related neural activity suggests no network for monitoring these signals.
text 2: The presence of vocal feedback-related neural activity suggests a network responsible for monitoring these signals.

text 1: Neurons do not respond to playback of vocalizations, indicating auditory cortical dysfunction.
text 2: Neurons respond to playback of vocalizations, indicating auditory cortical function.

text 1: Feedback through the descending auditory pathway likely causes vocalization-related excitation.
text 2: Feedback through the ascending auditory pathway likely causes vocalization-related excitation.

text 1: Humans and monkeys show vocalization-induced suppression due to modulatory circuits.
text 2: Humans and monkeys do not show vocalization-induced suppression due to modulatory circuits.

text 1: The cerebellar cortex contains three main types of neurons organized into five layers.
text 2: The cerebellar cortex contains five main types of neurons organized into three layers.

text 1: Mossy fibers form inhibitory synapses on the dendrites of granule cells in the molecular layer.
text 2: Mossy fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of granule cells in the granular layer.

text 1: Purkinje cells fire at rates as high as several hundred spikes per second during active movements.
text 2: Purkinje cells remain silent during active movements.

text 1: Each Purkinje cell is contacted by a single granule cell.
text 2: Each Purkinje cell is contacted potentially by axons from somewhere between 200,000 and 1 million granule cells.

text 1: Climbing fibers cause complex spikes that seem specialized for event detection.
text 2: Climbing fibers cause simple spikes specialized for continuous monitoring.

text 1: The cerebellar microcircuit is replicated many times across the surface of the cerebellar cortex.
text 2: The cerebellar microcircuit appears only once in the cerebellar cortex.

text 1: Parallel fibers allow each mossy fiber to influence a large number of Purkinje cells.
text 2: Parallel fibers restrict each mossy fiber to influence only a single Purkinje cell.

text 1: Mitochondria are absent in the structures of the glomerulus, indicating low metabolic activity.
text 2: Mitochondria are present in all of the structures in the glomerulus, consistent with their high metabolic activity.

text 1: The cerebellar cortex performs unique computations on each of its inputs.
text 2: The cerebellar cortex performs the same basic canonical computation on all of its inputs.

text 1: Recurrent loops in the cerebellar cortex involve Golgi cells.
text 2: Recurrent loops in the cerebellar cortex do not involve any Golgi cells.

text 1: Excitation and inhibition do not converge in the cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei.
text 2: Excitation and inhibition converge both in the cerebellar cortex and in the deep nuclei.

text 1: Inhibitory inputs from Purkinje cells converge with excitatory inputs from axon collaterals of mossy and climbing fibers.
text 2: Inhibitory inputs from Purkinje cells are not involved in convergence with excitatory inputs from mossy and climbing fibers.

text 1: Neurons of the deep cerebellar nuclei are inactive without synaptic inputs.
text 2: Neurons of the deep cerebellar nuclei are active spontaneously even in the absence of synaptic inputs.

text 1: Stellate cells affect Purkinje cells via synapses that are on the cell body.
text 2: Stellate cells affect Purkinje cells via synapses that are on distal dendrites.

text 1: Golgi cells receive both excitatory and inhibitory inputs.
text 2: Golgi cells receive only excitatory inputs.

text 1: Microtubules (Mt) are prominent cytoskeletal filaments in the nuclear envelope.
text 2: Microtubules (Mt) are prominent cytoskeletal filaments in the cytosol.

text 1: The Golgi apparatus in neurons is solely responsible for energy production.
text 2: The Golgi apparatus in neurons is involved in processing membrane and secretory proteins.

text 1: The nuclear envelope is isolated from the endoplasmic reticulum.
text 2: The nuclear envelope is continuous with the endoplasmic reticulum.

text 1: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is not involved with calcium storage in neurons.
text 2: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum acts as a regulated internal Ca2+ store throughout the neuronal cytoplasm.

text 1: Nuclear pores block all molecules regardless of size from passing through by diffusion.
text 2: Nuclear pores allow molecules with molecular weights less than 5,000 to pass freely by diffusion.

text 1: Polyribosomes in dendritic spines are mainly involved in DNA replication.
text 2: Polyribosomes in dendritic spines mediate local protein synthesis.

text 1: A specialized portion of the rough endoplasmic reticulum forms the mitochondrial membrane.
text 2: A specialized portion of the rough endoplasmic reticulum forms the nuclear envelope.

text 1: Proteins destined for the endoplasmic reticulum are formed after polysomes attach to its membrane.
text 2: Proteins destined for the nucleus are formed after polysomes attach to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.

text 1: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum extends into the neck of a dendritic spine.
text 2: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is primarily located in axon terminals.

text 1: The nuclear envelope is solid and lacks any channels for transport.
text 2: The nuclear envelope is interrupted by nuclear pores that form hydrophilic channels.

text 1: Concentrations of polyribosomes in dendritic spines mediate local protein synthesis.
text 2: Concentrations of polyribosomes in dendritic spines mediate lipid synthesis.

text 1: There is no functional boundary between the cell body and axon at the axon hillock.
text 2: A sharp functional boundary exists between the cell body and axon at the axon hillock.

text 1: Molecules with any molecular weight can pass through nuclear pores freely by diffusion.
text 2: Molecules with molecular weights less than 5,000 can pass through nuclear pores freely by diffusion.

text 1: The cytoplasm of the nerve cell body is functionally distinct from the dendritic tree.
text 2: The cytoplasm of the nerve cell body extends into the dendritic tree without functional differentiation.

text 1: In axons, the smooth endoplasmic reticulum is absent from thin processes called spines.
text 2: In dendrites, the smooth endoplasmic reticulum is prominent at the base of thin processes called spines.

text 1: Gradients of ephrins provide purely attractant signals in the brain, guiding retinal axons to their proper termination zones within the tectum.
text 2: Gradients of ephrins provide inhibitory signals in the brain, guiding retinal axons to their proper termination zones within the tectum.

text 1: Ephrin-B2 prevents nasal retinal axons, which express EphB1, from crossing the midline at the optic chiasm by acting as a repellent signal.
text 2: Ephrin-B2 prevents temporal retinal axons, which express EphB1, from crossing the midline at the optic chiasm by acting as a repellent signal.

text 1: Pioneer axons use intermediate targets and molecular cues in cells or the extracellular matrix to navigate toward their destinations.
text 2: Pioneer axons navigate exclusively using gradients of molecular signals, without the aid of intermediate targets.

text 1: Retinal axons from the nasal hemiretina cross the optic chiasm and project to the ipsilateral side of the brain.
text 2: Retinal axons from the nasal hemiretina cross the optic chiasm and project to the contralateral side of the brain.

text 1: In humans, most retinal axons project to the superior colliculus, with a smaller number reaching the lateral geniculate nucleus.
text 2: In humans, most retinal axons project to the lateral geniculate nucleus, with a smaller number reaching the superior colliculus.

text 1: Retinal axons exclusively rely on molecular gradients to navigate long distances, avoiding intermediate targets.
text 2: Retinal axons use a combination of intermediate targets and molecular gradients to navigate long distances.

text 1: Class A ephrins are transmembrane proteins, while Class B ephrins are linked to the membrane via a glycosyl phosphatidylinositol tether.
text 2: Class A ephrins are linked to the membrane via a glycosyl phosphatidylinositol tether, while Class B ephrins are transmembrane proteins.

text 1: The optic chiasm plays no role in retinal axon divergence, as all axons automatically project ipsilaterally.
text 2: The optic chiasm is a key decision region where retinal axons diverge either to the ipsilateral or contralateral sides.

text 1: Layer-specific cues in the tectum direct retinal axons to ascend or descend but do not influence arborization.
text 2: Layer-specific cues in the tectum trigger retinal axons to stop and form synaptic arborizations.

text 1: Heterophilic interactions among immunoglobulin superfamily proteins, such as NCAM, mediate axon outgrowth and adhesion.
text 2: Homophilic interactions among immunoglobulin superfamily proteins, such as NCAM, mediate axon outgrowth and adhesion.

text 1: The fraction of temporal retinal axons projecting ipsilaterally is higher in humans than in rodents.
text 2: The fraction of temporal retinal axons projecting ipsilaterally is higher in rodents than in humans.

text 1: Laminins in the extracellular matrix promote axon growth via interactions with integrin receptors.
text 2: Laminins in the extracellular matrix inhibit axon growth via interactions with integrin receptors.

text 1: Semaphorin proteins influence axonal growth by interacting with integrin and catenin receptors.
text 2: Semaphorin proteins influence axonal growth by interacting with plexin and neuropilin receptors.

text 1: Netrins mediate only chemoattractant responses through interactions with DCC and Unc-5 coreceptors.
text 2: Netrins mediate both chemoattractant and chemorepellent responses through interactions with DCC and Unc-5 coreceptors.

text 1: Slit proteins mediate attractant responses through interactions with Robo class receptors.
text 2: Slit proteins mediate repellent responses through interactions with Robo class receptors.

text 1: Myotonia congenita is characterized by muscle stiffness present from birth and is a consequence of mutations in the gene coding for the ClC-1 Cl– channel in the skeletal muscle membrane.
text 2: Myotonia congenita is characterized by muscle stiffness present from adulthood and is a consequence of mutations in the gene coding for the ClC-1 Cl– channel in the skeletal muscle membrane.

text 1: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is caused by missense mutations in the voltage-sensor domains of either Ca2+ channels or Na+ channels in skeletal muscle.
text 2: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is caused by missense mutations in the voltage-sensor domains of either Cl– channels or Na+ channels in skeletal muscle.

text 1: Inherited diseases of skeletal muscle with transient episodes of weakness (periodic paralysis) or involuntary after-contractions lasting seconds (myotonia) are caused by missense mutations in voltage-gated ion channels.
text 2: Inherited diseases of skeletal muscle with transient episodes of weakness (myotonia) or involuntary after-contractions lasting seconds (periodic paralysis) are caused by gain-of-function mutations in receptor proteins.

text 1: Chronic depolarization and gain of excitability with paralysis can result from more pronounced inactivation defects in mutant Na+ channels expressed in skeletal muscle.
text 2: Chronic depolarization and loss of excitability with paralysis can result from more pronounced inactivation defects in mutant Na+ channels expressed in skeletal muscle.

text 1: Small animal models with precisely defined genetic defects are proving invaluable for the diagnosis of clinical symptoms.
text 2: Small animal models with precisely defined genetic defects are proving invaluable for the analysis of mechanisms of disease pathogenesis.

text 1: In skeletal muscle, a decrease in Cl– influx leads to membrane depolarization and repetitive firing, causing myotonia.
text 2: In skeletal muscle, an increase in Ca2+ influx leads to membrane depolarization and repetitive firing, causing myotonia.

text 1: Paramyotonia congenita is a clinical disorder characterized by myotonia and is associated with SCN4A Na+ channel mutations.
text 2: Paramyotonia congenita is a clinical disorder characterized by paralysis and is associated with SCN1A Na+ channel mutations.

text 1: The disease myotonia congenita does not involve muscle wasting, permanent muscle weakness, or other organ involvement.
text 2: The disease myotonia congenita involves muscle wasting, permanent muscle weakness, and other organ involvement.

text 1: The anomalous cation leak in hypokalemic periodic paralysis is significant and negates susceptibility to depolarization.
text 2: The anomalous cation leak in hypokalemic periodic paralysis is small but still increases susceptibility to depolarization.

text 1: Inherited as dominant, semi-dominant, or recessive traits, myotonia congenita leads to repetitive firing due to a decrease in Cl– influx.
text 2: Inherited as dominant, semi-dominant, or recessive traits, paramyotonia congenita leads to repetitive firing due to an increase in Cl– influx.

text 1: Muscle stiffness in myotonia congenita is nonprogressive and does not lead to muscle wasting.
text 2: Muscle stiffness in myotonia congenita is progressive and always leads to muscle wasting.

text 1: Myotonia and periodic paralysis are caused by mutations in genes that code for non-voltage-gated ion channels in the skeletal muscle membrane.
text 2: Myotonia and periodic paralysis are caused by mutations in genes that code for voltage-gated ion channels in the skeletal muscle membrane.

text 1: Leaky Na+ channels in hypokalemic periodic paralysis result from frameshift mutations in voltage-sensor domains.
text 2: Leaky Na+ channels in hypokalemic periodic paralysis result from missense mutations in voltage-sensor domains.

text 1: Mutation-induced anomalous ion channel leaks in skeletal muscle results in increased susceptibility to depolarization.
text 2: Mutation-induced anomalous ion channel leaks in skeletal muscle results in resistance to depolarization.

text 1: Muscle fibers in inherited skeletal muscle diseases become polarized and overly conductive during episodes of weakness.
text 2: Muscle fibers in inherited skeletal muscle diseases become depolarized and refractory during episodes of weakness.

text 1: Neurotrophins promote cell survival through inhibition of Trk receptors.
text 2: Neurotrophins promote cell survival through activation of Trk receptors.

text 1: Nerve growth factor (NGF) supports the survival of sensory and sympathetic neurons in vitro.
text 2: Nerve growth factor (NGF) supports the survival of only motor neurons in vitro.

text 1: The Trk family comprises only two membrane-spanning tyrosine kinases named TrkA and TrkB.
text 2: The Trk family comprises three membrane-spanning tyrosine kinases named TrkA, TrkB, and TrkC.

text 1: Blockade of nerve-muscle activity with curare rescues many motor neurons that would otherwise die.
text 2: Blockade of nerve-muscle activity with curare enhances the scheduled death of motor neurons.

text 1: Nearly all motor neurons generated in the spinal cord survive the embryonic development.
text 2: Approximately half of all motor neurons generated in the spinal cord die during embryonic development.

text 1: Mechanical neurons that innervate Merkel cells depend on NT-3.
text 2: Mechanical neurons that innervate Merkel cells depend on NGF.

text 1: When activity is decreased, some inhibitory neurons switch to using the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate.
text 2: When activity is decreased, some excitatory neurons switch to using the inhibitory neurotransmitter acetylcholine.

text 1: The discovery of NGF was dramatically confirmed by Levi-Montalcini and Stanley Cohen.
text 2: The discovery of NGF was solely credited to Viktor Hamburger.

text 1: NGF supports the survival of sensory and sympathetic neurons.
text 2: NGF supports the survival of interneurons and astrocytes.

text 1: Levi-Montalcini showed that adding a limb leads to the excessive death of sensory neurons.
text 2: Levi-Montalcini showed that removal of a limb leads to the excessive death of sensory neurons.

text 1: Motor neurons only depend on neurotrophin-3 (NT-3) for survival.
text 2: Motor neurons depend on glial cell line–derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) and other factors.

text 1: Activity-dependent neurotransmitter plasticity may be a more common phenomenon in the adult nervous system.
text 2: Activity-dependent neurotransmitter plasticity is non-existent in the adult nervous system.

text 1: Dimerization results in phosphorylation of specific tyrosine residues in the activation loop of the kinase domain.
text 2: Dimerization results in inhibition of all tyrosine residues in the activation loop of the kinase domain.

text 1: The target of a neuron is a key source of factors essential for the neuron’s survival.
text 2: The target of a neuron is irrelevant to the neuron’s survival.

text 1: Neurotrophins interact with two major classes of receptors, the Trk receptors and p75.
text 2: Neurotrophins interact exclusively with calcium channels.

text 1: SA1 receptors register the sharpest image of Braille symbols and fall silent when spaces between symbols provide no stimulation.
text 2: SA1 receptors provide a blurred image of Braille symbols and continue firing during spaces between symbols.

text 1: RA2 receptors, or Pacinian corpuscles, are exquisitely sensitive to high-frequency vibratory stimuli ranging from 30–500 Hz.
text 2: RA2 receptors, or Pacinian corpuscles, are sensitive primarily to low-frequency vibratory stimuli under 30 Hz.

text 1: Vibratory stimuli of higher amplitude excite SA1 and RA1 fibers, albeit weaker than RA2 fibers.
text 2: Vibratory stimuli of higher amplitude exclusively excite RA2 fibers while SA1 and RA1 fibers remain unresponsive.

text 1: Proprioceptive information from SA2 fibers is primarily used for detecting skin temperature changes.
text 2: Proprioceptive information from SA2 fibers helps humans preshape their hands to efficiently grasp objects.

text 1: RA1 fibers sense how quickly a grasp is applied when an object is held between the thumb and index finger.
text 2: RA1 fibers detect skin stretch when fingers are fully extended and abducted.

text 1: SA1 fibers signal the amount of grip force applied by each finger during object manipulation.
text 2: SA1 fibers signal vibrations transmitted through the object when lifted off the surface.

text 1: When stimulated at 20 Hz, tactile afferent fibers fire spike bursts at intervals of approximately 10 ms.
text 2: When stimulated at 20 Hz, tactile afferent fibers fire spike bursts at intervals of approximately 50 ms.

text 1: RA2 fibers enable us to feel conditions at the tool’s working surface as if our fingers were touching the object directly.
text 2: RA2 fibers only detect steady pressure applied to the hands, not working surface conditions of tools.

text 1: Pacinian corpuscles consist of concentric, fluid-filled lamellae of connective tissue surrounding the terminal of RA2 fibers.
text 2: Pacinian corpuscles consist exclusively of compact solid structures, lacking fluid-filled lamellae or connective tissues.

text 1: Humans detect smallest vibrations at 200 Hz when grasping a large object.
text 2: Humans detect smallest vibrations at 200 Hz when using a tuning fork.

text 1: The temporal pattern of spike trains conveys vibratory frequency, while amplitude is encoded by total spikes fired per second.
text 2: The vibratory frequency is conveyed by total spikes fired per second, while amplitude is encoded by the temporal spike pattern.

text 1: RA1, RA2, and SA1 fibers continuously fire action potentials even in the absence of tactile stimuli.
text 2: RA1, RA2, and SA1 fibers are normally silent in the absence of tactile stimuli.

text 1: All four classes of touch fibers respond to object grasp and monitor particular functions during skilled movements.
text 2: Only RA2 fibers respond to object grasp, while SA1, RA1, and SA2 do not participate in monitoring such movements.

text 1: Tests of vibration sense are primarily used for assessing muscle strength rather than sensitivity to touch.
text 2: Tests of vibration sense are useful measures of dynamic sensitivity to touch, especially in cases of nerve damage.

text 1: The SA2 fibers provide exteroceptive information used exclusively for detecting tactile properties of objects in hand.
text 2: The SA2 fibers provide proprioceptive information about hand shape and finger movements when the hand is empty.

text 1: The growth cone advances under the control of cellular motors.
text 2: The growth cone stagnates due to the inactivity of cellular motors.

text 1: When PKA activity is high, the resulting elevation in intracellular cAMP causes the growth cone to be attracted to a local source of netrin.
text 2: When PKA activity is high, the resulting elevation in intracellular cAMP causes the growth cone to be repelled from a local source of netrin.

text 1: Sperry’s key experiment was to sever the optic nerve in a frog and then rotate the eye in its socket by 180° before regeneration of the nerve.
text 2: Sperry’s key experiment was to sever the optic nerve in a frog and then rotate the eye in its socket by 90° before regeneration of the nerve.

text 1: Recognition between axons and their targets relied on functional validation and refinement of random connections rather than molecular matching.
text 2: Recognition between axons and their targets relied on molecular matching rather than functional validation and refinement of random connections.

text 1: We now recognize that the activity of neural circuits has no role in shaping connectivity.
text 2: We now recognize that the activity of neural circuits can play a crucial role in shaping connectivity.

text 1: Most receptors have an extracellular domain that selectively binds the cognate ligand and an intracellular domain that couples to the cytoskeleton.
text 2: Most receptors lack an extracellular domain for binding ligands and an intracellular domain for coupling to the cytoskeleton.

text 1: Advances in biochemical and molecular-biological methods made the task of isolating recognition molecules less feasible.
text 2: Advances in biochemical and molecular-biological methods made the task of isolating recognition molecules more feasible.

text 1: Axon guidance remains a mystery and cannot be explained by ligand presentation and growth cone information integration.
text 2: Axon guidance can be explained by describing how and where ligands are presented and how the growth cone integrates this information.

text 1: Ligands presented to one side of the growth cone have no effect on local activation or inhibition, and do not lead to turning.
text 2: Ligands presented to one side of the growth cone can result in local activation or inhibition, leading to turning.

text 1: Stereotaxis or resonance is not considered a crucial force in initial patterning of neuronal circuits today.
text 2: Stereotaxis or resonance is considered a crucial force in initial patterning of neuronal circuits today.

text 1: Retinal axons terminate in their target areas creating an orderly retinotopic map of the visual field.
text 2: Retinal axons terminate in random areas without creating an orderly retinotopic map of the visual field.

text 1: Frogs can reestablish projections to the tectum after the optic nerve is cut, restoring vision.
text 2: Frogs cannot reestablish projections to the tectum after the optic nerve is cut, preventing vision restoration.

text 1: Protein ligands are presented by cells along the pathway an axon follows and the receptors by the growth cone itself.
text 2: Protein ligands are presented by the axon itself and the receptors are located along the pathway.

text 1: Axonal guidance is viewed as an orderly consequence of protein–protein interactions.
text 2: Axonal guidance is viewed as a random process without clear consequences from protein–protein interactions.

text 1: The chemospecificity hypothesis prompted the search for axonal and synaptic recognition molecules.
text 2: The chemospecificity hypothesis discouraged the search for axonal and synaptic recognition molecules.

text 1: In brain imaging studies, addictions to both drugs and behavioral rewards are associated with similar dysregulation of the brain’s reward circuitry.
text 2: In brain imaging studies, addictions to both drugs and behavioral rewards have no association with dysregulation of the brain’s reward circuitry.

text 1: Motivational states drive behaviors that only seek rewards and never avoid aversive stimuli.
text 2: Motivational states drive behaviors that either seek rewards or defend against or avoid aversive stimuli.

text 1: Rewards tend to elicit motivational states that drive approach behaviors.
text 2: Rewards tend to elicit motivational states that drive avoidance behaviors.

text 1: Dopamine itself fully accounts for hedonic experiences.
text 2: Dopamine itself does not account for hedonic experiences.

text 1: Drug addiction can be defined as the occasional seeking of a drug without any negative consequences.
text 2: Drug addiction can be defined as the compulsive seeking and taking of a drug despite negative consequences to one’s physical health or occupational and social functioning.

text 1: Drugs of abuse compose only a very small fraction of known chemical compounds.
text 2: Drugs of abuse compose a majority of known chemical compounds.

text 1: Addiction requires only a single exposure to a drug of abuse.
text 2: Addiction requires repeated exposure to a drug of abuse.

text 1: An important goal of current research is to understand how molecular changes underlie changes in neural and synaptic function.
text 2: An important goal of current research is to disregard molecular changes in the study of addiction.

text 1: All individuals show addiction-like behavioral abnormalities to nondrug rewards such as food, gambling, and sex.
text 2: A subset of individuals show addiction-like behavioral abnormalities to nondrug rewards such as food, gambling, and sex.

text 1: Sleep consumes only a tenth of our lives—approximately 10 years in the average lifetime.
text 2: Sleep consumes fully a third of our lives—approximately 25 years in the average lifetime.

text 1: Sleep function certainly involves no synaptic remodeling and consolidation of memory traces.
text 2: Sleep function may involve synaptic remodeling and consolidation of memory traces.

text 1: Researchers typically use a polysomnogram for studying sleep, which includes EEG, EOG, and EMG.
text 2: Researchers use only EEG when studying sleep, excluding EOG and EMG.

text 1: Sleep consists only of REM sleep without Non-REM sleep.
text 2: Sleep consists of alternating periods of REM and Non-REM sleep.

text 1: Narcolepsy is unaffected by a loss of orexinergic neurons.
text 2: Narcolepsy is caused by a loss of orexinergic neurons.

text 1: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder is caused by excess activity in REM Sleep Paralysis Circuits.
text 2: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder is caused by failure of REM Sleep Paralysis Circuits.

text 1: The distal and proximal stumps are both preserved after axotomy due to nutrient supply from the cell body.
text 2: The distal stump degenerates while the proximal stump is preserved after axotomy because of a signaling pathway in the axon.

text 1: NMNAT2's breakdown following axotomy activates SARM1, leading to the preservation of NAD.
text 2: NMNAT2's breakdown following axotomy disinhibits SARM1, leading to the loss of NAD.

text 1: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a fatal disease of motor neurons with prominent axonal degeneration.
text 2: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a benign disease of motor neurons with no axonal degeneration.

text 1: Central axons regenerate efficiently because the environment promotes axonal growth.
text 2: Central axons regenerate poorly because the environment inhibits axonal growth.

text 1: Oligodendrocytes efficiently dispose of myelin in the central nervous system.
text 2: Oligodendrocytes have little ability to dispose of myelin in the central nervous system.

text 1: Schwann cells prevent macrophages from reaching the lesion site in the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Schwann cells secrete factors that recruit macrophages to the lesion site in the peripheral nervous system.

text 1: The chromatolytic reaction involves the cell body shrinking and the nucleus becoming centrally located.
text 2: The chromatolytic reaction involves the cell body swelling and the nucleus moving to an eccentric position.

text 1: Peripheral nerves can often be repaired following injury due to the survival of connective tissue elements.
text 2: Peripheral nerves cannot be repaired following injury due to the destruction of connective tissue elements.

text 1: Reactive astrocytes contribute to the formation of a glial scar near injury sites in the central nervous system.
text 2: Reactive astrocytes prevent the formation of a glial scar near injury sites in the central nervous system.

text 1: Central axons do not grow well during development and cannot regenerate in immature mammals.
text 2: Central axons grow well during development and can regenerate in immature mammals.

text 1: Schwann cells produce growth factors that promote axon regeneration in the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Schwann cells inhibit axon regeneration in the peripheral nervous system by preventing growth factor secretion.

text 1: After axotomy, synaptic terminals may withdraw and be replaced by glial cells, leading to synaptic stripping.
text 2: After axotomy, synaptic terminals expand and are never replaced by glial cells, preventing synaptic stripping.

text 1: A peripheral nerve graft prevents regeneration of central axons across a lesion site.
text 2: A peripheral nerve graft can promote regeneration of central axons across a lesion site.

text 1: Central axons in adults have poor regeneration capability compared to those in lower vertebrates like fish and frogs.
text 2: Central axons in adults regenerate as well as those in lower vertebrates like fish and frogs.

text 1: Chemotropic factors secreted by Schwann cells attract axons to the distal stump in the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Chemotropic factors secreted by Schwann cells repel axons from the distal stump in the peripheral nervous system.

text 1: Ephrin-A concentrations run from posterior-high to anterior-low in tectum, while EphA concentrations run from posterior-high to anterior-low in retina.
text 2: Ephrin-A concentrations run from anterior-low to posterior-high in tectum, while EphA concentrations run from anterior-low to posterior-high in retina.

text 1: EphB signaling directs the projection of dorsal retinal axons to the ventral tectum.
text 2: EphB signaling directs the projection of ventral retinal axons to the dorsal tectum.

text 1: Netrin-1 is expressed by cells of the floor plate as well as by progenitors along the ventral midline.
text 2: Netrin-1 is expressed by cells of the roof plate as well as by progenitors along the dorsal midline.

text 1: Bone morphogenetic proteins act as attractants, directing commissural axons dorsally as they begin their journey.
text 2: Bone morphogenetic proteins act as repellents, directing commissural axons ventrally as they begin their journey.

text 1: Ephrin/EphB pairs are involved in establishing order along the anteroposterior axis of the retinal map.
text 2: Ephrin/EphB pairs are involved in establishing order along the dorsoventral axis of the retinal map.

text 1: Overexpression of ephrin-A2 in the developing optic tectum generates small patches that are abnormally rich in ephrin-A2.
text 2: Overexpression of ephrin-A2 in the developing optic tectum generates large patches that are abnormally rich in ephrin-A2.

text 1: In mice lacking both ephrin-A proteins, deficits in retinal axon termination are less severe than with either single mutant.
text 2: In mice lacking both ephrin-A proteins, deficits in retinal axon termination are more severe than with either single mutant.

text 1: Temporal retinal axons normally grow towards the ephrin-rich caudal tectum.
text 2: Temporal retinal axons normally avoid the ephrin-rich caudal tectum.

text 1: Nasal retinal axons normally avoid the caudal tectum and are perturbed by excess ephrin-A.
text 2: Nasal retinal axons normally grow toward the caudal tectum and are not perturbed by excess ephrin-A.

text 1: Axons from posterior retinal ganglion cells are repelled most strongly by the high level of ephrin-A in the posterior tectum.
text 2: Axons from posterior retinal ganglion cells are attracted most strongly by the high level of ephrin-A in the posterior tectum.

text 1: EphA receptors in the retina are expressed in an anteroposterior gradient.
text 2: EphA receptors in the retina are expressed in a dorsoventral gradient.

text 1: Chemotactic factors were considered by Ramón y Cajal as potential repellents for axons nearly a century ago.
text 2: Chemotactic factors were considered by Ramón y Cajal as potential attractants for axons nearly a century ago.

text 1: In EphA mutant mice, posterior retinal axons are able to project to a more posterior domain within the tectum.
text 2: In EphA mutant mice, posterior retinal axons are unable to project to a more posterior domain within the tectum.

text 1: In developing visual circuits, more precise spatial mapping of retinal inputs is regulated by patterns of neural activity.
text 2: In developing visual circuits, more precise spatial mapping of retinal inputs is regulated solely by molecular cues.

text 1: Netrin protein is structurally unrelated to the protein product of unc-6, a gene shown to regulate axon guidance in C. elegans.
text 2: Netrin protein is structurally related to the protein product of unc-6, a gene shown to regulate axon guidance in C. elegans.

text 1: The brain stem is the caudal continuation of the spinal cord, and its motor and sensory components are different in structure to those of the spinal cord.
text 2: The brain stem is the rostral continuation of the spinal cord, and its motor and sensory components are similar in structure to those of the spinal cord.

text 1: Cranial nerves I and II enter at the base of the forebrain.
text 2: Cranial nerves I and II enter at the base of the midbrain.

text 1: The trochlear (IV) nerve leaves the midbrain from its ventral surface just behind the inferior colliculus.
text 2: The trochlear (IV) nerve leaves the midbrain from its dorsal surface just behind the inferior colliculus.

text 1: The olfactory (I) nerve is associated with the brain stem.

text 1: The trigeminal (V) nerve is purely a sensory nerve with no motor axons.
text 2: The trigeminal (V) nerve is a mixed nerve containing both sensory and motor axons.

text 1: The facial (VII) nerve innervates the muscles of mastication.
text 2: The facial (VII) nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression.

text 1: The abducens (VI) nerve contracts the medial rectus muscle to move the globe laterally.
text 2: The abducens (VI) nerve contracts the lateral rectus muscle to move the globe laterally.

text 1: The olfactory (I) nerve is described in detail in Chapter 21.
text 2: The olfactory (I) nerve is described in detail in Chapter 29.

text 1: Cranial nerves with sensory functions do not have associated sensory ganglia.
text 2: Cranial nerves with sensory functions have associated sensory ganglia that operate much as dorsal root ganglia do for spinal nerves.

text 1: Early on, Bell's palsy may cause the face to pull toward the affected side.
text 2: Early on, Bell's palsy may cause the face to pull toward the unaffected side.

text 1: The oculomotor (III) nerve provides sympathetic innervation responsible for pupillary dilation.
text 2: The oculomotor (III) nerve provides parasympathetic innervation responsible for pupillary constriction.

text 1: The vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve contains two main bundles of sensory axons from two ganglia.

text 1: The trigeminal (V) nerve's motor root innervates the muscles of facial expression.

text 1: The spinal accessory (XI) nerve can be considered a cranial nerve anatomically but actually is a spinal nerve.

text 1: The glossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus (X) nerves supply only facial innervation.
text 2: The glossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus (X) nerves also supply visceral sensory and motor innervation of the neck.

text 1: Potassium channels have a narrow pore that excludes Na+.
text 2: Potassium channels have a wide pore that accommodates Na+.

text 1: The effective diameter of Na+ is larger than K+ in solution.
text 2: The effective diameter of K+ is larger than Na+ in solution.

text 1: K+ can approach a binding site with high negative field strength more closely than Na+ can.
text 2: Na+ can approach a binding site with high negative field strength more closely than K+ can.

text 1: Sodium channels have a selectivity filter that binds Na+ ions very strongly.
text 2: Sodium channels have a selectivity filter that weakly binds Na+ ions.

text 1: Applying pressure to the patch pipette greatly increased the tightness of the seal.
text 2: Applying a small amount of suction to the patch pipette greatly increased the tightness of the seal.

text 1: Neher and Sakmann developed the patch-clamp technique in 1976.
text 2: Neher and Sakmann developed the patch-clamp technique in 1986.

text 1: A micropipette containing KCl was pressed tightly against a muscle membrane to record current.
text 2: A micropipette containing ACh was pressed tightly against a muscle membrane to record current.

text 1: The conductance of the ACh receptor channel is approximately 25 picosiemens (pS).
text 2: The conductance of the ACh receptor channel is approximately 250 picosiemens (pS).

text 1: In channels with small pore diameter, an ion does not need to be stripped completely of its water shell.
text 2: In channels with large pore diameter, an ion does not need to be stripped completely of its water shell.

text 1: A Na+ ion's stronger interaction with water means it interacts more weakly with some binding sites compared to K+.
text 2: A Na+ ion's weaker interaction with water means it interacts more strongly with some binding sites compared to K+.

text 1: The effective size of an ion increases as it diffuses through solution carrying its cloud of water molecules.
text 2: The effective size of an ion decreases as it diffuses through solution carrying its cloud of water molecules.

text 1: The patch-clamp technique is a refinement of the original voltage clamp technique.
text 2: The patch-clamp technique is a development from the magnetic resonance imaging technique.

text 1: According to Coulomb's law, the electrostatic interaction depends directly on the distance between two charges.
text 2: According to Coulomb's law, the electrostatic interaction depends inversely on the distance between two charges.

text 1: Many ion channels show linear relation between current and membrane voltage, behaving as simple resistors.
text 2: Many ion channels show nonlinear relation between current and membrane voltage, behaving as simple resistors.

text 1: The dissociation constant in typical enzyme interactions is above 1 mM.
text 2: The dissociation constant in typical enzyme interactions is below 1 μM.

text 1: An axon can convey electrical signals over distances ranging from 0.1 mm to 1 m.
text 2: An axon can convey electrical signals over distances ranging from 1 mm to 1 cm.

text 1: The amplitude of an action potential traveling down the axon remains constant at 10 mV.
text 2: The amplitude of an action potential traveling down the axon remains constant at 100 mV.

text 1: The myelin sheath is interrupted at regular intervals by the nodes of Ranvier.
text 2: The myelin sheath is continuous without any interruptions along the axon.

text 1: Most presynaptic terminals end on the postsynaptic neuron's dendrites.
text 2: Most presynaptic terminals end on the postsynaptic neuron's axons.

text 1: Ramón y Cajal developed the silver-staining method himself to study neurons.
text 2: Ramón y Cajal used the silver-staining method introduced by Golgi to study neurons.

text 1: Unipolar neurons are characteristic of the invertebrate nervous system.
text 2: Unipolar neurons are characteristic of the vertebrate nervous system.

text 1: Bipolar cells have a dendrite that receives signals and an axon that transmits signals.
text 2: Bipolar cells have an axon that receives signals and a dendrite that transmits signals.

text 1: Multipolar neurons typically have a single axon and many dendrites.
text 2: Multipolar neurons typically have several axons and a single dendrite.

text 1: The term efferent applies to information reaching the central nervous system from the periphery.
text 2: The term afferent applies to information reaching the central nervous system from the periphery.

text 1: Sensory neurons carry information for the purpose of both perception and motor coordination.
text 2: Motor neurons carry information for the purpose of both perception and motor coordination.

text 1: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum receive about a hundred synaptic contacts.
text 2: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum receive as many as a million synaptic contacts.

text 1: Alan Hodgkin and Andrew Huxley first recorded the intracellular action potential in 1949.
text 2: Alan Hodgkin and Andrew Huxley recorded the first published intracellular recording of an action potential in 1939.

text 1: The neuron doctrine holds that each neuron is a discrete cell with distinctive processes arising from its cell body.
text 2: The neuron doctrine holds that neurons are continuous with each other without distinct boundaries.

text 1: Electrical signals within a nerve cell flow in multiple directions according to the principle of dynamic polarization.
text 2: Electrical signals within a nerve cell flow in only one direction according to the principle of dynamic polarization.

text 1: Connectional specificity states that nerve cells make specific connections with certain postsynaptic target cells and not with others.
text 2: Connectional specificity states that nerve cells connect randomly with one another.

text 1: The retina has dozens of types of interneurons, and the spinal cord has more than a hundred types of motor neurons.
text 2: The retina has hundreds of types of interneurons, and the spinal cord has less than a dozen types of motor neurons.

text 1: The mammalian central nervous system likely contains more than a thousand types of neurons.
text 2: The mammalian central nervous system is known to contain fewer than a thousand types of neurons.

text 1: The neural tube arises from the ectoderm during development.
text 2: The neural tube arises from the mesoderm during development.

text 1: Signals from the mesoderm and endoderm define the rostrocaudal pattern of the neural plate.
text 2: Signals from the ectoderm and endoderm define the rostrocaudal pattern of the neural plate.

text 1: Sonic Hedgehog protein secreted from the notochord and floor plate patterns the ventral neural tube.
text 2: Bone Morphogenetic Proteins secreted from the notochord and floor plate pattern the ventral neural tube.

text 1: Bone Morphogenetic Proteins pattern the dorsal neural tube during development.
text 2: Sonic Hedgehog protein patterns the dorsal neural tube during development.

text 1: Dorsoventral patterning mechanisms are conserved along the rostrocaudal extent of the neural tube.
text 2: Dorsoventral patterning mechanisms vary significantly along the rostrocaudal extent of the neural tube.

text 1: Local signals do not influence functional subclasses of neurons during development.
text 2: Local signals determine functional subclasses of neurons during development.

text 1: Dorsoventral position is the sole determinant of motor neuron subtype.
text 2: Rostrocaudal position is a major determinant of motor neuron subtype.

text 1: The homogeneity of neuronal types limits the computational properties of the mammalian nervous system.
text 2: The diversity of neuronal types contributes to the computational properties of the mammalian nervous system.

text 1: Peptide growth factors and their inhibitors mediate neural induction.
text 2: Peptide growth factors and their inhibitors are unrelated to the process of neural induction.

text 1: Interactions with the environment modify or consolidate neural connections during early development.
text 2: Neural connections formed during early development are entirely independent of environmental interactions.
