text 1: Signals from organizing centers within the neural tube pattern the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain.
text 2: Signals from organizing centers within the neural tube pattern only the hindbrain.

text 1: The developmental principles that direct nervous system differentiation are adapted from principles used in other tissues.
text 2: The developmental principles that direct nervous system differentiation are entirely unique to the nervous system.

text 1: Unexpected heterogeneity is being discovered in what were previously thought to be homogeneous classes of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes.
text 2: The classes of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes are confirmed to be homogeneous without any evidence of heterogeneity.

text 1: The highly polygenic risk architecture of mood and anxiety disorders means that testing for one or a few risk gene variants provides clear diagnostic value for these disorders.
text 2: The highly polygenic risk architecture of mood and anxiety disorders means that there is no diagnostic value in testing for one or a few risk gene variants that might be associated with these disorders.

text 1: Polygenic risk scores (PRS) provide only a probability and cannot offer a definitive diagnosis for mood and anxiety disorders due to the significant contribution of environmental risk factors.
text 2: Polygenic risk scores (PRS) offer definitive diagnostic value for mood and anxiety disorders, removing the influence of environmental risk factors.

text 1: Serious illness, whether acute or chronic, is associated with the onset of major depression and anxiety.
text 2: Serious illness, whether acute or chronic, is unlikely to impact the onset of major depression and anxiety.

text 1: Cortisol and synthetic glucocorticoids like dexamethasone inhibit further release of ACTH and CRH in a healthy feedback mechanism.
text 2: Cortisol and synthetic glucocorticoids like dexamethasone promote further release of ACTH and CRH in a healthy feedback mechanism.

text 1: In approximately half of people with major depression, the HPA axis becomes resistant to suppression by potent synthetic glucocorticoids like dexamethasone.
text 2: In approximately half of people with major depression, the HPA axis remains highly responsive to suppression by potent synthetic glucocorticoids like dexamethasone.

text 1: Resting-state fMRI studies have found no significant differences in intrinsic connectivity within neural circuits that regulate cognition and emotion between subjects with major depression and healthy controls.
text 2: Resting-state fMRI studies suggest differences in intrinsic connectivity within neural circuits that regulate cognition and emotion in subjects with major depression compared to healthy controls.

text 1: Early childhood adversity, such as physical or sexual abuse, is a documented developmental risk factor for depression.
text 2: Early childhood adversity, such as physical or sexual abuse, has not been linked to depression as a developmental risk factor.

text 1: Pattern identification through resting-state fMRI shows early promise in distinguishing among different forms of mood and anxiety disorders.
text 2: Resting-state fMRI has failed to show promise in identifying patterns useful for distinguishing among forms of mood and anxiety disorders.

text 1: Major depression accompanying a chronic illness such as type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease has no impact on overall medical outcomes.
text 2: Major depression accompanying a chronic illness such as type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease leads to worse overall medical outcomes.

text 1: Excess cortisol production due to Cushing disease has no link to depression-like symptoms.
text 2: Excess cortisol production due to Cushing disease may contribute to depression-like symptoms.

text 1: Functional neuroimaging studies have found decreased amygdala activity in response to innocuous stimuli in individuals suffering from PTSD, other anxiety disorders, and major depression.
text 2: Functional neuroimaging studies have found heightened amygdala activity in response to innocuous stimuli in individuals suffering from PTSD, other anxiety disorders, and major depression.

text 1: Prefrontal cortical regions interconnected with the basal amygdala exhibit decreased activity in anxiety disorders and major depression.
text 2: Prefrontal cortical regions interconnected with the basal amygdala exhibit heightened activity in anxiety disorders and major depression.

text 1: Studies of subjects exposed to fearful faces suggest altered autonomic and brain responses among individuals with anxiety disorders and major depression.
text 2: Studies of subjects exposed to fearful faces suggest normal autonomic and brain responses among individuals with anxiety disorders and major depression.

text 1: Mood and anxiety disorders are universally associated with identical presentations of depressive and anxiety symptoms across populations.
text 2: Mood and anxiety disorders are associated with diverse combinations of depressive and anxiety symptoms across populations due to polygenic and environmental risk factors.

text 1: Altered patterns of neural connectivity derived from resting-state fMRI do not contribute to refining predictive models for mood and anxiety disorders.
text 2: Altered patterns of neural connectivity derived from resting-state fMRI show the potential to refine predictive models for mood and anxiety disorders when combined with polygenic risk scores and additional measures.

text 1: Two forms of muscular dystrophy are caused by deletion mutations in the dystrophin gene.
text 2: Two forms of muscular dystrophy are caused by insertion mutations in the dystrophin gene.

text 1: The DMD gene has 50 exons and approximately 2.0 × 106 base pairs.
text 2: The DMD gene has 79 exons and approximately 2.0 × 106 base pairs.

text 1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy results from a deletion that disrupts the reading frame.
text 2: Duchenne muscular dystrophy results from a deletion that preserves the reading frame.

text 1: Becker muscular dystrophy usually results from a deletion that disrupts the reading frame.
text 2: Becker muscular dystrophy usually results from a deletion that preserves the reading frame.

text 1: Dystrophin molecule production with an internal deletion and disrupted ends can preserve some muscle function.
text 2: Dystrophin molecule production with an internal deletion but intact ends can preserve some muscle function.

text 1: A short form of the dystrophin gene, mini-dystrophin, is about 70% of the full-length protein.
text 2: A short form of the dystrophin gene, mini-dystrophin, is about 30% of the full-length protein.

text 1: During an attack of periodic paralysis, muscles of respiration and swallowing are affected.
text 2: During an attack of periodic paralysis, muscles of respiration and swallowing are spared.

text 1: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis is caused by missense mutations in a gene encoding a Na+ channel.
text 2: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis is caused by missense mutations in a gene encoding a K+ channel.

text 1: Periodic paralysis is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
text 2: Periodic paralysis is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.

text 1: Functional dystrophin is almost totally absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
text 2: Functional dystrophin is abundant in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

text 1: Inherited muscle diseases can lead to periodic paralysis or myotonia.
text 2: Inherited muscle diseases can lead to continuous paralysis or myotonia.

text 1: Mutations in ClC-1 Cl– channels contribute to muscle disease.
text 2: Mutations in Na+/K+ pumps contribute to muscle disease.

text 1: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis attacks occur during periods of high venous K+.
text 2: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis attacks occur during periods of low venous K+.

text 1: Muscle function is generally normal between episodes of periodic paralysis.
text 2: Muscle function is generally impaired between episodes of periodic paralysis.

text 1: The end-plate potential triggers an action potential in muscle fibers.
text 2: The end-plate potential directly triggers muscle contraction without action potentials.

text 1: Sleep apnea is one of the most common sleep disorders, affecting about 5% of adults and children.
text 2: Sleep apnea is one of the least common sleep disorders, affecting less than 1% of adults and children.

text 1: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea have repeated episodes of airway obstruction that force the individual to briefly awaken from sleep to resume breathing.
text 2: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea experience continuous breathing and do not wake during the night.

text 1: Narcolepsy typically begins in the teen years as moderate to severe sleepiness every day, even with ample amounts of sleep at night.
text 2: Narcolepsy typically begins in adulthood and does not involve daily sleepiness despite lack of sleep at night.

text 1: Elements of REM sleep often occur during wakefulness in people with narcolepsy, such as sleep paralysis or vivid dream-like hallucinations.
text 2: Elements of REM sleep never occur during wakefulness in people with narcolepsy.

text 1: Narcolepsy is associated with a loss of hypothalamic neurons that produce the orexin neuropeptides.
text 2: Narcolepsy is associated with a loss of hypothalamic neurons that produce dopamine neurotransmitters.

text 1: Orexinergic neurons suppress wakefulness and promote REM sleep.
text 2: Orexinergic neurons promote wakefulness and suppress REM sleep.

text 1: The dysregulation of REM sleep in narcolepsy is not detectable, and patients never experience REM sleep during daytime naps.
text 2: The dysregulation of REM sleep in narcolepsy is apparent on the Multiple Sleep Latency Test, where patients often experience REM sleep during daytime naps.

text 1: Sodium oxybate taken during the night suppresses deep sleep and increases cataplexy during the day.
text 2: Sodium oxybate taken during the night enhances deep sleep and helps reduce cataplexy during the day.

text 1: Restless legs syndrome commonly occurs in about 10% of the population and involves an irresistible urge to move the legs.
text 2: Restless legs syndrome occurs rarely in less than 0.1% of the population and does not involve leg movement urges.

text 1: Periodic limb movement disorder features stereotyped leg movements every 20 to 40 seconds during non-REM sleep.
text 2: Periodic limb movement disorder features random leg movements only during REM sleep.

text 1: Patients with non-REM parasomnias such as sleepwalking often experience sudden arousal from stage N3 sleep.
text 2: Patients with non-REM parasomnias such as sleepwalking are typically awake and conscious during these episodes.

text 1: REM sleep behavior disorder involves the loss of paralysis during REM sleep, allowing patients to act out their dreams.
text 2: REM sleep behavior disorder involves full paralysis during REM sleep and prevents any physical movement.

text 1: Narcolepsy symptoms such as cataplexy are likely triggered by an autoimmune attack on orexin neurons.
text 2: Narcolepsy symptoms such as cataplexy are triggered by iron deficiency in the brainstem neurons.

text 1: Cataplexy is a strengthening of muscles triggered by emotional responses.
text 2: Cataplexy is emotionally triggered muscle weakness similar to REM sleep paralysis.

text 1: Iron deficiency is a common cause of restless legs syndrome, and treatment with iron is often helpful.
text 2: Iron deficiency has no relation to restless legs syndrome, and iron treatment is ineffective.

text 1: The resting membrane potential is typically in the range of -10 mV to -20 mV.
text 2: The resting membrane potential is typically in the range of -60 mV to -70 mV.

text 1: Voltage-gated channels open in response to membrane depolarization.
text 2: Voltage-gated channels open in response to membrane hyperpolarization.

text 1: At rest, the extracellular surface of the membrane has an excess of positive charge.
text 2: At rest, the extracellular surface of the membrane has an excess of negative charge.

text 1: Resting channels are important in maintaining the resting membrane potential.
text 2: Resting channels are important in generating action potentials.

text 1: Action potentials are graded responses triggered by hyperpolarization.
text 2: Action potentials are all-or-none responses triggered by depolarization.

text 1: The resting membrane potential results from the uniform distribution of charge across the cell membrane.
text 2: The resting membrane potential results from the separation of charge across the cell membrane.

text 1: Open channels in glial cells are permeable to sodium only.
text 2: Open channels in glial cells are permeable to potassium only.

text 1: Membrane capacitance slows the time course of electrical signals.
text 2: Membrane capacitance speeds up the time course of electrical signals.

text 1: Small axons are more easily excited than large axons.
text 2: Large axons are more easily excited than small axons.

text 1: Passive electrical properties of neurons contribute to the integration of synaptic potentials.
text 2: Passive electrical properties of neurons inhibit the integration of synaptic potentials.

text 1: Hyperpolarization is a decrease in charge separation, leading to a less negative membrane potential.
text 2: Hyperpolarization is an increase in charge separation, leading to a more negative membrane potential.

text 1: Depolarization increases the separation of charge across the membrane.
text 2: Depolarization decreases the separation of charge across the membrane.

text 1: The separation of charge is maintained because the lipid bilayer is a barrier to ion diffusion.
text 2: The separation of charge is maintained because the lipid bilayer allows free ion diffusion.

text 1: The Hodgkin-Huxley equation quantifies the contributions of different ions to the resting membrane potential.
text 2: The Goldman Equation quantifies the contributions of different ions to the resting membrane potential.

text 1: Active transport of ions gives rise to the resting potential.
text 2: The passive flux of ions gives rise to the resting potential.

text 1: There is a consistent link between schizophrenia and the basal ganglia insofar as a major class of antipsychotic drugs acts to suppress serotonergic neurotransmission.
text 2: There is a consistent link between schizophrenia and the basal ganglia insofar as a major class of antipsychotic drugs acts to suppress dopaminergic neurotransmission.

text 1: Dopaminergic transmission within the basal ganglia is likely to be influenced most profoundly by dopamine-related pharmacological therapies.
text 2: Dopaminergic transmission within the basal ganglia is likely to be influenced most profoundly by serotonin-related pharmacological therapies.

text 1: ADHD, like schizophrenia, could in part be the result of a failure in the mechanism responsible for suppressing nonselected sensory options, thereby making it difficult to maintain a focus of attention.
text 2: ADHD, like schizophrenia, could in part be the result of a failure in the mechanism responsible for enhancing selected sensory options, thereby making it difficult to maintain a focus of attention.

text 1: The spatial topography is disrupted throughout the intrinsic basal ganglia connections, as well as in projections back to the cortex, limbic system, and brain stem structures.
text 2: The spatial topography is maintained throughout the intrinsic basal ganglia connections, as well as in projections back to the cortex, limbic system, and brain stem structures.

text 1: Basal ganglia architecture appeared recently in vertebrate evolution and has not been highly conserved.
text 2: Basal ganglia architecture appeared at the outset of vertebrate evolution and has been highly conserved throughout.

text 1: Recent optogenetic investigations have denied that phasic dopamine signaling can act as a training signal for reinforcement learning.
text 2: Recent optogenetic investigations have confirmed that phasic dopamine signaling can act as a training signal for reinforcement learning.

text 1: In Tourette syndrome, the involuntary behavioral intrusions are associated with aberrant activity in the cortical–basal ganglia–thalamic loops.
text 2: In Tourette syndrome, the involuntary behavioral intrusions are associated with typical activity in the cortical–basal ganglia–thalamic loops.

text 1: Phasic excitatory input to the basal ganglia is mediated by the neurotransmitter serotonin.
text 2: Phasic excitatory input to the basal ganglia is mediated by the neurotransmitter glutamate.

text 1: Tonic inhibitory output from the basal ganglia is mediated by the neurotransmitter GABA.
text 2: Tonic inhibitory output from the basal ganglia is mediated by the neurotransmitter glutamate.

text 1: Obsessive-compulsive disorder symptoms are expected when the input salience of relevant functional channels is abnormally recessive.
text 2: Obsessive-compulsive disorder symptoms are expected when the input salience of relevant functional channels is abnormally dominant.

text 1: The basal ganglia operate as a generic selection module.
text 2: The basal ganglia operate as a specific selection module only for cognitive territories.

text 1: Reinforcement learning cannot bias selections on the basis of outcome value or by an acquired automatic stimulus–response association.
text 2: Reinforcement learning can bias selections on the basis of outcome value or by an acquired automatic stimulus–response association.

text 1: The multidimensional aspects of action can be independently modified by reinforcement learning.
text 2: The multidimensional aspects of action cannot be independently modified by reinforcement learning.

text 1: The basal ganglia are an essential substrate for reinforcement learning where selections are biased by the valence/value of past outcomes.
text 2: The basal ganglia are not involved in reinforcement learning where selections are biased by the valence/value of past outcomes.

text 1: Addiction-related stimuli have no effect on the ability of these stimuli to capture behavior.
text 2: Addiction-related stimuli lead to observed increases in the ability of these stimuli to capture behavior.

text 1: BMP inhibitors secreted from the organizer region bind to BMPs and promote the ability of ectodermal cells to acquire an epidermal fate, thus suppressing neural character.
text 2: BMP inhibitors secreted from the organizer region bind to BMPs and block the ability of ectodermal cells to acquire an epidermal fate, thus promoting neural character.

text 1: Signals from the organizer region spread through the ectoderm to induce neural tissue in Xenopus frog embryos.
text 2: Signals from the ectoderm spread through the organizer region to induce neural tissue in Xenopus frog embryos.

text 1: The hindbrain vesicle divides to form the metencephalon and myelencephalon, which will give rise to the pons, cerebellum, and medulla.
text 2: The hindbrain vesicle divides to form the telencephalon and diencephalon, which will give rise to the pons, cerebellum, and medulla.

text 1: The forebrain vesicle divides to form the metencephalon and myelencephalon, which will give rise to the cortex, hippocampus, and basal ganglia.
text 2: The forebrain vesicle divides to form the telencephalon and diencephalon, which will give rise to the cortex, hippocampus, and basal ganglia.

text 1: Dopaminergic and serotonergic molecules are important classes of factors that initiate rostrocaudal patterning in the neural plate.
text 2: Retinoic acid and FGFs are important classes of factors that initiate rostrocaudal patterning in the neural plate.

text 1: The isthmic organizer forms at the boundary of the hindbrain and midbrain and patterns these two domains of the neural tube.
text 2: The isthmic organizer forms at the boundary of the forebrain and midbrain and patterns these two domains of the neural tube.

text 1: Wnt proteins are produced by mesodermal cells and contribute to rostrocaudal patterning of the neural plate.
text 2: Wnt proteins are produced by ectodermal cells and contribute to rostrocaudal patterning of the neural plate.

text 1: As the neural tube develops, all three of the primary embryonic vesicles divide further to form five vesicles.
text 2: As the neural tube develops, two of the primary embryonic vesicles divide further to form five vesicles.

text 1: Signals from the mesoderm and endoderm define the rostrocaudal pattern of the neural plate.
text 2: Signals from the ectoderm and mesoderm define the rostrocaudal pattern of the neural plate.

text 1: At early stages of neural tube development, there are two brain vesicles: prosencephalon and mesencephalon.
text 2: At early stages of neural tube development, there are three brain vesicles: prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon.

text 1: The auditory system acquires information about the world through the simple absorption of air.
text 2: The auditory system acquires information about the world through the simple compression and rarefaction of air.

text 1: The peripheral nerve endings of a variety of specialized detector neurons transduce chemical energy into neuronal signals.
text 2: The peripheral nerve endings of a variety of specialized detector neurons transduce mechanical energy into neuronal signals.

text 1: The senses of taste and smell acquire information about the chemical composition of the world.
text 2: The senses of taste and smell acquire information about the mechanical composition of the world.

text 1: There are only a few olfactory receptors with unique patterns of affinity for airborne molecules.
text 2: There are hundreds of olfactory receptors with unique patterns of affinity for airborne molecules.

text 1: Perception reflects the temporary possibilities of sensation.
text 2: Perception reflects the permanent possibilities of sensation.

text 1: Perinatal injections of testosterone or DHT can rescue a significant number of the dying neurons and muscle fibers in the female rat.
text 2: Perinatal injections of testosterone or DHT can rescue a significant number of the dying neurons and muscle fibers in the male rat.

text 1: Conversely, treatment of male pups with an androgen receptor antagonist increases the number of dying neurons and muscle fibers.
text 2: Conversely, treatment of female pups with an androgen receptor antagonist increases the number of dying neurons and muscle fibers.

text 1: The receptor resides on the Y chromosome, so all males that carry a mutant gene on their one and only Y chromosome are feminized and sterile.
text 2: The receptor resides on the X chromosome, so all males that carry a mutant gene on their one and only X chromosome are feminized and sterile.

text 1: If androgen receptors were required in the muscles, one would expect only receptor-expressing SNB motor neurons to survive.
text 2: If androgen receptors were required in the neuron, one would expect only receptor-expressing SNB motor neurons to survive.

text 1: These neurons receive a trophic cue from the androgen-dependent bulbocavernosus and the levator ani muscles.
text 2: These neurons receive a trophic cue from the androgen-independent bulbocavernosus and the levator ani muscles.

text 1: Low levels of androgens during this critical period lead to an irreversible reduction in the number of SNB motor neurons.
text 2: High levels of androgens during this critical period lead to an irreversible reduction in the number of SNB motor neurons.

text 1: The robust nucleus of the archistriatum (RA) in the adult male zebra finch contains five times as many neurons as the same nucleus in females.
text 2: The robust nucleus of the archistriatum (RA) in the adult female zebra finch contains five times as many neurons as the same nucleus in males.

text 1: In females, a large number of RA neurons die and in males the axons of HVC neurons enter the RA nucleus.
text 2: In males, a large number of RA neurons die and in females the axons of HVC neurons enter the RA nucleus.

text 1: The male-specific Y chromosome of fruit flies does not bear a sex-determining locus.
text 2: The male-specific Y chromosome of fruit flies bears a sex-determining locus.

text 1: A ratio of 1 is determinative for female differentiation, whereas a ratio of 0.5 drives male differentiation.
text 2: A ratio of 0.5 is determinative for female differentiation, whereas a ratio of 1 drives male differentiation.

text 1: The dsx gene encodes a transcription factor that is essential for sexual differentiation of the nervous system and the rest of the body.
text 2: The fru gene encodes a transcription factor that is essential for sexual differentiation of the nervous system and the rest of the body.

text 1: Males carrying a genetically modified fru allele that can only be spliced in the female-specific manner have essentially normal, dsx-dependent sexual differentiation.
text 2: Males carrying a genetically modified fru allele that can only be spliced in the male-specific manner have essentially normal, dsx-dependent sexual differentiation.

text 1: FruF is required for male courtship and copulation.
text 2: FruM is required for male courtship and copulation.

text 1: In wild type females without fruM, the neural pathways are wired such that these flies exhibit sexually receptive behaviors toward males.
text 2: In wild type males without fruM, the neural pathways are wired such that these flies exhibit sexually receptive behaviors toward females.

text 1: When synaptic transmission is genetically enhanced in these neurons in adult males, all components of courtship behavior are abolished.
text 2: When synaptic transmission is genetically blocked in these neurons in adult males, all components of courtship behavior are abolished.

text 1: The cerebellum calibrates eye movements based on visual feedback and mediates the learning process that keeps them accurate over time.
text 2: The cerebellum calibrates eye movements based on auditory feedback and mediates the learning process that keeps them accurate over time.

text 1: Vergence is a function of the horizontal rectus muscles only, because the two eyes are horizontally, not vertically, displaced.
text 2: Vergence is a function of the vertical rectus muscles only, because the two eyes are vertically, not horizontally, displaced.

text 1: Six muscles work together to move each eye. These eye muscles are yoked in three pairs.
text 2: Four muscles work together to move each eye. These eye muscles are yoked in two pairs.

text 1: Accommodation is elicited by the blurring of an image, and whenever accommodation occurs, the eyes also converge.
text 2: Accommodation is elicited by the sharpening of an image, and whenever accommodation occurs, the eyes also diverge.

text 1: The firing pattern of eye muscle neurons combines independent signals that code eye position and direction.
text 2: The firing pattern of eye muscle neurons combines independent signals that code eye position and velocity.

text 1: Motor neurons for the extraocular muscles lie in five brainstem nuclei.
text 2: Motor neurons for the extraocular muscles lie in three brainstem nuclei.

text 1: There are six different types of eye movements, with different control systems.
text 2: There are eight different types of eye movements, with different control systems.

text 1: The posterior parietal cortex projects an attentional signal to the superior colliculus that accurately distinguishes between attention and movement.
text 2: The posterior parietal cortex projects an attentional signal to the superior colliculus that does not distinguish between attention and movement.

text 1: Oculomotor deficits may experience alarming symptoms such as double vision.
text 2: Oculomotor deficits may experience calming symptoms such as improved vision.

text 1: Saccades shift the fovea rapidly to a new visual target.
text 2: Saccades keep the fovea stationary on the current visual target.

text 1: The mesencephalic reticular formation provides the position and velocity signals for vertical and torsional eye movements.
text 2: The mesencephalic reticular formation provides the position and velocity signals for only horizontal eye movements.

text 1: Smooth pursuit is driven by a network that includes the flocculus of the cerebellum.
text 2: Smooth pursuit is driven by a network that excludes neuronal structures related to the cerebellum.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex maintains the eye on target by driving the eye with a velocity opposite to that of the head movement.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex maintains the eye on target by driving the eye with a velocity in the same direction as that of the head movement.

text 1: Patients with oculomotor deficits are unlikely to experience symptoms.
text 2: Patients with oculomotor deficits may experience symptoms such as double vision.

text 1: The pursuit area of the frontal eye fields initiates smooth-pursuit movements.
text 2: The pursuit area of the frontal eye fields prevents smooth-pursuit movements.

text 1: The anteroposterior pattern of the neural plate is established by exposure of neural cells to a gradient of Wnt signals.
text 2: The anteroposterior pattern of the neural plate is established by exposure of neural cells to a gradient of Shh signals.

text 1: FGF signals from the isthmic organizer act in concert with Shh signals from the ventral midline to specify the identity and position of dopaminergic and serotonergic neurons.
text 2: FGF signals from the zona limitans intrathalamica act in concert with Shh signals from the dorsal midline to specify the identity and position of dopaminergic and serotonergic neurons.

text 1: Cells in the hindbrain and midbrain domains of the neural plate express Otx2, whereas cells in the forebrain domain express Gbx2.
text 2: Cells in forebrain and midbrain domains of the neural plate express Otx2, whereas cells in the hindbrain domain express Gbx2.

text 1: Wnt1 is involved in the proliferation of cells in the forebrain–spinal cord domain and in the maintenance of Shh expression.
text 2: Wnt1 is involved in the proliferation of cells in the midbrain–hindbrain domain and in the maintenance of FGF8 expression.

text 1: The spread of FGF8 from the isthmic organizer into the hindbrain domain marked by Gbx2 expression triggers the differentiation of serotonergic neurons.
text 2: The spread of FGF8 from the isthmic organizer into the midbrain domain marked by Gbx2 expression triggers the differentiation of serotonergic neurons.

text 1: The isthmic organizer is a source of retinoic acid, and the ZLI and anterior neural ridge are sources of fibroblast growth factor.
text 2: The ZLI is a source of sonic hedgehog, and the isthmic organizer and anterior neural ridge are sources of fibroblast growth factor.

text 1: Hoxb1 expression and Krox20 expression become mutually exclusive, thus endowing each cell with a unique molecular identity.
text 2: Hoxb1 expression and Otx2 expression become mutually exclusive, thus endowing each cell with a unique molecular identity.

text 1: EphA4 and ephrinB3 repel each other, driving migration of isolated cells and sharpening the segment border.
text 2: EphA4 and ephrinB3 attract each other, facilitating the merging of isolated cells and blurring the segment border.

text 1: The dorsal half of the neural tube generates projection neurons and local circuit interneurons that process incoming sensory information.
text 2: The ventral half of the neural tube generates projection neurons and local circuit interneurons that process incoming sensory information.

text 1: Ventral patterning signals are initially provided by the roof plate, a glial cell group.
text 2: Ventral patterning signals are initially provided by the notochord, a mesodermal cell group.

text 1: FGFs, BMPs, cytokines, Wnt proteins, and retinoic acid are used in different regions and at different times to program neuronal cell types.
text 2: FGFs, BMPs, hedgehog proteins, Wnt proteins, and retinoic acid are used in different regions and at different times to program neuronal cell types.

text 1: The neural tube generates distinct progenitor cell types along its anteroposterior axis.
text 2: The neural tube generates distinct progenitor cell types along its dorsoventral axis.

text 1: Inductive and adhesive interactions combine with repressive or inhibitory ones to pattern the nervous system.
text 2: Inductive and adhesive interactions are sufficient on their own to pattern the nervous system.

text 1: Dorsoventral patterning of the neural tube involves mechanisms solely at the midbrain level.
text 2: Dorsoventral patterning of the neural tube involves mechanisms at different rostrocaudal levels.

text 1: FGFs and Shh are described in the context of their prominent role in patterning the cortex and spinal cord.
text 2: FGFs and Shh are described in the context of their prominent role in patterning the brainstem and cerebellum.

text 1: The inferior temporal cortex is essential for recognizing auditory stimuli.
text 2: The inferior temporal cortex is essential for object recognition.

text 1: Visual signals are processed in the lateral geniculate nucleus before reaching the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Visual signals are processed in the lateral geniculate nucleus before reaching the primary visual cortex.

text 1: The ventral stream extends from V1 directly to the prefrontal cortex in macaque monkeys.
text 2: The ventral stream extends from V1 through V2, via V4, into the inferior temporal cortex in macaque monkeys.

text 1: Neuropsychological evidence shows no distinction between the anterior and posterior parts of the inferior temporal cortex.
text 2: Neuropsychological evidence distinguishes between anterior and posterior parts of the inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: Apperceptive agnosia is more common after damage to the posterior inferior temporal cortex.
text 2: Apperceptive agnosia is more common after damage to the anterior inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: Functional evidence indicates there are no subdivisions within the inferior temporal cortex.
text 2: Functional evidence suggests subdivisions within the inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: Object representations are only stored in short-term memory and cannot be recalled.
text 2: Object representations can be stored in working memory and recalled with other memories.

text 1: The ventral stream in visual processing is associated with object recognition.
text 2: The dorsal stream in visual processing is primarily responsible for object recognition.

text 1: Sanger Brown and Edward Albert Schäfer discovered that experimental lesions of the parietal lobe in primates affected object recognition.
text 2: Sanger Brown and Edward Albert Schäfer found experimental lesions of the temporal lobe in primates affected object recognition.

text 1: Visual agnosia results from damage to the superior parietal cortex.
text 2: Visual agnosia can result from damage to the inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: The ventral stream operates independently without input from preceding stages.
text 2: The ventral stream is hierarchically organized and receives input from preceding stages.

text 1: Assocaition of sensory representations with object knowledge is impaired in associative agnosia.
text 2: Apperceptive agnosia involves the loss of sensory associations with object knowledge.

text 1: Inferior temporal neurons integrate a vast region of visual space.
text 2: Inferior temporal neurons have a very limited integration of visual space.

text 1: The term visual agnosia was coined by Sigmund Freud.
text 2: The term visual agnosia was introduced by Carl Jung.

text 1: Neurophysiological studies show inferior temporal neuron activity is unrelated to object representation.
text 2: Neurophysiological studies provide insights into how inferior temporal neuron activity represents objects.

text 1: In the central nervous system, neurons that release glutamate typically act on receptors that produce inhibition.
text 2: In the central nervous system, neurons that release glutamate typically act on receptors that produce excitation.

text 1: Type I synapses typically contact the cell body instead of dendritic projections.
text 2: Type I synapses typically contact specialized dendritic projections called spines.

text 1: A depolarization of 10 mV or more is required to reach the threshold for generating an action potential.
text 2: A depolarization of less than 1 mV is required to reach the threshold for generating an action potential.

text 1: Inhibitory synapses are normally formed only on the specialized dendritic spines.
text 2: Inhibitory synapses are normally formed on dendritic shafts, the cell body, and the axon initial segment.

text 1: John Eccles and his colleagues conducted experiments on synaptic inputs onto spinal motor neurons in the 1970s.
text 2: John Eccles and his colleagues conducted experiments on synaptic inputs onto spinal motor neurons in the 1950s.

text 1: Excitatory postsynaptic potentials are produced in parallel with inhibitory postsynaptic potentials on antagonistic muscles during the stretch reflex.
text 2: Inhibitory postsynaptic potentials are only produced in parallel with excitatory potentials on the same muscle during the stretch reflex.

text 1: In the laboratory, a single motor neuron can be stimulated intracellularly to directly elicit a small unitary inhibitory postsynaptic potential in the interneuron.
text 2: In the laboratory, a single interneuron can be stimulated intracellularly to directly elicit a small unitary inhibitory postsynaptic potential in the motor neuron.

text 1: Excitatory synapses are typically axodendritic.
text 2: Excitatory synapses are typically axosomatic.

text 1: Type I synapses are typically inhibitory with flat synaptic vesicles.
text 2: Type I synapses are typically excitatory with round synaptic vesicles.

text 1: The proximity of a synapse to the dendritic tips determines its effectiveness in influencing action potential output.
text 2: The proximity of a synapse to the axon initial segment determines its effectiveness in influencing action potential output.

text 1: Type II synapses have oval or flattened synaptic vesicles, resulting in a more symmetric appearance.
text 2: Type II synapses have round synaptic vesicles, resulting in an asymmetric appearance.

text 1: Type I and type II synapses were described using electron microscopy by E. G. Gray.
text 2: Type I and type II synapses were described using fluorescence microscopy by E. G. Gray.

text 1: Depolarization produced by the EPSP becomes larger as more sensory afferent fibers are excited.
text 2: Depolarization produced by the EPSP becomes smaller as more sensory afferent fibers are excited.

text 1: Most type II synapses are glutamatergic and excitatory.
text 2: Most type II synapses are GABAergic and inhibitory.

text 1: A transmitter is always excitatory regardless of the type of ion channels in the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: A transmitter is usually inhibitory or excitatory based on the type of ion channels in the postsynaptic cell.

text 1: Curare is used to study the neuromuscular junction by blocking ACh binding to its receptor, thus lowering the postsynaptic potential below the threshold for an action potential.
text 2: Curare enhances the binding of ACh to its receptor, thus raising the postsynaptic potential above the threshold for an action potential.

text 1: The basal lamina is impermeable to ions and small organic compounds, preventing passage of the ACh transmitter.
text 2: The basal lamina freely permeable to ions and small organic compounds, including the ACh transmitter.

text 1: The toxin α-bungarotoxin acts as a reversible, competitive agonist of ACh by binding loosely to the ACh binding site.
text 2: The toxin α-bungarotoxin acts as an irreversible, noncompetitive antagonist of ACh by binding extremely tightly to the ACh binding site.

text 1: The electric ray Torpedo marmorata's electric organ generates a large voltage drop of up to 200 V outside the fish.
text 2: The electric ray Torpedo marmorata's electric organ generates a small voltage drop of up to only 10 V outside the fish.

text 1: End-plate potentials rise within 1 to 2 ms but decay more slowly.
text 2: End-plate potentials rise within 1 to 2 seconds and decay rapidly.

text 1: Paul Fatt and Bernard Katz used α-bungarotoxin in their study to isolate the end-plate potential.
text 2: Paul Fatt and Bernard Katz used curare in their study to isolate the end-plate potential.

text 1: The muscular junction is covered by a myelin sheath, which consists of lipoproteins.
text 2: The muscular junction is covered by basal lamina, which consists of collagen and glycoproteins.

text 1: Junctional folds contain a high density of ACh receptors, facilitating synaptic transmission.
text 2: Junctional folds contain no ACh receptors, hindering synaptic transmission.

text 1: Inward ionic current at the end-plate corresponds to an efflux of positive charge, which hyperpolarizes the inside of the membrane.
text 2: Inward ionic current at the end-plate corresponds to an influx of positive charge, which depolarizes the inside of the membrane.

text 1: The ACh receptors are spread evenly along the muscle fiber, away from the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: The ACh receptors are concentrated at the end-plate, opposite the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: Curare is a competitive agonist of ACh at the nicotinic receptor.
text 2: Curare is a competitive antagonist of ACh at the nicotinic receptor.

text 1: The presynaptic bouton contains mitochondria and synaptic vesicles clustered around active zones.
text 2: The presynaptic bouton contains lysosomes and synaptic vesicles clustered around inactive zones.

text 1: Under normal circumstances, stimulation of the motor axon produces an action potential in a skeletal muscle cell.
text 2: Under normal circumstances, stimulation of the motor axon prevents an action potential in a skeletal muscle cell.

text 1: The end-plate potential was first studied in detail by Paul Fatt and Bernard Katz using intracellular voltage recordings.
text 2: The end-plate potential was first studied in detail by Stephen Kuffler using extracellular voltage recordings.

text 1: Acetylcholine receptors in the vertebrate neuromuscular junction are concentrated at the bottom one-third of the junctional folds.
text 2: Acetylcholine receptors in the vertebrate neuromuscular junction are concentrated at the top one-third of the junctional folds.

text 1: Leptin is more effective in defending against low fat stores than in resisting obesity.
text 2: Leptin is more effective in resisting obesity than in defending against low fat stores.

text 1: Energy balance involves short-term and long-term feedback signals, including signals from the gut and leptin.
text 2: Energy balance is regulated only by long-term feedback signals such as leptin.

text 1: Short-term signals from the brain mediate satiation, which terminates meals.
text 2: Short-term signals from the gut mediate satiation, which terminates meals.

text 1: Leptin is secreted by adipocytes in proportion to the amount of fat stores.
text 2: Leptin is secreted by neurons in proportion to the amount of brain activity.

text 1: When fat stores are high, low levels of leptin signal the brain to induce a hunger state.
text 2: When fat stores are low, low levels of leptin signal the brain to induce a hunger state.

text 1: POMC-, AgRP-, and MC4R-expressing neurons in the hypothalamus are key nodes in controlling energy balance.
text 2: POMC-, AgRP-, and MC4R-expressing neurons in the cortex are key nodes in controlling energy balance.

text 1: Some neurons in the lamina terminalis are activated by both dehydration and loss of intravascular volume.
text 2: All neurons in the lamina terminalis are activated solely by dehydration.

text 1: When the neurons in the lamina terminalis are activated, they cause hunger and release of insulin from the pancreas.
text 2: When the neurons in the lamina terminalis are activated, they cause thirst and release of vasopressin from the posterior pituitary.

text 1: Leptin regulates hunger and energy expenditure by activating POMC neurons and inhibiting AgRP neurons.
text 2: Leptin regulates hunger and energy expenditure by inhibiting POMC neurons and activating AgRP neurons.

text 1: Hunger-promoting AgRP neurons are regulated in a feedforward fashion by cues that anticipate future changes in energy balance.
text 2: Hunger-promoting AgRP neurons are regulated only by current immediate changes in energy balance.

text 1: Neurons that signal satiety are inhibited by satiety-promoting POMC neurons and activated by hunger-promoting AgRP neurons.
text 2: Neurons that signal satiety are activated by satiety-promoting POMC neurons and inhibited by hunger-promoting AgRP neurons.

text 1: Vasopressin release is slowly regulated only after disturbances in osmolarity have occurred.
text 2: Vasopressin release is rapidly regulated by cues that anticipate future disturbances in osmolarity.

text 1: CCK, released by neurons in the brain, plays a key role in hunger.
text 2: CCK, released by intestinal endocrine cells, plays a key role in satiation.

text 1: Leptin is more effective in defending against low fat stores than in resisting obesity.
text 2: Leptin is more effective in resisting obesity than in defending against low fat stores.

text 1: How specificity for a given goal is retained as neural information flows from the hypothalamus to the accumbens is a mystery of motivated behaviors.
text 2: How specificity for a given goal is lost as neural information flows from the hypothalamus to the accumbens is the known pathway of motivated behaviors.

text 1: Gs protein inhibits cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production via adenylyl cyclase.
text 2: Gs protein stimulates cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production via adenylyl cyclase.

text 1: G proteins that contain different α-subunits couple with different classes of receptors and effectors.
text 2: G proteins that contain different α-subunits couple with the same classes of receptors and effectors.

text 1: Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is hydrolyzed by phospholipase C to produce AMP and ADP.
text 2: Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is hydrolyzed by phospholipase C to produce DAG and IP3.

text 1: Phosphodiesterases convert cAMP to cyclic guanosine monophosphate.
text 2: Phosphodiesterases convert cAMP to adenosine monophosphate.

text 1: Approximately 35% of genes in the human genome code for G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: Approximately 3.5% of genes in the human genome code for G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: The αs-subunit exchanges GTP for GDP upon activation.
text 2: The αs-subunit exchanges GDP for GTP upon activation.

text 1: The β2-adrenergic receptor associates with Gs protein α-subunits.
text 2: The β2-adrenergic receptor associates with Gi protein α-subunits.

text 1: Hydrolysis of phospholipids by phospholipase D produces IP3 and DAG.
text 2: Hydrolysis of phospholipids by phospholipase C produces IP3 and DAG.

text 1: Serine residues in the receptor's carboxy-terminal tail are sites for phosphorylation.
text 2: Threonine residues in the receptor's carboxy-terminal tail are sites for phosphorylation.

text 1: The αq-subunit of Go protein is expressed at particularly high levels in the brain.
text 2: The αo-subunit of Go protein is expressed at particularly high levels in the brain.

text 1: Phospholipase C hydrolyzes phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane.
text 2: Phospholipase C hydrolyzes phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane.

text 1: Many G protein–coupled receptors are visual receptors in retinal neurons.
text 2: Many G protein–coupled receptors are odorant receptors in olfactory neurons.

text 1: Protein phosphatases add phosphate groups to substrate proteins, releasing inorganic phosphate.
text 2: Protein phosphatases remove phosphate groups from substrate proteins, releasing inorganic phosphate.

text 1: Each G protein–coupled receptor consists of multiple polypeptides with seven membrane-spanning regions.
text 2: Each G protein–coupled receptor consists of a single polypeptide with seven membrane-spanning regions.

text 1: Gq/11 proteins contain αq- or α11-subunits that activate phospholipase C.
text 2: Gq/11 proteins contain αq- or α11-subunits that inhibit phospholipase C.

text 1: Acetylcholine receptors are synthesized by neurons cultured without muscle cells.
text 2: Acetylcholine receptors are synthesized by muscle cells cultured without neurons.

text 1: Damaged peripheral axons regenerate readily and form new neuromuscular junctions.
text 2: Damaged central nervous system axons regenerate readily and form new neuromuscular junctions.

text 1: Fernando Tello-Muñóz noted that the new junctions form randomly across the muscle fiber surface.
text 2: Fernando Tello-Muñóz noted that the new junctions form at preexisting synaptic sites on denervated muscle fibers.

text 1: The active zones form directly opposite the mouths of the postsynaptic junctional folds.
text 2: The active zones form randomly on the muscle surface without relation to junctional folds.

text 1: Laminin-211 absence leads to severe muscular dystrophy.
text 2: Laminin-211 abundance leads to severe muscular dystrophy.

text 1: Isoforms bearing the β2 chain are absent in the synaptic cleft.
text 2: Isoforms bearing the β2 chain predominate in the synaptic cleft.

text 1: Laminins act on the extracellular domain of the channels, whereas the intracellular segment recruits or stabilizes other components of the release apparatus.
text 2: Laminins act only on the intracellular domain of the channels.

text 1: Agrin is synthesized by motor neurons and released from nerve terminals.
text 2: Agrin is synthesized by muscle fibers and absorbed by nerve terminals.

text 1: The phenotype of mutant mice lacking agrin shows that agrin has a central role in organizing ACh receptors.
text 2: The phenotype of mutant mice lacking agrin shows that agrin has no role in organizing ACh receptors.

text 1: MuSK and LRP4 are not involved in synaptic sites in muscle membranes.
text 2: MuSK and LRP4 are normally concentrated at synaptic sites in the muscle membrane.

text 1: Muscles of mutant mice lacking MuSK or LRP4 do not have ACh receptor clusters.
text 2: Muscles of mutant mice lacking MuSK or LRP4 have hyperactive ACh receptor clusters.

text 1: The distribution of ACh receptors remains the same once synapse formation is complete.
text 2: The distribution of ACh receptors changes drastically once synapse formation is complete.

text 1: Agrin's major receptor is a simple single protein without any subunits.
text 2: Agrin's major receptor is a complex of a muscle-specific tyrosine kinase called MuSK and a coreceptor subunit called LRP4.

text 1: Different laminin isoforms are localized at synaptic and extrasynaptic areas of the basal lamina.
text 2: The same laminin isoforms are distributed uniformly across all areas of the basal lamina.

text 1: The β2 laminins appear to act by binding to voltage-sensitive calcium channels that reside in the axon terminal membrane.
text 2: The β2 laminins appear to act independently of any calcium channels.

text 1: Learning in the cerebellar microcircuit can occur in the cerebellar cortex and the deep cerebellar nuclei.
text 2: Learning in the cerebellar microcircuit can only occur in the cerebellar cortex and not in the deep cerebellar nuclei.

text 1: Cerebellar damage leads to profound movement incoordination called ataxia, which affects all movements including balance and walking.
text 2: Cerebellar damage has little effect on coordination and balance, affecting primarily cognitive functions.

text 1: Purkinje cells receive many synaptic contacts from many climbing fibers.
text 2: Purkinje cells receive many synaptic contacts from a single climbing fiber.

text 1: Climbing fibers cause 'simple spikes' that can discharge at very high rates.
text 2: Mossy fibers cause 'simple spikes' that can discharge at very high rates.

text 1: The cerebellum operates independently without connections to the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The cerebellum acts through its connections to other brain structures including the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Cerebellar learning does not require feedback and is spontaneous.
text 2: Cerebellar learning requires feedback about movement errors and updates movement on a trial-by-trial basis.

text 1: Climbing fibers fire at very low frequencies and cause unitary 'complex spikes' in Purkinje cells.
text 2: Climbing fibers fire at very high frequencies and cause unitary 'simple spikes' in Purkinje cells.

text 1: The cerebellum plays no role in movement coordination, and damage does not lead to ataxia.
text 2: The cerebellum plays a critical role in movement, and damage leads to ataxia.

text 1: The cerebellum also plays a role in cognitive and emotional behavior.
text 2: The cerebellum is only involved in motor functions, not cognitive or emotional behavior.

text 1: Learning is confined to the deep cerebellar nuclei and never involves the cerebellar cortex.
text 2: Learning may occur first in the cerebellar cortex and then be transferred to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

text 1: The cerebellum processes movements without combining sensory inputs with corollary discharge.
text 2: The cerebellum relies on computations that combine sensory inputs with corollary discharge reporting the movement that was commanded.

text 1: The cerebellum is important for generating reliable feedforward action.
text 2: The cerebellum is not involved in generating feedforward actions.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity in the cerebellum only involves potentiation without any depression of synapses.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity in the cerebellum includes long-term depression of synapses from parallel fibers to Purkinje cells.

text 1: Reciprocal connections between the cerebellum and the cerebral cortex include sensory and motor cortices.
text 2: Reciprocal connections between the cerebellum and the cerebral cortex exclude sensory and motor cortices.

text 1: Cerebrocerebellar connections are organized as a series of parallel, closed, recurrent loops.
text 2: Cerebrocerebellar connections are organized in random, non-recurrent patterns.

text 1: Large M1 lesions in monkeys have mild consequences, usually allowing recovery of independent finger and thumb movements.
text 2: Large M1 lesions in monkeys have more drastic consequences, including initial paralysis and usually the permanent loss of independent movements of the thumb and fingers.

text 1: Severe difficulties in navigating a complex environment in cats result from large motor cortex lesions.
text 2: Severe difficulties in navigating a complex environment in cats result from large sensory cortex lesions.

text 1: Lesions limited to part of the motor map, such as the contralateral arm, leg, or face, lead to paralysis of that body part.
text 2: Lesions limited to part of the motor map, such as the contralateral arm, leg, or face, lead to enhanced function of that body part.

text 1: In humans, small motor cortex lesions result in severe motor deficits usually with limited potential for recovery.
text 2: In humans, large motor cortex lesions result in severe motor deficits usually with limited potential for recovery.

text 1: The complexity of the motor map in M1 allows it to control movements of every part of the body.
text 2: The complexity of the sensory map in M1 allows it to control movements of every part of the body.

text 1: CM cells are less prominent in humans than in other species, contributing to mild effects of M1 lesions.
text 2: CM cells are more prominent in humans than in other species, contributing to the profound effects of M1 lesions.

text 1: Edward Evarts was the first to analyze M1 neuron activity in cats during knee movements without external loads.
text 2: Edward Evarts was the first to analyze M1 neuron activity in monkeys during wrist movements using external loads.

text 1: Monkeys recover some ability to make clumsy movements of the hands and arms and to walk and climb despite M1 lesions.
text 2: Monkeys recover full coordination and precise movements of the hands and arms despite M1 lesions.

text 1: Representational models assume the sensory system plans and controls movement parameters directly.
text 2: Representational models assume the motor system plans and controls movement parameters directly.

text 1: The activity of single neurons in M1 reflects a combination of parameters not tied to any identifiable specific coordinate framework.
text 2: The activity of single neurons in M1 reflects a combination of parameters closely tied to a specific coordinate framework.

text 1: In tasks requiring precise pinches using the thumb and index finger, M1 neuron activity varies with static isometric force levels.
text 2: In tasks requiring broad hand movements, M1 neuron activity varies with static isometric force levels.

text 1: Neurons with identical preferred directions discharge at different rates during any given movement.
text 2: Neurons with varied preferred directions discharge at different rates during any given movement.

text 1: Instructive tasks for monkeys with reaching movements in eight directions show M1 activity closely related to sensory feedback.
text 2: Instructive tasks for monkeys with reaching movements in eight directions show M1 activity closely related to causal kinetics.

text 1: Proximal limb muscle activity during reaching exhibits minimum activity in a preferred movement direction.
text 2: Proximal limb muscle activity during reaching exhibits maximum activity in a preferred movement direction.

text 1: The pyramidal tract neurons are more activated during obstacle clearance in cats compared to normal locomotion.
text 2: The pyramidal tract neurons are less activated during obstacle clearance in cats compared to normal locomotion.

text 1: The ability of owls to orient to sounds in space is completely disrupted by inactivation of the avian equivalent of the frontal eye fields.
text 2: The ability of owls to orient to sounds in space is unaffected by inactivation of the avian equivalent of the frontal eye fields.

text 1: Subcortical pathways are required for more complex sound-localization tasks in both mammals and birds.
text 2: Cortical pathways are required for more complex sound-localization tasks in both mammals and birds.

text 1: In the visual system, the output from the primary visual cortex is segregated into separate dorsal and ventral streams.
text 2: In the visual system, the output from the primary visual cortex is integrated into a single pathway.

text 1: Projections from the auditory cortex innervate the inferior colliculus and olivocochlear neurons.
text 2: Projections from the auditory cortex innervate only the thalamus, not the inferior colliculus or olivocochlear neurons.

text 1: There are almost 10 times as many corticofugal fibers entering the sensory thalamus as there are axons projecting from the thalamus to the cortex.
text 2: There are almost 10 times as many axons projecting from the thalamus to the cortex as there are corticofugal fibers entering the sensory thalamus.

text 1: Conditioned fear responses to simple auditory stimuli are mediated by complex cortical pathways.
text 2: Conditioned fear responses to simple auditory stimuli are mediated by direct rapid pathways from the auditory thalamus to the amygdala.

text 1: Cortical circuitry allows for working memory, complex recognition tasks, and evaluation of stimuli significance.
text 2: Subcortical circuitry allows for working memory, complex recognition tasks, and evaluation of stimuli significance.

text 1: The frontal areas receiving anterior auditory projections are generally implicated in nonspatial functions.
text 2: The frontal areas receiving anterior auditory projections are generally implicated in spatial functions.

text 1: The upper limit of phase-locking in A1 is greater than 3000 Hz.
text 2: The upper limit of phase-locking in A1 is less than 100 Hz.

text 1: Temporal codes alone are sufficient to represent time-varying sounds in the auditory system.
text 2: The combination of temporal and rate codes represents time-varying sounds in the auditory system.

text 1: Cortical neurons use rate codes to represent rapidly changing sounds beyond phase-locking limits.
text 2: Cortical neurons use temporal firing patterns to represent rapidly changing sounds beyond phase-locking limits.

text 1: Nonsynchronized neurons represent rapidly changing sound events by firing rate changes.
text 2: Nonsynchronized neurons represent rapidly changing sound events by synchronized firing.

text 1: The auditory cortex can actively adjust and improve auditory signal processing in subcortical structures.
text 2: The auditory cortex passively receives signals without modulating processing in subcortical structures.

text 1: Electrophysiological studies show caudal and parietal areas are more active for localizing stimuli.
text 2: Electrophysiological studies show ventral areas are more active for localizing stimuli.

text 1: Medial-belt areas of the auditory cortex project to both dorsal and ventral frontal cortices.
text 2: Medial-belt areas of the auditory cortex only project to ventral frontal cortices.

text 1: In the central nervous system, severed axons typically fail to regrow past the site of injury.
text 2: In the central nervous system, severed axons easily regrow past the site of injury.

text 1: Peripheral axons failed to regenerate through their own distal nerve trunk.
text 2: Peripheral axons regenerated well through their own distal nerve trunk.

text 1: Insertion of a section of peripheral nerve into a central nerve tract suppresses regeneration.
text 2: Insertion of a section of peripheral nerve into a central nerve tract promotes regeneration.

text 1: Schwann cells, or cells engineered to secrete trophic factors, have been grafted into sites of injury to promote axon growth.
text 2: Schwann cells have been removed from injury sites as they inhibit axon growth.

text 1: Central neuronal tissue contains high levels of laminin and an abundance of trophic molecules.
text 2: Central neuronal tissue contains little laminin and low levels of trophic molecules.

text 1: Myelin inhibits regeneration of central axons.
text 2: Myelin supports regeneration of central axons.

text 1: Nogo, MAG, and OMgp bind to common membrane receptors like NogoR and PirB.
text 2: Nogo, MAG, and OMgp bind to entirely distinct receptors with no overlap.

text 1: Spinal axon collaterals sprouting following injury is enhanced in rats treated to prevent myelin formation.
text 2: Spinal axon collaterals sprouting is uninfluenced by treatments to prevent myelin formation.

text 1: Laminin is a component of Schwann cell basal laminae that inhibits neurite outgrowth.
text 2: Laminin is a component of Schwann cell basal laminae that promotes neurite outgrowth.

text 1: The insertion of fibers rich in extracellular matrix molecules like laminin prevents axonal growth.
text 2: The insertion of fibers rich in extracellular matrix molecules like laminin can serve as a scaffold for axonal growth.

text 1: Tello found that injured central axons grew toward peripheral nerve implants.
text 2: Tello found that injured central axons avoided peripheral nerve implants.

text 1: Components of myelin encourage neurite outgrowth.
text 2: Components of myelin inhibit neurite outgrowth.

text 1: Research suggests that central nerves contain only growth-promoting elements.
text 2: Research suggests that central nerves contain inhibitory components in addition to growth-promoting elements.

text 1: Peripheral nerve stumps begin to produce neurotrophins and other trophic molecules after being denervated.
text 2: Peripheral nerve stumps cease production of neurotrophins and other trophic molecules after being denervated.

text 1: Regeneration of central axons remains limited, with axons generally failing to extend long distances.
text 2: Regeneration of central axons is generally extensive, with axons easily extending long distances.

text 1: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area are selective for objects of particular shapes and fire when the monkey is looking at or preparing to grasp an object.
text 2: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area are selective for objects of particular colors and fire when the monkey is looking away or preparing to release an object.

text 1: In the medial intraparietal area, neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target related to retina-centered direction of reach.
text 2: In the medial intraparietal area, neurons fire only after the monkey has reached for a target unrelated to retina-centered direction of reach.

text 1: In the ventral intraparietal area, all neurons have retina-centered receptive fields.
text 2: In the ventral intraparietal area, some neurons have head-centered receptive fields.

text 1: The neurons in the lateral intraparietal area have retina-centered receptive fields, and their activity depends on attention.
text 2: The neurons in the lateral intraparietal area have head-centered receptive fields, and their activity is completely independent of attention.

text 1: Monkeys trained to use a tool have reduced receptive fields in the anterior intraparietal area.
text 2: Monkeys trained to use a tool show expanded receptive fields encompassing the tool in the ventral intraparietal area.

text 1: Parietal cortex circuits are only involved in feedback processing after movements end.
text 2: Parietal cortex circuits might generate feedforward signals for early movement planning.

text 1: VIP neurons have fixed receptive fields regardless of tool use.
text 2: VIP neurons can dynamically expand their receptive fields once a tool is grasped.

text 1: Premotor cortex plays an important role in early movement planning.
text 2: Premotor cortex is involved only in executing movements after planning in other areas.

text 1: The lateral intraparietal area neurons fire when attention is directed to a stimulus within their receptive field.
text 2: The lateral intraparietal area neurons fire equally regardless of attention to stimuli within their receptive field.

text 1: Neurons selectively respond to retina-centered direction of reach in the medial intraparietal area.
text 2: Neurons selectively respond to shoulder-centered gestures unrelated to reaching in the medial intraparietal area.

text 1: In the ventral intraparietal area, visual receptive fields remain unchanged and strictly limited to the hand's position even with tool use.
text 2: In the ventral intraparietal area, visual receptive fields can incorporate the tool as an extension of the limb.

text 1: All neurons in the parietal cortex have static receptive fields that do not change with tool use.
text 2: Some neurons in the parietal cortex have receptive fields that dynamically expand once a tool is grasped.

text 1: Internally generated feedback may influence parietal cortex activity to help estimate the current arm state.
text 2: Externally generated auditory signals are the primary influence on parietal cortex activity for arm state estimation.

text 1: The anterior intraparietal area neurons fire when the monkey is looking at or preparing to grasp specific shaped objects.
text 2: The anterior intraparietal area neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to release objects of any shape.

text 1: Premotor cortex contributes to motor selection and planning based on sensory inputs and motivational states.
text 2: Premotor cortex is solely responsible for executing pre-planned motor actions without sensory or motivational input.

text 1: During the calibration phase, decision boundaries are arbitrary and not determined by a statistical model.
text 2: During the calibration phase, decision boundaries that partition the population activity space into different regions are determined by a statistical model.

text 1: Decoding accuracy typically decreases with an increasing number of simultaneously recorded neurons.
text 2: Decoding accuracy typically increases with an increasing number of simultaneously recorded neurons.

text 1: The population vector algorithm assigns each neuron's pushing vector to point away from the neuron's preferred direction.
text 2: The population vector algorithm assigns each neuron's pushing vector to point along the neuron's preferred direction.

text 1: Continuous decoding algorithms that take into account neural activity in the recent past provide higher decoding accuracy than those that do not.
text 2: Continuous decoding algorithms that ignore neural activity in the recent past provide higher decoding accuracy than those that account for it.

text 1: A more accurate decoder, the optimal linear estimator, incorporates the properties of spiking noise to determine pushing vectors.
text 2: The optimal linear estimator ignores the properties of spiking noise to determine pushing vectors.

text 1: Agrin prevents the aggregation of acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at synaptic sites.
text 2: Agrin induces aggregation of acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at synaptic sites.

text 1: Agrin is a small (~40 kDa) extracellular matrix proteoglycan.
text 2: Agrin is a large (~400 kDa) extracellular matrix proteoglycan.

text 1: Dok7, Crk, and CrkL are unrelated to ACh receptor clustering.
text 2: Dok7, Crk, and CrkL are key intracellular signaling molecules for ACh receptor clustering.

text 1: Rapsyn disperses the ACh receptors at synaptic sites.
text 2: Rapsyn interacts with and clusters the ACh receptors.

text 1: Muscles of mutant mice lacking Dok7 or rapsyn synthesize ACh receptors.
text 2: Muscles of mutant mice lacking Dok7 or rapsyn cannot synthesize ACh receptors.

text 1: In wild-type mice, ACh receptor clusters do not form under nerve terminals by birth.
text 2: In wild-type mice, ACh receptor clusters form under each nerve terminal by birth.

text 1: Agrin works by counteracting receptor dispersion mediated by ACh.
text 2: Agrin does not affect receptor dispersion mediated by ACh.

text 1: Axons do not participate in sculpting the postsynaptic membrane.
text 2: Axons sculpt the postsynaptic membrane through the action of agrin and a dispersal factor.

text 1: Agrin renders ACh receptors immune to the declustering effects of ACh.
text 2: Agrin enhances the declustering effects of ACh on ACh receptors.

text 1: The motor nerve has no role in regulating the transcriptional program for ACh receptor genes.
text 2: The motor nerve regulates the transcriptional program for ACh receptor genes.

text 1: ACh receptor gene expression is repressed in extrasynaptic regions due to electrical activity.
text 2: ACh receptor gene expression is increased in extrasynaptic regions due to electrical activity.

text 1: Denervation decreases ACh receptor density in the postsynaptic membrane.
text 2: Denervation induces a marked increase in ACh receptor density in the postsynaptic membrane.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of denervated muscle decreases ACh receptor density in the extrasynaptic membrane.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of denervated muscle increases ACh receptor density in the extrasynaptic membrane.

text 1: ACh receptors synthesized near the ends of fibers effortlessly reach the synapse without degradation.
text 2: ACh receptors synthesized near the ends of fibers are unlikely to reach the synapse without degradation.

text 1: The neuromuscular junction matures instantly without any regulatory mechanisms.
text 2: The neuromuscular junction matures in a series of steps involving multiple regulatory mechanisms.

text 1: Neural activity that reflects the causal forces and the spatiotemporal features of muscle activity necessary to move the limb is particularly prominent in the premotor cortex.
text 2: Neural activity that reflects the causal forces and the spatiotemporal features of muscle activity necessary to move the limb is particularly prominent in the primary motor cortex.

text 1: Monkeys made reaching movements to spatial targets on a touch screen.
text 2: Monkeys made reaching movements to spatial targets using a joystick.

text 1: Primary motor cortex in primates has a representation of the entire body along its mediolateral axis.
text 2: Primary motor cortex in primates has a representation of the entire body along its anterior-posterior axis.

text 1: Posterior parietal cortex plays a prominent role in initiating voluntary movement.
text 2: Posterior parietal cortex plays a prominent role in identifying potential goals and objects in the environment.

text 1: Voluntary motor control has long been separated into two stages—planning and execution.
text 2: Voluntary motor control has long been separated into three stages—sensation, planning, and execution.

text 1: Dynamical systems models of voluntary motor control assume that motor circuits find empirical solutions for the computations underlying the planning and execution of movements.
text 2: Dynamical systems models of voluntary motor control assume that motor circuits use purely stochastic processes for the computations underlying movement.

text 1: Neurons and cursor motions were rotated clockwise by 45°, and the monkeys showed significant adaptation to the perturbation within a few hundred trials.
text 2: Neurons and cursor motions were rotated counterclockwise by 90°, and the monkeys showed significant adaptation to the perturbation within the first trial.

text 1: New technologies such as single-neuron recordings will lead to deeper insights into the functionality of cortical motor circuits.
text 2: New technologies such as large-scale multi-neuron recording and imaging methods will lead to deeper insights into the functional architecture of cortical motor circuits.

text 1: Voluntary motor behavior is involuntary and operates independently of an individual's choice or decision.
text 2: Voluntary motor behavior implements an individual’s intentional choice or decision to move within the environment.

text 1: Primary motor cortex activity cannot reflect changes based on the behavioral context and performance goals.
text 2: Primary motor cortex activity can reflect changes based on the behavioral context and performance goals.

text 1: Top discharge response of a typical M1 neuron is shown with histograms aligned with the final screen contact.
text 2: Top discharge response of a typical M1 neuron is shown with raster plots and spike-timing histograms aligned with the initial screen contact.

text 1: Primary motor cortex in primates provides a large component of the corticospinal tract.
text 2: Primary motor cortex in primates provides no components to the corticospinal tract.

text 1: Neural circuits in cortical motor regions play no role in motor skill learning.
text 2: Neural circuits in cortical motor regions are critical for motor skill learning.

text 1: Premotor and prefrontal cortices play a prominent role only in motor execution.
text 2: Premotor and prefrontal cortices play a prominent role in task selection and motor planning.

text 1: Neural decoders are used to explore how neurons and neural populations contribute to motor skill learning.
text 2: Neural decoders are used to explore how only single neurons contribute to motor skill learning.

text 1: Lesioning of a monkey’s posterior parietal cortex, which includes the lateral intraparietal area, decreases the latency of saccades and improves their accuracy.
text 2: Lesioning of a monkey’s posterior parietal cortex, which includes the lateral intraparietal area, increases the latency of saccades and reduces their accuracy.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area stop responding as soon as the object appears and resume after the saccade begins.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond from the moment the object appears and continue firing after the object has vanished and throughout the delay until the saccade begins.

text 1: Patients with frontal lesions have no difficulty suppressing the unwanted saccade to the stimulus.
text 2: Patients with frontal lesions have great difficulty suppressing the unwanted saccade to the stimulus.

text 1: Bilateral lesions of both the frontal eye fields and the superior colliculus have no effect on a monkey's ability to make saccades.
text 2: Bilateral lesions of both the frontal eye fields and the superior colliculus render monkeys unable to make saccades at all.

text 1: The lateral intraparietal area in the monkey is important in the generation of both visual attention and saccades.
text 2: The lateral intraparietal area in the monkey is unrelated to visual attention and saccades.

text 1: Movement-related neurons in the frontal eye field control the superior colliculus through two pathways.
text 2: Movement-related neurons in the frontal eye field have no control over the superior colliculus.

text 1: Damage to the frontal eye field has no impact and causes no deficits.
text 2: Damage to the frontal eye field alone causes more subtle deficits, such as transient contralateral neglect.

text 1: In humans, the presence of frontal eye field signals does not affect the suppression of saccades.
text 2: In humans, the failure to suppress a saccade is therefore to be expected when the frontal eye field signals are absent.

text 1: Activity of visual neurons in the frontal eye field is not well aligned with the beginning of the saccade.
text 2: Activity of visual neurons in the frontal eye field is perfectly aligned with the beginning of the saccade.

text 1: Patients with Balint syndrome make many saccades and can describe multiple peripheral targets.
text 2: Patients with Balint syndrome make few saccades and can therefore describe only a foveal target.

text 1: Lesions of the superior colliculus in monkeys produce only transient damage to the saccade system.
text 2: Lesions of the superior colliculus in monkeys produce permanent damage to the saccade system.

text 1: The supplementary eye field at the most rostral part of the supplementary motor area contains neurons that encode spatial information other than the direction of the desired eye movement.
text 2: The supplementary eye field does not encode any spatial information relating to eye movements.

text 1: Visuomovement neurons are least active before visually guided saccades.
text 2: Visuomovement neurons discharge most strongly before visually guided saccades.

text 1: Monkeys can be trained to make saccades of a specific direction and amplitude in total darkness.
text 2: Monkeys cannot make saccades without visual targets even in darkness.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the frontal eye field suppresses all saccades.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the frontal eye field evokes saccades to the movement fields of the stimulated cells.

text 1: The human brain contains on the order of 86 billion neurons, classified into at least a thousand different types.
text 2: The human brain contains exactly 100 billion neurons, classified into at least five thousand different types.

text 1: Dendrites are the transmitting element of neurons, some extending more than 1 meter within the body.
text 2: Axons are the transmitting element of neurons, some extending more than 1 meter within the body.
