text 1: The branches of a single axon may form synapses with as many as 1,000 postsynaptic neurons.
text 2: The branches of a single dendrite may form synapses with as many as 1,000 presynaptic neurons.

text 1: The cell body of a neuron includes the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum.
text 2: The axon of a neuron includes the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum.

text 1: Most axons in the central nervous system are very thin compared to the diameter of the cell body.
text 2: Most axons in the central nervous system are very thick compared to the diameter of the cell body.

text 1: The action potential is initiated at the dendritic spine and propagates to the synapse.
text 2: The action potential is initiated at the initial segment of the axon and propagates to the synapse.

text 1: Many axons are insulated by a sheath of fatty myelin.
text 2: Many dendrites are insulated by a sheath of fatty myelin.

text 1: Neurons and their connections are fixed and cannot be modified by experience.
text 2: Neurons and their connections can be modified by experience.

text 1: Each nerve cell is part of a circuit that mediates specific behaviors.
text 2: Each nerve cell functions independently and does not mediate specific behaviors.

text 1: Nerve cells, or neurons, are the basic signaling units of the brain.
text 2: Glial cells, or glia, are the basic signaling units of the brain.

text 1: The brain actively organizes sensory information for perception, action, and decision-making.
text 2: The brain passively receives sensory information for perception, action, and decision-making.

text 1: The cell body usually gives rise to several short dendrites and one long axon.
text 2: The cell body usually gives rise to several long dendrites and one short axon.

text 1: Axons vary greatly in length, with some extending more than 1 meter within the body.
text 2: Dendrites vary greatly in length, with some extending more than 1 meter within the body.

text 1: The synapse is the site at which signals flow from one neuron to another.
text 2: The synapse is the site at which signals are stored and not transmitted to another neuron.

text 1: The nervous system has two main classes of cells: nerve cells and epithelial cells.
text 2: The nervous system has two main classes of cells: nerve cells and glial cells.

text 1: The mouse Hoxb1 gene controls the identity and projection of hindbrain motor neurons.
text 2: The mouse Hoxb1 gene controls the identity and projection of spinal cord motor neurons.

text 1: In wild-type mice, trigeminal motor neurons are generated in rhombomere r4.
text 2: In wild-type mice, trigeminal motor neurons are generated in rhombomere r2.

text 1: Facial motor neurons generated in rhombomere r4 project their axons out of the hindbrain at the r2 level.
text 2: Facial motor neurons generated in rhombomere r4 project their axons out of the hindbrain at the r4 level.

text 1: Prosomeres 4 to 6 give rise to the rostral diencephalon and telencephalon.
text 2: Prosomeres 4 to 6 give rise to the caudal diencephalon and hypothalamus.

text 1: Pax6 is expressed at high levels at anterior levels of the developing neocortex.
text 2: Pax6 is expressed at high levels at posterior levels of the developing neocortex.

text 1: Emx2 is expressed in high levels at anterior levels of the developing neocortex.
text 2: Emx2 is expressed in high levels at posterior levels of the developing neocortex.

text 1: In mice lacking Pax6 activity, visual and auditory areas are expanded.
text 2: In mice lacking Pax6 activity, motor and somatosensory areas are expanded.

text 1: Changing the Hox code within motor pools changes the pattern of muscle connectivity.
text 2: Changing the LIM code within motor pools changes the pattern of muscle connectivity.

text 1: RNA interference knock-down of Hox9 suppresses innervation of the Pec muscle.
text 2: RNA interference knock-down of Hox6 suppresses innervation of the Pec muscle.

text 1: The spatial distribution of Pax6 and Emx2 helps establish the initial regional pattern of the neocortex.
text 2: The spatial distribution of Pax6 and Emx2 helps establish the final pattern of the telencephalon.

text 1: Motor neurons in the medial and lateral divisions of the lateral motor column project axons into the ventral and dorsal halves of the limb, respectively.
text 2: Motor neurons in the lateral division of the lateral motor column project axons into both ventral and dorsal halves of the limb.

text 1: LIM homeodomain protein Isl1 directs a high level of expression of EphA receptors.
text 2: LIM homeodomain protein Isl1 directs a high level of expression of EphB receptors.

text 1: Lhx1 directs a high level of expression of EphA receptors in lateral LMC neurons.
text 2: Lhx1 directs a high level of expression of EphB receptors in lateral LMC neurons.

text 1: The axons of lateral motor column neurons are guided into the limb by ephrin class tyrosine kinase receptors.
text 2: The axons of lateral motor column neurons are guided into the limb by LIM class homeodomain proteins.

text 1: Cross-repressive interactions between Hox6, Hox9, and Hox10 proteins refine Hox profiles.
text 2: Cross-repressive interactions between Hox6, Hox7, and Hox8 proteins refine Hox profiles.

text 1: Cre recombinase is expressed at sufficient levels selectively in CA1 cells under the control of the CaMKIIα promoter.
text 2: Cre recombinase is expressed at sufficient levels selectively in CA3 cells under the control of the CaMKIIα promoter.

text 1: Transgenic mice express CaMKII–Asp286 in the forebrain, and this expression can be turned off by administering doxycycline to the mice.
text 2: Transgenic mice express CaMKII–Asp286 in the hindbrain, and this expression can be turned off by administering doxycycline to the mice.

text 1: The Cre/loxP system allows for gene knockout in selective regions by flanking genes with loxP sites and using Cre recombinase.
text 2: The Cre/loxP system allows for gene expression in selective regions by flanking genes with loxP sites and using Cre recombinase.

text 1: In mutant mice, expression of the mRNA for NR1 is greatly reduced in the CA1 region of the hippocampus.
text 2: In mutant mice, expression of the mRNA for NR1 is greatly reduced in the CA3 region of the hippocampus.

text 1: Tetracycline given to the offspring increases binding of tTA protein to tetO, promoting transgene expression.
text 2: Tetracycline given to the offspring causes a conformational change that leads to the unbinding of tTA protein from tetO, blocking transgene expression.

text 1: RNA interference and CRISPR have great potential to increase the power of genetic analysis in various species.
text 2: RNA interference and CRISPR are limited in application to only traditional model organisms.

text 1: In flies, the DNA to be injected is cloned into a transposable element (P element) for insertion into germ cell nuclei.
text 2: In flies, the DNA to be injected is not cloned into any transposable element before insertion.

text 1: Genes can be experimentally introduced in mice by injecting DNA into the nucleus of newly fertilized eggs.
text 2: Genes can be experimentally introduced in mice by injecting DNA into adult mice cells.

text 1: Mice with patches of pigmented fur indicate successful expression of injected DNA.
text 2: Mice with albino fur indicate successful expression of injected DNA.

text 1: CRISPR tools are not considered for repair of hereditary mutations in people with severe inherited genetic diseases.
text 2: CRISPR tools are considered for repair of hereditary mutations in people with severe inherited genetic diseases.

text 1: Cre-mediated loxP recombination adds a new gene in cell types where the promoter driving Cre expression is active.
text 2: Cre-mediated loxP recombination deletes the floxed gene in cell types where the promoter driving Cre expression is active.

text 1: The tTA protein activates tetO promoter leading to transcription of mutant CaMKII-Asp286.
text 2: The tTA protein prevents activation of tetO promoter leading to transcription of mutant CaMKII-Asp286.

text 1: Gene incorporation in mice is confirmed by testing a sample of DNA from the injected animals.
text 2: Gene incorporation in mice is confirmed by observing changes in behavior of the injected animals.

text 1: P elements cannot be engineered to express genes at specific times and in specific cells in flies.
text 2: P elements can be engineered to express genes at specific times and in specific cells in flies.

text 1: Single copy of the gene is inserted randomly into one chromosome in each cell of transgenic animals.
text 2: Multiple copies of the gene are inserted in organized locations on chromosomes in each cell of transgenic animals.

text 1: The ionotropic glutamate receptors contain a large extracellular amino terminus, with a transmembrane domain containing three membrane-spanning α-helixes (M1, M3, and M4), and a loop that dips into the cytoplasmic side of the membrane (M2).
text 2: The ionotropic glutamate receptors contain a small extracellular amino terminus, with a transmembrane domain containing two membrane-spanning α-helixes (M1 and M4), and a loop that dips into the cytoplasmic side of the membrane (M2).

text 1: The ligand-binding domain of the ionotropic glutamate receptor is formed by the intracellular region of the receptor on the carboxyl-terminal side of the M1 segment and by the extracellular loop connecting M2 and M3.
text 2: The ligand-binding domain of the ionotropic glutamate receptor is formed by the extracellular region of the receptor on the amino-terminal side of the M1 segment and by the extracellular loop connecting M3 and M4.

text 1: In ionotropic glutamate receptors, the amino-terminal domain does not bind glutamate but is thought to modulate receptor function and synapse development.
text 2: In ionotropic glutamate receptors, the amino-terminal domain binds glutamate and is thought to mediate neurotransmission.

text 1: A typical postsynaptic density is around 350 nm in diameter and contains about 20 NMDA receptors.
text 2: A typical postsynaptic density is around 150 nm in diameter and contains about 50 NMDA receptors.

text 1: The PDZ domains in PSD-95 bind to specific sequences at the amino terminus of a number of proteins.
text 2: The PDZ domains in PSD-95 bind to specific sequences at the carboxy terminus of a number of proteins.

text 1: PSD-95 directly interacts with AMPA receptors and binds to the amino terminus of the TARP family of membrane proteins.
text 2: PSD-95 does not directly interact with AMPA receptors but binds to the carboxyl terminus of the TARP family of membrane proteins.

text 1: In adults, the GluA2 protein exists almost exclusively in the unedited form, coding for glutamine.
text 2: In adults, the GluA2 protein exists almost exclusively in the edited form, coding for arginine.

text 1: Neuroligin mutations are thought to contribute to some cases of autism.
text 2: Neuroligin mutations are thought to contribute to some cases of Alzheimer's disease.

text 1: In early development, synapses containing only NMDA receptors are common.
text 2: In early development, synapses containing only AMPA receptors are common.

text 1: The postsynaptic density is a stable structure that can be biochemically isolated and characterized.
text 2: The postsynaptic density is an unstable structure that cannot be biochemically isolated or characterized.

text 1: AMPA receptor-channels expressed from edited transcripts primarily conduct Ca2+.
text 2: AMPA receptor-channels expressed from unedited transcripts conduct Ca2+.

text 1: The edited GluA2 transcript codes for the neutral residue glutamine.
text 2: The edited GluA2 transcript codes for the positively charged residue arginine.

text 1: PSD-95 also interacts with the presynaptic membrane protein neuroligin, which contacts the postsynaptic membrane protein neurexin.
text 2: PSD-95 also interacts with the postsynaptic membrane protein neuroligin, which contacts the presynaptic membrane protein neurexin.

text 1: The postsynaptic cell membrane is organized into a macromolecular complex at excitatory synapses.
text 2: The presynaptic cell membrane is organized into a macromolecular complex at inhibitory synapses.

text 1: Proteins containing PDZ domains help organize the distribution of AMPA and NMDA glutamate receptors at the postsynaptic density.
text 2: Proteins containing SH3 domains help organize the distribution of AMPA and NMDA glutamate receptors at the postsynaptic density.

text 1: The suprachiasmatic nucleus is most active during the daily light period in diurnal mammals like humans.
text 2: The suprachiasmatic nucleus is most active during the daily dark period in diurnal mammals like humans.

text 1: Individuals with familial advanced sleep-phase syndrome prefer to go to bed late and wake up around noon due to mutations in the genes coding for Period or Casein kinase-1 delta.
text 2: Individuals with familial advanced sleep-phase syndrome go to bed early and cannot sleep past 3 or 4 am due to mutations in the genes coding for Period or Casein kinase-1 delta.

text 1: Blind people with damaged melanopsin-containing neurons lack the ability to entrain to external light–dark conditions, often leading to non–24-hour sleep–wake rhythm disorder.
text 2: Blind people with intact melanopsin-containing neurons lack the ability to entrain to external light–dark conditions, often leading to non–24-hour sleep–wake rhythm disorder.

text 1: Melatonin is made by the pineal gland and signals darkness.
text 2: Melatonin is made by the adrenal gland and signals light.

text 1: The subparaventricular zone fires in antiphase to the suprachiasmatic nucleus, being most active at night.
text 2: The subparaventricular zone fires in phase with the suprachiasmatic nucleus, being most active during the day.

text 1: Neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus contain serotonin receptors, which reinforce circadian rhythms.
text 2: Neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus contain melatonin receptors, which reinforce circadian rhythms.

text 1: The average period in humans placed in a continuous dim light environment is exactly 24 hours.
text 2: The average period in humans placed in a continuous dim light environment is 24.1 hours.

text 1: The suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates body temperature, autonomic functions, endocrine functions, and behavioral functions.
text 2: The suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates hematological functions and digestive movements.

text 1: Sleep tends to be fragmented in Alzheimer disease due to the loss of neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus.
text 2: Sleep tends to be uninterrupted in Alzheimer disease due to the addition of neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus.

text 1: Exogenous melatonin or melatonin agonists inhibit circadian rhythms, disrupting sleep by irregularizing sleep onset.
text 2: Exogenous melatonin or melatonin agonists can entrain circadian rhythms, promoting sleep by regularizing sleep onset.

text 1: Sleepiness impairs cognition, but sleep itself helps consolidate memories.
text 2: Sleepiness enhances cognition, but sleep itself disrupts the consolidation of memories.

text 1: REM sleep is correlated with improvement of certain types of memory consolidation for a visual perception task.
text 2: Stage N2 non-REM sleep is correlated with improvement of certain types of memory consolidation for a visual perception task.

text 1: Insomnia is defined as excellent quality of sleep leading to improved function the next day.
text 2: Insomnia is defined as difficulty falling asleep or trouble staying asleep, so that function the next day is impaired.

text 1: In rats, simultaneous activity in components of the arousal system during stress can produce a unique state with slow waves consistent with sleep.
text 2: In rats, simultaneous activity in components of the arousal system during stress can produce no detectable changes consistent with sleep.

text 1: Sleep recordings from a premature infant exhibit a low percentage of REM-like sleep, indicating most of the day is spent in active movement.
text 2: Sleep recordings from a premature infant exhibit a high percentage of REM-like sleep, indicating a large fraction of the day in a brain-activated but movement-inhibited state.

text 1: Olfactory preferences in Drosophila are shaped by sensory neurons as demonstrated by Troemel, Kimmel, and Bargmann in 1997.
text 2: Olfactory preferences in C. elegans are shaped by sensory neurons as demonstrated by Troemel, Kimmel, and Bargmann in 1997.

text 1: Vosshall, Amrein, Morozov, Rzhetsky, and Axel provided a spatial map of olfactory receptor expression in mammals in 1999.
text 2: Vosshall, Amrein, Morozov, Rzhetsky, and Axel provided a spatial map of olfactory receptor expression in Drosophila antenna in 1999.

text 1: Zhang Y and colleagues in 2003 identified different receptor cells for sour, salty, and umami tastes that share similar signaling pathways.
text 2: Zhang Y and colleagues in 2003 identified different receptor cells for sweet, bitter, and umami tastes that share similar signaling pathways.

text 1: Sweet stimuli responses in cells require the proton channel Otop1 as identified by Teng, Wilson, Tu, Joshi, Kinnamon, and Liman in 2019.
text 2: Sour stimuli responses in cells require the proton channel Otop1 as identified by Teng, Wilson, Tu, Joshi, Kinnamon, and Liman in 2019.

text 1: The olfactory bulb was discussed by Shepherd and Greer in both the 3rd and 5th editions of 'The Synaptic Organization of the Brain'.
text 2: The olfactory bulb was discussed by Shepherd and Greer in both the 4th and 5th editions of 'The Synaptic Organization of the Brain'.

text 1: Vassar, Ngai, and Axel in 1993 researched the spatial segregation of odorant receptor expression in the mammalian olfactory epithelium.
text 2: Vassar, Ngai, and Axel in 1993 researched the spatial segregation of odorant receptor expression in the Drosophila antenna.

text 1: An olfactory sensory map in the fly brain was developed by Vosshall, Wong, and Axel in 2000.
text 2: An olfactory sensory map in the mammalian brain was developed by Vosshall, Wong, and Axel in 2000.

text 1: The olfactory receptor gene superfamily of the mouse was analyzed by Zhang and Firestein in 2002.
text 2: The olfactory receptor gene superfamily of the Drosophila was analyzed by Zhang and Firestein in 2002.

text 1: Wilson discussed early olfactory processing in mammals in the Annual Review of Neuroscience in 2013.
text 2: Wilson discussed early olfactory processing in Drosophila in the Annual Review of Neuroscience in 2013.

text 1: Zhao GQ, Zhang Y, Hoon MA, et al. described receptors for mammalian bitter and salty tastes in 2003.
text 2: Zhao GQ, Zhang Y, Hoon MA, et al. described receptors for mammalian sweet and umami tastes in 2003.

text 1: Stettler and Axel discussed representations of odor in the piriform cortex in 2009.
text 2: Stettler and Axel discussed representations of taste in the piriform cortex in 2009.

text 1: Sullivan, Adamson, Ressler, Kozak, and Buck examined the chromosomal distribution of mouse odorant receptor genes in 1996.
text 2: Sullivan, Adamson, Ressler, Kozak, and Buck examined the chromosomal distribution of human odorant receptor genes in 1996.

text 1: Wang, Wong, Flores, Vosshall, and Axel used MRI imaging to reveal an odor-evoked map of activity in the fly brain.
text 2: Wang, Wong, Flores, Vosshall, and Axel used two-photon calcium imaging to reveal an odor-evoked map of activity in the fly brain.

text 1: The Tomb of the Dancers in Ruvo di Puglia contains frescoes of 25 Peucetian women dancing.
text 2: The Tomb of the Dancers in Ruvo di Puglia contains frescoes of 30 Peucetian women dancing.

text 1: The panels with frescoes from the Tomb of the Dancers are exhibited in the Naples National Archaeological Museum.
text 2: The panels with frescoes from the Tomb of the Dancers are exhibited in the British Museum.

text 1: Mast cells are secretory cells of the endocrine system that contain large dense-core vesicles filled with the transmitters dopamine and norepinephrine.

text 1: Exocytosis of the secretory vesicles is normally triggered by the binding of antigen complexed to an immunoglobulin (IgE).
text 2: Exocytosis of the secretory vesicles is normally triggered by the binding of antigen complexed to an immunoglobulin (IgA).

text 1: The reversible opening and closing of a fusion pore represents a very slow method of membrane retrieval.
text 2: The reversible opening and closing of a fusion pore represents a very rapid method of membrane retrieval.

text 1: The increments in capacitance caused by fusion of individual vesicles are too small to resolve.
text 2: The increments in capacitance caused by fusion of individual vesicles are large and easily resolved.

text 1: A second pathway of ultrafast clathrin-independent endocytosis is 200 times slower than the classical clathrin-mediated pathway.
text 2: A second pathway of ultrafast clathrin-independent endocytosis is 200 times faster than the classical clathrin-mediated pathway.

text 1: Clathrin forms a helical structure that surrounds the membrane during endocytosis.

text 1: The giant presynaptic terminals of bipolar neurons in the retina are more than 5 μm in diameter.
text 2: The giant presynaptic terminals of bipolar neurons in the retina are less than 5 μm in diameter.

text 1: Ultrafast endocytosis occurs just inside the active zone.
text 2: Ultrafast endocytosis occurs just outside of the active zone.

text 1: A partial-cell patch clamp is used to record membrane current associated with the opening of a fusion pore.
text 2: A whole-cell patch clamp is used to record membrane current associated with the opening of a fusion pore.

text 1: Serotonin is never released through the reversible opening and closing of the fusion pore prior to full fusion.

text 1: Capacitance measurements cannot be used to study exocytosis of large dense-core vesicles in neuroendocrine cells.
text 2: Capacitance measurements can be used to study exocytosis of large dense-core vesicles in neuroendocrine cells.

text 1: The pore has an initial conductance of approximately 200 pS.

text 1: During depolarization, no Ca2+ current is elicited.

text 1: Clathrin-mediated recycling completes in less than a millisecond.

text 1: High-frequency firing can result in the exocytosis of a large number of vesicles over time, more than the number evident within the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: The motor pattern of stepping is organized at the cerebral level.
