text 1: Experiments suggest that there are probably a single CPG for all limbs.
text 2: Experiments suggest that there are probably separate CPGs for each limb.

text 1: A prominent locomotor pattern can be observed immediately after spinal transection in all vertebrates except higher primates and humans.
text 2: A prominent locomotor pattern can be observed immediately after spinal transection in all vertebrates including higher primates and humans.

text 1: Thomas Graham Brown demonstrated the intrinsic capacity of the brain to generate a rudimentary locomotor pattern.
text 2: Thomas Graham Brown demonstrated the intrinsic capacity of the isolated spinal cord to generate a rudimentary locomotor pattern.

text 1: The concept of a central pattern generator (CPG) suggests that rhythm and pattern can be generated independent of sensory inputs.
text 2: The concept of a central pattern generator (CPG) suggests that rhythm and pattern require continuous sensory inputs.

text 1: CPGs have only been analyzed in terrestrial locomotion systems.
text 2: CPGs have been analyzed in many rhythmic motor systems, including swimming and flying.

text 1: The spinal circuits responsible for locomotion can be modified by experience.
text 2: The spinal circuits responsible for locomotion cannot be modified by experience.

text 1: Training quadrupedal animals with complete thoracic spinal cord lesions can regain remarkable hindlimb walking ability.
text 2: Training quadrupedal animals with complete thoracic spinal cord lesions does not improve hindlimb walking ability.

text 1: The lamprey swims with a wave of left-right bending from front to back.
text 2: The lamprey swims with a wave of up-down bending from front to back.

text 1: Glutamatergic neurons excite commissural inhibitory neurons in the lamprey swimming network.
text 2: Glutamatergic neurons inhibit commissural inhibitory neurons in the lamprey swimming network.

text 1: A central pattern generator (CPG) can generate only the rhythm of locomotion, not the pattern.
text 2: A central pattern generator (CPG) can generate both the rhythm and the pattern of locomotion.

text 1: Rhythmical activity in motor neurons was inhibited by L-DOPA and nialamide in spinal cats.
text 2: Rhythmical activity in motor neurons was stimulated by L-DOPA and nialamide in spinal cats.

text 1: Rhythm and pattern generation have been studied exclusively in mammalian models.
text 2: Rhythm and pattern generation have been studied using models with fewer neurons such as the turtle and tadpole.

text 1: The swimming central pattern generator uses commissural interneurons to excite contralateral motor neurons.
text 2: The swimming central pattern generator uses commissural interneurons to inhibit contralateral motor neurons.

text 1: In adult zebrafish, rhythm-generating circuits drive motor neurons only at a single speed of swimming.
text 2: In adult zebrafish, rhythm-generating circuits drive motor neurons at different speeds of swimming.

text 1: In a typical resting neuron, the inside of the cell is about 65 mV more negative than the outside.
text 2: In a typical resting neuron, the inside of the cell is about 65 mV more positive than the outside.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump actively pumps Na+ into the cell and K+ out of it.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump actively pumps Na+ out of the cell and K+ into it.

text 1: Action potentials decrease in amplitude significantly before reaching the axon terminal.
text 2: Action potentials are actively propagated, preventing amplitude diminishment before reaching the axon terminal.

text 1: Hyperpolarization makes a cell less likely to generate an action potential.
text 2: Hyperpolarization makes a cell more likely to generate an action potential.

text 1: Receptor potentials are all-or-none signals like action potentials.
text 2: Receptor potentials are graded and can vary based on the intensity of a stimulus.

text 1: Receptor potentials are depolarizing in most sensory systems, but can be hyperpolarizing in the retina.
text 2: Receptor potentials are hyperpolarizing in most sensory systems, but can be depolarizing in the retina.

text 1: The resting membrane potential in different nerve cells ranges from –40 to –80 mV.
text 2: The resting membrane potential in different nerve cells ranges from +40 to +80 mV.

text 1: The resting state of a cell is perturbed by the uptake of Na+ or Ca2+ ions.
text 2: The resting state of a cell is perturbed by the efflux of Na+ or Ca2+ ions.

text 1: The Na+ concentration inside a neuron is kept low by the Na+-K+ pump.
text 2: The Na+ concentration inside a neuron is kept high by the Na+-K+ pump.

text 1: Action potentials lead to a brief and explosive change in membrane potential to -40 mV.
text 2: Action potentials lead to a brief and explosive change in membrane potential to +40 mV.

text 1: The resting membrane potential is predominantly unaffected by ion permeability.
text 2: The resting membrane potential is predominantly maintained by the selective permeability of the membrane to ions.

text 1: A synaptic potential is graded and depends on the amount of neurotransmitter released.
text 2: A synaptic potential is not graded and is unaffected by the amount of neurotransmitter released.

text 1: Projection interneurons have the same four functional regions as model neurons.
text 2: Projection interneurons lack functional regions similar to model neurons.

text 1: Signaling is organized in completely different manners in all neurons due to their diverse functions.
text 2: Signaling is organized in a similar manner in almost all neurons despite their diverse functions.

text 1: In excitable cells, a change from –65 to –55 mV decreases the membrane's permeability to Na+.
text 2: In excitable cells, a change from –65 to –55 mV increases the membrane's permeability to Na+.

text 1: The sympathetic outflow is organized into a single continuous ganglion.
text 2: The sympathetic outflow is organized into groups of paravertebral and prevertebral ganglia.

text 1: Preganglionic axons in the splanchnic nerves form synapses with postganglionic neurons in prevertebral ganglia.
text 2: Preganglionic axons in the splanchnic nerves form synapses directly with effector organs.

text 1: Parasympathetic neurons release ACh, which activates muscarinic G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: Parasympathetic neurons release norepinephrine, which activates adrenergic receptors.

text 1: The enteric plexus contains interneurons, sensory neurons, and motor neurons.
text 2: The enteric plexus contains only motor neurons.

text 1: The enteric system is modulated by external inputs from sympathetic prevertebral ganglia and parasympathetic components of the vagus nerve.
text 2: The enteric system functions independently and is not modulated by any external inputs.

text 1: The superior cervical ganglion supplies parasympathetic innervation to the entire head.
text 2: The superior cervical ganglion supplies sympathetic innervation to the entire head, including the cerebral vasculature.

text 1: Acetylcholine and norepinephrine are the principal transmitters of autonomic motor neurons.
text 2: Dopamine and serotonin are the principal transmitters of autonomic motor neurons.

text 1: Parasympathetic ganglia generally innervate multiple end organs and lie far from the end organs they regulate.
text 2: Parasympathetic ganglia generally innervate single end organs and lie near to or within the end organs they regulate.

text 1: Sympathetic neurons release acetylcholine, which activates muscarinic receptors.
text 2: Sympathetic neurons release norepinephrine, which activates α- and β-adrenergic G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: The cranial and sacral parasympathetic ganglia innervate different targets.
text 2: The cranial and sacral parasympathetic ganglia innervate the same targets.

text 1: The enteric system regulates local blood flow and immune function in Peyer’s patches.
text 2: The enteric system is not involved in regulating local blood flow or immune function.

text 1: Activation of ganglionic neurons triggers action potentials that propagate to postganglionic synapses with end organs.
text 2: Activation of ganglionic neurons suppresses action potentials to postganglionic synapses with end organs.

text 1: The vagus nerve projects broadly to parasympathetic ganglia in the heart, lungs, liver, gallbladder, and pancreas.
text 2: The vagus nerve projects only to the heart and lungs.

text 1: Sympathetic pathways have an orderly somatotopic relation to one another from their segmental origin in preganglionic neurons to their terminus in peripheral targets.
text 2: Sympathetic pathways are randomly organized with no discernible order in their relation from preganglionic neurons to peripheral targets.

text 1: The sympathetic outflow extends bilaterally as two chains from the first cervical segment to the last sacral segment.
text 2: The sympathetic outflow extends unilaterally from the thoracic segment only.

text 1: Pyramidal neurons in layer VI provide the principal output from each column.
text 2: Pyramidal neurons in layer V provide the principal output from each column.

text 1: Neurons in layers II and III project to layer V in the same column, to higher cortical areas in the same hemisphere, and to mirror-image locations in the opposite hemisphere.
text 2: Neurons in layers II and III project to layer VI in the same column, to lower cortical areas in the same hemisphere, and to adjacent locations in the same hemisphere.

text 1: The neural map of the body in the human brain is termed the cerebellum.
text 2: The neural map of the body in the human brain is termed the homunculus.

text 1: Feedback signals from layers IV and V of lower somatosensory cortical areas are provided to layer III in higher cortical areas.
text 2: Feedback signals from layers II and III of higher somatosensory cortical areas are provided to layer I in lower cortical areas.

text 1: The columns within the primary somatic sensory cortex are arranged topographically for a complete somatotopic representation.
text 2: The columns within the primary motor cortex are arranged randomly without a somatotopic representation.

text 1: Neurons in areas 2 and 5 of S-I process details of surface texture.
text 2: Neurons in areas 3b and 1 of S-I process details of surface texture.

text 1: The nervous system modulates sensation through local inhibitory interneurons.
text 2: The nervous system modulates sensation through reciprocal inhibition.

text 1: Cortical magnification refers to the amount of cortical area dedicated to memory formation.
text 2: Cortical magnification refers to the amount of cortical area devoted to a unit area of skin.

text 1: Rodent barrel cortices receive inputs from individual neural maps on the body.
text 2: Rodent barrel cortices receive inputs from individual vibrissae on the face.

text 1: Sacral segments are represented medially in the cortical map.
text 2: Sacral segments are represented laterally in the cortical map.

text 1: Neurons deeper in layer V project to subcortical structures including the basal ganglia and spinal cord.
text 2: Neurons deeper in layer III project to subcortical structures including the basal ganglia and spinal cord.

text 1: The primary somatosensory cortex in the macaque monkey lies anterior to the central sulcus as in the human brain.
text 2: The primary somatosensory cortex in the macaque monkey lies caudal to the central sulcus as in the human brain.

text 1: There is only a partial somatotopic representation of the body in each of the four areas of S-I.
text 2: There is a complete somatotopic representation of the body in each of the four areas of S-I.

text 1: In humans and monkeys, more cortical columns are devoted to the fingers than to the entire trunk.
text 2: In humans and monkeys, more cortical columns are devoted to the trunk than to the fingers.

text 1: Feedback pathways may enhance sensory signals during non-motor activity.
text 2: Feedback pathways may gate sensory signals during motor activity.

text 1: Radial glial cells serve as vehicles for neuron transport from the ventricular zone to the striatum.
text 2: Radial glial cells serve as scaffolds for neuron migration from the ventricular zone to the pial surface of the cortex.

text 1: Patients with lissencephaly often have a mature cortex reduced from four to two neuronal layers.
text 2: Patients with lissencephaly often have a mature cortex reduced from six to four neuronal layers.

text 1: The Lis1 and doublecortin proteins are involved in actin filament-dependent nuclear movement.
text 2: The Lis1 and doublecortin proteins are involved in microtubule-dependent nuclear movement.

text 1: Reelin acts through cell-surface receptors that include the ApoE receptor 2 and the very-low-density lipoprotein receptor.
text 2: Reelin acts through cell-surface receptors that include the ApoE receptor 1 and the high-density lipoprotein receptor.

text 1: In mice lacking functional reelin, neurons fail to detach from their radial glial scaffolds.
text 2: In mice lacking functional reelin, neurons easily detach from their radial glial scaffolds.

text 1: The ganglionic eminences are regions in the dorsal telencephalon where many cortical interneurons originate.
text 2: The ganglionic eminences are regions in the ventral telencephalon where many cortical interneurons originate.

text 1: Interneurons generated in the lateral ganglionic eminence contribute to the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Interneurons generated in the medial ganglionic eminence contribute to the olfactory bulb.

text 1: Nkx2.1 is selectively expressed by cells in the caudal ganglionic eminence.
text 2: Nkx2.1 is selectively expressed by cells in the medial ganglionic eminence.

text 1: Dlx1 and Dlx2 are homeodomain proteins expressed in the ganglionic eminences.
text 2: Dlx1 and Dlx2 are homeodomain proteins expressed in the cortical ventricular zone.

text 1: Migrating neurons receive repulsive cues from motogenic factors like slits, semaphorins, and ephrins.
text 2: Migrating neurons receive attractive cues from motogenic factors like slits, semaphorins, and ephrins.

text 1: Neurons generated in the lateral ganglionic eminence migrate rostrally to contribute to the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Neurons generated in the lateral ganglionic eminence migrate rostrally to contribute to the hippocampus.

text 1: Chain migration involves cells migrating to the striatum using neighboring migrating cells as substrates.
text 2: Chain migration involves cells migrating to the olfactory bulb using neighboring migrating cells as substrates.

text 1: Cortical interneurons arise from both medial and caudal ganglionic eminences.
text 2: Cortical interneurons arise from the lateral and caudal ganglionic eminences only.

text 1: Reelin signals are transduced by the intracellular protein Dab1.
text 2: Reelin signals are transduced by the intracellular protein Dab2.

text 1: Actin filaments envelop the nucleus in a cage-like structure during neuronal migration.
text 2: Microtubules envelop the nucleus in a cage-like structure during neuronal migration.

text 1: Gain of reelin severely disrupts the layering of the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Loss of reelin severely disrupts the layering of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Neurons in the inferior temporal cortex of the monkey are involved in face recognition.
text 2: Neurons in the inferior frontal cortex of the monkey are involved in face recognition.

text 1: Prosopagnosia is an example of category-specific dyslexia.
text 2: Prosopagnosia is an example of category-specific agnosia.

text 1: Columns of neurons representing the same stimulus properties do not extend throughout the cortical thickness.
text 2: Columns of neurons representing the same stimulus properties extend throughout the cortical thickness.

text 1: Kanwisher found that the fusiform face area responded significantly more to faces compared to other objects.
text 2: Kanwisher found that the fusiform face area responded equally to faces and other objects.

text 1: Face-selective areas are primarily located in the temporal and prefrontal cortices.
text 2: Face-selective areas are primarily located in the occipital and parietal cortices.

text 1: Several small subpopulations of neurons are activated by objects and landscapes.
text 2: Several small subpopulations of neurons are activated by faces and hands.

text 1: Nancy Kanwisher used X-ray technology to discover face-selective regions in the human brain.
text 2: Nancy Kanwisher used functional magnetic resonance imaging to discover face-selective regions in the human brain.

text 1: Face patches found in macaque monkeys respond more selectively to landscapes than to faces.
text 2: Face patches found in macaque monkeys respond more selectively to faces than to other objects.

text 1: Inferior temporal cortex neurons are organized in randomly disconnected units.
text 2: Inferior temporal cortex neurons are organized in functionally specialized columns.

text 1: Peristimulus time histograms illustrate the frequency of blood flow in response to different images.
text 2: Peristimulus time histograms illustrate the frequency of action potentials in response to different images.

text 1: Face recognition cells in the inferior temporal cortex do not respond to specific faces or expressions.
text 2: Face recognition cells in the inferior temporal cortex respond to specific faces and expressions.

text 1: The fusiform face area is located in the human temporal lobe.
text 2: The fusiform face area is located in the human parietal lobe.

text 1: Horizontal connections can facilitate the formation of distributed networks for encoding objects.
text 2: Horizontal connections inhibit the formation of distributed networks for encoding objects.

text 1: Cells with unique selectivities in the inferior temporal cortex provide inputs to higher-order neurons.
text 2: Cells with unique selectivities in the inferior temporal cortex avoid inputs to higher-order neurons.

text 1: Charles Gross discovered small subpopulations of neurons activated by abstract concepts.
text 2: Charles Gross discovered small subpopulations of neurons activated by meaningful objects.

text 1: Gamma motor neurons innervate the contractile polar regions of the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles.
text 2: Gamma motor neurons innervate the non-contractile central regions of the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles.

text 1: Each Golgi tendon organ is innervated by multiple Ib axons that do not branch inside the capsule.
text 2: Each Golgi tendon organ is innervated by a single Ib axon that branches into many fine endings inside the capsule.

text 1: The flexion-withdrawal reflex exclusively activates monosynaptic reflex pathways that only result in contraction of extensor muscles.
text 2: The flexion-withdrawal reflex activates polysynaptic reflex pathways that often result in a coordinated contraction of flexor muscles.

text 1: Stimulation of Golgi tendon organs provides precise information exclusively about muscle length.
text 2: Stimulation of Golgi tendon organs can provide precise information about a muscle's contraction state.

text 1: Type II sensory fibers have a slower conduction velocity and signal relay through interneurons, leading to more variable and delayed muscular responses.
text 2: Type II sensory fibers have a faster conduction velocity and direct monosynaptic connections, leading to rapid muscular responses.

text 1: Golgi tendon organs are most sensitive to changes in muscle length.
text 2: Golgi tendon organs are most sensitive to changes in muscle tension.

text 1: Golgi tendon organs do not participate in feedback regarding muscle tension.
text 2: Golgi tendon organs assist in the complex regulation of movement by providing feedback on muscle tension.

text 1: Flexion-withdrawal is a protective reflex that persists after complete transection of the spinal cord.
text 2: Flexion-withdrawal disappears after complete transection of the spinal cord.

text 1: Golgi tendon organs were once thought to have a purely protective function.
text 2: Golgi tendon organs were never assumed to have any protective function.

text 1: The firing frequency of Ib axons in tendon organs serves as an index of force in a contracting muscle.
text 2: The firing frequency of Ia axons in tendon organs serves as an index of force in a contracting muscle.

text 1: Ib fibers from tendon organs form widespread connections with motor neurons that affect muscles at different joints.
text 2: Ib fibers from tendon organs form connections exclusively with motor neurons of the same muscle.

text 1: The musculoskeletal responses elicited by group II fibers are faster than the monosynaptic stretch reflex.
text 2: The musculoskeletal responses elicited by group II fibers are delayed compared to the monosynaptic stretch reflex.

text 1: Dynamic gamma motor neurons are activated during rapid and unpredictable changes in muscle length.
text 2: Static gamma motor neurons are activated during rapid and unpredictable changes in muscle length.

text 1: Golgi tendon organs primarily signal coarse changes in muscle tension, lacking precision.
text 2: Golgi tendon organs signal minute changes in muscle tension, providing precise information to the nervous system.

text 1: Flexion reflexes are entirely independent of stimulus intensity in determining the extent and force of muscle contraction.
text 2: Flexion reflexes depend on stimulus intensity to determine the extent and force of muscle contraction.

text 1: The cerebellum constitutes only 20% of the total volume of the brain and contains less than one-third of its neurons.
text 2: The cerebellum constitutes only 10% of the total volume of the brain but contains more than one-half of its neurons.

text 1: The cerebellum acts in response to sensory feedback arising from movement, providing feedback control of muscular contractions.
text 2: The cerebellum acts in advance of sensory feedback arising from movement, thus providing feedforward control of muscular contractions.

text 1: Patients with cerebellar damage often have slurred speech with irregular timing, known as dysarthria.
text 2: Patients with cerebellar damage often have perfectly clear and regularly timed speech, without any signs of dysarthria.

text 1: The most prominent symptom of cerebellar disorders is ataxia, or lack of coordination of movement.
text 2: The most prominent symptom of cerebellar disorders is hypercoordination, or excessive coordination of movement.

text 1: The cerebellum contributes to feedforward sensorimotor control.
text 2: The cerebellum contributes solely to feedback sensorimotor control.

text 1: People with cerebellar disorders make movements that qualitatively appear jerky, irregular, and highly variable.
text 2: People with cerebellar disorders make movements that are smooth, regular, and highly predictable.

text 1: The cerebellar cortex is organized into three functionally specialized layers.
text 2: The cerebellar cortex is organized into six functionally specialized layers.

text 1: Ataxia is a specific term used for identifying muscle strength in individuals with cerebellar damage.
text 2: Ataxia is a generic term used to describe the collective motor features associated with cerebellar damage.

text 1: The cerebellum rejects the concept of an internal model of the motor apparatus.
text 2: The cerebellum incorporates an internal model of the motor apparatus.

text 1: Patients with cerebellar damage exhibit increased resistance to passive limb displacements known as hypertonia.
text 2: Patients with cerebellar damage exhibit reduced resistance to passive limb displacements called hypotonia.

text 1: Climbing-fiber activity changes the synaptic efficacy of parallel fibers.
text 2: Climbing-fiber activity has no effect on the synaptic efficacy of parallel fibers.

text 1: The cerebellar microcircuit architecture suggests a canonical computation.
text 2: The cerebellar microcircuit architecture suggests no form of computation.

text 1: The cerebellum is hypothesized to perform several general computational functions.
text 2: The cerebellum is hypothesized to perform no computational functions.

text 1: The cerebellum participates in motor skill learning.
text 2: The cerebellum is not involved in motor skill learning.

text 1: Different movements are controlled by functional lateral zones in the cerebellum.
text 2: Different movements are controlled by functional longitudinal zones in the cerebellum.

text 1: The Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells lie in the deep layers of the skin below the subcutaneous layer, 2.0 to 3.0 mm below the skin surface.
text 2: The Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells lie in the superficial layers of the skin at the base of the epidermis, 0.5 to 1.0 mm below the skin surface.

text 1: RA2 fibers innervate Pacinian corpuscles without branching.
text 2: RA2 fibers innervate multiple sensory receptors by branching multiple times.

text 1: Receptive fields on the fingertips are the smallest on the body, averaging 11 mm2 for SA1 fibers and 25 mm2 for RA1 fibers.
text 2: Receptive fields on the fingertips are the largest on the body, averaging 50 mm2 for SA1 fibers and 75 mm2 for RA1 fibers.

text 1: The SA2 fibers innervate Ruffini endings concentrated at the finger and wrist joints.
text 2: The SA2 fibers innervate Ruffini endings concentrated at the elbow and shoulder joints.

text 1: Pacinian corpuscles are small spherical structures that mainly detect slow, steady pressure.
text 2: Pacinian corpuscles are large onion-like structures facilitating high-frequency vibration detection.

text 1: Each ridge is bordered by epidermal folds called limiting ridges which increase the stiffness and rigidity of the skin.
text 2: Each ridge is bordered by dermal folds called tightening ridges which soothe the skin.

text 1: Merkel cells are densely clustered in the center of each papillary ridge, at the base of the intermediate ridge surrounding the epidermal sweat ducts.
text 2: Merkel cells are scattered randomly across the layers of skin with no specific clustering.

text 1: The threshold for tactile acuity on the fingertips of young adults is approximately 5 mm.
text 2: The threshold for tactile acuity on the fingertips of young adults is approximately 1 mm.

text 1: Frictional forces are reduced when fingerprint ridges contact textured surfaces.
text 2: Frictional forces are augmented when fingerprint ridges contact textured surfaces.

text 1: Tactile acuity is highest on the fingertips and the lips, where receptive fields are smallest.
text 2: Tactile acuity is highest on the back and the thighs, where receptive fields are largest.

text 1: Fingerprints increase the friction allowing us to grasp objects without slippage.
text 2: Fingerprints decrease friction making it difficult to grasp objects.

text 1: Irregular spacing of papillary ridges disrupts spatial alignment of surface features during scanning.
text 2: The regular spacing of papillary ridges allows constant spatial alignment of surface features during scanning.

text 1: Each Pacinian corpuscle receives a single RA2 axon.
text 2: Each Pacinian corpuscle receives multiple RA2 axons.

text 1: The capsule of the Pacinian corpuscle amplifies high-frequency vibration.
text 2: The capsule of the Pacinian corpuscle dampens high-frequency vibration.

text 1: Roland Johansson and Andrew Pruszynski found RA1 and SA1 fibers respond less intensely to edges contacting multiple sensory terminals.
text 2: Roland Johansson and Andrew Pruszynski found RA1 and SA1 fibers respond more intensely to edges contacting multiple sensory terminals.

text 1: James Papez proposed that sensory information from the cerebral cortex is sent to both the thalamus and the hypothalamus.
text 2: James Papez proposed that sensory information from the thalamus is sent to both the hypothalamus and the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The Papez circuit includes the hypothalamus, anterior thalamus, and cingulate cortex.
text 2: The Papez circuit includes the hypothalamus, posterior thalamus, and hippocampus.

text 1: The thalamus is involved in organizing emotional reactions.
text 2: The hypothalamus is involved in organizing emotional reactions.

text 1: MacLean believed that emotional responses are essential for survival.
text 2: MacLean believed that emotional responses were irrelevant for survival.

text 1: The Klüver-Bucy syndrome indicates the amygdala might be important for emotion.
text 2: The Klüver-Bucy syndrome indicates the hippocampus might be important for emotion.

text 1: The hippocampus is involved in learned fear.
text 2: The amygdala is involved in learned fear.

text 1: Walter B. Cannon proposed the hypothalamus might be key in controlling fight-or-flight responses.
text 2: Walter B. Cannon proposed the thalamus might be key in controlling fight-or-flight responses.

text 1: Phillip Bard was a colleague of Walter Cannon.
text 2: Phillip Bard was a student of Walter Cannon.

text 1: The limbic system was initially called the visceral brain.
text 2: The limbic system was initially called the peripheral brain.

text 1: The cerebellum received significant attention in emotion studies.
text 2: The amygdala received significant attention in emotion studies.

text 1: James Papez expanded the Cannon-Bard theory.
text 2: James Papez replaced the Cannon-Bard theory.

text 1: Cryogenetics is used in studies involving the hypothalamus and emotion.
text 2: Optogenetics is used in studies involving the hypothalamus and emotion.

text 1: MacLean noted that emotions are processed by many sub-cortical and cortical regions.
text 2: MacLean noted that emotions are processed only by the limbic system.

text 1: The hippocampus is associated only with emotional response.
text 2: The hippocampus is associated with both emotional response and memory.

text 1: Cannon called hypothalamically mediated reactions 'sham rage'.
text 2: Cannon called hypothalamically mediated reactions 'true rage'.

text 1: The great majority of sensory axons in the cochlea carry signals from inner hair cells.
text 2: The great majority of sensory axons in the cochlea carry signals from outer hair cells.

text 1: Efferent axons largely innervate the outer hair cells and do so directly.
text 2: Efferent axons largely innervate the inner hair cells and do so directly.

text 1: Relatively few cochlear ganglion cells contact outer hair cells, and each such neuron extends branching terminals to numerous outer hair cells.
text 2: A majority of cochlear ganglion cells contact outer hair cells, and each such neuron extends branching terminals to numerous inner hair cells.

text 1: Mature inner hair cells do not receive efferent input.
text 2: Mature inner hair cells receive extensive efferent input.

text 1: The relationship between sound level in decibels SPL and firing rate in each fiber of the cochlear nerve is non-linear.
text 2: The relationship between sound level in decibels SPL and firing rate in each fiber of the cochlear nerve is approximately linear.

text 1: The number of implanted cochlear prostheses worldwide is now approaching 3,500,000.
text 2: The number of implanted cochlear prostheses worldwide is now approaching 350,000.

text 1: Cochlear prosthesis effectiveness is uniform across all individuals.
text 2: Cochlear prosthesis effectiveness varies widely from person to person.

text 1: Input–output transformations occur in the trisynaptic circuitry of the mammalian hippocampus, proceeding from the dentate gyrus input region, to the CA3 area, and to the CA1 output region.
text 2: Input–output transformations occur in the trisynaptic circuitry of the mammalian hippocampus, proceeding from the CA1 output region, to the CA3 area, and to the dentate gyrus input region.

text 1: Sharp-wave ripples are prominent during active exploration rather than resting periods.
text 2: Sharp-wave ripples are prominent during resting periods after recent exploration of an environment.

text 1: Place cells recorded in the hippocampal CA1 region provide more complete spatial coverage when entire populations are analyzed.
text 2: Place cells recorded in the hippocampal CA1 region provide less complete spatial coverage when entire populations are analyzed.

text 1: Replayed sequences within sharp-wave ripples occur at the same speed as during exploration.
text 2: Replayed sequences within sharp-wave ripples are time compressed, occurring about 10 to 20 times faster than during exploration.

text 1: O'Keefe initially postulated the idea of a cognitive map in the hippocampus.
text 2: Edward Tolman initially postulated the idea of a cognitive map in the hippocampus.

text 1: Theta waves are present during exploration and large negative sharp waves during immobility.
text 2: Large negative sharp waves are present during exploration and theta waves during immobility.

text 1: Place cell sequences experienced during behavior are replayed in both forward and reverse directions during sharp-wave ripples.
text 2: Place cell sequences experienced during behavior never replay in reverse direction during sharp-wave ripples.

text 1: Smaller numbers of presynaptic neurons connect to larger numbers in convergent connections.
text 2: Larger numbers of presynaptic neurons connect to smaller numbers in convergent connections.

text 1: Population coding features have restricted the development of new computational analyses.
text 2: Population coding features have paved the way for new and powerful computational analyses.

text 1: During immobile or resting behavior, the hippocampus enters a regime dominated by discrete semi-synchronous population bursts termed sharp-wave ripples.
text 2: During active exploration, the hippocampus enters a regime dominated by discrete semi-synchronous population bursts termed sharp-wave ripples.

text 1: Recurrent connections involve synaptic connections in a single direction between neurons.
text 2: Recurrent connections involve synaptic connections in multiple directions between neurons.

text 1: Sharp-wave ripples are thought to be internally generated by circuitry within the hippocampus.
text 2: Sharp-wave ripples are externally induced by stimuli outside the hippocampus.

text 1: Feedforward circuits process information from a more primary area toward a higher area with more complex response properties.
text 2: Feedforward circuits process information from a higher area toward a more primary area with simpler response properties.

text 1: Electrophysiological methods available to O’Keefe in 1971 were capable of recording thousands of place cells simultaneously.
text 2: Electrophysiological methods available to O’Keefe in 1971 were limited to recording one place cell at a time.

text 1: Neurons tend to be highly interconnected, both with nearby neurons and with neurons in distal brain areas.
text 2: Neurons tend to be isolated and have limited interconnections with nearby neurons and neurons in distal brain areas.

text 1: Unlike natural rewards, addictive drugs cause dopamine release in the reward circuitry even when the drug no longer produces subjective pleasure.
text 2: Unlike addictive drugs, natural rewards cause dopamine release in the reward circuitry even when they no longer produce subjective pleasure.

text 1: Animals will work to deliver electrical current into parts of the brain’s reward circuitry, and drugs of abuse reduce the stimulation threshold for such self-stimulation.
text 2: Animals will work to avoid electrical current into parts of the brain’s reward circuitry, and drugs of abuse increase the stimulation threshold for such self-stimulation.

text 1: Reserpine and tetrabenazine interfere with the transport of norepinephrine (NE), dopamine, and serotonin into synaptic vesicles by blocking the vesicular monoamine transporter VMAT2.
text 2: Reserpine and tetrabenazine enhance the transport of norepinephrine (NE), dopamine, and serotonin into synaptic vesicles by activating the vesicular monoamine transporter VMAT2.

text 1: The hallucinogen lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is an antagonist at 5-HT2A receptors on postsynaptic serotoninergic neurons.
text 2: The hallucinogen lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a partial agonist at 5-HT2A receptors on postsynaptic serotoninergic neurons.

text 1: Phenelzine and tranylcypromine block MAO-A and MAO-B, effective for depression and panic disorder.
text 2: Phenelzine and tranylcypromine block COMT, effective for depression and panic disorder.

text 1: Exposure therapy produces extinction learning by erasing the memory of the phobic stimulus.
text 2: Exposure therapy produces extinction learning by suppressing the fearful response through new information that the stimulus is not dangerous.

text 1: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is ineffective for the treatment of serious major depressive disorder.
text 2: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is highly effective for the treatment of serious major depressive disorder.

text 1: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is used in wide use for treatment of Parkinson disease and essential tremor.
text 2: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders.

text 1: The rostral anterior cingulate cortex is activated by sadness and has been used as a DBS target for treatment-resistant depression.
text 2: The rostral anterior cingulate cortex is activated by happiness and has been used as a DBS target for treatment-resistant depression.

text 1: Ondansetron is an agonist at 5-HT3 receptors, the only ligand-gated channel among the monoamine receptors.
text 2: Ondansetron is an antagonist at 5-HT3 receptors, the only ligand-gated channel among the monoamine receptors.

text 1: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) induces currents to flow within axons in regions of the cerebral cortex above the device.
text 2: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) induces currents to flow within axons in regions of the cerebral cortex beneath the device.

text 1: Tricyclic drugs, such as clomipramine, have mixed actions with relative selectivity for the serotonin transporter.
text 2: Tricyclic drugs, such as clomipramine, are selectively blocking only the norepinephrine transporter.

text 1: Clonidine is an antagonist at α2-adrenergic receptors, promoting NE release.
text 2: Clonidine is an agonist at α2-adrenergic receptors, inhibiting NE release.

text 1: Risperidone and olanzapine are antagonists at 5-HT2A receptors and block D2 dopamine receptors.
text 2: Risperidone and olanzapine are agonists at 5-HT2A receptors and block D2 dopamine receptors.

text 1: Moclobemide is selective for MAO-A and is effective against depression.
text 2: Moclobemide is selective for MAO-B and is effective against depression.

text 1: Tropolone inhibits MAO, which inactivates NE at postsynaptic neurons.
text 2: Tropolone inhibits COMT, which inactivates NE at postsynaptic neurons.

text 1: Propranolol is an agonist at β-adrenergic receptors that blocks many effects of the sympathetic nervous system.
text 2: Propranolol is an antagonist at β-adrenergic receptors that blocks many effects of the sympathetic nervous system.

text 1: Neurons have receptive dendrites at one end and a transmitting axon at the other, facilitating unidirectional neuronal signaling.
text 2: Neurons have receptive axons at one end and transmitting dendrites at the other, facilitating unidirectional neuronal signaling.

text 1: The cell membrane of neurons contains specialized proteins—ion channels and receptors—that facilitate the flow of specific inorganic ions.
text 2: The cell membrane of neurons contains specialized proteins—ion channels and receptors—which inhibit the flow of specific inorganic ions.

text 1: Glial cells play roles like forming insulating sheaths for axons and regulating neuronal function.
text 2: Glial cells exclusively form insulating sheaths for axons without any role in regulating neuronal function.

text 1: Oligodendrocytes provide myelin sheaths for axons in the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Oligodendrocytes provide myelin sheaths for axons in the central nervous system.

text 1: Schwann cells myelinate axons in the peripheral nervous system and promote repair at the neuromuscular synapse.
text 2: Schwann cells myelinate axons in the central nervous system and promote repair at the neuromuscular synapse.

text 1: Astrocytes are star-shaped glial cells in the peripheral nervous system that play a role in maintaining the blood-brain barrier.
text 2: Astrocytes are star-shaped glial cells in the central nervous system that play a role in maintaining the blood-brain barrier.

text 1: In the white matter, oligodendrocytes can wrap their membranous processes around a single axon.
text 2: In the white matter, oligodendrocytes can wrap their membranous processes around multiple axons.

text 1: Microglia have no homeostatic functions in the healthy brain and act only as resident immune cells.
text 2: Microglia have homeostatic functions in the healthy brain and act as resident immune cells.

text 1: Schwann cells form myelin sheaths approximately 1 mm long between nodes of Ranvier.
text 2: Schwann cells form myelin sheaths approximately 10 mm long between nodes of Ranvier.

text 1: Astrocytes support synaptic signaling but do not have nutritive functions.
text 2: Astrocytes support synaptic signaling and have nutritive functions via their end-feet in contact with capillaries.

text 1: In the peripheral nervous system, Schwann cells only myelinate axons and play no role in developmental processes.
text 2: In the peripheral nervous system, Schwann cells have roles beyond myelination, including promoting development and repair at the neuromuscular synapse.

text 1: Mitochondria generate ATP and play roles in calcium homeostasis and lipid biogenesis.
text 2: Mitochondria generate ATP but are not involved in calcium homeostasis or lipid biogenesis.

text 1: The vacuolar apparatus is anatomically and functionally disconnected.
text 2: The vacuolar apparatus is functionally connected via transport vesicles that move membranous and lumenal material.

text 1: Peroxisomes prevent the accumulation of hydrogen peroxide, a strong oxidizing agent.
text 2: Peroxisomes promote the accumulation of hydrogen peroxide, a strong oxidizing agent.

text 1: The cytoplasm consists of cytosol and membranous organelles, including mitochondria and peroxisomes.
text 2: The cytoplasm consists only of membranous organelles, excluding cytosol.

text 1: The cerebellum is necessary for motor learning in several different movement systems, ranging from limb and eye movements to walking.
text 2: The cerebellum is not necessary for motor learning in several different movement systems, including limb and eye movements.

text 1: Adaptation of limb movements requiring eye–hand coordination cannot be demonstrated using prism goggles that deflect light paths sideways.
text 2: Adaptation of limb movements requiring eye–hand coordination can be demonstrated using prism goggles that deflect light paths sideways.

text 1: Patients with damaged cerebellar cortex or inferior olive are severely impaired or unable to adapt in the prism goggles test.
text 2: Patients with damaged cerebellar cortex or inferior olive can easily adapt in the prism goggles test.

text 1: Classical conditioning of the eye-blink response depends on an intact cerebellum.
text 2: Classical conditioning of the eye-blink response does not depend on the cerebellum.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex helps keep images stable on the retina by initiating eye movements opposite to the direction of head rotation.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex causes images to slip across the retina during head rotation by initiating eye movements in the same direction as head rotation.

text 1: The baseline vestibulo-ocular reflex does not depend heavily on the cerebellum, but its adaptation does.
text 2: The baseline vestibulo-ocular reflex heavily depends on the cerebellum, unlike its adaptation.

text 1: Lesions in the lateral part of the vestibulocerebellum, known as the floccular complex, enhance adaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
text 2: Lesions in the lateral part of the vestibulocerebellum, known as the floccular complex, can block adaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

text 1: Saccadic eye movements are independent of the condition of Purkinje cells in the oculomotor vermis.
text 2: Saccadic eye movements depend on the integrity of Purkinje cells in the oculomotor vermis.

text 1: Lesions of the vermis cause saccades to become hypometric, unlike arm movements in cerebellar patients.
text 2: Lesions of the vermis cause saccades to become hypermetric, similar to arm movements in cerebellar patients.

text 1: Recordings during saccadic adaptation do not involve climbing fiber inputs to Purkinje cells signaling saccadic errors during learning.
text 2: Recordings during saccadic adaptation show climbing fiber inputs to Purkinje cells signaling saccadic errors during learning.

text 1: Patients with unilateral infarctions in the territory of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery fail in adaptation tests involving prism goggles.
text 2: Patients with unilateral infarctions in the territory of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery excel in adaptation tests involving prism goggles.

text 1: Motor learning allows improved feedforward control of movements, reducing dependence on sensory feedback after adaptation.
text 2: Motor learning relies entirely on sensory feedback and does not aim to establish feedforward control of movements.

text 1: Cerebellar learning enhances flawed parallel-fiber inputs conveying erroneous central commands.
text 2: A key feature of cerebellar learning is the suppression of flawed parallel-fiber inputs conveying erroneous central commands.

text 1: Adaptation of motor learning persists even after prisms are removed, causing an overcompensation in dart throws.
text 2: Adaptation of motor learning ceases immediately after prisms are removed, causing no residual effect on dart throws.

text 1: Saccadic adaptation decreases the amplitude of initial saccades to match a target’s new location after several trials.
text 2: Saccadic adaptation increases the amplitude of initial saccades to match a target’s new location after several trials.

text 1: The left and right horizontal semicircular canals work together to signal head movement.
text 2: The left and right horizontal semicircular canals work independently to signal head movement.

text 1: The receptors in the left horizontal semicircular canal excite when the head turns to the left, whereas the right horizontal canal receptors inhibit.
text 2: The receptors in the left horizontal semicircular canal inhibit when the head turns to the left, whereas the right horizontal canal receptors excite.

text 1: The human utricle contains approximately 30,000 hair cells, whereas the saccule contains some 16,000.
text 2: The human utricle contains approximately 16,000 hair cells, whereas the saccule contains some 30,000.

text 1: Otolithic membranes are covered with fine, dense particles of calcium carbonate called otoconia.
text 2: Otolithic membranes are covered with fine, dense particles of calcium sulfate called otoconia.

text 1: The saccular maculae are oriented horizontally in nearly parasagittal planes.
text 2: The saccular maculae are oriented vertically in nearly parasagittal planes.

text 1: The vestibular nerve projects ipsilaterally to four vestibular nuclei in the dorsal part of the pons and medulla.
text 2: The vestibular nerve projects contralaterally to four vestibular nuclei in the dorsal part of the pons and medulla.

text 1: The lateral vestibular nucleus (Deiters’ nucleus) receives fibers from the otolith organs medially and the semicircular canals laterally.
text 2: The lateral vestibular nucleus (Deiters’ nucleus) receives fibers from the semicircular canals medially and the otolith organs laterally.

text 1: Vestibular projections to the spinal systems include only excitatory projections using neurotransmitters like glutamate and dopamine.
text 2: Vestibular projections to the spinal systems include both excitatory and inhibitory projections using neurotransmitters like glutamate and GABA.

text 1: Many vestibular nuclei neurons receive motion information from the opposite ear through an excitatory commissural pathway using GABA.
text 2: Many vestibular nuclei neurons receive motion information from the opposite ear through an inhibitory commissural pathway using GABA.

text 1: The macula of each utricle is raised above the naso-occipital axis by approximately 30°.
text 2: The macula of each utricle is raised above the naso-occipital axis by approximately 45°.

text 1: The vestibular system compensates only for head rotations, not linear motion.
text 2: The vestibular system compensates for both head rotations and linear motion.

text 1: When the head is tilted in the direction of a hair cell’s axis of polarity, the cell inhibits the afferent fiber by hyperpolarizing.
text 2: When the head is tilted in the direction of a hair cell’s axis of polarity, the cell excites the afferent fiber by depolarizing.

text 1: The directional polarity of each hair cell is organized relative to a reversal region in the utricle called the otoconia.
text 2: The directional polarity of each hair cell is organized relative to a reversal region in the utricle called the striola.

text 1: Tilt in any direction hyperpolarizes all cells in the utricle.
text 2: Tilt in any direction depolarizes some cells and hyperpolarizes others in the utricle.

text 1: Many vestibular nuclei neurons have reciprocal connections with the cerebellum, primarily in the frontal lobe.
text 2: Many vestibular nuclei neurons have reciprocal connections with the cerebellum, primarily in the floculo-nodular lobe.

text 1: Nav1.4 channels in skeletal muscle fibers and Nav1.5 channels in cardiac muscle conduct the voltage-gated Na+ current that generates action potentials in these tissues.
text 2: Nav1.4 channels in cardiac muscle fibers and Nav1.5 channels in skeletal muscle conduct the voltage-gated Na+ current that generates action potentials in these tissues.

text 1: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels give rise to an outward current that helps hyperpolarize the cell.
text 2: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels give rise to an inward current that helps depolarize the cell.

text 1: Kv1 channels are formed exclusively by homomeric combinations of gene products.
text 2: Kv1 channels can be formed by heteromeric combinations of at least five different gene products.

text 1: Kv3 channels require small depolarizations and are activated early in the rising phase of an action potential.
text 2: Kv3 channels require large depolarizations and are activated late in the rising phase of an action potential.

text 1: Cav1 and Cav2 family channels are known as low-voltage activated (LVA) Ca2+ channels.
text 2: Cav1 and Cav2 family channels are known as high-voltage activated (HVA) Ca2+ channels.

text 1: Nav1.8 channels are largely restricted to a subset of peripheral sensory neurons, with prominent expression in pain-sensing primary sensory neurons.
text 2: Nav1.8 channels are widely expressed in central neurons, with prominent expression throughout the brain.

text 1: T-type Ca2+ channels are opened by large depolarizations as positive as +10 mV.
text 2: T-type Ca2+ channels are opened by small depolarizations as negative as −65 mV.

text 1: A-type K+ current remains constantly active during all depolarizations without inactivation.
text 2: A-type K+ current inactivates during large depolarizations but is also subject to steady-state inactivation by small depolarizations.

text 1: Kv7 channels are upregulated by acetylcholine acting through muscarinic G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: Kv7 channels are downregulated by acetylcholine acting through muscarinic G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: The S6 membrane-spanning α-helix is labeled in red in the basic transmembrane topology of a voltage-gated K+ channel α-subunit.
text 2: The S4 membrane-spanning α-helix is labeled in red in the basic transmembrane topology of a voltage-gated K+ channel α-subunit.

text 1: Kv3 channels have slow kinetics of activation, preventing them from playing a role in action potential termination.
text 2: Kv3 channels have rapid kinetics of activation, allowing them to help terminate action potentials.

text 1: Cyclic nucleotide-activated cation channels include subclasses that do not show high discrimination between Na+ and K+.
text 2: Cyclic nucleotide-activated cation channels show high discrimination between Na+ and K+.

text 1: Nav1.1 channels are strongly expressed in inhibitory GABAergic interneurons.
text 2: Nav1.1 channels are strongly expressed in excitatory glutamatergic neurons.

text 1: Cav3 family members are low-voltage activated and typically inactivated at normal resting potentials.
text 2: Cav3 family members are high-voltage activated and remain active at normal resting potentials.

text 1: Inward-rectifying K+ channels are formed from a truncated version of the basic building block with only two membrane-spanning regions.
text 2: Inward-rectifying K+ channels are formed from a full version of the basic building block with four membrane-spanning regions.

text 1: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System and has a strong magnetic field.
text 2: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Milky Way and has a strong magnetic field.

text 1: Jupiter primarily consists of hydrogen and helium.
text 2: Jupiter primarily consists of hydrogen and carbon.

text 1: Surface electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings unambiguously indicate the polarity of synaptic events.
text 2: Surface electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings do not unambiguously indicate the polarity of synaptic events.

text 1: A thalamocortical excitatory signal in layer V causes a downward voltage deflection at the surface EEG electrode.
text 2: A thalamocortical excitatory signal in layer V causes an upward voltage deflection at the surface EEG electrode.

text 1: The focal abnormality may indicate that the seizure focus in this patient is in the right temporal lobe.
text 2: The focal abnormality may indicate that the seizure focus in this patient is in the left temporal lobe.

text 1: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift (PDS) is largely dependent on cholinergic and NMDA-type glutamate receptor-channels.
text 2: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift (PDS) is largely dependent on AMPA- and NMDA-type glutamate receptor-channels.

text 1: Focal onset seizures originate within a small group of neurons.
text 2: Focal onset seizures originate within a large group of neurons.

text 1: The interictal period is followed by synchronization of activity within the seizure focus.
text 2: The interictal period is followed immediately by a secondary generalization phase.

text 1: In the cerebral cortex, excitatory axons from the contralateral hemisphere terminate primarily on dendrites in layers II and III.
text 2: In the cerebral cortex, excitatory axons from the contralateral hemisphere terminate primarily on dendrites in layer IV.

text 1: New recording and analytical methods such as X-rays are used to detect abnormal zones of synchrony within a seizure focus.
text 2: New recording and analytical methods such as spectral analysis of the EEG are used to detect abnormal zones of synchrony within a seizure focus.

text 1: Neurons in a seizure focus have normal bursting activity.
text 2: Neurons in a seizure focus have abnormal bursting activity.

text 1: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift is a depolarization that is sudden, large, and long-lasting.
text 2: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift is a depolarization that is gradual, large, and short-lasting.

text 1: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift can be viewed as a massive decrease of depolarizing and hyperpolarizing synaptic components.
text 2: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift can be viewed as a massive enhancement of depolarizing and hyperpolarizing synaptic components.

text 1: Benzodiazepines block inhibition and are used in the emergency treatment of prolonged repetitive seizures.
text 2: Benzodiazepines enhance GABAA-mediated inhibition and are used in the emergency treatment of prolonged repetitive seizures.

text 1: Focal onset seizures are characterized by the enhanced excitability of a small group of neurons.
text 2: Focal onset seizures are characterized by the reduced excitability of a small group of neurons.

text 1: The brain stem and spinal cord are sites of integration of sensory inputs, perhaps generating the internal model of body orientation and balance.
text 2: The brain stem and cerebellum are sites of integration of sensory inputs, perhaps generating the internal model of body orientation and balance.

text 1: Lesions of the brain stem and vestibulocerebellum produce a variety of deficits in head and trunk control including a tendency to tilt from vertical, even with eyes open.
text 2: Lesions of the brain stem and spinocerebellum produce a variety of deficits in head and trunk control including a tendency to tilt from vertical, even with eyes open.

text 1: The spinocerebellum has a role in adapting postural responses to changing conditions and in scaling postural responses to anticipated postural disturbances.
text 2: The vestibulocerebellum has a role in adapting postural responses to changing conditions and in scaling postural responses to anticipated postural disturbances.

text 1: Patients with spinocerebellar disorders have difficulty modifying the magnitude of balance adjustments with practice, over the course of repeated trials.
text 2: Patients with vestibular disorders have difficulty modifying the magnitude of balance adjustments with practice, over the course of repeated trials.

text 1: Individuals with spinocerebellar disease often overrespond to postural disturbances, although the timing of muscle activation is normal.
text 2: Individuals with vestibular disease often overrespond to postural disturbances, although the timing of muscle activation is normal.

text 1: A patient with cerebellar damage employs the same muscle activation pattern for both sitting and standing initially.
text 2: A patient with Parkinson disease employs the same muscle activation pattern for both sitting and standing initially.

text 1: The vestibulocerebellum is important for quickly adjusting the postural set when conditions suddenly change.
text 2: The basal ganglia are important for quickly adjusting the postural set when conditions suddenly change.

text 1: The corticoospinal tract has minimal effect on balance even though it produces a profound disturbance of voluntary limb movements.
text 2: The vestibulospinal tract has minimal effect on balance even though it produces a profound disturbance of voluntary limb movements.

text 1: Lesions of the vestibulospinal tracts result in profound ataxia and postural instability.
text 2: Lesions of the corticospinal tracts result in profound ataxia and postural instability.

text 1: The medial and lateral reticulospinal tracts originate from the reticular formation of the pons and medulla.
text 2: The medial and lateral reticulospinal tracts originate from the cortex.

text 1: Patients with cerebellar disorders cannot scale the size of postural responses based on feedforward control using the anticipated amplitude of postural displacements.
text 2: Patients with basal ganglia disorders cannot scale the size of postural responses based on feedforward control using the anticipated amplitude of postural displacements.

text 1: The basal ganglia are interconnected with the vestibular nuclei and reticular formation of the pons and medulla.
text 2: The vestibulocerebellum is interconnected with the vestibular nuclei and reticular formation of the pons and medulla.

text 1: Both the vestibulocerebellum and the basal ganglia regulate muscle tone and force for voluntary postural adjustments.
text 2: Both the spinocerebellum and the basal ganglia regulate muscle tone and force for voluntary postural adjustments.

text 1: Humans with spinal cord injuries have various amounts of antigravity muscle tonus but lack automatic postural responses below the level of the lesion.
text 2: Humans with cerebellar damage have various amounts of antigravity muscle tonus but lack automatic postural responses below the level of the lesion.

text 1: The cerebellum and vestibular system modulate the descending commands to spinal motor centers of the limbs and trunk.
text 2: The brain stem and cerebellum modulate the descending commands to spinal motor centers of the limbs and trunk.

text 1: At an electrical synapse, the synaptic delay is remarkably long due to indirect current passing between neurons.
text 2: At an electrical synapse, the synaptic delay is remarkably short due to direct current passing between neurons.

text 1: Gap-junction channels in neurons are often formed from connexin 36 in mammals.
text 2: Gap-junction channels in neurons are often formed from connexin 21 in mammals.

text 1: The gap between neurons at a gap junction is 20 nm wide, much narrower than the typical extracellular space.
text 2: The gap between neurons at a gap junction is 4 nm wide, much narrower than the typical extracellular space.

text 1: Gap-junction channels have a smaller pore than ion-selective channels, not allowing any organic molecules to pass through.
text 2: Gap-junction channels have a larger pore than ion-selective channels, allowing small organic molecules to pass through.

text 1: Each connexon within a gap-junction channel is composed of six identical subunits called connexins.
text 2: Each connexon within a gap-junction channel is composed of four identical subunits called connexins.

text 1: The pore of gap-junction channels allows inorganic ions and small organic molecules to pass between cells.
text 2: The pore of gap-junction channels only allows large organic molecules to pass, excluding inorganic ions.

text 1: Electrical synapses cannot transmit depolarizing currents, only hyperpolarizing ones.
text 2: Electrical synapses can transmit both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing currents.

text 1: All gap-junction channels lack voltage-dependent gates and conduct current in multiple directions.
text 2: Some gap-junction channels have voltage-dependent gates that conduct current in only one direction.

text 1: A presynaptic action potential with a large hyperpolarizing afterpotential cannot generate any response in the postsynaptic cell at an electrical synapse.
text 2: A presynaptic action potential with a large hyperpolarizing afterpotential can generate a biphasic response in the postsynaptic cell at an electrical synapse.

text 1: Most gap-junction channels open in response to lowered cytoplasmic pH or elevated cytoplasmic Ca2+.
text 2: Most gap-junction channels close in response to lowered cytoplasmic pH or elevated cytoplasmic Ca2+.

text 1: The connexin genes in all tissues are identical and always encode proteins that respond in the same way to modulatory factors.
text 2: The connexin genes in other tissues are different and encode proteins that respond differently to modulatory factors.

text 1: Electrical synapses are designed for slow signal transmission unlike the rapid propagation of electrical signals.
text 2: Electrical synapses are designed for rapid signal transmission similar to the passive propagation of electrical signals.

text 1: Gap-junction channels have a circular outline with a small pore diameter of approximately 0.5 nm.
text 2: Gap-junction channels have a hexagonal outline with a large pore diameter of approximately 1.5 nm.

text 1: Subthreshold currents at electrical synapses cannot initiate any response in the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Subthreshold currents at electrical synapses can initiate postsynaptic depolarization even below action potential threshold.

text 1: Connexin subunits in gap-junction channels are arranged to form a continuous bridge between cells.
text 2: Connexin subunits in gap-junction channels are arranged to prevent direct communication between cells.

text 1: The perinatal surge of testosterone acts largely via aromatization into estrogens to masculinize the brain.
text 2: The perinatal surge of testosterone acts largely via conversion into progesterone to masculinize the brain.

text 1: Sex hormones regulate differentiation and adult function of neural circuits along male- or female-typical lines.
text 2: Sex hormones regulate differentiation and adult function of neural circuits equally without regard to gender.

text 1: INAH3 is significantly larger in women than in men.
text 2: INAH3 is significantly larger in men than in women.

text 1: Sex hormones control sexually dimorphic behaviors in a modular genetic manner.
text 2: Sex hormones control sexually dimorphic behaviors in a comprehensive, single pathway manner.

text 1: The human hypothalamus contains four small, discrete neuronal clusters, INAH1 to INAH4.
text 2: The human hypothalamus contains six small, discrete neuronal clusters, INAH1 to INAH6.

text 1: Sex hormone–regulated genes are expressed in sexually dimorphic patterns different for different brain regions.
text 2: Sex hormone–regulated genes are expressed uniformly across all brain regions without dimorphic patterns.

text 1: Experimental inactivation of sex hormone–regulated genes influences only subsets of sexually dimorphic social interactions.
text 2: Experimental inactivation of sex hormone–regulated genes influences all aspects of social interactions equally.

text 1: The BNST and VMH regulate mating and aggression in the two sexes.
text 2: The BNST and VMH regulate feeding and sleep in the two sexes.

text 1: Sexual dimorphisms have been found exclusively at the level of sensory neurons.
text 2: Sexual dimorphisms have been found at the level of sensory neurons, motor neurons, and intermediary neurons.

text 1: Testosterone signaling largely controls the developmental organizational phase of masculinization.
text 2: Estrogen signaling largely controls the developmental organizational phase of masculinization.

text 1: Experimental removal of sex hormones dramatically alters gene expression in the brain of adult mice.
text 2: Experimental removal of sex hormones has minimal impact on gene expression in the brain of adult mice.

text 1: Male mice lacking androgen receptor exclusively in the nervous system exhibit more intense male-type sexual and aggressive behaviors.
text 2: Male mice lacking androgen receptor exclusively in the nervous system exhibit male-type sexual and aggressive behaviors with diminished intensity.

text 1: Most behaviors are exclusive to one sex and do not reflect sexual dimorphisms in neuronal populations.
text 2: Most behaviors are shared between the sexes and reflect sexual dimorphisms in key neuronal populations.

text 1: Sytl4 mRNA expression is sexually dimorphic in the BNST of adult mice.
text 2: Sytl4 mRNA expression is uniform between males and females in the BNST of adult mice.

text 1: Sex hormones modulate a large array of complex social interactions.
text 2: Sex hormones only impact reproductive interactions without affecting other social behaviors.
