text 1: Neurotransmitter Receptors Become Localized at Peripheral Synapses
text 2: Neurotransmitter Receptors Become Localized at Central Synapses

text 1: Synaptic Organizing Molecules Pattern Central Nerve Terminals
text 2: Synaptic Organizing Molecules Pattern Peripheral Nerve Terminals

text 1: Axons from the spinal trigeminal nucleus descend on the opposite side of the brain stem into the cervical spinal cord, where they cross the midline in the posterior commissure with spinothalamic axons.
text 2: Axons from the spinal trigeminal nucleus descend on the same side of the brain stem into the cervical spinal cord, where they cross the midline in the anterior commissure with spinothalamic axons.

text 1: The principal sensory trigeminal nucleus lies in the mid-pons just lateral to the trigeminal motor nucleus.
text 2: The principal sensory trigeminal nucleus lies in the mid-pons just medial to the trigeminal motor nucleus.

text 1: Special visceral afferents from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue travel to the nucleus of the solitary tract through the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.
text 2: Special visceral afferents from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue travel to the nucleus of the solitary tract through the hypoglossal nerve.

text 1: The vestibular nuclei include four distinct cell groups that relay information to various motor sites in the brain stem, cerebellum, and spinal cord.
text 2: The vestibular nuclei include three distinct cell groups that relay information to various motor sites in the brain stem, cerebellum, and spinal cord.

text 1: The solitary nucleus projects directly to somatic motor neurons in the medulla and spinal cord.
text 2: The solitary nucleus projects directly to parasympathetic and sympathetic preganglionic motor neurons in the medulla and spinal cord.

text 1: The synchronization of neurons in a seizure focus is dependent not only on the intrinsic properties of each individual cell but also on the number and strength of connections between neurons.
text 2: The synchronization of neurons in a seizure focus is solely dependent on the intrinsic properties of each individual cell.

text 1: During the interictal period, the abnormal activity freely spreads beyond the seizure focus.
text 2: During the interictal period, the abnormal activity is confined to the seizure focus by inhibition of the surrounding tissue.

text 1: Vagal nerve stimulation can be activated solely by patient thought without any physical interaction.
text 2: Vagal nerve stimulation can be programmed at regular intervals and activated on demand by placing a magnet over the chest.

text 1: The breakdown of surround inhibition results in the desynchronization of neurons in a seizure focus.
text 2: The breakdown of surround inhibition leads to synchronization of neurons in a seizure focus.

text 1: NMDA-type glutamate receptor activity and GABAergic inhibition can undergo changes dependent on the frequency of firing of the presynaptic neuron.
text 2: NMDA-type glutamate receptor activity is constant and independent of any firing frequency.

text 1: Some patients learn to recognize triggers such as sleep deprivation or stress to avoid seizure occurrence.
text 2: Patients with epilepsy do not recognize any triggers; seizures happen completely at random.

text 1: The inability to predict when a seizure will occur is a debilitating aspect of epilepsy.
text 2: Seizure occurrences are typically predictable and thus not a debilitating aspect of epilepsy.

text 1: Only presynaptic changes in the release of dopamine impact seizure activity.
text 2: Presynaptic changes in the release of GABA or postsynaptic changes in GABA receptors may impact seizure activity.

text 1: Inhibitory circuits in the cerebral cortex have a simple and straightforward morphology and connectivity.
text 2: Inhibitory circuits in the cerebral cortex have complex morphology and connectivity.

text 1: GABAergic interneurons play a crucial role in the inhibitory surround during interictal periods.
text 2: GABAergic interneurons have no role in the inhibitory surround during interictal periods.

text 1: Prolonged firing suppresses action potentials and prevents any form of neural propagation.
text 2: Prolonged firing transmits action potentials to distant sites, potentially triggering backpropagation.

text 1: Feedforward and feedback inhibition does not involve GABAergic inhibitory interneurons.
text 2: Feedforward and feedback inhibition by GABAergic inhibitory interneurons contributes to inhibitory surround.

text 1: Connections between the neocortex and thalamus are irrelevant to seizure propagation.
text 2: Reciprocal connections between the neocortex and thalamus may contribute to seizure propagation.

text 1: Flashing lights can trigger seizures in some patients, showing how repeated excitation affects network excitability.
text 2: Flashing lights are a safe environment for patients with epilepsy, with no effect on network excitability.

text 1: Acute seizure detection is typically done by observing patient's behavior without technological assistance.
text 2: Acute seizure detection often requires EEG monitoring with surface or implanted electrodes.

text 1: Neural activity representing an object disappears while the object is held in working memory.
text 2: Neural activity representing an object is sustained while the object is held in working memory.

text 1: Monkeys were trained to perform a shape match-to-sample task with a brief delay between the sample and the match.
text 2: Monkeys were trained to perform a color match-to-sample task with a brief delay between the sample and the match.

text 1: The occipital lobe is involved in associative visual memories.
text 2: The inferior temporal cortex is involved in associative visual memories.

text 1: A neuron's activity corresponded to the learned associations between stimulus pairs A and B.
text 2: A neuron's activity corresponded to a random selection of stimuli during the pairing task.

text 1: Associative visual memories in the visual cortex are stored without changes in neuronal connectivity.
text 2: Associative visual memories in the visual cortex are stored through changes in functional connectivity between neurons.

text 1: The cerebellum and parietal lobe are essential for the acquisition of associative visual memories.
text 2: The hippocampus and medial temporal lobe are essential for the acquisition of associative visual memories.

text 1: Learning does not alter the stimulus selectivity of neurons in the inferior temporal and perirhinal cortices.
text 2: Learning alters the stimulus selectivity of neurons in the inferior temporal and perirhinal cortices.

text 1: Visual perception is only a product of direct inputs to inferior temporal neurons.
text 2: Visual perception is a product of both direct and indirect inputs to inferior temporal neurons.

text 1: Prefrontal cortex input is necessary for the conscious recall of learned associations.
text 2: Prefrontal cortex input is unnecessary for the conscious recall of learned associations.

text 1: Lesions to the inferior temporal cortex have no effect on object recognition.
text 2: Lesions to the inferior temporal cortex can cause visual agnosia.

text 1: Object recognition relies on the occipital cortex.
text 2: Object recognition relies on the inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: Visual associative memories are implemented without any changes in synaptic strength.
text 2: Visual associative memories are implemented by changes in synaptic strength.

text 1: The hippocampus facilitates reorganization in the inferior temporal cortex necessary for store associative visual memories.
text 2: The hippocampus hinders reorganization in the inferior temporal cortex necessary for storing associative visual memories.

text 1: The prefrontal cortex is uninvolved in maintaining information in working memory during a delayed match-to-sample task.
text 2: The prefrontal cortex helps maintain information in working memory during a delayed match-to-sample task.

text 1: Hebbian plasticity has no role in the reorganization of neuron circuits for visual memories.
text 2: Hebbian plasticity may play a role in the reorganization of neuron circuits for visual memories.

text 1: Group II fibers mediate thermal and noxious stimuli, as well as light touch in hairy skin.
text 2: Group II fibers innervate cutaneous mechanoreceptors that respond to touch.

text 1: The conduction velocity of large myelinated fibers is approximately six times the axon diameter.
text 2: The conduction velocity of large myelinated fibers is approximately three times the axon diameter.

text 1: Unmyelinated group IV cutaneous afferents mediate thermal and noxious stimuli.
text 2: Myelinated group IV cutaneous afferents mediate thermal and noxious stimuli.

text 1: The Aβ wave corresponds to group II fibers that innervate mechanoreceptors mediating touch and proprioception.
text 2: The Aγ wave corresponds to group II fibers that innervate mechanoreceptors mediating touch and proprioception.

text 1: Voltages sufficient to activate unmyelinated C fibers evoke sensations of tingling.
text 2: Voltages sufficient to activate unmyelinated C fibers evoke sensations of burning pain.

text 1: Sensory fibers from muscle are classified according to their conduction velocity.
text 2: Sensory fibers from muscle are classified according to their diameter.

text 1: The unmyelinated fibers conduct at 4 to 5 times the axon diameter.
text 2: The unmyelinated fibers conduct at 1.5 to 2.5 times the axon diameter.

text 1: In the neuropathy characteristic of diabetes, the large-diameter sensory fibers degenerate.
text 2: In the neuropathy characteristic of diabetes, the small-diameter sensory fibers degenerate.

text 1: The first neural signal recorded in the compound action potential occurs in fibers with conduction velocities greater than 90 m/s.
text 2: The first neural signal recorded in the compound action potential occurs in fibers with conduction velocities less than 30 m/s.

text 1: Group III fibers are the largest myelinated muscle afferents.
text 2: Group III fibers are the smallest myelinated muscle afferents.

text 1: Nerves that innervate the skin contain two sets of myelinated fibers: group II and group III.
text 2: Nerves that innervate the skin contain three sets of myelinated fibers: group I, group II, and group III.

text 1: Mechanoreceptors mediate thermal and noxious stimuli.
text 2: Mechanoreceptors mediate touch and proprioception.

text 1: The sensation of the Aα wave is barely perceived by the subject in the region innervated.
text 2: The sensation of the Aα wave is intensely perceived by the subject in the region innervated.

text 1: Action potentials first occur in the smallest axons because they have the lowest electrical resistance.
text 2: Action potentials first occur in the largest axons because they have the lowest electrical resistance.

text 1: Electrical stimuli evoke action potentials first in the smallest axons.
text 2: Electrical stimuli evoke action potentials first in the largest axons.

text 1: The mean firing rate varies as a function of motion strength.
text 2: The mean firing rate remains constant regardless of motion strength.

text 1: Microstimulation in the experiment caused the monkey to decide equally in favor of either direction regardless of the stimulated neurons.
text 2: Microstimulation in the experiment caused the monkey to decide more often in favor of the preferred direction of the simulated neurons.

text 1: Decision-making is instantaneous, and viewing duration does not affect the accuracy of decisions.
text 2: Decision-making normally takes some time, so decisions tend to be more accurate with a longer viewing duration.

text 1: Microstimulation completely alters the total signal that the brain uses to make its decision.
text 2: Microstimulation only changes the total signal that the brain uses to make its decision by a small amount.

text 1: The decision variable arises from the uniformity of firing rates across all direction-selective neurons.
text 2: The decision variable arises from the difference in the mean firing rates from two opposing pools of direction-selective neurons.

text 1: Accumulation of noisy evidence is termed a biased random walk or drift plus diffusion process.
text 2: Accumulation of noisy evidence is termed a linear and constant movement process.

text 1: Silencing induces a bias in choices towards the direction of the silenced neurons in every trial.
text 2: Silencing induces a bias in choices against the direction of the silenced neurons, especially in difficult trials.

text 1: The accumulation of noisy evidence follows a path of consistent steps in only the positive direction.
text 2: The accumulation of noisy evidence follows a path comprising random steps in both positive and negative direction.

text 1: Only a single neuron in the brain represents the entire accumulation of evidence related to decision-making.
text 2: Neurons in several parts of the brain represent the accumulation of evidence related to decision-making.

text 1: The effect of microstimulation is most pronounced when the motion strength is strongest.
text 2: The effect of microstimulation is most pronounced when the motion strength is weakest.

text 1: Neurons in the parietal and prefrontal cortices maintain a constant firing rate irrespective of the accumulation of evidence.
text 2: Neurons in the parietal and prefrontal cortices change their firing rates to represent the accumulation of evidence.

text 1: The perceptual decision is independent of any criterion or evidence.
text 2: The perceptual decision arises from a criterion applied to noisy evidence.

text 1: Without evidence for sufficiency or necessity, a neuroscientist might wrongly conclude that neurons in MT do not affect perceptual decisions.
text 2: With or without evidence, it is impossible for a neuroscientist to conclude anything about neurons in MT affecting perceptual decisions.

text 1: The stopping bounds have no correlation with decision speed or accuracy.
text 2: The stopping bounds explain the relationship between decision speed and accuracy.

text 1: A decision is made when an accumulation reaches an upper stopping bound.
text 2: A decision is made randomly without any consideration of stopping bounds or accumulation.

text 1: In chronic neurogenic diseases, the muscle innervated by a dying motor neuron becomes atrophic and some muscle fibers disappear.
text 2: In chronic neurogenic diseases, the muscle innervated by a healthy motor neuron becomes atrophic and some muscle fibers disappear.

text 1: Fibrillations are spontaneous contractions within multiple muscle fibers and can be recorded with an EMG.
text 2: Fibrillations are spontaneous contractions within single muscle fibers and can be recorded with an EMG.

text 1: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis primarily affects motor neurons and does not affect sensory neurons.
text 2: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis primarily affects sensory neurons and does not affect motor neurons.

text 1: Lower motor neuron disorders cause atrophy, fasciculations, decreased muscle tone, and loss of tendon reflexes.
text 2: Lower motor neuron disorders cause increased muscle tone and overactive tendon reflexes.

text 1: Most cases of ALS involve only the upper motor neurons.
text 2: Most cases of ALS involve both the upper and lower motor neurons.

text 1: In ALS, the symptoms usually start with painless weakness in a single arm or leg.
text 2: In ALS, the symptoms usually start with severe pain in a single arm or leg.

text 1: Progressive bulbar palsy affects muscles innervated by cranial nerves, causing dysarthria and dysphagia.
text 2: Progressive bulbar palsy affects muscles innervated by spinal nerves, causing dysarthria and dysphagia.

text 1: Peripheral neuropathy is first manifested by weakness that is usually proximal.
text 2: Peripheral neuropathy is first manifested by weakness that is usually distal.

text 1: SOD1 encodes the protein copper/zinc cytosolic catalase enzyme.
text 2: SOD1 encodes the protein copper/zinc cytosolic superoxide dismutase.

text 1: Mutations in TDP43 and a few other ALS genes affect RNA homeostasis.
text 2: Mutations in TDP43 and a few other ALS genes affect protein folding.

text 1: The primary symptom of disorders of the neuromuscular junction is weakness.
text 2: The primary symptom of disorders of the neuromuscular junction is severe pain.

text 1: Diseases of peripheral nerves may affect either axons or myelin.
text 2: Diseases of peripheral nerves only affect axons.

text 1: The SMN protein is implicated in trafficking RNA in and out of the nucleus.
text 2: The SMN protein is implicated in trafficking proteins in and out of the nucleus.

text 1: ASOs are administered to alter splicing of the SMN2 gene.
text 2: ASOs are administered to alter translation of the SMN2 gene.

text 1: Fasciculations are often signs of neurogenic diseases and result from involuntary contractions of all muscle fibers in a motor unit.
text 2: Fasciculations are often signs of neurogenic diseases and result from voluntary contractions of all muscle fibers in a motor unit.

text 1: The cerebellum is functionally connected with only a few cerebral areas.
text 2: The cerebellum is functionally connected with nearly all cerebral areas.

text 1: Injection into the cerebellum of a retrograde virus, such as rabies virus, will label neurons that project to it.
text 2: Injection into the cerebral cortex of a retrograde virus, such as rabies virus, will label neurons that project to it.

text 1: Areas of the cerebral cortex connected to the cerebellum include the posterior intraparietal area and secondary motor cortex.
text 2: Areas of the cerebral cortex connected to the cerebellum include anterior intraparietal area and primary motor cortex.

text 1: The cerebellum is isolated from the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The cerebellum connects to many areas of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The vestibulocerebellum receives input from the vestibular labyrinth.
text 2: The vestibulocerebellum receives input from the auditory cortex.

text 1: The red nucleus is influenced by the cerebrocerebellum.
text 2: The red nucleus is influenced by the spinocerebellum.

text 1: The spinocerebellum controls proximal muscles and limb extensors.
text 2: The vestibulocerebellum controls proximal muscles and limb extensors.

text 1: The cerebellum is shown unfolded in the text.
text 2: The cerebellum is shown folded in the text.

text 1: The cortical-cerebellar circuit in monkeys was traced using only MRI scans.
text 2: The cortical-cerebellar circuit in monkeys was traced with fluorescence-labeled transsynaptic viruses.

text 1: Injection into the cerebral cortex of an anterograde virus, such as the H129 strain, labels neurons that are targets.
text 2: Injection into the cerebral cortex of an anterograde virus, such as the rabies virus, labels neurons that are targets.

text 1: The cerebellum influences the motor and premotor cortices via the ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus.
text 2: The cerebellum influences the motor and premotor cortices via the dorsal nucleus of the thalamus.

text 1: Nuclei in the lateral parts of the cerebellar hemispheres control limb muscles.
text 2: Nuclei in the intermediate parts of the cerebellar hemispheres control limb muscles.

text 1: The ventrolateral thalamus is targeted by the spinocerebellum.
text 2: The ventrolateral thalamus is targeted by the cerebrocerebellum.

text 1: Nuclei in the intermediate cerebellar parts control limb extensors.
text 2: Nuclei in the vestibulocerebellum and vermis control limb extensors.

text 1: The cerebellum contains only the dentate and fastigial nuclei.
text 2: The cerebellum contains the dentate, fastigial, and interposed nuclei.

text 1: Schizophrenia affects 0.25% to 0.75% of the population worldwide, with only modest regional differences.
text 2: Schizophrenia affects 25% to 75% of the population worldwide, with only modest regional differences.

text 1: Schizophrenia typically begins during the early childhood years or the late thirties.
text 2: Schizophrenia typically begins during the late teen years or the early to mid-twenties.

text 1: The most common hallucinations in schizophrenia are visual.
text 2: The most common hallucinations in schizophrenia are auditory.

text 1: Antipsychotic drugs exert no beneficial effects on cognitive impairments or deficit symptoms.
text 2: Antipsychotic drugs significantly improve cognitive impairments and deficit symptoms.

text 1: Schizophrenia is characterized mainly by physical symptoms, with little to no mental impairment.
text 2: Schizophrenia is characterized by cognitive impairments, deficit symptoms, and psychotic symptoms.

text 1: Psychotic episodes in schizophrenia are frequently accompanied by clear and logical patterns of speech.
text 2: Psychotic episodes in schizophrenia are frequently accompanied by disordered thought and odd patterns of speech.

text 1: Schizophrenia risk is transmitted within families strictly as Mendelian dominant or recessive traits.
text 2: Schizophrenia risk is not transmitted within families as Mendelian dominant or recessive traits.

text 1: Psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia tend to be episodic.
text 2: Psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia tend to be constant and unchanging.

text 1: Schizophrenia typically has an onset during the second and third decades of life.
text 2: Schizophrenia typically has an onset during infancy.

text 1: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia share about 50% of their DNA sequences.
text 2: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia share about 10% of their DNA sequences.

text 1: Cognitive impairments in schizophrenia primarily affect physical strength and coordination.
text 2: Cognitive impairments in schizophrenia target working memory, executive function, and verbal fluency.

text 1: The risk of schizophrenia decreases with genetic relatedness to an affected individual.
text 2: The risk of schizophrenia rises with genetic relatedness to an affected individual.

text 1: Kraepelin’s term for what later came to be called schizophrenia was dementia praecox.
text 2: Kraepelin’s term for what later came to be called schizophrenia was manic depression.

text 1: Females are more commonly affected by schizophrenia than males, with the sex ratio estimated to be 3:2.
text 2: Males are more commonly affected by schizophrenia than females, with the sex ratio estimated to be 3:2.

text 1: Only a small fraction of individuals in the ultra-high-risk state progress to develop the full spectrum of symptoms warranting a diagnosis of schizophrenia.
text 2: Most individuals in the ultra-high-risk state progress to develop the full spectrum of symptoms warranting a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

text 1: In the auditory system, acoustic information from speech is transmitted to Wernicke’s area in the temporal lobe, which has a strong role in language comprehension.
text 2: In the auditory system, acoustic information from speech is transmitted to Broca’s area in the parietal lobe, which has a strong role in visual processing.

text 1: Dorsal stream information generates nouns that we use to identify and classify motor actions, spatial awareness, and decision making.
text 2: Ventral stream information generates nouns that we use to identify and classify persons, places, and objects.

text 1: The dorsal stream in the temporal lobe analyzes and represents information about stimulus shape and color.
text 2: The dorsal stream in the parietal lobe analyzes and represents information about stimulus location and motion.

text 1: Each primary sensory area of cortex has extensive projections back to its principal afferent relay nucleus in the thalamus.
text 2: Each primary sensory area of cortex has no projections back to its principal afferent relay nucleus in the thalamus.

text 1: Neurons in the motor cortex can alter the sensitivity of sensory receptors in skeletal muscle that signal muscle length.
text 2: Neurons in the sensory cortex can alter the sensitivity of auditory receptors in the cochlea.

text 1: Only feed-forward circuits are involved in the anatomical connections between visual processing areas.
text 2: Feed-forward and feedback circuits are involved in the anatomical connections between visual processing areas.

text 1: The ventral stream in the temporal lobe analyzes information about the form and structure of visual scenes.
text 2: The ventral stream in the parietal lobe analyzes information about the motion and spatial position of visual scenes.

text 1: Contemporary neuroscientists have found that sensory events do not influence neuronal activation patterns.
text 2: Contemporary neuroscientists have discovered that sensory events evoke sequences of neuronal activation.

text 1: Sensory systems respond to stimuli based on modality, location, intensity, and duration.
text 2: Sensory systems respond to stimuli based solely on intensity and duration.

text 1: Wernicke’s area in the temporal lobe is involved in language comprehension.
text 2: Wernicke’s area in the frontal lobe is involved in language production.

text 1: Activation of beta motor neurons by corticospinal pathways enhances sensory responses of photoreceptors to light.
text 2: Activation of gamma motor neurons by corticospinal pathways enhances sensory responses of muscle spindle afferents to stretch.

text 1: Sensory inputs are weakened and de-emphasized by excitatory neurons in the relay nuclei of the nervous system.
text 2: Sensory inputs are integrated and emphasized by inhibiting neurons in the relay nuclei of the nervous system.

text 1: Ventral stream information motivates actions based on reflective thought, such as dreaming or imagining.
text 2: Dorsal stream information motivates actions based on sensory inputs, such as grasping, lifting, or driving.

text 1: Associative neural learning involves forging connections through repetition of perceptual experiences.
text 2: Associative neural learning involves severing connections through random exposure to unrelated experiences.

text 1: Charles F. Stevens noted that maximum entropy codes are highly efficient in representing diverse stimuli.
text 2: Charles F. Stevens noted that maximum entropy codes are inefficient and unable to represent diverse stimuli.

text 1: Shell temperature is held relatively constant, while core temperature fluctuates extensively due to its high surface-to-mass ratio.
text 2: Core temperature is held relatively constant, while shell temperature fluctuates extensively due to its high surface-to-mass ratio.

text 1: Most primary afferents that detect temperature have their cell bodies in the spinal dorsal root ganglia.
text 2: Most primary afferents that detect temperature have their cell bodies in the hypothalamic medial preoptic area.

text 1: Motor neurons can be distinguished from all other classes of neurons in the central nervous system by the fact that they have dendrites that extend into the periphery.
text 2: Motor neurons can be distinguished from all other classes of neurons in the central nervous system by the fact that they have axons that extend into the periphery.

text 1: There are approximately 600 skeletal muscles in a typical mammal, which implies an equal number of motor neuron types.
text 2: There are approximately 300 skeletal muscles in a typical mammal, which implies an equal number of motor neuron types.

text 1: The position of Hox genes in chromosomal clusters roughly corresponds to their domain of expression along the neural tube's anteroposterior axis.
text 2: The position of Hox genes in chromosomal clusters roughly corresponds to their domain of expression along the dorsoventral axis of the neural tube.

text 1: Hoxb1 is expressed at high levels in rhombomere 2, which gives rise to facial motor neurons.
text 2: Hoxb1 is expressed at high levels in rhombomere 4, which gives rise to facial motor neurons.

text 1: Mutations eliminating Hoxb1 activity in mice cause rhombomere 4 cells to generate motor neurons that innervate trigeminal instead of facial targets.
text 2: Mutations eliminating Hoxb1 activity in mice cause rhombomere 4 cells to generate motor neurons that innervate vagus instead of facial targets.

text 1: Spinal motor neurons are clustered within longitudinal columns based on their peripheral targets.
text 2: Spinal motor neurons are randomly distributed throughout the spinal cord, irrespective of their peripheral targets.

text 1: Motor neurons in the lateral motor columns innervate forelimb and hindlimb muscles at cervical and lumbar levels of the spinal cord.
text 2: Motor neurons in the lateral motor columns innervate cranial nerves VII and IX at cervical and lumbar levels of the spinal cord.

text 1: Wnt proteins expressed in spinal motor columns at specific levels contribute to the distinct identities of motor neurons.
text 2: Hox proteins expressed in spinal motor columns at specific levels contribute to the distinct identities of motor neurons.

text 1: Repressive interactions between Hox6 and Hox9 proteins help establish distinct columnar identities for motor neurons in the spinal cord.
text 2: Synergistic interactions between Hox6 and Hox9 proteins help establish distinct columnar identities for motor neurons in the spinal cord.

text 1: Hox6 proteins activate retinoic acid signaling paths, which direct the expression of downstream transcription factors like Is11 and Lhx1.
text 2: Hox9 proteins activate retinoic acid signaling paths, which direct the expression of downstream transcription factors like Is11 and Lhx1.

text 1: All motor neuron columns in the spinal cord are determined solely by Hox protein activity, including the median motor column.
text 2: Not all motor neuron columns in the spinal cord are determined by Hox protein activity; the median motor column is controlled by Wnt4/5 signals.

text 1: Hox gene activity determines motor pools within lateral motor columns in higher vertebrates.
text 2: Hox gene activity determines motor pools within the preganglionic motor column in higher vertebrates.

text 1: Ephrin receptors guide motor neuron axons within the limb mesenchyme.
text 2: Ephrin receptors guide motor neuron axons within the neural tube mesenchyme.

text 1: The clustered organization of Hox genes is conserved from flies to vertebrates.
text 2: The clustered organization of Hox genes is specific to vertebrates and absent in flies.

text 1: In mice, mutations affecting Hox gene expression exclusively affect sensory neuron connectivity and subtype identity.
text 2: In mice, mutations affecting Hox gene expression alter motor neuron connectivity and subtype identity.

text 1: Piezo1 is expressed in mechanosensory DRG and trigeminal neurons that mediate the senses of touch and proprioception.
text 2: Piezo2 is expressed in mechanosensory DRG and trigeminal neurons that mediate the senses of touch and proprioception.

text 1: Cool receptors are activated by skin cooling temperatures below 25°C.
text 2: Cool receptors are activated by skin cooling temperatures above 35°C.

text 1: Pacinian corpuscles detect pressure changes and are exclusively located in the skin.
text 2: Pacinian corpuscles detect vibration and are also located in the mesentery, between layers of muscle, and on interosseous membranes.

text 1: Piezo proteins conduct excitatory depolarizing current through nonspecific cation-permeable channels.
text 2: Piezo proteins conduct inhibitory hyperpolarizing current through potassium-selective channels.

text 1: Meissner corpuscles detect vibration and are marked by TRPV3.
text 2: Meissner corpuscles detect stroking and flutter and are marked by Piezo2.

text 1: Merkel cells cluster in touch domes of hairy skin and near fingerprint ridges in glabrous skin.
text 2: Merkel cells are exclusively located in smooth muscle tissues.

text 1: TRPV1 receptors are commonly associated with detecting cold temperatures below 5°C.
text 2: TRPV1 receptors are commonly associated with detecting hot temperatures above 45°C.

text 1: Hair cells in the inner ear use direct channel gating similar to some touch receptors in the skin.
text 2: Hair cells in the inner ear rely exclusively on indirect protein signaling for mechanical stimulation.

text 1: Polymodal nociceptors detect light stroking and express Piezo2.
text 2: Polymodal nociceptors detect slow, burning pain and express TRPV1 or TRPA1.

text 1: Piezo1 and Piezo2 perform identical functions across all neural tissues.
text 2: Two isoforms, Piezo1 and Piezo2, serve distinct mechanosensory functions in mammals.

text 1: The Piezo1 ion channel forms a dimer made of two identical protein subunits.
text 2: The Piezo1 ion channel forms a trimer made of three identical protein subunits.

text 1: The N-terminals of Piezo1 protein subunits form a propeller-like structure.
text 2: The C-terminals of Piezo1 protein subunits form a propeller-like structure.

text 1: Merkel cell–neurite complexes respond to the velocity and amplitude of pressure applied to the skin.
text 2: Merkel cell–neurite complexes are primarily responsible for detecting vibration and flutter.

text 1: C-LTMR fibers mediate slow stroking and gentle touch.
text 2: C-LTMR fibers mediate sharp pricking pain.

text 1: Touch receptors were first extensively studied in the 1920s by Edgar Adrian and Yngve Zotterman.
text 2: Touch receptors were first extensively studied in the 1960s by Edgar Adrian and Yngve Zotterman.

text 1: Afferent fibers from vestibular receptors terminate only in the cerebellum, not the brain stem.
text 2: Afferent fibers from vestibular receptors terminate in the brain stem and cerebellum.

text 1: Fibers from semicircular canals project primarily to the lateral portions of the inferior vestibular nuclei and bypass the cerebellum.
text 2: Fibers from semicircular canals project primarily to the medial portions of the superior and medial vestibular nuclei, the descending vestibular nucleus, the cerebellum (nodulus and uvula), and the reticular formation.

text 1: Central projections to the vestibular nuclei arise from a number of cortical, brain stem, and spinal cord regions.
text 2: Central projections to the vestibular nuclei arise solely from the spinal cord.

text 1: The vestibular nuclei project exclusively to cortical brain regions.
text 2: The vestibular nuclei project to a number of brain regions below the cortical level.

text 1: The vestibular nuclei project to the reticular formation and the lateral medullary nuclei in the brain stem.
text 2: The vestibular nuclei project only to the cerebellum, ignoring the brain stem.

text 1: Ascendin projections to the supragenual nucleus, the dorsal tegmental nucleus, the oculomotor nuclei (abducens, oculomotor, and trochlear), and the neural integrator nuclei are very prominent.
text 2: Ascending projections skip oculomotor nuclei and target only auditory areas.

text 1: The comparator struggles to determine the direction of movement without external input.
text 2: The comparator is able to determine the direction of movement with great specificity.

text 1: Any disruption of the normal balance between left and right ear canal inputs is always ignored by the brain.
text 2: Any disruption of the normal balance between left and right ear canal inputs will be interpreted by the brain as a head rotation, even though the head is stationary.

text 1: Vestibular inputs signaling body posture and motion are always precise and clear.
text 2: Vestibular inputs signaling body posture and motion can be ambiguous.

text 1: Central vestibular and cerebellar cells encode head tilt, whereas other cells encode translational motion.
text 2: All vestibular and cerebellar cells encode only translational motion.

text 1: The preferential response to passive motion has been interpreted as sensory prediction error signals.
text 2: The preferential response to passive motion is unrelated to sensory prediction error signals.

text 1: Vestibular signals are negligible during actively generated head movements.
text 2: Vestibular signals remain critically important when coupled to self-motion estimation and head movement control during actively generated head movements.

text 1: Vestibulo-ocular reflexes stabilize the eyes when the head moves.
text 2: Vestibulo-ocular reflexes destabilize the eyes during head movement.

text 1: Vision provides the brain with the only corrective feedback for stabilizing the image on the retina.
text 2: Vision is slower and less effective than vestibular processing for image stabilization.

text 1: The vestibular apparatus signals how fast the head is rotating.
text 2: The vestibular apparatus only signals static head position.

text 1: In the visual cortex, horizontal connections link neurons similar in function but representing distant locations in the visual field, suggesting a role in contour integration.
text 2: In the visual cortex, horizontal connections link neurons similar in function, representing immediate locations in the visual field, suggesting a role in color integration.

text 1: Perceptual learning involves repeating a discrimination task many times and requires error feedback to improve performance.
text 2: Perceptual learning involves repeating a discrimination task many times and does not require error feedback to improve performance.

text 1: Feedback connections from higher-order cortical areas are less extensive than the feedforward connections that originate in the thalamus or earlier stages of cortical processing.
text 2: Feedback connections from higher-order cortical areas are as extensive as the feedforward connections that originate in the thalamus or earlier stages of cortical processing.

text 1: The receptive fields of cells within the lesion projection zone shift from the lesioned part of the retina to the functioning area surrounding the lesion over several months.
text 2: The receptive fields of cells within the lesion projection zone shift immediately from the lesioned part of the retina to the entire visual field over several days.

text 1: Training on a three-line bisection task leads to substantial improvement in all similar discrimination tasks, including the vernier discrimination task.
text 2: Training on a three-line bisection task leads to substantial improvement in that task without affecting performance on the vernier discrimination task.

text 1: Perceptual learning is a form of implicit learning that does not involve conscious processes.
text 2: Perceptual learning is a form of explicit learning that involves conscious processes.

text 1: The cortical representation of the lesioned part of the retina shrinks while that of the surrounding region expands as neurons form new synaptic connections.
text 2: The cortical representation of the lesioned part of the retina expands while that of the surrounding region shrinks due to neuron inactivity.

text 1: Pop-out of complex shapes such as numerals supports the idea that early visual processing can represent shapes more complex than line segments.
text 2: Pop-out of complex shapes such as numerals contradicts the idea that early visual processing can represent only simple shapes.

text 1: The judgment of the senses may be modified by experience and training derived under various circumstances.
text 2: The judgment of the senses is fixed and cannot be modified by experience or training.

text 1: Scene segmentation involves both bottom-up processes and top-down processes that create object expectation.
text 2: Scene segmentation relies solely on bottom-up processes and does not involve any top-down processes.

text 1: With practice, subjects improve their ability to detect longer contours, but V1 neurons become less sensitive to these contours.
text 2: With practice, subjects improve their ability to detect shorter contours, and V1 neurons become correspondingly more sensitive to shorter contours.

text 1: Training on one task automatically transfers to all other tasks, demonstrating the universality of perceptual learning.
text 2: Training on one task does not transfer to other tasks, demonstrating the specificity of perceptual learning.

text 1: Spatial attention can change focus without any movement of an observer's eyes.
text 2: Spatial attention requires movement of an observer's eyes to change focus.

text 1: The plasticity of cortical maps evolved as a direct response to retinal lesions.
text 2: The plasticity of cortical maps did not evolve as a response to lesions but as a mechanism for improving perceptual skills.

text 1: Pop-out likely occurs late in cortical processing, after feature information has been encoded.
text 2: Pop-out probably occurs early in the visual cortex, where feature information is encoded.

text 1: The corollary discharge allows visual perception across eye movements by affecting the activity of visual neurons.
text 2: The corollary discharge prevents visual perception across eye movements by suppressing the activity of visual neurons.

text 1: Inactivation of the thalamic pathway affects the accuracy of the second saccade in the double-step task.
text 2: Inactivation of the thalamic pathway has no effect on the accuracy of the second saccade in the double-step task.

text 1: The superior colliculus only provides motor command vectors, not corollary discharges.
text 2: The superior colliculus provides both motor command vectors and corollary discharges.

text 1: Remapping facilitates both visual perception around the time of a saccade and the accuracy of visually guided movement.
text 2: Remapping hinders visual perception around the time of a saccade and the accuracy of visually guided movement.

text 1: Physiological studies in Rhesus monkeys show that corollary discharge affects parietal neuron responsiveness.
text 2: Physiological studies in Rhesus monkeys show that corollary discharge does not affect parietal neuron responsiveness.

text 1: Efference copy is another term for corollary discharge used in the 20th century.
text 2: Efference copy is another term for corollary discharge used in the 19th century.

text 1: The brain constructs the visual scene by using saccade vectors, despite changes in retinal images after each saccade.
text 2: The brain constructs the visual scene without considering saccade vectors and changes in retinal images after each saccade.

text 1: The corollary discharge is seen at the level of a single neuron in the lateral intraparietal area.
text 2: The corollary discharge is not seen at the level of a single neuron in the lateral intraparietal area.

text 1: Each neuron in the superior colliculus is tuned to multiple vectors.
text 2: Each neuron in the superior colliculus is tuned to saccades of a specific vector.

text 1: The efference copy is a term coined in the 20th century to describe a motor command copy.
text 2: The efference copy is a term coined in the 19th century to describe a motor command copy.

text 1: Remapping only occurs in cortical areas, not in subcortical areas like the superior colliculus.
text 2: Remapping occurs in both cortical and subcortical areas such as the lateral intraparietal area and the superior colliculus.

text 1: During a saccade, the receptive field remapping allows neural responses to targets previously outside the receptive field.
text 2: During a saccade, the receptive field remapping prevents neural responses to targets previously outside the receptive field.

text 1: The double-step task is used to illustrate how the brain compensates for individual saccades.
text 2: The double-step task does not illustrate how the brain compensates for individual saccades.

text 1: Ascending pathways from the superior colliculus reach the cerebral cortex through the thalamus.
text 2: Ascending pathways from the superior colliculus bypass the thalamus on their way to the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Helmholtz referred to a motor command copy as an 'efference copy' in the 19th century.
text 2: Helmholtz referred to a motor command copy as a 'sense of effort' in the 19th century.

text 1: Visual deprivation of one eye during a critical period reduces the width of the ocular dominance columns for that eye.
text 2: Visual deprivation of one eye during a critical period increases the width of the ocular dominance columns for that eye.

text 1: Label injected into the open eye results in wider labeled stripes and narrower unlabeled stripes in the visual cortex of an 18-month-old monkey whose right eye had been surgically closed at 2 weeks of age.
text 2: Label injected into the open eye results in wide labeled stripes and narrow unlabeled stripes in the visual cortex of a surgically closed eye.

text 1: Closure of an eye at birth leads to dominance by the closed eye because little segregation has occurred.
text 2: Closure of an eye at birth leads to dominance by the open eye because little segregation has occurred.

text 1: Stimulation of optic nerves asynchronously leads to the establishment of ocular dominance columns.
text 2: Stimulation of optic nerves synchronously leads to the establishment of ocular dominance columns.

text 1: Competition between afferent axons for the same population of target neurons drives their segregation into distinct target territories.
text 2: Cooperation between afferent axons for the same population of target neurons drives their segregation into distinct target territories.

text 1: Sensory afferent fibers innervating the hand transmit tactile information through the median, ulnar, and superficial radial nerves.
text 2: Sensory afferent fibers innervating the hand transmit tactile information through the sciatic, tibial, and deep radial nerves.

text 1: Neurons in the dorsal column nuclei project their axons directly to the cerebellum without crossing the midline.
text 2: Neurons in the dorsal column nuclei project their axons across the midline in the medulla to form the medial lemniscus.

text 1: RA1 fibers are silent during steady grasp and respond to slipping objects.
text 2: RA1 fibers are active during steady grasp and do not respond to slippery objects.

text 1: The RA1 and RA2 fibers cease responding after grasp is established.
text 2: The SA1 and SA2 fibers cease responding after grasp is established.

text 1: Objects with rough textures are grasped more firmly than those with smooth surfaces.
text 2: Objects with smooth surfaces are grasped more firmly than those with rough textures.

text 1: The ventral posterior lateral nucleus transmits cutaneous information to area 3b of the primary somatosensory cortex.
text 2: The ventral posterior lateral nucleus transmits cutaneous information to the temporal lobe.

text 1: In the spinal cord, fibers for touch and proprioception ascend in the contralateral lateral column.
text 2: In the spinal cord, fibers for touch and proprioception ascend in the ipsilateral dorsal column.

text 1: The grip force is adjusted automatically based on the frictional coefficient between the fingers and object.
text 2: The grip force is adjusted manually without reliance on frictional coefficient.

text 1: The medial lemniscus transmits information from the contralateral side of the body.
text 2: The medial lemniscus transmits information from the ipsilateral side of the body.

text 1: In the medulla, neurons cross the midline to form the medial lemniscus.
text 2: In the medulla, neurons remain on the same side and do not form the medial lemniscus.

text 1: SA1 fibers encode the grip force, and SA2 fibers encode the hand posture.
text 2: RA1 fibers encode the hand posture, and RA2 fibers encode grip force.

text 1: The cuneate fascicle is associated with the upper body representation.
text 2: The gracile fascicle is associated with the upper body representation.

text 1: RA1 fibers sense tangential slip movements in objects when they begin to slip.
text 2: RA2 fibers sense tangential slip movements in objects when they begin to slip.

text 1: The left side of the brain receives input from the left side of the body.
text 2: The left side of the brain receives input from the right side of the body.

text 1: Somatosensory submodalities of touch and proprioception are processed together without functional segregation.
text 2: Somatosensory submodalities of touch and proprioception are segregated functionally.

text 1: The maps of the body surface in the primary somatic sensory cortex differ among individuals in a manner that reflects their use of specific sensory pathways.
text 2: The maps of the body surface in the primary somatic sensory cortex are identical among all individuals regardless of their use of specific sensory pathways.

text 1: The reorganization of afferent inputs as a result of behavior is not evident at the level of the dorsal column nuclei.
text 2: The reorganization of afferent inputs as a result of behavior is evident at the level of the dorsal column nuclei.

text 1: Practice decreases synaptic connections by weakening the effectiveness of existing connections.
text 2: Practice may expand synaptic connections by strengthening the effectiveness of existing connections.

text 1: In an experiment with monkeys, the skin surfaces of two adjacent fingers were surgically connected, abolishing the normally sharp discontinuity between the zones in the somatosensory cortex.
text 2: In an experiment with monkeys, the skin surfaces of two adjacent fingers were surgically connected, reinforcing the sharp discontinuity between the zones in the somatosensory cortex.

text 1: People trained to perform a task with their fingers show an expansion in the fMRI signal in the primary motor cortex during performance of the task.
text 2: People trained to perform a task with their fingers show no change in the fMRI signal in the primary motor cortex during performance of the task.

text 1: String instrument players have the same representation of the left hand in the cortex as nonmusicians.
text 2: String instrument players have greater representation of the left hand in the cortex compared to nonmusicians.

text 1: The representation of the left hand is more prominent in players who started to play their instrument before age 13.
text 2: The representation of the left hand is more prominent in players who started to play their instrument after age 13.

text 1: Many aspects of personality are guided by implicit memory.
text 2: Many aspects of personality are controlled strictly by explicit memory.

text 1: In mammals, only innate defensive responses involve the amygdala.
text 2: In mammals, both innate and learned defensive responses involve the amygdala.

text 1: Habits are routines that are acquired gradually by repetition.
text 2: Habits are routines that are acquired instantly without repetition.

text 1: Damage to the human amygdala impairs implicit threat conditioning but does not affect the explicit memory of having been conditioned.
text 2: Damage to the human amygdala has no impact on implicit threat conditioning but affects the explicit memory of having been conditioned.

text 1: All individuals have the same brain modifications regardless of environmental experiences and genetic makeup.
text 2: Each individual's brain is uniquely modified due to different environmental experiences and genetic makeup.

text 1: Electrophysiological responses of neurons in the lateral amygdala decrease during Pavlovian conditioning.
text 2: Electrophysiological responses of neurons in the lateral amygdala are enhanced during Pavlovian conditioning.

text 1: The amygdala-based defense system can associate a new neutral stimulus with a known threatening stimulus on a single paired exposure.
text 2: The amygdala-based defense system requires multiple paired exposures to associate a new neutral stimulus with a known threatening stimulus.

text 1: The study of unconscious psychic processes was limited by the lack of suitable experimental methods.
text 2: The study of unconscious psychic processes had a wide range of suitable experimental methods from the beginning.

text 1: Preganglionic motor neurons regenerate selective connections with their sympathetic neuronal targets after nerve damage.
text 2: Preganglionic motor neurons regenerate non-selective connections with their sympathetic neuronal targets after nerve damage.

text 1: Axons that arise from rostrally located thoracic neurons innervate superior cervical ganglion neurons that project to rostral targets, like intrinsic eye muscles.
text 2: Axons that arise from rostrally located thoracic neurons innervate ganglion neurons that project to caudal targets, like the blood vessels of the ear.

text 1: Preganglionic axons selectively form synapses with ganglion neurons that terminate in specific peripheral targets.
text 2: Preganglionic axons randomly form synapses with ganglion neurons without specificity to peripheral targets.

text 1: Laminar specificity restricts axons and dendrites to particular plexiform sublayers in the retina.
text 2: Laminar specificity allows axons and dendrites to diffuse freely across all plexiform sublayers in the retina.

text 1: Retinal ganglion neurons express specific subsets of immunoglobulin superfamily adhesion molecules like Sdk1 and Dscam during development.
text 2: Retinal ganglion neurons express random subsets of adhesion molecules without any evolutionary specificity.

text 1: Loss-of-function experiments reveal that recognition molecules play no significant role in establishing synaptic specificity in the retina.
text 2: Loss-of-function experiments demonstrate that recognition molecules are critical for establishing synaptic specificity in the retina.

text 1: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses multiple types of odorant receptors simultaneously.
text 2: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses one of approximately 1,000 types of odorant receptors.

text 1: Neurons expressing the same odorant receptor distribute their axons across multiple glomeruli in the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Neurons expressing the same odorant receptor converge their axons onto a single glomerulus in the olfactory bulb.

text 1: Deletion of specific olfactory receptors results in axons failing to converge into specific glomeruli.
text 2: Deletion of specific olfactory receptors has no effect on axons converging into specific glomeruli.

text 1: Activity-independent mechanisms drive the initial coarse mapping of olfactory neurons to bulb targets.
text 2: Activity-dependent mechanisms drive the initial coarse mapping of olfactory neurons to bulb targets.

text 1: Second messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate has no influence on the expression of guidance molecules in the olfactory system.
text 2: Second messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate influences the expression of guidance molecules in the olfactory system.

text 1: Postnatal activation of odorant receptors by odorants disrupts connectivity in the olfactory system.
text 2: Postnatal activation of odorant receptors by odorants refines connectivity in the olfactory system.

text 1: Odorant receptor deletions alter axon-target matching in the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Odorant receptor deletions have no effect on axon-target matching in the olfactory bulb.

text 1: Sidekick 2 helps interneurons choose specific ganglion cells as synaptic partners in the retina.
text 2: Sidekick 2 prevents interneurons from choosing specific ganglion cells as synaptic partners in the retina.

text 1: Odorant receptors help determine both responsiveness to odorants and appropriate synaptic formation in olfactory neurons.
text 2: Odorant receptors determine responsiveness to odorants but play no role in synaptic formation in olfactory neurons.

text 1: Humans perceive colors because photoreceptors in the retina encode wavelengths of light within the ultraviolet spectrum.
text 2: Humans perceive colors because photoreceptors in the retina encode specific wavelengths of light within the visible spectrum.

text 1: Sensory coding involves the transformation of electrical signals into stimulus energy by specialized receptors.
text 2: Sensory coding involves the transformation of stimulus energy into electrical signals by specialized receptors.

text 1: Chemoreceptors are responsible for olfaction, gustation, itch, pain, and many visceral sensations.
text 2: Mechanoreceptors are responsible for olfaction, gustation, itch, pain, and many visceral sensations.

text 1: Photoreceptors respond equally to all wavelengths of light, with no specific range of sensitivity.
text 2: Photoreceptors respond to specific ranges of wavelengths, such as blue cone cells responding best to light around 430 to 440 nm.

text 1: Stimulus transduction is the process by which electrical signals are converted into mechanical stimuli.
text 2: Stimulus transduction is the process by which specific stimulus energy is converted into an electrical signal.

text 1: Thermoreceptors in the skin sense warming and cooling, but hypothalamic thermoreceptors monitor oxygen levels in the blood.
text 2: Thermoreceptors in the skin sense warming and cooling, while a hypothalamic thermoreceptor monitors blood temperature.

text 1: Meissner’s corpuscles are mechanoreceptors that respond to mechanical pressure and deformation of the skin.
text 2: Meissner’s corpuscles are photoreceptors that respond to wavelengths of light and color stimuli.

text 1: The brain segregates sensory input components, ensuring they remain independent without integration.
text 2: The brain integrates diverse components of sensory input to create an ensemble representation of stimuli.

text 1: Taste submodalities include sweet, sour, salty, savory, and bitter, which are mediated by mechanoreceptors.
text 2: Taste submodalities include sweet, sour, salty, savory, and bitter, which are mediated by subclasses of chemoreceptors.

text 1: Hair cell receptors in the cochlea encode the wavelength, color, and brightness of sound signals.
text 2: Hair cell receptors in the cochlea encode tonal frequency, loudness, and duration of sound-pressure waves.

text 1: Sensory receptors are classified as mechanoreceptors, chemoreceptors, photoreceptors, or magnetoreceptors depending on the stimulus energy.
text 2: Sensory receptors are classified as mechanoreceptors, chemoreceptors, photoreceptors, or thermoreceptors depending on the stimulus energy.

text 1: Humans do not perceive ultraviolet light or infrared radiation because we lack receptors for these wavelengths.
text 2: Humans perceive ultraviolet light and infrared radiation because we have receptors for these wavelengths.

text 1: Rod cells in the retina contain the photopigment hemoglobin, which changes configuration upon absorbing light.
text 2: Rod cells in the retina contain the photopigment rhodopsin, which changes configuration upon absorbing light.

text 1: Olfactory sensory neurons in mucosal surfaces detect mechanical pressure to initiate sensory coding for smells.
text 2: Olfactory sensory neurons in mucosal surfaces bind specific odorant molecules to initiate sensory coding for smells.

text 1: Muscle mechanoreceptors signal muscle length, velocity, and force to the brain.
text 2: Muscle mechanoreceptors signal wavelength, brightness, and electromagnetic energy to the brain.

text 1: A slowly adapting mechanoreceptor responds at the beginning and end of the pressure stimulus, but remains silent during steady pressure.
text 2: A slowly adapting mechanoreceptor responds as long as pressure is applied to the skin, and its firing rate is higher at the beginning of skin contact than during steady pressure.

text 1: The receptive field of a sensory neuron refers to the specific region of skin or other sense organ where tactile stimuli evoke action potentials in that neuron.
text 2: The receptive field of a sensory neuron refers to the specific region of skin or sense organ where tactile stimuli evoke inhibitory signals in that neuron.

text 1: The spatial resolution of a sensory system increases with the density of receptor neurons and decreases with the size of their receptive fields.
text 2: The spatial resolution of a sensory system decreases with the density of receptor neurons and increases with the size of their receptive fields.

text 1: Mechanoreceptors are evenly distributed across the body, which results in consistent touch sensitivity regardless of location.
text 2: Mechanoreceptors are concentrated in the fingertips, which have smaller receptive fields compared to the arm or trunk, allowing for increased touch sensitivity.

text 1: Ganglion cells in the periphery of the retina have smaller receptive fields, enabling detailed visual information processing.
text 2: Ganglion cells in the central retina (the fovea) have smaller receptive fields, enabling detailed visual information processing.

text 1: Recurrent excitatory connections in relay neurons amplify sensory signals and facilitate spatial summation of inputs.
text 2: Recurrent excitatory connections in relay neurons suppress sensory signals and reduce spatial summation of inputs.

text 1: Inhibitory regions of receptive fields help enhance contrast between stimuli, increasing the ability to resolve spatial detail.
text 2: Inhibitory regions of receptive fields reduce contrast between stimuli, decreasing the ability to resolve spatial detail.

text 1: Central sensory neurons are not connected to specific classes of receptors but are randomly assigned to sensory modalities.
text 2: Many central sensory neurons are connected to specific classes of receptors and are dedicated to distinct sensory modalities, such as visual or auditory systems.

text 1: Deficits in sensory, cognitive, or motor function following local brain injury may result from disruption to circuits rather than damage to a single node.
text 2: Deficits in sensory, cognitive, or motor function following local brain injury exclusively result from damage to a single node.

text 1: The representation created by sensory networks in the brain combines detailed receptor input to enhance saliency of important features while ignoring others.
text 2: The representation created by sensory networks in the brain is purely a reflection of environmental events with no subjective modification.

text 1: Sensory relays strive to reduce signal redundancy during recoding, while retaining most essential information.
text 2: Sensory relays increase redundancy during recoding to enhance transmission of detailed information.

text 1: Visual resolution improves as the density of neurons increases and the receptive field size decreases.
text 2: Visual resolution worsens as the density of neurons increases and the receptive field size decreases.

text 1: Neurons of the peripheral retina provide a detailed representation of the visual scene due to their tightly packed photoreceptors and small receptive fields.
text 2: Neurons of the fovea provide a detailed representation of the visual scene due to their tightly packed photoreceptors and small receptive fields.

text 1: The brain integrates sensory input from various modalities to construct representations of objects and scenes.
text 2: Sensory representations of objects and scenes are constructed exclusively by peripheral sensory receptors, not the brain.

text 1: Touch-sensitive neurons have receptive fields defined by regions of the skin where tactile stimuli evoke action potentials.
text 2: Touch-sensitive neurons have receptive fields defined by regions of the skin where tactile stimuli evoke inhibitory signals.

text 1: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal cortex signal the size, depth, and orientation of objects that can be grasped and are active during grasping movements.
text 2: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal cortex signal motion and color associations of objects during grasping movements.

text 1: The parietal cortex provides visual information necessary for independent movement of the fingers.
text 2: The parietal cortex provides auditory information necessary for independent movement of the fingers.

text 1: The representation of space in the parietal cortex is divided into at least four areas: LIP, MIP, VIP, and AIP, each suited for specific motor systems.
text 2: The representation of space in the parietal cortex is organized into a single map like the retinotopic map in the primary visual cortex.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond briskly to all stable stimuli, regardless of saliency, in the receptive field.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond briskly to salient stimuli in the receptive field.

text 1: Patients with lesions of the parietal cortex cannot adjust their grip width using auditory cues alone.
text 2: Patients with lesions of the parietal cortex cannot adjust their grip width using visual information alone.

text 1: The dorsal visual pathway extends to the occipital cortex and does not connect to the frontal cortex.
text 2: The dorsal visual pathway extends to the posterior parietal cortex and then to the frontal cortex.

text 1: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area describe targets for color identification and project to the occipital cortex.
text 2: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area describe targets for reaching movements and project to the premotor area controlling these movements.

text 1: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal cortex respond equally to all shapes and orientations.
text 2: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal cortex respond selectively to specific shapes, such as rectangles.

text 1: Stable objects consistently evoke enhanced neuronal responses regardless of their relevance to the animal’s behavior.
text 2: Stable objects can evoke enhanced neuronal responses when they become relevant to the animal’s behavior.

text 1: The ventral visual pathway is studied in Chapter 24, while the dorsal pathway extends to the parietal and frontal cortices.
text 2: Both the ventral and dorsal pathways extend exclusively to the occipital cortex without parietal involvement.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area fire intensely when a saccade brings a stable object into the receptive field.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area fire intensely when a saccade brings the location of the recent light flash into the receptive field.

text 1: Patients with intact parietal lobes and deficits in the ventral stream can adjust their grip width despite being unable to describe object size or orientation.
text 2: Patients with intact parietal lobes and deficits in the ventral stream cannot adjust their grip width or describe object size or orientation.

text 1: The visual system is only responsible for determining object color and does not adjust grip width.
text 2: The visual system helps adjust grip width before the hand arrives at an object, such as a pencil or glass.

text 1: Neurons are equally active when any stimulus, attention-evoking or stable, is brought into the receptive field.
text 2: Neurons are more active when an attention-evoking stimulus is brought into the receptive field compared to a stable, task-irrelevant stimulus.

text 1: The anterior intraparietal cortex is involved in analyzing object qualities necessary for grasping movements.
text 2: The anterior intraparietal cortex is primarily responsible for identifying auditory signals for grasping movements.

text 1: Light absorption by rhodopsin leads to closure of cGMP-gated channels, hyperpolarizing the rod cell.
text 2: Light absorption by rhodopsin leads to opening of cGMP-gated channels, depolarizing the rod cell.

text 1: The central fovea is adapted for daytime vision due to its dense packing of cones and absence of rods.
text 2: The central fovea is adapted for nighttime vision due to its dense packing of rods and absence of cones.

text 1: In the dark, cGMP levels are low, keeping cation channels closed and preventing Na+ and Ca2+ from entering the photoreceptor.
text 2: In the dark, cGMP levels are high, keeping cation channels open and allowing Na+ and Ca2+ to flow into the photoreceptor.

text 1: Cones respond faster than rods to brief flashes of light, peaking earlier with brighter flashes.
text 2: Rods respond faster than cones to brief flashes of light, peaking earlier with brighter flashes.

text 1: Phototransduction in rods and cones involves an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration upon light stimulation.
text 2: Phototransduction in rods and cones involves a decrease in intracellular Ca2+ concentration upon light stimulation.

text 1: Opsin, the protein in rhodopsin, loops seven times across the membrane of the rod disc.
text 2: Opsin, the protein in rhodopsin, loops five times across the membrane of the rod disc.

text 1: The L and M cone opsins share 96% identity in their amino acid sequences.
text 2: The L and S cone opsins share 96% identity in their amino acid sequences.

text 1: Rhodopsin undergoes a conformational change to metarhodopsin II upon light absorption.
text 2: Rhodopsin undergoes a conformational change to metarhodopsin I upon light absorption.

text 1: The 11-cis retinal in rhodopsin converts to the all-trans configuration upon photon absorption.
text 2: The all-trans retinal in rhodopsin converts to the 11-cis configuration upon photon absorption.

text 1: Hyperpolarization of photoreceptors due to light increases the release of glutamate.
text 2: Hyperpolarization of photoreceptors due to light reduces the release of glutamate.

text 1: The visual center of the retina, the fovea, is specialized for the highest visual acuity during daylight.
text 2: The visual center of the retina, the fovea, is specialized for the highest visual acuity during nighttime.

text 1: The absorption of a photon is the only light-dependent step in vision.
text 2: Conformational changes in photoreceptors occur independently of photon absorption in vision.

text 1: S cones, which make up 10% of all cones, are absent from the central fovea of the retina.
text 2: S cones, which make up 10% of all cones, are densely packed in the central fovea of the retina.

text 1: Old World monkeys, which have three visual pigments, separated evolutionarily from New World monkeys, which generally have only two.
text 2: New World monkeys, which have three visual pigments, separated evolutionarily from Old World monkeys, which generally have only two.

text 1: Calcium ion concentration increases in phototransduction, modulating the feedback on rhodopsin, GC, and cGMP-gated channels.
text 2: Calcium ion concentration drops in phototransduction, modulating the feedback on rhodopsin, GC, and cGMP-gated channels.

text 1: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 5 degrees, corresponding to an interaural time difference of 50 μs.
text 2: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 1 degree, corresponding to an interaural time difference of 10 μs.

text 1: The maximal interaural delay in humans is approximately 600 μs.
text 2: The maximal interaural delay in humans is approximately 300 μs.

text 1: Low-frequency sounds are deflected by the head, producing a sound shadow on the far side.
text 2: High-frequency sounds are deflected by the head, producing a sound shadow on the far side.

text 1: Animals lose interaural timing and intensity cues if they lose hearing in one ear.
text 2: Animals retain interaural timing and intensity cues even if they lose hearing in one ear.

text 1: Interaural time differences can be used by mammals to localize broadband sounds in both the vertical and horizontal planes.
text 2: Spectral filtering can be used by mammals to localize broadband sounds in both the vertical and horizontal planes.

text 1: The cochlear nuclei and the ventral nuclei of the lateral lemniscus are the only central auditory neurons that receive monaural input.
text 2: The cochlear nuclei and the ventral nuclei of the inferior colliculus are the only central auditory neurons that receive monaural input.

text 1: Humans can understand speech in the midst of noise due to redundant cues in the vocal apparatus.
text 2: Humans find it difficult to understand speech in the midst of noise due to inadequate cues in the vocal apparatus.

text 1: Acoustic information flows from the bilateral inferior colliculi to the ipsilateral hippocampus, the relay to auditory areas of the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Acoustic information flows from the bilateral inferior colliculi to the ipsilateral thalamus, the relay to auditory areas of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Musical pitches are largely in the high-frequency range in which auditory nerve fibers fire in phase with sounds.
text 2: Musical pitches are largely in the low-frequency range in which auditory nerve fibers fire in phase with sounds.

text 1: In dissonant sounds, there is less regularity both in the sound itself and in the firing of auditory nerve fibers.
text 2: In euphonious sounds, there is less regularity both in the sound itself and in the firing of auditory nerve fibers.

text 1: If the shape of the ear is experimentally altered, even adult humans can learn to make use of a new pattern of spectral cues.
text 2: If the shape of the ear is experimentally altered, adult humans are unable to learn to use a new pattern of spectral cues.

text 1: The central auditory pathways extend from the brain stem through the midbrain and thalamus to the auditory cortex.
text 2: The central auditory pathways extend from the brain stem directly to the cerebellum.

text 1: Neurons of the inferior colliculus project to the superior colliculus and to the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
text 2: Neurons of the inferior colliculus project directly to the cerebellum and to the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.

text 1: Most vertebrates take advantage of having two ears for localizing sounds in the vertical plane.
text 2: Most vertebrates take advantage of having two ears for localizing sounds in the horizontal plane.

text 1: Interaural time differences are particularly well conveyed by neurons that encode relatively low frequencies.
text 2: Interaural time differences are particularly well conveyed by neurons that encode relatively high frequencies.

text 1: Intermediate-level visual processing involves assembling local elements of an image without forming a unified percept of objects and background.
text 2: Intermediate-level visual processing involves assembling local elements of an image into a unified percept of objects and background.

text 1: Contour integration is the first step in generating a representation of the unified visual field.
text 2: Contour integration is the last step in generating a representation of the unified visual field.

text 1: Local orientation computation is an example of high-level visual processing.
text 2: Local orientation computation is an example of low-level visual processing.

text 1: The perception of a surface's brightness and color can be influenced by the context of surrounding elements.
text 2: The perception of a surface's brightness and color is unaffected by the context of surrounding elements.

text 1: Visual processing in the cortex is independent of cognitive functions such as attention and expectation.
text 2: Visual processing in the cortex is influenced by cognitive functions such as attention and expectation.

text 1: Induced pluripotent stem cells can be generated from an individual's blood cells, avoiding issues of immunological incompatibility.
text 2: Induced pluripotent stem cells can be generated from an individual's skin cells, avoiding issues of immunological incompatibility.

text 1: Transplanting neural precursors into the adult brain can help differentiate into neurons in a hospitable environment.

text 1: Dopaminergic neurons can be lost from the striatum in Parkinson disease.

text 1: ES cells are derived from early blastocyst stage embryos and can give rise to all cells of the body.
text 2: ES cells are derived from late blastocyst stage embryos and can give rise to all cells of the body.

text 1: Neural stem cells and committed precursors have been transplanted successfully.

text 1: Melanin-rich dopaminergic neurons are present in the substantia nigra of a diseased brain.
text 2: Melanin-rich dopaminergic neurons are present in the substantia nigra of a healthy brain.

text 2: Direct injection of embryonic dopaminergic neurons into the putamen reactivates the globus pallidus output pathways.

text 1: iPS cells bypass many concerns associated with ES cells.

text 1: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis involves the loss of spinal motor neurons.
text 2: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis involves the gain of spinal motor neurons.

text 1: Induced pluripotent stem cells can only be used to generate precursors of glial types.
text 2: Induced pluripotent stem cells can be reprogrammed to generate precursors of many neuronal and glial types.

text 1: Neurogenesis in adults is ordinarily distributed throughout the entire brain.

text 1: Research using human ES cells has been hindered by practical, political, and ethical concerns.

text 1: Endogenous neuronal precursors prevent injuries from occurring in the first place.

text 1: Methods for generating specific classes of neural precursors remain undeveloped.

text 1: Clinical trials using ES and iPS cell-derived neurons have been completely abandoned.

text 1: Axons from sensory neurons that express one type of receptor converge on multiple variable glomeruli in the antennal lobe.
text 2: Axons from sensory neurons that express one type of receptor converge on two invariant glomeruli in the antennal lobe.

text 1: In Drosophila, the antennal lobe is strikingly similar to the first sensory relay in the vertebrate olfactory bulb.
text 2: In Drosophila, the antennal lobe is strikingly different from the first sensory relay in the vertebrate olfactory bulb.

text 1: A single insect receptor protein that detects many odors can be stimulated by some odors and inhibited by others.
text 2: A single insect receptor protein that detects many odors can only be stimulated by odors, not inhibited.

text 1: Projection neurons from the antennal lobe extend directly to the spinal cord.
text 2: Projection neurons from the antennal lobe extend to higher brain centers called mushroom bodies and lateral protocerebrum.

text 1: The nematode roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans has over 1000 neurons in the entire animal.
text 2: The nematode roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans has only 302 neurons in the entire animal.

text 1: Chemosensory neurons in C. elegans use G proteins to regulate cyclic guanosine 3′,5′-monophosphate (cGMP) and a cGMP-gated channel.
