text 1: The G protein–coupled receptor for the volatile odorant diacetyl is unique and not part of the approximately 1,700 predicted G protein–coupled chemoreceptor genes in C. elegans.
text 2: The G protein–coupled receptor for the volatile odorant diacetyl is one of around 1,700 predicted G protein–coupled chemoreceptor genes in C. elegans.

text 1: The odr-10 gene is active in all types of neurons in C. elegans.
text 2: The odr-10 gene is active only in the AWA neurons in C. elegans.

text 1: The mushroom bodies are primarily responsible for motor function in insects.
text 2: The mushroom bodies are sites of olfactory associative learning and multimodal associative learning.

text 1: The molecular mechanisms of olfaction in C. elegans were elucidated through behavioral training methods.
text 2: The molecular mechanisms of olfaction in C. elegans were elucidated through genetic screens for mutant worms lacking the ability to detect odors (anosmia).

text 1: Bitter and sour tastants elicit innately pleasurable sensations in humans.
text 2: Sweet and umami tastants elicit innately pleasurable sensations in humans.

text 1: Taste and flavor are synonymous and have the same qualities.
text 2: Taste refers strictly to the five qualities encoded in the gustatory system, whereas flavor stems from multisensory integration.

text 1: In C. elegans, each neuron responds to only one specific odor without distinction required.
text 2: In C. elegans, a single neuron responds to many odors but efficiently distinguishes them if they are sensed by different primary sensory neurons.

text 1: Nematodes signal through G proteins and a cGMP-gated channel, similar to vertebrate photoreceptors.
text 2: Nematodes signal through direct electrical synapses, unlike vertebrate photoreceptors.

text 1: Insects, mammals, and nematodes evolved from a common olfactory system without modification.
text 2: Insects, mammals, and nematodes independently modified their olfactory systems due to evolutionary requirements.

text 1: Monozygotic twins share nearly all genes and have a 100% risk of sharing the disease state.
text 2: Monozygotic twins share nearly all genes and have a high (but not 100%) risk of sharing the disease state.

text 1: A score of zero represents no correlation (the average result for two random people), whereas a score of 1.0 represents a perfect correlation.
text 2: A score of zero represents no correlation (the average result for monozygotic twins), whereas a score of 1.0 represents a perfect correlation.

text 1: The risk of developing schizophrenia is greater in close relatives of a schizophrenic patient.
text 2: The risk of developing schizophrenia is the same in all relatives of a schizophrenic patient.

text 1: Parents, siblings, children, and dizygotic twins share 50% of their genetic material with the patient.
text 2: Parents, siblings, children, and dizygotic twins share 100% of their genetic material with the patient.

text 1: If only a single gene accounted for schizophrenia, the risk should differ for parents, siblings, children, and dizygotic twins of patients.
text 2: If only a single gene accounted for schizophrenia, the risk should be the same for parents, siblings, children, and dizygotic twins of patients.

text 1: Each cell in the body contains the DNA for every gene but only expresses a specific subset of the genes as RNAs.
text 2: Each cell in the body only contains the DNA for the genes it needs to express.

text 1: Promoters are typically found close to the beginning of the region to be transcribed.
text 2: Promoters are found distant from the beginning of the region to be transcribed.

text 1: The brain expresses a greater number of genes than any other organ in the body.
text 2: The brain expresses fewer genes than most other organs in the body.

text 1: A gene consists only of coding regions (exons) with no noncoding regions.
text 2: A gene consists of coding regions (exons) separated by noncoding regions (introns).

text 1: Transcription produces only exons in the RNA transcript, without introns.
text 2: Transcription leads to production of a primary single-stranded RNA transcript that includes both exons and introns.

text 1: Humans have about 20,000 genes but only 46 chromosomes.
text 2: Humans have about 20,000 genes and 44 chromosomes.

text 1: Most multicellular animals are haploid; every somatic cell carries one complete set of chromosomes.
text 2: Most multicellular animals are diploid; every somatic cell carries two complete sets of chromosomes.

text 1: Environmental influences can alter the expression of genes in neural circuits.
text 2: Environmental influences have no effect on gene expression in neural circuits.

text 1: Genes interact with the environment to influence biological processes.
text 2: Genes function independently and do not interact with the environment in influencing biological processes.

text 1: DNA double helix consists of a sugar phosphate backbone with four different nucleotide bases.
text 2: DNA double helix consists solely of nucleotide bases without a sugar phosphate backbone.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex helps maintain gaze constant when the body remains still.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex helps maintain gaze constant when the head moves.

text 1: Vestibular signals are important for perception despite changing retinal images.

text 2: The cerebellum enhances the vestibulo-ocular reflex during volitional head movements.

text 1: Optokinetic nystagmus is a full-field stabilization system maintaining nystagmus.
text 2: Optokinetic nystagmus is a foveal stabilization system maintaining nystagmus.

text 1: After adaptation of the VOR, Purkinje cell input to target neurons remains necessary.
text 2: After adaptation of the VOR, Purkinje cell input to target neurons is no longer necessary.

text 1: Glasses for nearsightedness require an increase in the VOR gain.
text 2: Glasses for farsightedness require an increase in the VOR gain.

text 1: Plasticity of the VOR is evident in patients with cerebellar disease, often characterized by abnormal VOR response.
text 2: Vestibular plasticity is not evident in patients with cerebellar disease.

text 1: Spatial awareness is independent of orientation relative to gravity.

text 1: The parietoinsular vestibular cortex is involved in processing multisensory motion stimuli.

text 1: Vestibular signals are central within a purely vestibular cortex.

text 1: Multisensory cue integration aids the perception of motion through space.
text 2: Multisensory cue integration impairs the perception of motion through space.

text 1: Tilt perception neglects vestibular information for spatial orientation.
text 2: Tilt perception involves vestibular information critical for spatial orientation.

text 1: Vestibular information to the thalamus is simple and unisensory.
text 2: Vestibular information to the thalamus remains complicated due to its multisensory nature.

text 1: Patients with lesions in the parietoinsular vestibular cortex report vertigo and loss of visual vertical perception.
text 2: Patients with lesions in the parietoinsular vestibular cortex do not report vertigo.

text 1: Declarative memory tends to be easily forgotten, although repeated exposure can lead to long-lasting retention.
text 2: Declarative memory tends to be resistant to forgetting, and repeated exposure is usually unnecessary for retention.

text 1: Sensorimotor learning can be divided into two broad classes: adaptations to alterations in properties of sensorimotor systems and learning new skills.
text 2: Sensorimotor learning can only be categorized as learning new skills, disregarding adaptations to alterations in properties of sensorimotor systems.

text 1: Error-based learning ignores sensory prediction errors, focusing solely on internal sensorimotor models.

text 1: When shooting a basketball, the difference between the actual and desired outcome is termed the target error.

text 1: Error-based learning tends to lead to trial-by-trial reduction in error.
text 2: Error-based learning tends to maintain the same level of error trial-by-trial.

text 1: Early in learning, co-contraction increases the errors while an internal model is being learned.

text 1: Subjects normally show a large aftereffect in the opposite direction, demonstrating they have compensated for the perturbation.

text 1: Adaptation is composed of underlying processes that adapt on different timescales.
text 2: Adaptation is composed of a single process that adapts uniformly over one timescale.

text 1: Accuracy measures systematic errors or biases, while precision measures random errors or statistical variability.
text 2: Accuracy measures random errors, while precision measures systematic errors or biases.

text 1: Vision is more important than proprioception and tactile input in learning dynamic tasks.
text 2: Proprioception and tactile input are more important than vision in learning dynamic tasks.

text 1: Error-based learning processes appear to underlie adaptation across different movement types and effectors.
text 2: Error-based learning processes rarely underlie adaptation across different movement types and effectors.

text 1: Learning skills involves improving performance in the presence of continuous perturbations.

text 1: Maurice Smith and colleagues have demonstrated that adaptation results from a single underlying process.
text 2: Maurice Smith and colleagues have demonstrated that adaptation is composed of multiple underlying processes.

text 1: Once a motor task is no longer performed, deadaptation is typically faster.
text 2: Once a motor task is no longer performed, deadaptation is typically slower.

text 1: Most motor learning tends to become automatic with time.

text 1: Long-term depression may depend on a metabotropic action of NMDA receptor-channels.

text 1: LTD is likely necessary to enhance LTP saturation and reduce memory storage flexibility.
text 2: LTD is likely necessary to prevent LTP saturation and enhance memory storage flexibility.

text 2: Mice froze in a neutral environment when specific neurons were light-activated.

text 1: Pattern separation in the hippocampus involves distinct firing patterns formed by projection onto a population of target cells.

text 1: The entorhinal cortex is critical for differentiating between similar environments.

text 1: Experimental data show freezing response is greater in light-activated conditions.

text 1: Memory retrieval requires activation of specific cell assemblies.
text 2: Memory retrieval does not require activation of specific cell assemblies.

text 1: The cerebellum is critical in processing fear in humans.

text 1: This region of the brain, together with the cerebellum, may also be the most important for our conscious experience of emotions.

text 1: Increasingly, modern studies use sophisticated genetic and cellular techniques solely to measure muscle function.
text 2: Increasingly, modern studies use sophisticated genetic and cellular techniques to image and causally manipulate brain function.

text 1: Motivational states influence attentiveness, goal selection, investment of effort in the pursuit of goals, and responsiveness to stimuli.
text 2: Motivational states do not influence attentiveness, goal selection, investment of effort in the pursuit of goals, and responsiveness to stimuli.

text 1: Internal variables include physiological signals concerning hunger or thirst.

text 1: Repeated exposure to a drug of abuse has no lasting impact.

text 1: Motivational states are only influenced by current rewarding stimuli, not predictive ones.
text 2: Motivational states can be influenced by stimuli that predict future rewarding and aversive events.

text 1: Natural addictions share biological mechanisms with drug addictions.

text 1: Motivational states have no relation to an individual's desires.

text 1: Motivational states are influenced only by internal variables.
text 2: Motivational states are influenced by both internal and external variables.

text 1: Ablation or inhibition of areas 2 or 5 produces deficits in roughness discrimination but few other alterations in passive touch.

text 1: Long-term depression at synapses in the amygdala may mediate threat conditioning.

text 2: Low-frequency tetanic stimulation of the direct or indirect pathway from the thalamus to the lateral nucleus initiates long-term potentiation (LTP).

text 1: The basolateral complex of the amygdala includes three key input nuclei: lateral (LA), basolateral (BL), and basomedial (BM).

text 1: Threat learning can be induced by pairing an auditory conditioned stimulus with direct depolarization of lateral amygdala neurons.

text 2: Researchers infected pyramidal neurons in the lateral nucleus with a virus causing expression of AMPA receptors tagged with a fluorescent label.

text 1: Studies have implicated pathways to the hippocampus in human threat learning.

text 2: An aversive shock itself is not necessary to induce threat learning; rather, it is the association of a stimulus with activation of the lateral amygdala that is key.

text 1: A human subject trained to do rapid finger movements will improve in accuracy and speed after 3 weeks of daily training.
text 2: A human subject trained to do rapid finger movements will improve in accuracy and speed after 3 days of daily training.

text 1: Functional imaging studies have found that the hippocampus is activated by threats only when the person is aware of the presence of the threat.

text 1: Neurons expressing lower levels of CREB are selectively recruited during threat learning.
text 2: Neurons expressing higher levels of CREB are selectively recruited during threat learning.

text 1: In glial cells, the resting potential is approximately -75 mV due to permeability to only Na+ ions.
text 2: In glial cells, the resting potential is approximately -75 mV due to permeability to only K+ ions.

text 1: Na+ and K+ are concentrated outside the cell and Cl− and A− are concentrated inside the cell in nerve cells.

text 1: The sodium-potassium pump uses ATP to extrude two Na+ ions and bring in three K+ ions.
text 2: The sodium-potassium pump uses ATP to extrude three Na+ ions and bring in two K+ ions.

text 1: The equilibrium potential for K+ in the squid giant axon is -75 mV.
text 2: The equilibrium potential for K+ in the squid giant axon is +75 mV.

text 1: The Nernst equation helps calculate the equilibrium potential of any ion present on both sides of a membrane.
text 2: The Nernst equation can only be used for ions that are not present on both sides of the membrane.

text 1: In a resting nerve cell, the membrane conductance of K+ is relatively high.
text 2: In a resting nerve cell, the membrane conductance of Na+ is relatively high.

text 1: Glial cells have high concentrations of Na+ and Cl− on the inside and K+ and A− on the outside.
text 2: Glial cells have high concentrations of K+ and A− on the inside and Na+ and Cl− on the outside.

text 1: Nerve cells are permeable to Na+, K+, and A− ions at rest.
text 2: Nerve cells are permeable to Na+, K+, and Cl− ions at rest.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump generates a net outward ionic current by extruding three Na+ and bringing in two K+.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump generates a net inward ionic current by extruding two K+ and bringing in three Na+.

text 1: The electrical driving force on Na+ exactly balances the chemical driving force at the K+ equilibrium potential.
text 2: The electrical driving force on K+ exactly balances the chemical driving force at the K+ equilibrium potential.

text 1: In glial cells, the flux of K+ is determined by the concentration gradient alone.
text 2: In glial cells, the flux of K+ is determined by both the K+ concentration gradient and the membrane potential.

text 1: A nerve cell's resting membrane potential is slightly more negative than the K+ equilibrium potential.
text 2: A nerve cell's resting membrane potential is slightly more positive than the K+ equilibrium potential.

text 1: The sodium-potassium pump moves ions along their electrochemical gradients.
text 2: The sodium-potassium pump moves ions against their electrochemical gradients.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump is electrogenic because it extrudes more positive charge than it brings in.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump is electrogenic because it brings in more positive charge than it extrudes.

text 1: The membrane potential in glial cells is generated by the efflux of K+ down its concentration gradient.
text 2: The membrane potential in glial cells is generated by the influx of Na+ down its concentration gradient.

text 1: The ability of different motor systems to perform different behaviors is called motor equivalence.
text 2: The ability of different motor systems to achieve the same behavior is called motor equivalence.

text 1: The cost of movement is a way of quantifying what is good or bad about a movement.
text 2: The cost of movement is a way of ensuring all movements have consistent quality.

text 1: Increase in movement accuracy with increasing speed is known as the speed–accuracy trade-off.
text 2: Decrease in movement accuracy with increasing speed is known as the speed–accuracy trade-off.

text 1: Effort and accuracy typically align easily without conflict during movement.
text 2: Effort and accuracy are generally in conflict during movement.

text 1: Optimal feedback control does not make a hard distinction between feedforward and feedback control.
text 2: Optimal feedback control makes a clear distinction between feedforward and feedback control.

text 1: Intervening often enhances motor control performance by minimizing variability.
text 2: Intervening unnecessarily in motor control will lead to a decrement in performance.

text 1: The aim of optimal feedback control is to eliminate all disturbances regardless of cost.
text 2: The aim of optimal feedback control is to minimize cost even in the presence of disturbances.

text 1: Optimal feedback control emphasizes setting feedback gains tuned to the task.
text 2: Optimal feedback control reduces the need for feedback gains specific to each task.

text 1: Implicit learning requires constant practice to be retained for extended periods.
text 2: Implicit learning can be retained for extended periods without practice.

text 1: Skill learning always prioritizes speed over accuracy.
text 2: Part of skill learning involves increasing speed without sacrificing accuracy.

text 1: Motor noise enhances success in movement tasks by reducing variability.
text 2: Motor noise limits success in movement tasks.

text 1: The same result will always have the same cost regardless of the method used.
text 2: Different ways of achieving a task will lead to different costs.

text 1: Optimal feedback control allows for task-irrelevant variability.
text 2: Optimal feedback control aims to eliminate all variability in movement.

text 1: The minimize intervention principle promotes frequent intervention for precision.
text 2: The minimize intervention principle advises intervening only if deviations affect task success.

text 1: Motor learning is not necessary for adapting to new environments.
text 2: Motor learning is required to adapt to new environments.

text 1: Batteries in BMIs would need to be larger and replaced more often.
text 2: Batteries in BMIs would need to be smaller, yet replaced more often.

text 1: Using power in BMIs generates heat, which the brain can tolerate only in small increases.
text 2: Using power in BMIs generates heat, which the brain can tolerate in large increases.

text 1: Software running on electronic hardware is optional in BMIs.

text 1: The activity of a single neuron can unambiguously provide movement decoding information.
text 2: The activity of a single neuron cannot unambiguously provide movement decoding information.

text 1: BMIs leverage the activity of many neurons to decode movements.
text 2: BMIs leverage the activity of a single neuron to decode movements.

text 1: The motor system exhibits minimal redundancy, with few neurons carrying similar movement information.
text 2: The motor system exhibits a great deal of redundancy, with many neurons carrying similar movement information.

text 1: Communication BMIs can use both discrete and continuous decoders to select movement goals.
text 2: Communication BMIs can only use discrete decoders to select movement goals.

text 1: Decoding algorithms estimate intended movements from neural activity.

text 1: Continuous decoders in BMIs solve regression problems.
text 2: Continuous decoders in BMIs solve classification problems.

text 1: In BMIs, movement decoding uses the activity of many neurons on a single trial.
text 2: In BMIs, movement information is accurately decoded using the activity of a single neuron in multiple trials.

text 1: Neural activity is usually not noisy and can consistently determine movement directions.

text 1: Using more neurons in BMIs typically allows for more accurate movement direction decoding.
text 2: Using fewer neurons in BMIs typically allows for more accurate movement direction decoding.

text 1: The spike histogram for one neuron can be used to fully decode movement direction.
text 2: The spike histogram for many neurons can be used to help decode movement direction.

text 1: Discrete decoders estimate the moment-by-moment details of a movement trajectory.
text 2: Continuous decoders estimate the moment-by-moment details of a movement trajectory.

text 1: Millions of neurons across brain areas work together to produce simple movements like reaching for a cup.
text 2: Millions of neurons across brain areas work together to produce complex movements like typing.

text 1: At some central synapses, the presynaptic terminal contains multiple active zones, and each active zone releases multiple vesicles in response to an action potential.

text 1: The distribution of responses is composed of the sum of several exponential functions.

text 1: The unit response has the same amplitude as the spontaneous miniature end-plate potentials, indicating that it is caused by the release of a single quantum of transmitter.

text 1: The parameter n describes the maximum number of quantal units that can be released in response to a single action potential if the probability p reaches 1.0.
text 2: The parameter n describes the minimum number of quantal units that can be released in response to a single action potential if the probability p reaches 1.0.

text 1: In the central nervous system, most presynaptic boutons have multiple active zones where an action potential usually releases at most a single quantum of transmitter.
text 2: In the central nervous system, most presynaptic boutons have only a single active zone where an action potential usually releases at most a single quantum of transmitter.

text 1: The mean size of a synaptic response is often described as the product of the probability that an individual quantum is released, the number of synapses, and the duration of synaptic activity.

text 1: The variability associated with each quantal event increases linearly with the number of quanta per event.
text 2: The variability associated with each quantal event decreases linearly with the number of quanta per event.

text 1: The probability of transmitter release follows a Poisson distribution.
text 2: The probability of transmitter release follows a normal distribution.

text 1: Quantal transmission has been demonstrated at only some chemical synapses examined.
text 2: Quantal transmission has been demonstrated at all chemical synapses so far examined.

text 1: The spread of the unit peak reflects the consistency in the amount of transmitter in a quantum.
text 2: The spread of the unit peak reflects the variability in the amount of transmitter in a quantum.

text 1: The postsynaptic response reaches only a minimal amplitude when the postsynaptic receptor sites become fully occupied by transmitter.

text 1: Synaptic strength is independent of the probability of transmitter release and other quantal parameters.

text 1: The probability of vesicle release encompasses the need for sustainable K+ influx.

text 1: The product of n and p yields an estimate m of the mean number of quanta that will be released.

text 1: Active zones are generally found scattered randomly with no relation to the postsynaptic membrane patches that contain neurotransmitter receptors.

text 1: In the prefrontal cortex, persistent states represent plans of action, abstract rules, and strategies.
text 2: In the prefrontal cortex, persistent states represent only sensory responses and reflex actions.

text 1: Decision-makers take more time to choose between items of similar value than items that differ substantially in value.
text 2: Decision-makers take less time to choose between items of similar value than items that differ substantially in value.

text 1: The striatum encodes the value associated with an action.

text 1: The analogy to perceptual decision-making fully captures the interesting aspects of value-based decisions.
text 2: The analogy to perceptual decision-making misses the more interesting aspects of value-based decisions.

text 1: Persistent neural activity is only found in the sensory areas and does not associate with memory.
text 2: Persistent neural activity is apparent in areas of the brain that associate sources of information from senses and memory.

text 1: The value of most items is not given by biology but instead is learned.
text 2: The value of most items is strictly determined by biology and not subject to learning.

text 1: Perceptual decision-making is referenced to understand broader cognitive functions.
text 2: Perceptual decision-making is irrelevant to understanding cognitive functions.

text 1: Knowledge states require continuous sensory input to persist.
text 2: Knowledge states persist without continuous sensory input.

text 1: The parietal association neurons interrogate the sensory areas for evidence of a possible behavior.
text 2: The parietal association neurons do not interact with the sensory areas at all.

text 1: The computation leading to a knowledge state has the structure of a decision.
text 2: The computation leading to a knowledge state is purely sensory.

text 1: Gibson was criticized for claiming perceptual processes directly picked up affordances from the optical array.
text 2: Gibson's theories were universally accepted without criticism regarding perceptual processes.

text 1: Hemineglect involves enhanced perception of the neglected side of the visual field.
text 2: Hemineglect involves ignoring one side of the visual field due to damage in areas like the parietal lobe.

text 1: States of knowledge are often tied to possible behaviors rather than just features of sensory information.
text 2: States of knowledge are always restricted to features of sensory information and not behaviors.

text 1: Perceptual decision-making can help explain inconsistent decisions in preference choices.
text 2: Perceptual decision-making has no relation to decisions in preference choices.

text 1: The representation of potential behavior is like a provisional commitment to a plan.
text 2: The representation of potential behavior is a definitive commitment to automatic action.

text 1: Neurons in the association cortex represent the possibility of acting, not an immediate action.
text 2: Neurons in the association cortex directly command immediate actions.

text 1: The cyclic AMP pathway is among the best-understood second-messenger signaling cascades.
text 2: The cyclic AMP pathway is among the least-understood second-messenger signaling cascades.

text 1: Endocannabinoids are synthesized from protein precursors and can act across synapses as retrograde messengers.
text 2: Endocannabinoids are synthesized from lipid precursors and can act across synapses as retrograde messengers.

text 1: The M-type current is a rapidly activating voltage-gated Na+ current that underlies action potential adaptation.
text 2: The M-type current is a slowly activating voltage-gated K+ current that underlies action potential adaptation.

text 1: Neuromodulators can close ion channels, thus producing increases in membrane conductance.
text 2: Neuromodulators can close ion channels, thus producing decreases in membrane conductance.

text 1: Transmitter release is regulated by depolarization of the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: Transmitter release is regulated by polarization of the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: Calcium binding to synapsin triggers transmitter release.
text 2: Calcium binding to synaptotagmin triggers transmitter release.

text 1: SNARE proteins catalyze fusion of vesicles with the plasma membrane.

text 1: Synaptic vesicles discharge transmitter by endocytosis and are recycled by exocytosis.
text 2: Synaptic vesicles discharge transmitter by exocytosis and are recycled by endocytosis.

text 1: The synapsins are important for vesicle restraint and mobilization.
text 2: The synapsins are unimportant for vesicle restraint and mobilization.

text 1: The receptor tyrosine kinases gate ion channels directly in response to binding various peptide hormones.
text 2: The receptor tyrosine kinases gate ion channels indirectly in response to binding various peptide hormones.

text 1: At most central synapses, transmitter is released from the presynaptic cell at presynaptic boutons.

text 2: Phospholipase C produces ATP and IP3, which play important roles in intracellular Ca2+ handling.

text 1: Transmitter release is triggered by sodium influx.

text 1: Transmitter is released in continuous units.

text 1: The fusion machinery is embedded in a conserved protein scaffold at the active zone.
text 2: The fusion machinery is embedded in a random protein collection at the active zone.

text 1: Auditory nerve fibers terminate in the ventral and dorsal cochlear nuclei, distributing acoustic information to four major groups of principal cells that form parallel ascending pathways through the brain stem.
text 2: Auditory nerve fibers terminate in the ventral and dorsal cochlear nuclei, distributing acoustic information to a single group of principal cells forming a singular ascending pathway through the brain stem.

text 1: Mammals use spectral filtering of sounds greater than approximately 6,000 Hz by the head, shoulders, and external ears to determine sound location in the vertical dimension and whether they arise from the front or the back.
text 2: Mammals use spectral filtering of sounds greater than approximately 3,000 Hz by the head, shoulders, and external ears to determine sound location in the vertical dimension and whether they arise from the front or the back.

text 1: The dorsal cochlear nucleus integrates acoustic signals with somatosensory information in its principal cells.
text 2: The ventral cochlear nucleus integrates acoustic signals with somatosensory information in its principal cells.

text 1: Auditory brainstem pathways diverge in the inferior colliculus.
text 2: Auditory brainstem pathways converge in the inferior colliculus.

text 1: Auditory cortex is involved in processing visual feedback signals during speaking.
text 2: Auditory cortex is involved in processing vocal feedback signals during speaking.

text 1: Speaking induces an increase in neural activity in auditory cortex that begins several hundred milliseconds prior to the vocal onset.
text 2: Speaking induces suppression of neural activity in auditory cortex that begins several hundred milliseconds prior to the vocal onset.

text 1: Auditory circuits in the cerebral cortex are segregated into separate processing streams, with dorsal and ventral streams concerned respectively with sound location in space and sound identification.
text 2: Auditory circuits in the cerebral cortex are merged into a single processing stream, with both dorsal and ventral streams concerned with sound identification.

text 1: A projection from the inferior colliculus carries information about the location of sounds to the superior colliculus.
text 2: A projection from the inferior colliculus carries information about the location of sounds to the amygdala.

text 1: The inferior colliculus feeds acoustic information through the medial geniculate body of the thalamus to auditory cortex.
text 2: The inferior colliculus feeds visual information through the medial geniculate body of the thalamus to auditory cortex.

text 1: To determine where sounds arise in the horizontal plane, many mammals compute differences in the time of arrival at the two ears for sounds greater than approximately 3,000 Hz.
text 2: To determine where sounds arise in the horizontal plane, many mammals compute differences in the time of arrival at the two ears for sounds less than approximately 3,000 Hz.

text 1: Auditory neurons continue to become more selective to the stimuli to which they respond within auditory cortex.
text 2: Auditory neurons become less selective to the stimuli to which they respond within auditory cortex.

text 1: Auditory cortex transforms slowly varying features of sounds into firing-rate-based representations.
text 2: Auditory cortex also transforms rapidly varying features of sounds into firing-rate-based representations.

text 1: Projections from the auditory cortex innervate only the thalamus and inferior colliculus, excluding other structures.
text 2: Projections from the auditory cortex innervate the thalamus, inferior colliculus, olivocochlear neurons, some basal ganglionic structures, and even the dorsal cochlear nucleus.

text 1: Octopus cells detect and sharpen the encoding of spectral peaks and valleys and convey that spectral information to the dorsal cochlear nucleus.
text 2: Stellate cells detect and sharpen the encoding of spectral peaks and valleys and convey that spectral information to the dorsal cochlear nucleus.

text 1: Bushy cells sharpen and convey information about the fine structure of sounds used in the binaural pathways to make interaural comparisons of timing and intensity.
text 2: Bushy cells diffuse and convey information about the fine structure of sounds used in the monaural pathways to make interaural comparisons of timing and intensity.

text 1: Norepinephrine stimulates smooth muscle contraction in arteries, urethra, gastrointestinal tract, and iris.
text 2: Norepinephrine relaxes smooth muscle in arteries, urethra, gastrointestinal tract, and iris.

text 1: Vasoactive intestinal peptide causes constriction of blood vessels supplying the gland to control secretion.
text 2: Vasoactive intestinal peptide causes dilation of blood vessels supplying the gland to control secretion.

text 1: The parasympathetic system promotes arousal, defense, and escape, whereas the sympathetic system promotes eating and procreation.
text 2: The sympathetic system promotes arousal, defense, and escape, whereas the parasympathetic system promotes eating and procreation.

text 1: Cotransmission involves the activation of more than one type of receptor by more than one transmitter.
text 2: Cotransmission involves the activation of only one type of receptor by one transmitter.

text 1: The baroreceptor reflex prevents orthostatic hypotension by compensating for rapid hydrostatic effects produced by changes in posture.
text 2: The baroreceptor reflex prevents hypertension by compensating for rapid hydrostatic effects produced by changes in posture.

text 1: Acetylcholine can activate both nicotinic and muscarinic receptors to produce slow and fast postsynaptic potentials, respectively.
text 2: Acetylcholine can activate both nicotinic and muscarinic receptors to produce fast and slow postsynaptic potentials, respectively.

text 1: Walter Cannon introduced the concept of homeostasis and appreciated that the fight-or-flight response is a sympathetic function.
text 2: Walter Cannon introduced the concept of homeostasis and believed the fight-or-flight response is a parasympathetic function.

text 1: Neuropeptide Y inhibits arterial contraction and reduces responses mediated by α1-adrenergic receptors.
text 2: Neuropeptide Y stimulates arterial contraction and potentiates responses mediated by α1-adrenergic receptors.

text 1: Acetylcholine and nitric oxide are frequently co-released from neurons that control glandular secretion.
text 2: Acetylcholine and vasoactive intestinal peptide are frequently co-released from neurons that control glandular secretion.

text 1: The micturition reflex is solely controlled by the parasympathetic system.
text 2: The micturition reflex involves coordination between sympathetic and parasympathetic systems.

text 1: Parasympathetic activity is critical for long-term blood pressure regulation.
text 2: Sympathetic activity is critical for long-term blood pressure regulation.

text 1: The sympathetic system is less diffusely organized than originally envisioned by Cannon.
text 2: The sympathetic system is more diffusely organized than originally envisioned by Cannon.

text 1: The baroreceptor reflex has a slower onset and is longer in its parasympathetic component compared to its sympathetic counterpart.
text 2: The baroreceptor reflex has a more rapid onset and is briefer in its parasympathetic component compared to its sympathetic counterpart.

text 1: The parasympathetic system can promote bladder contraction.

text 1: The nucleus of the solitary tract relays visceral sensory information to both the brain stem and forebrain.

text 1: The fine manipulative capacity provided by our fingers is possible because of their muscular strength.

text 1: The glabrous skin's hardness and rigidity play a major role in the sense of touch.

text 1: The heels are among the most densely innervated parts of the body.
text 2: The fingertips are among the most densely innervated parts of the body.

text 1: These receptors provide information about an object's position in the hand and its shape.
text 2: These receptors provide information about an object's color and weight.

text 1: The hand's anatomical structure enables humans to shape the hand in ways that mirror an object's color.
text 2: The hand's anatomical structure enables humans to shape the hand in ways that mirror an object's overall shape.

text 1: When we become skilled in the use of a tool, like a scalpel, we feel conditions at the tool's tip as if they occur at our fingertips.
text 2: When we become skilled in the use of a tool, like a scalpel, we feel conditions at the tool's handle as if they occur at our fingertips.

text 1: Active touch engages sensorimotor circuits in the posterior parietal cortex.

text 1: Only slowly adapting fibers are important for grip control.

text 1: Cortical columns are organized visually.
text 2: Cortical columns are organized somatotopically.

text 1: Tactile information becomes increasingly abstract in successive central synapses.
text 2: Tactile information becomes increasingly concrete in successive central synapses.

text 1: Lesions in somatosensory areas of the brain enhance tactile acuity.
text 2: Lesions in somatosensory areas of the brain produce specific tactile deficits.

text 1: The somatosensory cortex is organized into functionally uniform layers.

text 1: Active and passive touch have identical goals.
text 2: Active and passive touch have distinct goals.

text 1: Two-point discrimination tests measure tactile acuity.
text 2: Two-point discrimination tests measure visual acuity.

text 1: Rapidly adapting fibers detect motion and vibration.

text 1: Lesions in the spinocerebellum have large effects on smooth-pursuit eye movements.

text 1: Mossy fibers terminate in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex and excite granule cells.

text 1: The spinocerebellum is larger in humans and apes relative to its size in monkeys and cats.

text 1: The forebrain in primitive vertebrates, such as reptiles, amphibians, and fish, is mainly devoted to olfactory processing and the integration of autonomic and endocrine functions.
text 2: The forebrain in primitive vertebrates, such as reptiles, amphibians, and fish, is mainly devoted to auditory processing and the regulation of visual functions.

text 1: Hydranencephalic infants demonstrate that the brain stem can organize virtually all of the behavior of the newborn.

text 1: The action potential is generated by the flow of ions through voltage-gated channels.

text 1: Hodgkin and Huxley used the voltage clamp to measure the conductance of non-gated Na+ and K+ channels.

text 2: Voltage-gated sodium channels select sodium based on size, charge, and energy of hydration.

text 1: The action potential is conducted with decrement, causing the amplitude to decrease.

text 1: Neuronal excitability is fixed.

text 1: Action potentials were first recorded in the late 1900s.

text 1: The voltage clamp enhances the interaction between membrane potential and ion channel gating.

text 1: Voltage-gated hyperpolarization-deactivated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels exist.

text 1: Excitability properties are universal across all types of neurons.

text 1: All regions of the human brain equally process information for every sensory modality, multisensory systems, motor activity, or cognitive function.

text 1: The human cerebral cortex has been divided into 120 functional areas by the Human Connectome Project based largely on a variety of EEG techniques and neuroanatomy.
text 2: The human cerebral cortex has been divided into 180 functional areas by the Human Connectome Project based largely on a variety of fMRI techniques and neuroanatomy.

text 1: Gray-scaled regions of the brain exclusively serve sensory functions, comprising the anticorrelated 'task-positive' and 'default mode' networks.

text 1: Functional maps of early cortical areas are somatotopic, retinotopic, or tonotopic, maintaining location-specific features of sensory stimuli.

text 1: Visual features transmitted in a ventral pathway help identify what an object is and are conveyed to the temporal lobe, hippocampus, and entorhinal cortex.
text 2: Visual features transmitted in a ventral pathway help detect where an object is and are conveyed to the parietal lobe, amygdala, and hypothalamus.

text 1: Primary sensory areas of the cerebral cortex contain topographically organized maps corresponding to receptor locations.
text 2: Primary sensory areas of the cerebral cortex disregard receptor locations entirely, functioning without any topographic organization.

text 1: Each of the human cerebral cortex’s primary sensory areas consists of approximately 10 million neurons.
text 2: Each of the human cerebral cortex’s primary sensory areas consists of approximately 100 million neurons.

text 1: Neurons in the cerebral cortex exclusively integrate stimulus features related to spatial location without considering edge orientation or motion direction.
text 2: Neurons in the cerebral cortex integrate stimulus features like edge orientation, motion direction, and tonal sequences.

text 1: Central sensory neurons exhibit less variability in their responses to stimuli compared to peripheral receptors.
text 2: Central sensory neurons exhibit more variability in their responses to stimuli compared to peripheral receptors.

text 1: Hierarchical processing networks transmit sensory information initiated by skin stimuli directly to the cerebral cortex without intermediate processing.

text 1: Attention amplifies all sensory stimulus responses equally, preventing selective focus on task-related inputs in cortical areas.
text 2: Attention modifies sensory stimulus responses, allowing selective focus on task-related inputs in cortical areas.

text 1: Neurons in each successive stage of cortical processing become increasingly concerned with descriptive features, ignoring behavioral importance.
text 2: Neurons in each successive stage of cortical processing become less concerned with descriptive features and more focused on behavioral importance.

text 1: Feed-forward inhibition in relay nuclei is initiated by cortical descending commands acting on inhibitory interneurons.
text 2: Feed-forward inhibition in relay nuclei is initiated by sensory neuron afferent fibers terminating on inhibitory interneurons.

text 1: Descending inhibition allows cortical neurons to control the afferent relay of sensory information, aiding in attention selection.
text 2: Descending inhibition prevents cortical neurons from controlling the afferent relay of sensory information, limiting attention selection.

text 1: Inhibitory circuits suppress irrelevant information during goal-directed behaviors, focusing attention on specific task-related inputs.
text 2: Inhibitory circuits enhance irrelevant information during goal-directed behaviors, preventing focus on specific task-related inputs.

text 1: Microtubules grow by addition of guanosine triphosphate (GTP)-bound tubulin dimers at their plus end.

text 1: In Alzheimer disease, abnormal aggregates of tau are visible in the light microscope.
text 2: In Alzheimer disease, left-handed helix formations of tau are visible in the light microscope.

text 1: Microtubules are polarized with a plus end and a minus end.
text 2: Microtubules are non-polarized with ends of equal reactivity.

text 1: Tau accumulations assist axonal transport and aid the polymerization of tubulin.
text 2: Tau accumulations interfere with axonal transport and disturb the polymerization of tubulin.

text 1: Neurofilaments are unstable and frequently depolymerized in the cell.
text 2: Neurofilaments are stable and almost totally polymerized in the cell.

text 1: Actin filaments are short and concentrated at the cell’s periphery.
text 2: Actin filaments are elongated and concentrated at the cell's center.

text 1: MAP2 is present in dendrites but not in axons, where tau proteins and MAP1b are present.
text 2: MAP2 is present in axons but not in dendrites, where tau proteins and MAP1b are present.

text 1: In Parkinson disease, abnormal aggregates of β-synuclein accumulate in cell bodies of neurons.
text 2: In Parkinson disease, abnormal aggregates of α-synuclein accumulate in cell bodies of neurons.

text 1: The cytoskeleton includes four filamentous structures: microtubules, neurofilaments, microfilaments, and elastofilaments.
text 2: The cytoskeleton includes three filamentous structures: microtubules, neurofilaments, and microfilaments.

text 1: At least two genes code the α- and β-tubulin subunits, resulting in more than 10 isoforms present in the brain.
text 2: At least six genes code the α- and β-tubulin subunits, resulting in more than 20 isoforms present in the brain.

text 1: Microfilaments are the smallest-diameter fibers, approximately 7 nm.
text 2: Microfilaments are the largest-diameter fibers, approximately 25 nm.

text 1: Protofilament is made up of alternating γ- and δ-tubulin subunits.
text 2: Protofilament is made up of alternating α- and β-tubulin subunits.

text 1: A single microtubule can be as long as 0.1 mm.
text 2: A single microtubule can be as long as 0.5 mm.

text 1: Microtubules remain static in dividing cells, avoiding cycles of polymerization and depolymerization.
text 2: Microtubules undergo rapid cycles of polymerization and depolymerization in dividing cells.

text 1: Neurofibrillary tangles accumulate in neuronal cell bodies, dendrites, and axons.
text 2: Neurofibrillary tangles accumulate exclusively in the extracellular space.

text 1: GTP-bound tubulin dimers facilitate microtubule growth when added at the plus end.
text 2: GDP-bound tubulin dimers facilitate microtubule shrinkage when added at the minus end.

text 1: The terminals of sensory neurons form synapses with muscle fibers at specialized regions in the muscle membrane called end-plates.
text 2: The terminals of motor neurons form synapses with muscle fibers at specialized regions in the muscle membrane called end-plates.

text 1: Ligand binding causes the subunits to tilt outward and twist, opening up the leucine gate.
text 2: Ligand binding causes the subunits to tilt inward and twist, closing the leucine gate.

text 1: A conserved leucine in the middle of the M3 segment (position 9) forms a gate that constricts the pore in the closed state.

text 1: Higher-resolution structures have provided a detailed view of the dopamine ligand-binding pocket and the pore of the channel.

text 1: The ACh receptor is a pentamer composed of two α-subunits and one β-, γ-, and δ-subunit.

text 1: Patch-clamp recordings have revealed a smooth, continuous increase in current without discrete steps in response to the opening and closing of single ACh receptor-channels.
text 2: Patch-clamp recordings have revealed the step-like increase and decrease in current in response to the opening and closing of single ACh receptor-channels.

text 1: The net effect of ACh binding is largely due to the influx of Cl- ions, producing a depolarizing synaptic potential called the end-plate potential.
text 2: The net effect of ACh binding is largely due to the influx of Na+ ions, producing a depolarizing synaptic potential called the end-plate potential.

text 1: The current during the excitatory postsynaptic potential (IEPSP) is given by IEPSP = gEPSP × (Vm − EEPSP).

text 1: The end-plate region can be represented with an equivalent circuit that has three parallel current paths.

text 1: When no ACh is present, the ACh receptor-channels remain open and carry a steady current.
text 2: When no ACh is present, the ACh receptor-channels are closed and carry no current.

text 1: The negatively charged glutamates at positions 20, -1, and -4 correspond to the internal, middle, and external rings of charge.
text 2: The negatively charged glutamates at positions 20, -1, and -4 correspond to the external, middle, and internal rings of charge.

text 1: The end-plate conductance is parallel with a battery (EEPSP) with a value given by the reversal potential for synaptic current (0 mV).

text 1: The current through a population of ACh receptor-channels can be described by Kirchhoff’s laws.

text 1: The negatively charged glutamate at position -1 and the electronegative threonine at position 2 form the selectivity filter of the channel.

text 1: The brain is only responsible for simple motor behaviors like walking, not complex cognitive acts such as thinking and creating art.

text 1: Disorders of affect (feeling) and cognition (thought) result from disturbances of brain function.
text 2: Disorders of affect (feeling) and cognition (thought) do not result from disturbances of brain function.

text 1: Explaining behavior in terms of environmental factors is a major task of neural science.
text 2: Explaining behavior in terms of brain activity is a major task of neural science.

text 1: DNA sequencing and measurements of electrical properties of individual neurons might be sufficient to understand and treat certain genetic epilepsy disorders.

text 1: Ramón y Cajal concluded that nervous tissue is a network of discrete cells, not a syncytium.
text 2: Ramón y Cajal concluded that nervous tissue is a syncytium, not a network of discrete cells.

text 1: The neuron doctrine is the principle that individual neurons are the signaling elements of the nervous system.
text 2: The neuron doctrine suggests that neurons are not the signaling elements of the nervous system.

text 1: Gall believed that the brain is the organ of the mind and that all mental functions are embodied in the brain.

text 1: Modern neural science aims to understand mind as a product of brain and its neural activity.
text 2: Modern neural science aims to understand mind as independent of brain and its neural activity.

text 1: Functional areas of the cerebral cortex were identified empirically through direct examination of the brain.
text 2: Functional areas of the cerebral cortex were identified through Gall's theory of phrenology, involving bumps on the skull.

text 1: Modern electrophysiology began in the late 1700s when Luigi Galvani discovered the conduction speed of electrical activity along axons.
text 2: Modern electrophysiology originated in the 19th century through the work of German physiologists who measured the conduction speed of electrical activity along axons.

text 1: All higher functions of the mind are localized to specific brain areas according to the dominant view today.
text 2: Some higher functions of the mind are most likely highly distributed according to the dominant view today.

text 1: Neural science views mind and body as separate, with independent functions and roles.
text 2: Neural science sees mind and body as not separate but rather unified in brain function.

text 1: Integrating specialized knowledge into a coherent science is the goal of modern neural science.
text 2: The goal of modern neural science is to specialize different knowledge areas without integration.

text 1: Cajal's observations opposed the neuron doctrine by showing a continuous web of tissue in nervous structure.
text 2: Cajal's observations supported the neuron doctrine by demonstrating discrete cellular structures in nervous tissue.

text 1: In modern neural science, questions about levels of organization and specialization recur frequently.
text 2: In modern neural science, questions about levels of organization and specialization are rarely considered.

text 1: H.M. underwent brain surgery at the age of 27 to address seizures caused by damage sustained in a bicycle accident at age 7.
text 2: H.M. underwent brain surgery at the age of 27 to address seizures caused by damage sustained in a car accident at age 7.

text 1: H.M. retained long-term memory for events that occurred after the surgery, including his name and childhood experiences.
text 2: H.M. retained long-term memory for events that occurred before the surgery, including his name and childhood experiences.

text 1: H.M. had normal working memory for seconds or minutes, but lacked the ability to transfer new information into long-term memory.
text 2: H.M. had normal working memory for hours or days, but lacked the ability to transfer new information into long-term memory.

text 1: H.M. could repeat a new telephone number immediately and retained it even after being briefly distracted.
text 2: H.M. could repeat a new telephone number immediately but forgot it when briefly distracted due to anterograde amnesia.

text 1: H.M. could not recognize people he met after surgery, even after seeing them repeatedly.
text 2: H.M. could recognize people he met after surgery if he saw them repeatedly.

text 1: H.M.'s case demonstrated that the medial temporal lobe is critical for memory formation.
text 2: H.M.'s case demonstrated that the medial temporal lobe is not critical for memory formation.

text 1: H.M.'s ability to learn and perform tasks such as star tracing demonstrates intact implicit memory despite his amnesia.
text 2: H.M.'s inability to learn tasks such as star tracing demonstrates impaired implicit memory following his amnesia.

text 1: Patients with medial temporal lobe damage retain simple reflexive learning, including sensitization and habituation.
text 2: Patients with medial temporal lobe damage lose all forms of reflexive learning, including sensitization and habituation.

text 1: H.M. performed worse than healthy subjects during priming tasks due to his inability to recall the presented information.
text 2: H.M. performed as well as healthy subjects during priming tasks, despite not consciously recalling the presented information.

text 1: Damage to the medial temporal lobe impairs both conscious and nonconscious forms of memory equally.
text 2: Damage to the medial temporal lobe impairs memories that can be accessed consciously, but leaves nonconscious forms of memory intact.

text 1: Explicit memory includes only episodic memory and is unaffected by medial temporal lobe damage.
text 2: Explicit memory includes episodic and semantic memory, which can be affected by medial temporal lobe damage.

text 1: Implicit memory is conscious and primarily involves recalling facts and autobiographical events.
text 2: Implicit memory is typically unconscious and involves skills, habits, and conditioning.

text 1: Tasks relying on implicit memory, such as skill learning, cannot be improved in amnesic patients.
text 2: Tasks relying on implicit memory, such as skill learning, can be improved in amnesic patients.

text 1: Explicit memory is inflexible and cannot associate multiple pieces of information under different circumstances.
text 2: Explicit memory is highly flexible and allows multiple pieces of information to be associated under different circumstances.

text 1: Implicit memory is independent of the conditions under which the learning occurred.
text 2: Implicit memory is tightly tied to the conditions under which the learning occurred.

text 1: Sleepwalking usually occurs during deep (stage N3) non-REM sleep in young children.
text 2: Sleepwalking usually occurs during REM sleep in young children.

text 1: Night terrors occur during stage N3 sleep and are common in children aged 2 to 5.
text 2: Night terrors occur during REM sleep and are common in children aged 2 to 5.

text 1: Sleep has little to no role in memory consolidation or synaptic remodeling.
text 2: Sleep is essential for memory consolidation through processes like synaptic remodeling during sleep.

text 1: Insomnia is primarily caused by reduced neural activity in the arousal system and is best treated with medication.
text 2: Insomnia is often caused by hyperactivation of the arousal system and is best treated with cognitive behavioral therapy.

text 1: Narcolepsy is caused by an increase in the number of orexin neurons in the hypothalamus.
text 2: Narcolepsy is caused by the selective loss of orexin neurons in the hypothalamus.

text 1: The extracellular space in the brain expands during sleep, aiding in the clearance of beta-amyloid peptides.
text 2: The extracellular space in the brain decreases during sleep, hindering clearance of beta-amyloid peptides.

text 1: REM sleep behavior disorder involves loss of atonia, causing the individual to act out their dreams.
text 2: REM sleep behavior disorder involves an absence of dreaming during REM sleep.

text 1: The suprachiasmatic nucleus plays no role in circadian rhythm regulation.
text 2: The suprachiasmatic nucleus plays a key role in synchronizing the circadian cycle with light signals.

text 1: Sleep apnea is treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) to restore airway patency.
text 2: Sleep apnea is treated by reducing N3 sleep with tricyclic antidepressants.

text 1: The waking state is driven by neurons in the ascending arousal network, including glutamatergic and dopaminergic neurons.
text 2: The waking state is inhibited by neurons in the ascending arousal system, including glutamatergic and dopaminergic neurons.

text 1: Sleep alternates between non-REM and REM stages, with a complete cycle taking about 90 minutes.
text 2: Sleep remains in one continuous stage throughout the night without clear alternation.

text 1: Prolonged sleep deprivation enhances cognitive function by reducing extracellular waste products in the brain.
text 2: Prolonged sleep deprivation may impair cognitive functions due to the accumulation of extracellular waste products in the brain.

text 1: REM sleep bouts become longer as the night progresses.
text 2: REM sleep bouts become shorter as the night progresses.

text 1: Restless legs syndrome is a genetically influenced disorder associated with discomfort and disrupted sleep.
text 2: Restless legs syndrome is primarily caused by environmental factors and has no relationship with genetics.

text 1: Orexin neurons in the lateral hypothalamus promote transitions from wakefulness into REM sleep.
text 2: Orexin neurons in the lateral hypothalamus prevent transitions from wakefulness into REM sleep.

text 1: At chemical synapses, the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells communicate directly through bridging channels.
text 2: At chemical synapses, a cleft separates the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells, and the cells do not communicate through bridging channels.

text 1: Metabotropic receptors are ion channels that open when the transmitter binds.
text 2: Ionotropic receptors are ion channels that open when the transmitter binds.

text 1: The sign of the synaptic signal depends on the properties of the receptor with which the transmitter interacts.
text 2: The sign of the synaptic signal depends solely on the identity of the transmitter.

text 1: All transmitters are high-molecular-weight molecules, and peptides never act as messengers at synapses.
text 2: Most transmitters are low-molecular-weight molecules, but certain peptides can also act as messengers at synapses.

text 1: Only ionotropic receptors can result in excitation, while metabotropic receptors only result in inhibition.
text 2: Both ionotropic and metabotropic receptors can result in excitation or inhibition.

text 1: Electrophysiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology have not been used to study receptors in postsynaptic cells.
text 2: Electrophysiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology have been used to characterize the receptors in postsynaptic cells.

text 1: At electrical synapses, there is a large cleft between the presynaptic terminal and the postsynaptic cell, similar to chemical synapses.
text 2: At electrical synapses, the presynaptic terminal and the postsynaptic cell are in very close apposition at regions termed gap junctions.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity allows the strength of a synaptic connection to be modified by experience.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity makes synaptic connections fixed and unchangeable by experience.

text 1: Homosynaptic plasticity results from the activity of the synapse itself.
text 2: Homosynaptic plasticity depends on external factors and not on the activity of the synapse itself.

text 1: Electrical synapses involve the release of a chemical transmitter that binds to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.
text 2: Chemical synapses involve the release of a chemical transmitter that binds to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.

text 1: The concept of plasticity is a key theme running throughout the book.
text 2: The book does not discuss the concept of plasticity.

text 1: In synaptic plasticity, modifications may depend on the release of a modulatory transmitter.
text 2: In synaptic plasticity, modifications are always independent of any modulatory transmitters.

text 1: Gap junction channels only exist at chemical synapses and never at electrical synapses.
text 2: Gap junction channels physically connect the cytoplasm of the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells at electrical synapses.

text 1: Second-messenger pathways transduce signals within cells.
text 2: Second-messenger pathways act exclusively outside cells, not within them.

text 1: The book considers the molecular architecture of chemical synapses as simple.
text 2: The book considers the molecular architecture of chemical synapses as complex.

text 1: The ventricular zone is the major site for the production of neural cells in the central nervous system.
text 2: The ventricular zone is not a site for the production of neural cells in the central nervous system.

text 1: Radial glial cells serve as neural progenitors and structural scaffolds.
text 2: Radial glial cells serve only as structural scaffolds, not as neural progenitors.

text 1: Neurons are frequently 'born' far from where they end up, requiring migratory mechanisms.
text 2: Neurons are frequently 'born' exactly where they end up, requiring no migratory mechanisms.

text 1: Neurotrophic factors activate a latent cell death program.
text 2: Neurotrophic factors suppress a latent cell death program.

text 1: Delta-Notch signaling regulates the generation of neurons and glial cells.
text 2: Delta-Notch signaling inhibits the generation of neurons and glial cells.

text 1: Excitatory cortical neurons do not migrate radially along glial guides.
text 2: Excitatory cortical neurons migrate radially along glial guides.

text 1: The incidence of symmetric and asymmetric cell division is unaffected by environmental signals.
text 2: The incidence of symmetric and asymmetric cell division is influenced by environmental signals.

text 1: Radial glial cells can undergo both asymmetric and self-renewing cell division.
text 2: Radial glial cells can only undergo symmetric cell division.

text 1: Approximately half of the neurons generated in the mammalian nervous system are lost through programmed cell death.
text 2: Almost none of the neurons generated in the mammalian nervous system are lost through programmed cell death.

text 1: Initially, the neural plate contains only a few hundred cells arranged in a simple columnar epithelium.
text 2: Initially, the neural plate contains millions of cells arranged in a complex network.

text 1: Mature brains comprise billions of nerve and glial cells arranged in complex patterns.
text 2: Mature brains comprise only a few hundred nerve and glial cells arranged in complex patterns.

text 1: Newborn cells in the proliferative zones often become committed to neuronal or glial fates before migrating.
text 2: Newborn cells in the proliferative zones only become committed to neuronal fates after migrating.

text 1: Signals from synaptic inputs and targets have no influence on the transmitter phenotypes of neurons.
text 2: Signals from synaptic inputs and targets can influence the transmitter phenotypes of neurons.

text 1: The basic mechanisms of neurogenesis endow cells with unique, region-specific properties.
text 2: The basic mechanisms of neurogenesis endow cells with common neuronal properties.

text 1: Intrinsic programs and extrinsic factors determine the neurotransmitter phenotypes of neurons.
text 2: Intrinsic programs alone determine the neurotransmitter phenotypes of neurons.

text 1: Less than 1% of human genes are specific to humans.
text 2: Less than 10% of human genes are specific to humans.

text 1: The P elements are the most widely used transposable elements in Drosophila.
text 2: The L elements are the most widely used transposable elements in Drosophila.

text 1: Gene manipulation by classical and reverse genetics is conducted in humans, not in experimental animals.
text 2: Gene manipulation by classical and reverse genetics is conducted in experimental animals, not in humans.

text 1: In reverse genetics, the pathway of discovery moves from phenotype to genotype, from organism to gene.
text 2: In reverse genetics, the pathway of discovery moves from genotype to phenotype, from gene to organism.

text 1: A transcriptional oscillator regulates circadian rhythm in flies, mice, and humans.
text 2: A transcriptional oscillator regulates circadian rhythm only in humans.

text 1: Glycine is produced from α-ketoglutarate, an intermediate in the tricarboxylic acid cycle of intermediary metabolism.
text 2: Glutamate is produced from α-ketoglutarate, an intermediate in the tricarboxylic acid cycle of intermediary metabolism.

text 1: The vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT2) transports all three monoamines into synaptic vesicles for subsequent exocytotic release.
text 2: The vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT2) transports amino acids such as glutamate into synaptic vesicles for subsequent exocytotic release.

text 1: GABA is the major neurotransmitter of inhibitory neurons in the brain.
text 2: GABA is the major neurotransmitter of excitatory neurons in the brain.

text 1: The glutamate taken up by astrocytes is converted to glutamine by the enzyme glutamine synthase.
text 2: The glutamate taken up by astrocytes is converted to GABA by the enzyme glutamine synthase.

text 1: The concentration of GABA is approximately the same in inhibitory and excitatory cells.
text 2: The concentration of GABA is approximately 20 times greater in inhibitory cells than in excitatory cells.

text 1: VMAT1 was cloned based on its ability to protect cells from the neurotoxic effects of MPP+.
text 2: VAChT was cloned based on its ability to protect cells from the neurotoxic effects of MPP+.

text 1: Caffeine’s stimulatory effects depend on its inhibition of dopamine binding to P1 receptors.
text 2: Caffeine’s stimulatory effects depend on its inhibition of adenosine binding to P1 receptors.

text 1: Glycine is synthesized from serine by the mitochondrial form of the serine hydroxymethyltransferase.
text 2: Glutamate is synthesized from serine by the mitochondrial form of the serine hydroxymethyltransferase.

text 1: Both serotonin and dopamine are loaded into synaptic vesicles by the same transporter, VGAT.
text 2: Both GABA and glycine are loaded into synaptic vesicles by the same transporter, VGAT.

text 1: ATP and its degradation products act as transmitters at some synapses by binding to classes of G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: ATP and its degradation products do not act as transmitters and only serve as energy molecules.

text 1: Transmitter molecules are expelled from vesicles by vesicular transporters exchanging them for two protons into the vesicle.
text 2: Transmitter molecules are taken up into vesicles by vesicular transporters in exchange for the transport of two protons out of the vesicle.

text 1: Reserpine and tetrabenazine facilitate the uptake of amine transmitters by binding to the vesicular monoamine transporter.
text 2: Reserpine and tetrabenazine inhibit uptake of amine transmitters by binding to the vesicular monoamine transporter.

text 1: Dopamine can be concentrated up to 100,000-fold relative to its concentration in the cytoplasm by vesicular transporters.
text 2: Glutamine can be concentrated up to 100,000-fold relative to its concentration in the cytoplasm by vesicular transporters.

text 1: 3,4-methylenedioxy-N-methylamphetamine (MDMA or ecstasy) enhances storage of amine transmitter molecules in vesicles.
text 2: 3,4-methylenedioxy-N-methylamphetamine (MDMA or ecstasy) depletes vesicles of amine transmitter molecules.

text 1: Purines such as adenine and guanine are strong candidates for transmission at purinergic receptors.
text 2: Purines such as adenine and guanine are not involved in transmission at purinergic receptors.

text 1: The rotational VOR compensates for head rotation and receives its input predominantly from the semicircular canals.
text 2: The rotational VOR compensates for head rotation and receives its input predominantly from the otolith organs.

text 1: The translational VOR compensates for angular head movement.
text 2: The translational VOR compensates for linear head movement.

text 1: The compensatory eye rotation called the vestibular slow phase is not necessarily slow; the eyes may reach speeds of more than 200 degrees per second if the head’s rotation is fast.
text 2: The compensatory eye rotation called the vestibular slow phase always moves at a constant slow speed, never reaching 200 degrees per second.

text 1: A quadrisynaptic pathway connects each semicircular canal to the appropriate eye muscle.
text 2: A trisynaptic pathway, the three-neuron arc, connects each semicircular canal to the appropriate eye muscle.

text 1: Primary afferents from the otolith organs send excitatory signals through the vestibular nuclei and the medial longitudinal fasciculus to the contralateral abducens nucleus.
text 2: Primary afferents from the horizontal semicircular canals send excitatory signals through the vestibular nuclei and the medial longitudinal fasciculus to the contralateral abducens nucleus.

text 1: The three-neuron arc is part of the direct pathway of the rotational VOR.
text 2: The three-neuron arc is part of an indirect integrator pathway of the rotational VOR.

text 1: Without the second indirect integrator pathway, the eye would stay in its initial position due to stable oculomotor neuronal input.
text 2: Without the second indirect integrator pathway, the eye would drift away from its position since the oculomotor neurons would lack tonic input.

text 1: With continued head rotation, the eyes never reach the limit of their orbital range as they are continuously able to move.
text 2: With continued head rotation, the eyes eventually reach the limit of their orbital range and stop moving.

text 1: During prolonged rotation, leftward slow phases and a right-beating nystagmus result from excitation of the right horizontal canal.
text 2: During prolonged rotation, rightward slow phases and a left-beating nystagmus result from excitation of the right horizontal canal.

text 1: Damage to the left subcortical gray nuclei impairs grammatical processing in both speech and comprehension.
text 2: Damage to the left subcortical gray nuclei enhances grammatical processing in both speech and comprehension.

text 1: The sites of maximal overlap of lesions associated with deficits in naming of tools are the right sensorimotor cortex and right posterolateral temporal cortex.
text 2: The sites of maximal overlap of lesions associated with deficits in naming of tools are the left sensorimotor cortex and left posterolateral temporal cortex.

text 1: By the age of 3, young children have mastered all levels of language and can carry on a conversation with an adult.
text 2: By the age of 3, young children have typically mastered only basic vocabulary.

text 1: The left temporal cortex contains neural systems that hold the key to retrieving words denoting various categories of things but not words denoting actions.
text 2: The left temporal cortex contains neural systems that hold the key to retrieving words denoting actions but not words denoting various categories of things.

text 1: EEG and MEG brain imaging studies show no significant transition in phonetic perception between 6 and 12 months of age in infants.
text 2: EEG and MEG brain imaging studies mirror the transition in phonetic perception between 6 and 12 months of age in infants.

text 1: Broca’s aphasia is seen as a ventral stream deficit.
text 2: Broca’s aphasia is seen as a dorsal stream deficit.

text 1: By 12 months, infants’ discrimination for foreign-language sounds has dramatically increased.
text 2: By 12 months, infants’ discrimination for native-language sounds has dramatically increased.

text 1: Conduction aphasia is viewed as caused by a dorsal stream deficit.
text 2: Conduction aphasia is viewed as caused by a ventral stream deficit.

text 1: Hemispheric specialization generally decreases with age and language experience.
text 2: Hemispheric specialization generally increases with age and language experience.

text 1: Infants’ strategies for language learning are well described by Skinnerian operant conditioning.
text 2: Infants’ strategies for language learning are not well described by Skinnerian operant conditioning.

text 1: The dorsal stream mediates auditory-conceptual representations of words and is more right lateralized.
text 2: The dorsal stream mediates auditory-motor representations of speech and is more left lateralized.

text 1: Damage to areas of frontal cortex in the mesial surface of the left hemisphere impairs the initiation of movement and causes mutism.
text 2: Damage to areas of frontal cortex in the mesial surface of the left hemisphere enhances the initiation of movement and prevents mutism.

text 1: The ventral stream mediates auditory-motor representations of speech.
text 2: The ventral stream mediates auditory-conceptual representations of words.

text 1: Infants’ speech production and speech perception skills are not 'universal' at birth.
text 2: Infants’ speech production and speech perception skills are 'universal' at birth.

text 1: A 'dual-stream' model of language has no similarities to the dual-stream model for the visual system.
text 2: A 'dual-stream' model of language has similarities to the dual-stream model for the visual system.

text 1: Lesions of the orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus cause narcolepsy.
text 2: Lesions of the orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus cause insomnia.

text 1: Neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus fire fastest during deep sleep.
text 2: Neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus fire fastest during wakefulness.

text 1: Lesions of glutamatergic neurons in the dorsolateral rostral pons can cause heightened arousal.
text 2: Lesions of glutamatergic neurons in the dorsolateral rostral pons can cause a comatose state.

text 1: The ascending arousal system excludes cholinergic neurons in the dorsolateral pons and basal forebrain.
text 2: The ascending arousal system includes cholinergic neurons in the dorsolateral pons and basal forebrain.

text 1: Damage to the ascending arousal system can result in coma.
text 2: Damage to the ascending arousal system enhances wakefulness.

text 1: Lesions of the parafacial zone can result in loss of up to half of total sleep time.
text 2: Lesions of the parabrachial nucleus can result in loss of up to half of total sleep time.

text 1: The neural circuit for sleep transitions resembles a flip-flop switch.
text 2: The neural circuit for sleep transitions resembles a dial.

text 1: REM sleep is generated by a network of brain stem neurons centered in the pons.
text 2: REM sleep is generated by a network of brain stem neurons centered in the medulla.

text 1: Lesions of the posterior lateral hypothalamus cause increased arousal.
text 2: Lesions of the posterior lateral hypothalamus cause profound sleepiness.

text 1: Optogenetic activation of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain may produce arousal.
text 2: Optogenetic activation of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain may produce sleep.

text 1: Adenosine acts as a neuromodulator in the extracellular environment.
text 2: Adenosine decreases in the extracellular environment during sustained wakefulness.

text 1: Histaminergic neurons in the tuberomammillary nucleus contribute to wakefulness.
text 2: Histaminergic neurons in the tuberomammillary nucleus contribute to sleep.

text 1: Lesions of the ventrolateral preoptic area result in fragmented sleep.
text 2: Lesions of the ventrolateral preoptic area result in enhanced continuous sleep.

text 1: The supramammillary nucleus contains glutamatergic neurons that activate the cortex.
text 2: The supramammillary nucleus contains GABAergic neurons that inhibit the cortex.

text 1: Lesions confined to the thalamus enhance the content of consciousness and have a profound effect on wake-sleep cycles.
text 2: Lesions confined to the thalamus impair the content of consciousness but have little effect on wake-sleep cycles.

text 1: The hypothalamus lies at the base of the brain immediately above the pituitary gland and is bounded rostrally by the diagonal band of Broca.
text 2: The hypothalamus lies at the base of the brain immediately below the pituitary gland and is bounded rostrally by the diagonal band of Broca.

text 1: Physiological set points like body temperature and blood pressure are depicted as static properties encoded in single hypothalamic neurons without feedback loops.
text 2: Physiological set points like body temperature and blood pressure are depicted as emergent properties of hypothalamic feedback loops involving afferent and efferent neurons.

text 1: The lateral hypothalamic area is more closely linked to reward pathways and arousal than it is to homeostasis or survival behaviors.
text 2: The lateral hypothalamic area is primarily linked to regulating body temperature and survival behaviors.

text 1: The settling point model illustrates how systems require strict set points, feedback, and error detection to maintain constancy.
text 2: The settling point model illustrates how systems maintain constancy without set points, feedback, or error detection.
