text 1: The preoptic hypothalamus helps regulate water balance, thirst, temperature, sleep, sexual behavior, and circadian rhythms.
text 2: The preoptic hypothalamus exclusively regulates temperature and circadian rhythms, without involvement in other functions.

text 1: The hypothalamus regulates energy metabolism through hunger, feeding behavior, autonomic digestion control, and hormone release.
text 2: The hypothalamus regulates energy metabolism exclusively through autonomic digestion, without affecting hunger or hormone release.

text 1: The hypothalamus influences thermoregulatory behavior but does not control autonomic mechanisms for heat conservation and loss.
text 2: The hypothalamus influences thermoregulatory behavior and autonomic mechanisms for heat conservation and loss.

text 1: The anterior hypothalamic nucleus is located rostrally in the brain and contributes to defensive behavior and the stress response.
text 2: The anterior hypothalamic nucleus is located caudally in the brain and exclusively modulates circadian rhythms.

text 1: The mammillary body, part of the posterior hypothalamus, contributes to arousal and memory formation.
text 2: The mammillary body, part of the anterior hypothalamus, exclusively contributes to body temperature regulation.

text 1: Neurons in the hypothalamus regulate blood pressure exclusively by behavioral modifications, without influencing vasopressin release or vasomotor tone.
text 2: Neurons in the hypothalamus regulate six vital physiological functions, including blood pressure and electrolyte composition by controlling vasomotor tone and vasopressin release.

text 1: The hypothalamic nuclei communicate with the pituitary gland via projections and hormone release through the infundibulum (pituitary stalk).
text 2: The hypothalamic nuclei communicate with the pituitary gland via neural connections exclusively, avoiding hormone release.

text 1: The hypothalamus integrates autonomic and endocrine responses as part of its role in homeostasis.
text 2: The hypothalamus is solely responsible for autonomic responses without endocrine integration.

text 1: Histaminergic neurons in the tuberomammillary nucleus play a primary role in sleep induction rather than wakefulness.
text 2: Histaminergic neurons in the tuberomammillary nucleus affect arousal and wakefulness.

text 1: Orexin-expressing neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area are critical for promoting sleep during circadian rhythms.
text 2: Orexin-expressing neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area are critical for stabilizing wakefulness.

text 1: The hypothalamus orchestrates homeostatic responses in body temperature, blood pressure, and body fat through static set point encoding.
text 2: The hypothalamus orchestrates homeostatic responses in body temperature, blood pressure, and body fat through distributed settling point models.

text 1: Subjects experienced intentional binding when their actions were random and not followed by their intended goals.
text 2: Subjects experienced intentional binding when their actions were followed by their intended goals.

text 1: Action is always controlled by conscious stimuli, as demonstrated by a patient with damage to the inferior temporal cortex who can only orient a tablet accurately with conscious awareness of its orientation.
text 2: Action can be controlled by unconscious stimuli, as demonstrated by a patient with damage to the inferior temporal cortex who can orient a tablet accurately without conscious awareness of its orientation.

text 1: Subjects were not aware that they had moved their hand at an angle of 10° to the left to produce a vertical line on the screen.
text 2: Subjects were aware of moving their hand at an angle of 10° to the left to produce a vertical line on the screen.

text 1: The readiness potential occurs up to 1 second before a voluntary movement.
text 2: The readiness potential occurs after the voluntary movement has been made.

text 1: Temporal binding is reduced when movements are caused by magnetic stimulation to the brain.
text 2: Temporal binding is increased when movements are caused by magnetic stimulation to the brain.

text 1: Our sense of agency increases when actions have moral consequences.
text 2: Our sense of agency decreases when actions have moral consequences.

text 1: Free will's relevance to Libet's results is clear and undisputed.
text 2: Free will's relevance to Libet's results is controversial.

text 1: Subjects often misclassify semantically related new words as old ones due to unconscious priming.
text 2: Subjects can perfectly classify semantically related new words as new, without being fooled by any unconscious priming.

text 1: Amnesic patients may misclassify previously seen words as new due to their inability to recall them.
text 2: Amnesic patients always perfectly recall previously seen words and never misclassify them as new.

text 1: Patients with anosognosia for hemiplegia believe they can still move a paralyzed limb.
text 2: Patients with anosognosia for hemiplegia are fully aware of their inability to move a paralyzed limb.

text 1: Declarative memory impairment in amnesic patients always severely affects procedural memory.
text 2: Declarative memory impairment in amnesic patients is often circumscribed and does not affect procedural memory.

text 1: The sensation of a moving phantom limb is based on predicted proprioceptive sensations.
text 2: The sensation of a moving phantom limb is based on actual proprioceptive sensations.

text 1: The conscious recall of memories involves creative reconstruction, incorporating both conscious and unconscious elements.
text 2: The conscious recall of memories is a mere replay of past events, with no reconstruction involved.

text 1: Our belief in free will is closely linked to our sense of agency.
text 2: Our belief in free will is completely independent of our sense of agency.

text 1: The perception of unexpected sensory outcomes leads to no emotional response.
text 2: The perception of unexpected sensory outcomes leads to surprise.

text 1: Individual cells in inferior temporal cortex can be highly shape-selective and respond selectively, e.g., to a hand or a face.
text 2: Individual cells in inferior temporal cortex are not shape-selective and do not respond selectively to objects like a hand or a face.

text 1: Inferotemporal cortex is well-defined and consists of only a single area with one functional specialization.
text 2: Inferotemporal cortex comprises a yet-unknown number of areas with very different functional specializations.

text 1: Face recognition is supported by multiple face areas, each with a unique functional specialization.
text 2: Face recognition is supported by a single face area with no functional specialization.

text 1: Inferotemporal cortex is interconnected with perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices for memory formation.
text 2: Inferotemporal cortex is isolated and not interconnected with perirhinal or parahippocampal cortices.

text 1: Objects are perceived without categorization in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Objects are perceived as members of a category in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

text 1: Perceptual learning can improve the ability to discriminate between complex objects.
text 2: Perceptual learning does not affect the ability to discriminate between complex objects.

text 1: Visual information can be held in short-term working memory.
text 2: Visual information cannot be stored in short-term working memory.

text 1: Neurons in inferior temporal cortex lose selectivity across position, size, and rotation.
text 2: Neurons in inferior temporal cortex can maintain selectivity across position, size, and rotation.

text 1: Inferior temporal cortex does not receive any projections from the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Inferior temporal cortex receives projections from the prefrontal cortex related to visual working memory.

text 1: Face areas function independently and are not selectively coupled.
text 2: Face areas are selectively coupled to form a face-processing network.

text 1: High-level visual information processing does not change with top-down modulation.
text 2: High-level visual information processing changes with top-down modulation.

text 1: Visual scrutiny is driven by attention and arousal circuits.
text 2: Visual scrutiny is independent of attention and arousal circuits.

text 1: Neurons in inferior temporal cortex exhibit differing activity during bottom-up activation and cued recall.
text 2: Neurons in inferior temporal cortex exhibit similar activity during bottom-up activation and cued recall.

text 1: Face cells are organized into larger units called face areas.
text 2: Face cells are scattered randomly without organization into larger units.

text 1: The brain compensates for eye movements to create a stable representation of the visual world.
text 2: The brain does not compensate for eye movements, leading to an unstable visual world.

text 1: Application of a single pulse of serotonin is sufficient to mark synapses for the capture of gene products generated by five pulses of serotonin at another synapse.
text 2: Application of a single pulse of serotonin is sufficient to independently induce gene products without requiring five pulses of serotonin at another synapse.

text 1: Local phosphorylation by protein kinase C (PKC) allows synaptic marking necessary for the capture of gene products.
text 2: Local phosphorylation by protein kinase A (PKA) allows synaptic marking necessary for the capture of gene products.

text 1: Long-term maintenance of synaptic facilitation can occur without local protein synthesis at the activated synapse.
text 2: Long-term maintenance of synaptic facilitation requires local protein synthesis at the activated synapse.

text 1: Blocking local CPEB at an activated synapse inhibits long-term maintenance of synaptic facilitation but not its initiation or 24-hour maintenance.
text 2: Blocking local CPEB at an activated synapse inhibits both initiation and maintenance of synaptic facilitation.

text 1: The soluble form of neuronal Aplysia CPEB has prion-like self-sustaining properties that stabilize long-term facilitation.
text 2: The aggregated form of neuronal Aplysia CPEB has prion-like self-sustaining properties that stabilize long-term facilitation.

text 1: Five pulses of serotonin at a synapse activate gene transcription in the nucleus to produce mRNAs for synaptic facilitation.
text 2: Five pulses of serotonin at a synapse directly produce mRNAs locally without involving nuclear gene transcription.

text 1: Local synthesis of cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein (CPEB) is induced by dopamine in Aplysia sensory neuron terminals.
text 2: Local synthesis of cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein (CPEB) is induced by serotonin in Aplysia sensory neuron terminals.

text 1: Serotonin activates poly(A) polymerase, elongating the poly(A) tail of dormant mRNAs for translation at marked synapses.
text 2: Serotonin inhibits poly(A) polymerase, preventing elongation of the poly(A) tail of dormant mRNAs at marked synapses.

text 1: CPEB aggregates dissolve soluble CPEB molecules, preventing the translation of dormant mRNAs.
text 2: CPEB aggregates recruit soluble CPEB molecules, enabling the active translation of dormant mRNAs.

text 1: Prion-like active CPEB destabilizes synaptic structures by degrading mRNAs encoding actin and tubulin.
text 2: Prion-like active CPEB stabilizes newly grown synaptic structures by activating translation of mRNAs encoding actin and tubulin.

text 1: In Aplysia, mRNAs distributed throughout the neuron are translated equally at all synapses, regardless of CPEB activity.
text 2: In Aplysia, mRNAs distributed throughout the neuron are translated only at synapses marked by active CPEB aggregates.

text 1: Local translation of dormant mRNAs at marked synapses requires polyadenylation by the poly(A) polymerase machinery.
text 2: Local translation of dormant mRNAs at marked synapses occurs without polyadenylation by the poly(A) polymerase machinery.

text 1: Protein kinase A (PKA) and phosphoinositide 3 kinase (PI3 kinase) inhibit synaptic marking and long-term facilitation in Aplysia.
text 2: Protein kinase A (PKA) and phosphoinositide 3 kinase (PI3 kinase) work together to mark synapses and maintain long-term facilitation in Aplysia.

text 1: Dormant maternal mRNAs in Xenopus oocytes are activated by cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein (CPEB).
text 2: Dormant maternal mRNAs in Xenopus oocytes are inhibited by cytoplasmic polyadenylation element binding protein (CPEB).

text 1: Serotonin-induced translation at Aplysia synapses primarily disrupts alterations required for long-term memory storage.
text 2: Serotonin-induced translation at Aplysia synapses is crucial for maintaining alterations required for long-term memory storage.

text 1: The unique human species resulted from the invention of unique new human genes.
text 2: The unique human species did not result from the invention of unique new human genes.

text 1: Over half of all human genes are very similar to genes in invertebrates such as worms and flies.
text 2: Only a small fraction of all human genes are similar to genes in invertebrates such as worms and flies.

text 1: Sex-linked inheritance was discovered in fruit flies by Thomas Hunt Morgan in 1910.
text 2: Sex-linked inheritance was discovered in mice by Thomas Hunt Morgan in 1910.

text 1: Each parent supplies one X chromosome to female (XX) offspring.
text 2: Each parent supplies one Y chromosome to female (XX) offspring.

text 1: Mitochondria in all children come from the sperm.
text 2: Mitochondria in all children come from the ovum.

text 1: Recessive mutations usually result from loss or reduction of a functional protein.
text 2: Recessive mutations usually result in the gain of a functional protein.

text 1: Humans and chimpanzees share 99% of their protein-coding genes.
text 2: Humans and chimpanzees share 70% of their protein-coding genes.

text 1: None of the human genes have functions inferred from orthologous genes in other organisms.
text 2: Approximately one-half of the human genes have functions inferred from orthologous genes in other organisms.

text 1: The genomes of multicellular animals encode only a few transmembrane receptors.
text 2: The genomes of multicellular animals encode thousands of transmembrane receptors.

text 1: A mutant phenotype expressed only when both alleles of a gene are mutated is called dominant.
text 2: A mutant phenotype is expressed only when both alleles of a gene are mutated is called recessive.

text 1: DNA replication generally is carried out with high fidelity.
text 2: DNA replication generally is carried out with low fidelity.

text 1: Point mutations occur at a high spontaneous rate in oocytes and sperm.
text 2: Point mutations occur at a low spontaneous rate in oocytes and sperm.

text 1: Changes in more than a single base and less than 1000 base pairs are referred to as copy number variations (CNVs).
text 2: Changes in more than a single base and less than 1000 base pairs are referred to as insertion/deletions (indels).

text 1: The genotype of an organism is its entire set of alleles forming the genome of an individual.
text 2: The phenotype of an organism is its entire set of alleles forming the genome of an individual.

text 1: Animal experiments are never possible when experiments on humans are not.
text 2: Animal experiments are often possible when experiments on humans are not.

text 1: A sixth system, the fixation system, holds the eye stationary during intent gaze when the head is not moving by actively suppressing eye movement.
text 2: A sixth system, the fixation system, moves the eye rapidly during intent gaze when the head is not moving by actively enhancing eye movement.

text 1: Saccadic eye movements shift the fovea slowly to a new visual target.
text 2: Saccadic eye movements shift the fovea rapidly to a new visual target.

text 1: The trochlear nerve innervates the inferior oblique muscle, which elevates and extorts the eye.
text 2: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which depresses and intorts the eye.

text 1: Vergence movements move the eyes in the same direction so that the image of an object of interest is positioned on both foveae regardless of its distance.
text 2: Vergence movements move the eyes in opposite directions so that the image of an object of interest is positioned on both foveae regardless of its distance.

text 1: Optokinetic movements destabilize images during sudden head rotation or translation.
text 2: Optokinetic movements stabilize images during sustained head rotation or translation.

text 1: Hypertropia, a permanent downward deviation of the eye, can be seen when a patient is looking straight ahead.
text 2: Hypertropia, a permanent upward deviation of the eye, can be seen when a patient is looking straight ahead.

text 1: The velocity of a saccade is determined only by its duration.
text 2: The velocity of a saccade is determined only by its size.

text 1: Smooth-pursuit movements keep the image of a moving target on the fovea.
text 2: Smooth-pursuit movements keep the image of a still target on the fovea.

text 1: Vestibulo-ocular reflexes destabilize images on the retina during brief head movements.
text 2: Vestibulo-ocular reflexes stabilize images on the retina during brief head movements.

text 1: The right eye is in the center of the orbit, but the affected left eye is slightly below the right eye.
text 2: The right eye is in the center of the orbit, but the affected left eye is slightly above the right eye.

text 1: The saccadic pulse determines the duration of the saccade, whereas the length of the pulse controls the speed of the saccade.
text 2: The saccadic pulse determines the speed of the saccade, whereas the length of the pulse controls the duration of the saccade.

text 1: Corrections to the direction and/or amplitude of movement are made instantaneously during each saccade.
text 2: Corrections to the direction and/or amplitude of movement are made over the course of successive saccades.

text 1: Eyes explore the world in a series of very quick saccades that move the fovea from one fixation point to another.
text 2: Eyes explore the world in a series of very slow saccades that move the fovea from one fixation point to another.

text 1: Saccades are extremely fast, occurring within a fraction of a second at angular speeds up to 900° per second.
text 2: Saccades are extremely slow, occurring over a second at angular speeds up to 90° per second.

text 1: The frequency of the saccadic pulse determines the speed of the saccade.
text 2: The frequency of the saccadic pulse determines the direction of the saccade.

text 1: Depolarization of the presynaptic terminal opens voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (VGCCs), resulting in Ca2+ influx concentrated at presynaptic active zones.
text 2: Depolarization of the presynaptic terminal opens voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (VGCCs), resulting in Ca2+ influx evenly distributed across the neuronal membrane.

text 1: The relationship between Ca2+ influx and neurotransmitter release is loosely coupled and mostly linear.
text 2: The relationship between Ca2+ influx and neurotransmitter release is tightly coupled and steeply nonlinear.

text 1: P/Q- and N-type Ca2+ channels are particularly prominent at active zones in the central nervous system.
text 2: P/Q- and N-type Ca2+ channels are particularly prominent at all regions of the neuronal membrane.

text 1: Neurotransmitter release is steeply dependent on depolarization of the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: Neurotransmitter release is independent of depolarization and solely relies on sodium influx.

text 1: Chemical transmission involves the continuous release of neurotransmitter without quantal packets or vesicle association.
text 2: Chemical transmission generally involves the release of quantal packets of neurotransmitter corresponding to the contents of a single synaptic vesicle.

text 1: Synaptotagmin-1 (syt1) acts as a Ca2+ sensor but does not bind any Ca2+ ions.
text 2: Synaptotagmin-1 (syt1) acts as a Ca2+ sensor for regulation of vesicle release by binding multiple Ca2+ ions.

text 1: The SNARE complex is critical for vesicle fusion and is modulated by SM proteins such as Munc18.
text 2: The SNARE complex plays no role in vesicle fusion or neurotransmitter release.

text 1: Synaptic vesicle exocytosis is slow due to the absence of molecular machinery in active zones.
text 2: Synaptic vesicle exocytosis is rapid because its molecular machinery is embedded in an active zone protein scaffold.

text 1: Endocytosis retrieves vesicle membranes for recycling after exocytosis.
text 2: Endocytosis facilitates neurotransmitter release without membrane retrieval.

text 1: Synaptic terminals exhibit identical release properties and expression of presynaptic Ca2+ channels and synaptotagmins.
text 2: Synaptic terminals vary in their release properties and expression of presynaptic Ca2+ channels and synaptotagmins.

text 1: Neurotransmitter release dynamics are fixed and unaffected by intrinsic factors like depression or facilitation.
text 2: Neurotransmitter release dynamics can be modulated by intrinsic factors such as depression and facilitation.

text 1: Under conditions of lowered extracellular Ca2+, neurotransmitter release remains deterministic and predictable for every action potential.
text 2: Under conditions of lowered extracellular Ca2+, neurotransmitter release becomes probabilistic.

text 1: Biogenic amines and neuropeptides are packaged into small, clear vesicles for faster synaptic transmission.
text 2: Biogenic amines and neuropeptides are packaged into dense-core vesicles for slower synaptic transmission.

text 1: Exocytosis and endocytosis occur in rapid succession in nerve terminals.
text 2: Endocytosis and exocytosis occur independently and do not follow one another in nerve terminals.

text 1: Formation of the SNARE complex is modulated by SM proteins, exemplified by Munc18.
text 2: Formation of the SNARE complex exclusively depends on synaptotagmin and does not involve any SM proteins.

text 1: Monkeys were trained to choose between movements based on a spatial rule or a semantic rule.
text 2: Monkeys were trained to choose between movements based solely on visual cues without rules.

text 1: PMv exclusively controls hand movements without overlapping circuits.
text 2: PMv contains extensively overlapping circuits that control hand and mouth movements.

text 1: PMv neurons discharge selectively during certain hand actions.
text 2: PMv neurons discharge randomly without selectivity during hand actions.

text 1: All PMv neurons discharge only during specific movements regardless of the effector used.
text 2: Some PMv neurons discharge when grasping is executed with different effectors.

text 1: During the interval between f1 and f2, there was sustained activity in S-I representing the memorized f1.
text 2: During the interval between f1 and f2, there was no sustained activity in S-I representing the memorized f1.

text 1: Precision can be improved by combining prior knowledge with sensory inputs using Bayesian inference.
text 2: Precision can be improved by ignoring prior knowledge and only using sensory inputs.

text 1: A forward model estimates past sensory inputs based on current motor outputs.
text 2: A forward model estimates future sensory inputs based on motor outputs.

text 1: The efference copy is a copy of the sensory feedback.
text 2: The efference copy is a copy of the descending motor command.

text 1: Bayesian inference is used to make estimates about the world based on uncertain information.
text 2: Bayesian inference is used to make estimates about the world based on certain and clear information only.

text 1: The brain, rather than sensing the gaze direction, predicted it based on a copy of the motor command to the eye muscles.
text 2: The brain senses the gaze direction without using any motor command predictions.

text 1: An observer model helps compensate for sensorimotor delays and reduce uncertainty.
text 2: An observer model increases sensorimotor delays and uncertainty.

text 1: Delays in feedback do not reflect the present state of the body and world.
text 2: Delays in feedback accurately represent the present state of the body and world.

text 1: Predictive control is essential for rapid movements in dexterous behavior.
text 2: Predictive control is unnecessary for rapid movements in dexterous behavior.

text 1: The concept of sensory prediction error is crucial in motor control.
text 2: The concept of sensory prediction error is irrelevant in motor control.

text 1: Sensory feedback can arise from both external events and our own movements.
text 2: Sensory feedback arises only from external events.

text 1: A forward model can be used to anticipate how the motor system’s state will change.
text 2: A forward model cannot anticipate changes in the motor system’s state.

text 1: A forward model acts as a neural simulator of the musculoskeletal system moving in the environment.
text 2: A forward model does not simulate the musculoskeletal system.

text 1: The output of the forward model is the sensory feedback.
text 2: The output of the forward model is the predicted behavior.

text 1: Helmholtz suggested that the brain predicts gaze direction based on motor commands.
text 2: Helmholtz suggested that gaze direction is sensed without motor commands.

text 1: Active sensing involves only perception.
text 2: Active sensing involves both perception and action.

text 1: Opiates act on receptors in the cerebral cortex and exclusively control the sensory component of pain via the anterior cingulate gyrus.
text 2: Opiates act on receptors in the cerebral cortex and can influence the affective component of pain via the anterior cingulate gyrus.

text 1: Placebo analgesia does not involve endorphin release and cannot be reversed by naloxone.
text 2: Placebo analgesia involves endorphin release and can be reversed by naloxone.

text 1: Psychological dependence is purely physiological and not related to craving or misuse.
text 2: Psychological dependence is a craving for the drug associated with misuse and contributes to opiate use disorders.

text 1: Peripheral sensitization of nociceptors is unrelated to tissue injury and inflammation.
text 2: Peripheral sensitization of nociceptors can result from tissue injury and inflammation.

text 1: Tolerance to opioids involves a requirement for higher doses to achieve the same effect.
text 2: Tolerance to opioids means that lower doses are needed to achieve the same effect.

text 1: Endogenous opioids are not only expressed in pain-relevant areas of the brain.
text 2: Endogenous opioids are exclusively expressed in pain-relevant areas of the brain.

text 1: All nociceptors use glutamate as their excitatory neurotransmitter.
text 2: Not all nociceptors use glutamate as their excitatory neurotransmitter.

text 1: Naloxone is an opiate receptor antagonist that can block all opioid actions.
text 2: Naloxone is not an opiate receptor antagonist and cannot block opioid actions.

text 1: The pain relief produced by vibration does not involve GABAergic inhibitory circuits.
text 2: The pain relief produced by vibration involves GABAergic inhibitory circuits.

text 1: Naloxone binding to µ-opioid receptors can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in tolerant subjects.
text 2: Naloxone binding to µ-opioid receptors does not precipitate withdrawal symptoms.

text 1: The anterior cingulate gyrus is involved in the affective component of pain.
text 2: The anterior cingulate gyrus is not involved in the affective component of pain.

text 1: Morphine is not very useful in the management of postoperative pain.
text 2: Morphine is very useful in the management of postoperative pain.

text 1: Aβ afferents respond only to innocuous stimulation.
text 2: Aβ afferents only respond to painful stimuli.

text 1: Peripheral nociceptive axons only include large-diameter myelinated afferents.
text 2: Peripheral nociceptive axons include small-diameter unmyelinated and myelinated afferents.

text 1: Placebo analgesia is a component of the analgesic action of any pain-relieving drug, given the patient's belief in its effectiveness.
text 2: Placebo analgesia is not a component of the analgesic action of pain-relieving drugs.

text 1: LTP at many synapses depends on calcium influx into the postsynaptic cell mediated by the NMDA type of glutamate receptor.
text 2: LTP at many synapses depends on sodium influx into the postsynaptic cell mediated by the NMDA type of glutamate receptor.

text 1: The expression of LTP depends on either the insertion of the AMPA type of glutamate receptors in the postsynaptic membrane or an increase in presynaptic glutamate release.
text 2: The expression of LTP depends on either the insertion of the NMDA type of glutamate receptors in the postsynaptic membrane or an increase in presynaptic glutamate release.

text 1: Long-term memory is thought to depend on activity-dependent short-term synaptic plasticity within the cortico-hippocampal circuit.
text 2: Long-term memory is thought to depend on activity-dependent long-term synaptic plasticity within the cortico-hippocampal circuit.

text 1: Pharmacological and genetic manipulations that disrupt LTP often lead to an impairment of long-term memory.
text 2: Pharmacological and genetic manipulations that disrupt LTP often lead to an enhancement of long-term memory.

text 1: Many hippocampal neurons act as place cells, firing action potentials when an animal visits a particular location in its environment.
text 2: Many hippocampal neurons act as place cells, firing action potentials when an animal is not in any specific location.

text 1: The lateral portion of the entorhinal cortex contains neurons, called grid cells, that fire when an animal crosses the vertices of a hexagonal grid-like lattice of spatial locales.
text 2: The medial portion of the entorhinal cortex contains neurons, called grid cells, that fire when an animal crosses the vertices of a hexagonal grid-like lattice of spatial locales.

text 1: Grid cells in the entorhinal cortex are organized into completely rigid modules with identical grid frequencies.
text 2: Grid cells in the entorhinal cortex are organized into semi-independent semi-topographically organized modules with distinct grid frequencies.

text 1: Changes in grid-cell function have not been observed in electrophysiological recordings in mouse disease models and in humans.
text 2: Changes in grid-cell function have been observed in electrophysiological recordings in mouse disease models and in humans.

text 1: Studies in primates have shown the unimportance of the prefrontal cortex and the modulatory dopaminergic system during attention.
text 2: Studies in primates have shown the importance of the prefrontal cortex and the modulatory dopaminergic system during attention.

text 1: Elevated levels of soluble Aβ and tau enhance a number of cellular processes by increasing the magnitude of both early and late LTP.
text 2: Elevated levels of soluble Aβ and tau are thought to disrupt a number of cellular processes by reducing the magnitude of both early and late LTP.

text 1: Disorders of Autobiographical Memory often result from functional perturbations in the hippocampus.
text 2: Disorders of Autobiographical Memory often result from functional perturbations in the cerebellum.

text 1: The ability of place cells to represent events and locations experienced in the future likely underlies the ability of the hippocampus to encode complex memories of events.
text 2: The ability of place cells to represent events and locations experienced in the past likely underlies the ability of the hippocampus to encode complex memories of events.

text 1: Neurological and psychiatric disorders that disrupt spatial abilities often occur as a result of changes in neural circuitry within the occipital lobe and related regions in the temporal lobe.
text 2: Neurological and psychiatric disorders that disrupt spatial abilities often occur as a result of changes in neural circuitry within the hippocampus and related regions in the temporal lobe.

text 1: The hippocampus encodes neither spatial nor nonspatial signals.
text 2: The hippocampus encodes both spatial and nonspatial signals.

text 1: Mouse models of Alzheimer's disease show alterations in hippocampal place cell stability and population-level synchrony.
text 2: Mouse models of Alzheimer's disease show enhanced hippocampal place cell stability and population-level synchrony.

text 1: The POA contains more neurons in females, and the vlVMH contains more testosterone-expressing neurons in males.
text 2: The POA contains more neurons in males, and the vlVMH contains more progesterone-expressing neurons in females.

text 1: Stimulating galanin-positive neurons in males increases aggression and decreases nurturing pup grooming.
text 2: Stimulating galanin-positive neurons in males decreases aggression and induces nurturing pup grooming.

text 1: During a typical night, periods of REM sleep alternate with non-REM sleep about every 60 minutes.
text 2: During a typical night, periods of REM sleep alternate with non-REM sleep about every 90 minutes.

text 1: Stage N1 sleep is characterized by a slight slowing of EEG frequencies and slow roving eye movements, with less EMG activity.
text 2: Stage N1 sleep is characterized by rapid EEG frequencies and frequent eye movements, with increased EMG activity.

text 1: As the night progresses, the individual spends less time in the deepest stage of non-REM sleep, and the duration of REM sleep periods increases.
text 2: As the night progresses, the individual spends more time in the deepest stage of non-REM sleep, and the duration of REM sleep periods decreases.

text 1: During REM sleep, the EEG is similar to that of the awake state.
text 2: During REM sleep, the EEG is significantly different from that of the awake state.

text 1: During stage N3, the EEG shows abundant, very slow EEG delta activity.
text 2: During stage N3, the EEG shows high-frequency beta activity.

text 1: Stage N2 is characterized by fast EEG activity in the gamma range and absence of sleep spindles.
text 2: Stage N2 often contains some slow EEG activity in the theta and delta range as well as sleep spindles.

text 1: Muscle tone is extremely high during REM sleep, due to excitation of motor neurons by ascending pathways from the spinal cord.
text 2: Muscle tone is extremely low during REM sleep, owing to inhibition of motor neurons by descending pathways from the brain stem.

text 1: The entire period of slow EEG activity, from light drowsiness to deep sleep, is referred to as REM sleep and is divided into four stages.
text 2: The entire period of slow EEG activity, from light drowsiness to deep sleep, is referred to as non-REM sleep and is divided into three stages, N1 to N3.

text 1: Slow EEG activity and sleep spindles arise from cortico-cortical and cortico-thalamic electrophysiological interactions.
text 2: Slow EEG activity and sleep spindles arise from thalamo-cortical and thalamo-hippocampal electrophysiological interactions.

text 1: During stage N2 sleep, spindles arise from an interaction of basal ganglia neurons and thalamo-cortical relay neurons.
text 2: During stage N2 sleep, spindles arise from an interaction of neurons in the reticular nucleus of the thalamus and thalamocortical relay neurons.

text 1: The Descending Inhibition System promotes wakefulness.
text 2: The Ascending Arousal System promotes wakefulness.

text 1: Across the night, episodes of non-REM sleep alternate with REM sleep, and each of these sleep cycles takes about 40 minutes.
text 2: Across the night, episodes of non-REM sleep alternate with REM sleep, and each of these sleep cycles takes about 90 minutes.

text 1: Body temperature rises during non-REM sleep, and it can rise further during REM sleep.
text 2: Body temperature falls during non-REM sleep, and it can fall further during REM sleep.

text 1: During non-REM sleep, the EEG shows slower activity compared to periods of wakefulness.
text 2: During non-REM sleep, the EEG shows faster activity compared to periods of wakefulness.

text 1: Consciousness begins to fade during stage N1, but the individual may still be awakened by minimal stimulation.
text 2: Consciousness is fully maintained during stage N1, and the individual is easily distinguishable from wakefulness.

text 1: Synaptic vesicles are filled with neurotransmitters by active transport and join the vesicle cluster that may represent a reserve pool.
text 2: Synaptic vesicles are filled with neurotransmitters by passive diffusion and join the vesicle cluster that may represent a reserve pool.

text 1: During docking at the active zone, synaptic vesicles undergo passive priming, making them competent for Ca2+-triggered fusion release.
text 2: During docking at the active zone, synaptic vesicles undergo ATP-dependent priming, making them competent for Ca2+-triggered fusion release.

text 1: Reversible fusion pore mechanism is rapid and occurs within tens to hundreds of milliseconds.
text 2: Reversible fusion pore mechanism is slow and occurs within tens to hundreds of minutes.

text 1: Clathrin-mediated endocytosis retrieves excess membrane via clathrin-coated pits, which are found throughout the axon terminal except at active zones.
text 2: Clathrin-mediated endocytosis retrieves excess membrane via clathrin-coated pits, which are especially concentrated at active zones.

text 1: The bulk retrieval pathway involves excess membrane reentering via budding from clathrin-coated pits formed primarily at active zones.
text 2: The bulk retrieval pathway involves excess membrane reentering via budding from uncoated pits formed primarily at active zones.

text 1: Vesicular glutamate transporter (V-GluT) pumps neurotransmitter molecules into synaptic vesicles using energy stored in the electrochemical gradient for protons.
text 2: Vesicular glutamate transporter (V-GluT) pumps neurotransmitter molecules into synaptic vesicles using energy stored in the electrochemical gradient for calcium ions.

text 1: SNARE proteins are universally involved in membrane fusion across species, from yeast to humans.
text 2: SNARE proteins are involved in membrane fusion only in humans.

text 1: Synaptobrevin and syntaxin each contain two SNARE motifs, while SNAP-25 contains one SNARE motif.
text 2: Synaptobrevin and syntaxin each contain one SNARE motif, while SNAP-25 contains two SNARE motifs.

text 1: The crystal structure of the SNARE complex suggests the interaction forces membranes into a prefusion intermediate state.
text 2: The crystal structure of the SNARE complex suggests the interaction prevents membranes from forming a prefusion intermediate state.

text 1: Synapsins play a key role in regulating vesicle fusion by binding to the extracellular surface of synaptic vesicles.
text 2: Synapsins play a key role in regulating the reserve pool of vesicles by binding to the cytoplasmic surface of synaptic vesicles.

text 1: Protein kinase A and Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent kinase degrade synapsins during nerve terminal depolarization.
text 2: Protein kinase A and Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent kinase phosphorylate synapsins during nerve terminal depolarization.

text 1: The SNARE motif is 20 residues long and conserved across SNARE proteins involved in membrane fusion.
text 2: The SNARE motif is 60 residues long and conserved across SNARE proteins involved in membrane fusion.

text 1: Synaptotagmin-1 serves as a calcium sensor and coordinates its function with complexin during vesicle fusion.
text 2: Synaptotagmin-1 serves as a sodium sensor and coordinates its function with complexin during vesicle fusion.

text 1: The proton motive force for neurotransmitter loading into vesicles is generated by the vesicular H+ pump.
text 2: The proton motive force for neurotransmitter loading into vesicles is generated by the vesicular K+ pump.

text 1: The active zone protein complex positions vesicles within 1 micron of Ca2+ channels for rapid release.
text 2: The active zone protein complex positions vesicles within 100 nm of Ca2+ channels for rapid release.

text 1: Ion channels actively move ions against their concentration and electrical gradients using metabolic energy.
text 2: Ion channels allow ions to move down their concentration and electrical gradients without requiring metabolic energy.

text 1: Na+ ions move into a cell through voltage-gated Na+ channels during an action potential because external Na+ concentrations are greater than internal concentrations.
text 2: Na+ ions move out of a cell through voltage-gated Na+ channels during an action potential because internal Na+ concentrations are greater than external concentrations.

text 1: Pumps differ from ion channels because they use ATP to transport ions against their gradients and operate at a slower rate.
text 2: Pumps and ion channels operate at similar speeds and both use ATP to transport ions across membranes.

text 1: A typical ion channel can allow up to 100 million ions to pass through per second.
text 2: A typical ion channel can allow up to 10 ions to pass through per second.

text 1: K+ channels are approximately 100-fold more permeable to K+ than to Na+.
text 2: K+ channels are approximately 100-fold more permeable to Na+ than to K+.

text 1: Voltage-gated channels open in response to changes in membrane potential.
text 2: Voltage-gated channels open in response to the binding of chemical transmitters.

text 1: Smaller ions, like Na+, exhibit smaller water shells, which makes them behave as if they are smaller than K+ in solution.
text 2: Smaller ions, like Na+, exhibit larger water shells, which makes them behave as if they are larger than K+ in solution.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump transports ions against their gradients at a much slower rate than ion channels.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump transports ions against their gradients at a much faster rate than ion channels.

text 1: Ion channels are integral membrane proteins embedded within the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane.
text 2: Ion channels are peripheral proteins loosely attached to the cell membrane.

text 1: The core of the plasma membrane is formed by a double layer of phospholipids that is hydrophobic.
text 2: The core of the plasma membrane is formed by a double layer of phospholipids that is hydrophilic.

text 1: The resting potential of nerve cells is largely determined by a class of K+ channels.
text 2: The resting potential of nerve cells is largely determined by a class of Na+ channels.

text 1: Ion selectivity in channels can depend on the interaction of ions with waters of hydration.
text 2: Ion selectivity in channels is solely dependent on the crystal radius of ions.

text 1: The lipid bilayer is almost completely impermeable to ions unless they move through ion channels.
text 2: The lipid bilayer permits ions to freely pass through without the need for ion channels.

text 1: During an action potential, the electrostatic and diffusional forces drive Na+ ions into the cell.
text 2: During an action potential, the electrostatic and diffusional forces drive Na+ ions out of the cell.

text 1: Ion pumps utilize ATP to actively maintain the concentration gradients of ions, including Na+ and K+.
text 2: Ion pumps passively maintain the concentration gradients of ions without utilizing ATP.

text 1: The pattern of motor neuron activity can change the biochemical and functional properties of skeletal muscle cells.
text 2: The pattern of motor neuron activity cannot change the biochemical and functional properties of skeletal muscle cells.

text 1: Motor neurons that connect with fast and slow muscle fibers exhibit distinct patterns of electrical activity.
text 2: Motor neurons that connect with fast and slow muscle fibers exhibit identical patterns of electrical activity.

text 1: Fast motor neurons induce fast properties in the slow muscle.
text 2: Fast motor neurons induce slow properties in the fast muscle.

text 1: The neuromuscular junction comprises three types of cells: a motor neuron, a muscle fiber, and Schwann cells.
text 2: The neuromuscular junction comprises four types of cells: a motor neuron, a muscle fiber, Schwann cells, and glial cells.

text 1: When motor neurons are added to cultures, they extend neurites that contact muscle cells more or less randomly.
text 2: When motor neurons are added to cultures, they specifically seek out acetylcholine receptor clusters.

text 1: Uninnervated myotubes can synthesize functional acetylcholine receptors and gather them into high-density aggregates.
text 2: Uninnervated myotubes cannot synthesize functional acetylcholine receptors.

text 1: Nerve and muscle organize each other’s differentiation.
text 2: Nerve and muscle independently organize their differentiation without mutual influence.

text 1: New synaptic components are added in several distinct steps in neuromuscular junction development.
text 2: New synaptic components are added in a single step during neuromuscular junction development.

text 1: Muscles can signal retrogradely to motor nerve terminals.
text 2: Muscles cannot signal retrogradely to motor nerve terminals.

text 1: Multiple axons converge on a single site as the muscle matures, and none of the axons are eliminated.
text 2: Multiple axons converge on a single site as the muscle matures, and all but one axon is eventually eliminated.

text 1: Soon after the growth cone of a motor axon contacts a developing myotube, neurotransmission does not occur until much later.
text 2: Soon after the growth cone of a motor axon contacts a developing myotube, a rudimentary form of neurotransmission begins.

text 1: The postsynaptic apparatus completely deteriorates after axotomy leaves muscle fibers denervated.
text 2: The postsynaptic apparatus remains largely intact even after axotomy leaves muscle fibers denervated.

text 1: Vesicles in growth cones can synthesize and release ACh before reaching the target cells.
text 2: Vesicles in growth cones cannot synthesize or release ACh until they reach the target cells.

text 1: The nerve terminal accumulates synaptic vesicles and a basal lamina forms in the synaptic cleft during development.
text 2: The nerve terminal does not accumulate synaptic vesicles, and a basal lamina never forms in the synaptic cleft.

text 1: ACh receptors accumulate in the postsynaptic membrane before acetylcholinesterase does in the synaptic cleft.
text 2: Acetylcholinesterase accumulates in the synaptic cleft before ACh receptors do in the postsynaptic membrane.

text 1: The Tau protein is predominantly localized in axons while MAP2 is localized in dendrites.
text 2: The Tau protein is predominantly localized in dendrites while MAP2 is localized in axons.

text 1: Axonal specification occurs through cytoskeletal reconfigurations initiated by destabilizing actin filaments in an early neurite.
text 2: Axonal specification is entirely random and does not involve cytoskeletal reconfigurations or actin filaments.

text 1: Par proteins are critical for neuronal polarization by directly creating neurotransmitter signals.
text 2: Par proteins are critical for neuronal polarization by reconfiguring cytoskeletal arrangements.

text 1: Cultured neurons develop processes in a stereotyped sequence beginning with the extension of several short processes.
text 2: Cultured neurons develop processes randomly without following a structured sequence.

text 1: Extrinsic signals like semaphorins are irrelevant for dendritic orientation in vivo.
text 2: Extrinsic signals like semaphorins help orient dendrites in vivo but are absent in cultured neurons.

text 1: In the developing brain, the local release of semaphorins helps orient dendrites.
text 2: In the developing brain, semaphorins have no role in dendritic orientation.

text 1: In cultured neurons, all processes grow at the same rate, and axon formation is random.
text 2: In cultured neurons, one process grows faster than its neighbors and becomes the axon.

text 1: Signals from forming axons are irrelevant to dendrite formation or suppression of additional axons.
text 2: Signals from forming axons suppress the generation of additional axons and promote dendrite formation.

text 1: Semaphorins are unrelated to axonal guidance and neuronal polarization.
text 2: Semaphorins are examples of axonal guidance factors vital for neuronal polarization in vivo.

text 1: Dendritic structure is further refined by pruning after initial branching.
text 2: Dendritic structure is finalized during the initial branching without pruning.

text 1: Cytoskeletal differences are irrelevant to the distinctions between axons and dendrites.
text 2: Cytoskeletal differences amplify distinctions between axons and dendrites, supporting specialized trafficking and segment formation.

text 1: Neuronal polarization in tissue culture may be driven by small variations in signaling intensity within the neuron.
text 2: Neuronal polarization in tissue culture is unaffected by signaling variations within the neuron.

text 1: Par proteins link extracellular signals to cytoskeletal rearrangements during neuronal polarization.
text 2: Par proteins function exclusively in neurotransmitter release and are unrelated to cytoskeletal rearrangements.

text 1: The law of dynamic polarization describes information transmission from dendrites to axons.
text 2: The law of dynamic polarization describes information transmission from axons to dendrites.

text 1: MAP2 protein is enriched in dendrites and contributes to microtubule function.
text 2: MAP2 protein is enriched in axons and contributes to microtubule function.

text 1: Presynaptic facilitation can result from enhanced influx of Ca2+, which increases transmitter release onto the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Presynaptic facilitation can result from decreased influx of Ca2+, which increases transmitter release onto the postsynaptic cell.

text 1: Presynaptic inhibition can occur through the activation of postsynaptic G protein-coupled metabotropic receptors that modulate ion channels.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition can occur through the activation of presynaptic G protein-coupled metabotropic receptors that modulate ion channels.

text 1: Activation of presynaptic NMDA-type glutamate receptors enhances Ca2+ influx directly, increasing transmitter release.
text 2: Activation of postsynaptic NMDA-type glutamate receptors enhances Ca2+ influx directly, increasing transmitter release.

text 1: Presynaptic inhibition can reduce transmitter release by decreasing the amplitude of presynaptic action potentials via inactivation of Na+ channels.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition can increase transmitter release by increasing the amplitude of presynaptic action potentials via inactivation of Na+ channels.

text 1: Serotonin can increase the duration of the presynaptic action potential by closing K+ channels in molluscan neurons.
text 2: Serotonin can decrease the duration of the presynaptic action potential by closing K+ channels in molluscan neurons.

text 1: Presynaptic inhibition often depends on activation of ionotropic GABAA receptor-channels, leading to decreased Cl− conductance and depolarization of the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition often depends on activation of ionotropic GABAA receptor-channels, leading to increased Cl− conductance and depolarization of the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: Presynaptic facilitation increases transmitter release by prolonging the duration of the presynaptic action potential.
text 2: Presynaptic facilitation decreases transmitter release by prolonging the duration of the presynaptic action potential.

text 1: Posttetanic potentiation is a persistent decrease in synaptic strength following a high-frequency stimulation of the presynaptic neuron.
text 2: Posttetanic potentiation is a persistent increase in synaptic strength following a high-frequency stimulation of the presynaptic neuron.

text 1: Presynaptic inhibition reduces transmitter release by decreasing the activation of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition increases transmitter release by decreasing the activation of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.

text 1: Presynaptic inhibition is mediated by GABA acting on ionotropic receptors that increase Cl− conductance in the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition is mediated by GABA acting on metabotropic receptors that increase K+ conductance in the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: The increase in Ca2+ sensitivity of the release machinery can be a mechanism of presynaptic inhibition.
text 2: The reduction in Ca2+ sensitivity of the release machinery can be a mechanism of presynaptic inhibition.

text 1: Presynaptic terminals are capable of short-term changes in synaptic strength lasting seconds, minutes, and hours.
text 2: Presynaptic terminals are incapable of short-term changes in synaptic strength lasting seconds, minutes, and hours.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors at presynaptic terminals can directly increase Ca2+ influx by hyperpolarizing the terminal.
text 2: Ionotropic receptors at presynaptic terminals can indirectly increase Ca2+ influx by depolarizing the terminal.

text 1: Postsynaptic inhibition increases the likelihood that the postsynaptic cell will fire an action potential.
text 2: Postsynaptic inhibition decreases the likelihood that the postsynaptic cell will fire an action potential.

text 1: Synaptic strength can only be fine-tuned by mechanisms located in the postsynaptic terminals.
text 2: Synaptic strength can be fine-tuned by mechanisms located in the presynaptic terminals.

text 1: The basal ganglia's reinforcement learning helps maximize reward and minimize punishment through action selection.
text 2: The basal ganglia's reinforcement learning helps maximize punishment and minimize reward through action selection.

text 1: Reinforcement-induced boosts in input salience increase the probability of rewarded options being selected.
text 2: Reinforcement-induced boosts in input salience decrease the probability of rewarded options being selected.

text 1: The transition from goal-directed behavior to habitual behavior can be influenced by different reinforcement schedules.
text 2: The transition from goal-directed behavior to habitual behavior is never influenced by reinforcement schedules.

text 1: Goal-directed actions rely on the sensorimotor cortical-basal ganglia circuit involving the dorsolateral striatum and infralimbic cortex.
text 2: Goal-directed actions rely on the associative cortical-basal ganglia circuit involving the dorsomedial striatum and prelimbic cortex.

text 1: Diseases like Parkinson and Huntington are unrelated to basal ganglia dysfunctions involving selection and reinforcement malfunctions.
text 2: Diseases like Parkinson and Huntington can be linked to basal ganglia dysfunctions involving selection and reinforcement malfunctions.

text 1: A primary neurological deficit in Parkinson disease is the degeneration of dopaminergic neurotransmission in the basal ganglia.
text 2: A primary neurological deficit in Parkinson disease is the excessive growth of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia.

text 1: In Huntington disease, early neuronal damage is evident in the striatal medium spiny neurons.
text 2: In Huntington disease, early neuronal damage is evident primarily in the ventral midbrain.

text 1: Schizophrenia may involve a failure to suppress nonselected options within the basal ganglia.
text 2: Schizophrenia may involve an enhanced suppression of selected options within the basal ganglia.

text 1: Habit formation is favored when rewards are delivered immediately after every action.
text 2: Habit formation is favored when rewards are delivered according to random time intervals.

text 1: Parkinson disease symptoms primarily include excessive uncontrolled jerky movements called chorea.
text 2: Parkinson disease symptoms can include akinesia, bradykinesia, rigidity, and sometimes tremors.

text 1: The sensorimotor cortical-basal ganglia circuit is crucial for goal-directed behaviors.
text 2: The associative cortical-basal ganglia circuit is crucial for goal-directed behaviors.

text 1: Disrupted associative territories of the basal ganglia impair habitual control but leave goal-directed functions relatively intact.
text 2: Disrupted associative territories of the basal ganglia impair goal-directed control but leave habitual functions relatively intact.

text 1: Efficient habits triggered by stimuli are helpful but can lead to distorted behaviors in conditions like addiction.
text 2: Efficient habits triggered by stimuli are never associated with distorted behaviors in conditions like addiction.

text 1: Failure to suppress competing channels may explain symptoms in disorders like schizophrenia and ADHD.
text 2: Excessive suppression of selected channels may explain symptoms in disorders like schizophrenia and OCD.

text 1: Huntington disease affects the direct striatal pathway, tipping the balance toward suppression at the output nuclei.
text 2: Huntington disease affects the indirect striatal pathway, tipping the balance toward disinhibition at the output nuclei.

text 1: The corpus callosum is the major tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres.
text 2: The corpus callosum connects the cerebral hemispheres to the spinal cord.

text 1: Each cerebral hemisphere cannot function independently of the other even after the severance of the corpus callosum.
text 2: Each cerebral hemisphere can function independently of the other following the severance of the corpus callosum.

text 1: The right hemisphere plays a major role in language comprehension.
text 2: The right hemisphere plays only a minor role in language comprehension.

text 1: In one study, patients with severed corpus callosum demonstrated behaviors such as using both hands to symmetrically put on clothes.
text 2: In one study, patients with severed corpus callosum demonstrated behaviors such as using one hand to put on clothes while the other hand removed them.

text 1: Some areas of the cerebral cortex function entirely independently of other cortical and subcortical structures.
text 2: No area of the cerebral cortex functions independently of other cortical and subcortical structures.

text 1: The two cerebral hemispheres receive information from the opposite side of the body.
text 2: The two cerebral hemispheres receive information from the same side of the body.

text 1: Neurons are organized into circuits with specialized functions, with the simplest circuits mediating reflexes.
text 2: Neurons are randomly organized, with the simplest circuits mediating reflexes.

text 1: The neuron doctrine states that nerve cells are merely supportive structures in the nervous system.
text 2: The neuron doctrine states that individual nerve cells are the elementary building blocks and signaling elements of the nervous system.

text 1: Studies of circuits and brain areas show that muscle groups work independently without coordination.
text 2: Studies of circuits and brain areas can explain how widely separated muscle groups are coordinated.

text 1: There is no satisfactory theory that explains why only some information leads to conscious awareness.
text 2: Current neural science provides a complete theory explaining how all information leads to conscious awareness.

text 1: Most cognitive functions transpire without conscious awareness.
text 2: All cognitive functions require conscious awareness.

text 1: Neural recordings from animals have shown no relevance to understanding cognitive processes.
text 2: Neural recordings from animals have led to an understanding of cognitive processes such as decision making and planning.

text 1: The corpus callosum was severed as a treatment for epilepsy in some patients.
text 2: The corpus callosum was severed as a treatment for Parkinson’s disease in some patients.

text 1: Neural science seeks to understand the mechanisms of consciousness through attention and functional neural interactions.
text 2: Neural science claims consciousness arises only from external sensory inputs without neural mediation.

text 1: Cognitive processes such as reasoning are likely carried out by the brain in ways that only loosely resemble conscious deliberation.
text 2: Cognitive processes such as reasoning are identical to the steps observed during conscious deliberation.

text 1: The axon initial segment has a lower threshold for action potential generation because it has a higher density of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.
text 2: The axon initial segment has a higher threshold for action potential generation because it has a lower density of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.

text 1: In most neurons, the decision to initiate an action potential output is made at the axon initial segment.
text 2: In most neurons, the decision to initiate an action potential output is made at the cell body.

text 1: At the axon initial segment, the depolarization increment required to reach the threshold for an action potential is only 10 mV from the resting level of −65 mV.
text 2: At the axon initial segment, the depolarization increment required to reach the threshold for an action potential is 30 mV from the resting level of −65 mV.

text 1: A synaptic potential arising in a dendrite can generate an action potential at the synapse.
text 2: A synaptic potential arising in a dendrite can generate an action potential at the axon initial segment.

text 1: Spatial summation is the process by which consecutive synaptic potentials are added together in the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Temporal summation is the process by which consecutive synaptic potentials are added together in the postsynaptic cell.

text 1: Neurons with a long time constant have a greater capacity for temporal summation than neurons with a shorter time constant.
text 2: Neurons with a short time constant have a greater capacity for temporal summation than neurons with a long time constant.

text 1: Temporal summation is influenced by the length constant of the neuron.
text 2: Spatial summation is influenced by the length constant of the neuron.

text 1: In cells with a longer length constant, signals spread to the trigger zone with minimal decrement.
text 2: In cells with a shorter length constant, signals spread to the trigger zone with minimal decrement.

text 1: Basket cells send their axons to form synapses on the distal dendrites of postsynaptic neurons.
text 2: Basket cells send their axons to form synapses on the cell body and proximal dendrites of postsynaptic neurons.

text 1: Chandelier cells target the axon initial segment with their synapses.
text 2: Chandelier cells target the distal dendrites with their synapses.

text 1: The depolarization produced by an excitatory current from a dendrite must pass along the cell body membrane as it moves toward the axon.
text 2: The depolarization produced by an excitatory current from a dendrite does not pass along the cell body membrane as it moves toward the axon.

text 1: The effectiveness of inhibition is less when inhibition is initiated at the cell body or near the axon trigger zone.
text 2: The effectiveness of inhibition is more when inhibition is initiated at the cell body or near the axon trigger zone.

text 1: Martinotti cells specifically target distal dendrites and spines.
text 2: Martinotti cells specifically target the axon initial segment.

text 1: Neurons with a short length constant are more likely to be brought to threshold by inputs arising from different sites than neurons with a large length constant.
text 2: Neurons with a large length constant are more likely to be brought to threshold by inputs arising from different sites than neurons with a short length constant.

text 1: 80% of all neurons in the mammalian central nervous system are inhibitory.
text 2: Only 20% of all neurons in the mammalian central nervous system are inhibitory.

text 1: Advances in miniaturization and electronics technology now make it possible to record action potentials simultaneously from many hundreds of individual neurons across multiple brain areas.
text 2: Advances in miniaturization and electronics technology now make it impossible to record action potentials from any neuron in the brain areas.

text 1: Genetic-based approaches allow defined types of neurons to be permanently activated or silenced, hindering tests of causality.
text 2: Genetic-based approaches allow defined types of neurons to be activated or silenced during an experiment, supporting tests of causality.

text 1: High-throughput anatomical methods provide information about circuit wiring at an unprecedented level of detail and completeness.
text 2: High-throughput anatomical methods provide very limited information about circuit wiring.

text 1: Signal extraction is often done on the basis of a Bayesian approach.
text 2: Signal extraction is rarely done on the basis of a Bayesian approach.

text 1: Optical imaging methods use fluorescent sensors that signal changes in neural activity.
text 2: Optical imaging methods use non-fluorescent sensors that signal changes in neural activity.

text 1: Fluorescence calcium imaging enables simultaneous monitoring of many thousands of individually identified neurons.
text 2: Fluorescence calcium imaging is unable to monitor more than one neuron at a time.

text 1: Models of neural systems do not aim to reveal how the measured features of a neuron contribute to its function.
text 2: Models of neural systems aim to reveal how the measured features of a neuron contribute to its function.

text 1: Sensory information must be transformed into electrical signals that produce patterns of neural activity for decision making and action.
text 2: Sensory information does not need to be transformed into electrical signals to produce patterns of neural activity for decision making and action.

text 1: Neural coding is a major area of neuroscience research.
text 2: Neural coding is not considered a major area of neuroscience research.

text 1: Visual information is initially encoded in the retina by photoreceptor responses to color and light intensity.
text 2: Visual information is initially encoded in the retina independently of photoreceptor responses to color and light intensity.

text 1: The process by which information is extracted from neural activity is unrelated to decoding.
text 2: The process by which information is extracted from neural activity is called decoding.

text 1: Optogenetic approaches involve expression of light-sensitive proteins and subsequent light delivery to photosensitized neurons.
text 2: Optogenetic approaches do not involve light-sensitive proteins or light delivery.

text 1: Decoding methods are central to the development of neuroprosthetics for people with nervous system impairments.
text 2: Decoding methods do not contribute to the development of neuroprosthetics for people with nervous system impairments.

text 1: Optogenetic and chemogenetic tools offer precise spatiotemporal control over neuronal activity.
text 2: Optogenetic and chemogenetic tools do not offer precise control over neuronal activity.

text 1: The hippocampus does not require place cells for spatial representation of an environment.
text 2: The hippocampus requires place cells for spatial representation of the environment.

text 1: Spinal reflexes often diminish permanently after initial spinal shock.
text 2: Spinal reflexes can become greatly exaggerated after initial spinal shock.

text 1: Reflexes are isolated from centrally generated motor commands.
text 2: Reflexes are smoothly integrated into centrally generated motor commands.

text 1: Supraspinal centers are involved in spinal reflex pathways.
text 2: Only the spinal cord is involved in spinal reflex pathways.

text 1: Spinal cord plasticity is irrelevant in the acquisition of motor skills.
text 2: Spinal cord plasticity is essential in the acquisition of motor skills.

text 1: Research into locomotion has been extensively conducted on cats.
text 2: Research into locomotion has primarily focused on dogs.

text 1: The central pattern generator concept appeared only after 2000.
text 2: The central pattern generator concept has driven research since the 1970s.

text 1: Proprioception regulates the timing and amplitude of stepping.
text 2: Proprioception has no effect on the timing and amplitude of stepping.

text 1: The cerebellum regulates the timing and intensity of descending signals.
text 2: The cerebellum does not influence the timing and intensity of descending signals.

text 1: Mechanoreceptors in the skin are irrelevant for stepping adjustments.
text 2: Mechanoreceptors in the skin allow stepping to adjust to obstacles.

text 1: The spinal cord alone is responsible for the initiation of stepping.
text 2: Supraspinal structures are responsible for the initiation of stepping.

text 1: Visually guided locomotion bypasses the motor cortex.
text 2: Visually guided locomotion involves the motor cortex.

text 1: The basal ganglia do not influence any cortical or brain stem circuits.
text 2: The basal ganglia modify cortical and brain stem circuits.

text 1: Spinal locomotor networks lack organization into rhythm and pattern generation circuits.
text 2: Spinal locomotor networks are organized into rhythm and pattern-generation circuits.

text 1: Somatosensory inputs from moving limbs modulate locomotion.
text 2: Somatosensory inputs do not influence locomotion.

text 1: Spinal circuits responsible for locomotion can be modified by experience.
text 2: Spinal circuits responsible for locomotion cannot be changed by experience.

text 1: Jupiter primarily consists of hydrogen and oxygen.
text 2: Jupiter primarily consists of hydrogen and helium.

text 1: The autonomic division of the peripheral nervous system mediates visceral sensation as well as motor control of the viscera, vascular system, and exocrine glands.
text 2: The autonomic division of the peripheral nervous system only mediates sensation but not motor control of the viscera, vascular system, and exocrine glands.

text 1: The sympathetic system participates in the body's response to stress, whereas the parasympathetic system acts to conserve body resources and restore homeostasis.
text 2: The sympathetic system acts to conserve body resources and restore homeostasis, whereas the parasympathetic system participates in the body's response to stress.

text 1: The hippocampus is unrelated to the medial temporal lobe memory system that encodes and stores memories of our lives.
text 2: The hippocampus is a key component of a medial temporal lobe memory system that encodes and stores memories of our lives.

text 1: The peripheral nervous system supplies the central nervous system with information only about the external environment of the body.
text 2: The peripheral nervous system supplies the central nervous system with information about both the external and internal environments of the body.

text 1: Voluntary movement requires coordination of all components of the motor system such as the motor cortex, basal ganglia, and spinal cord.
text 2: Voluntary movement is independent of components of the motor system such as the motor cortex, basal ganglia, and spinal cord.

text 1: The modulatory neurotransmitter norepinephrine is synthesized and released by neurons in the locus coeruleus.
text 2: The modulatory neurotransmitter norepinephrine is synthesized and released by neurons in the dorsal raphe nucleus.

text 1: The basal nucleus of Meynert, a group of dopaminergic modulatory neurons, is involved in arousal or attention.
text 2: The basal nucleus of Meynert, a group of cholinergic modulatory neurons, is involved in arousal or attention.

text 1: The brain stem does not have distinct modulatory systems for attention and arousal.
text 2: Distinct modulatory systems within the brain stem modulate attention and arousal.

text 1: The enteric nervous system controls the function of smooth muscle and secretions of the gut.
text 2: The enteric nervous system controls the skeletal muscles and secretions of the gut.

text 1: A group of dopaminergic neurons in the midbrain are important for monitoring reinforcements and rewards.
text 2: A group of serotonergic neurons in the midbrain are important for monitoring reinforcements and rewards.

text 1: Memory is mediated by structures distinct from those that carry out sensation or movement.
text 2: Memory is mediated by the same structures that carry out sensation or movement.

text 1: The somatic division of the peripheral nervous system only includes sensory neurons receiving information from joints.
text 2: The somatic division of the peripheral nervous system includes sensory neurons receiving information from the skin, muscles, and joints.

text 1: Receptors associated with sensory neurons do not provide information about muscle and limb position, touch, or pressure.
text 2: Receptors associated with sensory neurons provide information about muscle and limb position, touch, and pressure.

text 1: The physiological satisfaction from eating decreases the chances of behaviors leading to successful predation.
text 2: The physiological satisfaction from eating reinforces behaviors leading to successful predation.

text 1: The somatic division carries information from the skin to the brain and from the brain to muscles.
text 2: The somatic division carries information from the brain to the skin only.

text 1: The lateral geniculate nucleus in each hemisphere receives input from the nasal retina of the ipsilateral eye and the temporal retina of the contralateral eye.
text 2: The lateral geniculate nucleus in each hemisphere receives input from the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye and the nasal retina of the contralateral eye.

text 1: Parvocellular geniculate neurons project to cortical layer IVCβ, while magnocellular neurons project to IVCα.
text 2: Parvocellular geniculate neurons project to cortical layer IVCα, while magnocellular neurons project to IVCβ.

text 1: Koniocellular neurons project to the cytochrome oxidase blobs in cortical layers 2 and 3.
text 2: Koniocellular neurons project to cortical layer IVCβ instead of the cytochrome oxidase blobs.

text 1: The contralateral eye projects to layers 2, 3, and 5 of the lateral geniculate nucleus.
text 2: The contralateral eye projects to layers 1, 4, and 6 of the lateral geniculate nucleus.

text 1: Columnar organization in the visual cortex increases the brain's use of volume but sacrifices processing speed.
text 2: Columnar organization in the visual cortex minimizes the distance required for neurons with similar functional properties to communicate.

text 1: Neurons in the deeper layers of V1 have smaller receptive fields compared to neurons in the superficial layers.
text 2: Neurons in the deeper layers of V1 have larger receptive fields compared to neurons in the superficial layers.

text 1: The dorsal pathway is dedicated to visually guided movement, with cells selective for direction of movement.
text 2: The dorsal pathway carries information primarily about form and color.

text 1: The ventral stream is primarily concerned with object identification, carrying information about form and color.
text 2: The ventral stream is dedicated to visually guided movement, with cells selective for motion.

text 1: Neurons in the parvocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus are primarily involved in detecting motion.
text 2: Neurons in the parvocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus are associated with high-resolution pattern recognition.

text 1: Parallel processing in the visual pathways only processes one submodality at a time, such as either form or movement.
text 2: Parallel processing in the visual pathways allows for simultaneous processing of different submodalities like form, color, and movement.

text 1: Layers 1 and 2 of the lateral geniculate nucleus are parvocellular layers.
text 2: Layers 1 and 2 of the lateral geniculate nucleus are magnocellular layers.

text 1: The cycling of columns for analyzing visual attributes, like orientation and color, occurs rapidly across the cortical surface.
text 2: The cycling of columns for analyzing visual attributes occurs gradually across the cortical surface.

text 1: Pyramidal neurons in layer VI are responsible for connecting primary cortex to higher-order areas.
text 2: Pyramidal neurons in layer VI are responsible for feedback projections to the thalamus and lower-order cortical areas.

text 1: The visual cortex relies solely on excitatory neurons to transform visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus.
text 2: The visual cortex uses local circuits of both excitatory and inhibitory neurons to transform neural information.

text 1: There is considerable interaction between the dorsal and ventral visual streams, allowing for integration of visual features.
text 2: The dorsal and ventral visual streams are completely segregated, with no interaction between them.

text 1: NMDA receptors have a distinctively high permeability to Ca2+.
text 2: NMDA receptors have a distinctively low permeability to Ca2+.

text 1: The NMDA receptor is unique among ligand-gated channels because its opening depends on membrane voltage as well as transmitter binding.
text 2: The NMDA receptor is not unique among ligand-gated channels because its opening only depends on transmitter binding.

text 1: NMDA receptors are largely activated by Mg2+ at the normal resting potential.
text 2: NMDA receptors are largely inhibited by Mg2+ at the normal resting potential.

text 1: NMDA receptor activation cannot translate electrical signals into biochemical ones.
text 2: NMDA receptor activation can translate electrical signals into biochemical ones.

text 1: Glutamate excitotoxicity can be prevented by high concentrations of glutamate.
text 2: Glutamate excitotoxicity can occur with excessively high concentrations of glutamate.

text 1: LTP does not require Ca2+ influx through the NMDA receptor-channels.
text 2: LTP requires Ca2+ influx through the NMDA receptor-channels.

text 1: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity can be induced by presynaptic activity alone.
text 2: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity can be induced by pairing presynaptic with postsynaptic action potentials.

text 1: In tissue culture, brief exposure to high concentrations of glutamate promotes neuron survival.
text 2: In tissue culture, brief exposure to high concentrations of glutamate can kill many neurons.

text 1: The high permeability of NMDA receptor-channels to Ca2+ can trigger various calcium-dependent signaling cascades.
text 2: The high permeability of NMDA receptor-channels to Ca2+ does not involve calcium-dependent signaling cascades.

text 1: APV selectively binds to and activates the NMDA receptor.
text 2: APV selectively binds to and blocks the NMDA receptor.

text 1: The NMDA receptor acts as a molecular 'coincidence detector.'
text 2: The NMDA receptor does not act as a molecular 'coincidence detector.'

text 1: Phencyclidine activates the NMDA receptor.
text 2: Phencyclidine inhibits the NMDA receptor.

text 1: Long-term potentiation occurs without strong postsynaptic depolarization.
text 2: Long-term potentiation requires strong postsynaptic depolarization.
