text 1: NMDA receptors contribute to a late, slow phase of the EPSC and EPSP.
text 2: NMDA receptors only contribute to an early, fast phase of the EPSC and EPSP.

text 1: Physiological levels of NMDA receptor activation always cause damage and cell death.
text 2: Physiological levels of NMDA receptor activation may protect neurons from damage and cell death.

text 1: The process of ubiquitination involves three enzymes: E1, E2, and E3, with E1 providing specificity in the process.
text 2: The process of ubiquitination involves three enzymes: E1, E2, and E3, with E3 providing specificity in the process.

text 1: Monoubiquitination tags a protein for synthesis in the endosomal–lysosomal system.
text 2: Monoubiquitination tags a protein for degradation in the endosomal–lysosomal system.

text 1: Phosphorylation at the hydroxyl group in serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues is a common posttranslational modification.
text 2: Phosphorylation at the hydroxyl group in alanine, threonine, or tyrosine residues is a common posttranslational modification.

text 1: Glycosylation can increase the hydrophilicity of a protein, making it useful for secretory proteins.
text 2: Glycosylation can decrease the hydrophilicity of a protein, making it useful for secretory proteins.

text 1: RNA interference (RNAi) is the targeted synthesis of double-stranded RNAs.
text 2: RNA interference (RNAi) is the targeted destruction of double-stranded RNAs.

text 1: Transport vesicles arrive at the trans side of the Golgi complex and deliver their contents into the Golgi.
text 2: Transport vesicles arrive at the cis side of the Golgi complex and deliver their contents into the Golgi.

text 1: The Golgi complex is composed of membranous sacks aligned with one another in long ribbons.
text 2: The Golgi complex is composed of membranous sacks aligned with one another in circular patterns.

text 1: Large dense-core vesicles are targeted primarily to axons.
text 2: Large dense-core vesicles are targeted primarily to dendrites.

text 1: COPI coats assist in evaginating Golgi complex membrane during endocytosis.
text 2: Clathrin coats assist in evaginating Golgi complex membrane during endocytosis.

text 1: Proteins from the Golgi complex are carried in transport vesicles to the endoplasmic reticulum for modification.
text 2: Proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum are carried in transport vesicles to the Golgi complex for modification.

text 1: Isoprenylation is a posttranslational modification important for anchoring proteins to the extracellular side of membranes.
text 2: Isoprenylation is a posttranslational modification important for anchoring proteins to the cytosolic side of membranes.

text 1: Vesicular traffic is essential for maintaining the area of the membrane in a steady state.
text 2: Vesicular traffic is irrelevant for maintaining the area of the membrane in a steady state.

text 1: The ATP–ubiquitin–proteasome pathway is a mechanism for the selective and regulated proteolysis of proteins.
text 2: The ATP–ubiquitin–proteasome pathway is a mechanism for the selective and regulated synthesis of proteins.

text 1: Posttranslational modification by cytosolic enzymes can occur during protein synthesis.
text 2: Cotranslational modification by cytosolic enzymes can occur during protein synthesis.

text 1: Secretory proteins are synthesized in the Golgi complex after being transported from the rough endoplasmic reticulum.
text 2: Secretory proteins are modified in the Golgi complex after being transported from the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

text 1: Functional imaging studies have identified neural correlates of feelings primarily from animals and from behavioral observations of wild populations.
text 2: Functional imaging studies have identified neural correlates of feelings primarily from humans and from neuropsychological testing of patients with specific brain lesions.

text 1: The insular cortex is activated in the conscious sensation of light and sound.
text 2: The insular cortex is activated in the conscious sensation of pain and temperature.

text 1: Direct electrical stimulation of the subgenual sector of the anterior cingulate cortex has no effect on the mood of patients with severe depression.
text 2: Direct electrical stimulation of the subgenual sector of the anterior cingulate cortex can dramatically improve the mood of some patients with severe depression.

text 1: Positron emission tomography was used in a study where subjects recalled personal episodes to test emotions correlated with cortical and subcortical somatosensory regions.
text 2: Positron emission tomography was used in a study where subjects recalled fictional episodes to test emotions correlated with cortical and subcortical motor regions.

text 1: The medial prefrontal cortex is involved in immediate defensive responses to a close threat.
text 2: The medial prefrontal cortex is involved in planning and anticipation related to a distant threat.

text 1: The feeling of dread is associated with activity in the periaqueductal gray.
text 2: The feeling of dread is associated with activity in the cerebellum.

text 1: Emotion states function independently of organismal parameters like somatic behavior, autonomic responses, and cognition.
text 2: Emotion states integrate changes in organismal parameters such as somatic behavior, autonomic responses, and cognition.

text 1: Functional MRI studies are used to understand the varying roles of emotions and neural circuitry.
text 2: Functional MRI studies are used to diagnose psychological disorders and determine specific treatments.

text 1: Feelings of fear induced by anticipation of electrical shock lead to activation of specific brain areas which have been studied with fMRI.
text 2: Feelings of fear induced by viewing horror films lead to activation of specific brain areas which have been studied with EEG.

text 1: Pure autonomic failure severely compromises visceral afferent information.
text 2: Pure autonomic failure enhances visceral afferent information.

text 1: The insular cortex processes both interoceptive and emotional information.
text 2: The occipital cortex processes both interoceptive and emotional information.

text 1: Studies in neuroeconomics link emotion processing to value-based decision making.
text 2: Studies in neuroeconomics link emotion processing to physical endurance levels of athletes.

text 1: Emotion states are more flexible and context-dependent than simple reflexes.
text 2: Emotion states are less flexible and context-dependent than simple reflexes.

text 1: The amygdala is part of a distributed system involved in the emotion of fear.
text 2: The hippocampus is the sole brain region involved in the emotion of fear.

text 1: Emotions in humans can be both deliberately controlled and spontaneously expressed.
text 2: Emotions in humans are completely autonomic and cannot be deliberately controlled.

text 1: The miniature end-plate potential (mEPP) measures between 5 and 10 mV and occurs at a rate of about 10 per second.
text 2: The miniature end-plate potential (mEPP) measures between 0.5 and 1.0 mV and occurs at a rate of about 1 per second.

text 1: Del Castillo and Katz concluded that an mEPSP represents the action of a single ACh molecule, not a multimolecular packet.
text 2: Del Castillo and Katz concluded that an mEPSP represents the action of a multimolecular packet, not a single ACh molecule.

text 1: The mean open time for ACh receptor-channels is approximately 1 ms, allowing the movement of about 17,000 ions during each opening.
text 2: The mean open time for ACh receptor-channels is approximately 10 ms, allowing the movement of about 170,000 ions during each opening.

text 1: At a resting potential of −90 mV, the current conducted by a single ACh receptor-channel is approximately −2.7 pA.
text 2: At a resting potential of −90 mV, the current conducted by a single ACh receptor-channel is approximately −27 pA.

text 1: The ligand-gated channels at the end-plate are permeable only to K+, excluding Na+ during depolarization of the end-plate potential.
text 2: The ligand-gated channels at the end-plate are permeable to both Na+ and K+, contributing to depolarization during the end-plate potential.

text 1: The reversal potential of ACh receptor-channels is −70 mV and corresponds directly to the equilibrium potential for Na+.
text 2: The reversal potential of ACh receptor-channels is 0 mV and is a weighted average of the equilibrium potentials for Na+ and K+.

text 1: The pore diameter of the ACh receptor-channel is estimated to be approximately 1.0 nm, making it larger than most voltage-gated channels.
text 2: The pore diameter of the ACh receptor-channel is estimated to be approximately 0.6 nm, allowing permeation by tetramethylammonium.

text 1: Voltage-clamp experiments revealed that the end-plate current rises and decays more slowly than the resultant end-plate potential.
text 2: Voltage-clamp experiments revealed that the end-plate current rises and decays more rapidly than the resultant end-plate potential.

text 1: The elementary currents through ACh receptor-channels follow a stochastic pattern governed by statistical laws such as radioactive decay.
text 2: The elementary currents through ACh receptor-channels are deterministic and predictable under normal conditions.

text 1: The conductance of a single ACh receptor-channel is approximately 30 pS, behaving as a simple ohmic resistor.
text 2: The conductance of a single ACh receptor-channel is approximately 300 pS, acting as a highly voltage-dependent resistor.

text 1: The patch-clamp technique is used for recording currents from groups of ACh receptor-channels simultaneously.
text 2: The patch-clamp technique allows for the recording of currents from individual ACh receptor-channels on the muscle membrane.

text 1: At the reversal potential, the influx of Na+ is balanced by an equal efflux of K+, resulting in no net current flow.
text 2: At the reversal potential, the influx of Na+ exceeds the efflux of K+, causing a net inward current flow.

text 1: Opening of ACh receptor-channels leads to outward current during negative membrane potentials and inward current during positive potentials.
text 2: Opening of ACh receptor-channels leads to inward current during negative membrane potentials and outward current during positive potentials.

text 1: The noise produced by low doses of ACh provided the first glimpse of the electrical signaling properties of individual ACh receptor-channels.
text 2: The noise produced by low doses of ACh disrupted efforts to understand the properties of individual ACh receptor-channels.

text 1: Micro-iontophoresis is used to apply ACh directly to the postsynaptic membrane by ejecting positively charged ACh from a microelectrode.
text 2: Micro-iontophoresis is used to measure electrical potential while introducing positively charged proteins from a microelectrode.

text 1: Protanopia and deuteranopia almost always occur in males, each with a frequency of about 1%.
text 2: Protanopia and deuteranopia almost always occur in females, each with a frequency of about 10%.

text 1: The genes for the L and S pigments reside on the Y chromosome in a head-to-tail arrangement.
text 2: The genes for the L and M pigments reside on the X chromosome in a head-to-tail arrangement.

text 1: Tritanopia involves the loss or dysfunction of the S cone.
text 2: Tritanopia involves the loss or dysfunction of the L cone.

text 1: Dichromats have only two classes of cones instead of three.
text 2: Dichromats have four classes of cones instead of three.

text 1: Anomalous trichromacy results from the increase in the number of cone pigments.
text 2: Anomalous trichromacy results from the replacement of one of the normal cone pigments by an altered protein.

text 1: The rod signal is fed into the cone system after a detour involving AII amacrine cells.
text 2: The rod signal is fed directly to the ganglion cells without any detour.

text 1: Protanopia and deuteranopia are transmitted by men who are not themselves affected.
text 2: Protanopia and deuteranopia are transmitted by women who are not themselves affected.

text 1: Most abnormalities of color vision have been characterized in detail as congenital.
text 2: Most abnormalities of color vision are newly emerging and not well understood.

text 1: Tritanopia affects about 1 in 100 people.
text 2: Tritanopia affects about 1 in 10,000 people.

text 1: The M-cells project to the magnocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus.
text 2: The M-cells project to the koniocellular layers of the lateral geniculate nucleus.

text 1: The opponent-process theory involves two processes that respond in the same way to light of different colors.
text 2: The opponent-process theory involves three processes that respond in opposite ways to light of different colors.

text 1: Colorblind individuals usually notice their defect early in life.
text 2: Colorblind individuals can grow up without noticing their defect.

text 1: Light adaptation in the retina adjusts sensitivity to ambient illumination.
text 2: Light adaptation in the retina adjusts sensitivity to sound variations.

text 1: There is an OFF bipolar cell dedicated exclusively to rods.
text 2: There is no OFF bipolar cell dedicated to rods.

text 1: The total number of L and M cones in the dichromat retina is not altered.
text 2: The total number of L and M cones in the dichromat retina is drastically reduced.

text 1: The axon of an olfactory sensory neuron as well as the primary dendrite of each mitral and tufted relay neuron terminate in a single glomerulus.
text 2: The axon of an olfactory sensory neuron as well as the primary dendrite of each mitral and tufted relay neuron terminate in multiple glomeruli.

text 1: In each glomerulus, the axons of several hundred sensory neurons converge on the dendrites of approximately 400 to 500 relay neurons.
text 2: In each glomerulus, the axons of several thousand sensory neurons converge on the dendrites of approximately 40 to 50 relay neurons.

text 1: The convergence of neurons results in approximately a 10-fold decrease in the number of neurons transmitting olfactory signals.
text 2: The convergence of neurons results in approximately a 100-fold decrease in the number of neurons transmitting olfactory signals.

text 1: Olfactory sensory neurons with the same odorant receptor are randomly scattered in one epithelial zone.
text 2: Olfactory sensory neurons with the same odorant receptor are orderly arranged in one epithelial zone.

text 1: Each glomerulus receives input from multiple types of odorant receptors.
text 2: Each glomerulus receives input from just one type of odorant receptor.

text 1: The patterns of glomerular activation elicited by individual odorants are vastly different in all individuals and are asymmetrical in the two adjacent bulbs.
text 2: The patterns of glomerular activation elicited by individual odorants are similar in all individuals and are bilaterally symmetrical in the two adjacent bulbs.

text 1: The neural code for an odorant in the brain is maintained over time, assuring that an odorant encountered previously can be recognized years later.
text 2: The neural code for an odorant in the brain frequently changes, preventing recognition of an odorant encountered years later.

text 1: Signals from thousands of sensory neurons with the same odorant receptor type always diverge to multiple glomeruli.
text 2: Signals from thousands of sensory neurons with the same odorant receptor type always converge on the same few glomeruli.

text 1: Studies using transgenic mice indicate that external signals somehow determine the target of the axon.
text 2: Studies using transgenic mice indicate that the odorant receptor itself somehow determines the target of the axon.

text 1: Each glomerulus is encircled by periglomerular interneurons that receive inhibitory input from sensory axons.
text 2: Each glomerulus is encircled by periglomerular interneurons that receive excitatory input from sensory axons.

text 1: Granule cell interneurons deep in the bulb provide positive feedback onto mitral and tufted cells.
text 2: Granule cell interneurons deep in the bulb provide negative feedback onto mitral and tufted cells.

text 1: The olfactory cortex comprises multiple anatomically distinct areas including the piriform cortex.
text 2: The olfactory cortex comprises a single anatomically distinct area, the piriform cortex.

text 1: The piriform cortex is thought to be important for odor learning.
text 2: The piriform cortex is thought to be important for visual learning.

text 1: The olfactory cortex projects to the olfactory bulb, providing another possible means of signal modulation.
text 2: The olfactory cortex projects away from the olfactory bulb, eliminating an additional chance of signal modulation.

text 1: Pyramidal neurons in the olfactory cortex transmit information indirectly to the orbitofrontal cortex through the thalamus.
text 2: Pyramidal neurons in the olfactory cortex transmit information directly to the orbitofrontal cortex, bypassing the thalamus.

text 1: The step cycle is divided into four phases, with flexion (F) and first extension (E1) occurring during the swing phase, while second extension (E2) and third extension (E3) occur during the stance phase.
text 2: The step cycle is divided into three phases, with flexion (F) and first extension (E1) occurring during the stance phase, while second extension (E2) occurs during the swing phase.

text 1: Flexor and extensor muscles in the cat's hind leg are generally active during the stance and swing phases, respectively.
text 2: Flexor and extensor muscles in the cat's hind leg are generally active during the swing and stance phases, respectively.

text 1: During a trot, the diagonal limbs (e.g., the left hindlimb and the right forelimb) are out of phase, and the phase difference between homolateral limbs is 1.0.
text 2: During a trot, the diagonal limbs (e.g., the left hindlimb and the right forelimb) are in phase, and the phase difference between homolateral limbs is 0.5.

text 1: Locomotor-like activity in an isolated spinal cord can be induced by the application of dopamine and adrenaline to the bathing solution.
text 2: Locomotor-like activity in an isolated spinal cord can be induced by the application of NMDA and serotonin to the bathing solution.

text 1: The flexor-extensor alternation is seen as in-phase activity between L2 and L5 ventral roots on the same side of the cord.
text 2: The flexor-extensor alternation is seen as out-of-phase activity between L2 and L5 ventral roots on the same side of the cord.

text 1: E2 is characterized by extension at the knee and ankle as the leg begins to bear the animal’s weight.
text 2: E2 is characterized by flexion at the knee and ankle as the leg begins to bear the animal’s weight.

text 1: Muscles within a single limb must be activated and coordinated in a precise spatiotemporal pattern during locomotion.
text 2: Muscles within a single limb can be activated and coordinated in a random spatiotemporal pattern during locomotion.

text 1: The central nervous system is responsible for appropriate intra- and inter-limb coordination during locomotion.
text 2: The peripheral nervous system is responsible for appropriate intra- and inter-limb coordination during locomotion.

text 1: Activity in more caudal roots occurs later than in more rostral roots, and the activity on each side of the body is reciprocal.
text 2: Activity in more rostral roots occurs later than in more caudal roots, and the activity on each side of the body is non-reciprocal.

text 1: During walking, activity between the homolateral limbs usually varies by a phase value of 0.75.
text 2: During walking, activity between the homolateral limbs usually varies by a phase value of 0.25.

text 1: Rhythmic locomotion in an intact animal can be recorded as an electrocardiogram.
text 2: Rhythmic locomotion in an intact animal can be recorded as an electromyogram.

text 1: In an isolated spinal cord, rhythmic patterns similar to those in a swimming lamprey can be recorded from four ventral roots.
text 2: In an isolated spinal cord, rhythmic patterns similar to those in a swimming frog can be recorded from four ventral roots.

text 1: In the hindlimb, swing is initiated by flexion of the knee produced by activation of muscles such as the semitendinosus.
text 2: In the hindlimb, swing is initiated by extension of the knee produced by activation of muscles such as the semitendinosus.

text 1: Phase relationships between limbs of the same girdle are more stable during gaits produced by alternating limb activation.
text 2: Phase relationships between limbs of the same girdle are less stable during gaits produced by alternating limb activation.

text 1: Locomotion is induced chemically by application of dopaminergic or adrenergic receptor agonists, or electrically by stimulating the heart.
text 2: Locomotion is induced chemically by application of glutamatergic or serotonergic receptor agonists, or electrically by stimulating the brain stem.

text 1: A single climbing fiber from neurons in the inferior olive forms up to 100 terminals on a single Purkinje neuron in the cerebellum.
text 2: A single climbing fiber from neurons in the inferior olive forms up to 10,000 terminals on a single Purkinje neuron in the cerebellum.

text 1: Most central neurons form thousands of synapses with any one postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Most central neurons form only a few synapses with any one postsynaptic cell.

text 1: The probability of transmitter release from a single active zone is consistently around 0.5 among presynaptic terminals.
text 2: The probability of transmitter release from a single active zone varies among presynaptic terminals from less than 0.1 to greater than 0.9.

text 1: Synaptic reliability is the certainty that an action potential will not lead to a response in the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Synaptic reliability is the probability that an action potential in a presynaptic cell leads to a measurable response in the postsynaptic cell.

text 1: Most central neurons communicate at synapses that have a low probability of transmitter release.
text 2: Most central neurons communicate at synapses that have a high probability of transmitter release.

text 1: Reliable transmission at the neuromuscular junction is essential for survival.
text 2: Reliable transmission at the neuromuscular junction is unnecessary for survival.

text 1: Approximately 90% of the ACh that leaves the presynaptic terminals at the neuromuscular junction does so through synchronous release.
text 2: Approximately 90% of the ACh that leaves the presynaptic terminals at the neuromuscular junction does so through continuous leakage.

text 1: Synaptic vesicles release their contents by directly fusing with the presynaptic membrane, a process termed exocytosis.
text 2: Synaptic vesicles release their contents by disintegrating in the synaptic cleft.

text 1: Heuser and Reese found that deformations of the presynaptic membrane occur only when vesicles are discharged.
text 2: Heuser and Reese found that deformations of the presynaptic membrane persist after transmitter is released.

text 1: Endocytosis through coated pit formation is the only means of vesicle membrane retrieval.
text 2: Endocytosis through coated pit formation represents one of several means of vesicle membrane retrieval.

text 1: In certain neurons, no change in surface area of the plasma membrane during exocytosis is detected.
text 2: In certain neurons, the increase in surface area of the plasma membrane during exocytosis can be detected as increases in membrane capacitance.

text 1: The capacitance of the membrane is inversely proportional to its surface area.
text 2: The capacitance of the membrane is proportional to its surface area.

text 1: Exocytosis is independent of the formation of a temporary fusion pore.
text 2: Exocytosis depends on the formation of a temporary fusion pore that spans the membranes of the vesicle and plasma membranes.

text 1: The fusion pore has no similarity to the conductance of gap-junction channels.
text 2: The fusion pore starts out with a conductance of approximately 200 pS, similar to that of gap-junction channels.

text 1: Transmitter can be released through the fusion pore prior to pore expansion and vesicle collapse.
text 2: Transmitter is not released through the fusion pore until after vesicle collapse.

text 1: The blood oxygenation level–dependent (BOLD) contrast relies on differences in magnetic properties between water levels in brain regions.
text 2: The blood oxygenation level–dependent (BOLD) contrast relies on differences in magnetic properties between oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

text 1: Oxygenated blood causes faster T2* decay due to interactions with the magnetic field.
text 2: Deoxygenated blood causes faster T2* decay due to interactions with the magnetic field.

text 1: The hemodynamic response function typically peaks around 1 to 2 seconds after local neural activity.
text 2: The hemodynamic response function typically peaks around 4 to 5 seconds after local neural activity.

text 1: fMRI data preprocessing involves steps like motion correction, slice-time correction, temporal filtering, spatial smoothing, and anatomical alignment.
text 2: fMRI preprocessing involves steps like temporal filtering, behavioral scoring, and electrode placement.

text 1: Motion correction addresses noise in the data caused by the subject's head movement during a scan.
text 2: Motion correction addresses noise in the data caused by changes in blood oxygenation levels.

text 1: Preprocessing removes only machine-related noise but not subject-related noise.
text 2: Standard preprocessing removes known sources of noise caused by both the subject and the MRI machine.

text 1: Multivariate pattern analysis predicts future blood oxygenation levels based solely on heart rate variability.
text 2: Multivariate pattern analysis can involve training a classifier model to distinguish between task conditions based on voxel patterns.

text 1: Functional connectivity analysis examines how BOLD activity is correlated between voxels over time.
text 2: Functional connectivity analysis examines how neural firing rates directly generate BOLD signals.

text 1: The concept of 'initial dip' refers to an immediate focal rise in deoxygenated blood at the site of neuronal activity.
text 2: The concept of 'initial dip' refers to an immediate oversupply of oxygenated blood at the site of neuronal activity.

text 1: The temporal profile of the BOLD response begins with a decrease in oxygenation followed by a delayed increase.
text 2: The temporal profile of the BOLD response begins with an immediate increase in oxygenation without a subsequent decrease.

text 1: Neurovascular coupling is solely determined by the activity of blood vessels, without any role for astrocytes.
text 2: Astrocytes may play a functional role in neurovascular coupling.

text 1: The growing use of machine learning in fMRI analysis reflects its focus on measuring electrical neural spikes directly.
text 2: The growing use of machine learning in fMRI analysis reflects its complexity and large data sizes.

text 1: Slice-time correction addresses timing differences in the acquisition of samples across slices in EPI sequences.
text 2: Slice-time correction addresses timing differences in the hemodynamic response across brain regions.

text 1: Standard preprocessing makes raw fMRI data immediately ready for analysis without any further correction.
text 2: Standard preprocessing steps help reduce noise, improve signal-to-noise ratio, and align data to a standard brain template.

text 1: Univariate activation analysis describes voxel-by-voxel modeling of BOLD responses based on task conditions.
text 2: Univariate activation analysis compares head movement artifacts directly across participants in a study.

text 1: Damage to the midline cerebellum or vermis seems to be related to emotional or affective dysregulation, likely due to its interconnectivity with limbic structures.
text 2: Damage to the lateral cerebellum or hemispheres seems to be related to emotional or affective dysregulation, likely due to its interconnectivity with limbic structures.

text 1: Peter Strick and his colleagues demonstrated disynaptic connections between the cerebellum and basal ganglia in nonhuman primates.
text 2: Peter Strick and his colleagues demonstrated monosynaptic connections between the cerebellum and basal ganglia in nonhuman primates.

text 1: The vestibulocerebellum receives auditory and gustatory inputs, projects to the vestibular nuclei in the brain stem, and participates in balance, other vestibular reflexes, and eye movements.
text 2: The vestibulocerebellum receives vestibular and visual inputs, projects to the vestibular nuclei in the brain stem, and participates in balance, other vestibular reflexes, and eye movements.

text 1: The cerebellum is connected to the brain stem by three symmetrical pairs of peduncles: inferior, middle, and superior cerebellar peduncles.
text 2: The cerebellum is connected to the brain stem by four symmetrical pairs of peduncles: inferior, middle, superior, and lateral cerebellar peduncles.

text 1: Most of the output axons of the cerebellum arise from the deep nuclei and project through the superior cerebellar peduncle to other brain areas.
text 2: Most of the output axons of the cerebellum arise from the cerebellar cortex and project through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to other brain areas.

text 1: The cerebellum occupies most of the posterior cranial fossa and is composed of an outer mantle of gray matter, internal white matter, and three pairs of deep nuclei.
text 2: The cerebellum occupies most of the anterior cranial fossa and is composed of an outer mantle of gray matter, internal white matter, and three pairs of deep nuclei.

text 1: The cerebellum is divided into four lobes by three deep transverse fissures: anterior, posterior, flocculonodular, and occipital lobes.
text 2: The cerebellum is divided into three lobes by two deep transverse fissures: anterior, posterior, and flocculonodular lobes.

text 1: Damage to the left cerebellar hemisphere is related to language and verbal dysfunction, presumably due to its connection with the left cerebral cortical hemisphere.
text 2: Damage to the right cerebellar hemisphere is related to language and verbal dysfunction, presumably due to its connection with the left cerebral cortical hemisphere.

text 1: The cerebellum indirectly controls movement through other brain structures.
text 2: The cerebellum directly controls movement without interaction with other brain structures.

text 1: The most striking deficits following lesions of the lateral vestibulocerebellum are in rapid reflexive eye movement toward the opposite side of the lesion.
text 2: The most striking deficits following lesions of the lateral vestibulocerebellum are in smooth-pursuit eye movement toward the side of the lesion.

text 1: Disruption of vestibulocerebellum projections through lesions or disease enhances equilibrium.
text 2: Disruption of vestibulocerebellum projections through lesions or disease impairs equilibrium.

text 1: The cerebellum connects with the cerebral cortex through recurrent loops involving medulla and hypothalamus.
text 2: The cerebellum connects with the cerebral cortex through recurrent loops involving pons and thalamus.

text 1: Cognitive deficits may be less significant and short lasting when cerebellar damage is acquired in childhood.
text 2: Cognitive deficits may be more robust and long lasting when cerebellar damage is acquired in childhood.

text 1: Damage to the left cerebellar hemisphere is related to language dysfunction, probably because this hemisphere is interconnected with the right cerebral cortical hemisphere.
text 2: Damage to the left cerebellar hemisphere is related to visuospatial dysfunction, probably because this hemisphere is interconnected with the right cerebral cortical hemisphere.

text 1: Most studies show cognitive deficits are most pronounced shortly after damage to the cerebellum, with compensations by the cerebral cortex over time.
text 2: Most studies show cognitive deficits are minor immediately after damage to the cerebellum but worsen over time due to lack of cerebral cortical compensation.

text 1: In amnesic patients with damage to the hippocampus, the ability to imagine new events is markedly impaired.
text 2: In amnesic patients with damage to the hippocampus, the ability to imagine new events is remarkably enhanced.

text 1: Studies involving brain imaging show no neural activity in specific areas of the brain during imagining or daydreaming.
text 2: Studies involving brain imaging have shown that neural activity occurs in specific areas of the brain when imagining or daydreaming.

text 1: The fusiform face area shows increased activity when viewing houses.
text 2: The fusiform face area shows increased activity when viewing faces.

text 1: Signal detection theory, developed in the 1950s, provides a robust methodology for measuring the ability to detect a stimulus independently of any reporting biases.
text 2: Signal detection theory, developed in the 1950s, was created to explore reporting biases, rather than measure the ability to detect a stimulus.

text 1: Weber’s law states that the just-noticeable difference between two stimuli is proportional to the magnitude of the stimuli.
text 2: Weber’s law states that the just-noticeable difference between two stimuli is inversely proportional to the magnitude of the stimuli.

text 1: Psychophysics is the study of the relationship between sensation and perception.
text 2: Psychophysics is the study of the relationship between cognition and behavior.

text 1: Introspection was considered a minor method for obtaining data in psychology a hundred years ago.
text 2: Introspection was the major method for obtaining data in psychology a hundred years ago.

text 1: The fusiform gyrus is also known as the face recognition area.
text 2: The parahippocampal place area is also known as the face recognition area.

text 1: Malingerers are not aware they are simulating disorders.
text 2: Malingerers are aware they are simulating disorders.

text 1: Subjective reports were disregarded during the dominance of behaviorism.
text 2: Subjective reports were heavily relied upon during the dominance of behaviorism.

text 1: Patients with damage to the anterior prefrontal cortex retain the ability to detect visual signals but show a deficit in metacognitive accuracy.
text 2: Patients with damage to the anterior prefrontal cortex lose the ability to detect visual signals but have enhanced metacognitive accuracy.

text 1: Behavioral observations alone are sufficient to explore cognitive processes.
text 2: Behavioral observations must be supplemented with subjective reports to explore cognitive processes.

text 1: Brain imaging cannot provide any confirmation of the content of experience reported by the subject.
text 2: Brain imaging can provide independent confirmation of the content of experience reported by the subject.

text 1: The parahippocampal place area shows decreased activity when viewing houses.
text 2: The parahippocampal place area shows increased activity when viewing houses.

text 1: Metacognitive accuracy allows one to discriminate between right and wrong answers.
text 2: Metacognitive accuracy has no relation to discriminating between right and wrong answers.

text 1: At an intermediate sarcomere length, Lo, the amount of overlap between actin and myosin is minimal and the relative force is least.
text 2: At an intermediate sarcomere length, Lo, the amount of overlap between actin and myosin is optimal and the relative force is maximal.

text 1: When the sarcomere is stretched beyond the length at which the thick and thin filaments overlap, cross bridges form and force is maximized.
text 2: When the sarcomere is stretched beyond the length at which the thick and thin filaments overlap, cross bridges cannot form and no force is exerted.

text 1: Muscle force reaches a maximum at the maximal shortening velocity (Vmax).
text 2: Muscle force reaches a minimum at the maximal shortening velocity (Vmax).

text 1: The force that a myofibril can exert is equal to the average sarcomere force and is not influenced by the number of sarcomeres in series.
text 2: The force that a myofibril can exert is influenced by the number of sarcomeres in series.

text 1: The force capacity of a fiber depends on the number of sarcomeres in series and hence on the length of the fiber.
text 2: The force capacity of a fiber depends on the number of sarcomeres in parallel and hence on the diameter or cross-sectional area of the fiber.

text 1: The relative orientation, or pennation angle of the fascicles, always exceeds 30°.
text 2: The relative orientation, or pennation angle of the fascicles, ranges from close to 0° to approximately 30°.

text 1: Muscles with large pennation angles typically have fewer fascicles in parallel and hence smaller cross-sectional areas.
text 2: Muscles with large pennation angles typically have more fascicles in parallel and hence large cross-sectional areas.

text 1: Given the linear relation between cross-sectional area and maximal force, muscles with larger cross-sectional areas are capable of greater maximal force.
text 2: Muscles with larger cross-sectional areas are capable of lesser maximal force.

text 1: The magnitude of muscle rotation from the line of pull is expressed as the compression angle.
text 2: The magnitude of muscle rotation from the line of pull is expressed as the pennation angle.

text 1: If two muscles have identical numbers of fibers but the fibers in one are twice as long, the muscle with longer fibers will have a greater range of motion.
text 2: If two muscles have identical numbers of fibers but the fibers in one are twice as long, the muscle with longer fibers will have a reduced range of motion.

text 1: Muscles with longer fibers can exert more force and produce more power at a given absolute shortening velocity.
text 2: Muscles with shorter fibers can exert more force and produce more power at a given absolute shortening velocity.

text 1: At the level of the muscle, functional attributes are unaffected by the orientation of fascicles to the line of pull.
text 2: At the level of the muscle, functional attributes are modified by the orientation of fascicles to the line of pull and the fiber length relative to the muscle length.

text 1: Different pennation angles allow more fibers to fit into a given muscle volume, affecting force production.
text 2: Different pennation angles do not allow more fibers to fit into a given muscle volume and have no effect on force production.

text 1: Muscle fiber lengths and cross-sectional areas are uniform throughout the human body, suggesting consistent contractile properties.
text 2: Muscle fiber lengths and cross-sectional areas vary substantially throughout the human body, suggesting varying contractile properties.

text 1: The muscle with longer fibers, and consequently greater range of motion, can exert more force at a given absolute shortening velocity.
text 2: The muscle with shorter fibers can exert more force at a given absolute shortening velocity, regardless of range of motion.

text 1: The cerebellum is a forebrain structure vital for sensory perception but does not play a role in motor coordination.
text 2: The cerebellum is a hindbrain structure vital for motor coordination but also implicated in the adaptive regulation of autonomic, sensory, and cognitive functions.

text 1: Each granule cell in the cerebellum receives thousands of inputs from different sources.
text 2: Each granule cell in the cerebellum receives just a handful of inputs, around four on average.

text 1: The cerebellar granule cells provide an extreme example of convergent feedback connectivity with approximately 200 million output fibers.
text 2: The cerebellar granule cells provide an extreme example of divergent feedforward connectivity with approximately 200 million input fibers.

text 1: In divergent connections, the number of neurons that receive a given type of input exceeds the number of neurons providing that input.
text 2: In divergent connections, the number of neurons providing a given input exceeds the number of neurons that receive that input.

text 1: Visual information is processed exclusively in a single brain region without hierarchical arrangement.
text 2: Visual information is processed within the brain regions that are hierarchically arranged.

text 1: Recurrent circuitry is needed to produce ongoing, dynamic patterns of activity.
text 2: Feedforward circuitry alone can produce ongoing, dynamic patterns of activity without recurssion.

text 1: A single Purkinje cell receives input from over a hundred thousand granule cells.
text 2: A single Purkinje cell receives input from only a few hundred granule cells.

text 1: The arrangement of receptive fields in visual areas is randomly organized, not matching the retina's layout.
text 2: The arrangement of receptive fields in visual areas is topographically matched to the retina's layout.

text 1: Machine learning networks are far from reaching human-level performance on any object recognition tasks.
text 2: Machine learning networks can reach human-level performance on some object recognition tasks.

text 1: Oculomotor neurons that control the eye muscles increase action potential firing transiently to evoke movement.
text 2: Oculomotor neurons control eye muscles by maintaining constant action potential firing without change.

text 1: Neurons at higher visual processing stages respond more selectively to a larger part of the visual field.
text 2: Neurons at higher visual processing stages respond less selectively to a smaller part of the visual field.

text 1: The firing of individual granule cells is limited to a single stimulus at a time.
text 2: The firing of individual granule cells may represent a vast range of combinations of stimuli or events.

text 1: Neurons have a perfect memory with synaptic inputs sustaining indefinitely without decay.
text 2: Neurons are inherently forgetful with transient synaptic input typically decaying within milliseconds.

text 1: Integration requires sustained activity at a constant level even after the input is gone.
text 2: Integration relies on transient activity that ceases completely after the input is removed.

text 1: Receptive fields enlarge as neurons progress from lower to higher stages of visual processing.
text 2: Receptive fields shrink as neurons progress from lower to higher stages of visual processing.

text 1: The micturition reflex requires interplay between the parasympathetic and sympathetic divisions of the autonomic system.
text 2: The micturition reflex requires interplay only within the parasympathetic division of the autonomic system.

text 1: When bladder volume is low, urinary outflow is inhibited because activity in the sympathetic pathway is greater than activity in the parasympathetic pathway.
text 2: When bladder volume is low, urinary outflow is enhanced because activity in the parasympathetic pathway is greater than activity in the sympathetic pathway.

text 1: The sympathetic component of the baroreceptor reflex includes outputs that increase heart rate and the strength of contractions.
text 2: The sympathetic component of the baroreceptor reflex includes outputs that decrease heart rate and the strength of contractions.

text 1: The caudal ventral lateral medulla creates positive feedback so that an increase in blood pressure enhances sympathetic activity.
text 2: The caudal ventral lateral medulla creates negative feedback so that an increase in blood pressure inhibits sympathetic activity.

text 1: Visceral information is distributed from the nucleus of the solitary tract and ascending spinal pathways.
text 2: Visceral information is distributed solely from the parabrachial nucleus.

text 1: The periaqueductal gray helps redirect blood flow from the digestive system to the hind limbs during the defensive 'fight-or-flight' response.
text 2: The periaqueductal gray redirects blood flow from the hind limbs to the digestive system during the defensive 'fight-or-flight' response.

text 1: The medial prefrontal cortex solely controls voluntary movement without affecting autonomic functions.
text 2: The medial prefrontal cortex includes areas that interact to produce autonomic effects like contractions of the stomach.

text 1: Selective lesions of the amygdalar region prevent conditioned emotional responses.
text 2: Selective lesions of the amygdalar region amplify conditioned emotional responses.

text 1: The pituitary gland is a single uniform structure without distinct subdivisions.
text 2: The pituitary gland has two functionally and anatomically distinct subdivisions.

text 1: Parasympathetic neurons in the cardiac ganglion create an inhibitory cardiac input that is functionally antagonistic to the sympathetic pathway.
text 2: Parasympathetic neurons in the cardiac ganglion enhance sympathetic activity by creating a supportive cardiac input.

text 1: Sympathetic postganglionic fibers enhance parasympathetic activity by promoting preganglionic release of acetylcholine.
text 2: Sympathetic postganglionic fibers reduce parasympathetic activity by inhibiting preganglionic release of acetylcholine.

text 1: During bladder filling, descending pathways inhibit sympathetic and somatic outflows through inhibitory spinal interneurons.
text 2: During bladder filling, descending pathways promote sympathetic and somatic outflows through excitatory spinal interneurons.

text 1: Descending activity from the pontine micturition center excites the parasympathetic outflow.
text 2: Descending activity from the pontine micturition center inhibits the parasympathetic outflow.

text 1: Inhibition of somatic motor neurons in Onuf’s nucleus causes relaxation and opening of the external sphincter.
text 2: Inhibition of somatic motor neurons in Onuf’s nucleus causes contraction and closing of the external sphincter.

text 1: The sympathetic pathway increases heart rate and constricts arteries raising blood pressure.
text 2: The sympathetic pathway decreases heart rate and dilates arteries reducing blood pressure.

text 1: Van Gogh painted 'Bedroom at Arles' with the walls painted pale lilac.
text 2: Van Gogh painted 'Bedroom at Arles' with the walls painted deep purple.

text 1: Van Gogh's painting includes a blanket that is sky-blue.
text 2: Van Gogh's painting includes a blanket that is blood-red.

text 1: Van Gogh's painting features a dressing-table that is violet.
text 2: Van Gogh's painting features a dressing-table that is orange.

text 1: There is still debate about the cause of Van Gogh's psychotic episodes.

text 1: Van Gogh had wished to express utter repose with the various tones in his painting.
text 2: Van Gogh had wished to express chaos and unrest with the various tones in his painting.

text 1: Dostoevsky's experience of epilepsy had no impact on his writing.

text 1: Van Gogh is thought to have possibly suffered from lead poisoning among other conditions.
text 2: There is no suggestion that Van Gogh suffered from lead poisoning.

text 1: Prince Muishkin feels no change in consciousness before an epileptic fit.
text 2: Prince Muishkin feels an intense consciousness of self just before an epileptic fit.

text 1: Van Gogh used flat tints but coarsely brushed in full impasto in his painting.

text 1: Van Gogh and Gaugin did not communicate through letters.
text 2: Van Gogh communicated with his friend Gaugin through letters.

text 1: Van Gogh's pillows and sheet are painted in bright orange.

text 1: Van Gogh had psychotic episodes, a debated topic regarding their exact causes.

text 1: Prince Muishkin reflects on his experiences during epileptic fits.
text 2: Prince Muishkin is indifferent to his experiences during epileptic fits.

text 1: Epileptic fits bring Prince Muishkin moments of fear and dread.
text 2: Epileptic fits provide Prince Muishkin with moments of joy and hope.

text 1: Lesions of the supplementary motor area (SMA) and presupplementary motor area (pre-SMA) enhance the initiation and adjustment of movements.
text 2: Lesions of the supplementary motor area (SMA) and presupplementary motor area (pre-SMA) produce deficits in the initiation and suppression of movements.

text 1: The medial premotor areas, including SMA, pre-SMA, and CMA, are implicated in self-initiated movements and action suppression.
text 2: The medial premotor areas, including SMA, pre-SMA, and CMA, are only involved in executing pre-programmed actions.

text 1: Neurons in the supplementary motor complex encode specific sequences of motor acts.
text 2: Neurons in the supplementary motor complex only execute random motor acts without sequence specificity.

text 1: Dorsal premotor cortex is involved in planning sensory-guided movement of the arm.
text 2: Dorsal premotor cortex is not involved in planning any movements of the arm.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the SMC below movement initiation threshold results in no neuronal activity.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the SMC below movement initiation threshold can evoke an introspective urge to move.

text 1: Lesions of the SMC eliminate all voluntary motor control without specific deficits in initiation or suppression.
text 2: Lesions of the SMC produce problems initiating desired movements or suppressing undesirable movements.

text 1: SMC neurons discharge randomly without respect to the specific sequence of movements.
text 2: SMC neurons discharge before the start of specific movement sequences but not before a different sequence of the same movements.

text 1: Premotor cortex lesions have no effect on the selection of motor actions.
text 2: Premotor cortex lesions lead to impairments in the selection of motor actions.

text 2: Focal lesions of the dorsal premotor cortex improve the ability to learn and recall sensorimotor mappings.

text 1: The readiness potential peaks in the cortex centered in the SMC before movement onset.
text 2: The readiness potential peaks in the cortex centered in the occipital lobe before any visual stimulus is processed.

text 1: CMA is solely responsible for executing pre-planned motions without adjustments.
text 2: CMA appears to be involved in selecting alternate actions following motor errors.

text 1: Utilization behavior involves restrained use of objects tailored to social needs.
text 2: Utilization behavior involves compulsively using objects without consideration of social context.

text 1: PMd neurons can signal the intention to generate a motor act independent of the effector used.
text 2: PMd neurons exclusively signal actions dependent on the effector used.

text 1: SMC is only involved in the stabilizing and continuation of the same action plan.

text 2: Lesions affecting premotor cortex enhance the use of visual information to shape hand movements before grasping.

text 1: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) is composed of the cuneiform nucleus (CNF) and the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) in the midbrain.

text 1: Low-frequency stimulation in the CNF results only in slow, exploratory locomotion.
text 2: Low-frequency stimulation in the CNF results only in fast, escape locomotion.

text 1: Most modern MRI machines are 3T, and the use of higher field strengths like 7T offers some advantages, including the possibility of higher-resolution imaging of cortical layers.

text 1: fMRI experiments enable investigators to track brain structure based on changes in local blood oxygen levels that occur in response to neural activity.

text 1: A key property of protons is that they intrinsically rotate around an axis, giving protons angular momentum and a magnetic dipole along the axis.
text 2: A key property of protons is that they remain stationary, without any rotation around an axis, giving them no angular momentum or magnetic dipole.

text 1: The Larmor equation determines the speed of precession, according to the field strength and a gyromagnetic ratio specific to each type of atom.
text 2: The Euler equation determines the speed of precession, according to the field strength and a gyromagnetic ratio specific to each type of atom.

text 1: Visual stimuli are directly projected onto a screen located on the side of the bore without using a mirror.
text 2: Visual stimuli are typically viewed through a mirror on the head coil angled toward a screen at the back of the bore.

text 1: fMRI depends solely on electrical conductivity and nerve impulses.

text 1: Subjects lie on a bed with their head in a helmet-like head coil, which receives signals from the brain.

text 1: Neuronal activity leads to increased delivery of oxygenated blood, reducing field inhomogeneities.
text 2: Neuronal activity leads to decreased delivery of oxygenated blood, increasing field inhomogeneities.

text 1: During fMRI, no gradients are applied to select specific slices of brain tissue.
text 2: During fMRI, one gradient is applied in a specific direction to select a slice of brain tissue.

text 1: Functional MRI can be performed and repeated without harm in many different types of subjects, from children to the elderly.
text 2: Functional MRI can only be performed once and is harmful to most subjects, especially to children.

text 1: Gray matter is brighter than white matter in T1-weighted images.

text 1: The standard pulse sequence for measuring brain function is the gradient recall sequence.

text 2: Protons precessing synchronously can be measured by transmitting a radiofrequency (RF) pulse.

text 1: The transverse magnetization dissipates over time, and signal is lost.

text 1: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System and has a strong magnetic field.

text 2: NMDA receptor channels are highly permeable to Ca2+.

text 1: American infants exposed to live Mandarin speakers did not discriminate the Mandarin phonemes.
text 2: American infants exposed to live Mandarin speakers discriminated the Mandarin phonemes.

text 2: Infants exposed through TV or tapes showed no learning of Mandarin phonemes.

text 2: The performance of American infants exposed to live Mandarin speakers was equivalent to that of monolingual American infants the same age.

text 1: Infants learn language implicitly through detailed analysis of the patterns of statistical variation in natural speech.
text 2: Infants learn language explicitly through instructive feedback and repetition.

text 1: Adults learn language more naturally and efficiently than children.

text 1: Prosodic cues can convey both linguistic and paralinguistic information.
text 2: Prosodic cues only convey linguistic information.

text 2: Infants show a preference for the language spoken by their mothers during pregnancy.

text 1: Transitional probabilities do not help infants distinguish words in continuous speech.
text 2: Transitional probabilities help infants distinguish words in continuous speech.

text 1: Transitional probabilities between syllables within a word are low because the sequence is unpredictable.

text 1: Neural commitment to native language can interfere with learning a second language.
text 2: Neural commitment to native language enhances the learning of a second language.

text 1: The neurotransmitter dopamine plays a role in opening the critical period for language learning.
text 2: The neurotransmitter GABA plays a role in opening the critical period for language learning.

text 1: 'Parentese' is a formal speaking style used in professional settings.

text 1: Infants learn language through sophisticated analysis of information provided through social interaction.
text 2: Infants learn language purely through self-exploration without any social interaction.

text 1: Infants recognize word-like units using high transitional probabilities between syllables.
text 2: Infants recognize word-like units without considering transitional probabilities between syllables.

text 1: Edgar Adrian, Wade Marshall, and Philip Bard discovered that touching different parts of a cat’s body elicits electrical activity in distinct regions of the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Edgar Adrian, Wade Marshall, and Philip Bard discovered that touching different parts of a cat’s body elicits electrical activity in indistinct regions of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has revealed that thinking about a word's meaning activates a different area in the left frontal cortex.

text 1: Functional specialization is not a key organizing principle in the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Functional specialization is a key organizing principle in the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Studies of patients with brain damage provide little insight into how the brain is organized for language.

text 1: Sign language processing, as with spoken language processing, localizes to the left hemisphere.
text 2: Sign language processing localizes to the right hemisphere, unlike spoken language processing.

text 1: Broca’s area, once thought to be dedicated to language production, is exclusively involved in speech production.
text 2: Broca’s area, once thought to be dedicated to language production, is involved in a variety of linguistic tasks including comprehension.

text 2: Production and comprehension of signed and spoken languages do not involve identical brain areas, but the overlap is remarkable.

text 1: The ventral visual stream, or what pathway, is solely concerned with spatial properties without associating with socializing.

text 1: Phrenologists introduced the idea of localization in an exaggerated form and without adequate evidence.
text 2: Phrenologists introduced the idea of localization in a moderate form with overwhelming evidence.

text 1: Functional magnetic resonance imaging tends to elucidate areas that are recruited differentially.
text 2: Functional magnetic resonance imaging tends to elucidate areas that are universally recruited for all functions.

text 1: Many interconnected cortical and subcortical areas are concerned with processing particular aspects of sensory stimuli.
text 2: Only a few interconnected cortical and subcortical areas are concerned with processing all aspects of sensory stimuli.

text 1: Signed languages use hand movements and are perceived by sight rather than sound, but have the same structural complexity as spoken languages.
text 2: Signed languages use hand movements and are perceived by sound rather than sight, having a simpler structural complexity than spoken languages.

text 1: Investigations have shown that the brain functions as a singular cognitive system without distinct areas.
text 2: Investigations have provided additional support for the idea that the brain has distinct cognitive systems.

text 2: Damage to the left hemisphere can affect sign comprehension and fluency in signed languages.

text 1: The concept 'apple' exists in the brain as a single unified representation.

text 1: Horizontal rotation of the eye away from the nose is called abduction, and rotation toward the nose is adduction.
text 2: Horizontal rotation of the eye toward the nose is called abduction, and rotation away from the nose is adduction.

text 1: The primary objective of the oculomotor system is to control the position of the fovea, the central point in the retina with the highest density of photoreceptors.

text 1: Most eye movements are conjugate; that is, both eyes move in the same direction.
text 2: Most eye movements are disjunctive; that is, both eyes move in opposite directions.

text 1: Eye movements are described as rotations around horizontal, vertical, and torsional axes.
text 2: Eye movements are described as rotations around diagonal, radial, and orbital axes.

text 1: The inferior colliculus integrates visual and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.
text 2: The superior colliculus integrates visual and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.

text 1: The fovea is less than 1 mm in diameter and covers less than 1% of the visual field.
text 2: The fovea is more than 1 cm in diameter and covers more than 10% of the visual field.

text 1: Saccades are controlled by the cerebral cortex through the superior colliculus.
text 2: Saccades are controlled by the spinal cord through the superior colliculus.

text 1: Horizontal saccades are generated in the cerebellum.
text 2: Horizontal saccades are generated in the pontine reticular formation.

text 1: The eye is moved by eight extraocular muscles forming four agonist–antagonist pairs.
text 2: The eye is moved by six extraocular muscles forming three agonist–antagonist pairs.

text 1: The smooth-pursuit system keeps stationary targets on the fovea.
text 2: The smooth-pursuit system keeps moving targets on the fovea.

text 1: Vertical movements are referred to as elevation (upward rotation) and depression (downward rotation).
text 2: Vertical movements are referred to as abduction (upward rotation) and adduction (downward rotation).

text 1: All rapid gaze shifts require independent head and eye movements.
text 2: Some rapid gaze shifts require coordinated head and eye movements.

text 1: The vergence system aligns the eyes to look at targets at different depths.
text 2: The vergence system aligns the eyes to look at targets at the same depth.

text 1: Torsional movements include extorsion (rotation of the top of the cornea toward the nose) and intorsion (rotation away from the nose).
text 2: Torsional movements include intorsion (rotation of the top of the cornea toward the nose) and extorsion (rotation away from the nose).

text 1: In humans and other primates, the oculomotor system requires the coordination of twelve extraocular muscles.
text 2: In humans and other primates, the oculomotor system requires the coordination of six extraocular muscles.

text 1: ∆FosB accumulates in neurons of the nucleus accumbens after repeated exposure to virtually any drug of abuse.
text 2: ∆FosB is immediately and transiently induced in neurons of the nucleus accumbens after a single exposure to a drug of abuse.

text 1: Repeated drug exposure induces upregulation of the transcription factor CREB in neurons through the cAMP pathway.
text 2: Repeated drug exposure reduces transcription factor CREB activity in neurons due to suppression of the cAMP pathway.

text 1: Alcohol, nicotine, and marijuana consistently show larger experimental changes in brain reward regions compared to psychostimulants and opiates.
text 2: Psychostimulants and opiates show larger experimental changes in brain reward regions compared to other drugs of abuse.

text 1: Tolerance refers to the diminishing effect of a drug after repeated administration at the same dose.
text 2: Tolerance refers to escalating effects experienced after repeated administration of the same drug dose.

text 1: Dependence occurs only during continuous drug administration without withdrawal.
text 2: Dependence is unmasked during withdrawal, which occurs when drug taking stops.

text 1: Reward tolerance can trigger relapse during longer withdrawal periods.
text 2: Reward sensitization can trigger relapse after longer withdrawal periods.

text 1: Psychostimulant-induced changes in the ventral tegmental area cause no behavioral link to addiction.
text 2: Psychostimulant-induced changes in the ventral tegmental area are linked causally to addiction behaviors.

text 1: The μ opioid receptor is the most important for reward and addiction among opiates.
text 2: The δ opioid receptor is the most important for reward and addiction among opiates.

text 1: Amphetamines inhibit the dopamine transporter without stimulating dopamine release.
text 2: Amphetamines act as substrates for the dopamine transporter, stimulating dopamine release in nerve terminals.

text 1: Nicotine acts as an antagonist for nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
text 2: Nicotine acts as an agonist for nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

text 1: Methamphetamine is classified as a cannabinoid that affects CB1 receptors.
text 2: Methamphetamine is classified as a psychomotor stimulant that affects the dopamine transporter.

text 1: Early life stress is a significant environmental risk factor for addiction.
text 2: Early life stress has no correlation to addiction risk factors.

text 1: Sensitivity (reverse tolerance) results in escalating effects of a drug upon repeated doses.
text 2: Sensitivity results in diminished effects of a drug upon repeated doses.

text 1: Caffeine does not generally result in compulsive use or addiction.
text 2: Caffeine results in compulsive use and addiction similar to hallucinogens.

text 1: Alcohol addiction is associated with widespread public health consequences.
text 2: Alcohol addiction is associated with negligible public health consequences.

text 1: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability to passively stabilize the upper body by avoiding external forces acting on the body.
text 2: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability to actively stabilize the upper body by resisting external forces acting on the body.

text 1: Maintaining balance while standing requires aligning the center of pressure with the center of mass at all times.
text 2: Maintaining balance while standing requires keeping the downward projection of the center of mass within the base of support.

text 1: Somatosensory, vestibular, and visual information function independently to provide a coherent sense of the body’s position and velocity in space.
text 2: Somatosensory, vestibular, and visual information are integrated to provide a coherent sense of the body’s position and velocity in space.

text 1: The base of support is an imaginary area defined by parts of the body in contact with the environment.
text 2: The base of support is an area solely defined by visual cues from the environment.

text 1: Dynamic equilibrium during walking can be maintained even when the center of mass briefly moves outside the base of support.
text 2: Dynamic equilibrium during walking can only be maintained when the center of mass remains within the base of support.

text 1: The center of mass is located about 2 cm behind the second lumbar vertebra in standing adults.
text 2: The center of mass is located about 2 cm in front of the second lumbar vertebra in standing adults.

text 1: Automatic postural responses compensate for sudden disturbances to balance.
text 2: Automatic postural responses fail to compensate for sudden disturbances to balance.

text 1: The center of pressure is defined as the point of maximum downward force on the ground caused by body weight.
text 2: The center of pressure is defined as the origin of the ground reaction force vector on the support surface.

text 1: Postural control relies exclusively on visual information to maintain balance in dynamic situations.
text 2: Postural control integrates somatosensory, vestibular, and visual information to maintain balance in dynamic situations.

text 1: Misalignment of the center of mass and center of pressure causes motion of the center of mass.
text 2: Misalignment of the center of mass and center of pressure results in static equilibrium.

text 1: Antigravity support may be excessive when spasticity occurs after a stroke.
text 2: Antigravity support is always insufficient when spasticity occurs after a stroke.

text 1: The control of posture involves equilibrium and orientation, which are crucial for most daily tasks.
text 2: The control of posture involves equilibrium alone, which is crucial for most daily tasks.

text 1: The body’s center of mass remains fixed with respect to the base of support during stable stance.
text 2: The body’s center of mass continually moves with respect to the base of support, even during stable stance.

text 1: Dynamic postural strategies can only involve movement of the feet to maintain equilibrium.
text 2: Dynamic postural strategies involve moving body segments like hips and arms to maintain equilibrium.

text 1: Body segments can only be aligned with visual references regardless of the task.
text 2: Body segments may be aligned with gravitational, visual, or support surface references depending on the task.

text 1: The classification of epilepsies has primarily evolved based on clinical observation.
text 2: The classification of epilepsies has primarily evolved based on precise cellular, molecular, and genetic understanding.

text 1: The surface EEG primarily reflects the activity of deep brain structures, such as the hippocampus and thalamus.
text 2: The surface EEG primarily reflects the activity of cortical neurons in close proximity to EEG electrodes on the scalp.

text 1: Alpha waves are most prominent over frontal areas during intense mental activity.
text 2: Alpha waves are most prominent over parietal and occipital sites during relaxed wakefulness.

text 1: Beta waves of lower amplitude are more prominent in frontal areas during intense mental activity.
text 2: Beta waves of lower amplitude are more prominent over occipital sites during relaxed wakefulness.

text 1: Theta and delta waves during wakefulness suggest brain dysfunction.
text 2: Theta and delta waves during wakefulness suggest normal brain function.

text 1: The EEG signal primarily reflects slower voltage changes across the cell membrane, such as synaptic potentials.
text 2: The EEG signal primarily reflects high-frequency action potentials in single cells.

text 1: Extracellular electrodes can detect the synchronized activity of ensembles of cells called field potentials.
text 2: Intracellular electrodes can detect the synchronized activity of ensembles of cells called field potentials.

text 1: The EEG does not show patterns that correlate with various stages of sleep and wakefulness.
text 2: The EEG shows patterns that correlate with various stages of sleep and wakefulness.

text 1: The EEG represents a set of field potentials as recorded by multiple electrodes on the surface of the scalp.
text 2: The EEG represents individual action potentials as recorded by electrodes inserted deep into the brain.

text 1: High-frequency activity in single cells is the primary focus of the EEG signal.
text 2: High-frequency activity in single cells is filtered out by the EEG signal.

text 1: The amplitude of EEG signals is much larger than the voltage changes in a single neuron.
text 2: The amplitude of EEG signals is much smaller than the voltage changes in a single neuron.

text 1: The EEG signal is distorted by the filtering and attenuation caused by intervening layers of tissue and bone.
text 2: The EEG signal is not affected by intervening layers of tissue and bone.

text 1: The normal human EEG shows activity over the range of 1 to 30 Hz.
text 2: The normal human EEG shows activity over the range of 40 to 100 Hz.

text 1: Alerting relaxed subjects by asking them to open their eyes results in an increase in alpha activity.
text 2: Alerting relaxed subjects by asking them to open their eyes results in a reduction in alpha activity.

text 1: Pyramidal neurons are the major projection neurons in the cortex and are a principal source of EEG activity.
text 2: Glial cells are the major projection neurons in the cortex and are a principal source of EEG activity.

text 1: The X-ray crystal structure of the bacterial potassium channel reveals that each of the four KcsA K+ channel subunits contributes three membrane-spanning helices, an outer helix (blue) and an inner helix (red).
text 2: The X-ray crystal structure of the bacterial potassium channel reveals that each of the four KcsA K+ channel subunits contributes two membrane-spanning helices, an outer helix (blue) and an inner helix (red).

text 1: The form of the KcsA selectivity filter appears to have significant variations among various types of mammalian voltage-gated K+ channels.
text 2: The form of the KcsA selectivity filter appears to be highly conserved among various types of mammalian voltage-gated K+ channels.

text 1: X-ray analysis shows that the bacterial potassium channel can be occupied by at most five K+ ions at any instant.
text 2: X-ray analysis shows that the bacterial potassium channel can be occupied by at most three K+ ions at any instant.

text 1: The Kv1.2 channel has a pore domain formed by the S1-S4 segments at the central axis of the channel.
text 2: The Kv1.2 channel has a pore domain formed by the S5-P–S6 segments at the central axis of the channel.

text 1: The S1 helix of the Kv1.2–2.1 chimera is bent at a flexible three-amino-acid hinge, resulting in an open channel conformation.
text 2: The S6 helix of the Kv1.2–2.1 chimera is bent at a flexible three-amino-acid hinge, resulting in an open channel conformation.

text 1: In the closed bacterial K+ channels, the four inner transmembrane helices correspond to the S6 helices in voltage-gated K+ channels.
