text 1: TEA can block the channel even when the internal gate is closed by depolarization.
text 2: TEA can block the channel only when the internal gate is opened by depolarization.

text 1: A single K+ ion within the selectivity filter remains stationary during conduction.
text 2: A pair of K+ ions within the selectivity filter hop in tandem between pairs of binding sites during conduction.

text 1: A water molecule is always interposed between K+ ions within the selectivity filter due to electrostatic repulsion.
text 2: Adjacent K+ ions always occupy binding sites within the selectivity filter without any interposing molecules due to mutual attraction.

text 1: Positive charges on S4 residues within the lipid bilayer are stabilized by interactions with negatively charged acidic residues on S1–S3 helices.
text 2: Positive charges on S4 residues within the lipid bilayer are destabilized by interactions with negatively charged acidic residues on S1–S3 helices.

text 1: The loose fit between the K+ channel selectivity filter and K+ ions contributes to the high selectivity of these channels.
text 2: The snug fit between the K+ channel selectivity filter and K+ ions explains the high selectivity of these channels.

text 1: Once inside the channel lumen, TEA blocks K+ permeation because it is too large to pass through the selectivity filter.
text 2: Once inside the channel lumen, TEA allows K+ permeation because it easily passes through the selectivity filter.

text 1: Some bacterial proteins have S1–S4 domains and lack a pore domain, one of which forms a voltage-gated calcium channel.
text 2: Some bacterial proteins have S1–S4 domains and lack a pore domain, one of which forms a voltage-gated proton channel.

text 1: A negative voltage inside the cell causes the S4 helix to move outward, contributing to channel gating.
text 2: A negative voltage inside the cell causes the S4 helix to move inward, contributing to channel gating.

text 1: The S4–S5 coupling helix lies roughly parallel to the membrane at its cytoplasmic surface.
text 2: The S4–S5 coupling helix lies perpendicular to the membrane at its cytoplasmic surface.

text 1: The terminals of retinal ganglion cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus remain intermixed during normal development.
text 2: The terminals of retinal ganglion cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus become segregated during normal development.

text 1: In most species, axons from one eye remain functionally undifferentiated.
text 2: In some species, axons from one eye segregate into functionally specialized sublayers.

text 1: The refinement involves both growth of terminal arbors in the appropriate layer and elimination of terminals from the inappropriate layer.
text 2: The refinement process lacks the elimination of terminals from inappropriate layers.

text 1: Application of tetrodotoxin to the optic nerves enhances the segregation of the inputs from each eye.
text 2: Application of tetrodotoxin to the optic nerves disrupts the segregation of the inputs from each eye.

text 1: Segregation of inputs is complete before the onset of visual experience in monkeys.
text 2: Segregation of inputs begins after the onset of visual experience in monkeys.

text 1: Retinal ganglion neurons are spontaneously active in utero, well before the eyes open.
text 2: Retinal ganglion neurons are active only after the eyes open.

text 1: The pattern of ganglion cell activity is independent of inputs from amacrine cells.
text 2: The pattern of ganglion cell activity is coordinated by excitatory inputs from amacrine cells.

text 1: Spontaneous activity hinders circuit refinement.
text 2: Spontaneous activity can lead to circuit refinement.

text 1: Activity-dependent control of refinement is a general property of neural circuits in the mammalian brain.
text 2: Activity-dependent control of refinement is limited to specific neural circuits in the visual system.

text 1: The refining process is only guided by sensory input.
text 2: The refining process involves both spontaneous activity and sensory input.

text 1: The retinotectal map becomes precise when retinal activity is inhibited.
text 2: The retinotectal map becomes coarse when retinal activity is inhibited.

text 1: Activity merely acts as a precondition for refinement without an organizing role.
text 2: Activity has an organizing role in determining which axons win or lose the competition.

text 1: Stroboscopic illumination results in a coarse retinotectal map.
text 2: Stroboscopic illumination results in a precise retinotectal map.

text 1: Refinement in sensory modalities occurs during critical periods.
text 2: Refinement in sensory modalities can occur randomly at any time.

text 1: Owls use interaural time differences to calculate the precise position of prey.
text 2: Owls rely solely on visual cues and ignore interaural time differences to locate prey.

text 1: The induction of LTP at the CA3-CA1 synapse is largely presynaptic.
text 2: The induction of LTP at the CA3-CA1 synapse is largely postsynaptic.

text 1: The NMDA receptor-channels have a low permeability to Ca2+.
text 2: The NMDA receptor-channels have a high permeability to Ca2+.

text 1: Early LTP is typically induced by a single train of 100-Hz tetanic stimulation for 1 second.
text 2: Early LTP is typically induced by multiple trains of 100-Hz tetanic stimulation for 1 second.

text 1: Silent synapses become unsilenced by the addition of AMPA receptors.
text 2: Silent synapses become unsilenced by the addition of NMDA receptors.

text 1: Late LTP requires the synthesis of new proteins.
text 2: Late LTP does not require the synthesis of new proteins.

text 1: Protein kinase A (PKA) is activated by cGMP during late LTP.
text 2: Protein kinase A (PKA) is activated by cAMP during late LTP.

text 1: CREB-1 is phosphorylated during the late phase of LTP.
text 2: CREB-1 is dephosphorylated during the late phase of LTP.

text 1: Postsynaptic terminals are enhanced by retrograde messengers during LTP.
text 2: Presynaptic terminals are enhanced by retrograde messengers during LTP.

text 1: Silent synapses lack functional AMPA receptors.
text 2: Silent synapses lack functional NMDA receptors.

text 1: Phosphorylation of the AMPA receptor tail leads to their insertion in the postsynaptic membrane.
text 2: Dephosphorylation of the AMPA receptor tail leads to their insertion in the postsynaptic membrane.

text 1: The expression of LTP at CA1 synapses can only depend on postsynaptic events.
text 2: The expression of LTP at CA1 synapses can depend on presynaptic events that enhance transmitter release.

text 1: MAP kinase remains in the cytoplasm during late LTP.
text 2: MAP kinase translocates to the nucleus during late LTP.

text 1: In some cases, LTP expression depends on an increase in the response of the postsynaptic membrane to glutamate.
text 2: In some cases, LTP expression depends on a decrease in the response of the postsynaptic membrane to glutamate.

text 1: LTP recruits AMPA receptors from a reserve pool stored in endosomal vesicles.
text 2: LTP recruits NMDA receptors from a reserve pool stored in endosomal vesicles.

text 1: Silent synapses are characterized by a strong Na+ block of NMDA receptor-channels.
text 2: Silent synapses are characterized by a strong Mg2+ block of NMDA receptor-channels.

text 1: Mutant mice that overexpress the NR2B subunit of the NMDA receptor show impaired learning and memory for several different tasks.
text 2: Mutant mice that overexpress the NR2B subunit of the NMDA receptor show enhanced learning and memory for several different tasks.

text 1: Tetanic stimulation at 10 Hz in transgenic mice induces long-term potentiation of synaptic transmission in the Schaffer collateral pathway.
text 2: Tetanic stimulation at 10 Hz in transgenic mice induces long-term depression of synaptic transmission in the Schaffer collateral pathway.

text 1: Mice lacking the NMDA receptor in the CA1 region of the hippocampus exhibit enhanced spatial memory.
text 2: Mice lacking the NMDA receptor in the CA1 region of the hippocampus exhibit impaired spatial memory.

text 1: NMDA receptors are necessary only for spatial hippocampal-dependent explicit memories.
text 2: NMDA receptors are necessary for both spatial and nonspatial hippocampal-dependent explicit memories.

text 1: Long-term depression (LTD) was first discovered in the hippocampus, where it is important for motor learning.
text 2: Long-term depression (LTD) was first discovered in the cerebellum, where it is important for motor learning.

text 1: Activation of NMDA receptors can produce both potentiation and depression of synaptic strength.
text 2: Activation of NMDA receptors can only produce potentiation of synaptic strength.

text 1: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is selectively deleted in CA1 pyramidal neurons of certain mutant mice.
text 2: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is selectively overexpressed in CA1 pyramidal neurons of certain mutant mice.

text 1: In mutant mice, LTP at the CA1 Schaffer collateral synapses is enhanced.
text 2: In mutant mice, LTP at the CA1 Schaffer collateral synapses is abolished.

text 1: Mutant mice lacking the NMDA receptor spend more time in the target quadrant during a water maze probe trial.
text 2: Mutant mice lacking the NMDA receptor show equal time spent in all quadrants during a water maze probe trial.

text 1: Long-term potentiation requires activation of NMDA receptors.
text 2: Long-term potentiation does not require activation of NMDA receptors.

text 1: Transgenic expression of the CaMKII-Asp286 mutation results in a systematic shift in synaptic strength during long-term plasticity.
text 2: Transgenic expression of the CaMKII-Asp286 mutation has no effect on synaptic strength during long-term plasticity.

text 1: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP is likely required for many forms of explicit memory in the hippocampus.
text 2: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP is not required for any form of explicit memory in the hippocampus.

text 1: Reversible gene expression has been used to explore the role of CaMKII.
text 2: Reversible gene expression has been used to explore the role of dopamine receptors.

text 1: Field EPSPs were recorded in response to Schaffer collateral stimulation in studies involving NMDA receptor knockouts.
text 2: Field EPSPs were not recorded in response to Schaffer collateral stimulation in studies involving NMDA receptor knockouts.

text 1: The synaptic connections involved in hippocampal memories are never vulnerable to disruption by indiscriminate LTP.
text 2: The synaptic connections involved in hippocampal memories are vulnerable to disruption by indiscriminate LTP.

text 1: In Aplysia, the withdrawal reflex circuit involves approximately 50 mechanoreceptor neurons in the abdominal ganglion that innervate the siphon skin.
text 2: In Aplysia, the withdrawal reflex circuit involves approximately 24 mechanoreceptor neurons in the abdominal ganglion that innervate the siphon skin.

text 1: Sensitization in Aplysia can result from an enhancement in synaptic transmission at several connections in the neural circuit, including connections made by sensory neurons with motor neurons.
text 2: Sensitization in Aplysia can result from a reduction in synaptic transmission at several connections in the neural circuit, including connections made by sensory neurons with motor neurons.

text 1: Repeated tail shocks to Aplysia produce sensitization lasting for days to weeks.
text 2: Repeated tail shocks to Aplysia produce habituation lasting for days to weeks.

text 1: Long-term sensitization is associated with an increase in the number of synapses between sensory and motor neurons.
text 2: Long-term sensitization is associated with a reduction in the number of synapses between sensory and motor neurons.

text 1: In synapses specifically involved in learning, a relatively small amount of training can produce large and enduring changes in synaptic strength.
text 2: In synapses specifically involved in learning, a relatively large amount of training is required to produce only small and temporary changes in synaptic strength.

text 1: In classical conditioning of Aplysia's gill-withdrawal reflex, a weak shock to the tail is the conditioned stimulus while a strong touch to the siphon is the unconditioned stimulus.
text 2: In classical conditioning of Aplysia's gill-withdrawal reflex, a weak touch to the siphon is the conditioned stimulus while a strong shock to the tail is the unconditioned stimulus.

text 1: Habituation involves an increase in transmitter release at many synaptic sites throughout the reflex circuit.
text 2: Habituation involves a decrease in transmitter release at many synaptic sites throughout the reflex circuit.

text 1: Serotonergic interneurons are involved in habituation and they use dopamine as a transmitter.
text 2: Serotonergic interneurons are involved in sensitization and they use serotonin as a transmitter.

text 1: Classical conditioning in Aplysia can result in a more pronounced enhancement of reflexes compared to sensitization alone.
text 2: Classical conditioning in Aplysia typically results in a less pronounced enhancement of reflexes compared to sensitization alone.

text 1: In sensitization, presynaptic facilitation in response to release of serotonin by a tail shock lasts for a period of many minutes.
text 2: In sensitization, presynaptic facilitation in response to release of serotonin by a tail shock lasts only for a few seconds.

text 1: In the withdrawal reflex circuit of Aplysia, serotonergic interneurons form synapses on the postsynaptic terminals of motor neurons.
text 2: In the withdrawal reflex circuit of Aplysia, serotonergic interneurons form synapses on presynaptic terminals of sensory neurons.

text 1: A single shock to the tail of Aplysia produces short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex.
text 2: A single shock to the siphon of Aplysia produces short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex.

text 1: A stimulus that leads to an increase in gill withdrawal over time is considered to be habituating for Aplysia.
text 2: A stimulus that leads to a decrease in gill withdrawal over time is considered to be habituating for Aplysia.

text 1: The tone used in laboratory threat conditioning typically becomes associated with eliciting feeding behaviors.
text 2: The tone used in laboratory threat conditioning typically becomes associated with eliciting defensive behaviors.

text 1: In Aplysia, classical conditioning of the gill-withdrawal reflex involves activity-dependent depression.
text 2: In Aplysia, classical conditioning of the gill-withdrawal reflex involves activity-dependent facilitation.

text 1: Adolescent monkeys can experience remapping of digit representations in the somatosensory cortex.
text 2: Adult monkeys can experience remapping of digit representations in the somatosensory cortex.

text 1: Following the amputation of a digit, the associated cortical region becomes hyper-responsive.
text 2: Following the amputation of a digit, the associated cortical region becomes initially unresponsive.

text 1: In birds and insects, plasticity can persist beyond the classical critical period.
text 2: In cats and mice, plasticity can persist beyond the classical critical period.

text 1: Monocular deprivation at 2 months of age in mice has no detectable effect.
text 2: Monocular deprivation at 4 months of age in mice has no detectable effect.

text 1: Ocular dominance plasticity can be enhanced by sleep deprivation and fasting.
text 2: Ocular dominance plasticity can be enhanced by environmental enrichment and exercise.

text 1: Adult interneuron transplantation can reopen critical periods in young mice.
text 2: Immature inhibitory interneuron transplantation can reopen critical periods in older mice.

text 1: Critical periods are identical in duration across all brain areas and tasks.
text 2: Critical periods vary in time among different brain areas and tasks.

text 1: Plasticity of binocular interactions is more pronounced in adults than in early postnatal life.
text 2: Plasticity of binocular interactions is modest in adults compared to early postnatal life.

text 1: Critical periods demonstrate that the brain's capacity to remodel decreases in adulthood.
text 2: Critical periods demonstrate that the brain's capacity to remodel increases in adulthood.

text 1: Monocular deprivation during critical periods enhances responsiveness to input from the closed eye.
text 2: Monocular deprivation during critical periods can lead to loss of responsiveness to input from the closed eye.

text 1: Hunting decreases the plasticity of binaural tuning in adult owls.
text 2: Hunting increases the plasticity of binaural tuning in adult owls.

text 1: Binocular interaction alterations are driven by visual experience postnatally.
text 2: Binocular interaction alterations are unaffected by visual experience postnatally.

text 1: During early postnatal life, conditions impede plasticity due to lack of axonal growth.
text 2: During early postnatal life, conditions are optimal for plasticity due to axonal growth.

text 1: The end of the critical period is marked by the formation of myelin.
text 2: The beginning of the critical period is marked by the formation of myelin.

text 1: In mature circuits, molecular elements often promote stability over plasticity.
text 2: In mature circuits, molecular elements often promote plasticity over stability.

text 1: Postural responses can be learned and retained with practice.
text 2: Postural responses can be learned but tend to be forgotten immediately after practice.

text 1: Patients with neurological disorders, such as multiple sclerosis or Parkinson disease, can often learn to improve their postural control with practice.
text 2: Patients with neurological disorders, such as multiple sclerosis or Parkinson disease, cannot learn to improve their postural control with practice.

text 1: Anticipatory postural adjustments follow voluntary movement.
text 2: Anticipatory postural adjustments precede voluntary movement.

text 1: During voluntary arm pulls, arm muscles are activated before the leg muscles to prevent the body from rotating forward.
text 2: During voluntary arms pull, leg muscles are activated before the arm muscles to prevent the body from rotating forward.

text 1: The trajectory of a diver's center of mass is fixed once they leave the board.
text 2: The trajectory of a diver's center of mass can be altered after they leave the board.

text 1: During walking, the center of mass is always within the base of support regardless of foot position.
text 2: During walking, the center of mass is only within the base of support when both feet are on the ground.

text 1: Foot placement is planned solely based on proprioceptive feedback, without the need for visual information.
text 2: Visual information about the terrain and surrounding environment assists in planning foot placement several steps in advance.

text 1: Patients with abnormal postural stability during gait may still have normal automatic postural adjustments.
text 2: Patients with abnormal postural stability during gait cannot exhibit normal automatic postural adjustments.

text 1: Only one sensory modality is needed in postural centers to determine appropriate body orientation and motion.
text 2: Multiple modalities must be integrated in postural centers to determine appropriate body orientation and motion.

text 1: Group I fibers provide rapid information about biomechanical responses.
text 2: Group I fibers provide slow information about biomechanical responses.

text 1: Joint receptors can detect compressive forces on the joints.
text 2: Joint receptors detect changes in temperature rather than compressive forces.

text 1: Proprioceptive signals remain constant during upright stance regardless of muscle length changes.
text 2: Proprioceptive signals are generated during upright stance due to muscle length changes as the body sways.

text 1: Large-diameter, fast somatosensory fibers are critical for maintaining balance during stance.
text 2: Large-diameter, fast somatosensory fibers are irrelevant for maintaining balance during stance.

text 1: Anticipatory postural adjustments are specific to biomechanical conditions.
text 2: Anticipatory postural adjustments are generic and apply equally to all situations.

text 1: Moving the center of mass forward over the toes destabilizes the toe stance.
text 2: Moving the center of mass forward over the toes before activating the calf muscles stabilizes the toe stance.

text 1: The task of the motor systems is the reverse of the task of the sensory systems.
text 2: The task of the motor systems is the same as the task of the sensory systems.

text 1: Walking is solely controlled by descending commands without the involvement of central pattern generators or sensory information.
text 2: Walking involves the combined action of central pattern generators, gated sensory information, and descending commands.

text 1: Many actions, such as serving a tennis ball, occur too quickly to be shaped by sensory feedback.
text 2: All actions, including serving a tennis ball, rely solely on sensory feedback.

text 1: Motor systems are organized in a functional hierarchy with different decision-making levels.
text 2: Motor systems are organized in a simple, non-hierarchical manner without distinct decision-making levels.

text 1: The premotor cortex is responsible for emotional regulation, not movement characteristics.
text 2: The premotor cortex specifies the spatiotemporal characteristics of a movement.

text 1: Disruptions in motor hierarchies can produce distinctive symptoms like the movement-slowing seen in Parkinson disease.
text 2: Disruptions in motor hierarchies have no effect on movement, and Parkinson disease does not slow movements.

text 1: Focal stimulation of the basal ganglia has been shown to worsen motility in all Parkinson's disease patients.
text 2: Focal stimulation of the basal ganglia has been shown to restore motility in some Parkinson's disease patients.

text 1: Neural signals cannot be decoded or used to assist patients with paralysis.
text 2: Neural signals are decoded and used to drive devices for patients with paralysis.

text 1: Psychophysical analyses have no relevance in understanding the control rules of the motor system.
text 2: Psychophysical analyses reveal the control rules used by the motor system.

text 1: Simply standing upright requires no adjustment of postural muscles.
text 2: Simply standing upright requires continual adjustments of postural muscles.

text 1: The discovery that neurons in the basal ganglia of parkinsonian patients are deficient in dopamine was significant.
text 2: The discovery that neurons in the basal ganglia of parkinsonian patients are deficient in dopamine was insignificant.

text 1: Motor learning provides little insight into neural plasticity.
text 2: Motor learning is a rich subject for studies of neural plasticity.

text 1: Neurophysiological studies have no role in understanding neurotransmitter functions in movement.
text 2: Neurophysiological studies contribute to the understanding of neurotransmitter roles in movement.

text 1: Predictive models in the cerebellum allow for short latency corrections during movement.
text 2: The cerebellum is not involved in any form of predictive modeling during movement.

text 1: Motor processing begins with an internal representation of the desired purpose of movement.
text 2: Motor processing begins with an external stimulus, not with any internal representation.

text 1: Neuroanatomists locate axons and terminals of specific nerve cell bodies by microinjection of dyes.
text 2: Neuroanatomists locate axons and terminals of specific nerve cell bodies by injecting water.

text 1: The enzyme horseradish peroxidase is used for anterograde transport studies.
text 2: The enzyme horseradish peroxidase is used for retrograde transport studies.

text 1: Axonal transport is used to dissolve neuronal networks.
text 2: Axonal transport is used to identify neuronal networks.

text 1: The polio virus can be used to trace cortical pathways in monkeys.
text 2: The herpes simplex virus can be used to trace cortical pathways in monkeys.

text 1: Slow axonal transport carries neurotransmitter molecules across synapses.
text 2: Slow axonal transport carries cytosolic proteins and elements of the cytoskeleton.

text 1: Fast axonal transport is constant at 4 mm per day at body temperature.
text 2: Fast axonal transport is constant at 410 mm per day at body temperature.

text 1: Ribosomes in dendrites are concentrated at the axon terminal.
text 2: Ribosomes in dendrites are concentrated at the junction of the spine and main dendritic shaft.

text 1: Microtubules mediate anterograde and retrograde transport of mRNAs.
text 2: Microfilaments mediate anterograde and retrograde transport of mRNAs.

text 1: The mRNA for myelin basic protein is transported to the synaptic terminals.
text 2: The mRNA for myelin basic protein is transported to the ends of oligodendrocytes.

text 1: Proteins are synthesized in neurons similar to other secretory cells.
text 2: Proteins are not synthesized in neurons, unlike other secretory cells.

text 1: Cytosolic proteins are moved from the cell body by slow axonal transport.
text 2: Cytosolic proteins are moved from the cell body by fast axonal transport.

text 1: Microtubules are transported in monomeric form.
text 2: Microtubules are transported in polymerized form.

text 1: Proteins are synthesized on ribosomes dissolved in blood.
text 2: Proteins are synthesized on ribosomes attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.

text 1: Cotranslational transfer involves ribosomes attaching to the cytosolic surface of the reticulum.
text 2: Cotranslational transfer involves ribosomes attaching to the nuclear membrane.

text 1: Neurotransmitter receptors and ion channels are examples of secretory proteins.
text 2: Neurotransmitter receptors and ion channels are examples of membrane proteins.

text 1: Ia sensory fibers can evoke excitatory postsynaptic potentials in homonymous motor neurons in a monosynaptic reflex pathway.
text 2: Ia sensory fibers can evoke excitatory postsynaptic potentials in homonymous motor neurons in a disynaptic reflex pathway.

text 1: Gamma motor neurons adjust muscle spindle sensitivity by directly contracting extrafusal muscle fibers during movement.
text 2: Gamma motor neurons adjust muscle spindle sensitivity by contracting intrafusal muscle fibers to maintain spindle tension during movement.

text 1: Type Ia fibers have lower electrical activation thresholds than Type Ib fibers, on average.
text 2: Type Ia fibers have higher electrical activation thresholds than Type Ib fibers, on average.

text 1: Axons with larger diameters conduct action potentials more rapidly than those with smaller diameters.
text 2: Axons with smaller diameters conduct action potentials more rapidly than those with larger diameters.

text 1: The H-reflex is readily measurable in the soleus muscle and involves alpha motor neurons excited by stimulating the tibial nerve.
text 2: The H-reflex is readily measurable in the soleus muscle and involves Ia fibers excited by stimulating the tibial nerve.

text 1: Beta axons in mammals innervate only extrafusal muscle fibers, preventing alpha-gamma coactivation.
text 2: Beta axons in mammals innervate both intrafusal and extrafusal muscle fibers, allowing for alpha-gamma coactivation.

text 1: Alpha-gamma coactivation destabilizes muscle spindle sensitivity during voluntary movements.
text 2: Alpha-gamma coactivation stabilizes muscle spindle sensitivity during voluntary movements.

text 1: The latency for excitatory postsynaptic potentials in the monosynaptic Ia pathway is approximately 0.7 ms.
text 2: The latency for excitatory postsynaptic potentials in the monosynaptic Ia pathway is approximately 1.6 ms.

text 1: Type III and IV fibers have lower electrical activation thresholds compared to type I sensory fibers, ranging from 1 to 2 times higher.
text 2: Type III and IV fibers have higher electrical activation thresholds compared to type I sensory fibers, ranging from 10 to 50 times higher.

text 1: Disynaptic inhibitory pathways involving Ia inhibitory interneurons mediate the relaxation of antagonist muscles during a stretch reflex.
text 2: Monosynaptic inhibitory pathways involving Ia inhibitory interneurons mediate the relaxation of antagonist muscles during a stretch reflex.

text 1: Gamma motor neurons directly modulate extrafusal muscle contraction to regulate spindle sensitivity.
text 2: Gamma motor neurons modulate spindle sensitivity independently of extrafusal muscle contraction.

text 1: Unpredictable conditions decrease activity in dynamic gamma motor neurons, weakening spindle responsiveness during muscle stretch.
text 2: Unpredictable conditions increase activity in dynamic gamma motor neurons, enhancing spindle responsiveness during muscle stretch.

text 1: Electrically stimulating Ia sensory fibers helps precisely control the timing of afferent input during reflex studies.
text 2: Electrically stimulating Ia sensory fibers prevents precise control of the timing of afferent input during reflex studies.

text 1: Spindle sensitivity in mammals can be adjusted independently of muscle length by gamma motor neurons, unlike in lower vertebrates.
text 2: Spindle sensitivity in mammals cannot be adjusted independently of muscle length, similar to lower vertebrates.

text 1: The Hoffmann reflex becomes obscured at high stimulus strengths due to antidromic motor signals canceling reflexive activity.
text 2: The Hoffmann reflex becomes stronger at high stimulus strengths due to orthodromic motor signals enhancing reflexive activity.

text 1: Neurons in the primary auditory cortex (A1) are arranged tonotopically, with neurons tuned to high frequencies at the rostral end and those responsive to low frequencies at the caudal region.
text 2: Neurons in the primary auditory cortex (A1) are arranged tonotopically, with neurons tuned to low frequencies at the rostral end and those responsive to high frequencies at the caudal region.

text 1: Auditory cortex neurons in monkeys are exclusively tuned to frontal space, without sensitivity to rear space or spatial areas above and below the horizontal plane.
text 2: Auditory cortex neurons in monkeys are tuned to both frontal space and rear space, as well as space above and below the horizontal plane.

text 1: Electrophysiological and imaging studies have confirmed that A1 in humans lies on Heschl’s gyrus, in the temporal lobe, medial to the Sylvian fissure.
text 2: Electrophysiological and imaging studies have confirmed that A1 in humans lies on the frontal lobe, lateral to the Sylvian fissure.

text 1: Lesions of A1 can result in profound sound-localization deficits in complex tasks.
text 2: Lesions of A1 have no impact on sound-localization abilities, even in complex tasks.

text 1: Sustained firing by auditory cortex neurons has only been observed in awake animals.
text 2: Sustained firing by auditory cortex neurons has only been observed in anesthetized animals.

text 1: The auditory cortex includes multiple distinct functional areas on the ventral surface of the temporal lobe.
text 2: The auditory cortex includes multiple distinct functional areas on the dorsal surface of the temporal lobe.

text 1: In humans and monkeys, pure tones primarily activate peripheral areas of the auditory cortex.
text 2: In humans and monkeys, pure tones primarily activate core areas of the auditory cortex.

text 1: Within intracortical circuits of A1, neurons receive input primarily from neurons with dissimilar bandwidths and characteristic frequencies.
text 2: Within intracortical circuits of A1, neurons receive input primarily from neurons with similar bandwidths and characteristic frequencies.

text 1: Behavioral training in adult animals has no effect on the organization of the auditory cortex.
text 2: Behavioral training in adult animals can result in large-scale reorganization of the auditory cortex.

text 1: Neurons in the auditory cortex collectively cover the entire acoustic space with their sustained firing regions.
text 2: Neurons in the auditory cortex only cover a limited portion of the acoustic space with their sustained firing regions.

text 1: Auditory neurons in A1 can be excited either by input from both ears (EE neurons) or by a unilateral input (EI neurons).
text 2: Auditory neurons in A1 are excited exclusively by unilateral input and never by input from both ears.

text 1: The primary auditory cortex (A1) does not contain any map reflecting the sensory periphery and differs entirely from the visual cortex.
text 2: The primary auditory cortex (A1) contains a map reflecting the sensory periphery similar to the visual cortex.

text 1: Sustained firing in auditory nerve fibers is observed only under awake conditions.
text 2: Sustained firing in auditory nerve fibers can be observed under both anesthetized and awake conditions.

text 1: The auditory cortex's response remains uniform throughout, engaging the same neuronal population without restriction over time.
text 2: The auditory cortex's response changes over time, becoming restricted to a smaller population of neurons preferentially driven by the sound.

text 1: Neurons near the center of the isofrequency contours are tuned more broadly to bandwidth or frequency than those located away from the center.
text 2: Neurons near the center of the isofrequency contours are tuned more narrowly to bandwidth or frequency than those located away from the center.
