text 2: Velliste M, Perel S, Spalding MC, Whitford AS, Schwartz AB. 2008. Cortical control of a prosthetic leg for self-feeding. Nature 453:1098–1101.

text 1: Wessberg J, Stambaugh CR, Kralik JD, et al. 2000. Real-time prediction of hand trajectory by ensembles of cortical neurons in primates. Nature 408:361–365.
text 2: Wessberg J, Stambaugh CR, Kralik JD, et al. 2000. Real-time prediction of foot trajectory by ensembles of cortical neurons in primates. Nature 408:361–365.

text 1: Active touch is fundamentally a bottom-up process in which the subject passively reacts to external stimuli and does not control what occurs.
text 2: Active touch is fundamentally a top-down process in which the subject has agency, seeks particular information, and controls what occurs.

text 1: Type 1 touch fibers terminate in clusters of small receptor organs, such as Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells, in the superficial layers of the skin.
text 2: Type 1 touch fibers terminate in single large receptors, such as Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscles, in the deep layers of the skin.

text 1: Passive touch engages a top-down process in which subjects have agency and actively seek tactile information.
text 2: Passive touch engages a bottom-up process in which subjects react to external stimuli specified by the experimenter or clinician.

text 1: RA2 fibers are the most numerous tactile afferents in the hand, reaching a density of approximately 150 per cm2 at the fingertip.
text 2: RA1 fibers are the most numerous tactile afferents in the hand, reaching a density of approximately 150 per cm2 at the fingertip.

text 1: Meissner corpuscles are located in the dermal papillae and respond to lateral motion.
text 2: Meissner corpuscles are located in deep subcutaneous tissue and respond to vibration.

text 1: Type 2 fibers innervate the skin densely and terminate in clusters of small receptors like Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells.
text 2: Type 2 fibers innervate the skin sparsely and terminate in single large receptors like Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscles.

text 1: The sensory and motor components of touch are anatomically connected in the brain and guide motor behavior.
text 2: The sensory and motor components of touch are anatomically separate and do not influence motor behavior.

text 1: Pacinian corpuscles respond best to steady pressure stimuli and have a frequency range of 0–100 Hz.
text 2: Pacinian corpuscles respond best to rapid vibration stimuli and have a frequency range of 5–1,000 Hz.

text 1: Slowly adapting fibers respond to steady skin indentation with a sustained discharge.
text 2: Slowly adapting fibers respond only to motion and stop firing when the skin indentation becomes stationary.

text 1: Touch receptors in the superficial layers of the skin have smaller receptive fields than those in the deep layers.
text 2: Touch receptors in the superficial layers of the skin have larger receptive fields than those in the deep layers.

text 1: Type 1 fibers primarily innervate Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells in the hand.
text 2: Type 1 fibers primarily innervate Pacinian corpuscles and Ruffini endings in the hand.

text 1: Active touch conveys somatosensory information about the physical properties of objects and the motor actions of the subject’s hand and arm.
text 2: Active touch conveys somatosensory information solely about external tactile stimuli, with no involvement of motor actions.

text 1: Sensory deficits such as clumsiness or stiffness in hand use may result from sensory loss.
text 2: Motor deficits such as clumsiness or stiffness in hand use are unrelated to sensory loss.

text 1: The receptive fields of RA1 axons typically include integration of information from several adjacent fingerprint ridges.
text 2: The receptive fields of RA1 axons typically include integration of information from the deep subcutaneous tissue.

text 1: The density of SA2 fibers in human fingers is the least abundant, at approximately 9 fibers per cm2.
text 2: The density of SA2 fibers in human fingers is the most abundant, at approximately 150 fibers per cm2.

text 1: T-type Ca2+ channels open in response to strong depolarizations and are called high-voltage-activated Ca2+ channels.
text 2: T-type Ca2+ channels open in response to small depolarizations around the threshold for generating an action potential (-60 to -40 mV) and are called low-voltage-activated Ca2+ channels.

text 1: P/Q-type and N-type Ca2+ channels are predominantly found at the active zones of presynaptic terminals and mediate fast release of transmitters.
text 2: L-type and R-type Ca2+ channels are predominantly found at the active zones of presynaptic terminals and mediate fast release of transmitters.

text 1: Miniature end-plate potentials represent the response of the postsynaptic terminal during an action potential.
text 2: Miniature end-plate potentials represent the spontaneous release of small packets of ACh from the presynaptic terminal without an action potential.

text 1: Timothy syndrome is associated with mutations in the α1-subunit of L-type channels that affect dendritic integration.
text 2: Timothy syndrome is associated with mutations in the α1-subunit of T-type channels that affect dendritic integration.

text 1: The synchronous release of transmitter quanta during an action potential is primarily driven by Ca2+ influx into the presynaptic terminal.
text 2: The synchronous release of transmitter quanta during an action potential is primarily driven by K+ influx into the presynaptic terminal.

text 1: Approximately 150 quanta are released synchronously during an action potential, each generating a potential around 0.5 mV.
text 2: Approximately 300 quanta are released synchronously during an action potential, each generating a potential around 0.5 mV.

text 1: A miniature end-plate potential represents the summation of elementary currents through approximately 2,000 ACh receptor channels.
text 2: A miniature end-plate potential represents the summation of elementary currents through approximately 200 ACh receptor channels.

text 1: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels are comprised of three repeats of a domain with six membrane-spanning segments, including the S4 voltage-sensor and pore-lining P-region.
text 2: Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels are comprised of four repeats of a domain with six membrane-spanning segments, including the S4 voltage-sensor and pore-lining P-region.

text 1: The miniature end-plate potentials persist even if the presynaptic motor nerve degenerates.
text 2: The miniature end-plate potentials disappear if the presynaptic motor nerve degenerates and reappear when a new motor synapse is formed.

text 1: The active zones contain synaptic vesicles that release their contents gradually over time.
text 2: The active zones contain synaptic vesicles that release their contents in an all-or-none manner.

text 1: The L-type calcium channels are crucial for slower forms of release, such as neuropeptides and hormones.
text 2: The L-type calcium channels are crucial for fast synaptic transmission at active zones.

text 1: Lambert-Eaton syndrome involves antibodies targeting the L-type channel α1-subunit, reducing Ca2+ current.
text 2: Lambert-Eaton syndrome involves antibodies targeting the P/Q-type channel α1-subunit, reducing Ca2+ current.

text 1: Each quantum released during neurotransmission contains approximately 5,000 molecules of ACh.
text 2: Each quantum released during neurotransmission contains approximately 500 molecules of ACh.

text 1: At low calcium concentrations, the amplitude of end-plate potentials remains constant.
text 2: At low calcium concentrations, the amplitude of end-plate potentials varies randomly due to quantal release failures.

text 1: Synaptic vesicles at the active zone are typically clear, small, and oval, with a diameter of approximately 40 nm.
text 2: Synaptic vesicles at the active zone are typically dense, large, and round, with a diameter of approximately 100 nm.

text 1: A change in concentration of an odorant does not affect the perceived odor.
text 2: A change in concentration of an odorant can also change the perceived odor.

text 1: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses multiple odorant receptor genes.
text 2: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses only one odorant receptor gene.

text 1: Odorants are detected by only one receptor each.
text 2: Odorants are detected by a unique combination of receptors.

text 1: The olfactory bulb contains inhibitory interneurons.
text 2: The olfactory bulb does not contain inhibitory interneurons.

text 1: A single odorant receptor can recognize multiple odorants.
text 2: A single odorant receptor recognizes only one odorant.

text 1: Humans do not accommodate to odors that are continuously present.
text 2: Humans accommodate rapidly to odors that are continuously present.

text 1: Odorant receptors have six transmembrane domains characteristic of G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: Odorant receptors have seven transmembrane domains characteristic of G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: Neurons with the same receptor are confined to one zone in the olfactory epithelium.
text 2: Neurons with the same receptor are distributed across multiple zones in the olfactory epithelium.

text 1: Each glomerulus contains synaptic connections with mitral and tufted projection neurons.
text 2: Each glomerulus contains synaptic connections with only interneurons.

text 1: Olfactory sensory neurons terminate directly in the olfactory cortex.
text 2: Olfactory sensory neurons terminate on the dendrites of olfactory bulb neurons.

text 1: Odorant receptors are uniformly distributed across the olfactory epithelium.
text 2: Odorant receptors are distributed in spatial zones within the olfactory epithelium.

text 1: A change in the chemical structure of an odorant does not affect its perceived odor.
text 2: A change in the chemical structure of an odorant can alter its perceived odor.

text 1: Olfactory information remains unchanged as it travels to the brain.
text 2: Olfactory information is transformed as it travels to the brain.

text 1: Different combinations of receptors encode different odorants.
text 2: The same combination of receptors encodes all odorants.

text 1: Olfactory sensory neurons project to the ipsilateral olfactory bulb.
text 2: Olfactory sensory neurons project to the contralateral olfactory bulb.

text 1: The axons of ON bipolar cells end in the distal (upper) half, while those of OFF cells end in the proximal (lower) half.
text 2: The axons of ON bipolar cells end in the proximal (lower) half, while those of OFF cells end in the distal (upper) half.

text 1: ON and OFF cells use different types of receptors at the synapse with photoreceptors.
text 2: ON and OFF cells use the same types of receptors at the synapse with photoreceptors.

text 1: The isolated dot at left marks the sensitivity at high spatial frequency, a spatially variable field.
text 2: The isolated dot at left marks the sensitivity at zero spatial frequency, a spatially uniform field.

text 1: Photoreceptors release neurotransmitter in an all-or-nothing fashion using a specialized structure, the ribbon synapse.
text 2: Photoreceptors release neurotransmitter in a graded fashion using a specialized structure, the ribbon synapse.

text 1: The neurons’ sensitivity to light at different points on the retina is modeled as a 'difference-of-Gaussians' receptive field.
text 2: The neurons’ sensitivity to light at different points on the retina is modeled as a 'sum-of-Gaussians' receptive field.

text 1: Sensitivity increases at both high and low frequencies.
text 2: Sensitivity declines at both high and low frequencies.

text 1: The mean light level varied, decreasing by factors of 10 from the top to the bottom trace.
text 2: The mean light level varied, increasing by factors of 10 from the top to the bottom trace.

text 1: Amacrine cells generally receive inhibitory signals from bipolar cells at glutamatergic synapses.
text 2: Amacrine cells generally receive excitatory signals from bipolar cells at glutamatergic synapses.

text 1: Horizontal cells have broadly arborizing dendrites that spread laterally in the outer plexiform layer.
text 2: Horizontal cells have narrowly arborizing dendrites that spread laterally in the outer plexiform layer.

text 1: Signals in the parallel on and off pathways are modified by interactions with horizontal and amacrine cells.
text 2: Signals in the parallel on and off pathways are unaffected by interactions with horizontal and amacrine cells.

text 1: Approximately 30 types of amacrine cells are known.
text 2: Approximately 10 types of amacrine cells are known.

text 1: Bipolar cells can be distinguished by the morphology of their dendrites.
text 2: Bipolar cells cannot be distinguished by the morphology of their dendrites.

text 1: Horizontal cells are electrically coupled to each other through gap junctions.
text 2: Horizontal cells are not electrically coupled to each other.

text 1: Photoreceptors do not fire action potentials; like bipolar cells, they release neurotransmitter in a graded fashion.
text 2: Photoreceptors fire action potentials; unlike bipolar cells, they release neurotransmitter in an all-or-nothing fashion.

text 1: The diffuse bipolar cell receives input from a single cone and excites a P-type ganglion cell.
text 2: The diffuse bipolar cell receives input from many cones and excites an M-type ganglion cell.

text 1: For a small gaze shift, the eye and head move in sequence.
text 2: For a small gaze shift, the eye and head move simultaneously.

text 1: A certain frequency of firing in the abducens motor neuron affects head position and velocity.
text 2: A certain frequency of firing in the abducens motor neuron affects eye position and velocity.

text 1: The smooth-pursuit system fails to hold the image of a moving target on the fovea.
text 2: The smooth-pursuit system holds the image of a moving target on the fovea.

text 1: Lesions in the dorsolateral pons disrupt ipsiversive smooth pursuit.
text 2: Lesions in the dorsolateral pons disrupt contraversive smooth pursuit.

text 1: A diabetic patient had an acute partial abducens nerve lesion affecting one eye.
text 2: A diabetic patient had an acute partial oculomotor nerve lesion affecting one eye.

text 1: Head and body movements must be coordinated to direct the fovea to a target.
text 2: Head and eye movements must be coordinated to direct the fovea to a target.

text 1: Lesions of the superior temporal sulcus disrupt the ability to respond to moving targets.
text 2: Lesions of the medial superior temporal area disrupt the ability to respond to moving targets.

text 1: The eye compensates for head movement during a large gaze shift.
text 2: The head compensates for eye movement during a large gaze shift.

text 1: Neurons in the middle temporal area continue to fire even if the target disappears briefly.
text 2: Neurons in the medial superior temporal area continue to fire even if the target disappears briefly.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex ordinarily moves the eyes in the same direction as the head.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex ordinarily moves the eyes in the direction opposite that of the head.

text 1: The saccade system has a shorter latency than the smooth-pursuit system.
text 2: The smooth-pursuit system has a shorter latency than the saccade system.

text 1: Patients with brain stem and cerebellar lesions cannot pursue targets moving toward the lesion side.
text 2: Patients with brain stem and cerebellar lesions can easily pursue targets moving toward the lesion side.

text 1: The frontal eye field may be more important for initiating pursuit.
text 2: The superior colliculus may be more important for initiating pursuit.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the frontal eye field initiates contraversive pursuit.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the frontal eye field initiates ipsiversive pursuit.

text 1: The visual system ignores differences in retinal positions when creating a perception of depth.
text 2: The visual system uses slight differences in retinal positions to create a perception of depth.

text 1: The Cl− equilibrium potential is more negative than the resting membrane potential.
text 2: The resting membrane potential is more negative than the Cl− equilibrium potential.

text 1: In the equivalent circuit model, the membrane conductance for K+ is much lower than that for Na+.
text 2: In the equivalent circuit model, the membrane conductance for K+ is much greater than that for Na+.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump's electrogenic influence is included in the calculation of the resting potential.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump's electrogenic influence is ignored in the calculation of the resting potential.

text 1: For most nerve cells, the value of gCl ranges from one-fourth to one-half of gK.
text 2: For most nerve cells, the value of gCl ranges from three-fourths to one-half of gK.

text 1: At the peak of the action potential, gNa increases as much as 500-fold.
text 2: At the peak of the action potential, gNa is essentially unchanged from its resting value.

text 1: The resting membrane potential calculated from the given circuit model is −30 mV.
text 2: The resting membrane potential calculated from the given circuit model is −70 mV.

text 1: At the peak of the action potential, Vm is closer to EK than to ENa.
text 2: At the peak of the action potential, Vm is closer to ENa than to EK.

text 1: Equation 9–4 shows that the resting potential is calculated from the sum of the conductances and battery values for Na+, K+, and Cl−.
text 2: Equation 9–4 shows that the resting potential only considers the Na+ conductance and battery values.

text 1: The membrane potential rises and decays more slowly than a step change in current because of its capacitance.
text 2: The membrane potential rises and decays instantaneously with a step change in current due to its resistive properties.

text 1: A true resistor alters voltage proportionately with a change in capacitance.
text 2: A true resistor responds to a step change in current with a similar step change in voltage.

text 1: Vm is more negative in circuits with very low K+ current than in those with high K+ current.
text 2: Vm is more negative in circuits with very high K+ current than in those with low K+ current.

text 1: gNa's contribution to the resting potential is weighted in proportion to the membrane conductance for Na+.
text 2: gNa's contribution to the resting potential is weighted in proportion to the membrane conductance for Cl−.

text 1: In the equivalent circuit, gNa increases significantly during an action potential.
text 2: In the equivalent circuit, Ek increases significantly during an action potential.

text 1: Cm affects the amplitude of the membrane potential's steady-state response.
text 2: Cm affects the time course of the membrane potential's response.

text 1: In the equivalent circuit model, gNa is greater than gCl at rest.
text 2: In the equivalent circuit model, gCl is greater than gNa at rest.

text 1: The concentration of free Ca2+ in the cytoplasm of a resting cell is extremely low, about 10−7 M.
text 2: The concentration of free Ca2+ in the cytoplasm of a resting cell is extremely high, about 10−7 M.

text 1: Glutamatergic pyramidal neurons typically fire rapidly at the beginning of the current pulse followed by progressive slowing of firing.
text 2: Glutamatergic pyramidal neurons typically fire slowly at the beginning of the current pulse and then accelerate.

text 1: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons are associated with high levels of expression of Kv3 channels.
text 2: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons are associated with low levels of expression of Kv3 channels.

text 1: Afterdepolarizations can trigger a second action potential, resulting in all-or-none burst firing.
text 2: Afterhyperpolarizations can trigger a second action potential, resulting in all-or-none burst firing.

text 1: Fast-spiking neurons are limited to the mammalian peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Fast-spiking neurons occur throughout the mammalian central nervous system.

text 1: The axon initial segment has the lowest threshold for action potential generation.
text 2: The dendrites have the lowest threshold for action potential generation.

text 1: In dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra, pacemaking is driven by voltage-independent Ca2+ currents.
text 2: In dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra, pacemaking is partly driven by voltage-dependent Ca2+ currents.

text 1: The influx of Na+ during an action potential can open BK channels to help repolarize the action potential.
text 2: The influx of Ca2+ during an action potential can open BK channels to help repolarize the action potential.

text 1: SK channels are voltage-dependent and open only in response to voltage changes.
text 2: SK channels are not voltage-dependent but open only in response to increases in intracellular Ca2+.

text 1: Different types of neurons generate action potentials that have different shapes.
text 2: All types of neurons generate action potentials that are identical in shape.

text 1: Squid axon action potentials are followed by afterdepolarization.
text 2: Squid axon action potentials are followed by an afterhyperpolarization.

text 1: The pattern of action potential firing varies widely between neurons.
text 2: The pattern of action potential firing is identical across all neurons.

text 1: Many neurons in the mammalian brain fire spontaneously, often referred to as pacemaking.
text 2: Neurons never fire spontaneously without synaptic input.

text 1: Only synaptic inputs and outputs define neuronal function, not intrinsic excitability properties.
text 2: Intrinsic excitability properties define neuronal function along with synaptic inputs and outputs.

text 1: The afterdepolarization can lead to burst firing if it's large enough.
text 2: The afterhyperpolarization can lead to burst firing if it's large enough.

text 1: The general linear model (GLM) is used to explain observed BOLD activity as a linear combination of regressors that reflect task conditions and covariates.
text 2: The general linear model (GLM) is used to explain observed BOLD activity by examining correlations between different brain regions.

text 1: Univariate activation analysis measures the relative activity evoked by one condition versus another independently in each voxel or region.
text 2: Univariate activation analysis measures the correlation between voxels to infer functional brain networks.

text 1: Contrasts in fMRI analysis compare parameter estimates (betas) from different conditions to localize brain functions.
text 2: Contrasts in fMRI analysis compare raw BOLD signal intensities directly to localize brain functions.

text 1: The fusiform face area (FFA) is a region in the fusiform gyrus that shows robust and selective BOLD activity when humans view faces.
text 2: The fusiform face area (FFA) is a region in the fusiform gyrus that shows robust and selective BOLD activity when humans listen to voices.

text 1: Resting functional connectivity measures correlations in BOLD activity between brain regions while subjects lie still without performing a task.
text 2: Resting functional connectivity measures correlations in BOLD activity during cognitive tasks with subjects actively performing a task.

text 1: Classifier-based MVPA identifies brain networks by clustering regions with similar functional connectivity patterns.
text 2: Classifier-based MVPA trains machine learning models to discriminate between conditions using patterns of BOLD activity.

text 1: Repetition suppression refers to a reduction in BOLD activity when the same stimulus is presented repeatedly.
text 2: Repetition suppression refers to an increase in BOLD activity when the same stimulus is presented repeatedly.

text 1: Representational similarity analysis (RSA) uses similarity matrices to compare neural representations across conditions or stimuli.
text 2: Representational similarity analysis (RSA) uses correlation patterns to directly classify cognitive tasks.

text 1: The hemodynamic response delay is accounted for during the generation of regressors in fMRI analysis.
text 2: The hemodynamic response delay is ignored during the generation of regressors in fMRI analysis.

text 1: Multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) examines spatial patterns of BOLD activity over multiple voxels to decode information.
text 2: Multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) examines temporal patterns of BOLD activity within individual voxels to decode information.

text 1: The default mode network is a large-scale brain network characterized by its activity during task performance.
text 2: The default mode network is a large-scale brain network characterized by its activity during resting states.

text 1: Functional connectivity measures correlations in BOLD fluctuations between brain regions to infer communication.
text 2: Functional connectivity measures direct causal links in BOLD activity between brain regions.

text 1: The FFA was identified using fMRI studies showing selective activation in response to environmental sounds compared to face stimuli.
text 2: The FFA was identified using fMRI studies showing selective activation in response to face stimuli compared to non-face stimuli.

text 1: Task-based functional connectivity does not require accounting for stimulus-driven BOLD responses to isolate true correlations.
text 2: Task-based functional connectivity requires accounting for external stimulus-driven BOLD responses to isolate true correlations.

text 1: Graph theory can summarize properties of activity patterns, treating brain regions as temporal inputs only.
text 2: Graph theory can summarize properties of functional connectivity patterns, treating brain regions as nodes and connections as edges.

text 1: Several powerful and invasive approaches are available to locate the focus of a partial seizure, but they are rarely used in epilepsy surgery.
text 2: Several powerful and noninvasive approaches are available to locate the focus of a partial seizure, leading to successful epilepsy surgery for selected patients.

text 1: Epilepsy surgery is particularly successful for patients with complex partial seizures of hippocampal onset.
text 2: Epilepsy surgery is particularly unsuccessful for patients with complex partial seizures of hippocampal onset.

text 1: The increasing power of genetic, molecular, and modern cell-physiological approaches applied to the study of seizures and epilepsy offers no new hope for therapeutic options.
text 2: The increasing power of genetic, molecular, and modern cell-physiological approaches applied to the study of seizures and epilepsy provides hope for new therapeutic options.

text 1: Genetic approaches have limited insights into the function of the mammalian brain.
text 2: Genetic approaches provide new insights into the function of the mammalian brain.

text 1: Neurobiological studies of the progression from an acute seizure to epilepsy have not provided alternative strategies for treatment.
text 2: Neurobiological studies of the progression from an acute seizure to epilepsy should provide alternative strategies for treatment beyond standard options.

text 1: Genetic malformations of the human cerebral cortex have been studied in relation to epilepsy.
text 2: Genetic malformations of the human cerebral cortex are unrelated to epilepsy studies.

text 1: A seizure focus in the frontal lobe can approach an 80% success rate of treatment.
text 2: A seizure focus in the temporal lobe can approach an 80% success rate of treatment.

text 1: Prolonged seizures can cause brain damage due to systemic metabolic derangements.
text 2: Short seizures always cause brain damage due to systemic metabolic derangements.

text 1: Status epilepticus is a condition that involves a single seizure and is not considered an emergency.
text 2: Status epilepticus is a condition that involves repeated generalized seizures and is a true medical emergency.

text 1: Excitotoxicity is caused by excessive stimulation of glutamate receptors.
text 2: Excitotoxicity is caused by insufficient stimulation of glutamate receptors.

text 1: Domoic acid, a toxin from marine algae, can provide protection against seizures.
text 2: Domoic acid, a toxin from marine algae, can cause severe seizures and memory loss.

text 1: Patients with poorly controlled seizures are at risk for SUDEP, which is linked to cardiac arrhythmias.
text 2: Patients with well-controlled seizures are at risk for SUDEP, not linked to cardiac arrhythmias.

text 1: The hippocampus is particularly vulnerable to excitotoxicity.
text 2: The prefrontal cortex is particularly vulnerable to excitotoxicity.

text 1: All forms of epilepsy are caused solely by environmental factors, with no genetic influence.
text 2: Some forms of epilepsy are believed to result from a genetic predisposition.

text 1: Mutations in ion channels are among the genetic causes of epilepsy.
text 2: Mutations in ion channels do not contribute to the genetic causes of epilepsy.

text 1: Rett syndrome, linked to epilepsy and caused by mutations in MECP2, involves intellectual disability.
text 2: Rett syndrome is unrelated to epilepsy and is not caused by MECP2 mutations.

text 1: Excitotoxicity results from a decrease in glutamate receptor stimulation.
text 2: Excitotoxicity results more from excessive stimulation of glutamate receptors than from tonic increases in extracellular glutamate.

text 1: ADNFLE is linked to a mutation in the β2-subunit of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor-channel.
text 2: ADNFLE is linked to a mutation in the α4-subunit of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor-channel.

text 1: Status epilepticus can involve nonconvulsive seizures, where metabolic consequences are less severe.
text 2: Status epilepticus can involve nonconvulsive seizures, where metabolic consequences are more severe.

text 1: The mature brain is more vulnerable to seizure-related damage.
text 2: The immature brain is more vulnerable to seizure-related damage.

text 1: Seizure-related excitotoxicity is non-specific, affecting all brain regions equally.
text 2: Seizure-related excitotoxicity is specific to certain cell types and brain regions.

text 1: Interaural differences in the arrival of a sound help localize sound in the vertical plane.
text 2: Interaural differences in the arrival of a sound help localize sound in the horizontal plane.

text 1: The lateral superior olive forms a map of the location of sounds in the horizontal plane.
text 2: The lateral superior olive does not form a map of the location of sounds in the horizontal plane.

text 1: The locus ceruleus provides most of the noradrenergic inputs to the spinal cord's dorsal horn.
text 2: The locus ceruleus provides all of the serotonergic inputs to the spinal cord's dorsal horn.

text 1: Direct application of serotonin to dorsal horn neurons increases their response to noxious stimuli.
text 2: Direct application of serotonin to dorsal horn neurons inhibits their response to noxious stimuli.

text 1: Drugs that augment monoamine reuptake can help limit migraine headache pain.
text 2: Drugs that block monoamine reuptake can help limit migraine headache pain.

text 1: The substantia nigra pars compacta sends massive dopaminergic projections to the striatum to facilitate motor function.
text 2: The substantia nigra pars compacta sends serotonergic projections to the striatum to facilitate motor function.

text 1: Low dopamine levels reduce activity in direct pathway striatal neurons, inhibiting behavior release.
text 2: Low dopamine levels increase activity in direct pathway striatal neurons, facilitating behavior release.

text 1: Dopaminergic neurons provide a reward-prediction error signal useful for reinforcement learning.
text 2: Dopaminergic neurons provide a direct sensory processing signal unrelated to reinforcement learning.

text 1: Parkinson disease arises from degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the midbrain.
text 2: Parkinson disease arises from activation of serotonergic neurons in the midbrain.

text 1: Drugs that block β-adrenergic receptors are often used clinically to reduce tremor caused by stress.
text 2: Drugs that activate β-adrenergic receptors are often used clinically to reduce tremor caused by stress.

text 1: In REM sleep, the firing of serotonergic raphe neurons practically ceases.
text 2: In REM sleep, the firing of serotonergic raphe neurons increases significantly.

text 1: Noradrenergic cell groups in the pons facilitate excitatory inputs to motor neurons during stress responses.
text 2: Noradrenergic cell groups in the pons inhibit excitatory inputs to motor neurons during stress responses.

text 1: Activity in dopaminergic neurons decreases immediately after a conditioned stimulus during reward learning.
text 2: Activity in dopaminergic neurons increases immediately after a conditioned stimulus during reward learning.

text 1: The role of serotonin in migraine treatment includes presynaptic inhibition of pain afferents from the meninges.
text 2: The role of serotonin in migraine treatment includes presynaptic facilitation of pain afferents from the meninges.

text 1: The phasic mode of locus ceruleus activity facilitates selective attention to a stimulus about to initiate behavior.
text 2: The tonic mode of locus ceruleus activity facilitates selective attention to a stimulus about to initiate behavior.

text 1: Drugs that block serotonin receptors can induce hyperactivity and rigidity as part of serotonin syndrome.
text 2: Drugs that activate serotonin receptors can induce hyperactivity and rigidity as part of serotonin syndrome.

text 1: Monoaminergic neurons fire fastest during REM sleep and slow down during wakefulness.
text 2: Monoaminergic neurons fire fastest during wakefulness and practically halt during REM sleep.

text 1: Behavior therapy was shown to be slow and ineffective for phobias.
text 2: Behavior therapy was shown to be quick and effective for phobias.

text 1: Helmholtz was the first to measure the speed with which afferent signals in peripheral nerves are conducted.
text 2: Helmholtz was the first to measure the speed with which afferent signals in central nerves are conducted.

text 1: Cognitive therapists teach their clients methods for increasing the frequency of negative thoughts.
text 2: Cognitive therapists teach their clients methods for reducing the frequency of negative thoughts.

text 1: Cognition can become dysfunctional so that the knowledge acquired about the world is false.
text 2: Cognition can become optimal so that the knowledge acquired about the world is always accurate.

text 1: Most cognitive processing never enters consciousness.
text 2: Most cognitive processing always enters consciousness.

text 1: Schizophrenic patients frequently experience complex auditory hallucinations.
text 2: Schizophrenic patients rarely experience complex auditory hallucinations.

text 1: Visual perception is a prime example of simple computational processes.
text 2: Visual perception is a prime example of complex computational processes.

text 1: Blind sight refers to the inability to detect visual properties despite having full sensory perception.
text 2: Blind sight refers to the ability to detect visual properties despite having no sensory perception.

text 1: Patients with unilateral neglect often do not acknowledge objects on the left side.
text 2: Patients with unilateral neglect often do not acknowledge objects on the right side.

text 1: Helmholtz's ideas about unconscious inferences were largely ignored.
text 2: Helmholtz's ideas about unconscious inferences were widely accepted.

text 1: Francis Crick and Christopher Koch initiated the search for the neural correlates of consciousness.
text 2: Francis Crick and Christopher Koch ended the search for the neural correlates of consciousness.

text 1: The fusiform gyrus is specialized for the processing of faces.
text 2: The fusiform gyrus is specialized for the processing of landscapes.

text 1: Cognitive therapy has been particularly unsuccessful in the treatment of depression.
text 2: Cognitive therapy has been particularly successful in the treatment of depression.

text 1: Unconscious processing can be seen in cases of spatial neglect.
text 2: Unconscious processing cannot be seen in cases of spatial neglect.

text 1: Unconscious inferences play a significant role in what we perceive.
text 2: Unconscious inferences play no role in what we perceive.

text 1: Behavior therapy was shown to be quick and effective for phobias.
text 2: Behavior therapy was shown to be slow and ineffective for phobias.

text 1: Aaron Beck and Albert Ellis initiated cognitive therapy in the 1960s to strengthen psychoanalytic approaches based on unconscious motivation.
text 2: Aaron Beck and Albert Ellis initiated cognitive therapy in the 1960s to focus on changing thoughts rather than behavior.

text 1: Helmholtz measured the speed of afferent signals in peripheral nerves and found nerve conduction to be quite slow.
text 2: Helmholtz measured the speed of afferent signals in peripheral nerves and concluded nerve conduction was as fast as the speed of light.

text 1: The Rubin figure sometimes results in the perception of a vase and sometimes two faces looking at each other.
text 2: The Rubin figure only depicts a vase and never two faces.

text 1: Blind sight refers to a condition where patients have lesions in the primary visual cortex and exhibit unconscious visual awareness.
text 2: Blind sight refers to a condition where patients' primary visual cortex is intact, but they consciously deny visual perception.

text 1: Unilateral neglect is caused by lesions in the occipital lobe and results in vivid awareness of all visual regions.
text 2: Unilateral neglect is caused by lesions in the right parietal lobe and can result in ignoring the left side of space.

text 1: Patients with unilateral neglect consciously perceive fire in the house and choose it as the preferred residence.
text 2: Patients with unilateral neglect might unconsciously choose the house without fire as a preferred residence, despite claiming no visible differences.

text 1: Current neuroscience seeks to distinguish neural activity associated with conscious and unconscious cognitive processes.
text 2: Current neuroscience assumes no difference exists between neural activity associated with conscious and unconscious cognitive processes.

text 1: The computational approach to vision revealed perceiving objects is a trivial task even for artificial intelligence.
text 2: The computational approach to vision highlighted the complexity of perceptual processes despite their apparent simplicity for humans.

text 1: Patients experiencing Charles Bonnet Syndrome may have visual hallucinations correlated with activity in the secondary visual cortex.
text 2: Patients experiencing Charles Bonnet Syndrome lose all neural activity in the secondary visual cortex.

text 1: Schizophrenic auditory hallucinations occur randomly without any neural activity involvement.
text 2: Schizophrenic auditory hallucinations, often voices, are linked to specific changes in neural activity.

text 1: Change blindness demonstrates how perceptual changes can be missed despite significant sensory stimulation differences.
text 2: Change blindness refers to instant detection of changes in a sensory stimulation by observers.

text 1: Ambiguous figures such as the Rubin figure show how perception alternates between two valid interpretations.
text 2: Ambiguous figures consistently lead observers to perceive only one fixed interpretation.

text 1: Most neuroscientists agree we are conscious of perceptions but not cognitive processes.
text 2: Most neuroscientists agree we are conscious of underlying cognitive processes driving perception.

text 1: Helmholtz's work on unconscious inference demonstrated brain processes occur without conscious awareness.
text 2: Helmholtz argued that all brain processing requires conscious awareness.

text 1: Classical conditioning involves learning a relationship between two stimuli.
text 2: Classical conditioning involves learning a relationship between an organism's behavior and the consequences of that behavior.

text 1: Classical conditioning was first described in the early 1900s by Ivan Pavlov.
text 2: Classical conditioning was first described in the late 1800s by Ivan Pavlov.

text 1: The conditioned stimulus is paired with an unconditioned stimulus to produce a conditioned response.
text 2: The conditioned stimulus is paired with an innate response to produce an unconditioned response.

text 1: Extinction is unrelated to adaptive mechanisms.
text 2: Extinction is an important adaptive mechanism.

text 1: Operant conditioning involves associating specific behavior with a reinforcing event.
text 2: Operant conditioning involves associating two stimuli without reinforcement.

text 1: Extinction signifies that the CS now signals the US will not occur.
text 2: Extinction implies the CS now signals the US will certainly occur.

text 1: Operant conditioning is unrelated to the outcomes of an action.
text 2: Operant conditioning can be considered the formation of a predictive relationship between an action and an outcome.

text 1: Taste aversion develops even when the unconditioned response occurs after a long delay.
text 2: Taste aversion requires immediate occurrence of the unconditioned response.

text 1: Absent-mindedness results from a lack of attention to immediate experience.
text 2: Absent-mindedness results from consistent and focused attention.

text 1: Blocking refers to a temporary inability to access information stored in memory.
text 2: Blocking refers to permanent loss of information stored in memory.

text 1: Misattribution involves associating a memory with an incorrect time or place.
text 2: Misattribution involves associating memory accurately and without error.

text 1: Suggestibility enhances memory recall without external influence.
text 2: Suggestibility refers to incorporating new information into memory based on leading questions.

text 1: Bias involves distortions in memory due to one's general knowledge and beliefs.
text 2: Bias ensures memory accuracy by removing personal knowledge influences.

text 1: Persistence allows selective forgetting of unwanted memories.
text 2: Persistence refers to the constant remembering of information or events.

text 1: Operant behaviors are said to be emitted rather than elicited.
text 2: Operant behaviors are always elicited by a specific stimulus.

text 1: Intracortical electrodes record the activity of neurons near the electrode tip and can also be used to deliver electrical stimulation.
text 2: Intracortical electrodes record neuron activity throughout the entire brain and deliver electrical stimulation to all brain areas.

text 1: BMIs can help to regulate pathological neural activity by measuring neural activity, processing it, and subsequently stimulating neurons.
text 2: BMIs can help to regulate pathological neural activity by directly modifying the brain's structure and altering neuron pathways.

text 1: A discrete decoder estimates one of several possible movement goals from neural population activity.
text 2: A discrete decoder estimates continuous moment-by-moment movement details from neural population activity.

text 1: The field is making significant regress in the performance of BMIs, in terms of the slow and inaccurate estimation of movements.
text 2: The field is making substantial progress in increasing the performance of BMIs, in terms of speed and accuracy of estimated movements.

text 1: Using this paradigm, a recent study recorded neural activity only in the striatum and designated all neurons involved as nonoutput neurons.
text 2: Using this paradigm, a recent study recorded neural activity simultaneously in the primary cortex and striatum with M1 neurons designated as output neurons.

text 1: BMIs are medical devices that exclusively enhance electrophysiological activity without altering it at the level of individual neurons.
text 2: BMIs are medical devices that read out and/or alter electrophysiological activity at the level of populations of neurons.

text 1: BMIs raise no neuroethics questions, as their benefits to people with injury or disease are unequivocal.
text 2: BMIs raise new neuroethics questions, which need to be considered with the benefits provided by BMIs to people with injury or disease.

text 1: BMIs are rarely used as a tool for understanding brain function due to their complexity in brain interfaces.
text 2: BMIs are increasingly used as a tool for understanding brain function by simplifying the brain’s input and output interfaces.

text 1: In a BMI, one must use all recorded neurons to ensure universal control over movements.
text 2: In a BMI, one can choose to use only a subset of the recorded neurons (the output neurons) for controlling movements.

text 1: Efforts to increase the functional lifetime of electrodes include mitigating immunological responses.
text 2: Efforts to increase the functional lifetime of electrodes exclude addressing immunological responses.

text 1: BMIs based on different neural sensors have different risks and benefits.
text 2: BMIs based on different neural sensors have universal risks and benefits regardless of their differences.

text 1: Identifying output versus nonoutput neurons in a study using arm or eye movements is straightforward and simple.
text 2: Identifying output versus nonoutput neurons in a study using arm or eye movements would be challenging.

text 1: BMIs can help restore lost motor capabilities by exclusively measuring activity from limited individual neurons.
text 2: BMIs can help restore lost motor capabilities by measuring activity from many individual neurons.

text 1: Future advances of BMI will solely rely on the improvements in hardware technology alone.
text 2: Future advances of BMI will depend in part on developments in neurotechnology, including hardware and software.

text 1: BMIs can help restore lost sensory capabilities by removing neurons to stop sensory information from reaching the brain.
text 2: BMIs can help restore lost sensory capabilities by stimulating neurons to convey sensory information to the brain.

text 1: TRPM8 receptors respond to temperatures below 45°C (113°F), which are perceived as warm.
text 2: TRPM8 receptors respond to temperatures below 25°C (77°F), which are perceived as cool or cold.

text 1: TRPA1 receptors have thermal thresholds below 17°C (63°F), representing sensations described as frigid or cold.
text 2: TRPA1 receptors have thermal thresholds above 27°C (80°F), representing sensations described as warm.

text 1: TRPV1 and TRPV2 receptors respond to temperatures exceeding 45°C (113°F) and mediate sensations of burning pain.
text 2: TRPV1 and TRPV2 receptors respond to temperatures below 17°C (63°F) to mediate sensations of cold pain.

text 1: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to gradual increases in skin temperature than to sudden changes.
text 2: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to sudden drops in skin temperature than to gradual changes.

text 1: Nociceptors innervated by Aδ fibers produce dull, burning pain and respond to cooling stimuli like drafts or cold temperatures.
text 2: Nociceptors innervated by Aδ fibers produce sharp, pricking pain and respond to mechanical stimuli like punctures or pinches.

text 1: C fibers typically produce dull, burning pain and respond to polymodal stimuli such as puncture, noxious heat, and chemicals.
text 2: C fibers typically produce sharp, localized pain and respond to mechanical stimuli exclusively, such as pinching or puncture.

text 1: The H1 histamine receptor mediates pain sensations triggered by histamine and cannot be blocked by antihistamines.
text 2: The H1 histamine receptor mediates itch sensations triggered by histamine and can be blocked by antihistamines.

text 1: TRPA1 receptors mediate sensations from pungent substances like horseradish and garlic, triggering pain or irritation.
text 2: TRPA1 receptors mediate sensations from sweet substances like honey or sugar, triggering sensations of warmth and comfort.

text 1: Capsaicin, the active ingredient in chili peppers, activates TRPM8 receptors that mediate cooling sensations.
text 2: Capsaicin, the active ingredient in chili peppers, activates nociceptive C fibers that mediate burning pain.

text 1: Warm receptors are highly sensitive to rapid changes in skin temperature and respond sharply to temperature drops.
text 2: Warm receptors fire monotonically with increasing skin temperature and saturate at thresholds of pain.

text 1: Nociceptors signal impending tissue injury and provide constant reminders about already-injured tissues needing protection.
text 2: Nociceptors only provide signals for pain during initial tissue injury and are inactive for already-injured tissues.

text 1: Mechanical nociceptors respond to sharp objects that puncture the skin, such as pinpricks or serrated forceps.
text 2: Mechanical nociceptors respond to blunt objects that apply strong pressure but do not puncture the skin.

text 1: TRPV3 receptors respond to cooling of the skin below 17°C (63°F) and generate sensations of cold.
text 2: TRPV3 receptors respond to warming of the skin above 35°C (95°F) and generate sensations from warm to hot.

text 1: Sensory terminals express channels like Piezo2 or TRP receptors for sensory transduction, optimizing information gathering.
text 2: Sensory terminals express voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels for action potential generation, optimizing impulse transmission.

text 1: Visceral afferent fibers exclusively regulate respiratory function without involvement in gastrointestinal sensing.
text 2: Visceral afferent fibers regulate respiration, gastrointestinal function, and mechanical sensing like stomach distension.

text 1: Most ion channels have three states: open, closed, and inactivated or desensitized.
text 2: Most ion channels have four states: open, closed, semi-open, and inactivated or desensitized.

text 1: Ion channels act as pumps for the active transport of ions across the membrane.
text 2: Ion channels act as catalysts for the passive flux of ions across the membrane.

text 1: Ion transporters and pumps undergo conformational changes for different phases of the transport cycle.
text 2: Ion transporters and pumps provide continuous pathways for ions without conformational changes.

text 1: The expression patterns of some ion channels change during development and in response to changes in neuronal activity patterns.
text 2: The expression patterns of all ion channels remain constant during development and do not respond to changes in neuronal activity patterns.

text 1: Most ion channels are selectively permeable to certain ions.
text 2: Most ion channels are impermeable to all ions.

text 1: Ion channels have gates that always remain in a fixed position.
text 2: Ion channels have gates that open and close in response to different signals.

text 1: CLC exchangers have a single gate that control Cl− flux.
text 2: CLC exchangers have two gates that control Cl− flux.

text 1: Most exchangers and pumps are thought to have two gates, one external and one internal.
text 2: Most exchangers and pumps are thought to have only one gate that is alternately open internally and externally.

text 1: These features have only been conserved in humans.
text 2: These features have been conserved with surprising fidelity from prokaryotes through humans.

text 1: CLC channels are built on a structure similar to transporters, but with modified gates.
text 2: CLC channels are built on a completely different structure than transporters and have no gates.

text 1: Most ion channels are composed of a single subunit.
text 2: Most ion channels are composed of multiple subunits.

text 1: Structure-function studies have not provided any meaningful insights into K+ channel conduction.
text 2: Structure-function studies of voltage-gated ion channels have provided insights into K+ channel conduction.

text 1: The driving force for active ion fluxes comes from either the hydrolysis of ATP or favorable electrochemical potential difference.
text 2: The driving force for active ion fluxes only comes from mechanical stimuli.

text 1: Ions cross cell membranes through two main classes of integral membrane proteins—ion channels and ion pumps or transporters.
text 2: Ions cross cell membranes through one main class of integral membrane proteins—ion channels.

text 1: Ion channels prevent electrically charged ions from crossing the cell membrane.
text 2: Ion channels allow electrically charged ions to rapidly cross the nonpolar environment of the cell membrane.

text 1: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) parameters that activate the motor cortex improve the recovery of locomotion following incomplete spinal cord injury.
text 2: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) parameters that activate the motor cortex worsen the recovery of locomotion following incomplete spinal cord injury.

text 1: The motor cortex in humans plays a more important role in locomotion than in other mammals.
text 2: The motor cortex in humans plays a less important role in locomotion than in other mammals.

text 1: Spinal circuits cannot generate any locomotor pattern without descending and rhythmical peripheral afferent inputs.
text 2: Spinal circuits can generate a complex locomotor pattern in isolation from descending and rhythmical peripheral afferent inputs.

text 1: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is part of a network that contributes to the advanced planning of gait based on auditory information.
text 2: The posterior parietal cortex (PPC) is part of a network that contributes to the advanced planning of gait based on visual information.

text 1: Peripheral afferent inputs do not modulate the function of spinal locomotor circuits.
text 2: Peripheral afferent inputs modulate the function of spinal locomotor circuits.

text 1: Neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus cannot be affected in Parkinson disease and do not contribute to gait disturbances.
text 2: Neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus can be affected in Parkinson disease, contributing to severe gait disturbances.

text 1: Inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia are used to correct motor errors and select appropriate patterns of motor activity.
text 2: Inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia do not correct motor errors or select patterns of motor activity.

text 1: The available evidence suggests that the neural control mechanisms determined from experiments in animals are also used to control locomotion in humans.
text 2: The available evidence suggests that the neural control mechanisms determined from experiments in animals are not used to control locomotion in humans.

text 1: Imaging studies show increased activity in parts of the midbrain important for initiation and speed control of locomotion.
text 2: Imaging studies show decreased activity in parts of the midbrain important for initiation and speed control of locomotion.

text 1: Recent technological advances now offer unparalleled opportunities to investigate the control mechanisms underlying locomotion.
text 2: Recent technological advances limit opportunities to investigate the control mechanisms underlying locomotion.

text 1: The organization of neural pathways involved in the generation and regulation of locomotion in mammals remains poorly understood.
text 2: The organization of neural pathways involved in the generation and regulation of locomotion in mammals has been determined in significant detail.

text 1: Excitatory rhythm-generating neurons together with commissural inhibitory neurons are responsible for left–right alternation.
text 2: Excitatory neurons alone are responsible for left–right alternation, without the involvement of inhibitory neurons.

text 1: Circuits controlling speed of locomotion and selecting gaits are localized in the forebrain.
text 2: Circuits controlling speed of locomotion and selecting gaits are localized in the midbrain.

text 1: The motor cortex provides precise control of muscle activity patterns to allow animals to make visually guided anticipatory adjustments of their gait.
text 2: The motor cortex does not contribute to visually guided anticipatory adjustments of animal gait.

text 1: Activity in the pedunculopontine nucleus can affect locomotion in Parkinson disease.
text 2: Activity in the pedunculopontine nucleus does not affect locomotion in Parkinson disease.

text 1: The fragile X mutation leads to the expansion of the CGG triplet on the FMR1 gene to more than 200 repeats.
text 2: The fragile X mutation leads to the expansion of the CGG triplet on the FMR1 gene to less than 50 repeats.

text 1: Approximately 30% of boys with fragile X meet all diagnostic criteria for ASD.
text 2: Approximately 50% of boys with fragile X meet all diagnostic criteria for ASD.

text 1: Rett syndrome is primarily caused by gain-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene.
text 2: Rett syndrome is primarily caused by loss-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene.

text 1: Williams syndrome is caused by a segmental deletion of about 27 genes on chromosome 7.
text 2: Williams syndrome is caused by a duplication of about 27 genes on chromosome 7.

text 1: Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion on chromosome 15 inherited from the father.
text 2: Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion on chromosome 15 inherited from the mother.

text 1: Angelman syndrome is characterized by mild intellectual disability and inappropriate laughter.
text 2: Angelman syndrome is characterized by severe intellectual disability and inappropriate laughter.

text 1: Rett syndrome primarily affects boys due to its inheritance pattern linked to the X chromosome.
text 2: Rett syndrome primarily affects girls due to its inheritance pattern linked to the X chromosome.

text 1: Williams syndrome leads to increased sociability and an affinity for music.
text 2: Williams syndrome leads to decreased sociability and an aversion to music.

text 1: The prevalence of Rett syndrome is approximately 1 in 10,000 live female births.
text 2: The prevalence of Rett syndrome is approximately 1 in 10,000 live male births.

text 1: MECP2 duplication syndrome primarily affects females with mild intellectual disability.
text 2: MECP2 duplication syndrome primarily affects males with severe intellectual disability.

text 1: Lack of functional FMRP is responsible for fragile X syndrome.
text 2: Excess functional FMRP is responsible for fragile X syndrome.

text 1: The major challenges in developing treatments for fragile X include producing excess FMRP.
text 2: The major challenges in developing treatments for fragile X include identifying clinical endpoints.

text 1: The MECP2 gene product binds to unmethylated cytosine bases in DNA, regulating gene expression.
text 2: The MECP2 gene product binds to methylated cytosine bases in DNA, regulating gene expression.

text 1: Williams syndrome occurs in 1 in 10,000 live births.
text 2: Williams syndrome occurs in 1 in 20,000 live births.

text 1: Loss of function of the UBE3A gene on the maternal chromosome leads to Angelman syndrome.
text 2: Loss of function of the UBE3A gene on the paternal chromosome leads to Angelman syndrome.

text 1: The neuromuscular junction abnormalities in myasthenia gravis include reduced numbers of ACh receptors.
text 2: The neuromuscular junction abnormalities in myasthenia gravis include increased numbers of ACh receptors.

text 1: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors worsen symptoms in myasthenia gravis by shortening the action of acetylcholine.

text 1: In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the first postsynaptic potential is abnormally large, but subsequent responses decrease in amplitude.

text 1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects only males as it is transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait.
text 2: Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects both males and females equally as it is transmitted as an X-linked recessive trait.

text 1: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by prominent limb weakness with little weakness of cranial muscles.
text 2: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by prominent cranial muscle weakness with little weakness of limb muscles.

text 1: Dermatomyositis is defined by three clinical features: rash, myopathy, and neuropathy.
text 2: Dermatomyositis is defined by two clinical features: rash and myopathy.

text 1: The mutations in the slow channel syndrome decrease the affinity of the nicotinic ACh receptor for acetylcholine.
text 2: The mutations in the slow channel syndrome increase the affinity of the nicotinic ACh receptor for acetylcholine.

text 1: In congenital myasthenia, the infant has an acquired defect in some component of the neuromuscular junction.
text 2: In congenital myasthenia, the infant has an inherited defect in some component of the neuromuscular junction.

text 1: The fast channel syndrome can respond to neither acetylcholinesterase inhibitors nor 3,4-diaminopyridine.
text 2: The fast channel syndrome can respond to either acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or 3,4-diaminopyridine.

text 1: Becker muscular dystrophy is typically more severe than Duchenne because dystrophin is absent entirely.
text 2: Becker muscular dystrophy is typically milder than Duchenne because dystrophin is present but may be abnormal.

text 1: Plasmapheresis involves filtering the plasma and can be beneficial for myasthenia gravis patients.
text 2: Plasmapheresis involves adding antibodies to the plasma and can be beneficial for myasthenia gravis patients.

text 1: In congenital myasthenia, end-plate currents are fast to decay, causing decreased muscle potential response.
text 2: In congenital myasthenia, end-plate currents are slow to decay, causing prolonged muscle potential response.

text 1: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is rarely associated with small-cell lung cancer.
text 2: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is often associated with small-cell lung cancer.

text 1: Dystrophin confers tensile strength to the muscle cell by linking it to the extracellular matrix.
text 2: Dystrophin confers tensile strength to the muscle cell by preventing it from linking to the extracellular matrix.

text 1: Botulinum toxin increases the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals, causing neuromuscular block.
text 2: Botulinum toxin impairs the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals, causing neuromuscular block.

text 1: Marmoset monkeys exhibit human-like pitch perception and can discriminate a missing fundamental in harmonic sounds with a precision as small as one semitone for periodicity above 440 Hz.
text 2: Marmoset monkeys exhibit human-like pitch perception and can discriminate a missing fundamental in harmonic sounds with a precision as small as one semitone for periodicity above 200 Hz.

text 1: The pitch-selective neurons in marmoset monkeys are located at the low-frequency border between A1 and the rostral auditory cortex (area R).

text 1: The perception of the missing fundamental remains robust despite the loss of some harmonic components.
text 2: The perception of the missing fundamental is highly fragile and becomes distorted with the loss of some harmonic components.

text 1: Human imaging studies have identified a region at the lateral end of Heschl’s gyrus that mirrors the pitch center location in marmoset monkeys.
text 2: Human imaging studies have identified a region at the medial end of Heschl’s gyrus that mirrors the pitch center location in marmoset monkeys.

text 1: Pitch-selective neurons in marmosets respond to pitch-evoking sounds like harmonic sounds and click trains.
text 2: Pitch-selective neurons in marmosets do not respond to pitch-evoking sounds like harmonic sounds and click trains.

text 1: Harmonic template neurons are distributed across A1 and R, covering the entire hearing range of marmosets, from approximately 1 kHz to 32 kHz.
text 2: Harmonic template neurons are confined to a narrow region of A1, covering only a range from approximately 1 kHz to 5 kHz.

text 1: Xiaoqin Wang and colleagues discovered pitch-selective neurons in marmosets about a decade ago.
text 2: Xiaoqin Wang and colleagues discovered pitch-selective neurons in marmosets two decades ago.

text 1: Pitch-selective neurons increase their firing rates as the behavioral salience of pitch increases.
text 2: Pitch-selective neurons decrease their firing rates as the behavioral salience of pitch increases.

text 1: The core regions of auditory cortex in marmosets also contain a class of harmonic template neurons.
text 2: The core regions of auditory cortex in marmosets contain only pitch-selective neurons, not harmonic template neurons.

text 1: Pitch is irrelevant to linguistic information in tonal languages such as Chinese.
text 2: Pitch carries crucial linguistic information in tonal languages such as Chinese.

text 1: Pitch allows harmonically structured periodic sounds to be perceived and ordered on a musical scale.
text 2: Pitch does not allow harmonically structured periodic sounds to be perceived and ordered on a musical scale.

text 1: Monkeys are capable of spectral pitch discrimination and melody recognition.
text 2: Monkeys are incapable of spectral pitch discrimination and melody recognition.

text 1: When listening to an orchestra, we hear the melody of the soloist over the background of accompanying instruments.
text 2: When listening to an orchestra, we cannot hear the melody of the soloist over the background of accompanying instruments.

text 1: Birds, cats, and monkeys can also pick out pitch like humans.
text 2: Birds, cats, and monkeys cannot pick out pitch like humans.

text 1: The slowing of the phase-locking limit along the ascending auditory pathway is necessary for auditory information integration in the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The slowing of the phase-locking limit along the ascending auditory pathway is irrelevant for auditory information integration in the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Nerve growth factor (NGF) binds to TrkA receptors on primary nociceptive terminals, reducing expression of ion channels that decrease nociceptor excitability.
text 2: Nerve growth factor (NGF) binds to TrkA receptors on primary nociceptive terminals, triggering upregulation in expression of ion channels that increase nociceptor excitability.

text 1: Retrograde transport of signaling endosomes suppresses expression of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).
text 2: Retrograde transport of signaling endosomes enhances expression of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).

text 1: Central sensitization increases pain thresholds (allodynia) and eliminates spontaneous pain in the absence of peripheral stimulation.
text 2: Central sensitization decreases pain thresholds (allodynia) and can lead to spontaneous pain in the absence of peripheral stimulation.

text 1: Peripheral nerve damage increases GABAergic inhibitory controls, reducing hyperactivity of nociceptive pathways in the dorsal horn.
text 2: Peripheral nerve damage decreases GABAergic inhibitory controls, exacerbating hyperactivity of nociceptive pathways in the dorsal horn.

text 1: Peripheral nerve injury activates microglia, which release mediators that reduce inhibitory controls exerted by GABAergic interneurons.
text 2: Peripheral nerve injury activates microglia, which release mediators that increase inhibitory controls exerted by GABAergic interneurons.

text 1: Mechanical allodynia can involve inappropriate engagement of dorsal horn nociceptive pathways by Aβ myelinated afferents.
text 2: Mechanical allodynia typically involves appropriate engagement of dorsal horn nociceptive pathways by uninjured nociceptors.

text 1: NMDA receptor activation in the dorsal horn contributes to central sensitization and increased excitability of dorsal horn neurons.
text 2: NMDA receptor activation in the dorsal horn reduces central sensitization and decreases excitability of dorsal horn neurons.

text 1: Activation of NK1 receptors by C fibers generates transient depolarization that inhibits central sensitization.

text 1: Elevation of residual Ca2+ in presynaptic terminals decreases the release of glutamate and substance P, reducing dorsal horn neuron excitability.

text 1: Activation of postsynaptic NMDA receptors in dorsal horn neurons results in long-lasting depolarization and increased neural excitability.

text 1: Second-messenger systems influenced by NK1 receptors enhance the performance of NMDA receptors during dorsal horn sensitization.

text 1: Peripheral nerve injury prevents engagement of dorsal horn projection neurons by Aβ afferents.

text 1: Microglial cell activation in the dorsal horn releases mediators that enhance excitability and reduce GABAergic inhibition.

text 1: The inability to mentalize, or 'mind blindness,' was first tested in children with autism using a simple puppet game, the Sally-Anne test.

text 1: The Sally-Anne test involves Sally putting a ball into her basket before leaving the room.

text 1: Children with Down syndrome typically pass the Sally-Anne test at a younger age than children with autism.

text 1: The superior temporal sulcus is involved in face processing.

text 1: Young children with ASD show poor appreciation of physical causes and events.

text 1: Autism Spectrum Disorder Phenotypes Also Share Distinctive Cognitive Abnormalities.

text 1: Variations of the Sally-Anne test have been used with children and adults with ASD since the early 1970s.

text 1: From birth, normal infants prefer to attend to people rather than other stimuli.

text 1: Insight into the mental state of others depends on the capacity to mentalize effortfully.

text 1: Neurogenesis in the adult brain was initially met with skepticism, but later confirmed with improved technologies.
