text 2: Adult-born neurons are generated in the olfactory bulb and migrate to the lateral ventricles.

text 1: Adult neurogenesis can be influenced by environmental factors such as enrichment and physical activity.
text 2: Adult neurogenesis is unaffected by environmental factors such as enrichment and physical activity.

text 1: New neurons in the adult brain are completely dissimilar to those born at embryonic stages.
text 2: New neurons in the adult brain are highly similar to those born at embryonic stages.

text 1: The generation of new neurons in adults is linked to certain behaviors mediated by the olfactory bulb and hippocampus.
text 2: The generation of new neurons in adults has no link to behaviors mediated by the olfactory bulb and hippocampus.

text 1: Joseph Altman discovered neurogenesis continues into adulthood in some parts of the mammalian brain in the 1960s.
text 2: Joseph Altman discovered neurogenesis stops completely before adulthood in all parts of the mammalian brain.

text 1: New neurons are added to the adult olfactory bulb but do not form functional circuits.
text 2: New neurons are added to the adult olfactory bulb and form functional circuits.

text 1: Stem cells are not the source of neurons in the adult, only in the embryo.
text 2: Stem cells are the source of neurons in the adult as well as the embryo.

text 1: In the hematopoietic system, a few stem cells can repopulate the entire adaptive immune system.
text 2: In the hematopoietic system, a few stem cells cannot repopulate the entire adaptive immune system.

text 1: Neuronal death is rare following neural insults such as stroke and neurodegenerative disease.
text 2: Neuronal death is a frequent consequence of neural insults such as stroke and neurodegenerative disease.

text 1: Transplantation of developing neurons into experimental animals has never shown promising results.
text 2: Transplantation of developing neurons into experimental animals has shown promising results in reversing effects of injury.

text 1: Stem cells in adulthood are derived from radial glia.
text 2: Stem cells in adulthood are not derived from radial glia.

text 1: Neurogenesis in adult animals can be decreased in models of depression and chronic stress.
text 2: Neurogenesis in adult animals remains unchanged in models of depression and chronic stress.

text 1: Neurons born at embryonic stages are never replaced by later-born neurons.
text 2: Neurons born at embryonic stages are gradually replaced by later-born neurons, maintaining their total number.

text 1: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the posterior portion of the left frontal lobe (Broca’s area) enhances language capabilities.
text 2: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the posterior portion of the left frontal lobe (Broca’s area) produces a specific deficit in language.

text 1: Episodic memory involves interactions between the occipital lobe and association cortices.
text 2: Episodic memory involves interactions between the medial temporal lobe and association cortices.

text 1: Operant conditioning involves associating a specific behavior with a reinforcing event.
text 2: Operant conditioning involves associating a specific behavior with a non-reinforcing event.

text 1: The Hippocampus supports episodic memory by building relational associations.
text 2: The Hippocampus disrupts episodic memory by breaking relational associations.

text 1: Short-term memory maintains transient representations of information relevant to immediate goals.
text 2: Short-term memory maintains permanent representations of information relevant to long-term goals.

text 1: Memory involves encoding, storage, retrieval, and consolidation.
text 2: Memory involves only encoding and retrieval, but not storage and consolidation.

text 1: Implicit memory supports a range of behaviors in humans and animals.
text 2: Implicit memory supports only a narrow range of behaviors specific to humans.

text 1: Short-term memory automatically transfers all information to long-term memory without selection.
text 2: Short-term memory is selectively transferred to long-term memory.

text 1: Errors and imperfections in memory have no relevance to understanding normal memory processes.
text 2: Errors and imperfections in memory shed light on normal memory processes.

text 1: Working memory consists of a single unified system for all types of information.
text 2: Working memory consists of at least two subsystems: one for verbal information and another for visuospatial information.

text 1: The medial temporal lobe is irrelevant for episodic long-term memory.
text 2: The medial temporal lobe is critical for episodic long-term memory.

text 1: Memory storage involves many different parts of the brain.
text 2: Memory storage is confined to a single part of the brain.

text 1: Phonological storage has no dependency on articulatory processes in Broca’s area.
text 2: Phonological storage partially depends on articulatory processes in Broca’s area.

text 1: Working memory involves activation of representations of information stored in specialized cortical regions.
text 2: Working memory functions independently of representations in specialized cortical regions.

text 1: Executive control processes in working memory do not interact with verbal or visuospatial subsystems.
text 2: Executive control processes in working memory allocate attentional resources to the verbal and visuospatial subsystems.

text 1: The relative proportion of hybrid fibers in a muscle increases with age.
text 2: The relative proportion of hybrid fibers in a muscle decreases with age.

text 1: Physical activity has little effect on the composition of a muscle's fibers.
text 2: Physical activity drastically changes the composition of a muscle's fibers.

text 1: Strength training can increase the size of type I fibers by 0% to 20%.
text 2: Strength training can decrease the size of type I fibers by 0% to 20%.

text 1: Endurance training increases the enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways.
text 2: Endurance training decreases the enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways.

text 1: Bed rest or limb immobilization decreases the size and intrinsic force capacity of muscle fibers.
text 2: Bed rest or limb immobilization increases the size and intrinsic force capacity of muscle fibers.

text 1: Space flight increases the proportion of type I fibers in some leg muscles.
text 2: Space flight reduces the proportion of type I fibers in some leg muscles.

text 1: The force exerted by a muscle during contraction depends on the number of motor units that are activated.
text 2: The force exerted by a muscle during contraction is independent of the number of motor units that are activated.

text 1: The order in which motor units are recruited is random and not determined by intrinsic factors.
text 2: The order in which motor units are recruited is determined by intrinsic differences in the responsiveness of individual motor neurons.

text 1: Recruitment of motor neurons follows the size principle, starting with the largest first.
text 2: Recruitment of motor neurons follows the size principle, starting with the smallest first.

text 1: Small motor neurons have a lower input resistance due to more ion channels.
text 2: Small motor neurons have a higher input resistance due to fewer ion channels.

text 1: Motor units in hand muscles are all recruited by about 60% of maximal voluntary contraction.
text 2: Motor units in hand muscles are all recruited by about 100% of maximal voluntary contraction.

text 1: In biceps brachii, deltoid, and tibialis anterior muscles, recruitment continues up to approximately 50% of maximal force.
text 2: In biceps brachii, deltoid, and tibialis anterior muscles, recruitment continues up to approximately 85% of maximal force.

text 1: Beyond the upper limit of motor unit recruitment, changes in muscle force depend on synaptic inputs.
text 2: Beyond the upper limit of motor unit recruitment, changes in muscle force depend on action potential rate.

text 1: Variation in discharge rate affects muscle force consistently at all force levels.
text 2: Variation in discharge rate affects muscle force more significantly except at low forces.

text 1: The size principle of motor neuron recruitment was enunciated by Elwood Henneman.
text 2: The size principle of motor neuron recruitment was enunciated by Edgar Adrian.

text 1: In the painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa, Tingarri instructors are depicted as horseshoe shapes and their young initiates as concentric circles.
text 2: In the painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa, Tingarri instructors are depicted as concentric circles and their young initiates as horseshoe shapes.

text 1: The painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa depicts the rainforest region of northern Australia.
text 2: The painting by Anatjari Tjampitjinpa depicts the sandhill country of the central Australian desert.

text 1: Circuits controlling the forelimb are located in the lumbar spinal cord.
text 2: Circuits controlling the forelimb are located in the cervical enlargement.

text 1: The core of the rhythm-generating circuits in rodents includes Shox2ON and Hb9 neurons.
text 2: The core of the rhythm-generating circuits in rodents includes V0D and V0V neurons.

text 1: The flexor-extensor alternation around the different joints is simultaneous.
text 2: The flexor-extensor alternation around the different joints is sequential.

text 1: V0V commissural neurons make up about half of the V0 population.
text 2: V0D commissural neurons make up about half of the V0 population.

text 1: Left–right alternation depends on crossed inhibition.
text 2: Left–right alternation depends on direct excitation.

text 1: The dual inhibitory system in left–right alternation includes V3 commissural neurons.
text 2: The dual inhibitory system in left–right alternation includes V0 commissural neurons.

text 1: V2a excitatory neurons are part of the left–right alternating circuit.
text 2: V2a excitatory neurons are part of the flexor-extensor circuit.

text 1: Proprioceptors include stretch-sensitive ligaments and Golgi tendon organs.
text 2: Proprioceptors include stretch-sensitive muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs.

text 1: The swing phase becomes shorter as the stepping rate increases.
text 2: The stance phase becomes shorter as the stepping rate increases.

text 1: Preventing hip extension in a limb suppresses stepping in that limb.
text 2: Preventing hip flexion in a limb suppresses stepping in that limb.

text 1: Activation of sensory fibers from Golgi tendon organs in hip flexor muscles prolongs the stance phase.
text 2: Activation of sensory fibers from Golgi tendon organs in ankle extensor muscles prolongs the stance phase.

text 1: The interlimb coordination pathways involve both inhibitory and excitatory intersegmental connections.
text 2: The interlimb coordination pathways involve only inhibitory intersegmental connections.

text 1: Flexor and extensor modules provide direct motor neuron inhibition in a reciprocal fashion.
text 2: Flexor and extensor modules provide direct motor neuron excitation in a reciprocal fashion.

text 1: V0 commissural neurons are crucial for left–right synchrony at all speeds of locomotion.
text 2: V0 commissural neurons are crucial for left–right alternation at all speeds of locomotion.

text 1: Separate excitatory non-V0 commissural neurons are responsible for synchrony in gaits such as bound and gallop.
text 2: Separate inhibitory non-V0 commissural neurons are responsible for synchrony in gaits such as bound and gallop.

text 1: The organ of Corti contains approximately 10,000 hair cells arrayed in four rows: two rows of inner hair cells and two rows of outer hair cells.
text 2: The organ of Corti contains approximately 16,000 hair cells arrayed in four rows: a single row of inner hair cells and three rows of outer hair cells.

text 1: The tectorial membrane is anchored at its base, and its tapered distal edge forms a fragile connection with the organ of Corti.
text 2: The tectorial membrane is not anchored at its base, and its tapered distal edge forms a rigid connection with the organ of Corti.

text 1: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by Deiters’s cells.
text 2: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by pillar cells.

text 1: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 20,000 afferent nerve fibers that carry information into the brain along the eighth cranial nerve.
text 2: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 30,000 afferent nerve fibers that carry information into the brain along the eighth cranial nerve.

text 1: Hair bundles comprise a few tens to a few thousand cylindrical processes called stereocilia.
text 2: Hair bundles comprise a few tens to a few hundred cylindrical processes called stereocilia.

text 1: The inner hair-cell bundles of the mammalian cochlea have a roughly linear form.
text 2: The inner hair-cell bundles of the mammalian cochlea have a roughly circular form.

text 1: Each stereocilium varies in diameter along most of its length, tapering just below its basal insertion.
text 2: Each stereocilium is of constant diameter along most of its length, tapering just above its basal insertion.

text 1: Hair cells are neurons and they have both dendrites and axons.
text 2: Hair cells are not neurons; they lack both dendrites and axons.

text 1: Deflection of the hair bundle toward its tall edge opens additional channels, thereby depolarizing the cell.
text 2: Deflection of the hair bundle toward its short edge opens additional channels, thereby depolarizing the cell.

text 1: The logarithm of the frequency increases roughly in proportion to the distance from the cochlea’s base.
text 2: The logarithm of the frequency decreases roughly in proportion to the distance from the cochlea’s base.

text 1: The electrical properties of the cochlear partition as a whole determine the dispersion of sound's frequency components along the cochlea’s longitudinal axis.
text 2: The mechanical properties of the cochlear partition as a whole determine the dispersion of sound's frequency components along the cochlea’s longitudinal axis.

text 1: Afferent and efferent nerve endings contact the apical surface of the plasma membrane.
text 2: Afferent and efferent nerve endings contact the basolateral surface of the plasma membrane.

text 1: Outer hair-cell bundles have a V or W shape.
text 2: Outer hair-cell bundles have a linear shape.

text 1: In an unstimulated cell, 0% of the channels involved in stimulus transduction are open.
text 2: In an unstimulated cell, 10% to 50% of the channels involved in stimulus transduction are open.

text 1: Each stereocilium consists of a fascicle of collagen filaments heavily cross-linked by proteins plastin, fascin, and epsin.
text 2: Each stereocilium consists of a fascicle of actin filaments heavily cross-linked by proteins plastin, fascin, and epsin.

text 1: Fibers from the nasal hemiretina cross to the opposite hemisphere at the optic chiasm.
text 2: Fibers from the nasal hemiretina stay on the same side at the optic chiasm.

text 1: A lesion of the optic chiasm causes a loss of vision in the temporal half of each visual hemifield (bitemporal hemianopsia).
text 2: A lesion of the optic chiasm causes a loss of vision in the nasal half of each visual hemifield (binasal hemianopsia).

text 1: A lesion of the optic tract causes a loss of vision in the same half of the visual hemifield (ipsilateral hemianopsia).
text 2: A lesion of the optic tract causes a loss of vision in the opposite half of the visual hemifield (contralateral hemianopsia).

text 1: Cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus send their axons directly to the frontal cortex.
text 2: Cells in the lateral geniculate nucleus send their axons along the optic radiation to the primary visual cortex.

text 1: The dorsal pathway is concerned with object recognition.
text 2: The dorsal pathway is concerned with visually guided movement.

text 1: The primary visual cortex in each hemisphere represents slightly more than half the visual field.
text 2: The primary visual cortex in each hemisphere represents less than one-quarter of the visual field.

text 1: A major fiber bundle called the corpus callosum connects the two hemispheres.
text 2: A major fiber bundle called the optic nerve connects the two hemispheres.

text 1: The ventral pathway is concerned with object recognition.
text 2: The ventral pathway is concerned with pupil dilation.

text 1: The superior colliculus is involved in eye movement.
text 2: The superior colliculus is involved in auditory processing.

text 1: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is incapable of establishing homologies between primate visual areas.
text 2: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has helped to establish homologies between the visual areas of the macaque and human brains.

text 1: Functional streams in visual processing were appreciated based on pathway tracing studies in monkeys.
text 2: Functional streams in visual processing were dismissed based on pathway tracing studies in monkeys.

text 1: The visual areas of cortex are identical and cannot be differentiated by the functional properties of their neurons.
text 2: The visual areas of cortex can be differentiated by the functional properties of their neurons.

text 1: A lesion in the upper bank of the calcarine sulcus causes a partial deficit in the superior quadrant.
text 2: A lesion in the upper bank of the calcarine sulcus causes a partial deficit in the inferior quadrant.

text 1: Macacque monkeys have more than 30 areas involved with vision.
text 2: Macakque monkeys have only 10 areas involved with vision.

text 1: Light signals are relayed through the midbrain pretectum in the pupillary reflex.
text 2: Light signals are directly processed in the frontal cortex in the pupillary reflex.

text 1: The visual system calculates the brightness of surfaces from information about uniform brightness within the surfaces.
text 2: The visual system calculates the brightness of surfaces from information about contrast at the edges of surfaces.

text 1: Some neurons in V4 respond similarly to different illumination wavelengths if the perceived color remains constant.
text 2: Some neurons in V4 only respond to varying illumination wavelengths regardless of perceived color consistency.

text 1: The visual system assumes that illumination comes from below.
text 2: The visual system assumes that illumination comes from above.

text 1: A plaid pattern moving in a single direction is perceived when gratings are superimposed and moved independently in different directions.
text 2: Gratings are perceived to slide past each other when superimposed and moved independently in different directions.

text 1: The responses of some neurons in the visual cortex correlate with perceived brightness.
text 2: The responses of all neurons in the visual cortex solely depend on surface boundaries, not perceived brightness.

text 1: The barber-pole illusion is influenced by scene segmentation cues.
text 2: The barber-pole illusion is unaffected by scene segmentation cues and relies only on local motion.

text 1: Under most conditions, we do not perceive the object itself to be changing even as the retinal image of an object changes.
text 2: Under most conditions, we perceive the object itself to be changing whenever the retinal image changes.

text 1: Contextual influences are pervasive in intermediate-level visual processing.
text 2: Contextual influences have minimal impact on intermediate-level visual processing.

text 1: To identify an object, we must know the properties of its surface rather than those of the reflected light.
text 2: Identifying an object requires knowing the properties of the reflected light rather than its surface.

text 1: Perceptual fill-in occurs when neurons maintain distinct responses for boundaries and surrounding area without changes.
text 2: Perceptual fill-in happens when neurons with receptive fields within a disk begin to respond in a fashion similar to those with receptive fields in the surrounding area.

text 1: Motion perception is determined only by local motion signals, independent of scene segmentation cues.
text 2: Motion perception is influenced by the scene's segmentation cues.

text 1: No neurons respond to the interiors of surfaces; they only signal boundaries.
text 2: Some neurons do respond to the interiors of surfaces, signaling local brightness, texture, or color.

text 1: Gratings can test whether a neuron is sensitive to local or global motion signals.
text 2: Gratings provide no information about a neuron's sensitivity to motion signals.

text 1: Our ability to perceive an object's size and color as constant illustrates a fundamental principle of the visual system.
text 2: The visual system passively records images like a camera but often misperceives size and color.

text 1: Brightness perception is primarily unaffected by three-dimensional shape.
text 2: Brightness perception is influenced by three-dimensional shape.

text 1: Delay-period activity in the inferior temporal cortex is associated with long-term storage of auditory patterns and color information.
text 2: Delay-period activity in the inferior temporal cortex is associated with short-term storage of visual patterns and color information.

text 1: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex encode the spatial properties of the expected object from the beginning.
text 2: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex initially encode the sensory properties of the sample object and later encode the expected associated object.

text 1: Thomas Albright and colleagues trained monkeys to associate pairs of objects that had no prior relatedness.
text 2: Thomas Albright and colleagues trained monkeys using objects that had an inherent physical relatedness.

text 1: The visual paired-association task is identical to the delayed match-to-sample task because the match and cue are the same stimuli.
text 2: The visual paired-association task differs from delayed match-to-sample because the match and cue are two different stimuli.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral prefrontal cortex show category-specific responses.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral prefrontal cortex do not show any category-specific responses.

text 1: The delayed-response task does not require remembering information during a delay.
text 2: The delayed-response task requires a specific response based on remembered information during a brief delay.

text 1: Activity in the inferior temporal cortex can be eliminated by the appearance of another image.
text 2: Activity in the inferior temporal cortex remains unchanged regardless of new images appearing.

text 1: Earl Miller's experiments showed no change in delay-period activity based on tasks in the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Earl Miller's experiments demonstrated task-dependent delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex.

text 1: Visual information is maintained in short-term working memory by ongoing neuronal firing.
text 2: Visual information is maintained in short-term working memory without any neuronal activity.

text 1: Monkeys were trained to categorize images based on 20% or more features of an animal.
text 2: Monkeys were trained to categorize images as cat or dog if they had 50% or more features of that animal.

text 1: Peristimulus time histograms show no neuronal responses to visual stimuli.
text 2: Peristimulus time histograms show neuronal responses to visual stimuli.

text 1: Delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex is unrelated to the recall of long-term memories.
text 2: Delay-period activity in the prefrontal cortex may be involved in the recall of long-term memories.

text 1: The visual paired-association task involves associating nonidentical stimuli through learning.
text 2: The visual paired-association task involves associating identical stimuli through learning.

text 1: Inferior temporal neurons respond indiscriminately to all objects.
text 2: Inferior temporal neurons respond selectively to familiar objects.

text 1: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex may generate top-down signals to the inferior temporal cortex.
text 2: Neurons in the prefrontal cortex do not interact with the inferior temporal cortex.

text 1: Yu FH and Catterall WA provided an overview of the calcium channel family in Genome Biology in 2003.
text 2: Yu FH and Catterall WA provided an overview of the voltage-gated sodium channel family in Genome Biology in 2003.

text 2: Sigworth FJ and Neher E observed single Na+ channel currents in cultured rat muscle cells in Nature in 1980.

text 2: Pan X, Li Z, Zhou Q, et al. studied the structure of the human voltage-gated sodium channel Na(v)1.4 in complex with β1 in Science in 2018.

text 2: Puopolo M, Raviola E, and Bean BP studied roles of subthreshold potassium current and sodium current in spontaneous firing of mouse midbrain dopamine neurons in 2007.

text 2: Tai C, Abe Y, Westenbroek RE, Scheuer T, and Catterall WA studied impaired excitability of astrocytes in a mouse model of Dravet syndrome in 2014.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) have been extensively studied for their role in representing decision variables during decision-making processes.
text 2: Neurons in the motor cortex have been extensively studied for their role in representing decision variables during decision-making processes.

text 1: The accumulation of evidence in the decision-making process can resemble a drift-diffusion process.
text 2: The accumulation of evidence in the decision-making process cannot resemble a drift-diffusion process.

text 1: The bounded accumulation framework suggests that the brain does not terminate decisions when accumulated evidence reaches a threshold.
text 2: The bounded accumulation framework suggests that the brain terminates decisions when accumulated evidence reaches a threshold.

text 1: The decision variable in perceptual decision-making is an accumulation of signal only.
text 2: The decision variable in perceptual decision-making is an accumulation of both signal and noise.

text 1: Persistent neural activity has only been observed in the frontal lobe.
text 2: Persistent neural activity has been observed in both the frontal lobe and the motor cortex.

text 1: The flutter-vibration task demonstrates that the persistent neural activity can represent sensory qualities, such as the vibration frequency of the reference stimulus.
text 2: The flutter-vibration task demonstrates that the persistent neural activity cannot represent sensory qualities, such as the vibration frequency of the reference stimulus.

text 1: Random dot motion tasks highlight the role of persistent neural activity in accumulating evidence for decisions.
text 2: Random dot motion tasks do not highlight the role of persistent neural activity in accumulating evidence for decisions.

text 1: The process of evidence accumulation for decision-making is never noisy and cannot be anticorrelated between competing choices.
text 2: The process of evidence accumulation for decision-making is often noisy and can be anticorrelated between competing choices.

text 1: Studies by Romo in the prefrontal cortex have shown neurons respond immediately without any graded manner to flutter-vibration stimuli.
text 2: Studies by Romo in the prefrontal cortex have shown neurons respond persistently and in a graded manner to flutter-vibration stimuli.

text 1: Gradual increase in neuron firing rates often indicates accumulation of evidence for one choice over the other in decision-making.
text 2: Gradual increase in neuron firing rates does not indicate accumulation of evidence for one choice over the other in decision-making.

text 1: Neurons representing evolving decisions start at a common firing rate level and change as more evidence is acquired.
text 2: Neurons representing evolving decisions do not start at a common firing rate level and do not change as more evidence is acquired.

text 1: Romo found that neurons in the prefrontal cortex respond during the delay period while the monkey awaited a second stimulus.
text 2: Romo found that neurons in the parietal cortex respond during the delay period while the monkey awaited a second stimulus.

text 1: Fluctuations in neuronal response can indicate the variability of evidence being accumulated.
text 2: Fluctuations in neuronal response do not indicate the variability of evidence being accumulated.

text 1: The striatum is a proposed candidate for where the threshold operation is applied in decision-making processes.
text 2: The cerebellum is a proposed candidate for where the threshold operation is applied in decision-making processes.

text 1: Persistent neural activity in the brain is thought to involve working memory as well as decision-making.
text 2: Persistent neural activity in the brain is thought not to involve working memory but only decision-making.

text 1: The decision process in perceptual tasks is an accumulation of both signal and noise represented by neuronal firing rates.
text 2: The decision process in perceptual tasks is only an accumulation of signal represented by neuronal firing rates.

text 1: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from the production of antibodies that bind to the intracellular domain of the ACh receptor.
text 2: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from the production of antibodies that bind to the extracellular domain of the ACh receptor.

text 1: In the neuronal ACh receptor, two α-subunits combine with three β-subunits to form the pentamer.
text 2: In the neuronal ACh receptor, one α-subunit combines with four β-subunits to form the pentamer.

text 1: Each α-subunit binds two molecules of nicotine at a site located at the interface with a neighboring γ-subunit.
text 2: Each α-subunit binds one molecule of nicotine at a site located at the interface with a neighboring β-subunit.

text 1: The M2 segment of each subunit forms the lining of the pore.
text 2: The M3 segment of each subunit forms the lining of the pore.

text 1: The high-resolution X-ray crystal structure model of a human neuronal nicotinic ACh receptor-channel is reproduced with permission from Morales-Perez et al. 2018.
text 2: The high-resolution X-ray crystal structure model of a human neuronal nicotinic ACh receptor-channel is reproduced with permission from Morales-Perez et al. 2016.

text 1: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis leads to a decrease in the number or function of the nicotinic ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
text 2: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis leads to an increase in the number or function of the nicotinic ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

text 1: The pore of the ACh receptor gradually widens within the bilayer of the membrane.
text 2: The pore of the ACh receptor gradually narrows within the bilayer of the membrane.

text 1: The extracellular region of the receptor-channel is approximately 3 nm in length.
text 2: The extracellular region of the receptor-channel is approximately 6 nm in length.

text 1: Negatively charged amino acids on each subunit form three rings of negative charge around the pore.
text 2: Positively charged amino acids on each subunit form three rings of positive charge around the pore.

text 1: Binding of ligand is thought to promote the closure of the cleft between neighboring subunits.
text 2: Binding of ligand is thought to promote the opening of the cleft between neighboring subunits.

text 1: A mutation in an amino acid residue in the M2 segment leads to a prolonged channel open time.
text 2: A mutation in an amino acid residue in the M1 segment leads to a prolonged channel open time.

text 1: The desensitized state of the neuronal nicotinic receptor has M2 segments that form a narrow constriction near the intracellular side of the membrane.
text 2: The desensitized state of the neuronal nicotinic receptor has M3 segments that form a narrow constriction near the intracellular side of the membrane.

text 1: The pore diameter in the open state is approximately 0.6 nm based on electrophysiological measurements.
text 2: The pore diameter in the open state is approximately 1 nm based on electrophysiological measurements.

text 1: The hydrophobic constriction is thought to provide a high-energy barrier that restricts the passage of hydrated cations.
text 2: The hydrophilic constriction is thought to provide a low-energy barrier that restricts the passage of hydrated cations.

text 1: Nicotine binds to the receptor-channel at the interface with neighboring β-subunits in neuronal receptors.
text 2: Nicotine binds to the receptor-channel at the interface with neighboring γ-subunits in neuronal receptors.

text 1: Each hemisphere of the brain is primarily concerned with sensory and motor processes on the contralateral side of the body.
text 2: Each hemisphere of the brain is primarily concerned with sensory and motor processes on the ipsilateral side of the body.

text 1: The crests of the convolutions in the brain's cortex are called gyri, and the grooves are called sulci or fissures.
text 2: The grooves in the brain's cortex are called gyri, and the crests are called sulci or fissures.

text 1: Broca's area, related to speech production, is located in the left frontal lobe.
text 2: Broca's area, related to speech production, is located in the right frontal lobe.

text 1: Wernicke's area processes visual input for language and is important for understanding speech.
text 2: Wernicke's area processes auditory input for language and is important for understanding speech.

text 1: In Broca's aphasia, a patient can understand language but cannot speak grammatically.
text 2: In Broca's aphasia, a patient cannot understand language but can speak fluently.

text 1: The central sulcus unites the precentral gyrus with the postcentral gyrus.
text 2: The central sulcus separates the precentral gyrus from the postcentral gyrus.

text 1: The frontal lobe is involved in planning future actions and control of movement.
text 2: The frontal lobe is primarily involved in processing auditory information and memory recall.

text 1: The temporal lobe is responsible for the recognition of objects and faces.
text 2: The occipital lobe is responsible for the recognition of objects and faces.

text 1: Conduction aphasia occurs when the arcuate fasciculus is destroyed.
text 2: Conduction aphasia occurs when Broca's area is destroyed.

text 1: In conduction aphasia, patients cannot form coherent words or sentences at all.
text 2: In conduction aphasia, patients understand spoken and written language but struggle to repeat it.

text 1: Broca founded neuropsychology as an empirical science distinct from phrenology.
text 2: Broca founded phrenology as an empirical science distinct from neuropsychology.

text 1: Area 17 in Brodmann's classification corresponds to the motor cortex, which controls voluntary movement.
text 2: Area 4 in Brodmann's classification corresponds to the motor cortex, which controls voluntary movement.

text 1: Karl Wernicke described a type of aphasia characterized by a failure of comprehension rather than expression.
text 2: Karl Wernicke described an aphasia where patients can understand language perfectly but cannot speak comprehensibly.

text 1: Brodmann's cortical localization method distinguished areas by cell shapes and layered arrangements.
text 2: Brodmann's cortical localization method distinguished areas by cell shapes and neuronal connectivity patterns.

text 1: The parietal lobe forms a body image and relates it to extrapersonal space.
text 2: The occipital lobe forms a body image and relates it to extrapersonal space.

text 1: The thalamus acts as a passive relay station for information to the cerebral cortex, transmitting all sensory data without alteration.
text 2: The thalamus acts as a gatekeeper for information to the cerebral cortex, preventing or enhancing the passage of specific information depending on the behavioral state of the organism.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus project to the primary visual cortex.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus project to the primary auditory cortex.

text 1: The thalamic reticular nucleus is made up almost totally of inhibitory neurons that synapse onto the relay cells and does not project to the neocortex.
text 2: The thalamic reticular nucleus is made up almost totally of excitatory neurons that synapse onto the relay cells and projects to the neocortex.

text 1: Each of the sensory systems, including olfaction, has a similar processing step within a distinct region of the thalamus.
text 2: Each of the sensory systems, except olfaction, has a similar processing step within a distinct region of the thalamus.

text 1: Somatosensory information is conveyed from dorsal root ganglia directly to the primary motor cortex.
text 2: Somatosensory information is conveyed from dorsal root ganglia to the ventral posterior lateral nucleus and from there to the primary somatosensory cortex.

text 1: The anterior group of thalamic nuclei is thought to be related to memory and emotion.
text 2: The anterior group of thalamic nuclei is primarily involved in direct sensory relay.

text 1: The ventral posterior nuclei convey olfactory information to the neocortex.
text 2: The ventral posterior nuclei convey somatosensory information to the neocortex.

text 1: The medial geniculate nucleus is a component of the auditory system.
text 2: The medial geniculate nucleus is mainly involved in visual processing.

text 1: The pulvinar is primarily connected only with the frontal lobe.
text 2: The pulvinar is extensively interconnected with widespread regions of the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.

text 1: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei are responsible for processing visual information.
text 2: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei are important for motor control and carry information to the motor cortex.

text 1: The reticular nucleus provides output directly to the primary auditory cortex.
text 2: The reticular nucleus receives input from axons leaving the thalamus en route to the neocortex.

text 1: The thalamic nuclei do not receive any feedback projections from the neocortex.
text 2: The thalamic nuclei receive extensive feedback projections back from the neocortex.

text 1: The lateral geniculate nucleus receives information exclusively from the auditory system.
text 2: The lateral geniculate nucleus receives information from the retina.

text 1: The pulvinar is disproportionately enlarged in the human brain compared to rodents.
text 2: The pulvinar is smaller in the human brain compared to rodents.

text 1: The thalamus is a passive relay station where information is simply passed on to the neocortex.
text 2: The thalamus is an important step in the hierarchy of sensory processing and is not a passive relay station.

text 1: Cholinergic neurons are divided into ventrolateral and dorsomedial clusters in the mesopontine region.
text 2: Cholinergic neurons are divided into ventromedial and dorsolateral clusters in the mesopontine region.

text 1: Dopaminergic neurons found in the olfactory bulb are classified as A16.
text 2: Dopaminergic neurons found in the olfactory bulb are classified as A14.

text 1: The A8 and A10 dopaminergic cell groups play a key role in the initiation of movement.
text 2: The A8 and A9 dopaminergic cell groups play a key role in the initiation of movement.

text 1: The A10 group of neurons is located in the ventral tegmental area and projects to the frontal and temporal cortex.
text 2: The A10 group of neurons is located in the dorsolateral tegmental area and projects to the parietal and occipital cortex.

text 1: Monoaminergic neurons typically have irregular firing patterns regulated by intrinsic burst currents.
text 2: Monoaminergic neurons typically have spontaneous regular firing patterns regulated by intrinsic pacemaker currents.

text 1: The basal ganglia depend on continuous serotonin exposure to facilitate motor responses.
text 2: The basal ganglia depend on continuous dopamine exposure to facilitate motor responses.

text 1: Serotonin regulates renal filtration and hepatic metabolism.
text 2: Serotonin regulates cardiovascular control and gastrointestinal peristalsis.

text 1: Serotonergic neurons are involved in the response to a rise in O2 levels.
text 2: Serotonergic neurons are involved in the response to a rise in CO2 levels.

text 1: Histaminergic cell groups are mainly found in the thalamic nucleus.
text 2: Histaminergic cell groups are mainly found in the tuberomammillary nucleus.

text 1: The E1-E5 histaminergic cell groups are a minor source of histamine in the brain.
text 2: The E1-E5 histaminergic cell groups are the sole source of histamine in the brain.

text 1: Dopaminergic neurons project to the hippocampus and play an important role in movement initiation.
text 2: Dopaminergic neurons project to the striatum and play an important role in movement initiation.

text 1: Serotonin has complex functions due to at least 14 different serotonin receptors.
text 2: Serotonin has complex functions due to at least 10 different serotonin receptors.

text 1: The A11 and A14 cell groups are located in the zona incerta of the hypothalamus.
text 2: The A11 and A13 cell groups are located in the zona incerta of the hypothalamus.

text 1: Acetylcholine neurons in the pons project to the brain stem reticular formation and thalamus.
text 2: Acetylcholine neurons in the pons project to the cerebral cortex and hippocampus.

text 1: The basal forebrain cholinergic neurons play an important role in arousal and selective attention.
text 2: The basolateral cholinergic neurons play an important role in arousal and selective attention.

text 1: Deficiencies of vitamin A can lead to night blindness and eventually to blindness if untreated.
text 2: Deficiencies of vitamin B can lead to night blindness and eventually to blindness if untreated.

text 1: The brain’s comparison of signals from different rod types is the basis for color vision.
text 2: The brain’s comparison of signals from different cone types is the basis for color vision.

text 1: Activated rhodopsin in the form of metarhodopsin II diffuses within the disc membrane to encounter melanopsin.
text 2: Activated rhodopsin in the form of metarhodopsin II diffuses within the disc membrane to encounter transducin.

text 1: In darkness, when the cGMP concentration is high, a sizeable K+ influx maintains the cell at a depolarized level of approximately –40 mV.
text 2: In darkness, when the cGMP concentration is high, a sizeable Na+ influx maintains the cell at a depolarized level of approximately –40 mV.

text 1: Stationary night blindness results when rod function has been lost but cone function remains intact.
text 2: Stationary night blindness results when cone function has been lost but rod function remains intact.

text 1: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes spatial constancy in stimuli.
text 2: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes temporal changes in stimuli.

text 1: In night vision, only the rods are active, so all functional photoreceptors have the same absorption spectrum.
text 2: In night vision, only the cones are active, so all functional photoreceptors have the same absorption spectrum.

text 1: Excited rhodopsin activates a phosphodiesterase through the protein melanopsin.
text 2: Excited rhodopsin activates a phosphodiesterase through the G protein transducin.

text 1: Each phosphodiesterase molecule can hydrolyze more than 1,000 molecules of ATP per second.
text 2: Each phosphodiesterase molecule can hydrolyze more than 1,000 molecules of cGMP per second.

text 1: Rod cells transmit neural images to the brain through the optic nerve.
text 2: Ganglion cells transmit neural images to the brain through the optic nerve.

text 1: The ganglion cell layer produces a relatively simple neural representation of the visual scene.
text 2: The photoreceptor layer produces a relatively simple neural representation of the visual scene.

text 1: In a single-photoreceptor system, a green light has the same effect on the visual system as a red light of greater intensity.
text 2: In a single-photoreceptor system, a blue light has the same effect on the visual system as a yellow light of greater intensity.

text 1: M-cells have faster and more transient responses than P-cells.
text 2: P-cells have faster and more transient responses than M-cells.

text 1: Active transducin (Tα-GTP) has an intrinsic ATPase activity.
text 2: Active transducin (Tα-GTP) has an intrinsic GTPase activity.

text 1: Retinal processing extracts high-level features of the scene useful for guiding behavior.
text 2: Retinal processing extracts low-level features of the scene useful for guiding behavior.

text 1: The 22q11.2 microdeletion accounts for approximately 10% of patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.
text 2: The 22q11.2 microdeletion accounts for approximately 1% of patients diagnosed with schizophrenia.

text 1: Individuals with the 22q.11.2 microdeletion have a 5% to 10% risk of schizophrenia and a 50% risk of autism.
text 2: Individuals with the 22q.11.2 microdeletion have a 25% to 40% risk of schizophrenia and a 20% risk of autism.

text 1: The best replicated finding in schizophrenia is an increase of gray matter in prefrontal, temporal, and parietal regions with counterbalancing decreases in the size of the cerebral ventricles.
text 2: The best replicated finding in schizophrenia is the loss of gray matter in prefrontal, temporal, and parietal regions with counterbalancing increases in the size of the cerebral ventricles.

text 1: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from cell death rather than loss of synaptic contacts.
text 2: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from loss of synaptic contacts rather than loss of cells.

text 1: Functional neuroimaging has demonstrated that patients' deficits in working memory tasks are associated with increased activation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Functional neuroimaging has demonstrated that patients' deficits in working memory tasks are associated with decrements in activation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

text 1: Abnormalities in the brain's connectivity are characterized by enhanced connections between brain regions in schizophrenia.
text 2: Abnormalities in the brain's connectivity are characterized by disruptions between brain regions in schizophrenia.

text 1: Postmortem studies have shown that gray matter loss in schizophrenia is due to a reduction in glial cells.
text 2: Postmortem studies have shown that gray matter loss in schizophrenia is due to a reduction in dendritic processes.

text 1: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia often exhibit more gray matter loss than those diagnosed with schizophrenia.
text 2: First-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia often exhibit gray matter loss intermediate between healthy individuals and those diagnosed with schizophrenia.

text 1: Genes identified through genetic studies of schizophrenia can inform the development of therapeutic drugs.
text 2: Genes identified through genetic studies of schizophrenia have no impact on the development of therapeutic drugs.

text 1: Polygenic risk scores have no utility in stratifying populations by genetic susceptibility to schizophrenia.
text 2: Polygenic risk scores provide probabilistic information and can help stratify populations by genetic susceptibility to schizophrenia.

text 1: Loss of gray matter in schizophrenia is primarily due to widespread cell death.
text 2: Loss of gray matter in schizophrenia is not associated with cell death but is linked to a reduction in synaptic connections.

text 1: The potential to study individuals carrying penetrant mutations offers insights into the biology of psychosis.
text 2: The potential to study individuals carrying penetrant mutations has no insights to offer into the biology of psychosis.

text 1: Environmental factors associated with schizophrenia include nutrient deprivation in utero and season of birth.
text 2: Environmental factors associated with schizophrenia include nutrient excess in utero and summer season of birth.

text 1: Syndromic forms of schizophrenia provide important windows into the biology of psychosis.
text 2: Syndromic forms of schizophrenia do not provide any insights into the biology of psychosis.

text 1: Monozygotic twins with schizophrenia have been found to show disease-specific cortical thinning.
text 2: Monozygotic twins with schizophrenia have been found to show an increase in cortical thickness.

text 1: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to test the hypothesis that in patients with schizophrenia working memory engages circuits in the prefrontal cortex differently than in controls.
text 2: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to test the hypothesis that in patients with schizophrenia working memory engages circuits in the occipital cortex differently than in controls.

text 1: The greater demand on working memory requires greater activation of occipital cortical circuits.
text 2: The greater demand on working memory requires greater activation of prefrontal cortical circuits.

text 1: Activity in the parietal cortex of two groups—patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls—was examined while subjects performed a working memory task.
text 2: Activity in the prefrontal cortex of two groups—patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls—was examined while subjects performed a working memory task.

text 1: Brain regions that showed statistically significant reductions in functional connectivity in patients compared to controls are highlighted in red.
text 2: Brain regions that showed statistically significant increases in functional connectivity in patients compared to controls are highlighted in red.

text 1: Unbiased, large-scale genetic studies have found that the strongest association with risk for schizophrenia lies within the major histocompatibility (MHC) locus on chromosome 6.
text 2: Unbiased, large-scale genetic studies have found that the strongest association with risk for schizophrenia lies within the mitochondrial DNA.

text 1: The complement system in the brain strengthens weak or inefficient synapses.
text 2: The complement system in the brain tags weak or inefficient synapses for removal by microglia.

text 1: All current antipsychotic drugs produce their therapeutic effects by blocking D2 dopamine receptors in the forebrain.
text 2: All current antipsychotic drugs produce their therapeutic effects by blocking serotonin receptors.

text 1: Complement factor C4, a component of the complement cascade, is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.
text 2: Complement factor C4, a component of the complement cascade, is synthesized by neurons and astrocytes.

text 1: Elevated expression of the complement factor C4A involved in synaptic pruning is one of the mechanisms leading to schizophrenia.
text 2: Elevated expression of the complement factor C4A involved in synaptic strengthening is one of the mechanisms leading to schizophrenia.

text 1: Overpruning of synapses during adolescence is one plausible mechanism that should be explored further in studies of youth at high risk for schizophrenia.
text 2: Underpruning of synapses during adolescence is one plausible mechanism that should be explored further in studies of youth at high risk for schizophrenia.

text 1: Increased expression in the brain of C4B is associated with a higher risk for schizophrenia.
text 2: Increased expression in the brain of C4A is associated with a higher risk for schizophrenia.

text 1: Variants within the MHC locus that give rise to high levels of C4A expression in brain increase schizophrenia risk.
text 2: Variants within the MHC locus that give rise to low levels of C4A expression in brain increase schizophrenia risk.

text 1: Photomicrographs of pyramidal neurons from the cerebral cortex show the morphology of layer V pyramidal neurons.
text 2: Photomicrographs of pyramidal neurons from the cerebral cortex show the morphology of layer III pyramidal neurons.

text 1: Antipsychotic drugs act by enhancing dopamine receptor activity in the brain.
text 2: Antipsychotic drugs act by blocking D2 dopamine receptors in the brain.

text 1: The complement factor C4 is associated with the blood clotting cascade which is involved in synaptic pruning.
text 2: The complement factor C4 is associated with the complement cascade which is involved in synaptic pruning.

text 1: Mirror neurons discharge only when the monkey actively grasps objects and not when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.
text 2: Mirror neurons discharge both when the monkey actively grasps objects and when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.

text 1: During motor action with 'mixed' objects, few neurons in PMv and M1 display a strong dependence on different grasping actions.
text 2: During motor action with 'mixed' objects, many neurons in PMv and M1 display a strong dependence on different grasping actions.

text 1: Acetylcholine (ACh) is released at all vertebrate neuromuscular junctions by spinal motor neurons.
text 2: Acetylcholine (ACh) is released at vertebrate neuromuscular junctions predominantly by sensory neurons.

text 1: Otto Loewi demonstrated that stimulation of the adrenal gland terminals in frog hearts released 'vagustoff,' later identified as ACh.
text 2: Otto Loewi demonstrated that stimulation of the vagus nerve terminals in frog hearts released 'vagustoff,' later identified as ACh.

text 1: Neuropeptides are processed in mitochondria and packaged in large dense-core vesicles approximately 70–250 nm in diameter.
text 2: Neuropeptides are processed in the Golgi apparatus and packaged in large dense-core vesicles approximately 70–250 nm in diameter.

text 1: Large dense-core vesicles contain both catecholamines and neuroactive peptides and do not undergo local recycling after fusion with the plasma membrane.
text 2: Large dense-core vesicles only contain catecholamines and undergo local recycling after fusion with the plasma membrane.

text 1: Acetylcholine is released only by sympathetic postganglionic neurons in the autonomic nervous system.
text 2: Acetylcholine is released by all preganglionic neurons in the autonomic nervous system and by parasympathetic postganglionic neurons.

text 1: Small synaptic vesicles are characteristic of neurons that use ACh, glutamate, GABA, and glycine as transmitters.
text 2: Small synaptic vesicles are characteristic of neurons that use serotonin and dopamine as transmitters.

text 1: Many small-molecule substances act as classical neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, glutamate, GABA, glycine, and melatonin.
text 2: Only a few small-molecule substances act as classical neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine, glutamate, GABA, glycine, and ATP.

text 1: Neurotransmitters can activate autoreceptors on postsynaptic neurons to inhibit transmitter synthesis.
text 2: Neurotransmitters can activate autoreceptors on the presynaptic neuron that modulate further transmitter release or synthesis.

text 1: Astrocytes and microglia can synthesize, store, and release neurotransmitters, as well as express receptors that modulate their function.
text 2: Astrocytes and microglia only store and release neurotransmitters but do not synthesize them.

text 1: Dale and Loewi shared the Nobel Prize in 1956 for their work on neurotransmitter discoveries.
text 2: Dale and Loewi shared the Nobel Prize in 1946 for their work on neurotransmitter discoveries.

text 1: The chromaffin vesicles of the adrenal gland were named due to their reaction with mercury and were shown to accumulate neurotransmitters like epinephrine.
text 2: The chromaffin vesicles of the adrenal gland were named due to their reaction with chromate and were shown to accumulate neurotransmitters like epinephrine.

text 1: Classical neurotransmitters are removed from extracellular environments solely through synaptic clefts.
text 2: Classical neurotransmitters are removed from the extracellular environment through mechanisms specific to either synaptic clefts or extrasynaptic spaces.

text 1: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter that does not follow classical rules as it is not released from vesicles.
text 2: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter that follows all classical rules of neurotransmission and is released from vesicles.

text 1: The biosynthesis of acetylcholine depends on dietary choline delivered to neurons through the bloodstream.
text 2: The biosynthesis of acetylcholine involves choline synthesized directly by nervous tissue.

text 1: Acetylcholine biosynthesis involves multiple enzymatic reactions including oxidation and methylation.
text 2: Acetylcholine is synthesized in a single enzymatic reaction catalyzed by choline acetyltransferase.

text 1: Thunberg’s illusion, first demonstrated in 1896, is a mild, often painless heat felt after placing the hand on a grill with uniform temperature bars.
text 2: Thunberg’s illusion, first demonstrated in 1896, is a strong, often painful heat felt after placing the hand on a grill of alternating warm and cool bars.

text 1: Positron emission tomography (PET) was used to compare the cortical areas activated by Thunberg’s grill with those activated by cool, warm, noxious cold, and noxious heat stimuli separately.
text 2: Positron emission tomography (PET) was used to compare the cortical areas activated by Thunberg’s grill with auditory and visual stimuli.

text 1: The anterior cingulate cortex is activated by Thunberg’s grill and by noxious heat and cold, but not by discrete warm and cool stimuli.
text 2: The anterior cingulate cortex is activated by Thunberg’s grill and discrete warm stimuli, but not by noxious heat and cool stimuli.

text 1: A serotonergic pathway arises in the nucleus raphe magnus and projects through the dorsolateral funiculus to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
text 2: A serotonergic pathway arises in the locus ceruleus and projects through the dorsolateral funiculus to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

text 1: Naloxone blocks stimulation-produced analgesia, indicating the presence of endogenous opioids in the brain.
text 2: Naloxone enhances stimulation-produced analgesia, indicating the absence of endogenous opioids in the brain.

text 1: Stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter blocks spinally mediated withdrawal reflexes that are normally evoked by noxious stimulation.
text 2: Stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter enhances spinally mediated withdrawal reflexes that are normally evoked by noxious stimulation.

text 1: Opioid receptors fall into four major classes: alpha (α), beta (β), gamma (γ), and epsilon (ε).
text 2: Opioid receptors fall into four major classes: mu (μ), delta (δ), kappa (κ), and orphanin FQ.

text 1: Pain perception is unaffected by any balance of activity in nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.
text 2: Pain perception is regulated by a balance of activity in nociceptive and nonnociceptive afferent fibers.

text 1: The shaking of the hand that follows a hammer blow or burn exacerbates pain by activating small-diameter afferent fibers.
text 2: The shaking of the hand that follows a hammer blow or burn may alleviate pain by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

text 1: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) uses stimulating electrodes placed at peripheral locations to inhibit small-diameter afferent fibers.
text 2: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) uses stimulating electrodes placed at peripheral locations to activate large-diameter afferent fibers.

text 1: The anterior cingulate and insula regions of the cerebral cortex are activated when the hand is placed on Thunberg’s grill but not when warm and cool stimuli are applied separately.
text 2: The occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral cortex are activated when the hand is placed on Thunberg’s grill and when warm and cool stimuli are applied separately.

text 1: Opioid receptors are highly concentrated in the superficial dorsal horn of the spinal cord and the ventral.
text 2: Opioid receptors are highly concentrated in the deep dorsal horn of the spinal cord and the cerebellum.

text 1: Mice in which the gene for the μ receptor has been inactivated are hypersensitive to morphine and other opiate agonists.
text 2: Mice in which the gene for the μ receptor has been inactivated are insensitive to morphine and other opiate agonists.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia by inhibiting the cerebral cortex directly.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia specifically by activating the periaqueductal gray region.

text 1: The gate-control hypothesis was proposed in the 1960s to account for the fact that activation of low-threshold primary afferent fibers can attenuate pain.
text 2: The gate-control hypothesis was proposed in the 1960s to explain why activation of high-threshold primary afferent fibers enhances pain.

text 1: The neuronal signal for horizontal saccades originates in the paramedian pontine reticular formation.
text 2: The neuronal signal for horizontal saccades originates in the medial vestibular nucleus.

text 1: Omnipause neurons fire intermittently and increase firing during saccades.
text 2: Omnipause neurons fire continuously except around the time of a saccade; firing ceases shortly before and during all saccades.

text 1: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons inhibit motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.
text 2: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons make direct excitatory connections to motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.

text 1: The medial vestibular nucleus and nucleus prepositus hypoglossi perform neural integration of the velocity signal for horizontal eye movements.
text 2: The lateral vestibular nucleus performs neural integration of the velocity signal for horizontal eye movements.

text 1: Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus disconnect the medial rectus motor neurons from the abducens interneurons.
text 2: Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus connect the medial rectus motor neurons to the abducens interneurons.

text 1: The burst neurons responsible for vertical saccades are found in the caudal interstitial nucleus of the lateral longitudinal fasciculus.
text 2: The burst neurons responsible for vertical saccades are found in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.

text 1: Vertical and torsional neural integration are performed in the abducens nucleus.
text 2: Vertical and torsional neural integration are performed in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal.

text 1: The oculomotor portion of the dorsal vermis contributes to weakening the saccade.
text 2: The oculomotor portion of the dorsal vermis controls the duration of the pulse and thus the accuracy of the saccade.

text 1: A midline lesion of the commissural connections in the brain enhances the neural integrator's function.
text 2: A midline lesion of the commissural connections in the brain may cause failure of the neural integrator.

text 1: The flocculus and paraflocculus of the vestibulocerebellum calibrate the neural integrator.
text 2: The flocculus and paraflocculus of the vestibulocerebellum impede the neural integrator.

text 1: Lesions that include the paramedian pontine reticular formation result in paralysis of ipsiversive horizontal gaze of both eyes.
text 2: Lesions that include the paramedian pontine reticular formation improve ipsiversive horizontal gaze of both eyes.

text 1: Purely vertical saccades require activity on both sides of the mesencephalic reticular formation.
text 2: Purely vertical saccades require activity on one side of the mesencephalic reticular formation.

text 1: If the motor neurons received signals from only the burst cells, the eyes would drift back to the starting position after a saccade.
text 2: If the motor neurons received signals from only the burst cells, the eyes would remain fixed after a saccade.

text 1: Burst neurons and omnipause cells are coordinated to control saccade stability.
text 2: Burst neurons and omnipause cells operate independently during saccades to control stability.

text 1: The fastigial nucleus increases saccade velocity at the beginning of contraversive saccades.
text 2: The fastigial nucleus decreases saccade velocity at the beginning of contraversive saccades.

text 1: Astrocytes are found in all areas of the brain; they constitute nearly half the number of brain cells.
text 2: Astrocytes are found only in specific areas of the brain; they constitute a quarter of the number of brain cells.

text 1: In the central nervous system, less than half of the protein in myelin is the proteolipid protein (PLP).
text 2: In the central nervous system, more than half of the protein in myelin is the proteolipid protein (PLP).

text 1: Shiverer mice that inherit both defective genes have only approximately 10% of the myelin basic protein (MBP) found in normal mice.
text 2: Shiverer mice that inherit both defective genes have approximately 90% of the myelin basic protein (MBP) found in normal mice.

text 1: Astrocytes express many of the same voltage-gated ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors that neurons do.
text 2: Astrocytes do not express any of the same voltage-gated ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors that neurons do.

text 1: The mutation that causes the shiverer disease is a dominant deletion of five of the six exons of the gene for myelin basic protein.
text 2: The mutation that causes the shiverer disease is a recessive deletion of five of the six exons of the gene for myelin basic protein.

text 1: Myelin composition is similar to the plasmalemma, consisting of 70% lipid and 30% protein.
text 2: Myelin composition is similar to the plasmalemma, consisting of 30% lipid and 70% protein.

text 1: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a rare inherited peripheral neuropathy and is characterized by progressive muscle strength.
text 2: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is the most common inherited peripheral neuropathy and is characterized by progressive muscle weakness.

text 1: Astrocytes play minimal roles in nourishing neurons and do not regulate ion concentrations.
text 2: Astrocytes play important roles in nourishing neurons and regulating ion concentrations.

text 1: Shiverer mice with the transfected gene express the wild-type gene and produce 80% of the normal amounts of MBP.
text 2: Shiverer mice with the transfected gene express the wild-type gene but produce only 20% of the normal amounts of MBP.

text 1: In the peripheral nervous system, myelin contains no P0 protein, only the hydrophobic protein PMP22.
text 2: In the peripheral nervous system, myelin contains P0 protein, as well as the hydrophobic protein PMP22.

text 1: Proteolipids are soluble only in aqueous solutions because they contain short chains of fatty acids.
text 2: Proteolipids are soluble only in organic solvents because they contain long chains of fatty acids.

text 1: Myelin basic protein is situated on the outermost surface of compact myelin.
text 2: Myelin basic protein is situated on the cytoplasmic surface of compact myelin.

text 1: Mutations of the PMP22 gene cause several central nervous system disorders.
text 2: Mutations of the PMP22 gene cause several hereditary peripheral neuropathies.

text 1: Astrocytes can act as spatial buffers by taking up K+ at sites of neuronal activity.
text 2: Astrocytes cannot act as spatial buffers and do not take up K+ at sites of neuronal activity.

text 1: Astrocytes and neurons communicate to inhibit synaptic signaling in well-understood ways.
text 2: Astrocytes and neurons communicate to modulate synaptic signaling in poorly understood ways.

text 1: Learning and memory are enhanced in mice that overexpress a subunit of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor.
text 2: Learning and memory are diminished in mice that overexpress a subunit of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor.

text 1: The amplitude of the current generated by the NMDA receptors is enhanced in hippocampal neurons from mice that express higher levels of the NR2B subunit compared to wild type mice.
text 2: The amplitude of the current generated by the NMDA receptors is reduced in hippocampal neurons from mice that express higher levels of the NR2B subunit compared to wild type mice.

text 1: Long-term potentiation produced by tetanic stimulation of Schaffer collateral synapses is greater in transgenic mice than in wild type mice.
text 2: Long-term potentiation produced by tetanic stimulation of Schaffer collateral synapses is weaker in transgenic mice than in wild type mice.

text 1: Spatial learning is enhanced in transgenic mice, with transgenic mice reducing their escape latency faster than wild type mice.
text 2: Spatial learning is reduced in transgenic mice, with transgenic mice reducing their escape latency slower than wild type mice.

text 1: Transgenic mice spend less time in the target quadrant than do wild-type mice during the probe trial.
text 2: Transgenic mice spend more time in the target quadrant than do wild-type mice during the probe trial.

text 1: Doxycycline can reverse deficits in long-term potentiation in transgenic mice overexpressing CaMKII-Asp286 kinase.
text 2: Doxycycline enhances deficits in long-term potentiation in transgenic mice overexpressing CaMKII-Asp286 kinase.

text 1: Transgenic mice with doxycycline perform worse than wild type mice in learning the Barnes maze task.
text 2: Transgenic mice with doxycycline perform as well as wild type mice in learning the Barnes maze task.

text 1: Protein phosphatase 2A is required for long-term depression (LTD).
text 2: Protein phosphatase 2A is not required for long-term depression (LTD).

text 1: Inhibition of phosphatase 2A reduces behavioral flexibility in transgenic mice.
text 2: Inhibition of phosphatase 2A enhances behavioral flexibility in transgenic mice.

text 1: The NMDA receptors are required for long-term depression.
text 2: The NMDA receptors are not required for long-term depression.

text 1: Expression of a phosphatase inhibitor in transgenic mice can block the induction of LTD.
text 2: Expression of a phosphatase inhibitor in transgenic mice enhances the induction of LTD.

text 1: When a phosphatase inhibitor transgene is turned off, transgenic mice display impaired learning.
text 2: When a phosphatase inhibitor transgene is turned off, transgenic mice display normal learning.

text 1: The removal of AMPA receptors through endocytosis is involved in long-term depression.
text 2: The insertion of AMPA receptors is involved in long-term depression.

text 1: In the hippocampal CA1 region, a 1 Hz stimulation can produce long-term depression.
text 2: In the hippocampal CA1 region, a 10 Hz stimulation can produce long-term depression.

text 1: APV, a drug, can block the NMDA receptors and subsequently inhibit long-term depression.
text 2: APV, a drug, can enhance NMDA receptor activity and subsequently promote long-term depression.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) fire when a monkey directs attention to the object's location.
text 2: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) fire when a monkey directs attention to the object's location.

text 1: The likelihood ratio (LR) greater than 1 favors rain.
text 2: The likelihood ratio (LR) greater than 1 favors no rain.

text 1: In the lateral intraparietal area (LIP), neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target.
text 2: In the medial intraparietal area (MIP), neurons fire when the monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target.

text 1: The log-likelihood ratio complicates the scale for belief and replaces addition with multiplication.
text 2: The log-likelihood ratio provides a natural scale for belief and replaces multiplication with addition.

text 1: A monkey had to decide whether to look at a red or green target, only one of which would lead to a reward.
text 2: A monkey had to decide whether to look at a red or blue target, both of which would lead to a reward.

text 1: Monkeys can be trained to perform a version of the weather prediction task.
text 2: Monkeys cannot be trained to perform a version of the weather prediction task.

text 1: Persistent neural activity maintains working memory, attention, and plans of action.
text 2: Transient neural activity maintains working memory, attention, and plans of action.

text 1: The neuron assigned negative values when the red target was in the response field.
text 2: The neuron assigned positive values when the red target was in the response field.

text 1: Neurons encode the cumulative sum of the logarithm of the probability ratios.
text 2: Neurons encode the cumulative difference of the probabilities.

text 1: The neuron does not fire if an object is presented outside the neuron’s response field even if the monkey is asked to attend to the location of the neuron’s response field.
text 2: The neuron fires if an object is presented outside the neuron’s response field, regardless of the monkey’s attention.

text 1: A good decision-maker should base the decision on the product of the likelihood ratios or the sum of their logarithms.
text 2: A good decision-maker should base the decision on the sum of the likelihood ratios rather than their product.

text 1: LRs greater than 1 have positive logarithms.
text 2: LRs greater than 1 have negative logarithms.

text 1: The firing stops immediately after the stimulus has been removed.
text 2: The firing can persist for several seconds after the stimulus has been removed.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) represent the accumulation of noisy evidence.
text 2: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) represent the accumulation of noisy evidence.

text 1: All shapes were equally reliable predictors for rewards regardless of color choice.
text 2: Some shapes were highly reliable predictors that a reward will occur if the choice is for green or red.

text 1: Mania improves cognitive processes, enhancing attention and verbal memory.
text 2: Mania affects cognitive processes, often impairing attention and verbal memory.

text 1: Bipolar disorder can be exacerbated by sleep deprivation.
text 2: Bipolar disorder can be easily managed with sleep deprivation.

text 1: Anxiety disorders are the most common psychiatric disorders worldwide.
text 2: Anxiety disorders are the rarest psychiatric disorders worldwide.

text 1: Fear activates the sympathetic nervous system to prepare the body to cope.
text 2: Fear deactivates the sympathetic nervous system to prepare the body to cope.

text 1: The DSM-5 combines pathological anxiety syndromes into a single disorder.
text 2: The DSM-5 divides pathological anxiety syndromes into several distinct disorders.

text 1: Panic attacks are a severe manifestation of anxiety with discrete periods of intense foreboding.
text 2: Panic attacks are a mild manifestation of anxiety with no periods of intense foreboding.

text 1: PTSD follows an experience of severe danger or injury.
text 2: PTSD follows experiences of mild inconvenience or minor injury.

text 1: Generalized anxiety disorder is diagnosed when a person suffers chronic worry not warranted by circumstances.
text 2: Generalized anxiety disorder is diagnosed when a person suffers no worry regardless of circumstances.

text 1: Bipolar disorder generally begins in late adulthood.
text 2: Bipolar disorder generally begins in young adulthood.

text 1: Anxiety disorders can lead to excessive preoccupation with possible threats.
text 2: Anxiety disorders eliminate preoccupation with possible threats.

text 1: Social anxiety disorder can lead to avoidance of verbal classroom participation.
text 2: Social anxiety disorder encourages verbal classroom participation.

text 1: Individuals with rapid cycles in bipolar disorder tend to be less responsive to mood-stabilizing drugs.
text 2: Individuals with rapid cycles in bipolar disorder tend to be more responsive to mood-stabilizing drugs.

text 1: Manic episodes of type 2 bipolar disorder always require hospitalization.
text 2: Manic episodes of type 2 bipolar disorder do not require hospitalization.

text 1: Fear encourages ongoing behaviors by calming and soothing responses.
text 2: Fear interrupts ongoing behaviors by alerting and aversive responses.

text 1: In bipolar disorder, periods of normal mood vary widely among patients.
text 2: In bipolar disorder, periods of normal mood are consistent across all patients.

text 1: Decision-making has been studied exclusively in simple organisms, notably worms and flies, and not in mammals such as mice or primates.
text 2: Decision-making has been studied in simple organisms, notably worms, flies, bees, and leeches, as well as in mammals from mice to primates.

text 1: Insights from simple organisms are believed to be irrelevant to understanding processes in mammals, especially primates.
text 2: The hope is that biological insights from simple organisms will inform our understanding of processes characterized in mammals, especially primates.

text 1: All plans come to fruition, and all thought leads to action.
text 2: Not all plans come to fruition, and not all thought leads to action.

text 1: Psychologists and neuroscientists have long been concerned with decisions.
text 2: Until recently, decisions were only studied by economists and political scientists, with no input from psychologists and neuroscientists.

text 1: Detection experiments showed that the visual system cannot detect a single photon.
text 2: Detection experiments provided evidence that the visual system is capable of detecting a single photon.

text 1: The decision rule is to say “yes” if the evidence exceeds some criterion or threshold.
text 2: The decision rule is to say “no” if the evidence exceeds some criterion or threshold.

text 1: A false alarm occurs when a decision-maker responds “yes” when there was no stimulus.
text 2: A false alarm occurs when a decision-maker responds “no” when there was a stimulus.

text 1: The criterion represents a decision rule which instantiates knowledge about the problem.
text 2: The criterion is merely a formality and does not relate to knowledge about the problem.

text 1: The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) does not relate to changes in criterion or decision accuracy.
text 2: The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) shows how changing the criterion affects the accuracy of the decision.

text 1: The neural bases for cognitive decisions have not been examined in the context of extending perceptual decisions.
text 2: The neural bases for more cognitive decisions have been examined by extending simple perceptual decisions.

text 1: Every yes/no answer is arbitrary and unrelated to sensory evidence.
text 2: Every yes/no answer is a choice based on the sensory evidence.

text 1: The height of curves in signal detection theory is unrelated to the probability of observing measurements under signal conditions.
text 2: The height of curves in signal detection theory represents the probability of observing a measurement under two conditions: signal present or absent.
