text 1: The challenge for neuroscience is to relate signal, noise, and criterion to neural representations.
text 2: There are no challenges in neuroscience related to signal, noise, and criterion in neural representations.

text 1: Decision-makers do not make the same decision even when confronting repetitions of identical facts.
text 2: Decision-makers always make the same decision when confronting repetitions of identical facts.

text 1: A lax criterion prevents false alarms because background noise never exceeds the threshold.
text 2: A lax criterion too often results in many false alarms because background noise exceeds the threshold.

text 1: Depth is computed from the difference between the two eyes’ views of the world and must be reconciled by the brain.
text 2: Depth is computed solely from the information received by a single eye without any input from the other.

text 1: An object lying in the plane of fixation produces images at corresponding positions on the two retinas.
text 2: An object lying in the plane of fixation produces images at non-corresponding positions on the two retinas.

text 1: The concept of binocular disparity involves objects located at different depths from the observer.
text 2: The concept of binocular disparity involves objects at the same distance from the observer.

text 1: Visual cortical neurons are selective only for objects lying on the plane of fixation.
text 2: Visual cortical neurons can be selective for objects lying both in front of the plane of fixation and behind it.

text 1: Objects near the observer are always completely visible without occlusion.
text 2: Objects near the observer can partially occlude those situated farther away.

text 1: Neurons in area V2 show sensitivity to global disparity cues.
text 2: Neurons in area V2 show no sensitivity to global disparity cues.

text 1: The integration of binocular input begins in the primary visual cortex.
text 2: The integration of binocular input begins in the auditory cortex.

text 1: Ocular dominance varies among cells in V1.
text 2: Ocular dominance is uniform among all cells in V1.

text 1: Depth plays an important role in both surface segmentation and establishing three-dimensional properties.
text 2: Depth is irrelevant to surface segmentation and establishing three-dimensional properties.

text 1: Binocular disparity excludes properties such as near cells and far cells.
text 2: Binocular disparity involves properties known as near cells and far cells.

text 1: Some neurons are selective for objects lying on the plane of fixation.
text 2: All neurons are selective for objects lying on the plane of fixation.

text 1: Random-dot stereograms demonstrate a localized scope of disparity analysis.
text 2: Random-dot stereograms demonstrate the global scope of disparity analysis.

text 1: Depth determination uses no monocular cues.
text 2: Depth determination uses many monocular cues.

text 1: Binocular neurons compute depth exclusively from brain signals without retinal involvement.
text 2: Binocular neurons are selective for depth, computing it from relative retinal positions.

text 1: Determining the depths of multiple objects requires linking the retinal images of all objects in the two eyes.
text 2: Determining the depths of multiple objects requires linking the retinal images in one eye only.

text 1: Neural crest cells pass through the posterior half of each somite but avoid the anterior half.
text 2: Neural crest cells pass through the anterior half of each somite but avoid the posterior half.

text 1: Neural crest stem cells are a small group of neuroepithelial cells at the center of the neural tube.
text 2: Neural crest stem cells are a small group of neuroepithelial cells at the boundary of the neural tube and epidermal ectoderm.

text 1: Neural crest cell migration does not require any cytoarchitectural and cell adhesive changes and is similar to most migratory events in the central nervous system.
text 2: Neural crest cell migration requires significant cytoarchitectural and cell adhesive changes and differs from most migratory events in the central nervous system.

text 1: BMPs trigger changes in neural crest cells by inducing expression of transcription factors like snail, slug, and twist.
text 2: BMPs trigger changes in neural crest cells by inhibiting expression of transcription factors like snail, slug, and twist.

text 1: Neural crest cells express integrins, which are receptors for extracellular matrix proteins found along peripheral migratory paths.
text 2: Neural crest cells avoid expressing integrins, which are receptors for extracellular matrix proteins found along peripheral migratory paths.

text 1: The first structures encountered by migrating neural crest cells are blood vessels.
text 2: The first structures encountered by migrating neural crest cells are somites.

text 1: Neural crest cells migrate to various sites throughout the body by relying heavily on scaffolding, hence termed assisted migration.
text 2: Neural crest cells migrate to various sites throughout the body without relying on scaffolding, hence termed free migration.

text 1: Outer radial glia maintain contact with the ventricular surface and exhibit the same molecular characteristics as inner radial glia.
text 2: Outer radial glia lack contact with the ventricular surface and exhibit molecular differences from inner radial glia.

text 1: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are not required for neural crest migration at later stages.
text 2: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are required for neural crest migration at later stages.

text 1: Ephrins provide an attractive signal that encourages neural crest cells to invade the posterior half of somites.
text 2: Ephrins provide a repellant signal that prevents neural crest cells from invading the posterior half of somites.

text 1: Development of sensory neurons is completed before the cells emigrate from the neural tube.
text 2: Development of sensory neurons is initiated at the time the cells emigrate from the neural tube.

text 1: Sensory neurons that express Runx1 and TrkA become proprioceptors.
text 2: Sensory neurons that express Runx1 and TrkA become nociceptors.

text 1: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) cannot be reprogrammed from adult skin cells.
text 2: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can be reprogrammed from adult skin cells.

text 1: Neurogenin-1 and neurogenin-2 are key bHLH factors for the differentiation of GABAergic interneurons.
text 2: Neurogenin-1 and neurogenin-2 are key bHLH factors for the differentiation of glutamatergic pyramidal neurons.

text 1: Neurotransmitter choice determines the communication capabilities of neurons with their postsynaptic targets.
text 2: Neurotransmitter choice has no impact on the communication capabilities of neurons with their postsynaptic targets.

text 1: The mouse brain contains approximately 1,000-fold fewer neurons than the human brain.
text 2: The human brain has approximately 1,000-fold fewer neurons than the mouse brain.

text 1: Damage to the right temporal lobe can lead to unilateral visual neglect, causing patients to be unaware of the left side of space or objects.
text 2: Damage to the right parietal lobe can lead to unilateral visual neglect, causing patients to be unaware of the left side of space or objects.

text 1: Prosopagnosia, or face recognition deficits, is associated with lesions of the temporal lobe.
text 2: Prosopagnosia, or face recognition deficits, is associated with lesions of the parietal lobe.

text 1: The ‘what’ pathway in the brain is specialized for processing faces, objects, color, and semantic memory.
text 2: The ‘where’ pathway in the brain is specialized for processing faces, objects, color, and semantic memory.

text 1: The dorsal stream is primarily responsible for motor actions like reaching and grasping.
text 2: The ventral stream is primarily responsible for motor actions like reaching and grasping.

text 1: Wernicke aphasia, a form of agnosia, is associated with deficits in face recognition.
text 2: Wernicke aphasia, a form of agnosia, is associated with language comprehension deficits.

text 1: Damage to the left temporal-parietal junction is commonly associated with theory of mind deficits.
text 2: Damage to the right temporal-parietal junction is commonly associated with theory of mind deficits.

text 1: The ventral visual pathway is often referred to as the ‘where’ pathway.
text 2: The ventral visual pathway is often referred to as the ‘what’ pathway.

text 1: Neurons involved in color constancy help in recognizing the spectral properties of objects under varying lighting conditions.
text 2: Neurons involved in color constancy fail to adapt to spectral variations in lighting conditions.

text 1: Consciousness only involves levels of arousal, such as wakefulness and sleep.
text 2: Consciousness involves subjective experiences such as awareness, volition, and agency.

text 1: Sleep, delirium, and hypoglycemia are examples of altered states of consciousness.
text 2: Delirium, hallucinations, and epilepsy are examples of normal states of consciousness.

text 1: Conscious awareness is required for all decision-making processes to influence behavior.
text 2: Nonconscious mental processes can influence decisions and behaviors without conscious awareness.

text 1: Neural circuits associated with theory of mind are active in tasks that require reasoning about another person’s motivations.
text 2: Neural circuits associated with theory of mind are primarily active during motor coordination tasks.

text 1: Children under 3 years old often pass theory of mind tasks, showing an advanced understanding of others’ beliefs.
text 2: Children under 3 years old often fail theory of mind tasks, showing an inability to predict another's belief based on false information.

text 1: The brain cannot process sounds nonconsciously and relies solely on conscious awareness for sound recognition.
text 2: The brain can process sounds nonconsciously, such as distinguishing a baby’s cry from ambient noise.

text 1: Provisional commitments to actions like reaching or grasping involve decision-making processes in the brain.
text 2: Provisional commitments to actions like reaching or grasping are purely reflexive and not related to decision-making.

text 1: During non-REM sleep, the patient's PCO2 decreases to near 60 mm Hg.
text 2: During non-REM sleep, the patient's PCO2 increases to near 60 mm Hg.

text 1: Repetitive apnea at the rate of approximately once per minute causes the patient’s SaO2 to rise repetitively and dramatically.
text 2: Repetitive apnea at the rate of approximately once per minute causes the patient’s SaO2 to fall repetitively and dramatically.

text 1: Descending inputs from the limbic system can produce hypoventilation in connection with pain or anxiety.
text 2: Descending inputs from the limbic system can produce hyperventilation in connection with pain or anxiety.

text 1: Monoaminergic neurons in the brain stem can modulate motor tone.
text 2: Monoaminergic neurons in the brain stem cannot modulate motor tone.

text 1: The ventral respiratory group is connected with the pontine respiratory group in the pons.
text 2: The ventral respiratory group is connected with the thalamic respiratory group in the pons.

text 1: The A8–A10 cell groups are located in and near the substantia nigra and modulate motor systems and forebrain mechanisms of reward.
text 2: The A8–A10 cell groups are located in and near the cerebellum and modulate motor systems and forebrain mechanisms of reward.

text 1: The monoaminergic systems were among the last in the brain to be identified and mapped due to their fluorescence when exposed to formaldehyde.
text 2: The monoaminergic systems were among the first in the brain to be identified and mapped due to their fluorescence when exposed to formaldehyde.

text 1: All histaminergic neurons are found mostly within the tuberomammillary nucleus in the posterior lateral hypothalamus.
text 2: All histaminergic neurons are found mostly within the anterior lateral hypothalamus outside the tuberomammillary nucleus.

text 1: Breathing in most normal individuals becomes unstable during sleep at high altitudes.
text 2: Breathing in most normal individuals becomes stable during sleep at high altitudes.

text 1: Serotonergic neurons do not modulate afferent pain signals, thermoregulation, cardiovascular control, and breathing.
text 2: Serotonergic neurons modulate afferent pain signals, thermoregulation, cardiovascular control, and breathing.

text 1: The locus ceruleus does not play any role in arousal and attention.
text 2: The locus ceruleus plays an important role in arousal and attention.

text 1: Sleep apnea often goes undetected in many people.
text 2: Sleep apnea is always detected in many people.

text 1: Hyperventilation during exercise leads to a sustained drop in blood CO2.
text 2: Hyperventilation during exercise leads to an increase in blood CO2.

text 1: Breathing must be coordinated with many motor actions that share the same muscles.
text 2: Breathing need not be coordinated with any motor actions that share the same muscles.

text 1: Voluntary motor pathways can never take over the control of breathing during talking, eating, singing, swimming, or playing a wind instrument.
text 2: Voluntary motor pathways can take over the control of breathing during talking, eating, singing, swimming, or playing a wind instrument.

text 1: The monoaminergic systems adjust the responsiveness of a wide variety of sensory systems.
text 2: The monoaminergic systems do not adjust the responsiveness of any sensory systems.

text 1: Three semicircular canals in each inner ear detect rotational motion and work in bilateral synergistic pairs.
text 2: Three semicircular canals in each inner ear detect linear motion and work in unilateral pairs.

text 1: Two otolith organs in each ear detect linear translations and tilts relative to gravity.
text 2: Two otolith organs in each ear detect rotational movements and sound vibrations.

text 1: Vestibular nuclei neurons receive signals solely from cerebellar and proprioceptive sources.
text 2: Vestibular nuclei neurons receive converging multisensory and motor signals from visual, proprioceptive, cerebellar, and cortical sources.

text 1: Projections from the vestibular nuclei prevent eye muscles from compensating for head movement.
text 2: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the oculomotor system allow eye muscles to compensate for head movement through the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

text 1: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to motor areas and the spinal cord facilitate postural stability.
text 2: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to motor areas hinder postural stability.

text 1: Projections from the vestibular nuclei serve solely to regulate balance and posture.
text 2: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the thalamus and cortex ensure spatial orientation and influence spatial perception more generally.

text 1: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are primarily for auditory processing.
text 2: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are crucial for spatial location and navigation functions.

text 1: Disease or trauma to the vestibular system can produce nausea, vertigo, dizziness, balance disorders, visual instability, and spatial confusion.
text 2: Disease or trauma to the vestibular system affects only the visual system.

text 1: Vestibular signals and visual signals operate independently in the brain, without integration.
text 2: Vestibular signals are combined with visual signals in several cortical regions through Bayesian cue integration to provide motion perception.

text 1: We are only beginning to appreciate the role of the vestibular system in cognition.
text 2: The role of the vestibular system in cognition is well understood and needs no further research.

text 1: When lifting two objects of different size but equal weight, people report that the larger object feels heavier.
text 2: When lifting two objects of different size but equal weight, people report that the smaller object feels heavier.

text 1: The sensorimotor system relies entirely on conscious perception to generate grip and load forces appropriate to the weights of objects.
text 2: The sensorimotor system can independently generate grip and load forces appropriate to the weights of objects despite persistent perception of weight differences.

text 1: Motor planning ensures that all movements are encoded as specific joint motions for precise execution.
text 2: Motor planning allows purposeful movements to be represented abstractly in the brain, enabling flexibility of action.

text 1: Hand movements typically follow curved paths, which demonstrates the brain's reliance on joint-centered motor planning.
text 2: The tendency for hand movements to follow straight-line paths highlights task-centered motor planning efforts by the brain.

text 1: Optic ataxia results from damage to the dorsal stream, causing a deficit in the control of actions despite intact perception.
text 2: Optic ataxia results from damage to the ventral stream, causing impaired visual perception but intact control of actions.

text 1: The size–weight illusion occurs because sensorimotor actions depend directly on conscious weight estimation.
text 2: The size–weight illusion demonstrates the separation between sensorimotor actions and high-level cognitive centers in the brain.

text 1: Visual information for action is processed in the dorsal stream, which projects to the posterior parietal cortex.
text 2: Visual information for action is processed in the ventral stream, which projects to the posterior parietal cortex.

text 1: Hand speed profiles are typically smooth, unimodal, and roughly symmetric during straight-line movements.
text 2: Hand speed profiles are irregular, multimodal, and asymmetrical during straight-line movements.

text 1: Damage to the ventral stream in the brain can result in visual agnosia, impairing conscious visual perception.
text 2: Damage to the dorsal stream in the brain can result in visual agnosia, impairing conscious visual perception.

text 1: Patients with visual agnosia are unable to put a card through a slot or indicate its orientation verbally.
text 2: Patients with visual agnosia can put a card through a slot even though they are unable to indicate its orientation verbally.

text 1: Motor equivalence shows that handwriting differs significantly depending on the limb or body segment used.
text 2: Motor equivalence demonstrates that handwriting appears structurally similar regardless of limb or body segment used.

text 1: Planning movements with reference to joints requires computing nonlinear combinations of joint angles.
text 2: Planning movements with reference to joints results in linear combinations of joint angles.

text 1: Reaching movements typically produce curved arcs, directly reflecting muscle rotations at joints.
text 2: Reaching movements tend to follow straight paths, even though muscle rotations induce joint arcs.

text 1: Subjects cannot adjust fingertip forces for the true weight of objects when experiencing weight illusions.
text 2: Subjects can rapidly learn to scale fingertip forces appropriately for the true weight of objects despite illusions.

text 1: Motor systems achieve redundancy, allowing the same task to be performed in multiple ways.
text 2: Motor systems lack redundancy, requiring a fixed approach for performing each task.

text 1: DBS can help people with Parkinson disease by delivering electrical pulses to targeted areas in the brain to disrupt the aberrant neural activity.
text 2: DBS can help people with Parkinson disease by implanting sensor electrodes to visualize brain activity without delivering electrical pulses.

text 1: Communication BMIs are designed to solely interpret speech and translate it into visual text.
text 2: Communication BMIs are designed to provide a fast and accurate interface with a plethora of electronic devices.

text 1: Antiseizure BMIs operate by discontinuously analyzing neural activity without monitoring specific brain regions.
text 2: Antiseizure BMIs operate by continuously monitoring neural activity in a brain region determined to be involved with seizures.

text 1: Intracortical electrode arrays are implanted on the scalp rather than the cortex.
text 2: Intracortical electrode arrays are implanted in the outer 1 to 2 mm of cortex.

text 1: Replacement part BMIs are incapable of addressing any damage from strokes.
text 2: Replacement part BMIs can potentially restore lost functionality of a brain region damaged by stroke.

text 1: Deep brain stimulation can help reduce Parkinson disease-related tremor for years.
text 2: Deep brain stimulation can reduce tremor associated with Parkinson disease for only a few minutes.

text 1: BMIs build on basic neuroscientific research in voluntary movement.
text 2: BMIs build primarily on aesthetic medical sciences unrelated to movement.

text 1: Arrays of penetrating intracortical electrodes can only record from neuron clusters instead of individual neurons.
text 2: Arrays of penetrating intracortical electrodes can record action potentials from individual neurons.

text 1: Communication BMIs could benefit people with ALS who often cannot communicate with the outside world.
text 2: Communication BMIs have no benefits for people with ALS.

text 1: Visual cortex injury can impact how BMIs interpret neural signals.
text 2: Visual cortex injury has no effect on BMIs since they don't rely on neural signals.

text 1: Measuring and modulating neural activity depends only on basic technology.
text 2: Measuring and modulating neural activity relies on advanced neurotechnology.

text 1: Replacement part BMIs might also be used to initiate and guide neural plasticity.
text 2: Replacement part BMIs do not contribute to neural plasticity initiation or guidance.

text 1: Antiseizure BMIs take several minutes to respond to unusual neural activity.
text 2: Antiseizure BMIs respond within milliseconds to disrupt seizure-related neural activity.

text 1: BMIs exclusively focus on enhancing sensory functions rather than motor functions.
text 2: BMIs can improve quality of life by restoring some lost motor function.

text 1: The design and development of BMIs have primarily come from human clinical trials.
text 2: The design and development of BMIs have largely depended on laboratory animal research.

text 1: Aristotle defined seven senses—vision, hearing, touch, taste, smell, balance, and intuition—each linked to specific sense organs in the body.
text 2: Aristotle defined five senses—vision, hearing, touch, taste, and smell—each linked to specific sense organs in the body: eyes, ears, skin, tongue, and nose.

text 1: Sensory information is processed in sequential pathways in the spinal cord.
text 2: Sensory information is processed in parallel pathways in the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Pain is not considered to be a specific sensory modality but rather an affliction of the soul.
text 2: Pain is considered to be a specific sensory modality linked to the nervous system.

text 1: The principal receptor cells include nociceptors, olfactoreceptors, thermoreceptors, and mechanoreceptors.
text 2: The principal receptor cells include photoreceptors, chemoreceptors, thermal receptors, and mechanoreceptors.

text 1: Feedback pathways from the brain regulate sensory coding mechanisms.
text 2: Feedback pathways from the peripheral nerves regulate sensory coding mechanisms.

text 1: Sense organs transform electrical energy into stimulus signals that are encoded as trains of action potentials.
text 2: Sense organs transform stimulus energy into electrical signals that are encoded as trains of action potentials.

text 1: Psychophysics quantifies the transmission of neural signals.
text 2: Psychophysics quantifies the perception of stimulus properties.

text 1: The modern study of sensation and perception began in the 19th century with the emergence of experimental psychology.
text 2: The modern study of sensation and perception began in the 18th century with the emergence of experimental physics.

text 1: The somatosensory modalities—thermal senses, pain, visceral sensations, and proprioception—are mediated by receptors distributed throughout the body.
text 2: The semiotic sensory modalities—thermal senses, pain, visceral sensations, and proprioception—are mediated by receptors distributed throughout the body.

text 1: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been used to identify regions of the spinal cord involved in the perception of pain.
text 2: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has been used to identify regions of the brain involved in the perception of pain.

text 1: Kant classified the five senses as mere physical attributes.
text 2: Kant classified the five senses as categories of human understanding.

text 1: Sensation confuses all life, and the fundamentals of sensory processing have evolved independently among vertebrates.
text 2: Sensation informs and enriches all life, and the fundamentals of sensory processing have been conserved throughout vertebrate evolution.

text 1: Locke, the preeminent empiricist, advanced the idea that the mind at birth is full of innate ideas.
text 2: Locke, the preeminent empiricist, advanced the idea that the mind at birth is a blank slate, or tabula rasa.

text 1: Sequences of action potentials signal the temporal dynamics of stimuli.
text 2: Sequences of action potentials signal the spatial dynamics of stimuli.

text 1: The sensory pathways have both serial and parallel components, consisting of fiber tracts with thousands or millions of axons.
text 2: The sensory pathways have only serial components, consisting of fiber tracts with tens of axons.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area of the monkey represent only those objects of potential importance to the monkey.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area of the monkey represent all objects in the visual field regardless of their importance.

text 1: Patients with lesions of the right parietal lobe tend to report less of what lies in the left hemifield than in the right hemifield.
text 2: Patients with lesions of the right parietal lobe tend to report more of what lies in the left hemifield than in the right hemifield.

text 1: The gradual appearance of a visual stimulus involuntarily evokes attention.
text 2: The abrupt appearance of a visual stimulus involuntarily evokes attention.

text 1: Activity evoked by a saccade plan lies at the base of the priority map.
text 2: Activity evoked by a saccade plan lies at the peak of the priority map.

text 1: The responses to a behaviorally irrelevant stimulus are much larger than for any event that evokes attention.
text 2: The responses to a behaviorally irrelevant stimulus are much smaller than for any event that evokes attention.

text 1: The dorsal horn contains large motor neurons, whereas the ventral horn contains smaller sensory neurons.

text 1: The proportion of white matter to gray matter is greater at sacral levels than at cervical levels.

text 1: Descending axons in the ventral columns control axial muscles and posture.

text 1: The epicritic system is responsible for fine touch, pressure, and proprioception.

text 1: The cerebellum adjusts movements based on proprioceptive information from peripheral sensory receptors.

text 1: Intermediate-level visual processing includes contour integration and surface segmentation.

text 1: The association field mediates contour integration in visual cortex.

text 1: Feedback connections in cortical areas are as important as feedforward connections.

text 1: Neurons maintain fixed functions regardless of behavioral contexts.

text 1: High-level visual processing operates independently of memory and executive areas.

text 1: Object recognition does not involve perceptual constancy.

text 1: Visual memory interacts only with long-term memory systems but not with working memory.

text 1: Intermediate-level processing deals exclusively with color identification.

text 1: The visual system directly reproduces point-by-point light intensities, similar to the operation of a camera.

text 1: The Gestalt psychologists argued that perception depends on the properties of the stimulus as well as its context within the visual field.
text 2: The Gestalt psychologists argued that perception depends solely on the properties of the stimulus, independent of its context within the visual field.

text 1: Separating figure from background in a visual scene relies only on geometric principles, with no influence from attention or expectation.

text 2: The principle of good continuation helps link line elements into unified shapes in visual perception.

text 1: Vision is a biological process that has evolved in step with our ecological needs, prioritizing useful information over exact details.
text 2: Vision is a biological process that evolved to prioritize exact details of the visual scene over ecological context.

text 1: The visual system processes information about shape, color, distance, and movement only using learned cultural norms.
text 2: The visual system processes information about shape, color, distance, and movement using computational rules inherent in neural wiring.

text 1: Statistical studies of natural scenes show that object boundaries often contain visual elements in close proximity and maintaining smooth contours.
text 2: Statistical studies of natural scenes show that object boundaries rarely contain visual elements in close proximity or smooth contours.

text 1: Visual processing occurs only at one level, focusing solely on object recognition.

text 1: Visual perception is a passive process, limited to the information provided to the retina without neural involvement or prior experience.

text 1: The Gestalt principle of proximity means that features farther apart are more likely to be grouped visually.

text 1: The German term Gestalt translates to configuration or form, emphasizing the holistic interpretation of visual stimuli.

text 1: Smooth contours in a visual scene tend to stand out due to the principle of contour saliency.

text 1: Layer IV is the principal layer of input from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.

text 1: The intrinsic cortical excitatory connections are mediated by smooth stellate and pyramidal cells.

text 1: Feedback connections may support integration because they originate from cells with larger receptive fields.
text 2: Feedback connections may support integration because they originate from cells with smaller receptive fields.

text 1: Dendritic arbors are colored brown, and axonal arbors are shown in blue.

text 1: Cholesterol is the precursor of all steroid hormones and is converted via a series of enzymatic reactions into cortisol and testosterone.
text 2: Cholesterol is the precursor of all steroid hormones and is converted via a series of enzymatic reactions into progesterone and testosterone.

text 1: In adulthood, patients with CAIS opt for keeping the testes and hormonal supplementation appropriate for males.

text 1: Female SNB motor neurons are larger in size and have larger dendritic arbors, with a corresponding decrease in the number of synapses they receive.

text 1: Narrative limits our ability to reason in complex environments compared to simple reports.

text 1: The conscious awareness of an item might arise when the nonconscious brain reaches a decision to report the item to another mind.

text 1: De novo copy number variations tended to cluster in distinct regions of the genome.

text 1: Neuroactive peptides are processed within the neuron’s intracellular membrane system by specific proteolytic cleavage.

text 1: Hundreds of neurexin isoforms are generated through differences in promoter choice and alternative splicing.

text 1: Neuroligins are not subject to alternative splicing, resulting in limited presynaptic partners.

text 2: PDZ-containing proteins serve as scaffolding molecules that link components on both sides of the synapse.

text 1: Fibroblast cells engineered to express neuroligin induce presynaptic specializations in neurons.
text 2: Fibroblast cells engineered to express neuroligin induce postsynaptic specializations in neurons.

text 1: Neurons grown with control cells fail to form pre- and postsynaptic specializations.
text 2: Neurons grown with control cells form extensive pre- and postsynaptic specializations.

text 1: FGF proteins are unrelated to synaptic organizing mechanisms.
text 2: FGF proteins are among the recently discovered synaptic organizing molecules.

text 1: The PSD family of proteins contains no domains that interact with synaptic proteins.
text 2: The PSD family contains PDZ domains that interact with synaptic proteins to assemble signaling complexes.

text 1: Bradykinin directly inhibits both Aδ and C nociceptors and decreases the synthesis and release of prostaglandins from nearby cells.
text 2: Bradykinin directly activates both Aδ and C nociceptors and increases the synthesis and release of prostaglandins from nearby cells.

text 1: The COX-2 enzyme is preferentially induced under conditions of peripheral inflammation, enhancing pain sensitivity.
text 2: The COX-1 enzyme is preferentially induced under conditions of peripheral inflammation, enhancing pain sensitivity.

text 1: Release of substance P and CGRP from C fibers provokes plasma stabilization and vasoconstriction.
text 2: Release of substance P and CGRP from C fibers provokes plasma extravasation and vasodilation.

text 1: Aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective in controlling pain because they enhance the activity of COX enzymes.
text 2: Aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective in controlling pain because they block the activity of COX enzymes.

text 1: Neurogenic inflammation depends on neural activity and is influenced by the release of neuropeptides like CGRP.
text 2: Neurogenic inflammation is independent of neural activity and unaffected by the release of neuropeptides like CGRP.

text 1: Promotion of NGF function and signaling blocks pain sensation as effectively as COX inhibitors and opiates.
text 2: Inhibition of NGF function and signaling blocks pain sensation as effectively as COX inhibitors and opiates.

text 1: Repeated exposure to noxious stimuli can lead to central sensitization, involving N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors.
text 2: Repeated exposure to noxious stimuli can lead to peripheral sensitization, involving GABA receptors.

text 1: Pharmacological agonists of substance P can block neurogenic inflammation and vasodilation in humans.
text 2: Pharmacological antagonists of substance P can block neurogenic inflammation and vasodilation in humans.

text 1: Neurotrophins like NGF and BDNF are causative agents in pain, especially in inflammatory states.
text 2: Neurotrophins like NGF and BDNF are preventive agents in pain, especially in inflammatory states.

text 1: Histamine is released from mast cells after tissue injury and deactivates polymodal nociceptors.
text 2: Histamine is released from mast cells after tissue injury and activates polymodal nociceptors.

text 1: ATP, acetylcholine, and serotonin are released from healthy endothelial cells and platelets.
text 2: ATP, acetylcholine, and serotonin are released from damaged endothelial cells and platelets.

text 1: COX enzymes prevent prostaglandin synthesis, which can be increased by aspirin.
text 2: COX enzymes are key to prostaglandin synthesis, which can be reduced by aspirin.

text 1: Substance P acts on mast cells to inhibit degranulation and release of histamine.
text 2: Substance P acts on mast cells to evoke degranulation and release of histamine.

text 1: Prostaglandins are metabolites of arachidonic acid generated through COX enzyme activity.
text 2: Prostaglandins are metabolites of arachidonic acid generated through lipoxygenase activity.

text 1: Repeated noxious stimuli exposure leads to long-term changes in dorsal horn neuron responses, termed 'windup.'
text 2: Repeated noxious stimuli exposure leads to short-term changes in dorsal horn neuron responses, termed 'windcool.'

text 1: Autism spectrum disorder is present in at least 5% of the population.
text 2: Autism spectrum disorder is present in at least 1.5% of the population.

text 1: Autism spectrum disorders occur predominantly in males, with a typically cited 1:1 male-to-female ratio.
text 2: Autism spectrum disorders occur predominantly in males, with a typically cited 4:1 male-to-female ratio now being called into question.

text 1: ASD must be detectable before 6 years of age, and recent studies suggest it is difficult to identify affected children before 3 years of age.
text 2: ASD must be detectable before 3 years of age, but recent studies have shown it is possible to identify affected children within the first year of life in high-risk families.

text 1: Approximately 50% of clearly affected children with ASD show significant improvement, with no evidence of social disability later in life.
text 2: Approximately 10% of clearly affected children with ASD show improvement, with little or no evidence of social disability later in life.

text 1: Within the scientific community, a consensus has emerged that the increase in ASD prevalence reflects changing diagnostic criteria, increased awareness, diagnostic substitution, and some true increase in incidence.
text 2: Within the scientific community, a consensus has emerged that the increase in ASD prevalence solely reflects a true increase in incidence without changes in diagnostic criteria.

text 1: ASD only affects individuals with an IQ below average, and the majority have intellectual disability.
text 2: Individuals across the IQ spectrum are affected by ASD, and about half of all individuals with ASD also have intellectual disability based on current diagnostic practices.

text 1: ASD diagnosis is based on definitive biological markers, rather than behavioral criteria.
text 2: Although ASD clearly affects the brain, no definitive biological markers have been identified, and diagnosis is based on behavioral criteria.

text 1: ASD is limited to developed countries and higher socioeconomic groups.
text 2: ASD occurs in all countries, cultures, and socioeconomic groups.

text 1: Until recently, the term 'Asperger syndrome' was used to describe individuals with autism-related traits but normal language acquisition and IQ in the normal range.
text 2: The term 'Asperger syndrome' was always used to describe individuals with delayed language acquisition and below-average IQ.

text 1: Profound social disability has probably always been present in human populations, but autism was first described as a medical syndrome in 1943 by Leo Kanner and in 1944 by Hans Asperger.
text 2: Profound social disability was first recognized in 1900, and autism was defined as a medical syndrome by Freud in 1923.

text 1: ASD is characterized by impaired social communication and stereotyped behaviors with highly restricted interests.
text 2: ASD is characterized by enhanced social communication and diverse, unrestricted interests.

text 1: The current diagnostic framework places Asperger syndrome and pervasive developmental disorder under a single ASD spectrum construct in DSM-5.
text 2: The current DSM-5 diagnostic framework keeps Asperger syndrome and pervasive developmental disorder as separate from ASD.

text 1: Autism is not progressive; rather, special education programs and professional support often lead to improvements in behavior and adaptive functioning.
text 2: Autism is a progressive disorder, with social and behavioral symptoms worsening over time.

text 1: No single behavior is conclusively diagnostic for ASD due to variability in development and external factors like environment and social context.
text 2: A single behavior, such as lack of eye contact, is conclusively diagnostic for ASD regardless of age or context.

text 1: Recent longitudinal studies show 90% of children with ASD significantly improve over time.
text 2: Recent longitudinal studies show approximately 10% of children with ASD significantly improve over time.

text 1: A motor unit comprises a single muscle fiber and the neurons it innervates.
text 2: A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates.

text 1: The axons from a motor nucleus exit the spinal cord in a single ventral root and peripheral nerve.
text 2: The axons from a motor nucleus exit the spinal cord in several ventral roots and peripheral nerves.

text 1: Synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold.
text 2: Synaptic input hyperpolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold.

text 1: Once synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron above threshold, the neuron generates an action potential.
text 2: Once synaptic input depolarizes the membrane potential of a motor neuron below threshold, the neuron generates an action potential.

text 1: The action potential releases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular synapse.
text 2: The action potential releases dopamine at the neuromuscular synapse.

text 1: A muscle fiber has electrical properties similar to those of a small-diameter, myelinated axon.
text 2: A muscle fiber has electrical properties similar to those of a large-diameter, unmyelinated axon.

text 1: Most muscle contractions involve the activation of a single motor unit.
text 2: Most muscle contractions involve the activation of many motor units.

text 1: Compound action potentials can be detected by electromyography.
text 2: Compound action potentials cannot be detected by electromyography.

text 1: The electromyogram (EMG) is typically small and difficult to record with electrodes.
text 2: The electromyogram (EMG) is typically large and can be easily recorded with electrodes.

text 1: Motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually clustered into an elongated motor nucleus.
text 2: Motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually dispersed randomly around the motor nucleus.

text 1: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are usually clustered into a motor nucleus that extends over one to four segments within the ventral spinal cord.
text 2: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are scattered throughout the entire spinal cord.

text 1: Action potentials do not propagate along the sarcolemma of the muscle fiber.
text 2: Action potentials propagate along the sarcolemma of the muscle fiber.

text 1: A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates, illustrated by motor neuron A1.
text 2: A motor unit comprises a single muscle fiber, illustrated by muscle fiber A1.

text 1: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are clustered into an elongated motor nucleus.
text 2: The motor neurons innervating one muscle are scattered across different motor clusters.

text 1: Action potentials in all the muscle fibers of a motor unit occur at vastly different times.
text 2: Action potentials in all the muscle fibers of a motor unit occur at approximately the same time.

text 1: During the critical window, ovaries produce a transient surge of estrogen that masculinizes the developing bipotential nervous system.
text 2: During the critical window, testes produce a transient surge of testosterone that masculinizes the developing bipotential nervous system.

text 1: Sex hormones detach from cognate hormone receptors to suppress gene expression.
text 2: Sex hormones bind to cognate hormone receptors that modulate gene expression.

text 1: Many neuronal populations that are sexually dimorphic by morphological and other criteria have been identified in the vertebrate brain over the past few decades.
text 2: Few neuronal populations that are sexually dimorphic by morphological and other criteria have been identified in the vertebrate brain over the past few decades.

text 1: Pheromones guide choice of dietary preference in rodents.
text 2: Pheromones guide choice of sexual partner in rodents.

text 1: Sex hormones control sexual differentiation of neural pathways by utilizing cellular processes such as apoptosis, neurite extension, and synapse formation.
text 2: Sex hormones control sexual differentiation of neural pathways by suppressing cellular processes like apoptosis, neurite growth, and synapse formation.

text 1: Recent molecular studies have identified many sex hormone-regulated genes whose expression patterns are sexually dimorphic.
text 2: Recent molecular studies have identified few sex hormone-regulated genes whose expression patterns are uniform across sexes.

text 1: Both sensory stimuli and past experience minimally influence the display of sexually dimorphic behaviors.
text 2: Both sensory stimuli and past experience profoundly regulate the display of sexually dimorphic behaviors.

text 1: There are many sex differences between the brains of men and women, and in some instances, these sex differences align with gender in adult life rather than gender assigned at birth.
text 2: There are few sex differences between the brains of men and women, and these differences align strictly with gender assigned at birth.

text 1: Many of the actions of estrogen that masculinize the nervous system occur following its conversion to testosterone locally at the site of action.
text 2: Many of the actions of testosterone that masculinize the nervous system occur following its conversion to estrogen locally at the site of action.

text 1: Such sexually dimorphic neuronal populations are exclusive to one sex and guide behavior exclusively along male-typical patterns.
text 2: Such sexually dimorphic neuronal populations are likely embedded within neural circuits found in both sexes, and they are thought to guide behavior along male- or female-typical patterns.

text 1: Effector caspases (caspase-8, -9, and -10) cleave and activate initiator caspases.
text 2: Initiator caspases (caspase-8, -9, and -10) cleave and activate effector caspases.

text 1: The survival of mammalian neurons depends on the balance between antiapoptotic and proapoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family of proteins.
text 2: The survival of mammalian neurons depends on the balance between growth factors and neurotransmitters.

text 1: The binding of neurotrophic factors to their tyrosine kinase receptors is thought to lead to phosphorylation of protein substrates that promote Bcl-2–like activities.
text 2: The binding of neurotrophic factors to G-protein coupled receptors is thought to lead to phosphorylation of protein substrates that promote Bcl-2–like activities.

text 1: The activation of cell-surface death receptors like Fas results in the activation of caspase-8 or -10.
text 2: The activation of cell-surface death receptors like Fas results in the activation of neurotransmitters.

text 1: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.
text 2: Stem cells near the pial surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.

text 1: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the pial surface.
text 2: Processes of radial glia extend from the pial to the cortical surface.

text 1: Unlike excitatory neurons, forebrain interneurons arise subcortically in ganglionic eminences and then migrate tangentially.
text 2: Excitatory neurons and forebrain interneurons both arise in the cortex and migrate radially.

text 1: Neural crest cells migrate from their source at the dorsal tip of the neural tube to form sensory and autonomic neurons and glia.
text 2: Neural crest cells migrate from their source at the pial surface of the neural tube to form sensory and autonomic neurons and glia.

text 1: The greater complexity of the human brain compared to lower mammals is due in part to a larger pool of neuronal progenitors.
text 2: The greater complexity of the human brain compared to lower mammals is due exclusively to the larger size of the neocortex.

text 1: Cerebral organoids enable analysis of some aspects of early brain development.
text 2: Cerebral organoids enable analysis of mature cortical characteristics.

text 1: The nervous system generates up to half as many neurons as are needed in adulthood.
text 2: The nervous system generates up to twice as many neurons as survive in adulthood.

text 1: Neurotransmitters play a crucial role in determining which neurons within a population live or die.
text 2: Trophic factors play a crucial role in determining which neurons within a population live or die.

text 1: Neurotrophins bind to and activate kinases called JNK receptors.
text 2: Neurotrophins bind to and activate kinases called Trk receptors.

text 1: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube increase cytochrome c in neurons.
text 2: Stem cells near the ventricular surface of the neural tube divide to expand the neuroepithelium.

text 1: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the pial surface.
text 2: Processes of radial glia extend from the ventricular to the ganglionic eminences.

text 1: Motor adaptation in monkeys demonstrates that with practice, their initially straight reach trajectories become curved as they adapt to a predictable external force field.
text 2: Motor adaptation in monkeys demonstrates that with practice, their initially curved reach trajectories straighten as they adapt to a predictable external force field.

text 1: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise causes monkeys to move their arms clockwise, aligning cursor movement away from the visual target with practice.
text 2: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise causes monkeys to move their arms counterclockwise, aligning cursor movement directly to the visual target with practice.

text 1: Spike-timing dependent increases in synaptic strength contribute to M1 motor map changes caused by ICMS conditioning between cortical sites A and B.
text 2: Spike-timing dependent decreases in synaptic strength contribute to M1 motor map changes caused by ICMS conditioning between cortical sites A and B.

text 1: Selective changes during visuomotor learning occur universally across all neurons, which is why adaptation generalizes well to all other directions.
text 2: Selective changes during visuomotor learning occur only in neurons near the learned direction, which is why adaptation generalizes poorly to other directions.

text 1: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex inhibit trial-by-trial motor adaptation based on feedback learning.
text 2: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex facilitate trial-by-trial motor adaptation based on feedback learning.

text 1: Changes in M1 neuron activity during force-field adaptation follow a cosine-like function depending on the angle between the force direction and the preferred direction of the neuron.
text 2: Changes in M1 neuron activity during force-field adaptation follow a random pattern regardless of the angle between the force direction and the preferred direction of the neuron.

text 1: Cortical areas like M1 show an increased firing response to motor errors simulated using ICMS, enabling adaptive reaching movements.
text 2: Cortical areas like M1 show a decreased firing response to motor errors simulated using ICMS, disabling adaptive reaching movements.

text 1: Monkeys fail to correct movement errors when allowed brief visual feedback of hand position relative to the target after each reach.
text 2: Monkeys rapidly correct movement errors when allowed brief visual feedback of hand position relative to the target after each reach.

text 1: During visuomotor learning, corrections are never made online after movement onset and remain uniformly inconsistent despite practice.
text 2: During visuomotor learning, corrections are initially made online after movement onset but are gradually refined through practice.

text 1: Adaptation-dependent changes in M1 activity increase progressively as the angle between the force field and cell preferred direction increases.
text 2: Adaptation-dependent changes in M1 activity diminish progressively as the angle between the force field and cell preferred direction increases.

text 1: Neural adaptation during visuomotor rotation occurs only for trained directions, explaining poor generalization to untrained directions.
text 2: Neural adaptation during visuomotor rotation occurs for all directions, explaining strong generalization to untrained directions.

text 1: Decreases in synaptic strength within M1 horizontal connections hinder motor performance through cortical disorganization.
text 2: Changes in synaptic strength within M1 horizontal connections support improved motor performance through cortical reorganization.

text 1: Learning motor skills like pellet retrieval results in expanded motor map areas for practiced movements in monkeys.
text 2: Learning motor skills like pellet retrieval results in reduced motor map areas for practiced movements in monkeys.

text 1: Adaptive changes in M1 neuron tuning during visuomotor learning occur randomly across all neurons regardless of preferred direction.
text 2: Adaptive changes in M1 neuron tuning during visuomotor learning occur at neurons whose preferred directions align closest to the learned movement direction.

text 1: Maintaining a consistent relationship between directional tuning of M1 neurons and cursor motion hinders motor learning in brain-machine interfaces.
text 2: Changing the relationship between directional tuning of M1 neurons and cursor motion significantly alters motor learning in brain-machine interfaces.

text 1: The information conveyed by receptors in the viscera is crucial for regulating autonomic functions, particularly in the cardiovascular, respiratory, digestive, and renal systems.
text 2: The information conveyed by receptors in the viscera is crucial for regulating autonomic functions, particularly in the musculoskeletal, endocrine, sensory, and immune systems.

text 1: Interoceptors are primarily chemoreceptors that monitor organ function through such indicators as blood gases and pH.
text 2: Interoceptors are primarily mechanoreceptors that monitor organ function through such indicators as temperature and pressure.

text 1: Somatosensory information from the skin, muscles, and joint capsules is only conveyed by DRG neurons, not by trigeminal sensory neurons.
text 2: Somatosensory information from the skin, muscles, joint capsules, and viscera is conveyed by DRG neurons innervating the limbs and trunk or by trigeminal sensory neurons that innervate cranial structures.

text 1: Functional imaging of individual DRG neurons expressing genetically encoded calcium sensors such as GCaMP6 is not useful for simultaneous optical recordings of activity from multiple receptor neurons.
text 2: Functional imaging of individual DRG neurons expressing genetically encoded calcium sensors such as GCaMP6 enables simultaneous optical recordings of activity from populations of receptor neurons.

text 1: The identification of Piezo protein ion channels as the molecular transducers of vision and hearing in mammalian auditory receptors has provided a novel system for assessing the role of these channels in the senses of sight and sound.
text 2: The identification of Piezo protein ion channels as the molecular transducers of touch and proprioception in mammalian mechanoreceptors has provided a novel system for assessing the role of these channels in the senses of touch, proprioception, and visceral function.

text 1: Dorsal root ganglion neurons are a type of multipolar cell, called bipolar cells.
text 2: Dorsal root ganglion neurons are a type of bipolar cell, called pseudo-unipolar cells.

text 1: The peripheral terminals of individual DRG neurons innervate the skin, muscle, joint capsules, or viscera and contain receptors specialized for particular kinds of stimuli.
text 2: The peripheral terminals of individual DRG neurons innervate only the brain and do not contain receptors specialized for particular kinds of stimuli.

text 1: This axon is called the primary afferent fiber.
text 2: This axon is called the secondary efferent fiber.

text 1: Each DRG neuron can be subdivided into five functional zones: the receptive zone, the spike generation site, the peripheral nerve fiber, the DRG cell body, and the spinal or cranial nerve.
text 2: Each DRG neuron can be subdivided into four functional zones: the axonal terminal, the central relay station, the synaptic cleft, and the dorsal horn.

text 1: The soma of a DRG neuron contains the cell nucleus.
text 2: The soma of a DRG neuron is devoid of a cell nucleus.

text 1: DRGs that innervate mechanoreceptors that sense touch and proprioception have the smallest cell bodies and unmyelinated axons.
text 2: DRGs that innervate mechanoreceptors that sense touch and proprioception have the largest cell bodies and large myelinated axons.

text 1: Peripheral nerve fibers with large cell bodies express neurofilament heavy polypeptide (NFH).
text 2: Peripheral nerve fibers with large cell bodies do not express neurofilament heavy polypeptide (NFH).

text 1: Peripheral nerve fibers are classified into functional groups purely based on chemical properties, disregarding axon diameter and presence of myelination.
text 2: Peripheral nerve fibers are classified into functional groups based on properties related to axon diameter and myelination, conduction velocity, and whether they are sensory or motor.

text 1: DRG neurons are identical in size, gene expression profile, conduction velocity of their axons, and physiological function.
text 2: DRG neurons differ in the size of their cell soma, gene expression profile, conduction velocity of their axons, sensory transduction molecule(s), innervation pattern in the body, and physiological function.

text 1: Damage to peripheral nerves or their targets in the brain never produces sensory deficits in somatosensory submodalities.
text 2: Damage to peripheral nerves or their targets in the brain may produce sensory deficits in more than one somatosensory submodality or motor deficits in specific muscle groups.

text 1: The density of ACh receptors is reduced over time in myasthenia.
text 2: The density of ACh receptors is increased over time in myasthenia.

text 1: Type 1A axonal neuropathy involves a defect in peripheral myelin protein P0.
text 2: Type 1A axonal neuropathy involves a defect in peripheral myelin protein 22.

text 1: Synapse elimination occurs without any overall loss of axons—axons that lose at some muscle fibers win at others.
text 2: Synapse elimination occurs with a significant loss of axons—axons that lose at some muscle fibers rarely win at others.

text 1: Central synapses are not patterned by master organizers akin to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminins.
text 2: Central synapses are patterned by master organizers akin to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminins.

text 1: Loss of each central organizer studied to date is lethal, similar to agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminin mutants.
text 2: Loss of no single central organizer studied to date is lethal in the manner observed for agrin, MuSK, LRP4, and laminin mutants.

text 1: The competitive process of synapse elimination is driven by neural activity.
text 2: The competitive process of synapse elimination is driven by random chance.

text 1: Activity dependence of synapse elimination involves microglial cells using the complex system of complement factors.
text 2: Activity dependence of synapse elimination involves astrocytes using the complex system of complement factors.

text 1: In adult mammals, each muscle fiber bears only a single synapse.
text 2: In adult mammals, each muscle fiber bears multiple synapses.

text 1: The process of synapse elimination occurs long after the period of naturally occurring cell death.
text 2: The process of synapse elimination occurs simultaneously with the period of naturally occurring cell death.

text 1: Astrocytes promote both presynaptic and postsynaptic maturation.
text 2: Astrocytes inhibit both presynaptic and postsynaptic maturation.

text 1: Synapse formation is inhibited in the presence of astrocytes.
text 2: Synapse formation is enhanced in the presence of astrocytes.

text 1: Astrocytes are the glia found at neuromuscular junctions.
text 2: Schwann cells are the glia found at neuromuscular junctions.

text 1: Glial cells, including Schwann cells and astrocytes, only regulate synapse formation, not elimination.
text 2: Glial cells, including Schwann cells and astrocytes, regulate both formation and elimination of synapses.

text 1: Genetic variation in many central organizers and synaptic recognition molecules has been associated with behavioral disorders.
text 2: Genetic variation in few central organizers and synaptic recognition molecules has no association with behavioral disorders.

text 1: Paralysis of muscle reduces synapse elimination.
text 2: Paralysis of muscle enhances synapse elimination.

text 1: Synapse elimination provides a means by which activity can change the strength of specific synaptic connections.
text 2: Synapse elimination occurs independently of any changes in the strength of specific synaptic connections.

text 1: Astrocytes provide multiple signals to neurons, such as thrombospondin and cholesterol.
text 2: Astrocytes provide only a single type of signal to neurons, not multiple signals.

text 1: Synaptic transmission between autonomic nervous system neurons that innervate smooth muscle is slower and relies on diffusion of the transmitter.
text 2: Synaptic transmission between autonomic nervous system neurons that innervate smooth muscle is faster and does not rely on diffusion of the transmitter.

text 1: The action of a neurotransmitter depends on the properties of postsynaptic receptors, not the chemical properties of the transmitter.
text 2: The action of a neurotransmitter depends on the chemical properties of the transmitter, not the properties of postsynaptic receptors.

text 1: ACh acts on inhibitory ACh receptors at all neuromuscular junctions to prevent contraction.
text 2: ACh acts on excitatory ACh receptors at all neuromuscular junctions to trigger contraction.

text 1: Presynaptic terminals cannot have receptors that modify the release process.
text 2: Presynaptic terminals can have receptors that modify the release process.

text 1: Receptors that gate ion channels directly are referred to as metabotropic receptors.
text 2: Receptors that gate ion channels directly are referred to as ionotropic receptors.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors produce slow synaptic actions, typically lasting seconds to minutes.
text 2: Ionotropic receptors produce fast synaptic actions, typically lasting only milliseconds.

text 1: Metabotropic receptors can produce synaptic actions that last hundreds of milliseconds to minutes.
text 2: Metabotropic receptors can produce synaptic actions that last only milliseconds.

text 1: Electrical synapses are typically very rapid and synchronize the activity of neuron populations.
text 2: Electrical synapses are typically very slow and do not synchronize neuron activity.

text 1: Metabotropic receptors do not lead to the synthesis of second messengers like cAMP.
text 2: Metabotropic receptors often lead to the synthesis of second messengers like cAMP that regulate protein phosphorylation.

text 1: Electrical and chemical synapses cannot coexist and interact in the same neuron.
text 2: Electrical and chemical synapses can coexist and interact in the same neuron.

text 1: Gap junction coupling cannot be influenced by protein phosphorylation.
text 2: Gap junction coupling can be enhanced by protein phosphorylation.

text 1: Chemical synapses cannot amplify the presynaptic action potential as they release only a few transmitter molecules.
text 2: Chemical synapses allow for amplification of the presynaptic action potential through the release of thousands of transmitter molecules.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors are ligand-gated ion channels that rapidly excite or inhibit the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: Ionotropic receptors are not involved in rapid excitation or inhibition of the postsynaptic cell.

text 1: Receptor proteins derived from different gene families mediate direct or indirect gating of ion channels.
text 2: Receptor proteins derived from the same gene family mediate all ion channel gating.

text 1: John Langley postulated that skeletal muscle sensitivity to curare and nicotine was due to muscle fibers.
text 2: John Langley postulated that skeletal muscle sensitivity to curare and nicotine was due to a 'receptive molecule'.

text 1: Generalized onset seizures have distinctive electroencephalogram (EEG) and single-neuron patterns.
text 2: Generalized onset seizures lack distinctive electroencephalogram (EEG) and single-neuron patterns.

text 1: A typical absence seizure shows sudden onset of synchronous spikes at a frequency of 5 per second lasting approximately 14 seconds.
text 2: A typical absence seizure shows sudden onset of synchronous spikes at a frequency of 3 per second lasting approximately 14 seconds.

text 1: An absence seizure clinically manifests as a staring spell with occasional eye blinks.
text 2: An absence seizure clinically manifests as intense muscle contractions with occasional eye blinks.

text 1: Thalamocortical connections are irrelevant for the generation of generalized onset seizures.
text 2: Thalamocortical connections are thought to be essential for the generation of generalized onset seizures.

text 1: GABAergic inhibitory interneurons excite the thalamic relay cells.
text 2: GABAergic inhibitory interneurons inhibit the thalamic relay cells.

text 1: Mutations in P/Q-type sodium channels have produced several mouse models of generalized epilepsy.
text 2: Mutations in P/Q-type calcium channels have produced several mouse models of generalized epilepsy.

text 1: The typical patient with mesial temporal epilepsy has unilateral disease leading to shrinkage of the hippocampus on one side.
text 2: The typical patient with mesial temporal epilepsy has bilateral disease leading to shrinkage of the hippocampus on both sides.

text 1: Functional neuroimaging showcases changes in cerebral metabolism and blood flow during seizures.
text 2: Functional neuroimaging showcases changes in cerebral structure and mass during seizures.

text 1: During a focal onset seizure, there is approximately a three-fold decrease in glucose and oxygen utilization.
text 2: During a focal onset seizure, there is approximately a three-fold increase in glucose and oxygen utilization.

text 1: EEGs of mice with elevated T-type Ca2+ channels show a paroxysmal spike-wave discharge.
text 2: EEGs of mice with elevated T-type Na+ channels show a paroxysmal spike-wave discharge.

text 1: PET scans using nonhydrolyzable protein analogs are helpful in identifying seizure foci in patients with normal MRI scans.
text 2: PET scans using nonhydrolyzable glucose analogs are helpful in identifying seizure foci in patients with normal MRI scans.

text 1: Injection of radioisotopes and SPECT imaging at the time of a seizure reveal a pattern of hypermetabolism.
text 2: Injection of radioisotopes and SPECT imaging at the time of a seizure reveal a pattern of hypometabolism.

text 1: MRI allows noninvasive, quantitative assessment of the hippocampus size in epilepsy patients.
text 2: MRI allows invasive, quantitative assessment of the hippocampus size in epilepsy patients.

text 1: Functional neuroimaging takes advantage of changes in cerebral morphology during the ictal and interictal periods.
text 2: Functional neuroimaging takes advantage of changes in cerebral metabolism during the ictal and interictal periods.

text 1: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is used to map seizure foci unbiased toward neurons deep within the skull.
text 2: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is used to map seizure foci biased toward neurons adjacent to the skull.

text 1: Muscles perform positive work when they shorten and negative work when they lengthen.
text 2: Muscles perform positive work when they lengthen and negative work when they shorten.

text 1: The force exerted by the muscle during the shortening contraction is less than the peak forces measured during isotonic loading.
text 2: The force exerted by the muscle during the shortening contraction is greater than the peak forces measured during isotonic loading.

text 1: Coactivation of opposing muscles decreases the energetic cost of performing a task.
text 2: Coactivation of opposing muscles increases the energetic cost of performing a task.

text 1: Limb muscles in healthy young adults are active 80% to 90% of the time during waking hours.
text 2: Limb muscles in healthy young adults are active 10% to 20% of the time during waking hours.

text 1: The rate at which motor units are recruited during a voluntary contraction increases with contraction speed.
text 2: The rate at which motor units are recruited during a voluntary contraction decreases with contraction speed.

text 1: Sarcomere force during lengthening contractions is augmented by a Ca2+-mediated increase in titin stiffness.
text 2: Sarcomere force during lengthening contractions is reduced by a Ca2+-mediated increase in titin stiffness.

text 1: Negative velocity reflects a shortening contraction in a muscle.
text 2: Negative velocity reflects a lengthening contraction in a muscle.

text 1: The capacity of muscle to do positive work limits performance capabilities like the maximal height that can be jumped.
text 2: The capacity of muscle to do positive work establishes performance capabilities like the maximal height that can be jumped.

text 1: The force exerted by a muscle depends in part on the number and properties of the motor units that are activated.
text 2: The force exerted by a muscle depends irrespective of the number and properties of the motor units that are activated.

text 1: Unsteady support surfaces usually require joint relaxation through concurrent activation of opposing muscles.
text 2: Unsteady support surfaces usually require joint stiffening through concurrent activation of opposing muscles.

text 1: The nervous system coordinates multiple muscles to disconnect mechanical links for movement.
text 2: The nervous system coordinates multiple muscles to create a mechanical link for movement.

text 1: The sarcomere is the smallest element of muscle that includes a complete set of contractile proteins.
text 2: The sarcomere is the largest element of muscle that includes a complete set of contractile proteins.

text 1: Most of the force generated by activated sarcomeres is transmitted laterally through non-contractile proteins.
text 2: Most of the force generated by activated sarcomeres is transmitted vertically through non-contractile proteins.

text 1: Strain energy stored in the elastic elements of muscle and tendon is absorbed during the shortening phase.
text 2: Strain energy stored in the elastic elements of muscle and tendon can be released during the shortening phase.

text 1: Motor units tend to be activated randomly, with no correlation to motor neuron size.
text 2: Motor units tend to be activated in a stereotypical order highly correlated with motor neuron size.

text 1: The large end bulbs form synapses on stellate cells; smaller boutons contact bushy and octopus cells.
text 2: The large end bulbs form synapses on bushy cells; smaller boutons contact stellate and octopus cells.

text 1: In the dorsal cochlear nucleus, the cell bodies of fusiform and granule cells are intermixed between the outermost molecular layer and the deep layer.
text 2: In the dorsal cochlear nucleus, the cell bodies of bushy and stellate cells are intermixed between the outermost molecular layer and the deep layer.

text 1: Repetitive firing in stellate and fusiform cells is prevented by low-voltage-activated conductances.
text 2: Repetitive firing in bushy and octopus cells is prevented by low-voltage-activated conductances.

text 1: The rise and fall of voltage changes in bushy and octopus cells is slower than in stellate and fusiform cells.
text 2: The rise and fall of voltage changes in stellate and fusiform cells is slower than in bushy and octopus cells.

text 1: The brief synaptic potentials in bushy and octopus cells require larger synaptic currents but encode the timing of auditory nerve inputs more faithfully.
text 2: The brief synaptic potentials in bushy cells require smaller synaptic currents but encode the timing of auditory nerve inputs less faithfully.

text 1: The neurons of the medial superior olive form a representation of interaural phase along the rostrocaudal and lateromedial dimensions.
text 2: The neurons of the medial superior olive form a representation of interaural phase along the dorsoventral and anterior-posterior dimensions.

text 1: Each bushy, stellate, and fusiform cell receives input from a few auditory nerve fibers and is sharply tuned.
text 2: Each bushy, stellate, and octopus cell receives input from many auditory nerve fibers and is broadly tuned.

text 1: The large axons of globular bushy cells and the large calyceal terminals of Held allow for short and consistently timed delays.
text 2: The small axons of globular bushy cells and the small calyceal terminals of Held allow for long and inconsistently timed delays.

text 1: The medial superior olive receives coincident excitatory inputs from the two ears only when sounds come from the contralateral half of space.
text 2: The medial superior olive receives coincident excitatory inputs from the two ears when sounds come from the ipsilateral half of space.

text 1: Excitation superimposed on these inhibitory inputs plays a significant role in sharpening the map of interaural intensity.
text 2: Inhibition superimposed on these excitatory inputs plays a significant role in sharpening the map of interaural phase.

text 1: The brain receives information about interaural time differences with every cycle of an ongoing sound.
text 2: The brain receives information about interaural time differences only at the beginning and end of a sound.

text 1: Principal cells of the medial superior olive receive sharply timed excitation driven by sounds only from the ipsilateral side.
text 2: Principal cells of the medial superior olive also receive sharply timed inhibition driven by sounds from both the ipsilateral and contralateral sides.

text 1: The lateral superior olive detects interaural intensity differences.
text 2: The lateral superior olive detects interaural frequency differences.

text 1: The pathway that brings contralateral excitation through the lateral nucleus of the trapezoid body is well understood.
text 2: The pathway that brings ipsilateral inhibition through the lateral nucleus of the trapezoid body is less well understood.

text 1: Each medial superior olive forms a map of the location of sound sources in the ipsilateral hemifield.
text 2: Each medial superior olive forms a map of the location of sound sources in the contralateral hemifield.

text 1: The maturation of the field of psychiatric genetics and genomics over the past decade has revealed the frailty of testing pre-specified candidate genes.
text 2: The maturation of the field of psychiatric genetics and genomics over the past year has confirmed the robustness of testing pre-specified candidate genes.

text 1: A striking finding from recent advances in the genetics of human behavior has been the overlap of genetic risks for syndromes with distinct symptoms.
text 2: A striking finding from recent advances in the genetics of human behavior has been the distinct separation of genetic risks for syndromes with similar symptoms.

text 1: Findings across common psychiatric disorders suggest uniform genetic profiles with low rates of genetic heterogeneity.
text 2: Findings across common psychiatric disorders point to extremely high rates of genetic heterogeneity.

text 1: Copy number variations are not observed in any neurological and psychiatric disorders.
text 2: Copy number variations are observed in some neurological and psychiatric disorders.

text 1: Conservation of genes can only be detected in fossil records not in the sequence similarity at the base or amino acid level.
text 2: Conservation of genes can be detected by measuring the similarity of the sequences at the base or amino acid level.

text 1: Eukaryotes have cells with a complex internal structure, including a nucleus.
text 2: Eukaryotes are single-celled organisms with a simple internal structure that lacks a nucleus.

text 1: Introns are spliced from the RNA before the product is made.
text 2: Introns are crucial for protein synthesis and are integrated into the final product.

text 1: Recombination has no effect on the distinctness of chromosomes between offspring and parents.
text 2: Recombination has the effect of making the chromosomes of the offspring distinct from those of the parents.

text 1: Spliced RNAs destined to become templates for cellular waste products are known as mRNAs.
text 2: Spliced RNAs destined to become templates for protein synthesis are known as mRNAs.

text 1: Mutation refers accurately to a perfect replication of a genome with no alterations.
text 2: Mutation is an alteration in a genome compared to some reference state.

text 1: Animals, plants, and fungi are all eukaryotes.
text 2: Animals, plants, and fungi are all prokaryotes.

text 1: Centromere is where sister chromatids are joined.
text 2: Centromere is the region where different chromosomes are completely separated.

text 1: Proteins are not synthesized directly from genomic DNA; instead, an RNA template is constructed.
text 2: Proteins are synthesized directly from genomic DNA without any intermediate RNA template.

text 1: A deletion or duplication of a limited genetic region occurs without any resulting copy number variation.
text 2: A deletion or duplication of a limited genetic region results in copy number variation.

text 1: Conservation cannot be detected by sequence similarity measurement at the base or amino acid level.
text 2: Conservation can be detected by measuring the similarity of two sequences at the base or amino acid level.

text 1: The thalamus relays sensory information from the cerebral cortex to the periphery.
text 2: The thalamus relays sensory information from the periphery to the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The basal ganglia comprise the thalamus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.
text 2: The basal ganglia comprise the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

text 1: The corpus callosum contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.
text 2: The cingulate gyrus contains a large bundle of axons connecting the two hemispheres.

text 1: The primary somatosensory cortex occupies the gyrus immediately caudal to the central sulcus.
text 2: The primary motor cortex occupies the gyrus immediately caudal to the central sulcus.

text 1: The primary visual cortex occupies the central sulcus.
text 2: The primary visual cortex occupies the calcarine sulcus.

text 1: The amygdala and thalamus are regions of the cerebral cortex buried within the temporal lobe.
text 2: The amygdala and hippocampus are regions of the cerebral cortex buried within the temporal lobe.

text 1: The ventricles contain and produce the cerebrospinal fluid.
text 2: The ventricles fill and circulate blood throughout the brain.
