text 2: Loss of both SOCS3 and PTEN genes results in greater regenerative ability than the loss of either alone.

text 1: Gall's studies of localized brain functions led to phrenology, a discipline concerned with determining intelligence levels based on the detailed shape of the skull.
text 2: Gall's studies of localized brain functions led to phrenology, a discipline concerned with determining personality and character based on the detailed shape of the skull.

text 1: Pierre Flourens concluded that specific brain regions are not responsible for specific behaviors, suggesting a holistic view of the brain.

text 1: Hughlings Jackson studied focal epilepsy and showed that different motor and sensory functions could be traced to specific parts of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The cerebrum comprises four cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a heavily wrinkled outer layer known as the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The cerebrum comprises two cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a heavily wrinkled outer layer known as the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The cingulate cortex is important for regulation of emotion, pain perception, and cognition.

text 1: Neurons in areas V1 and V2 signal foreground–background relationships.

text 2: Differentiating the edge of each object from the background is essential for visual processing.

text 2: An object's direction and speed of movement must be integrated into a computation of the movement of a whole object.

text 1: Neuron-specific uptake mechanisms are crucial for recapturing neurotransmitters for reuse.

text 2: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, like fluoxetine, are generally less tolerated than tricyclic antidepressants.

text 2: COMT is significant in regulating cortical dopamine levels because of the low levels of the dopamine uptake transporter.

text 1: Julius Axelrod was not associated with the Nobel Prize related to neuronal norepinephrine uptake.

text 1: The early vertebrate embryo consists of three layers of cells—ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
text 2: The early vertebrate embryo consists of four layers of cells—ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm, and hypoderm.

text 1: The entire nervous system arises from the endoderm, specifically from a central strip called the neural plate.
text 2: The entire nervous system arises from the ectoderm, specifically from a central strip called the neural plate.

text 1: Formation of neural plate within the ectoderm occurs by a process called differentiation.

text 1: Regionalization along the anterior-posterior axis leads to a series of subdivisions, with the anterior region becoming the brain.

text 1: Recent advances enable neuroscientists to recapitulate some early neural development processes using laboratory animals only.

text 1: Neuronal membrane properties make an important contribution to the function of the central pattern generator (CPG).

text 1: Golgi tendon organs have inhibitory actions on ankle extensor motor neurons when the body is at rest.

text 1: In delay eyeblink conditioning, a neutral sensory stimulus such as a light or a tone is repeatedly paired with an aversive unconditioned stimulus like an air puff to the eye.

text 1: Recurrent excitation can explain how a brief pulse of input can lead to a persistent change in firing rate through a process akin to mathematical integration.

text 1: Damage to certain brain stem structures in humans can lead to gaze-evoked nystagmus.

text 1: Hebbian plasticity involves strengthening synapses when a presynaptic input helps cause a neuron to fire an action potential.

text 1: Experience-dependent changes responsible for learning and memory occur primarily at synapses.
text 2: Experience-dependent changes responsible for learning and memory occur primarily at cell bodies.

text 1: Experimental studies suggest that integrator networks are immune to modification via experience.
text 2: Experimental studies suggest that integrator networks are subject to modification via experience.

text 1: A transient input in a perfectly tuned recurrent network produces a change in firing rate that lasts indefinitely.
text 2: A transient input in a perfectly tuned recurrent network produces a change in firing rate that quickly disappears.

text 1: Recurrent excitation helps explain how neural circuits perform integration.
text 2: Recurrent excitation helps explain how neural circuits perform differentiation.

text 1: Neurons receive velocity information and provide steady output to the oculomotor neurons.
text 2: Neurons receive position information and provide steady output to the oculomotor neurons.

text 1: Mutual excitation among opposing neuron populations can play a role in sustaining activity and integration.
text 2: Mutual inhibition among opposing neuron populations can play a role in sustaining activity and integration.

text 1: The cerebellum's role in simple forms of motor learning is poorly understood.
text 2: The cerebellum's role in simple forms of motor learning is well understood.

text 1: Lesions in the medial vestibular nucleus in monkeys suggest that the neural integrator circuit lies within these structures.
text 2: Lesions in the medial vestibular nucleus in monkeys suggest that the neural integrator circuit lies outside of these structures.

text 1: Voluntary movements are purposeful, intentional, and context-dependent, unlike stereotypical fixed-latency reflexive responses.
text 2: Voluntary movements are automatic, reflexive, and trigger-based, unlike intentional context-dependent responses.

text 1: The primary motor cortex plays an important role in motor execution.
text 2: The primary motor cortex plays no role in motor execution.

text 1: The primary motor cortex includes a detailed map of the motor periphery.
text 2: The primary motor cortex lacks a detailed map of the motor periphery.

text 1: Some neurons in the primary motor cortex project directly to spinal motor neurons.
text 2: No neurons in the primary motor cortex project directly to spinal motor neurons.

text 1: Volitional self-control limits primate voluntary behavior to rigid and inflexible patterns.
text 2: Volitional self-control endows primate voluntary behavior with much of its richness and flexibility.

text 1: Voluntary movements allow choices between alternatives, including the choice not to act.
text 2: Voluntary movements eliminate choices and compel individuals to act.

text 1: The parietal cortex provides information about the world and the body for state estimation to plan and execute motor actions.
text 2: The parietal cortex does not provide any information for state estimation to plan and execute motor actions.

text 1: Premotor cortex supports motor selection and planning.
text 2: Premotor cortex is irrelevant to motor selection and planning.

text 1: Voluntary behavior is the physical manifestation of an individual's intention to act on the environment.
text 2: Voluntary behavior has nothing to do with an individual's intention to act on the environment.

text 1: Theories of perception, cognition, and movement are traditionally unified into a single undivided theory.
text 2: Theories of perception, cognition, and movement are traditionally partitioned into three analytic components: perceptual mechanisms, cognitive processes, and motor systems.

text 1: Humans must use locomotion to exploit their environment, with no independent use of fingers, hands, or arms.
text 2: Humans can use fingers, hands, and arms independent of locomotion to exploit their environment.

text 1: Throughout evolution, voluntary behavior features have become increasingly diminished in higher primates.
text 2: Throughout evolution, voluntary behavior features have become increasingly prominent in higher primates.

text 1: Large areas of the cerebral cortex are not involved in voluntary motor control.
text 2: Large areas of the cerebral cortex are implicated in various aspects of voluntary motor control.

text 1: Theoretical frameworks hinder the interpretation of behavior and the neural basis of voluntary control.
text 2: Theoretical frameworks help interpret behavior and the neural basis of voluntary control.

text 1: Voluntary movements are usually devoid of any sense of 'ownership' by the individual.
text 2: Voluntary movements are typically accompanied by a sense of 'ownership' of the actions.

text 1: The cochlear nerve contains 95% unmyelinated fibers, which receive input from outer hair cells, and 5% myelinated fibers that receive input from inner hair cells.
text 2: The cochlear nerve contains 95% myelinated fibers, which receive input from inner hair cells, and 5% unmyelinated fibers that receive input from outer hair cells.

text 1: Fibers encoding low frequencies terminate ventrally in the cochlear nuclei, while fibers encoding high frequencies terminate dorsally.
text 2: Fibers encoding high frequencies terminate ventrally in the cochlear nuclei, while fibers encoding low frequencies terminate dorsally.

text 1: Bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus project bilaterally to the superior olivary complex, enabling localization of sounds.
text 2: Bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus project unilaterally to the inferior colliculus, enabling sound localization.

text 1: Octopus cells are able to detect sound onsets and brief gaps, allowing animals to mark the spectral components from one source.
text 2: Octopus cells detect continuous sounds and spectral consistency, allowing animals to ignore changing sound sources.

text 1: Stellate cells encode temporal delays in sound and only terminate locally within the cochlear nuclei.
text 2: Stellate cells encode the spectrum of sounds with their tonotopic array and terminate widely across various auditory centers.

text 1: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus receive both somatosensory and auditory inputs, distinguishing between predictable and unpredictable sounds.
text 2: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus process only auditory inputs, distinguishing only loud sounds from soft sounds.

text 1: The medial superior olive is responsible for generating a map of interaural time differences to locate sound sources horizontally.
text 2: The medial superior olive is responsible for generating a map of sound frequencies to decode auditory pitch perception.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral superior olive integrate ipsilateral excitation and contralateral inhibition to measure interaural intensity differences.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral superior olive integrate ipsilateral inhibition and contralateral excitation to measure auditory pitch.

text 1: The cochlear nuclei are randomly organized, with no specific arrangement regarding frequency encoding.
text 2: The cochlear nuclei are organized tonotopically, meaning fibers carrying low-frequency information terminate ventrally, and fibers carrying high-frequency information terminate dorsally.

text 1: The unmyelinated fibers of the cochlear nerve are thought to respond to cochlear damage and contribute to hyperacusis.
text 2: Unmyelinated fibers of the cochlear nerve primarily enhance sound sensitivity and play no role in hyperacusis.

text 1: Octopus cells terminate in large excitatory calyceal endings on neurons of the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus.
text 2: Octopus cells only terminate locally within the cochlear nuclei without projecting to higher auditory centers.

text 1: Parallel circuits in the auditory pathway extract different acoustic information simultaneously from signals carried by cochlear nerve fibers.
text 2: Only a single auditory circuit operates at a time to extract acoustic information from cochlear nerve signals.

text 1: Large spherical bushy cells detect high-frequency sounds and contribute to interaural intensity processing.
text 2: Large spherical bushy cells in the ventral cochlear nucleus detect low-frequency sounds and contribute to interaural time delay processing.

text 1: Cartwheel cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus inhibit fusiform cells via cerebellar-like circuits.
text 2: Cartwheel cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus enhance fusiform cells' excitatory responses through specialized circuits.

text 1: Phase-locked firing occurs in cochlear nerve fibers above 4 kHz, allowing mammals to encode sound amplitude variations.
text 2: Phase-locked firing occurs in cochlear nerve fibers below 4 kHz, allowing mammals to encode timing information about sound.

text 1: The absolute refractory period of a nerve fiber typically lasts a few milliseconds during which it is easy to generate another action potential.
text 2: The absolute refractory period of a nerve fiber typically lasts a few milliseconds during which it is impossible to generate another action potential.

text 1: The relative refractory period typically lasts 15 to 20 ms and requires a smaller stimulus to generate another action potential.
text 2: The relative refractory period typically lasts 5 to 10 ms and requires a larger stimulus to generate another action potential.

text 1: Upon membrane repolarization, the gating charge movement generates a small outward current known as a gating current.
text 2: Upon membrane depolarization, the gating charge movement generates a large outward current known as a gating current.

text 1: Voltage-gated sodium channels select for sodium ions on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.
text 2: Voltage-gated potassium channels select for sodium ions on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.

text 1: Sodium conductance peaks at about 0 mV as all Na+ channels have moved to the activated conformation.
text 2: Sodium conductance peaks at about -100 mV as all Na+ channels have moved to the activated conformation.

text 1: The absolute refractory period corresponds to partial recovery from Na+ channel inactivation.
text 2: The relative refractory period corresponds to partial recovery from Na+ channel inactivation.

text 1: Activation of Na+ channels involves conformational changes enabling binding of cytoplasmic linkers to binding sites near the pore-forming helices.
text 2: Inactivation of Na+ channels involves conformational changes enabling binding of cytoplasmic linkers to binding sites near the pore-forming helices.

text 1: The gating current is produced by outward movement of positively charged residues through the membrane electric field.
text 2: The gating current is produced by inward movement of positively charged residues through the membrane electric field.

text 1: The empirical equations by Hodgkin and Huxley describe changes in channel mechanisms, but not conductance.
text 2: The empirical equations by Hodgkin and Huxley describe changes in conductance, but not channel mechanisms.

text 1: Voltage-gated ion channels exhibit conductance changes over a wide range of membrane potential with saturating values.
text 2: Voltage-gated ion channels exhibit conductance changes over a narrow range of membrane potential with saturating values.

text 1: Hodgkin and Huxley deduced that a conformational change moves charged particles through the membrane electric field.
text 2: Hodgkin and Huxley deduced that a conformational change moves uncharged particles through the membrane electric field.

text 1: Patch-clamp recordings have provided detailed information about properties of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.
text 2: Patch-clamp recordings have provided detailed information about properties of voltage-dependent K+ channels.

text 1: Early experiments showed possibility to easily generate another action potential immediately after the first due to Na+ channel activation.
text 2: Early experiments showed impossibity to generate another action potential immediately after the first due to Na+ channel inactivation.

text 1: Individual voltage-gated Na+ channels open in an all-or-none fashion, conducting brief current pulses.
text 2: Individual voltage-gated Na+ channels open in a gradual fashion, adjusting the amplitude of the current pulses.

text 1: Sodium channel selectivity involves high energetic costs due to Na+ ion's smaller radius and strong interaction with its waters of hydration.
text 2: Sodium channel selectivity involves low energetic costs due to Na+ ion's smaller radius and weak interaction with its waters of hydration.

text 1: The characteristic frequency of a cochlear hair cell depends on the size of the cochlear nerve rather than its position.
text 2: The characteristic frequency of a cochlear hair cell depends on its position along the longitudinal axis of the cochlea.

text 1: Hair cells that respond to low-frequency stimuli have the tallest hair bundles, while those that respond to high-frequency signals have the shortest.
text 2: Hair cells that respond to low-frequency stimuli have the shortest hair bundles, while those that respond to high-frequency signals have the tallest.

text 1: The tuning curve of a cochlear hair cell is typically flat, and the tip represents the cell's highest sensitivity to low frequencies.
text 2: The tuning curve of a cochlear hair cell is typically V-shaped, and the tip represents the cell's characteristic frequency.

text 1: Adaptation prevents hair bundles from responding to weak stimuli at their resting position.
text 2: Adaptation ensures that hair bundles maintain sensitivity to weak stimuli at their resting position.

text 1: Myosin molecules in hair cells are unrelated to tip-link tension or the opening of transduction channels at rest.
text 2: Myosin molecules in hair cells are involved in maintaining tip-link tension, which keeps transduction channels partially open at rest.

text 1: During adaptation, calcium ions increase the upward force of myosin molecules, leading to channel closure.
text 2: During adaptation, calcium ions reduce the upward force of myosin molecules, leading to channel closure.

text 1: The process of adaptation allows hair cells to remain sensitive to transient stimuli while disregarding static inputs.
text 2: The process of adaptation causes hair cells to be equally sensitive to both transient and static inputs.

text 1: Hair cells use passive filtering from the basilar membrane and mechanical amplification for frequency selectivity.
text 2: Hair cells use electrical amplification only and do not involve passive filtering for frequency selectivity.

text 1: The tuning fork analogy describes how cochlear nerve length varies systematically with sound frequency.
text 2: The tuning fork analogy describes how hair bundle heights vary systematically along the tonotopic axis.

text 1: Adaptation restores sensitivity to small, rapid hair-bundle deflections despite prolonged stimuli.
text 2: Adaptation eliminates sensitivity to small, rapid hair-bundle deflections during prolonged stimuli.

text 1: Hair-cell adaptation mechanisms rely on repositioning tip-link insertional plaques.
text 2: Hair-cell adaptation mechanisms are unaffected by changes in tip-link insertional plaques.

text 1: Hair cells are capable of high-pass filtering to disregard low-frequency inputs when appropriate.
text 2: Hair cells exclusively perform low-pass filtering, amplifying lower-frequency inputs.

text 1: The steepness of the tuning curve on the high-frequency side is greater compared to the low-frequency side.
text 2: The steepness of the tuning curve is uniform on both the high- and low-frequency sides.

text 1: Slow adaptation in hair cells can involve myosin motors driven by ATP hydrolysis.
text 2: Slow adaptation in hair cells occurs without the involvement of ATP-driven motors.

text 1: Fast adaptation kinetics are uniform across the tonotopic axis, independent of characteristic frequencies.
text 2: Fast adaptation kinetics vary along the tonotopic axis, helping set characteristic frequencies of responsiveness.

text 1: A mutation in a case of early onset narcolepsy and a generalized increase of hypocretin peptides is observed in human narcoleptic brains.
text 2: A mutation in a case of early onset narcolepsy and a generalized absence of hypocretin peptides is observed in human narcoleptic brains.

text 1: Wakefulness drives metabolite clearance from the adult brain.
text 2: Sleep drives metabolite clearance from the adult brain.

text 1: Field receptors exclusively respond to hair movement or air puffs and are not involved in sensing mechanical pain.
text 2: Field receptors respond to stroking or stretching of the skin in their receptive fields and are excited by painful stimuli like pulling hairs or strong pressure.

text 1: Muscle spindle afferent fibers encode the amplitude and speed of voluntary movements as well as passive limb displacement caused by external forces.
text 2: Muscle spindle afferent fibers encode only passive limb displacement caused by external forces and not voluntary movements.

text 1: Golgi tendon organs are embedded inside muscle fibers and primarily detect the length of the muscle.
text 2: Golgi tendon organs are located at the junction between skeletal muscle and tendons, measuring the forces generated by muscle contraction.

text 1: Joint receptors play little role in postural sensations of joint angle, which are mainly determined by muscle spindle receptors and efferent motor commands.
text 2: Joint receptors are the primary determinants of postural sensations of joint angle, independent of muscle spindle receptors or efferent motor commands.

text 1: Awl/auchene hairs are innervated by three different classes of sensory fibers: Aβ RA-LTMRs, Aδ-LTMRs, and C-LTMRs.
text 2: Awl/auchene hairs are exclusively innervated by Aβ RA-LTMRs, but no other sensory fiber classes.

text 1: TRP channels are gated by temperature and chemical ligands, and different types respond to different temperature ranges and activation thresholds.
text 2: TRP channels are exclusively gated by temperature and do not respond to chemical ligands.

text 1: TRPV1 receptors respond to heat and produce burning pain sensations, being activated by substances like capsaicin and acids.
text 2: TRPV1 receptors only respond to cold stimuli and are activated by soothing substances like menthol.

text 1: Intrafusal muscle fibers are positioned perpendicular to larger muscle fibers and detect muscle contraction via ion channels.
text 2: Intrafusal muscle fibers are aligned parallel to larger muscle fibers within a capsule, and they detect muscle stretch via mechanoreceptive ion channels.

text 1: The thermal qualities of objects are uniquely somatosensory and mediated by free nerve endings in the epidermis.
text 2: The thermal qualities of objects are primarily apprehended visually and not mediated by epidermal free nerve endings.

text 1: Temperature sense is transmitted exclusively by large-diameter afferent fibers involving one receptor type.
text 2: Temperature sense involves a combinatorial code of multiple receptor types, transmitted by small-diameter afferent fibers.

text 1: Humans are sensitive to sudden changes in skin temperature and are generally unaware of slow changes in the range of 31°C to 36°C.
text 2: Humans are equally sensitive to both sudden and slow changes in skin temperature, even within the range of 31°C to 36°C.

text 1: Piezo2 mediates signals transmitted by afferent fibers from muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs.
text 2: Piezo2 is involved exclusively in signals from joint receptors and not muscle spindles or Golgi tendon organs.

text 1: TRPM8 receptors respond to cooling, cold stimuli, and substances like menthol and mint.
text 2: TRPM8 receptors respond to heating, warm stimuli, and substances like camphor.

text 1: Merkel cells are evenly distributed across the surface of the epidermis and unrelated to guard hairs.
text 2: Merkel cells are located at the epidermal–dermal boundary surrounding large-diameter guard hairs.

text 1: Zigzag hairs are the most numerous type of hair follicles and are innervated by Aδ- and C-LTMRs.
text 2: Zigzag hairs are the least numerous type of hair follicles and are exclusively innervated by Aβ RA-LTMRs.

text 1: Cyclooxygenase is one of the enzymes that metabolizes arachidonic acid to produce prostaglandins and thromboxanes.
text 2: Cyclooxygenase metabolizes arachidonic acid to produce leukotrienes exclusively.

text 1: CB1 receptors are the most abundant type of G protein–coupled receptor in the brain and predominantly inhibit neurotransmitter release.
text 2: CB1 receptors are concentrated in the peripheral immune system and predominantly stimulate neurotransmitter release.

text 1: Anandamide consists of arachidonic acid coupled to glycerol and is the only identified endocannabinoid.
text 2: Anandamide consists of arachidonic acid coupled to ethanolamine and is one of the two main endocannabinoids.

text 1: Nitric oxide (NO) stimulates guanylyl cyclase to convert GTP into cyclic GMP.
text 2: Nitric oxide (NO) inhibits guanylyl cyclase, preventing the conversion of GTP into cyclic GMP.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors primarily regulate membrane conductance by opening or closing ion channels locally.
text 2: Ionotropic receptors regulate second-messenger cascades and are slower than metabotropic receptors.

text 1: Lipoxygenases metabolize arachidonic acid exclusively into prostaglandins and thromboxanes.
text 2: Lipoxygenases metabolize arachidonic acid into several active metabolites, including leukotrienes.

text 1: The activation of CB1 receptors can stimulate both GABA and glutamate release from presynaptic terminals.
text 2: The activation of CB1 receptors can inhibit both GABA and glutamate release from presynaptic terminals.

text 1: Endocannabinoids are water-soluble metabolites that only act inside the cell where they are synthesized.
text 2: Endocannabinoids are lipid metabolites that diffuse through membranes and modulate neighboring cells.

text 1: Activation of metabotropic receptors can increase or decrease the opening of ion channels.
text 2: Activation of metabotropic receptors exclusively increases the opening of ion channels.

text 1: Prostaglandins and thromboxane synthesis in the brain is stimulated by acute cerebral ischemia.
text 2: Prostaglandins and thromboxane synthesis in the brain is inhibited during acute cerebral ischemia.

text 1: Cyclooxygenase is activated by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin and indomethacin.
text 2: Cyclooxygenase is inhibited by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin and indomethacin.

text 1: Nitric oxide readily diffuses through membranes and does not require surface receptors for action.
text 2: Nitric oxide requires surface receptors for diffusion through membranes.

text 1: The CB2 receptor subtype predominantly inhibits neurotransmitter release in the brain.
text 2: The CB2 receptor subtype modulates immune responses by being primarily located on lymphocytes.

text 1: Cyclic GMP inhibits protein kinase (PKG) activity and prevents substrate phosphorylation.
text 2: Cyclic GMP activates a protein kinase (PKG) that phosphorylates specific substrates in neuronal cells.

text 1: Metabotropic receptors can act on ion channels far from their own location by utilizing second messengers.
text 2: Metabotropic receptors only affect ion channels localized near their binding site.

text 1: Late LTP recruits the cAMP and PKC signaling pathway to activate by phosphorylation the cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) transcription factor.
text 2: Late LTP recruits the cAMP and PKA signaling pathway to activate by phosphorylation the cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) transcription factor.

text 1: Late LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway is synapse specific.
text 2: Late LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway is non-synapse specific.

text 1: PKMζ is an atypical isoform of PKC that is constitutively active.
text 2: PKMζ is an atypical isoform of PKC that is conditionally active.

text 1: Spatial memory does not depend on long-term potentiation (LTP).
text 2: Spatial memory depends on long-term potentiation (LTP).

text 1: Uwe Frey and Richard Morris proposed the synaptic capture hypothesis to explain synapse non-specificity.
text 2: Uwe Frey and Richard Morris proposed the synaptic capture hypothesis to explain synapse specificity.

text 1: Blocking NMDA receptors in the hippocampus before training causes difficulty in learning spatial tasks.
text 2: Blocking NMDA receptors in the hippocampus before training enhances the learning of spatial tasks.

text 1: CaMKII can become persistently active after a brief exposure to Ca2+ through its autophosphorylation.
text 2: CaMKII cannot become persistently active after a brief exposure to Ca2+.

text 1: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP does not contribute to forming associations between events in explicit memory.
text 2: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP is important for forming associations between events in explicit memory.

text 1: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that synapses are tagged to avoid using newly synthesized proteins.
text 2: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that synapses are tagged to make use of newly synthesized proteins.

text 1: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is essential for functional NMDA receptor formation.
text 2: The NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor is non-essential for functional NMDA receptor formation.

text 1: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) is induced when the postsynaptic neuron fires just before the presynaptic neuron.
text 2: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) is induced when the presynaptic neuron fires just before the postsynaptic neuron.

text 1: PKMζ synthesis increases during LTP, altering synaptic strength rapidly.
text 2: PKMζ synthesis decreases during LTP, weakening synaptic strength rapidly.

text 1: Associative LTP enables weak synaptic inputs to be potentiated when paired with strong inputs.
text 2: Associative LTP prevents weak synaptic inputs from being potentiated even when paired with strong inputs.

text 1: Mutations in CREB binding protein (CBP) impair late LTP and learning in mice.
text 2: Mutations in CREB binding protein (CBP) enhance late LTP and learning in mice.

text 1: Genetic deletion of PKMζ shows negligible effect on late LTP.
text 2: Genetic deletion of PKMζ shows profound detrimental effects on late LTP.

text 1: Long-term potentiation (LTP) cannot be reverted by blocking PKMζ several hours after induction.
text 2: Long-term potentiation (LTP) can be reverted by blocking PKMζ several hours after induction.

text 1: The prism goggles displace the retinal image by 5° to 30° in adolescent owls.
text 2: The prism goggles displace the retinal image by 0° to 10° in adolescent owls.

text 1: Over several weeks, the ITD to which tectal neurons responded optimally changed until the visual and auditory maps came back into register.
text 2: Over several weeks, the ITD to which tectal neurons responded optimally did not change, preventing the visual and auditory maps from coming back into register.

text 1: Reorganization of auditory maps occurs optimally during a critical juvenile period.
text 2: Reorganization of auditory maps occurs optimally during any stage of adulthood.

text 1: In adult owls, the use of goggles has little effect on the organization of the auditory map unless they wore goggles as adolescents.
text 2: In adult owls, the use of goggles has a significant effect on the organization of the auditory map, regardless of their past experience.

text 1: Different functions and brain regions have different critical periods of development.
text 2: All functions and brain regions have the same critical period of development.

text 1: Visual and auditory maps can be realigned in adulthood through several strategies.
text 2: Visual and auditory maps cannot be realigned in adulthood under any circumstances.

text 1: Prism experience does not affect connections between any auditory nuclei in owls.
text 2: Prism experience causes rewiring of connections between two deeper auditory nuclei in owls.

text 1: The auditory pathway in a normal owl includes mapping ITD in frequency-specific channels in the brain stem.
text 2: The auditory pathway in a normal owl ignores ITD mapping in frequency-specific channels in the brain stem.

text 1: In humans, different cognitive skills have different timing of critical periods.
text 2: In humans, all cognitive skills develop during the same critical period.

text 1: Plasticity of binaural tuning in owls decreases when they hunt live prey.
text 2: Plasticity of binaural tuning in owls is greater when adult prism-wearing owls hunt live prey.

text 1: The timing of critical periods varies between brain regions.
text 2: The timing of critical periods is the same for all brain regions.

text 1: In cats, the critical periods for development of ocular dominance in visual neurons occur earlier than those for orientation selectivity.
text 2: In cats, the critical periods for development of orientation selectivity in visual neurons occur earlier than those for ocular dominance.

text 1: Reorganization due to prism experience in owls allows compensation for image displacement.
text 2: Reorganization due to prism experience in owls does not allow any compensation for image displacement.

text 1: Critical periods are permanently closed after early development, limiting brain plasticity.
text 2: Critical periods can be reopened in adulthood, increasing brain plasticity.

text 1: Certain cognitive capacities must be acquired before puberty to develop optimally.
text 2: Cognitive capacities can be acquired at any age with equal development outcome.

text 1: Short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex in Aplysia is produced by touching the siphon gently.
text 2: Short-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex in Aplysia is produced by applying a noxious stimulus to another part of the body, such as the tail.

text 1: The adenylyl cyclase converts cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) to adenosine triphosphate.
text 2: The adenylyl cyclase converts adenosine triphosphate to cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).

text 1: Presynaptic facilitation involves only one molecular pathway.
text 2: Presynaptic facilitation involves two molecular pathways.

text 1: Serotonin binds to metabotropic receptors in the sensory neuron terminal.
text 2: Serotonin binds to ionotropic receptors in the sensory neuron terminal.

text 1: The transition from short-term to long-term memory depends on a prolonged rise in cAMP.
text 2: The transition from short-term to long-term memory depends on a decrease in cAMP.

text 1: Spaced training over several days produces sensitization that persists for 1 or more weeks.
text 2: Spaced training over several days produces sensitization that lasts for only a few hours.

text 1: In the presynaptic sensory neuron, the adenylyl cyclase acts as a coincidence detector.
text 2: In the postsynaptic sensory neuron, the adenylyl cyclase acts as a coincidence detector.

text 1: The catalytic subunit of PKA phosphorylates and inhibits the transcription factor CREB-2.
text 2: The catalytic subunit of PKA phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor CREB-1.

text 1: Unlike the short-term form, long-term sensitization does not involve changes in synaptic connections.
text 2: Like the short-term form, long-term sensitization involves changes in the strength of connections at several synapses.

text 1: Activation of specific gene expression is required for long-term memory.
text 2: Activation of specific gene expression is not required for long-term memory.

text 1: In Aplysia, long-term memory involves the growth of new synaptic connections.
text 2: In Aplysia, long-term memory does not involve the growth of new synaptic connections.

text 1: The increase in cAMP leads to prolonged activation of PKA.
text 2: The increase in cAMP leads to inhibited activation of PKA.

text 1: Pathway 2: Serotonin binds to a second class of ionotropic receptor that activates the Gq/11 class of G protein.
text 2: Pathway 2: Serotonin binds to a second class of metabotropic receptor that activates the Gq/11 class of G protein.

text 1: PKC phosphorylates presynaptic proteins, resulting in the mobilization of vesicles containing glutamate.
text 2: PKC phosphorylates postsynaptic proteins, resulting in the depletion of vesicles containing glutamate.

text 1: The postsynaptic component in the gill motor neuron is similar to long-term potentiation in the mammalian brain.
text 2: The postsynaptic component in the gill motor neuron is similar to short-term potentiation in the mammalian brain.

text 1: The disordered myelination in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1A) results from increased production of peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22).
text 2: The disordered myelination in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1A) results from reduced production of peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22).

text 1: Astrocytes secrete several synaptogenic factors, including thrombospondins, hevin, and glycipans, that promote the formation of new synapses.
text 2: Astrocytes secrete several synaptogenic factors, including thrombospondins, hevin, and glycogen, that promote the formation of new synapses.

text 1: Microglia derive from myeloid progenitors in the yolk sac.
text 2: Microglia derive from neuroectodermal progenitors in the yolk sac.

text 1: Astrocytes can help remodel and eliminate excess synapses during development by phagocytosis.
text 2: Astrocytes do not engage in synapse elimination during development.

text 1: PMP22 gene duplication results in only one functioning PMP22 gene in patients with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
text 2: PMP22 gene duplication results in two functioning PMP22 genes in patients with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

text 1: Astrocytes prepare the surface of the neuron for synapse formation and stabilize newly formed synapses.
text 2: Astrocytes destabilize synapse formation in neurons, hindering synaptic stabilization.

text 1: Following injury and disease, microglia undergo changes in morphology and gene expression.
text 2: Following injury and disease, microglia remain morphologically static and do not alter gene expression.

text 1: Astrocytes degrade synaptic function and behavior by depleting nutrients and reducing blood flow.
text 2: Astrocytes improve synaptic function and even behavior by releasing nutrients and regulating blood flow.

text 1: Microglia disrupt neural circuits by destroying pre- and postsynaptic structures indiscriminately.
text 2: Microglia help sculpt developing neural circuits by engulfing pre- and postsynaptic structures.

text 1: Astrocytes never come into contact with the arterioles and capillaries in the brain.
text 2: Astrocytes ensheathe small arterioles and capillaries throughout the brain.

text 1: Astrocytes remain unchanged in response to brain injury and disease.
text 2: Astrocytes undergo a transformation called reactive astrogliosis in response to brain injury and disease.

text 1: Astrocytes release neurotrophic and gliotrophic factors that promote the development and survival of neurons.
text 2: Astrocytes prevent the development and survival of neurons by releasing inhibitory factors.

text 1: Reactive astrocytes always exclusively promote repair and recovery after CNS injury and never contribute to neuronal death.
text 2: Reactive astrocytes can promote repair and recovery or contribute to neuronal death after CNS injury.

text 1: Following brain injury, astrocytes do not retract from damaged postsynaptic cell bodies but instead advance towards them.
text 2: Following brain injury, astrocytes retract from damaged postsynaptic cell bodies.

text 1: Microglia serve to bring lymphocytes into the CNS during infection and stroke.
text 2: Microglia prevent the entry of lymphocytes into the CNS during infection and stroke.

text 1: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus are predominantly binaural, receiving input from the ipsilateral medial superior olive.
text 2: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus are predominantly monaural, receiving input only from the contralateral medial superior olive.

text 1: The inferior colliculus of mammals is subdivided into the central cortex, dorsal nucleus, and external nucleus.
text 2: The inferior colliculus of mammals is subdivided into the central nucleus, dorsal cortex, and external cortex.

text 1: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus are GABAergic and contribute to the precedence effect.
text 2: Neurons in the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus are glycinergic and do not contribute to the precedence effect.

text 1: The central nucleus of the inferior colliculus is organized tonotopically.
text 2: The central nucleus of the inferior colliculus is not organized tonotopically.

text 1: The inferior colliculus acts as a central point for converging auditory pathways.
text 2: The inferior colliculus acts as a peripheral point for converging auditory pathways.

text 1: The superior colliculus aligns auditory, visual, and somatosensory spatial maps.

text 1: Synaptotagmin proteins function as Ca2+ sensors in endocrine cells.

text 1: Calcium influx triggers rapid fusion of the vesicle and plasma membranes.

text 1: Some corticospinal fibers send collaterals to propriospinal neurons in the C3–C4 segments.
text 2: All corticospinal fibers send collaterals to propriospinal neurons in the C3–C4 segments.

text 1: Humans and Old World monkeys are the only species in which corticospinal neurons make direct connections with the spinal motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.
text 2: Humans and New World monkeys are the only species in which corticospinal neurons make direct connections with the spinal motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.

text 1: Propriospinal neurons in spinal segments C3–C4 mediate part of the descending motor command to cervical motor neurons.
text 2: Propriospinal neurons in spinal segments C3–C4 mediate only sensory inputs and not motor commands to cervical motor neurons.

text 1: In cats as well as most other vertebrates, the corticospinal tract has direct connections to spinal motor neurons.
text 2: In cats as well as most other vertebrates, the corticospinal tract has no direct connections to spinal motor neurons.

text 1: Propriospinal neurons project to motor neurons located in more cranial cervical segments.
text 2: Propriospinal neurons project to motor neurons located in more caudal cervical segments.

text 1: Presynaptic facilitation may help stabilize the execution of movements by encouraging excessive sensory feedback.
text 2: Presynaptic inhibition may help stabilize the execution of movements by preventing excessive sensory feedback.

text 1: Only humans have evolutionarily developed direct monosynaptic corticomotor connections.
text 2: Human and Old World monkeys have evolutionarily developed direct monosynaptic corticomotor connections.

text 1: Propriospinal neurons in the monkey spinal cord are only involved in reflex actions and not in mediating motor commands for reaching.

text 1: Lumbar interneurons receive solely inhibitory input from groups I and II sensory axons from muscle.
text 2: Lumbar interneurons receive input from groups I and II sensory axons from muscle and provide excitatory projections to spinal motor neurons.

text 1: Proprioceptive reflexes play no role in regulating voluntary movements.
text 2: Proprioceptive reflexes play an important role in regulating both voluntary and automatic movements.

text 1: Transmission in spinal reflex pathways can also be modified in connection with higher cognitive functions.
text 2: Transmission in spinal reflex pathways cannot be modified in connection with higher cognitive functions.

text 1: Spasticity is characterized by hypoactive tendon jerks and a decrease in resistance to rapid stretching of the muscle.
text 2: Spasticity is characterized by hyperactive tendon jerks and an increase in resistance to rapid stretching of the muscle.

text 1: Stretch reflexes are never used in clinical examinations of patients with neurological disorders.
text 2: Stretch reflexes are routinely used in clinical examinations of patients with neurological disorders.

text 1: Damage to the spinal cord does not affect the strength of spinal reflexes.
text 2: Damage to the spinal cord can cause large changes in the strength of spinal reflexes.

text 2: Bilateral amygdala lesions enhance the recognition of fear in the facial expressions of others.

text 2: Damage to the human insular cortex enhances addictive behaviors, such as smoking.

text 1: Patients with frontal lesions often fail in tasks where they must make decisions under conditions of uncertainty.
text 2: Patients with frontal lesions often succeed in tasks where they must make decisions under conditions of uncertainty.

text 1: Complete bilateral damage to the human insular cortices does not eliminate emotional feelings or body sensations.
text 2: Complete bilateral damage to the human insular cortices eliminates emotional feelings or body sensations.

text 1: Gage's injury to the parietal lobe in 1848 was the first evidence that parts of the prefrontal cortex played a role in emotions.
text 2: Gage's injury to the ventromedial prefrontal cortex in 1848 was the first evidence that parts of the prefrontal cortex played a role in emotions.

text 2: Patients with ventromedial prefrontal cortex damage often hold successful jobs and maintain financial independence.

text 1: Cochlear implants have not been able to restore any hearing or spoken language to individuals since their inception in the 1970s.

text 1: Neural decoding predicts emotional states from cardiovascular activity.

text 1: Functional electrical stimulation is primarily used to enhance auditory processing in the brain.

text 1: Cochlear nerve and central auditory pathways must be intact for cochlear implants to be effective.

text 1: Channelopathies are the only cause of monogenic human epilepsies.

text 1: Cognitive maps refer to knowledge of space, rules, and relations.

text 1: The retina's output is conveyed to the brain by just one million optic nerve fibers.
text 2: The retina's output is conveyed to the brain by just one billion optic nerve fibers.

text 1: The retina is composed of five major cell types arranged in three cellular layers.
text 2: The retina is composed of three major cell types arranged in five cellular layers.

text 1: The photoreceptor cells in the outermost layer absorb light and convert it into a neural signal.
text 2: The photoreceptor cells in the innermost layer absorb light and convert it into a neural signal.

text 1: Retinal ganglion cells are the output neurons of the retina, and their axons form the optic nerve.
text 2: Retinal ganglion cells are the input neurons of the retina, and their axons form the optic nerve.

text 1: Amacrine cells provide lateral connections in the outer synaptic layer of the retina.
text 2: Horizontal cells provide lateral connections in the outer synaptic layer of the retina.

text 1: The retina performs low-level visual processing and adjusts its sensitivity to changing illumination.
text 2: The retina performs high-level visual processing and does not adjust its sensitivity to changing illumination.

text 1: Visual information lost in the retina can be easily recovered.
text 2: Visual information lost in the retina cannot be recovered.

text 1: The lens forms a variable aperture in the eye.
text 2: The pupil forms a variable aperture in the eye.

text 1: Phototransduction links the absorption of a photon to a change in temperature.

text 1: There are three types of photoreceptors: rods, cones, and fibers.

text 1: Ganglion cells transmit neural images to the brain.

text 1: The output of ganglion cells emphasizes temporal changes in stimuli.

text 1: Spatial filtering is accomplished by lateral inhibition.

text 1: The primary genetic defect in myotonic dystrophy is a dominantly transmitted expansion of a triplet of base pairs (CTG) in myotonin kinase gene on chromosome 19.
text 2: The primary genetic defect in myotonic dystrophy is a recessively transmitted expansion of a triplet of base pairs (CTG) in myotonin kinase gene on chromosome 19.

text 1: Dysferlin and caveolin-3 are central to generating nuclear bindings that coalesce and repair muscle fiber tears.

text 1: In myotonic dystrophy, muscle stiffness is due to lack of electrical discharges associated with muscle relaxations.
text 2: In myotonic dystrophy, muscle stiffness is due to excessive electrical discharges associated with muscle contractions.

text 2: The EMG in myotonic dystrophy shows bursts of repetitive action potentials that delay relaxation.

text 1: Becker dystrophy results from a deletion of two exons, leading to a more severe form of the disease.

text 1: Some limb-girdle muscular dystrophy genes are dominantly transmitted.
text 2: Some limb-girdle muscular dystrophy genes are transmitted exclusively through maternal lines.

text 1: Skeletal muscle actin is associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

text 1: The receptive fields of cortical neurons are much smaller than those of somatosensory fibers in peripheral nerves.
text 2: The receptive fields of cortical neurons are much larger than those of somatosensory fibers in peripheral nerves.

text 1: The barrel cortex in rodents represents the auditory inputs in topographic patterns.
text 2: The barrel cortex in rodents represents the vibrissae in topographic patterns.

text 1: Rodents rhythmically sweep their whiskers across objects similarly to how humans use their fingertips.

text 1: Multiple whiskers map onto a single cluster of excitatory neurons in cortical layer IV called a barrel.
text 2: Each whisker maps one-to-one onto a distinct cluster of excitatory neurons in cortical layer IV called a barrel.

text 1: Neurons in area 3b of the primary somatosensory cortex have overlapping excitatory and inhibitory zones within their receptive field.
text 2: Neurons in area 3b of the primary somatosensory cortex have only excitatory zones within their receptive field.

text 1: The spatial pattern of the whiskers on the face is stereotyped from animal to animal.
text 2: The spatial pattern of the whiskers on the face varies greatly from animal to animal.

text 1: Mice and rats rely more heavily on their sense of whisker-mediated touch than on other senses during exploration.
text 2: Mice and rats rely more heavily on their sense of vision than on whisker-mediated touch during exploration.

text 1: The receptive fields of neurons are always isolated to very specific and unmoving regions of the skin.
text 2: The receptive fields of neurons can span functional regions of skin activated during motor activity.

text 1: Inputs from SA1 and RA1 touch receptors converge on common neurons in area 3b.
text 2: Inputs from SA1 and RA1 touch receptors diverge to separate neurons in area 3b.

text 1: Neurons in area 2 respond only to visual information about hand shape.
text 2: Neurons in area 2 integrate information about hand shape, grip force, and tactile stimulation.

text 1: Inhibitory receptive fields result from connections through interneurons that limit the spread of excitation.
text 2: Inhibitory receptive fields result from a lack of connections, allowing unrestrained neuronal activity.

text 1: The rat somatosensory cortex is thinner than the primary visual cortex of the cat.
text 2: The rat somatosensory cortex is thicker than the primary visual cortex of the cat.

text 1: Vibrissae and fingertips afford completely different psychophysical thresholds and discriminative sensitivities due to their structural differences.
text 2: Vibrissae and fingertips afford similar psychophysical thresholds and discriminative sensitivities despite structural differences.

text 1: Neurons in areas 1 and 2 of S-I are concerned with information more abstract than innervation sites.
text 2: Neurons in areas 1 and 2 of S-I are concerned with purely physical innervation sites.

text 1: The representation of the largest whiskers in rodent S-I is minimized relative to other body parts.
text 2: The representation of the largest whiskers in rodent S-I is enlarged relative to other body parts.

text 1: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli detected by a human observer as a function of time.
text 2: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli detected by a human observer as a function of the stimulus magnitude.

text 1: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 25% of the trials.
text 2: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 50% of the trials.

text 1: Sensory thresholds are typically determined by presenting a subject with a series of stimuli of fixed amplitude.
text 2: Sensory thresholds are typically determined statistically by presenting a subject with a series of stimuli of random amplitude.

text 1: The method of limits involves subjects reporting the intensity at which a steadily increasing stimulus becomes detectable.
text 2: The method of limits involves subjects reporting the intensity at which a progressively decreasing stimulus is no longer detectable.

text 1: A neural code describes the relationship between the amplitude of a stimulus and its psychological impact.
text 2: A neural code describes the relationship between activity in a specified neural population and its functional consequences for perception or action.

text 1: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the early stages of processing than at later stages in the brain.
text 2: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the later stages of processing than at early stages in the brain.

text 1: Experimental animals can be trained to respond to controlled sensory stimuli using devices that allow measurement of decision times.
text 2: Experimental animals cannot be trained to respond to controlled sensory stimuli due to their inability to understand decision times.

text 1: In signal detection theory, sensitivity is defined as the number of false positives divided by the total number of responses.

text 1: Discriminability in studies is measured with ROC analyses that compare the neural firing rates or choice probability evoked by pairs of stimuli.
text 2: Discriminability in studies is measured with ROC analyses that compare the reaction times of subjects.

text 1: The area under the ROC curve provides an inaccurate estimate of d′ for each stimulus pair.
text 2: The area under the ROC curve provides an accurate estimate of d′ for each stimulus pair.

text 1: Signal detection methods have been applied to studies of neural responses to visual stimuli that differ in orientation, spatial frequency, or coherence of motion.
text 2: Signal detection methods have not been applied to studies involving neural responses to visual stimuli that differ in orientation.

text 1: Values of AUC close to 1 characterize low sensitivity and low specificity.
text 2: Values of AUC close to 1 characterize high sensitivity and high specificity.

text 1: Neuroscientists cannot modify activity within sensory circuits by direct stimulation with electrical pulses.
text 2: Neuroscientists can modify activity within sensory circuits by direct stimulation with electrical pulses, chemical neurotransmitters, and modulators.

text 1: Charles Bell and Johannes Müller proposed the theory of specificity for sensory systems in the 19th century.
text 2: Charles Bell and Johannes Müller proposed the theory of specificity for sensory systems in the 20th century.

text 2: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) plots display sensitivity versus specificity on both axes.

text 1: The gaze of individuals with ASD is normal when watching social scenes, often fixating primarily on people's eyes.
text 2: The gaze of individuals with ASD is abnormal when watching social scenes, often fixating on people’s mouths rather than eyes.

text 1: Approximately 10% of individuals with ASD demonstrate savant syndrome, according to widely cited estimates.
text 2: Approximately 90% of individuals with ASD demonstrate savant syndrome, according to widely cited estimates.

text 1: Monozygotic twin pairs show 60% to 90% concordance for ASD, while dizygotic twins show 10% to 30% concordance.
text 2: Monozygotic twin pairs show 10% to 30% concordance for ASD, while dizygotic twins show 60% to 90% concordance.

text 1: Neuropsychological data contradict the idea that brain regions involved in perception are overfunctioning in savant syndrome.
text 2: Neuropsychological data support the idea that brain regions involved in perception are overfunctioning in savant syndrome.

text 1: Individuals with ASD have difficulties suggesting various different uses of a single object irrespective of their IQ.
text 2: Individuals with ASD have no difficulties suggesting various different uses of a single object irrespective of their IQ.

text 1: Researchers found that individuals with ASD fixate on people's eyes instead of showing the normal preference for mouths.
text 2: Researchers found that individuals with ASD fixate on people’s mouths instead of showing the normal preference for eyes.

text 1: A preference for manipulating bits of information that fit within a strict framework is one explanation for savant syndrome.

text 2: The male-to-female ratio of individuals with ASD is approximately 1:4.

text 1: The theory that vaccines contribute to ASD has been widely validated by subsequent investigations.

text 2: The drawing by the gifted artist with high-functioning autism shows remarkably detailed cityscapes.

text 2: Only approximately 60% of monozygotic twins were found to be concordant for the full diagnosis of autism.

text 1: ASD rarely runs in families, decreasing the risk of having a second affected child.

text 1: Current estimates suggest that if parents have one child with ASD, the risk for ASD in a second child remains unchanged.

text 1: Research has established that monognetic twins share all their DNA while dizygotic twins share as much DNA as any sibling pair.

text 1: Inner hair cells form a single row, and the stereocilia of each cell are arranged linearly.

text 1: Research over the past several decades has resulted in a detailed understanding of the neural circuits for both innate and learned defensive responses to threats in mammals, often referred to as 'fear learning.'

text 1: Memory storage in Drosophila involves the cAMP-PKA-CREB pathway and does not require new protein synthesis for long-term memory.

text 1: Flies can be classically conditioned when an odorant is paired with direct stimulation of the dopaminergic neurons, bypassing the foot shock.

text 2: In Aplysia, reconsolidation of memory involves a stabilization through protein synthesis without prior degradation.

text 1: Flies injected with a caged derivative of serotonin undergo aversive conditioning when dopaminergic neurons are activated by light exposure.

text 2: Studies in awake behaving rodents indicate that threat conditioning requires postsynaptic NMDA receptors in the lateral amygdala.

text 1: An inward-rectifying Na+ channel (GIRK) is opened directly by a G protein. Binding of ACh to a muscarinic receptor causes the Gi protein and αiβγ complex to dissociate; the free βγ-subunits bind to a cytoplasmic domain of the channel, causing the channel to open.

text 1: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons and hippocampal pyramidal neurons have distinctive patterns of dendritic branching.
text 2: Cerebellar Purkinje neurons and hippocampal pyramidal neurons have uniform patterns of dendritic branching.

text 1: Semaphorin-3A is an attractant for growing dendrites in the developing neocortex.

text 1: In the tiling of dendrites, the inhibitory interactions are among neurons of various types.

text 1: Drosophila Dscam1 encodes around 38,000 distinct proteins through alternative splicing.
text 2: Drosophila Dscam1 encodes around 800 distinct proteins through alternative splicing.

text 1: Dendrites of each neuron bind homophilically to neighboring dendrites, leading to self-avoidance.

text 1: The growth cone at the tip of the axon is responsible for axonal growth.

text 1: In neurons, transcription factors control the size and complexity of dendritic arbors.

text 1: Tiling causes neuron types to receive information with dendritic overlap.

text 1: Neurons must have intrinsic information about their shape, as patterns are reminiscent in tissue culture.
text 2: Neurons have no intrinsic information about their shape, as patterns differ in tissue culture.

text 1: Several cell-surface adhesion molecules mediate self-avoidance by causing attraction.

text 1: The cochlear prosthesis transmits signals across the skin to receiving antennas implanted subdermally behind the auricle, conveyed in a fine cable to an electrode array in the cochlea.

text 1: The organ of Corti contains approximately 16,000 mechanosensory hair cells.
text 2: The organ of Corti contains approximately 1,600 mechanosensory hair cells.

text 1: Hair cells directly transmit electrical signals to the brain without involving receptor potentials.

text 1: The frequency components of a sound stimulus are detected at different locations along the basilar membrane.

text 1: Hair cells uniquely amplify their inputs to enhance sensitivity and widen the range of detectable stimulus levels.

text 1: Mammals have a hearing range limited to frequencies below 5 kHz.

text 1: Sensorineural hearing loss is currently treated mostly with hearing aids or cochlear prostheses.

text 1: The cerebellum is important for motor control and some nonmotor functions.

text 1: Granule cells receive sensory inputs but not corollary discharge inputs.

text 1: Cerebellum-dependent learning adjusts predictions of vestibular input to account for changes in head movement.

text 1: Cerebellar lesions make tapping movements with hands irregular in rhythm.

text 1: Climbing fibers enhance synapses between parallel fibers and Purkinje cells with continuous stimulation.
text 2: Climbing fibers can selectively induce long-term depression in synapses between parallel fibers and Purkinje cells.

text 1: Climbing fiber activity prevents signaling error even when unexpected resistance is encountered.
text 2: Climbing fiber activity can signal error until unexpected resistance is learned during a well-practiced movement.

text 1: Long-term depression of the synaptic input from parallel fibers to Purkinje cells is a plausible mechanism for cerebellar learning.
text 2: Long-term enhancement of the synaptic input from parallel fibers to Purkinje cells is a plausible mechanism for cerebellar learning.

text 1: The nicotinic ACh receptor is a metabotropic receptor that indirectly opens an ion channel.
text 2: The nicotinic ACh receptor is an ionotropic receptor that directly opens an ion channel.

text 1: Action potentials in axons trigger the release of acetylcholine by causing the fusion of synaptic vesicles at active zones.
text 2: Action potentials in axons inhibit the release of acetylcholine by preventing the fusion of synaptic vesicles at active zones.

text 1: The synaptic cleft at the neuromuscular junction is approximately 100 micrometers wide.
text 2: The synaptic cleft at the neuromuscular junction is approximately 100 nm wide.

text 1: Schwann cells are absent at the neuromuscular junction.
text 2: Schwann cells partially enwrap the nerve terminal at the neuromuscular junction.

text 1: The ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction are packed at the crests of secondary folds.
text 2: The ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction are randomly distributed throughout the muscle surface.

text 1: Acetylcholinesterase slowly hydrolyzes acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
text 2: Acetylcholinesterase rapidly hydrolyzes acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

text 1: Synaptic boutons contain machinery for synthesis and release of acetylcholine.
text 2: Synaptic boutons lack machinery for synthesis and release of acetylcholine.

text 1: The end-plate potential can be calculated from an equivalent circuit.
text 2: The end-plate potential is unpredictable and cannot be calculated.

text 1: The neurotransmitter acetylcholine is released in discrete packets at the synapse.
text 2: Acetylcholine is released continuously at the synapse.

text 1: The ion channel at the end-plate is only permeable to potassium ions.
text 2: The ion channel at the end-plate is permeable to both sodium and potassium ions.

text 1: Muscle innervation in adults occurs at multiple random sites across the surface.
text 2: Muscle innervation in adults is restricted to one site called the motor end-plate.

text 1: Acetylcholine receptors are metabotropic and do not change membrane permeability.
text 2: Acetylcholine receptors are ionotropic and mediate a local change in membrane permeability.

text 1: The EPSP at a nerve-muscle synapse can be as large as 75 mV.
text 2: The EPSP at a nerve-muscle synapse typically does not exceed 10 mV.

text 1: Synthetic agents that activate nicotinic ACh receptors are generally toxic and not used therapeutically.
text 2: Synthetic agents that activate nicotinic ACh receptors can be useful therapeutic agents.

text 1: The high-resolution structure of the acetylcholine receptor-channel has not been determined.
text 2: The high-resolution structure of the acetylcholine receptor-channel is revealed by X-ray crystal studies.

text 1: Substance P is released from the central terminals of nociceptive afferents in response to tissue injury.
text 2: Substance P is released from the peripheral terminals of nociceptive afferents in response to tissue injury.

text 1: GABA is the primary neurotransmitter of all primary sensory neurons, regardless of sensory modality.
text 2: Glutamate is the primary neurotransmitter of all primary sensory neurons, regardless of sensory modality.

text 1: Substance P activates the serotonin receptor, which is expressed by neurons in the superficial dorsal horn.
text 2: Substance P activates the neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor, which is expressed by neurons in the superficial dorsal horn.

text 1: Many neurons in laminae VII and VIII respond to noxious stimuli.
text 2: Neurons in laminae I and II respond to noxious stimuli.

text 1: Substance P is a member of the neurokinin peptide family.
text 2: Substance P is a member of the opioid peptide family.

text 1: Hyperalgesia can be elicited by desensitizing peripheral nociceptors.
text 2: Hyperalgesia can be elicited by sensitizing peripheral nociceptors through repetitive exposure to noxious stimuli.

text 1: Substance P is stored in small, electron-lucent vesicles at the central terminals of nociceptive sensory neurons.
text 2: Substance P is stored in large, dense-core vesicles at the central terminals of nociceptive sensory neurons.

text 1: The activation of lamina VII neurons contributes to the diffuse quality of many pain conditions.
text 2: The activation of lamina V neurons contributes to the diffuse quality of many pain conditions.

text 1: Neuropeptides are released as cotransmitters by many nociceptors with myelinated axons.
text 2: Neuropeptides are released as cotransmitters by many nociceptors with unmyelinated axons.

text 1: Infusion of substance P coupled to a neurotoxin results in the selective destruction of neurons with mu-opioid receptors.
text 2: Infusion of substance P coupled to a neurotoxin results in the selective destruction of neurons with neurokinin receptors.

text 1: Neurons in lamina VI are activated by innocuous joint movement and do not contribute to the transmission of nociceptive information.
text 2: Neurons in lamina VI are activated by nociceptive stimuli and contribute to the transmission of nociceptive information.

text 1: Separate storage sites permit glutamate and neuropeptides to be selectively released under different physiological conditions.
text 2: Mixed storage sites prevent glutamate and neuropeptides from being selectively released under different physiological conditions.

text 1: The μ-opioid receptor, targeted by enkephalins, is expressed postsynaptically on the terminals of sensory neurons.
text 2: The μ-opioid receptor, targeted by enkephalins, is expressed presynaptically on the terminals of sensory neurons.

text 1: Referred pain can occur due to the convergence of visceral and somatic afferent fibers on the same projection neurons in the dorsal horn.
text 2: Referred pain occurs due to the separate transmission pathways of visceral and somatic afferent fibers in the dorsal horn.

text 1: Neurons in lamina V receive input from small-diameter unmyelinated Aβ mechanoreceptive fibers.
text 2: Neurons in lamina V receive input from large-diameter myelinated Aβ mechanoreceptive fibers.

text 1: Leptin and insulin are humoral signals sensed by receptors in the arcuate nucleus and the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) to reduce food intake and increase energy expenditure.
text 2: Leptin and insulin are humoral signals sensed by receptors in the arcuate nucleus and the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS) to increase food intake and decrease energy expenditure.

text 1: AgRP neurons promote hunger by releasing factors that inhibit PVH-MC4R satiety neurons and also directly inhibit POMC neurons.
text 2: AgRP neurons promote satiety by releasing factors that enhance PVH-MC4R satiety neurons and also directly activate POMC neurons.

text 1: POMC neurons release α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (αMSH), which inhibits melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and increases hunger.
text 2: POMC neurons release α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (αMSH), which activates melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and decreases hunger.

text 1: Environmental cues predicting food induce inhibition of AgRP neurons even in fasted mice, acting as anticipatory signals.
text 2: Environmental cues predicting food induce activation of AgRP neurons even in fed mice, acting as anticipatory signals.

text 1: The PVH-MC4R satiety neurons increase hunger via inhibitory projections to the lateral parabrachial nucleus.
text 2: The PVH-MC4R satiety neurons decrease hunger via excitatory projections to the lateral parabrachial nucleus.

text 1: Optogenetic stimulation of POMC neurons induces hyperphagia even in calorically replete mice.
text 2: Optogenetic stimulation of AgRP neurons induces hyperphagia even in calorically replete mice.

text 1: The arcuate nucleus contains AgRP neurons that release glutamate to induce satiety.
text 2: The arcuate nucleus contains VGLUT2 neurons that release glutamate to induce satiety.

text 1: Fasting inhibits AgRP neurons, which promote satiety, while feeding activates them.
text 2: Fasting activates AgRP neurons, which promote hunger, while feeding inhibits them.

text 1: Genetic ablation of AgRP neurons in mice causes obesity due to excessive hunger promotion.
text 2: Genetic ablation of AgRP neurons in mice causes starvation due to lack of hunger promotion.

text 1: Leptin treatment activates AgRP neurons while inhibiting POMC neurons, increasing hunger.
text 2: Leptin treatment inhibits AgRP neurons while activating POMC neurons, reducing hunger.

text 1: While genetic deficiency of POMC or MC4R causes obesity, their absence leads to reduced activation of satiety mechanisms.
text 2: While genetic deficiency of POMC or MC4R causes obesity, their absence leads to reduced activation of hunger mechanisms.

text 1: Short-term signals like ghrelin promote satiation during meals by stimulating vagus nerve sensory fibers.
text 2: Short-term signals like CCK promote satiation during meals by stimulating vagus nerve sensory fibers.

text 1: AgRP neurons release glutamate, NPY, and leptin to activate MC4R-expressing neurons and promote satiety.
text 2: AgRP neurons release GABA, NPY, and AgRP to inhibit MC4R-expressing neurons and promote hunger.

text 1: Drive reduction theory suggests that deficiency states create pleasurable conditions which motivate behavior to amplify the discomfort.
text 2: Drive reduction theory suggests that deficiency states create aversive conditions which motivate behavior to resolve discomfort.

text 1: Satiety-promoting POMC neurons release αMSH, which inhibits MC4R in PVH neurons to increase hunger.
text 2: Satiety-promoting POMC neurons release αMSH, which activates MC4R in PVH neurons to decrease hunger.

text 1: Broca’s Aphasia Results From a Large Lesion in the Left Frontal Lobe.
text 2: Broca’s Aphasia Results From a Large Lesion in the Right Parietal Lobe.

text 1: The Right Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.
text 2: The Left Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.

text 1: Transcortical Aphasias Result From Damage to Areas Near Broca’s and Wernicke’s Areas.
text 2: Transcortical Aphasias Result From Damage to Areas Near the Occipital Lobe.

text 1: Wernicke’s Aphasia Results From Damage to Left Posterior Temporal Lobe Structures.
text 2: Wernicke’s Aphasia Results From Damage to Right Anterior Temporal Lobe Structures.

text 1: A New Model for the Neural Basis of Language Has Emerged.
text 2: An Old Model for the Neural Basis of Language Has Emerged.

text 1: Studies of the Aphasias Have Provided No Insights into Language Processing.
text 2: Studies of the Aphasias Have Provided Insights into Language Processing.

text 1: Language Has a Single Structural Level: Each Word Stands Alone.
text 2: Language Has Many Structural Levels: Phonemes, Morphemes, Words, and Sentences.

text 1: Successful Bilingual Learning Depends on the Age at Which the Second Language Is Learned.
text 2: Successful Bilingual Learning Is Independent of the Age at Which the Second Language Is Learned.

text 1: The Visual System Is Not Involved in Language Production and Perception.
text 2: The Visual System Is Engaged in Language Production and Perception.

text 1: The Left Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.
text 2: The Right Hemisphere Is Dominant for Language.

text 1: Language Acquisition in Children Is Random and Without Pattern.
text 2: Language Acquisition in Children Follows a Universal Pattern.

text 1: The Neural Architecture for Language Develops Rapidly During Infancy.
text 2: The Neural Architecture for Language Develops Slowly During Middle Age.

text 1: Global Aphasia Results From Widespread Damage to Several Language Centers.
text 2: Global Aphasia Results From Damage Limited to the Auditory Cortex.

text 1: Prosodic Cues Are Learned Only After Birth.
text 2: Prosodic Cues Are Learned as Early as In Utero.

text 1: The “Universalist” Infant Becomes Linguistically Specialized by Age 5.
text 2: The “Universalist” Infant Becomes Linguistically Specialized by Age 1.

text 1: Only the Broca’s Area Contributes to Language Processing.
text 2: Numerous Specialized Cortical Regions Contribute to Language Processing.

text 1: The therapeutic action of most antipsychotic drugs is due to their ability to block D1 dopamine receptors.
text 2: The therapeutic action of most antipsychotic drugs is due to their ability to block D2 dopamine receptors.

text 1: Clozapine has greater efficacy than other antipsychotic drugs and was reintroduced in the late 1980s with weekly monitoring of white blood cells.
text 2: Clozapine has the same efficacy as other antipsychotic drugs and was introduced in the late 1980s without any monitoring requirements.

text 1: Chlorpromazine, the first effective antipsychotic drug, was originally developed to treat Parkinson's disease.
text 2: Chlorpromazine, the first effective antipsychotic drug, was initially developed for its antihistaminic and sedating effects.

text 1: The liability of second-generation antipsychotic drugs for causing Parkinson-like motor side effects is higher than first-generation drugs.
text 2: The liability of second-generation antipsychotic drugs for causing Parkinson-like motor side effects is lower than first-generation drugs.

text 1: Evidence suggests that schizophrenia solely involves hyperactivity in cortical dopaminergic systems.
text 2: Evidence suggests that schizophrenia may involve hyperactivity in subcortical dopaminergic systems and hypoactivity in cortical regions.

text 1: Antipsychotic drugs are equally effective at reducing hallucinations, delusions, and cognitive impairments in schizophrenia.
text 2: Antipsychotic drugs are effective at reducing hallucinations and delusions but do not improve cognitive impairments in schizophrenia.

text 1: Schizophrenia is hypothesized to be linked to excessive synaptic pruning during adolescence in the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Schizophrenia is hypothesized to be linked to the growth of additional synaptic connections during adolescence.

text 1: Postmortem studies reveal gray matter loss in the prefrontal and temporal cerebral cortex in schizophrenia.
text 2: Postmortem studies reveal no significant gray matter changes in the cerebral cortex in schizophrenia.

text 1: D1 dopamine receptors in the prefrontal cortex are primarily associated with reducing motor symptoms.
text 2: D1 dopamine receptors in the prefrontal cortex are associated with working memory and executive functions.

text 1: Large-scale clinical trials have shown that second-generation antipsychotic drugs are drastically more effective than first-generation drugs.
text 2: Large-scale clinical trials have shown that the efficacy of second-generation antipsychotic drugs is no greater than that of first-generation drugs.

text 1: The mechanism by which clozapine has superior efficacy is entirely understood and attributed solely to serotonin receptor binding.
text 2: The mechanism by which clozapine has superior efficacy compared to other antipsychotics is not fully understood.

text 1: Some antipsychotic drugs cause Parkinson-like motor symptoms by decreasing dopaminergic transmission.
text 2: Some antipsychotic drugs cause Parkinson-like motor symptoms by increasing dopaminergic transmission.

text 1: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release was found to be lower in individuals with schizophrenia compared to healthy subjects.
text 2: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release was found to be greater in individuals with schizophrenia compared to healthy subjects.

text 1: Schizophrenia is characterized by dramatic psychotic symptoms and deficits in cognition, emotion, and motivation.
text 2: Schizophrenia is exclusively characterized by dramatic cognitive impairment without any psychotic symptoms.

text 1: The discovery of chlorpromazine's psychotic symptom-reducing effects was initially unexpected.
text 2: The discovery of chlorpromazine's psychotic symptom-reducing effects was initially planned and expected.

text 1: The striatum receives direct input solely from the brain stem structures.
text 2: The striatum receives direct input from most regions of the cerebral cortex and limbic structures.

text 1: In the striatum, inhibitory GABAergic medium spiny neurons are the principal cell type making up more than 90% of all neurons.
text 2: In the striatum, excitatory glutamatergic neurons are the principal cell type making up more than 90% of all neurons.

text 1: The striatum is the only component of the basal ganglia with excitatory output connections.
text 2: The subthalamic nucleus is the only component of the basal ganglia with excitatory output connections.

text 1: The substantia nigra pars compacta contains an important population of dopaminergic neurons.
text 2: The globus pallidus contains an important population of cholinergic neurons.

text 1: The substantia nigra pars reticulata and internal globus pallidus are the two principal output nuclei of the basal ganglia.
text 2: The striatum and subthalamic nucleus are the two principal output nuclei of the basal ganglia.

text 1: Inhibitory (GABAergic) inputs to substantia nigra pars reticulata come from the striatum and globus pallidus.
