text 2: Excitatory (glutamatergic) inputs to substantia nigra pars reticulata come from the striatum and globus pallidus.

text 1: The external globus pallidus is classified as an intrinsic nucleus as most of its connections are with other basal ganglia nuclei.
text 2: The subthalamic nucleus is classified as an intrinsic nucleus as most of its connections are with other basal ganglia nuclei.

text 1: The internal globus pallidus receives glutamatergic and excitatory input from the subthalamic nucleus.
text 2: The internal globus pallidus receives serotonergic and inhibitory input from the subthalamic nucleus.

text 1: Important modulatory input to the striatum comes from the internal globus pallidus (serotonin).
text 2: Important modulatory input to the striatum comes from the substantia nigra pars compacta (dopamine).

text 1: Neurons of the internal globus pallidus are themselves glutamatergic and have low levels of tonic activity.
text 2: Neurons of the internal globus pallidus are themselves GABAergic and have high levels of tonic activity.

text 1: The striatum is subdivided functionally based on topographically organized afferents from the thalamus.
text 2: The striatum is subdivided functionally based on topographically organized afferents from the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Volume transmission occurs when neurotransmitters diffuse through the brain's extracellular fluid.
text 2: Volume transmission occurs when neurotransmitters diffuse directly across synaptic clefts.

text 1: The external globus pallidus provides inhibitory efferent connections to all the basal ganglia's input and output nuclei.
text 2: The subthalamic nucleus provides inhibitory efferent connections to all the basal ganglia's input and output nuclei.

text 1: The subthalamic nucleus projects back to the striatum and to structures outside the basal ganglia.
text 2: The globus pallidus projects back to the striatum and to structures outside the basal ganglia.

text 1: The highest concentration of cholinergic terminals is found in the striatum.
text 2: The highest concentration of dopaminergic terminals is found in the striatum.

text 1: Different receptor types exhibit identical levels of spontaneous activity and therefore generate identical levels of cAMP.
text 2: Different receptor types exhibit different levels of spontaneous activity and therefore generate different levels of cAMP.

text 1: Guidance molecules such as neuropilins mediate interactions among axons that scatter them to random regions of the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Guidance molecules such as neuropilins mediate interactions among axons that guide them to appropriate regions of the olfactory bulb.

text 1: Activation of olfactory receptors in olfactory sensory neurons inhibits the activation of adenylyl cyclase.
text 2: Activation of olfactory receptors in olfactory sensory neurons leads to activation of adenylyl cyclase.

text 1: Postnatally, olfactory receptors are activated by odorant molecules, leading to the generation of distinct levels of cAMP.
text 2: Postnatally, olfactory receptors are deactivated by odorant molecules, leading to a uniform level of cAMP.

text 1: Guidance molecules mediate interactions that segregate axonal terminals into glomeruli.
text 2: Guidance molecules mediate interactions that merge axonal terminals into a single mass.

text 1: Basket cell axons select domains on Purkinje cells by ignoring neurofascin.
text 2: Baskets cell axons select domains on Purkinje cells by recognizing neurofascin.

text 1: In the cerebellum, basket cell axons contact the distal dendritic spines.
text 2: In the cerebellum, basket cell axons contact the axon hillock and initial segment.

text 1: Neurofascin is absent from the axonal initial segment, directing basket cells elsewhere.
text 2: Neurofascin is present at high levels on the axonal initial segment, directing basket cells there.

text 1: Neural activity sharpens synaptic specificity by refining synaptic patterns.
text 2: Neural activity dulls synaptic specificity by randomizing synaptic patterns.

text 1: Neural activity broadens the specificity of synaptic connections of retinal ganglion cells.
text 2: Neural activity refines the specificity of synaptic connections of retinal ganglion cells.

text 1: Electrical activity refines synaptic patterns by concentrating axonal branches.
text 2: Electrical activity disperses synaptic patterns by scattering axonal branches.

text 1: Abolishing electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells decreases the remodeling of dendritic and axonal arbors.
text 2: Abolishing electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells increases the remodeling of dendritic and axonal arbors.

text 1: Retinal ganglion cells project to the optic tectum in the visual system.
text 2: Retinal ganglion cells project to the posterior thalamus in the visual system.

text 1: Individual motor axons innervate muscle fibers of a single type, even in mixed muscles.
text 2: Individual motor axons randomly innervate muscle fibers of any type in mixed muscles.

text 1: Different patterns of neural activity in fast and slow motor neurons are responsible for the switch in muscle properties.
text 2: Identical patterns of neural activity in fast and slow motor neurons maintain the uniformity of muscle properties.

text 1: The basilar membrane at the base of the cochlea is broader and floppier than at the apex.
text 2: The basilar membrane at the base of the cochlea is narrower and stiffer than at the apex.

text 1: The threshold of human hearing corresponds to a root-mean-square sound pressure of 20 μPa.
text 2: The threshold of human hearing corresponds to a root-mean-square sound pressure of 120 μPa.

text 1: The stapes footplate exerts smaller pressure changes on the liquid of the scala vestibuli compared to the tympanum due to area differences.
text 2: The stapes footplate exerts larger pressure changes on the liquid of the scala vestibuli compared to the tympanum due to area differences.

text 1: The loudest tolerable sound for humans, approximately 120 dB SPL, transiently alters atmospheric pressure by ±1.0%.
text 2: The loudest tolerable sound for humans, approximately 120 dB SPL, transiently alters atmospheric pressure by ±0.01%.

text 1: The middle ear amplifies pressure changes by up to 300-fold to match the impedances of air and the cochlear partition.
text 2: The middle ear amplifies pressure changes by up to 30-fold to match the impedances of air and the cochlear partition.

text 1: Otosclerosis is a chronic condition that increases the motion of the ossicles, potentially leading to conductive hearing loss.
text 2: Otosclerosis is a chronic condition that reduces the motion of the ossicles, potentially leading to conductive hearing loss.

text 1: The characteristic place on the basilar membrane for high-frequency sounds is near the base, where the membrane is narrow and stiff.
text 2: The characteristic place on the basilar membrane for high-frequency sounds is near the apex, where the membrane is wide and floppy.

text 1: Georg von Békésy demonstrated that maximal basilar membrane motion occurs later along the cochlea for lower frequencies.
text 2: Georg von Békésy demonstrated that maximal basilar membrane motion occurs earlier along the cochlea for lower frequencies.

text 1: The mechanical properties of the tympanic membrane allow it to perform spectral analysis of complex sounds.
text 2: The mechanical properties of the basilar membrane allow it to perform spectral analysis of complex sounds.

text 1: The pressure changes induced by the stapes are transmitted through the scala vestibuli and scala tympani as a traveling wave.
text 2: The pressure changes induced by the stapes are transmitted directly through air to the cochlear partition.

text 1: The Rinné test can only identify sensorineural hearing loss.
text 2: The Rinné test can help distinguish between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.

text 1: Low-frequency sounds produce maximal basilar membrane motion near the cochlear apex, where the membrane is broader.
text 2: Low-frequency sounds produce maximal basilar membrane motion near the cochlear base, where the membrane is stiffer.

text 1: Amplification in the middle ear reduces the likelihood of conductive hearing loss by improving energy transfer.
text 2: Amplification in the inner ear reduces the likelihood of conductive hearing loss by improving energy transfer.

text 1: The tympanum vibrates in response to sound pressure changes, with movements that can be in the picometer range for soft sounds.
text 2: The tympanum vibrates in response to sound pressure changes, with movements that can be in the millimeter range for soft sounds.

text 1: Radial collagen fibers in the basilar membrane contribute to its stiffness and elasticity.
text 2: Radial collagen fibers in the basilar membrane contribute to its ability to vibrate in unison along its length.

text 1: Patients with lesions in the posterior parietal cortex show profound difficulty with simple tactile tasks and no motor deficits in skilled movements, and are clinically described as experiencing 'useless hand' syndrome.
text 2: Patients with lesions in the posterior parietal cortex show profound difficulty with complex tactile recognition tasks, severe motor deficits in skilled tasks, and are clinically described as experiencing 'useless hand' syndrome.

text 1: Lesions in S-I cortex result only in mild sensory deficits and no motor impairments, including normal performance on tactile discrimination tasks like vibration sense and stereognosis.
text 2: Lesions in S-I cortex result in severe sensory and motor deficits, including difficulty with tactile discrimination tasks like vibration sense and stereognosis.

text 1: Experimental ablation of somatosensory areas in monkeys has demonstrated improvement in tactile discrimination abilities, such as lower touch thresholds and enhanced vibration sense.
text 2: Experimental ablation of somatosensory areas in monkeys has demonstrated chronic tactile discrimination deficits, such as higher touch thresholds and impaired vibration sense.

text 1: The motor system can compensate for the absence of tactile information by generating more force than necessary during grasping.
text 2: The motor system becomes completely ineffective in the absence of tactile information, causing inability to perform grasping movements.

text 1: Patients with local anesthesia of sensory nerve fibers in the hand experience clumsy movements and rely entirely on vision for guidance.
text 2: Patients with local anesthesia of sensory nerve fibers in the hand experience enhanced coordination and no reliance on vision for movement guidance.

text 1: Damage to the cuneate fascicle in macaque monkeys results in impaired tactile discrimination and major deficits in fine finger movements.
text 2: Damage to the cuneate fascicle in macaque monkeys enhances tactile discrimination and improves fine finger movements.

text 1: Patients with demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis often retain touch and proprioception but lose temperature perception and nociception.
text 2: Patients with demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis often lose touch and proprioception but retain temperature perception and nociception.

text 1: Lesions to the anterior parietal lobe result in severe motor impairments but only moderate somatosensory impairments.
text 2: Lesions to the anterior parietal lobe result in severe somatosensory impairments but only moderate motor impairments.

text 1: During active touch, predictive mechanisms allow neurons in the posterior parietal cortex to compare planned and actual movements.
text 2: During active touch, predictive mechanisms inhibit neurons in the posterior parietal cortex from comparing planned and actual movements.

text 1: Patients with combined lesions to anterior and posterior parietal cortex exhibit no impairments in sensory and motor tests.
text 2: Patients with combined lesions to anterior and posterior parietal cortex exhibit severe impairments in both sensory and motor tests.

text 1: Damage to the dorsal column due to late-stage syphilis results in chronic deficits in temperature perception but little loss of touch and proprioception.
text 2: Damage to the dorsal column due to late-stage syphilis results in chronic deficits in touch and proprioception but little loss of temperature perception.

text 1: Skilled hand movements cease entirely and cannot rely on sensory feedback when tactile information is lost.
text 2: Skilled hand movements are predictive, relying on sensory feedback for adjustment when tactile information is lost.

text 1: Local anesthesia of the median and ulnar nerves results in enhanced force generation during grasping despite absence of tactile sensibility.
text 2: Local anesthesia of the median and ulnar nerves results in slow force generation during grasping due to absence of tactile sensibility.

text 1: Macaque monkeys exhibit enhanced tactile discrimination when neurons in the hand-representation region of area 2 are inhibited.
text 2: Macaque monkeys exhibit tactile discrimination deficits when neurons in the hand-representation region of area 2 are inhibited.

text 1: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex improve shaping and orienting the hand properly to grasp objects, reducing kinematic deficits.
text 2: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex interfere with shaping and orienting the hand properly to grasp objects, contributing to kinematic deficits.

text 1: Phenylketonuria (PKU) affects one in 15,000 children.
text 2: Phenylketonuria (PKU) affects one in 150,000 children.

text 1: Williams syndrome is caused by a heterozygous deletion of the chromosome region 7q11.23.
text 2: Williams syndrome is caused by a homozygous deletion of the chromosome region 7q11.23.

text 1: The treatment for PKU involves a low-protein diet.
text 2: The treatment for PKU involves a high-protein diet.

text 1: Fragile X syndrome has been mapped to multiple genes on the X chromosome.
text 2: Fragile X syndrome has been mapped to a single gene on the X chromosome.

text 1: The deletion of chromosome 22q11 is not associated with schizophrenia.
text 2: The deletion of chromosome 22q11 is associated with schizophrenia and childhood-onset schizophrenia.

text 1: Rett syndrome is a Y-linked progressive neurodevelopmental disorder.
text 2: Rett syndrome is an X-linked progressive neurodevelopmental disorder.

text 1: Huda Zoghbi found that Rett syndrome is caused by mutations in the FMRP gene.
text 2: Huda Zoghbi found that Rett syndrome is caused by mutations in the MeCP2 gene.

text 1: Rett syndrome is almost always confined to females as mutations are lethal in male embryos.
text 2: Rett syndrome is almost always confined to males as mutations are lethal in female embryos.

text 1: Fragile X syndrome results from mutations that enhance expression of the FMRP gene.
text 2: Fragile X syndrome results from mutations that reduce expression of the FMRP gene.

text 1: De novo copy number variations are more common in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
text 2: De novo copy number variations are less common in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.

text 1: Approximately 0.2% to 0.3% of the population is affected by autism spectrum disorders.
text 2: Approximately 2% to 3% of the population is affected by autism spectrum disorders.

text 1: Williams syndrome individuals typically excel in spatial processing.
text 2: Williams syndrome individuals are profoundly impaired in spatial processing.

text 1: There is a significant female predominance in autism spectrum disorders.
text 2: There is a significant male predominance in autism spectrum disorders.

text 1: About 30% of boys with fragile X syndrome meet diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder.
text 2: About 30% of girls with fragile X syndrome meet diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder.

text 1: The US has never instituted mandatory testing for PKU in newborns.
text 2: The US has mandatory testing for PKU in newborns since the early 1960s.

text 1: Neurodevelopmental disorders manifesting in childhood highlight the role of rare syndromes in understanding complex brain functions.
text 2: Neurodevelopmental disorders primarily manifest in adulthood, indicating the complexity of brain functions.

text 1: The MthK channel consists of two major functional domains: an integral membrane protein and an intracellular Ca2+-binding gating ring.
text 2: The MthK channel consists of three major functional domains: an integral membrane protein, an extracellular gating protein, and a cytoplasmic ion regulator.

text 1: The extracellular Ca2+-binding protein controls the gate of the MthK channel.
text 2: The intracellular Ca2+-binding gating ring of the MthK channel controls the gate.

text 1: The view described is from the intracellular side of the MthK channel in the Ca2+-bound closed state.
text 2: The view described is from the extracellular side of the MthK channel in the Ca2+-bound open state.

text 1: Glial cells play essential roles in modulating pathological processes within the nervous system.
text 2: Glial cells play no roles in modulating pathological processes within the nervous system.

text 1: The polarization of functional properties in neurons restricts the predominant flow of voltage impulses to one direction.
text 2: The polarization of functional properties in neurons allows voltage impulses to flow in multiple directions.

text 1: Neurons use voltage-gated channels to produce the currents that generate self-propagating action potentials.
text 2: Neurons use ligand-gated channels to produce the currents that generate self-propagating action potentials.

text 1: Receptor channels generate the resting potential and underlie the passive electrical properties of neurons.
text 2: Resting channels generate the resting potential and underlie the passive electrical properties of neurons.

text 1: The neuronal cytoskeletal structure mediates efficient transport of proteins, mRNAs, and organelles.
text 2: The neuronal cytoskeletal structure hinders the transport of proteins, mRNAs, and organelles.

text 1: Sensory receptor channels open in response to neurotransmitters, generating local synaptic potentials.
text 2: Ligand-gated channels open in response to neurotransmitters, generating local synaptic potentials.

text 1: Different varieties of glial cells regulate specific aspects of neuronal function.
text 2: Different varieties of nerve cells regulate specific aspects of glial function.

text 1: Neurons have multiple distinct cell plans.
text 2: Neurons are variations on one basic cell plan.

text 1: Nerve cells possess receptive axons at one end and communicating dendrites at the other.
text 2: Nerve cells possess receptive dendrites at one end and communicating axons at the other.

text 1: Glial cells support synaptic transmission and facilitate learning and memory.
text 2: Nerve cells support synaptic transmission and facilitate learning and memory.

text 1: In neurons, action potentials are primarily enabled by voltage-gated channels.
text 2: In neurons, action potentials are primarily enabled by sensory receptor channels.

text 1: In Part II, there is a focus on the resting and voltage-gated channels in neurons.
text 2: In Part II, there is a focus on ligand-gated and sensory receptor channels in neurons.

text 1: Genes do not control behavior directly, but the RNAs and proteins encoded by genes act at different times and at many levels to affect the brain.
text 2: Genes control behavior directly and do not act at different times or levels to influence the brain.

text 1: Genes specify the developmental programs that assemble the brain and are essential to the properties of neurons, glia, and synapses that allow neuronal circuits to function.
text 2: Genes do not specify the developmental programs for the brain and are unrelated to the functionality of neurons, glia, and synapses.

text 1: Human psychiatric disorders and neurological diseases are never influenced by genetic components.
text 2: Many human psychiatric disorders and neurological diseases have a genetic component.

text 1: The extent to which environmental factors account for traits in a population is called heritability.
text 2: The extent to which genetic factors account for traits in a population is called heritability.

text 1: Identical twins tend to be more similar (concordant) for neurological and psychiatric traits than fraternal twins, providing evidence of a heritable component of these traits.
text 2: Fraternal twins tend to be more similar (concordant) for neurological and psychiatric traits than identical twins.

text 1: Estimates of heritability for neurological, psychiatric, and behavioral traits from twin studies are usually close to 0%.
text 2: Estimates of heritability for many neurological, psychiatric, and behavioral traits from twin studies are around 50%.

text 1: RNA replication ensures that nearly all of the genome is double-stranded.
text 2: DNA replication ensures that nearly all of the genome is double-stranded.

text 1: RNA is double-stranded like DNA and uses thymine instead of uridine.
text 2: RNA differs from DNA in that it is single-stranded, has a ribose rather than a deoxyribose backbone, and uses the nucleoside base uridine in the place of thymine.

text 1: A typical protein-coding gene consists only of coding regions without any noncoding regions.
text 2: A typical protein-coding gene consists of a coding region, which is translated into the protein, and noncoding regions.

text 1: Exons are the small coding segments of a typical protein-coding gene.
text 2: Introns are the small coding segments of a typical protein-coding gene.

text 1: The hippocampal formation is made up of several distinct cortical regions that are simpler in organization than the neocortex.
text 2: The hippocampal formation is made up of several distinct cortical regions that are more complex in organization than the neocortex.

text 1: The perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices are located in the occipital lobe.
text 2: The perirhinal and parahippocampal cortices are located in the medial temporal lobe.

text 1: Chapter 5 introduces the idea that the hippocampus encodes information about an animal’s spatial location in its environment.
text 2: Chapter 5 introduces the idea that the hippocampus is responsible for processing auditory information.

text 1: The entorhinal cortex lacks a layer IV and has a much more prominent layer II.
text 2: The entorhinal cortex has a prominent layer IV and lacks layer II.

text 1: The simplest subregion of the hippocampal formation is the dentate gyrus, which has multiple principal neurons of varied types.
text 2: The simplest subregion of the hippocampal formation is the dentate gyrus, which has a single principal neuron called the granule cell.

text 1: The hippocampal formation is responsible for the long-term storage of memories within itself.
text 2: The hippocampal formation is essential for the initial formation of memories, but these memories are ultimately stored elsewhere in the brain.

text 1: Damage to any one component of the hippocampal system would not affect memory formation.
text 2: Damage to any one component of the hippocampal system would lead to memory impairment.

text 1: The hippocampal circuit is closed by feedback pathways from the entorhinal cortex.
text 2: The hippocampal circuit is closed when the subiculum projects to the deep layers of the entorhinal cortex.

text 1: The hippocampal memory system is organized for reciprocal processing of simple information.
text 2: The hippocampal memory system is organized largely for serial processing of complex information.

text 1: Sensory systems are hierarchical and process progressively more complex stimuli at higher levels, especially in the neocortex.
text 2: Sensory systems randomly process stimuli without any hierarchy, ignoring the complexity at different levels.

text 1: The hippocampal system receives input directly from the occipital, parahippocampal, and retrosplenial cortices.
text 2: The hippocampal system receives input from the perirhinal, parahippocampal, and retrosplenial cortices.

text 1: In the hippocampal formation, the dendrites of CA3 pyramidal cells are confined solely within the cell body layer.
text 2: In the hippocampal formation, the dendrites of CA3 pyramidal cells extend above and below the cell body layer.

text 1: Somatic motor and sensory representation in the cerebral cortex of humans were studied exclusively through fMRI.
text 2: Somatic motor and sensory representation in the cerebral cortex of humans was studied by electrical stimulation.

text 1: Explicit memory and spatial representation rely on plastic changes in synaptic function.
text 2: Explicit memory and spatial representation rely on fixed synaptic structures.

text 1: The entorhinal cortex is the simplest part of the hippocampal formation due to its single-layered structure.
text 2: The entorhinal cortex is the most complex part of the hippocampal formation due to its multiple layers.

text 1: The spinothalamic tract is the most prominent ascending nociceptive pathway in the spinal cord.
text 2: The spinothalamic tract is the least prominent ascending nociceptive pathway in the spinal cord.

text 1: The spinoreticular tract is implicated more in the processing of acute, sharply localized pains.
text 2: The spinoreticular tract is implicated more in the processing of diffuse, poorly localized pains.

text 1: The spinohypothalamic tract contains axons of neurons found in spinal cord laminae I, V, VII, and VIII.
text 2: The spinohypothalamic tract contains axons of neurons found in spinal cord laminae II, III, and VI.

text 1: The spinoparabrachial tract projects to the parabrachial nucleus at the level of the pons.
text 2: The spinoparabrachial tract projects to the medulla oblongata at the level of the pons.

text 1: The lateral thalamus processes information about the diffuse location of an injury conveyed as chronic pain.
text 2: The lateral thalamus processes information about the precise location of an injury conveyed as acute pain.

text 1: Patients with insular cortex lesions may perceive noxious stimuli as painful but fail to display appropriate emotional responses.
text 2: Patients with insular cortex lesions are unable to perceive noxious stimuli as painful.

text 1: The anterior cingulate and insular cortex are not associated with the perception of pain.
text 2: The anterior cingulate and insular cortex are associated with the perception of pain.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the thalamus can result in intense pain sensations.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the thalamus typically results in no sensation of pain.

text 1: The spinothalamic tract has extensive, bilateral receptive fields.
text 2: The spinothalamic tract has discrete, unilateral receptive fields.

text 1: The medial nuclear group of the thalamus includes the medial dorsal and central lateral nucleus.
text 2: The medial nuclear group of the thalamus includes the lateral dorsal and central medial nucleus.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral thalamic nuclei have large receptive fields not matching those of presynaptic spinal neurons.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral thalamic nuclei have small receptive fields matching those of presynaptic spinal neurons.

text 1: The topographic map of the body in the thalamus and somatosensory cortex is fixed and does not change.
text 2: The topographic map of the body in the thalamus and somatosensory cortex can change with use and disuse.

text 1: Cortical reorganization may contribute to phantom limb pain.
text 2: Cortical reorganization prevents phantom limb pain.

text 1: Lesioning the spinothalamic tract can result in a marked reduction in pain sensation on the contralateral side.
text 2: Lesioning the spinothalamic tract increases pain sensation on the ipsilateral side.

text 1: The anterior cingulate gyrus is not involved in processing emotional states associated with pain.
text 2: The anterior cingulate gyrus is involved in processing emotional states associated with pain.

text 1: TRPV1 channels are activated by noxious thermal stimuli with a threshold around 45°C, the temperature that provokes heat pain.
text 2: TRPV1 channels are activated by noxious thermal stimuli with a threshold around 25°C, the temperature that provokes heat pain.

text 1: Silent nociceptors are predominantly found in the skin and are typically activated by mild stimulation, regardless of inflammation or chemical agents.
text 2: Silent nociceptors are found in viscera and are typically not activated by noxious stimulation, but inflammation and chemical agents reduce their firing threshold.

text 1: Nav1.7 is a voltage-gated calcium channel that plays no role in the perception of pain or mutations related to it.
text 2: Nav1.7 is a voltage-gated sodium channel that is a key molecular mechanism in the perception of pain, and mutations in its SCN9A gene can lead to insensitivity to pain.

text 1: Neuropathic pain, unlike nociceptive pain, does not respond well to NSAIDs and is generally poorly responsive to opiates.
text 2: Neuropathic pain responds extremely well to NSAIDs as a primary treatment and often does not require any additional medications.

text 1: Patients with allodynia feel pain in response to normally innocuous stimuli, such as light stroking of sunburned skin.
text 2: Patients with allodynia feel constant pain even in the absence of peripheral stimulation, without any external stimulus.

text 1: TRPM8 channels are heat-sensing and mustard oil-responsive, and they mediate extreme heat hypersensitivity caused by drugs like oxaliplatin.
text 2: TRPM8 channels are cold-sensing and menthol-responsive, and they mediate extreme cold hypersensitivity caused by drugs like oxaliplatin.

text 1: The activation threshold of TRPV1 is enhanced by inflammation and a reduction in pH levels.
text 2: The activation threshold of TRPV1 is unaffected by pH levels or inflammation.

text 1: Referred pain occurs because some lamina V neurons receive sensory input from both visceral and somatic regions, leading to the brain misattributing the source of the pain.
text 2: Referred pain occurs because lamina V neurons exclusively process input from visceral tissues, ignoring somatic inputs.

text 1: Nociceptive pain often involves inflammation and activation of nociceptors in response to tissue injury.
text 2: Nociceptive pain occurs without inflammation or activation of nociceptors, as it is purely psychological.

text 1: C fibers transmit fast, sharp pain, while Aδ fibers transmit slow, dull pain.
text 2: Aδ fibers transmit fast, sharp pain, while C fibers transmit slow, dull pain.

text 1: Lamina II, also called the substantia gelatinosa, contains excitatory and inhibitory interneurons involved in pain and itch processing.
text 2: Lamina II, also called the substantia gelatinosa, exclusively contains projecting neurons for pain processing.

text 1: Bradykinin activates TRPV1 and regulates its activity through signaling pathways involving phospholipase C (PLC) and protein kinase C (PKC).
text 2: Bradykinin directly inhibits TRPV1, preventing its activation by thermal stimuli.

text 1: Erythromelalgia is caused by mutations in the SCN9A gene, resulting in complete insensitivity to pain and loss of nociceptor function.
text 2: Erythromelalgia is caused by mutations in the SCN9A gene, leading to hyperexcitability of nociceptors and intense burning pain.

text 1: Afferent nociceptive neurons have cell bodies located in the substantia gelatinosa and project outward to the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Afferent nociceptive neurons have cell bodies located in the dorsal root ganglia and project centrally to the spinal cord.

text 1: Lidocaine blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels, effectively providing pain relief during dental procedures.
text 2: Lidocaine blocks voltage-gated Ca2+ channels, which specifically target temperature-sensing pathways.

text 1: Face-specific processing in the human fusiform gyrus is highlighted in the study by McCarthy et al. 1997.
text 2: Face-specific processing in the human fusiform gyrus is highlighted in the study by Sirotin et al. 2009.

text 1: Moeller et al. 2008 discussed a unified system for processing faces in the macaque temporal lobe.
text 2: Moeller et al. 2008 discussed a unified system for processing faces in the human frontal lobe.

text 1: Norman et al. 2006 focused on single-voxel pattern analysis of fMRI data.
text 2: Norman et al. 2006 focused on multi-voxel pattern analysis of fMRI data.

text 1: O’Doherty et al. 2007 applied model-based fMRI to visual perception studies.
text 2: O’Doherty et al. 2007 applied model-based fMRI to reward learning and decision making.

text 1: Owen et al. 2006 discussed detecting awareness in the lucid dream state.
text 2: Owen et al. 2006 discussed detecting awareness in the vegetative state.

text 1: Schapiro et al. 2012 focused on shaping of object representations based on temporal regularities.
text 2: Schapiro et al. 2012 focused on shaping object representations based on spatial irregularities.

text 1: Sirotin and Das 2009 found anticipatory haemodynamic signals not predicted by local neuronal activity.
text 2: Sirotin and Das 2009 found anticipatory haemodynamic signals directly predicted by local neuronal activity.

text 1: Squire 1992 synthesized findings regarding memory and the amygdala from rats, monkeys, and humans.
text 2: Squire 1992 synthesized findings regarding memory and the hippocampus from rats, monkeys, and humans.

text 1: Turk-Browne 2013 discussed functional interactions as small data in the human brain.
text 2: Turk-Browne 2013 discussed functional interactions as big data in the human brain.

text 1: Wagner et al. 1998 focused on building memories and brain activity predicting the remembering and forgetting of verbal experiences.
text 2: Wagner et al. 1998 focused on building memories and brain activity predicting the remembering and forgetting of visual experiences.

text 1: Wimmer and Shohamy 2012 studied how memory mechanisms in the hippocampus bias decisions.
text 2: Wimmer and Shohamy 2012 studied how memory mechanisms in the hippocampus simplify decisions.

text 1: Yarkoni et al. 2011 worked on large-scale automated synthesis of human functional neuroimaging data.
text 2: Yarkoni et al. 2011 worked on small-scale manual synthesis of human functional neuroimaging data.

text 1: McCarthy et al. 1997 worked on motion-specific processing in the fusiform gyrus.
text 2: McCarthy et al. 1997 worked on face-specific processing in the fusiform gyrus.

text 1: Moeller et al. 2008 studied patches with links for face processing in the macaque temporal lobe.
text 2: Moeller et al. 2008 studied patches with links for face processing in the human parietal lobe.

text 1: Turk-Browne 2013 found functional interactions as big data in the human brain.
text 2: Turk-Browne 2013 found functional interactions as minimal data in the human brain.

text 1: Vestibular receptor hair cells are mechanotransducers that exclusively sense rotational accelerations.
text 2: Vestibular receptor hair cells are mechanotransducers that sense rotational and linear accelerations.

text 1: Vestibular signals are used solely for motion perception.
text 2: Vestibular signals are used for balance, visual stability, spatial orientation, movement planning, and motion perception.

text 1: Damage to the hippocampal region improves spatial and directional abilities.
text 2: Damage to the hippocampal region impairs a variety of spatial and directional abilities.

text 1: Head direction cells indicate the animal's heading direction like a compass.
text 2: Head direction cells indicate the animal's heading direction in a random, non-specific manner.

text 1: Cold water introduced into the ear produces nystagmus beating to the opposite side.
text 2: Cold water introduced into the ear produces nystagmus beating to the same side.

text 1: Grid cells respond to multiple spatial locations in a unique triangular grid pattern.
text 2: Grid cells respond to multiple spatial locations in a random circular pattern.

text 1: Lesions of central vestibular networks disrupt head direction, place, and grid responses.
text 2: Lesions of central vestibular networks enhance head direction, place, and grid responses.

text 1: Rotation excites hair cells in semicircular canals oriented in the motion direction.
text 2: Rotation inhibits hair cells in semicircular canals oriented in the motion direction.

text 1: Vestibular nuclei responses are directly linked to driving spatially tuned cells.
text 2: Vestibular nuclei responses are inappropriate for driving spatially tuned cells.

text 1: Bilateral vestibular hypofunction is sometimes caused by ototoxicity from medications like gentamicin.
text 2: Bilateral vestibular hypofunction never involves ototoxicity from medications like gentamicin.

text 1: Warm water introduced into the ear induces nystagmus beating toward the same side.
text 2: Warm water introduced into the ear induces nystagmus beating toward the opposite side.

text 1: Spontaneous regeneration of vestibular hair cells occurs in humans but not in amphibians, reptiles, and birds.
text 2: Spontaneous regeneration of vestibular hair cells occurs in amphibians, reptiles, and birds.

text 1: Nystagmus can be induced by caloric irrigation as part of vestibular diagnostic tests.
text 2: Nystagmus cannot be induced by caloric irrigation and is unrelated to vestibular diagnostic tests.

text 1: Patients with vestibular system trauma may exhibit severe deficits in spatial orientation.
text 2: Patients with vestibular system trauma exhibit improved spatial orientation.

text 1: Vestibular signals reach navigation circuits and influence spatially tuned cells through indirect pathways.
text 2: Vestibular signals directly project to navigation circuits to influence spatially tuned cells.

text 1: When a well-hydrated cheetah comes across a watering hole during a search for antelopes, the sight of the water may serve as an incentive stimulus.
text 2: When a dehydrated cheetah comes across a watering hole during a search for antelopes, the sight of the water may serve as an incentive stimulus.

text 1: Brain stimulation can compete with, summate with, or substitute for other reward-predictive stimuli to induce motivational states.
text 2: Brain stimulation can only substitute for other reward-predictive stimuli to induce motivational states.

text 1: The ventral tegmental area plays a crucial role in brain stimulation reward and is influenced by dopaminergic pathways.
text 2: The ventral tegmental area plays a crucial role in brain stimulation reward and is influenced by serotonergic pathways.

text 1: Rats will avoid electrified grids and refrain from pressing a lever in order to trigger brain stimulation reward.
text 2: Rats will cross electrified grids or press a lever for hours on end in order to trigger brain stimulation reward.

text 1: In experiments, cocaine and nicotine influence the rate of electrical self-stimulation in animals by enhancing dopaminergic neurotransmission.
text 2: In experiments, cocaine and nicotine influence the rate of electrical self-stimulation in animals by inhibiting dopaminergic neurotransmission.

text 1: Addiction can reflect the avoidance of short-term pleasure despite long-term life problems emerging.
text 2: Addiction can reflect the habitual choice of short-term pleasure despite long-term life problems emerging.

text 1: Dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area project to areas including the nucleus accumbens and the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: Dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area project exclusively to the hippocampus and amygdala.

text 1: Dopamine is now considered to not produce hedonic qualities itself but to act as a learning signal.
text 2: Dopamine is now considered to be directly responsible for hedonic qualities and not act as a learning signal.

text 1: Many brain areas modulated by reward anticipation or receipt receive dopaminergic input.
text 2: Few brain areas modulated by reward anticipation or receipt receive dopaminergic input.

text 1: Motivational states are irrelevant to achieving complex long-term goals.
text 2: Motivational states must be sustained across challenging circumstances to achieve complex long-term goals.

text 1: Brain stimulation reward is only indicated by increased food consumption in the absence of drugs like cocaine and nicotine.
text 2: Brain stimulation reward is indicated by behaviors such as lever pressing in the presence of drugs like cocaine and nicotine.

text 1: Inhibition of dopaminergic neurons is a crucial component of the brain stimulation reward process.
text 2: Activation of dopaminergic neurons is part of the brain stimulation reward process.

text 1: Cholinergic input from the hindbrain plays a role in activating dopaminergic neurons during brain stimulation reward.
text 2: GABAergic input from the hindbrain plays a role in activating dopaminergic neurons during brain stimulation reward.

text 1: The absence of self-stimulation behavior is akin to behaviors seen in drug abuse.
text 2: The avidity of self-stimulation behavior is comparable to behaviors seen in drug abuse.

text 1: Electric brain stimulation has been shown to have little effect on motivational states and goal-directed behaviors.
text 2: Electric brain stimulation has been shown to influence motivational states by creating a strong drive for goal-directed behaviors.

text 1: Brain areas involved in reward processing exclude the prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens.
text 2: Brain areas involved in reward processing include the prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens.

text 1: Experimental treatments such as deep brain stimulation are being investigated for treatment of major depression and other psychiatric disorders.
text 2: Experimental treatments such as deep brain stimulation are not being investigated for treatment of major depression and other psychiatric disorders.

text 1: Cade’s observations initiated the modern era of psychopharmacology in which drugs are used to treat specific symptoms of mental disorders.
text 2: Cade’s observations initiated the modern era of psychopharmacology in which drugs are used to cure all mental disorders.

text 1: Bipolar disorder can be treated exclusively with first-generation antipsychotic drugs.
text 2: Bipolar disorder can be treated with lithium, certain anticonvulsant drugs such as valproic acid, and second-generation antipsychotic drugs.

text 1: Lithium was found ineffective in treating acute episodes of mania and did not help in stabilizing mood.
text 2: Lithium eventually proved to be effective in treating acute episodes of mania and in stabilizing mood by reducing the frequency of cycling into mania and depression.

text 1: Several drugs initially developed to treat epilepsy have also been shown to be effective in treating acute mania and for mood stabilization.
text 2: Several drugs developed to treat epilepsy are ineffective against acute mania and do not aid in mood stabilization.

text 1: Major depression is rare with less than 5% lifetime prevalence.
text 2: Major depression is common with a 15%–20% lifetime prevalence.

text 1: Anxiety disorders often co-occur with major depression.
text 2: Anxiety disorders rarely co-occur with major depression.

text 1: Bipolar disorder is less heritable than major depression or anxiety disorders.
text 2: Bipolar disorder is more heritable than major depression or anxiety disorders.

text 1: Mood and anxiety disorders have both genetic and nongenetic components of risk.
text 2: Mood and anxiety disorders have exclusively genetic components of risk.

text 1: Lithium's most likely molecular target is enhancement of glycogen synthase kinase type 3β.
text 2: Lithium's most likely molecular target is inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase type 3β.

text 1: Second-generation antipsychotic drugs have the highest affinity for D2 dopamine receptors compared to all other drugs.
text 2: Second-generation antipsychotic drugs have somewhat lower affinity for D2 dopamine receptors.

text 1: The neural circuitry of fear and anxiety disorders involves the hippocampus and cerebellum with no connection to the prefrontal cortex.
text 2: The neural circuitry of fear and anxiety disorders involves the amygdala and its interconnections with the prefrontal cortex.

text 1: Major depression and anxiety disorders can only be treated with physical exercise and diet change.
text 2: Major depression and anxiety disorders can be treated with diverse antidepressant drugs and by cognitive and behavioral therapies.

text 1: Electroconvulsive therapy is never effective for major depression that is unresponsive to medications.
text 2: Electroconvulsive therapy is effective for major depression that is unresponsive to medications.

text 1: Second-generation drugs for bipolar disorder also block serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.
text 2: Second-generation drugs for bipolar disorder only block D1 dopamine receptors.

text 1: The right hemisphere develops more specialization for language processing as maturation and learning occur.
text 2: The left hemisphere develops more specialization for language processing as maturation and learning occur.

text 1: Broca’s aphasia is caused by lesions of the dorsal stream, impairing grammatical processing and speech production.
text 2: Broca’s aphasia is caused by lesions of the ventral stream, enhancing grammatical processing and speech production.

text 1: Studies of infants show that native and nonnative speech syllables activate only the superior parietal regions.
text 2: Studies of infants show that native and nonnative speech syllables activate both inferior frontal regions and the cerebellum.

text 1: Prosody engages exclusively the left hemisphere for all types of information conveyed.
text 2: Prosody engages both the right and left hemispheres depending on the information conveyed.

text 1: Aphasias such as Broca's aphasia result from damage to the dorsal stream of language processing.
text 2: Aphasias such as Broca's aphasia result from enhancement of the dorsal stream of language processing.

text 1: Infants have increased motor activation in response to nonnative sounds as they struggle to generate motor plans.
text 2: Infants have decreased motor activation in response to nonnative sounds due to easy generation of motor plans.

text 1: EEG and MEG studies on young infants show that only the right hemisphere is activated by speech.
text 2: EEG and MEG studies on young infants show that the inferior frontal and temporal cortices are activated bilaterally by speech.

text 1: Helen Neville's studies show that linguistic information is only processed if it is conveyed auditorily.
text 2: Helen Neville's studies show that linguistic information, regardless of modality, is processed in the language network.

text 1: Evidence suggests left hemisphere specialization for language develops rapidly in infancy.
text 2: Evidence suggests right hemisphere specialization for language develops rapidly in infancy.

text 1: Neuroscientist Ping Mamiya demonstrated that immersion in a second language has no effect on white matter integrity.
text 2: Neuroscientist Ping Mamiya demonstrated that immersion in a second language in adulthood affects white matter integrity.

text 1: Deaf individuals process sign language in left hemisphere speech-processing regions.
text 2: Deaf individuals process sign language in right hemisphere emotional-processing regions.

text 1: Motor learning is crucial for linking auditory patterns to motor plans in language development.
text 2: Motor learning is irrelevant to linking auditory patterns to motor plans in language development.

text 1: Studies of 7-month-old infants show that gray matter concentrations in the cerebellum correlate with word production at 1 year.
text 2: Studies of 7-month-old infants show that gray matter concentrations in the cerebellum are unrelated to word production.

text 1: Chomsky's view supports the innate language capabilities evident in brain activation at birth.
text 2: Chomsky's view contradicts the innate language capabilities evident in brain activation at birth.

text 1: In adults, the dorsal pathway limits its connections to only temporal areas as compared to 7-year-olds.
text 2: In adults, the dorsal pathway exceeds its connections beyond the inferior frontal gyrus as compared to 7-year-olds.

text 1: Dehydration increases the activity of neurons in the SFO, OVLT, and MnPO, enhancing thirst and vasopressin secretion.
text 2: Dehydration decreases the activity of neurons in the SFO, OVLT, and MnPO, reducing thirst and vasopressin secretion.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the lamina terminalis structures suppresses drinking behavior.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the lamina terminalis structures elicits drinking behavior.

text 1: Leptin is a hormone secreted by adipocytes in proportion to fat stores size.
text 2: Leptin is a hormone secreted by pancreatic beta cells in proportion to fat stores size.

text 1: High blood volume is detected by the kidney, which increases its secretion of renin.
text 2: Low blood volume is detected by the kidney, which increases its secretion of renin.

text 1: Thirst is controlled by neurons in the OVLT, MnPO, and SFO.
text 2: Thirst is controlled by neurons in the amygdala and hippocampus.

text 1: Sympathetically controlled energy expenditure includes adaptive thermogenesis.
text 2: Sympathetically controlled energy expenditure includes digestion.

text 1: Renin converts circulating angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.
text 2: Renin converts circulating angiotensin I to angiotensinogen.

text 1: Insulin's primary function is to control blood glucose.
text 2: Insulin's primary function is to control blood osmolarity.

text 1: Amylin and insulin are released by β-cells after a meal.
text 2: Amylin and insulin are released by α-cells after a meal.

text 1: The physiological significance of ghrelin remains unclear because its gene deletion does not appear to affect hunger.
text 2: Ghrelin dramatically affects hunger and deleting its gene leads to increased appetite.

text 1: Leptin’s function varies widely across species.
text 2: Leptin’s function is highly conserved across species.

text 1: Circuits regulating energy balance rely solely on mineral ions.
text 2: Circuits regulating energy balance involve a significant role for neuropeptides.

text 1: The arcuate nucleus plays a role in controlling energy balance and hunger.
text 2: The arcuate nucleus is unrelated to energy balance and hunger control.

text 1: Fat can be stored when energy intake exceeds expenditure.
text 2: Fat cannot be stored regardless of energy intake versus expenditure.

text 1: ANG II excites SFO neurons that drive vasopressin and thirst neurons.
text 2: ANG II inhibits SFO neurons that drive vasopressin and thirst neurons.

text 1: Excessive energy storage promotes diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.
text 2: Excessive energy storage prevents diseases such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.

text 1: Long-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex of Aplysia primarily involves the inhibition of transmitter release at the synapses between sensory and motor neurons.
text 2: Long-term sensitization of the gill-withdrawal reflex of Aplysia involves long-lasting facilitation of transmitter release at the synapses between sensory and motor neurons.

text 1: Repeated tail shock in Aplysia leads to more pronounced elevation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), producing long-term facilitation that outlasts the increase in cAMP.
text 2: Repeated tail shock in Aplysia leads to a transient decrease in cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), thereby halting long-term facilitation.

text 1: The transcriptional activator cAMP response element binding protein 1 (CREB-1) binds to cAMP regulatory elements (CRE), repressing gene transcription in Aplysia.
text 2: The transcriptional activator cAMP response element binding protein 1 (CREB-1) binds to cAMP regulatory elements (CRE), activating gene transcription in Aplysia.

text 1: Protein kinase A (PKA) activates MAPK, which enhances CREB-2's inhibitory action during long-term memory consolidation.
text 2: Protein kinase A (PKA) activates MAPK, which phosphorylates the transcriptional repressor CREB-2, removing its inhibitory action during long-term memory consolidation.

text 1: CREB-1 represses the expression of C/EBP, which is critical for suppressing the growth of new synaptic connections.
text 2: CREB-1 activates the expression of C/EBP, a transcription factor important for the growth of new synaptic connections.

text 1: Histone acetylation, facilitated by CBP, increases the affinity of histones for DNA, thereby restricting access for transcriptional machinery.
text 2: Histone acetylation, facilitated by CBP, decreases the affinity of histones for DNA, thus improving access for transcriptional machinery.

text 1: Serotonin increases levels of miRNA-124, thereby inhibiting the translation of CREB-1 mRNA and preventing memory consolidation.
text 2: Serotonin decreases levels of miRNA-124, thereby disinhibiting the translation of CREB-1 mRNA and facilitating memory consolidation.

text 1: Ubiquitin hydrolase, expressed following CREB-1 activation, prevents the degradation of PKA's regulatory subunit, suppressing persistent PKA activity.
text 2: Ubiquitin hydrolase, expressed following CREB-1 activation, facilitates the degradation of PKA's regulatory subunit, enhancing persistent PKA activity.

text 1: Epigenetic regulation, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, plays a crucial role in memory consolidation by modulating chromatin accessibility.
text 2: Epigenetic regulation, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, plays no role in memory consolidation or chromatin accessibility.

text 1: PiRNA-F decreases in response to serotonin and prevents methylation of the promoter of CREB-2, thereby increasing its gene transcription.
text 2: PiRNA-F increases in response to serotonin and leads to the methylation of the promoter of CREB-2, thereby reducing its gene transcription.

text 1: CREB-2 acts as a transcriptional activator that promotes gene expression during memory formation.
text 2: CREB-2 acts as a transcriptional repressor that reduces gene expression during memory formation.

text 1: The threshold for long-term memory storage is unaffected by the presence of either a repressor (CREB-2) or an activator (CREB-1).
text 2: The threshold for long-term memory storage is influenced by the presence of both a repressor (CREB-2) and an activator (CREB-1).

text 1: Noncoding RNAs, such as miRNAs and piRNAs, play no role in transcriptional or posttranscriptional regulation for long-term facilitation.
text 2: Noncoding RNAs, such as miRNAs and piRNAs, regulate transcriptional and posttranscriptional mechanisms critical for long-term facilitation.

text 1: The transcription factor C/EBP, activated by CREB-1, is crucial for synthesizing proteins required for the growth of new synaptic connections.
text 2: The transcription factor C/EBP, activated by CREB-1, inhibits the synthesis of proteins required for the growth of new synaptic connections.

text 1: Serotonin's regulation of both miRNAs and piRNAs ensures coordinated activation of CREB-1 and suppression of CREB-2 during memory consolidation.
text 2: Serotonin's regulation of both miRNAs and piRNAs suppresses CREB-1 activity while enhancing CREB-2, thereby disrupting memory consolidation.

text 1: The fronto-orbital cortex and several gyri, including the precentral, superior frontal, and lingual gyri, occupy a significantly larger volume in adult men compared to adult women.
text 2: The fronto-orbital cortex and several gyri, including the precentral, superior frontal, and lingual gyri, occupy a significantly larger volume in adult women compared to adult men.

text 1: Stereo hormonal actions or experiences can result in sexual dimorphisms in the human brain.
text 2: Sexual dimorphisms in the human brain likely arise solely from genetic factors.

text 1: In girls with CAH, early exposure to androgens is correlated with subsequent changes in gender-related behaviors.
text 2: In girls with CAH, early exposure to estrogens is correlated with subsequent changes in gender-related behaviors.

text 1: Postmortem studies show that adults who had been abused as children exhibit lower promoter methylation of their glucocorticoid receptor genes.
text 2: Postmortem studies show that adults who had been abused as children exhibit greater promoter methylation of their glucocorticoid receptor genes.

text 1: In 5α-reductase II deficiency, symptoms arise from a defect in estrogen processing largely confined to the developing external genitalia.
text 2: In 5α-reductase II deficiency, symptoms arise from a defect in testosterone processing largely confined to the developing external genitalia.

text 1: Both CAIS and 5α-reductase II deficiency result in individuals being mistakenly raised as males until puberty.
text 2: Both CAIS and 5α-reductase II deficiency may result in individuals being mistakenly raised as females until puberty.

text 1: Most CAIS patients express a female gender identity and a sexual preference for men.
text 2: Most CAIS patients express a male gender identity and a sexual preference for women.

text 1: Humans do not have a functional vomeronasal organ (VNO).
text 2: Humans have a fully functional vomeronasal organ (VNO).

text 1: EST is present at higher concentrations in male sweat compared to female sweat.
text 2: AND is present at higher concentrations in male sweat compared to female sweat.

text 1: Hormonal influences are thought to underlie the dimorphism of the BNST in humans.
text 2: Genetic factors are solely responsible for the dimorphism of the BNST in humans.

text 1: The volume of the sexually dimorphic BNST is large in male-to-female transsexuals compared to men.
text 2: The volume of the sexually dimorphic BNST is small in male-to-female transsexuals compared to men.

text 1: Chemicals such as androstadienone (AND) and estratetraenol (EST) can produce sexual arousal in humans even at low concentrations.
text 2: Chemicals such as androstadienone (AND) and estratetraenol (EST) do not produce any sexual arousal in humans regardless of concentration.

text 1: The presence of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome directs the gonad to form testes.
text 2: The absence of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome directs the gonad to form testes.

text 1: 5α-reductase II patients experience a large increase in estrogen at puberty, leading to virilization.
text 2: 5α-reductase II patients experience a large increase in testosterone at puberty, leading to virilization.

text 1: Imaging studies suggest that homosexual men’s brains resemble those of heterosexual men.
text 2: Imaging studies suggest that homosexual men’s brains resemble those of heterosexual women.

text 1: Adult neurogenesis is primarily limited to inhibitory granule neurons in the hippocampus and excitatory granule neurons of the olfactory bulb.
text 2: Adult neurogenesis is primarily limited to inhibitory granule neurons in the olfactory bulb and excitatory granule neurons of the dentate gyrus.

text 1: LTP at the recurrent synapses between CA1 neurons is important for pattern completion.
text 2: LTP at the recurrent synapses between CA3 neurons is important for pattern completion.

text 1: Genetic silencing of CA2 disrupts the ability of a mouse to remember encounters with other mice, but does not impair other forms of hippocampal-dependent memory.
text 2: Genetic silencing of CA1 disrupts the ability of a mouse to remember encounters with other mice, but does not impair other forms of hippocampal-dependent memory.

text 1: Grid cells represent space using a hexagonal grid-like array, with firing unrelated to any specific landmarks or visual input.
text 2: Grid cells represent space using a circular grid-like array, depending heavily on specific landmarks and visual input.

text 1: Place cells in the hippocampus fire selectively when the animal is located at specific positions in its environment.
text 2: Place cells in the hippocampus fire constantly, irrespective of the animal's location in its environment.

text 1: Head direction cells encode the direction the animal is facing, often exhibiting grid-like firing properties in conjunction with spatial information.
text 2: Head direction cells encode the speed at which the animal is running, with no relation to the direction the animal is facing.

text 1: Object-vector cells encode an animal's distance and direction relative to salient landmarks.
text 2: Object-vector cells encode an animal's speed and acceleration irrespective of salient landmarks.

text 1: The firing rate of border cells increases when the animal approaches edges or walls in its environment.
text 2: The firing rate of border cells decreases when the animal approaches edges or walls in its environment.

text 1: Speed cells fire in proportion to the animal's location within the environment, irrespective of its velocity.
text 2: Speed cells fire in proportion to the running speed of the animal, regardless of its location or direction.

text 1: Place-cell maps in the hippocampus are allocentric, fixed with respect to external spatial references.
text 2: Place-cell maps in the hippocampus are egocentric, fixed with respect to the animal's current perspective.

text 1: Grid fields expand topographically from the dorsal to ventral medial entorhinal cortex.
text 2: Grid fields contract topographically from the dorsal to ventral medial entorhinal cortex.

text 1: Place cells provide transient spatial fields that change every few minutes in a given environment.
text 2: Place cells provide stable spatial fields that last for weeks to months in a given environment.

text 1: Marr hypothesized that recurrent excitatory connections of CA3 neurons facilitate pattern completion.
text 2: Marr hypothesized that recurrent inhibitory connections of CA3 neurons facilitate pattern completion.

text 1: Grid cells require bright light to activate and provide spatial information.
text 2: Grid cells are active throughout complete darkness, providing spatial information without relying on visual inputs.

text 1: The hippocampus integrates grid-cell inputs to form unique spatial representations.
text 2: The hippocampus generates spatial representations independently, without input from grid cells.

text 1: The sacral levels of the spinal cord have more white matter than gray matter.
text 2: The sacral levels of the spinal cord have less white matter than gray matter.

text 1: Spinal nerves at the cervical level are involved with sensory perception and motor function of the back of the head, neck, and arms.
text 2: Spinal nerves at the cervical level are involved with sensory perception and motor function of the trunk and legs.

text 1: The ventral horn of the spinal cord is larger at the levels where motor nerves innervate the arms and legs.
text 2: The ventral horn of the spinal cord is larger at the thoracic levels where motor nerves innervate the trunk.

text 1: Fibers for pain and temperature pass through the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system in the spinal cord.
text 2: Fibers for pain and temperature pass through the spinothalamic tract in the spinal cord.

text 1: Sensory neurons conveying information from the skin, muscles, and joints to the spinal cord are clustered in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.
text 2: Sensory neurons conveying information from the skin, muscles, and joints to the spinal cord are clustered in the dorsal root ganglia.

text 1: Epicritic fibers carry signals for touch and proprioception and travel in the posterior column-medial lemniscal system.
text 2: Epicritic fibers carry signals for pain and temperature and travel in the posterior column-medial lemniscal system.

text 1: The dorsal horn of the spinal cord is larger where sensory nerves from the trunk enter the cord.
text 2: The dorsal horn of the spinal cord is larger where sensory nerves from the limbs enter the cord.

text 1: In the cervical spinal cord, sensory fibers from the lower body are located laterally in the dorsal column.
text 2: In the cervical spinal cord, sensory fibers from the lower body are located medially in the dorsal column.

text 1: The sensory axons entering the spinal cord at the sacral level are greater compared to higher levels like lumbar and cervical.
text 2: The sensory axons entering the spinal cord at the sacral level are fewer compared to higher levels like lumbar and cervical.

text 1: Pain, itch, temperature, and visceral information are transmitted in the ipsilateral dorsal column-medial lemniscal system from the spinal cord to the brain.
text 2: Pain, itch, temperature, and visceral information are transmitted in the contralateral anterolateral system from the spinal cord to the brain.

text 1: The lumbosacral and cervical enlargements of the spinal cord are regions where more sensory and motor fibers enter to innervate the limbs.
text 2: The lumbosacral and thoracic enlargements of the spinal cord are regions where more sensory and motor fibers enter to innervate the limbs.

text 1: The central branch of the dorsal root ganglion neurons enters the ventral portion of the spinal cord.
text 2: The central branch of the dorsal root ganglion neurons enters the dorsal portion of the spinal cord.

text 1: The fibers carrying sensory information in the medial lemniscus are arranged somatotopically.
text 2: The fibers carrying sensory information in the medial lemniscus are arranged randomly.

text 1: Second-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract cross the midline in the spinal cord.
text 2: Second-order neurons in the spinothalamic tract remain ipsilateral in the spinal cord.

text 1: The axons of sensory neurons in the dorsal root ganglion are bifurcated into peripheral and central branches.
text 2: The axons of sensory neurons in the dorsal root ganglion are monofurcated into a single branch.

text 1: ON cells are excited by a dark spot in the receptive field center, OFF cells by a bright spot.
text 2: ON cells are excited by a bright spot in the receptive field center, OFF cells by a dark spot.

text 1: Sensitivity declines sharply at high spatial frequencies, with an absolute threshold at approximately 30 cycles per degree.
text 2: Sensitivity declines sharply at high spatial frequencies, with an absolute threshold at approximately 50 cycles per degree.

text 1: A very fine grating presents a single stripe to both the center and surround of the receptive field.
text 2: A very coarse grating presents a single stripe to both the center and surround of the receptive field.

text 1: In dim light, the visual system’s contrast sensitivity declines more at low than at high spatial frequencies.
text 2: In dim light, the visual system’s contrast sensitivity declines more at high than at low spatial frequencies.

text 1: The visual system is said to have low-pass behavior because it rejects all but a band of spatial frequencies.
text 2: The visual system is said to have band-pass behavior because it rejects all but a band of spatial frequencies.

text 1: Flicker at approximately 10 Hz is the most effective stimulus for human temporal contrast sensitivity.
text 2: Flicker at approximately 20 Hz is the most effective stimulus for human temporal contrast sensitivity.

text 1: The firing rate of an ON ganglion cell first decreases as a white bar passes over the receptive-field surround.
text 2: The firing rate of an ON ganglion cell first increases as a white bar passes over the receptive-field surround.

text 1: The low-pass behavior can be understood on the basis of spatial antagonism in center-surround receptive fields.
text 2: The band-pass behavior can be understood on the basis of spatial antagonism in center-surround receptive fields.

text 1: A model of retinal processing without center-surround antagonism predicts ganglion-cell firing rates.
text 2: A model of retinal processing with center-surround antagonism predicts ganglion-cell firing rates.

text 1: In dim light, the receptive fields of ganglion cells lose their antagonistic surrounds.
text 2: In bright light, the receptive fields of ganglion cells lose their antagonistic surrounds.

text 1: Patterns with a frequency of approximately 5 cycles per degree are most visible.
text 2: Patterns with a frequency of approximately 15 cycles per degree are most visible.

text 1: The contrast sensitivity curve provides a measure of color vision sensitivity to patterns of different scales.
text 2: The contrast sensitivity curve provides a measure of sensitivity of visual perception to patterns of different scales.

text 1: The firing rate of an ON ganglion cell decreases as the white bar enters the center of the receptive field.
text 2: The firing rate of an ON ganglion cell increases as the white bar enters the center of the receptive field.

text 1: Spot stimuli are used to probe how our visual system deals with spatial and temporal patterns.
text 2: Grating stimuli are used to probe how our visual system deals with spatial and temporal patterns.

text 1: A complementary population of ON ganglion cells conveys another neural activity profile in parallel.
text 2: A complementary population of OFF ganglion cells conveys another neural activity profile in parallel.

text 1: The corollary discharge provides the vector information after the saccade is made and is the only source of information.
text 2: The corollary discharge provides the vector information available before the saccade is made, but it is not the only source of information.

text 1: When the medial dorsal nucleus (MD) is inactivated, the response of a frontal eye field neuron to a stimulus probe in a future (post-saccade) receptive field is unaffected.
text 2: When the medial dorsal nucleus (MD) is inactivated, the response of a frontal eye field neuron to a stimulus probe in a future (post-saccade) receptive field is severely impaired.

text 1: The geniculostriate pathway is the primary visual pathway, passing through the LGN to the primary visual cortex.
text 2: The geniculostriate pathway is a secondary visual pathway, bypassing the LGN to the primary visual cortex.

text 1: Parvocellular layers receive input from midget retinal ganglion cells carrying red-green opponent information.
text 2: Parvocellular layers receive input from parasol ganglion cells carrying blue-yellow opponent information.

text 1: The LGN consists of six primary layers: two parvocellular and four magnocellular.
text 2: The LGN consists of six primary layers: four parvocellular and two magnocellular.

text 1: Koniocellular layers receive input from midget ganglion cells carrying achromatic information.
text 2: Koniocellular layers receive input from small and large bistratified ganglion cells carrying blue-yellow information.

text 1: Each geniculate layer receives input from both the ipsilateral and contralateral eyes.
text 2: Each geniculate layer receives input from either the ipsilateral or the contralateral eye.

text 1: The optic nerve fibers from the nasal hemiretinas cross at the optic chiasm.
text 2: The optic nerve fibers from the temporal hemiretinas cross at the optic chiasm.

text 1: The preservation of spatial arrangement from the retina is called retinotopy.
text 2: The preservation of spatial arrangement from the retina is called hierarchotopy.

text 1: The LGN receives modulatory feedback from the visual cortex affecting attention and arousal.
text 2: The LGN functions strictly as a relay station with no modulatory feedback from the visual cortex.

text 1: The primary visual cortex is known as the striate cortex due to its proximity to the optic chiasm.
text 2: The primary visual cortex is known as the striate cortex due to a myelin-rich stripe.

text 1: The ventral pathway carries information about what the visual stimulus is.
text 2: The ventral pathway carries information about where the visual stimulus is located.

text 1: The primary visual cortex constitutes the first level of cortical processing of visual information.
text 2: The primary visual cortex constitutes the final level of cortical processing of visual information.

text 1: The optic chiasm is located in the thalamus where optic nerve fibers terminate.
text 2: The optic chiasm is the midline crossing point where specific optic nerve fibers intersect.

text 1: Parasol ganglion cells provide input to magnocellular layers carrying achromatic contrast.
text 2: Parasol ganglion cells provide input to parvocellular layers carrying chromatic contrast.

text 1: A visual scene is analyzed at three levels: low-level, intermediate-level, and high-level processing.
text 2: A visual scene is analyzed at two levels: intermediate-level and high-level processing.

text 1: Retinotopic maps are neural maps that preserve the spatial arrangement of retinal inputs.
text 2: Retinotopic maps are neural maps that modify the spatial arrangement of retinal inputs.

text 1: The human retina contains approximately 5 million rods and 100 million cones.
text 2: The human retina contains approximately 100 million rods and 5 million cones.

text 1: The central fovea contains no cones but is densely packed with small rods.
text 2: The central fovea contains no rods but is densely packed with small cones.

text 1: Rods are responsible for vision under dim illumination such as moonlight.
text 2: Cones are responsible for vision under dim illumination such as moonlight.

text 1: Cones make no contribution to night vision and are solely responsible for vision in daylight.
text 2: Cones make a significant contribution to night vision and are solely responsible for vision in daylight.

text 1: Primates have three types of rod photoreceptors but only one kind of cone photoreceptor.
text 2: Primates have only one type of rod but three kinds of cone photoreceptors.

text 1: The inner segment of photoreceptor cells contains mitochondria and machinery for protein synthesis.
text 2: The inner segment of photoreceptor cells contains the light-transducing apparatus.

text 1: The outer segment of cones contains free-floating discs within the cytoplasmic space.
text 2: The outer segment of rods contains free-floating discs within the cytoplasmic space.

text 1: Rods and cones differ in their sensitivity to light, with cones being able to signal the absorption of a single photon.
text 2: Rods and cones differ in their sensitivity to light, with rods being able to signal the absorption of a single photon.

text 1: Light must traverse several layers of cells to reach the photoreceptors in most of the retina.
text 2: Light immediately reaches the photoreceptors without crossing any cellular layers in most of the retina.

text 1: The foveola at the center of the fovea has dense layers of cellular structures that increase light scattering.
text 2: The foveola at the center of the fovea has cellular layers pushed aside to reduce light scattering.

text 1: The optic disc is densely packed with photoreceptors and corresponds to the sharp vision area in the visual field.
text 2: The optic disc is devoid of photoreceptors and corresponds to the blind spot in the visual field.

text 1: Rods cease to respond to variations in light intensity as the light level increases toward dawn.
text 2: Rods continue to respond to variations in light intensity even when the light level increases toward dawn.

text 1: The retina contains two types of photoreceptors: rods and cones.
text 2: The retina contains three types of photoreceptors: rods, cones, and ganglion cells.

text 1: The spacing between photoreceptors in the fovea is significantly mismatched to the size of the optical blur circle.
text 2: The spacing between photoreceptors in the fovea matches the size of the optical blur circle.

text 1: The black pigment epithelium in the retina reflects light to enhance vision clarity.
text 2: The black pigment epithelium in the retina absorbs light to keep it from scattering back into the eye.

text 1: In the adult mammalian brain, short-distance neuronal migration occurs.
text 2: In the adult mammalian brain, long-distance neuronal migration occurs.

text 1: Chondroitinase ABC hinders functional recovery after spinal cord injury.
text 2: Chondroitinase ABC promotes functional recovery after spinal cord injury.

text 1: During the earliest phase of the EPSP, the membrane potential is far from its resting value, El.
text 2: During the earliest phase of the EPSP, the membrane potential is still close to its resting value, El.

text 1: The inward synaptic current leaves the cell as outward current through two parallel pathways.
text 2: The inward synaptic current leaves the cell only through a single pathway.

text 1: As the concentration of ACh in the synapse increases, the ACh receptor-channels begin to close.
text 2: As the concentration of ACh in the synapse decreases, the ACh receptor-channels begin to close.

text 1: When the EPSP is at its peak or steady-state value, Ic = 0.
text 2: When the EPSP is at its peak or steady-state value, Ic = 1.

text 1: In the peak EPSP calculation, gEPSP = 10 × 10−6 S and gl = 5 × 10−6 S.
text 2: In the peak EPSP calculation, gEPSP = 5 × 10−6 S and gl = 1 × 10−6 S.

text 1: The peak voltage of the EPSP is a weighted average of the electromotive forces of the two batteries.
text 2: The peak voltage of the EPSP is not influenced by the electromotive forces of the two batteries.

text 1: Most of the outward current leaves the cell as ionic current during the earliest phase of the EPSP.
text 2: Most of the outward current leaves the cell as capacitive current during the earliest phase of the EPSP.

text 1: The current through the ACh receptor-channels is independent of Ohm’s law: IEPSP = gEPSP + (Vm × EEPSP).
text 2: The current through the ACh receptor-channels is given by Ohm’s law: IEPSP = gEPSP × (Vm − EEPSP).

text 1: As the ACh receptor-channels close, IEPSP increases further.
text 2: As the ACh receptor-channels close, IEPSP decreases further.

text 1: When IEPSP and Il are no longer in balance, the membrane potential starts to depolarize.
text 2: When IEPSP and Il are no longer in balance, the membrane potential starts to repolarize.

text 1: Ic, the capacitive current, is inversely proportional to the rate of change of membrane potential.
text 2: Ic, the capacitive current, is directly proportional to the rate of change of membrane potential.

text 1: The weighted average of conductances affects how closely Vm approaches the value of EEPSP.
text 2: The weighted average of conductances does not affect how closely Vm approaches the value of EEPSP.

text 1: The peak amplitude of the EPSP is calculated as ΔVEPSP = Vm − El = −15 mV − (0 mV) = 75 mV.
text 2: The peak amplitude of the EPSP is calculated as ΔVEPSP = Vm − El = −15 mV − (−90 mV) = 75 mV.

text 1: During most of the declining phase, the ACh receptor-channels carry no current because they are all closed.
text 2: During most of the declining phase, the ACh receptor-channels carry significant current despite being closed.

text 1: Current is conducted through the membrane mostly as inward current during the declining phase.
text 2: Current is conducted through the membrane mostly as outward current during the declining phase.
