text 2: Metabotropic receptors underlie fast synaptic signaling that is the basis of all behaviors, from simple reflexes to complex cognitive processes.

text 1: Activation of metabotropic receptors regulates the opening of ion channels indirectly through biochemical signaling pathways.
text 2: Activation of ionotropic receptors regulates the opening of ion channels indirectly through biochemical signaling pathways.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors can modify reflex strength, activate motor patterns, focus attention, set emotional states, and contribute to long-lasting changes in neural circuits.
text 2: Metabotropic receptors can modify reflex strength, activate motor patterns, focus attention, set emotional states, and contribute to long-lasting changes in neural circuits.

text 1: The cyclic AMP pathway is the least understood second-messenger signaling cascade initiated by G protein–coupled receptors.
text 2: The cyclic AMP pathway is the best understood second-messenger signaling cascade initiated by G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: Ionotropic receptors can activate a variety of effectors, typically enzymes producing diffusible second messengers.
text 2: G protein–coupled receptors can activate a variety of effectors, typically enzymes producing diffusible second messengers.

text 1: Receptor tyrosine kinases initiate a cascade of protein phosphorylation reactions, beginning with autophosphorylation of the kinase itself on tyrosine residues.
text 2: G protein–coupled receptors initiate a cascade of protein phosphorylation reactions, beginning with autophosphorylation of the kinase itself on tyrosine residues.

text 1: Endocannabinoids enhance presynaptic transmitter release.
text 2: Endocannabinoids inhibit presynaptic transmitter release.

text 1: Gases like nitric oxide can act as transcellular signals inhibiting cyclic GMP synthesis.
text 2: Gases like nitric oxide can act as transcellular signals stimulating cyclic GMP synthesis.

text 1: Second-messenger cascades can increase or decrease the opening of many types of ion channels.
text 2: Second-messenger cascades can only decrease the opening of ion channels.

text 1: Cyclic AMP–dependent protein phosphorylation can open potassium channels.
text 2: Cyclic AMP–dependent protein phosphorylation can close potassium channels.

text 1: Upon the binding of ligand, a G protein–coupled receptor undergoes a conformational change that promotes the exchange of GDP with GTP.
text 2: Upon the binding of ligand, a G protein–coupled receptor remains unchanged and does not promote the exchange of GDP with GTP.

text 1: Once a ionotropic receptor binds a ligand, it can interact sequentially with more than one G protein macromolecule.
text 2: Once a G protein–coupled receptor binds a ligand, it can interact sequentially with more than one G protein macromolecule.

text 1: Protein kinase A is a heterotetrameric enzyme consisting of a dimer of two regulatory subunits and two catalytic subunits.
text 2: Protein kinase A is a homotetrameric enzyme consisting of only catalytic subunits.

text 1: Activation of protein kinase A requires the binding of cAMP to its regulatory subunits, freeing the catalytic subunits.
text 2: Activation of protein kinase A inhibits the binding of cAMP to its regulatory subunits, freeing the catalytic subunits.

text 1: Kinases can phosphorylate proteins on serine and threonine residues within a context of specific phosphorylation consensus sequences.
text 2: Kinases can phosphorylate proteins on any residue without requiring specific phosphorylation consensus sequences.

text 1: The Z disk is the basic functional unit of muscle.
text 2: The sarcomere is the basic functional unit of muscle.

text 1: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with the structural proteins tropomyosin and titin.
text 2: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with the regulatory proteins tropomyosin and troponin.

text 1: The protein titin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.
text 2: The protein desmin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.

text 1: Maximal force can be achieved with a single action potential that sustains the Ca2+ concentration in the sarcoplasm.
text 2: Maximal force can be achieved only with a series of action potentials that sustains the Ca2+ concentration in the sarcoplasm.

text 1: The amount of overlap between actin and myosin is optimal at an intermediate sarcomere length, and the relative force is maximal.
text 2: The amount of overlap between actin and myosin is optimal at a short sarcomere length, and the relative force is maximal.

text 1: Muscle stiffness corresponds to the slope of the relation between muscle force and muscle length.
text 2: Muscle stiffness corresponds to the slope of the relation between muscle tension and muscle width.

text 1: When the length of the muscle fiber is not held fixed, the direction and rate of change in sarcomere length depend on the amount of muscle fiber force.
text 2: When the length of the muscle fiber is held fixed, the direction and rate of change in sarcomere length depend on the load alone.

text 1: Sarcomere length decreases when the muscle fiber force exceeds the load.
text 2: Sarcomere length decreases when the muscle fiber force is less than the load.

text 1: The maximal rate at which a muscle fiber can shorten is limited by the energy capacity of the mitochondria.
text 2: The maximal rate at which a muscle fiber can shorten is limited by the peak rate at which cross bridges can form.

text 1: The variation in fiber force during contraction is largely caused by differences in the average force exerted by each cross bridge.
text 2: The variation in fiber force during contraction is largely caused by the energy storage in the muscle fiber.

text 1: The anatomy of a muscle has no apparent effect on its force capacity, range of motion, and shortening velocity.
text 2: The anatomy of a muscle has a pronounced effect on its force capacity, range of motion, and shortening velocity.

text 1: Each myofibril lies alone in a fiber, and is made up of sarcomeres arranged end to end.
text 2: Several myofibrils lie side by side in a fiber, and each myofibril is made up of sarcomeres arranged end to end.

text 1: Once activated, cross bridges perform work and cause the thick and thin filaments to slide relative to one another.
text 2: Once activated, cross bridges perform no work and keep thick and thin filaments stationary.

text 1: Conversely, the increase in force during a lengthening contraction reflects the compression of fully activated sarcomeres.
text 2: Conversely, the increase in force during a lengthening contraction reflects the stretching of incompletely activated sarcomeres.

text 1: The rate of cross-bridge cycling increases after a brief isometric contraction.
text 2: The rate of cross-bridge cycling decreases after a brief isometric contraction.

text 1: Voltage-gated K+ channels are blocked by application of tetrodotoxin, reducing the amplitude of the presynaptic spike below 50 mV, causing the EPSP to disappear.
text 2: Voltage-gated Na+ channels are blocked by application of tetrodotoxin, reducing the amplitude of the presynaptic spike below 40 mV, causing the EPSP to disappear.

text 1: When Na+ channels are progressively blocked by TTX, the presynaptic action potential and excitatory postsynaptic potential decrease.
text 2: When Na+ channels are progressively blocked by TTX, the presynaptic action potential and excitatory postsynaptic potential increase.

text 1: A 40-mV presynaptic action potential is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.
text 2: A 50-mV presynaptic action potential is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.

text 1: Transmitter release cannot be triggered by depolarizing the presynaptic terminal if voltage-gated Na+ channels are blocked by TTX.
text 2: Transmitter release can be triggered by depolarizing the presynaptic terminal, even if voltage-gated Na+ channels are completely blocked by TTX.

text 1: Blocking both Na+ and Ca2+ channels helps control presynaptic voltage and produces a steep input-output curve.
text 2: Blocking both Na+ and K+ channels helps control presynaptic voltage and produces a steep input-output curve.

text 1: Calcium channels inactivate quickly and close as soon as the presynaptic depolarization starts.
text 2: Calcium channels do not inactivate quickly and stay open as long as the presynaptic depolarization lasts.

text 1: Calcium channels are largely localized in presynaptic terminals at active zones, opposite the postsynaptic receptors.
text 2: Calcium channels are largely localized in postsynaptic terminals at active zones, opposite the presynaptic receptors.

text 1: The extracellular Ca2+ concentration is much higher than the intracellular concentration, approximately 105-fold greater.
text 2: The intracellular Ca2+ concentration is much higher than the extracellular concentration, approximately 105-fold greater.

text 1: Katz and Miledi demonstrated that both Na+ and K+ flux are required for transmitter release.
text 2: Katz and Miledi demonstrated that neither Na+ nor K+ flux is required for transmitter release.

text 1: Presynaptic Na+ influx is important only for depolarizing the membrane enough for transmitter release to occur.
text 2: Presynaptic Na+ influx is necessary for the actual process of transmitter release.

text 1: Voltage-sensitive Ca2+ and Mg2+ channels were blocked at the squid giant synapse to study Na+ influx.
text 2: Voltage-sensitive Na+ and K+ channels were blocked at the squid giant synapse to study Ca2+ influx.

text 1: Presynaptic depolarizations greater than 40 mV can lead to a steep increase in the EPSP.
text 2: Presynaptic depolarizations less than 40 mV can lead to a steep increase in the EPSP.

text 1: A 20-mV increase in presynaptic spike amplitude results in a 2-fold increase in EPSP amplitude.
text 2: A 13.5-mV increase in presynaptic spike amplitude results in a 10-fold increase in EPSP amplitude.

text 1: The original presynaptic resting membrane potential was approximately −70 mV.
text 2: The original presynaptic resting membrane potential was approximately −50 mV.

text 1: Ca2+ serves only as a carrier of depolarizing charge, not as a chemical signal.
text 2: Ca2+ serves as both a carrier of depolarizing charge and as a special chemical signal.

text 1: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions are generally too faint to be directly audible by others.
text 2: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions are usually readily audible to others.

text 1: The basilar membrane displays linear responsiveness that accommodates a wide range of sound pressure into a broad range of vibration amplitude.
text 2: The basilar membrane displays compressive nonlinearity that accommodates a wide range of sound pressure into a narrow range of vibration amplitude.

text 1: The vomeronasal organ is present in many mammals, including humans.
text 2: The vomeronasal organ is present in many mammals, although not in humans.

text 1: Specific anosmias to some odorants are uncommon, occurring in less than 1% of people.
text 2: Specific anosmias to some odorants are common, with a few occurring in 1% to 20% of people.

text 1: Although the V1R receptors are thought to recognize proteins, at least some V2Rs are thought to recognize volatile chemicals.
text 2: Although the V1R receptors are thought to recognize volatile chemicals, at least some V2Rs are thought to recognize proteins.

text 1: Recent studies indicate that specific anosmias are unrelated to mutations in odorant receptor genes.
text 2: Recent studies indicate that specific anosmias can be caused by mutations in particular odorant receptor genes.

text 1: Chronic anosmia or hyposmia can result from damage to the olfactory epithelium caused by infections.
text 2: Chronic anosmia or hyposmia cannot result from damage to the olfactory epithelium caused by infections.

text 1: Pheromones are detected by two separate structures: the nasal olfactory epithelium and the vomeronasal organ.
text 2: Pheromones are detected by only one structure: the nasal olfactory epithelium.

text 1: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family has only 60 genes.
text 2: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family has more than 600 genes.

text 1: Invertebrates can be used to study odor coding and behavior due to their simple nervous systems.
text 2: Invertebrates cannot be used to study odor coding and behavior due to their complex nervous systems.

text 1: Pheromones play important roles in both mammals and humans.
text 2: Pheromones play important roles in a variety of mammals, although they have not been demonstrated in humans.

text 1: The V2R receptor differs from both V1R and odorant receptors in having a large extracellular domain at the N-terminal end.
text 2: The V2R receptor does not have a large extracellular domain at the N-terminal end.

text 1: Sensory detection in the vomeronasal organ is the same as that in the olfactory epithelium.
text 2: Sensory detection in the vomeronasal organ differs from that in the olfactory epithelium.

text 1: The vomeronasal organ has a family of five formyl peptide-related receptors (FPRs).
text 2: The vomeronasal organ has a family of ten formyl peptide-related receptors (FPRs).

text 1: Each olfactory neuron expresses more than five functional odorant receptor genes.
text 2: Each olfactory neuron expresses one or sometimes two functional odorant receptor genes.

text 1: Variation in amino acid sequence between members of each receptor family suggests that each family recognizes only one ligand.
text 2: Variation in amino acid sequence between members of each receptor family suggests that each family may recognize a variety of different ligands.

text 1: The insect odorant receptors were discovered by finding a single gene receptor in the Drosophila genome.
text 2: The insect odorant receptors were discovered by finding multigene receptor families in the Drosophila genome.

text 1: The activation of the Na+ current is preceded by a brief capacitive gating current (Ig), reflecting the inward movement of negative charges within the walls of the Na+ channels.
text 2: The activation of the Na+ current is preceded by a brief capacitive gating current (Ig), reflecting the outward movement of positive charges within the walls of the Na+ channels.

text 1: The sodium channel α-subunit consists of four repeated domains, each containing six transmembrane regions.
text 2: The sodium channel α-subunit consists of three repeated domains, each containing six transmembrane regions.

text 1: Depolarization of the cell membrane causes gating charge to move inward, activating the sodium channel.
text 2: Depolarization of the cell membrane causes gating charge to move outward, activating the sodium channel.

text 1: The sodium channel selects for Na+ over K+ based on the electrostatic repulsion between the ions.
text 2: The sodium channel selects for Na+ over K+ based on the size and hydrogen-bonding characteristics of the ions.

text 1: The selectivity filter has rectangular dimensions of 1.0 × 1.5 nm, large enough to accommodate one Na+ ion contacting one water molecule.
text 2: The selectivity filter has rectangular dimensions of 0.3 × 0.5 nm, large enough to accommodate one Na+ ion contacting one water molecule.

text 1: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation is determined by the number of sodium ions.
text 2: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation is determined by the number of gating charges.

text 1: In mammalian neurons, genes encode nine different α-subunits for voltage-gated sodium channels.
text 2: In mammalian neurons, genes encode three different α-subunits for voltage-gated sodium channels.

text 1: The functional diversity of voltage-gated channels solely depends on the transmembrane domains of the protein.
text 2: The functional diversity of voltage-gated channels can result from the addition of regulatory elements in cytoplasmic domains.

text 1: Some neurons express a dozen or more types of voltage-gated ion channels to expand signaling capabilities.
text 2: Some neurons express only one type of voltage-gated ion channel to expand signaling capabilities.

text 1: The voltage-gated sodium channels allow only basic information processing in mammalian neurons.
text 2: The voltage-gated sodium channels allow complex information processing and modulatory control in mammalian neurons.

text 1: Mutations or epigenetic changes in voltage-gated channels have no effect on neuronal function.
text 2: Mutations or epigenetic changes in voltage-gated channels can produce neurological diseases known as channelopathies.

text 1: Principal pore-forming α-subunits of voltage-gated channels are commonly combined with different accessory subunits to form various functional types.
text 2: Principal pore-forming α-subunits of voltage-gated channels are never combined with accessory subunits.

text 1: Some β-subunits enhance the efficiency of transporting channel proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum to the membrane.
text 2: Some β-subunits reduce the efficiency of transporting channel proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum to the membrane.

text 1: Channel diversity varies widely between different areas of the nervous system and different types of neurons.
text 2: Channel diversity is identical across all areas of the nervous system and across all types of neurons.

text 1: Voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels are encoded by unrelated genes without a shared superfamily.
text 2: Voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels are encoded by an extended gene superfamily that also includes genes for cyclic nucleotide-gated channels.

text 1: The spinal motor cortex solely controls spinal activity and does not participate in selecting the timing and magnitude of muscle activity.
text 2: The primary motor cortex plays an important role in generating motor commands that control spinal activity, including selecting the timing and magnitude of muscle activity.

text 1: The primary motor cortex contains a chaotic motor map of ipsilateral body parts, making voluntary control random.
text 2: The primary motor cortex contains an orderly motor map of major parts of the contralateral body, necessary for voluntary control of corresponding body parts.

text 1: The motor map in primates disproportionately represents finely controlled body parts, such as fingers, face, and mouth, due to a larger number of neurons required for fine motor control.
text 2: The motor map in primates proportionately represents all body parts equally, regardless of their motor function or control complexity.

text 1: Neurons controlling proximal arm muscles are concentrated within a central zone of the arm motor map, while neurons for distal arm muscles are in a surrounding horseshoe-shaped ring.
text 2: Neurons controlling distal arm muscles are primarily concentrated within a central zone of the arm motor map, while neurons for proximal arm muscles are in a surrounding horseshoe-shaped ring.

text 1: Corticomotoneuronal cells, which synapse directly onto spinal motor neurons, are found mostly in the caudal primary motor cortex in the anterior bank of the central sulcus.
text 2: Corticomotoneuronal cells, which synapse directly onto spinal motor neurons, are evenly distributed throughout the primary motor cortex.

text 1: Studies by Wilder Penfield demonstrated that areas controlling the hand and mouth are smaller in humans compared to monkeys.
text 2: Studies by Wilder Penfield demonstrated that areas controlling the hand and mouth are larger in humans compared to monkeys.

text 1: The motor map in the human cortex is randomly organized and does not follow patterns observed in monkeys.
text 2: The motor map in the human cortex follows a general mediolateral organization similar to that observed in monkeys.

text 1: CM cells projecting to spinal motor pools display a wide and overlapping distribution within the arm motor map.
text 2: CM cells projecting to spinal motor pools are isolated to specific, non-overlapping regions within the arm motor map.

text 1: Stimulating adjacent areas of the primary motor cortex evokes movements in adjacent body parts, demonstrating a topographic relationship.
text 2: Stimulating adjacent areas of the primary motor cortex evokes movements in random body parts, with no topographic relationship.

text 1: Horizontal axonal connections within the motor map allow coordination across different sites during the formation of motor commands.
text 2: Horizontal axonal connections within the motor map inhibit coordination across different sites during the formation of motor commands.

text 1: CM cells are common in nonprimate species and become less prevalent in the corticospinal tract of higher primates.
text 2: CM cells are uncommon or absent in nonprimate species and constitute a progressively larger component of the corticospinal tract in primates.

text 1: The motor cortex's representation of body parts is not a point-to-point anatomical reproduction but emphasizes finely controlled body parts disproportionately.
text 2: The motor cortex's representation of body parts is a point-to-point anatomical reproduction without disproportionate emphasis on any body parts.

text 1: Lesioning a cortical site typically perturbs or eliminates voluntary movement of the corresponding body part.
text 2: Lesioning a cortical site has no effect on voluntary movement of the corresponding body part.

text 1: Experimental studies by Gustav Fritsch and Eduard Hitzig demonstrated electrical stimulation of the cortex evokes movements in parts of the contralateral body.
text 2: Experimental studies by Gustav Fritsch and Eduard Hitzig demonstrated electrical stimulation of the cortex evokes movements in parts of the ipsilateral body.

text 1: Each muscle can only be activated by stimulating a single site within the motor map.
text 2: Each muscle can be activated by stimulating multiple dispersed sites within the motor map.

text 1: Taste buds are clustered in papillae on the tongue.
text 2: Taste buds are randomly scattered on the tongue surface.

text 1: Fungiform papillae are located on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
text 2: Fungiform papillae are located on the posterior third of the tongue.

text 1: Circumvallate papillae are hollow structures without grooves.
text 2: Circumvallate papillae are structures surrounded by grooves lined with taste buds.

text 1: Taste cells extend fibers into the brain to contact chemicals dissolved in saliva.
text 2: Taste cells extend microvilli into the taste pore to contact chemicals dissolved in saliva.

text 1: Taste cells cannot generate action potentials.
text 2: Taste cells can generate action potentials.

text 1: Taste cells have voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels.
text 2: Taste cells have voltage-gated Cl-, Mg2+, and Fe2+ channels.

text 1: Sweet tastants are detected by a combination of T2R1 and T2R3 receptors.
text 2: Sweet tastants are detected by a combination of T1R2 and T1R3 receptors.

text 1: T1R3 was initially discovered at the mouse saccharin preference (Sac) locus.
text 2: T1R3 was initially discovered at the human carbohydrate preference (Carb) locus.

text 1: Taste cells are nonneural but resemble neurons.
text 2: Taste cells are neurons with direct connections to the brain.

text 1: Umami tastants are detected by a combination of T1R1 and T1R3 receptors.
text 2: Umami tastants are detected by a combination of T1R2 and T1R4 receptors.

text 1: Salty tastants activate specific ion channels directly.
text 2: Salty tastants activate G protein–coupled receptors.

text 1: Bitter tastants are detected by T1R receptors.
text 2: Bitter tastants are detected by T2R receptors.

text 1: Taste cells are long-lived and rarely replaced.
text 2: Taste cells are very short-lived and are continually replaced from stem cells.

text 1: The pleasurable sensation of umami taste encourages the ingestion of proteins.
text 2: The pleasurable sensation of umami taste discourages the ingestion of proteins.

text 1: Each taste bud contains approximately 100 taste receptor cells.
text 2: Each taste bud contains approximately 10 taste receptor cells.

text 1: Taste cell turnover allows detection of unlimited taste qualities.
text 2: Taste cell turnover requires cells to differentiate to detect one of the five taste qualities.

text 1: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential approaches the K+ equilibrium potential.
text 2: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential approaches the Na+ equilibrium potential.

text 1: The Goldman equation takes into account both ionic concentration gradients and membrane permeability to calculate membrane potential.
text 2: The Goldman equation considers only ionic concentration gradients and ignores membrane permeability to calculate membrane potential.

text 1: The permeability ratio at the peak of the action potential is PK: PNa: PCl = 1.0 : 0.04 : 0.45.
text 2: The permeability ratio at the peak of the action potential is PK: PNa: PCl = 1.0 : 20 : 0.45.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump moves two Na+ ions out and three K+ ions into the cell per cycle.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump moves three Na+ ions out and two K+ ions into the cell per cycle.

text 1: The lipid bilayer carries an electrical current across the membrane due to its conductance.
text 2: The lipid bilayer gives the membrane electrical capacitance by separating charges on either side.

text 1: A typical capacitance value for a nerve cell membrane is approximately 1 μF per cm² of membrane area.
text 2: A typical capacitance value for a nerve cell membrane is approximately 100 μF per cm² of membrane area.

text 1: According to Ohm’s law, ionic current through a single-ion channel is determined solely by the ion's concentration gradient.
text 2: According to Ohm’s law, ionic current through a single-ion channel is determined by the voltage across the membrane.

text 1: Resting membrane potential is primarily influenced by K+ channels, which have higher permeability compared to Na+ and Cl− channels.
text 2: Resting membrane potential is primarily influenced by Na+ channels, which have higher permeability compared to K+ and Cl− channels.

text 1: [Na+]o has a minor effect on resting potential as compared to [K+]o.
text 2: [Na+]o has a strong effect on resting potential as compared to [K+]o.

text 1: The equivalent circuit of a neuron includes components like resistors, batteries, and capacitors to represent electrical properties.
text 2: The equivalent circuit of a neuron includes only batteries and capacitors, disregarding resistors.

text 1: The resting K+ current depends only on the membrane potential, independent of EK.
text 2: The resting K+ current depends on the electrochemical driving force, which is given by (Vm − EK).

text 1: A spherical nerve cell with a resting potential of −60 mV requires a large majority of ions in the cytoplasm to create this voltage.
text 2: A spherical nerve cell with a resting potential of −60 mV requires only a small fraction of ions to create this voltage.

text 1: The bulk of cytoplasm remains electroneutral despite charge separation across the membrane.
text 2: The bulk of cytoplasm develops a significant charge imbalance due to charge separation across the membrane.

text 1: The Goldman equation replaces the Nernst equation regardless of permeability dominance.
text 2: The Goldman equation reduces to the Nernst equation when permeability to one ion dominates.

text 1: The Na+-K+ pump decreases the steady-state condition by overriding passive Na+ and K+ fluxes.
text 2: The Na+-K+ pump contributes to the steady-state condition by balancing passive Na+ and K+ fluxes.

text 1: Clathrin-mediated uptake is often referred to as vesicle-mediated endocytosis.
text 2: Clathrin-mediated uptake is often referred to as receptor-mediated endocytosis.

text 1: One oligodendrocyte produces myelin sheaths for one segment of one axon.
text 2: One oligodendrocyte produces myelin sheaths for segments of as many as 30 axons.

text 1: Schwann cells produce myelin in the central nervous system.
text 2: Schwann cells produce myelin in the peripheral nervous system.

text 1: Axons with very small diameters are heavily myelinated.
text 2: Axons with very small diameters are not myelinated.

text 1: Receptor-mediated endocytosis involves non-selective uptake of extracellular molecules.
text 2: Receptor-mediated endocytosis involves selective uptake of molecules via receptors.

text 1: Nodes of Ranvier are heavily myelinated regions of the axon.
text 2: Nodes of Ranvier are unmyelinated gaps that expose the axon to extracellular space.

text 1: Myelination decreases the speed of nerve impulse conduction.
text 2: Myelination greatly increases the speed of nerve impulse conduction.

text 1: Glial cells play critical roles in brain development, function, and disease.
text 2: Glial cells primarily serve as structural support with minor functional roles in the brain.

text 1: CNS myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes.
text 2: CNS myelin is produced by Schwann cells.

text 1: The nodes of Ranvier contain a high density of Na+ channels.
text 2: The nodes of Ranvier contain a low density of Na+ channels.

text 1: One Schwann cell produces a single myelin sheath for one segment of one axon.
text 2: One Schwann cell can myelinate segments of many axons.

text 1: Astrocytes interact with neurons and synapses in the brain.
text 2: Astrocytes exclusively interact with blood vessels in the brain.

text 1: Saltatory conduction occurs in myelinated axons because the signal jumps from node to node.
text 2: Saltatory conduction occurs in unmyelinated axons due to continuous signal propagation.

text 1: Peripheral myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes in the peripheral nervous system.
text 2: Peripheral myelin is produced by Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system.

text 1: The number of myelin layers is inversely proportional to the diameter of the axon.
text 2: The number of myelin layers is proportional to the diameter of the axon.

text 1: In spinal muscular atrophy, genetic lesions (commonly duplications) in SMN1 lead to a marked reduction in levels of total SMN protein.
text 2: In spinal muscular atrophy, genetic lesions (commonly deletions) in SMN1 lead to a marked reduction in levels of total SMN protein.

text 1: Normally, most of the survival motor neuron (SMN) protein is produced from the SMN1 gene, whose mRNA is spliced from eight exons.
text 2: Normally, most of the survival motor neuron (SMN) protein is produced from the SMN2 gene, whose mRNA is spliced from eight exons.

text 1: An alternative therapeutic approach is to deliver an antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) that blocks the effect of hnRNPA1/A2, thereby enhancing production of a full-length mRNA from SMN2.
text 2: An alternative therapeutic approach is to use small interfering RNA (siRNA) that blocks the effect of hnRNPA1/A2, thereby enhancing production of a full-length mRNA from SMN2.

text 1: The best-known chronic neuropathy is Guillain-Barré syndrome.
text 2: The best-known acute neuropathy is Guillain-Barré syndrome.

text 1: Neuropathies are only categorized as demyelinating.
text 2: Neuropathies may be categorized as demyelinating or axonal.

text 1: In demyelinating neuropathies, conduction velocity is slowed.
text 2: In demyelinating neuropathies, conduction velocity is increased.

text 1: In axonal neuropathies, the myelin sheath is affected and conduction velocity is slowed.
text 2: In axonal neuropathies, the myelin sheath is not affected and conduction velocity is normal.

text 1: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is characterized by muscle weakness and wasting.
text 2: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is characterized by muscle strength increase and growth.

text 1: One form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1) has the features of a demyelinating neuropathy.
text 2: One form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (type 1) has the features of an axonal neuropathy.

text 1: Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has normal nerve conduction velocity and is considered an axonal neuropathy without demyelination.
text 2: Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has reduced nerve conduction velocity and is considered a demyelinating neuropathy.

text 1: Myelin proteins are affected in a group of demyelinating hereditary peripheral neuropathies collectively termed Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.
text 2: Myelin proteins are unaffected in demyelinating hereditary peripheral neuropathies like Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.

text 1: Guillain-Barré syndrome always occurs after a preceding illness.
text 2: Guillain-Barré syndrome may occur without apparent preceding illness.

text 1: Peripheral neuropathies may only lead to negative symptoms such as loss of sensation.
text 2: Peripheral neuropathies may lead to positive symptoms such as paresthesias.

text 1: Axonal and demyelinating neuropathies may lead to both positive and negative symptoms.
text 2: Axonal and demyelinating neuropathies lead only to positive symptoms.

text 1: Demyelinating neuropathies are associated with an increase in conduction velocity.
text 2: Demyelinating neuropathies are associated with a slowing of conduction velocity.

text 1: IP3 stimulates the release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
text 2: IP3 stimulates the release of Ca2+ from external stores in the cytoplasmic membrane.

text 1: Calcium often acts by binding to the protein calmodulin to deactivate CaM kinase.
text 2: Calcium often acts by binding to the protein calmodulin to activate CaM kinase.

text 1: PKC is composed of a single protein molecule with both a regulatory domain and a catalytic domain.
text 2: PKC is composed of multiple protein molecules each with separate regulatory and catalytic domains.

text 1: PKC can become persistently active through the expression of a PKC isoform lacking a regulatory domain.
text 2: PKC can become persistently active through the expression of a PKC isoform lacking a catalytic domain.

text 1: Receptor tyrosine kinases are deactivated when bound by peptide hormones such as EGF and NGF.
text 2: Receptor tyrosine kinases are activated when bound by peptide hormones such as EGF and NGF.

text 1: Before autophosphorylation, receptor tyrosine kinases activate signaling cascades through adaptor proteins.
text 2: After autophosphorylation, receptor tyrosine kinases activate signaling cascades through adaptor proteins.

text 1: Tyrosine kinases regulate the activity of neuronal proteins they phosphorylate, including ion channel activity.
text 2: Tyrosine kinases decrease the activity of neuronal proteins they phosphorylate, including ion channel activity.

text 1: MAP kinases can be inhibited by a signaling cascade initiated by receptor tyrosine kinase.
text 2: MAP kinases can be activated by a signaling cascade initiated by receptor tyrosine kinase.

text 1: MAP kinases translocate to the cytoplasm to activate gene transcription by phosphorylating transcription factors.
text 2: MAP kinases translocate to the nucleus to turn on gene transcription by phosphorylating transcription factors.

text 1: Transcellular messengers only affect the cell that produces them and not neighboring cells.
text 2: Transcellular messengers can affect the cell that produces them and neighboring cells.

text 1: Endocannabinoids are a class of intracellular second messengers.
text 2: Endocannabinoids are a class of transcellular messengers.

text 1: Transcellular messengers act faster than those at slow synapses.
text 2: Transcellular messengers act slower than those at fast synapses.

text 1: Receptor Tyrosine Kinases initiate cascades involving adaptor proteins and protein kinases to change gene transcription.
text 2: Receptor Tyrosine Kinases inhibit cascades involving adaptor proteins and protein kinases to change gene transcription.

text 1: Calcium/calmodulin complex activates protein kinase by causing conformational changes.
text 2: Calcium/calmodulin complex deactivates protein kinase by causing conformational changes.

text 1: Phospholipase Cγ is activated by binding to phosphotyrosine residues.
text 2: Phospholipase Cγ is activated by binding to phosphoserine residues.

text 1: Cells in the primary visual cortex with similar functional properties are located close together in columns that extend from the surface of the cortex to the white matter.
text 2: Cells in the primary visual cortex with similar functional properties are randomly distributed across the cortex without any columnar organization.

text 1: Ocular dominance columns in the cortex are approximately 2500 μm in width and appear as overlapping left- and right-eye areas.
text 2: Ocular dominance columns in the cortex are approximately 750 μm in width and appear as alternating left- and right-eye stripes.

text 1: Ocular dominance reflects the integration of thalamocortical inputs from the same layer of the LGN.
text 2: Ocular dominance reflects the segregation of thalamocortical inputs arriving from different layers of the LGN.

text 1: The primary visual cortex develops properties like orientation specificity and the integration of inputs from the two eyes.
text 2: The primary visual cortex develops properties like sound localization and the integration of auditory inputs.

text 1: The magnification factor refers to the cortical area dedicated to each degree of visual space, which varies with eccentricity.
text 2: The magnification factor refers to the auditory area dedicated to each frequency, which varies with pitch.

text 1: The peripheral part of the visual field commands the largest area of cortex in the primary visual cortex V1.
text 2: The central part of the visual field commands the largest area of cortex in the primary visual cortex V1.

text 1: Receptive field size decreases with distance from the fovea.
text 2: Receptive field size increases with distance from the fovea.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus have linear asymmetric receptive fields with harmonious center and surround.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus have circular symmetric receptive fields with antagonistic center and surround.

text 1: A hypercolumn contains all possible combinations of orientation preference and left- and right-eye dominance.
text 2: A hypercolumn contains only one combination of orientation preference and eye dominance.

text 1: Blobs in the primary visual cortex are specialized to provide information about surfaces rather than edges.
text 2: Blobs in the primary visual cortex are specialized to provide information purely about edges and motion.

text 1: Cells with similar orientation preferences in the cortex are grouped into columns that cycle clockwise and counterclockwise.
text 2: Cells with similar orientation preferences in the cortex are randomly scattered without any cyclic pattern.

text 1: Orientation columns have a full 180° cycle that repeats every 750 μm in the cortex.
text 2: Orientation columns have a variable cycle that repeats every 2500 μm in the cortex.

text 1: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes external changes in retinal light adaptation.
text 2: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes changes in surface reflectance linked to metabolic needs of neurons.

text 1: The primary visual cortex is disorganized, and this structure lacks functional significance.
text 2: The primary visual cortex is organized into columns, and this structure reflects the functional role of that area in vision.

text 1: Histochemical labeling with cytochrome oxidase showed clusters of neurons with sound selectivity in the auditory cortex.
text 2: Histochemical labeling with cytochrome oxidase helped reveal clusters of neurons with color selectivity in the visual cortex.

text 1: Patients with global aphasia can comprehend language and easily formulate and repeat sentences.
text 2: Patients with global aphasia are almost completely unable to comprehend language or formulate and repeat sentences.

text 1: Wernicke's aphasia results from damage to the left posterior temporal lobe structures.
text 2: Wernicke's aphasia results from damage to the right anterior temporal lobe structures.

text 1: Broca's aphasia results from damage to the posterior occipital lobe and surrounding parietal fields.
text 2: Broca's aphasia results from damage to Broca's area and surrounding frontal fields.

text 1: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the right superior temporal gyrus and superior parietal lobe.
text 2: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the left superior temporal gyrus and inferior parietal lobe.

text 1: Transcortical motor aphasia involves damage to pathways connecting the cerebellum to the spinal cord.
text 2: Transcortical motor aphasia involves damage to pathways connecting speech centers of the cortex to the rest of the brain.

text 1: Transcortical sensory aphasia appears to be caused by damage to the ventral stream.
text 2: Transcortical sensory aphasia appears to be caused by damage to the dorsal stream.

text 1: Broca's aphasics typically have major difficulty perceiving speech sounds or recognizing their own errors.
text 2: Broca's aphasics typically have no difficulty perceiving speech sounds or recognizing their own errors.

text 1: Classic global aphasia involves damage to the inferior frontal and parietal cortices and the posterior superior temporal cortex.
text 2: Classic global aphasia involves damage to the inferior occipital and parietal cortices and the anterior superior temporal cortex.

text 1: Wernicke’s aphasics have difficulty selecting words that accurately represent their intended meaning, known as semantic paraphasia.
text 2: Wernicke’s aphasics do not experience difficulty selecting words that represent their intended meaning.

text 1: Damage to the right hemisphere occipital regions often produces visual deficits.
text 2: Damage to the left hemisphere auditory regions often produces speech production deficits.

text 1: Transcortical aphasias can be caused by damage that spares the arcuate fasciculus and the dorsal stream.
text 2: Transcortical aphasias can be caused by damage that affects the arcuate fasciculus and the dorsal stream.

text 1: Broca's aphasia patients may recover when damage is restricted to Broca's area alone.
text 2: Broca's aphasia patients never recover, even if damage is restricted to Broca's area alone.

text 1: Speech produced by Wernicke's aphasics is typically very clear and easily understood.
text 2: Speech produced by Wernicke's aphasics can sound melodic but be unintelligible due to phonemic paraphasias.

text 1: The inferior occipital area contributes to the initiation of speech.
text 2: The supplementary motor area contributes to the initiation of speech.

text 1: Damage to the right primary visual cortex can extend in cases of conduction aphasia.
text 2: Damage to the left primary auditory cortex can extend in cases of conduction aphasia.

text 1: Time delays in the sensorimotor system can be on the order of 10 ms and do not depend on the particular sensory modality.
text 2: Time delays in the sensorimotor system can be on the order of 100 ms and depend on the particular sensory modality.

text 1: Reflexes are random responses to any stimuli and occur on a longer timescale than voluntary responses.
text 2: Reflexes are stereotyped responses to specific stimuli and occur on a shorter timescale than voluntary responses.

text 1: Voluntary movements can be generated in the absence of a stimulus.
text 2: Voluntary movements require a stimulus to be generated.

text 1: Feedforward control situations involve open-loop control, reflecting that the sensorimotor loop is not completed by sensory feedback.
text 2: Feedforward control situations involve closed-loop control, reflecting that the sensorimotor loop is completed by sensory feedback.

text 1: Muscles have no passive properties and depend solely on the motor command acting on the muscle.
text 2: Muscles have substantial passive properties that depend on both the motor command acting on the muscle and the muscle’s length and rate of change of length.

text 1: The strength of a reflex is unaffected by the tension in a muscle, which is unrelated to gain-scaling.
text 2: The strength of a reflex tends to increase with the tension in a muscle, a concept known as gain-scaling.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex uses open-loop control to fix gaze on an object during head rotation.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex uses closed-loop control to fix gaze on an object during head rotation.

text 1: Feedforward control is required for rapid movements due to delays in sensing and acting in the sensorimotor system.
text 2: Feedforward control is not required for rapid movements as there are no delays in sensing and acting in the sensorimotor system.

text 1: Multisynaptic reflexes produce responses at around 700 ms and are not adaptable to changes in behavioral goals.
text 2: Multisynaptic reflexes can produce responses at around 70 ms and are adaptable to changes in behavioral goals.

text 1: Motor control occurs without hierarchy or planning and relies solely on spontaneous actions.
text 2: Motor control occurs through a hierarchy of control centers with higher levels planning more global goals.

text 1: Conscious processes are not necessary for moment-to-moment control of movement.
text 2: Conscious processes are essential for moment-to-moment control of movement.

text 1: Sensory inputs can cause motor output directly without intervention of higher brain centers.
text 2: Sensory inputs always require intervention of higher brain centers for motor output.

text 1: The motion of each body segment has no effect on other body segments.
text 2: The motion of each body segment produces torques and potentially motions at all other body segments through mechanical interactions.

text 1: Reflexes are generated by complex neural circuits in the cerebral cortex and occur slower than voluntary movements.
text 2: Reflexes are generated by simple neural circuits in the spinal cord or brain stem and occur faster than voluntary movements.

text 1: Voluntary correction to a small physical perturbation can occur with a latency of about 10 ms.
text 2: Voluntary correction to a small physical perturbation can occur with a latency of about 110 ms.

text 1: Circadian rhythms are driven by dopamine-releasing neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus located below the optic chiasm.
text 2: Circadian rhythms are driven by a small group of GABAergic neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus located in the hypothalamus above the optic chiasm.

text 1: BMAL1 and CLOCK form a dimer that binds to the D-box motif, regulating the transcription of Period and Cryptochrome genes.
text 2: BMAL1 and CLOCK form a dimer that binds to the E-box motif, regulating the transcription of Period and Cryptochrome genes.

text 1: The sublaterodorsal area in rodents corresponds to the subceruleus region in humans and is involved in generating REM sleep.
text 2: The sublaterodorsal area in rodents corresponds to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in humans and is involved in generating REM sleep.

text 1: Loss of REM-on neurons in the sublaterodorsal area causes insomnia because individuals cannot achieve REM sleep.
text 2: Loss of REM-on neurons in the sublaterodorsal area can result in REM sleep behavior disorder, allowing individuals to act out their dreams.

text 1: Serotonergic neurons in the pedunculopontine and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei promote REM sleep.
text 2: Cholinergic neurons in the pedunculopontine and laterodorsal tegmental nuclei promote REM sleep.

text 1: Orexinergic neurons play a role in maintaining wakefulness and are active during non-REM sleep.
text 2: Orexinergic neurons play a role in maintaining wakefulness but become inactive during REM sleep.

text 1: Homeostatic sleep drive gradually builds up during sleep and peaks during waking hours.
text 2: Homeostatic sleep drive gradually builds up during wakefulness and peaks at bedtime.

text 1: Antidepressants that increase monoamine levels suppress REM sleep.
text 2: Antidepressants that increase monoamine levels promote REM sleep.

text 1: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) releases glutamate and galanin to inhibit arousal systems during sleep.
text 2: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO) releases GABA and galanin to inhibit arousal systems during sleep.

text 1: The dorsal raphe nucleus inhibits the REM generator using acetylcholine inputs.
text 2: The dorsal raphe nucleus inhibits the REM generator using serotonergic inputs.

text 1: Circadian wake signals increase rapidly before bedtime as the homeostatic sleep drive falls.
text 2: Circadian wake signals collapse rapidly before bedtime as the homeostatic sleep drive rises.

text 1: Loss of orexinergic neurons can inhibit REM-on neurons, preventing REM sleep entirely.
text 2: Loss of orexinergic neurons can cause abrupt onset of REM sleep.

text 1: The flip-flop switch mechanism disrupts transitions between wakefulness and sleep.
text 2: The flip-flop switch mechanism helps regulate transitions between wakefulness and sleep.

text 1: The REM sleep switch involves both REM-on and REM-off neurons, which are mutually inhibitory.
text 2: The REM sleep switch involves only REM-on neurons that activate REM sleep.

text 1: Circadian rhythms in humans are primarily driven by homeostatic changes in melatonin secretion without clock genes.
text 2: Circadian rhythms in humans are primarily driven by transcriptional-translational cycles of clock genes.

text 1: Patients with amnesia have difficulty imagining the future as well as remembering the past due to loss of creativity.
text 2: Patients with amnesia have no difficulty imagining the future, only remembering the past.

text 1: Damage to the frontal cortex affects both metacognition and decision-making.
text 2: Damage to the frontal cortex can impair metacognition while leaving decision-making intact.

text 1: A sense of agency can become detached from the control of action in extreme cases.
text 2: A sense of agency is always reliably connected to the control of action.

text 1: Confidence in our choices is an example of metacognition.
text 2: Confidence in our choices is purely a result of instinct rather than metacognition.

text 1: Verbal reports are always reliable and cannot be faked.
text 2: Verbal reports are not always reliable because people can fake memory loss.

text 1: Memory is a creative process based on imperfect recall filled out with general knowledge.
text 2: Memory is a direct process identical to replaying a video.

text 1: Antipsychotic drugs act on dopaminergic systems in the brain.
text 2: Antipsychotic drugs primarily act on cholinergic systems in the brain.

text 1: Schizophrenia is characterized by cognitive impairments, deficit symptoms, and psychotic symptoms.
text 2: Schizophrenia is characterized only by psychotic symptoms.

text 1: Mental illnesses are the leading cause of disability worldwide.
text 2: Mental illnesses are a minor cause of disability worldwide.

text 1: Schizophrenia typically begins after the third decade of life.
text 2: Schizophrenia has a characteristic course of illness with onset during the second and third decades of life.

text 1: The psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia tend to be episodic.
text 2: The psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia are continuous.

text 1: Brain development abnormalities during childhood are solely responsible for schizophrenia.
text 2: Abnormalities in brain development during adolescence may be responsible for schizophrenia.

text 1: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex results primarily from the loss of cells.
text 2: Loss of gray matter in the cerebral cortex appears to result from loss of synaptic contacts rather than loss of cells.

text 1: Damage to the inferior temporal cortex can result in loss of conscious awareness of the shape of an object.
text 2: Damage to the inferior temporal cortex enhances conscious awareness of the shape of an object.

text 1: People can fake memory loss to escape justice, which resembles disorders such as hysterical amnesia.
text 2: People cannot fake memory loss to escape justice, as it always appears different from disorders like hysterical amnesia.

text 1: In adult muscle, ACh receptors are relatively stable with a half-life of approximately 2 days.
text 2: In adult muscle, ACh receptors are relatively stable with a half-life of approximately 2 weeks.

text 1: During the first few postnatal days, the δ gene in ACh receptors is turned off and a closely related gene called γ is activated.
text 2: During the first few postnatal days, the γ gene in ACh receptors is turned off and a closely related gene called ε is activated.

text 1: The metabolic stabilization of ACh receptors disperses them from synaptic sites and destabilizes the postsynaptic apparatus.
text 2: The metabolic stabilization of ACh receptors helps concentrate them at synaptic sites and stabilize the postsynaptic apparatus.

text 1: In the embryo, ACh receptors are turned over rapidly, with a half-life of approximately 1 day.
text 2: In the embryo, ACh receptors are turned over slowly, with a half-life of approximately 1 week.

text 1: The initial aggregate of ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction appears to have a plaque-like appearance.
text 2: The initial aggregate of ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction appears to have a pretzel-like appearance.

text 1: Central synapses and neuromuscular junctions are structurally and functionally similar in several ways.
text 2: Central synapses and neuromuscular junctions are completely distinct in structure and function.

text 1: The cellular logic of synapse formation is distinct between neuromuscular junctions and central synapses.
text 2: The cellular logic of synapse formation is conserved between neuromuscular junctions and central synapses.

text 1: Agrin and laminins play a critical role at central synapses just as they do at neuromuscular junctions.
text 2: Agrin and laminins do not play key roles at central synapses but are crucial at neuromuscular junctions.

text 1: Electrical activity regulates expression of neurotransmitter receptors in neurons.
text 2: Electrical activity inhibits expression of neurotransmitter receptors in neurons.

text 1: At inhibitory synapses, clusters of glycine receptors form normally in gephyrin-deficient mutant mice.
text 2: At inhibitory synapses, clusters of glycine receptors fail to form in gephyrin-deficient mutant mice.

text 1: Neurotransmitter receptors like GABA and glutamate receptors are distributed randomly across neuronal membranes.
text 2: Neurotransmitter receptors like GABA and glutamate receptors are concentrated in patches aligned with nerve terminals.

text 1: The postsynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction matures in stages, starting as loose aggregates and later forming folds.
text 2: The postsynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction matures in a single stage, immediately forming folds.

text 1: Newly formed ACh receptor clusters in the embryo are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and ε-subunits.
text 2: Newly formed ACh receptor clusters in the embryo are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and γ-subunits.

text 1: Neurexins are enriched in presynaptic membranes, and neuroligins are concentrated in postsynaptic membranes.
text 2: Neurexins are concentrated in postsynaptic membranes, and neuroligins are enriched in presynaptic membranes.

text 1: Glutamate and GABA receptors become selectively clustered beneath terminals releasing corresponding neurotransmitters.
text 2: Glutamate and GABA receptors are randomly clustered, independent of neurotransmitter release by terminals.

text 1: Microglia solely interact with synaptic elements in the healthy brain and do not contribute to neuroinflammation or synapse loss in neurodegenerative diseases.
text 2: Microglia interact with synaptic elements in the healthy brain and contribute to neuroinflammation and synapse loss in neurodegenerative diseases.

text 1: The choroid plexus is the primary site of cerebrospinal fluid production, with ciliary motion aiding its circulation.
text 2: The ependymal cells are the primary site of cerebrospinal fluid production, with ciliary motion aiding its circulation.

text 1: The choroid plexus epithelial cells form loose junctions to regulate molecule movement into the brain.
text 2: The choroid plexus epithelial cells form tight junctions to regulate molecule movement into the brain.

text 1: The choroid plexus epithelial cells synthesize and secrete many proteins into the cerebrospinal fluid that modulate neural stem cell development and cortical plasticity.
text 2: The choroid plexus epithelial cells do not synthesize or secrete proteins into the cerebrospinal fluid.

text 1: Neurons are highly polarized cells with non-specialized compartments for generalized cellular functions.
text 2: Neurons are highly polarized cells with dendritic and axonal compartments specialized for receiving and transmitting signals.

text 1: Most neuronal proteins are synthesized in dendrites and axons, with minimal synthesis occurring in the cell body.
text 2: Most neuronal proteins are synthesized in the cell body, but synthesis also occurs in dendrites and axons.

text 1: Astrocytes regulate extracellular ion concentrations but do not participate in synapse formation or function.
text 2: Astrocytes regulate extracellular ion concentrations and actively participate in the formation and function of synapses.

text 1: The cytoskeleton solely controls neuronal morphology and does not play a role in organelle transport.
text 2: The cytoskeleton provides a framework for organelle transport and controls axonal and dendritic morphology in neurons.

text 1: Transport of proteins and mRNA in neurons occurs with great specificity, supporting vectorial transport to selected membrane components.
text 2: Transport of proteins and mRNA in neurons occurs randomly and does not support vectorial transport.

text 1: Loose junctions between ependymal cells provide cerebrospinal fluid access to the brain's interstitial space.
text 2: Tight junctions between ependymal cells block cerebrospinal fluid access to the brain's interstitial space.

text 1: Neuronal activity profoundly modifies cell structure and function, driving neural circuit adaptation to experience.
text 2: Neuronal activity has no significant effect on cell structure or function, preventing adaptation to experience.

text 1: Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells produce myelin insulation to enable axons to conduct electrical signals rapidly.
text 2: Both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes produce myelin insulation to enable axons to conduct electrical signals rapidly.

text 1: The choroid plexus epithelial cell secretome can be altered by inflammatory signals, impacting neuronal function during infection and aging.
text 2: The choroid plexus epithelial cell secretome remains unchanged by inflammatory signals during infection or aging.

text 1: Fenestrated capillaries in the choroid plexus block passage of water and small molecules into the stromal space.
text 2: Fenestrated capillaries in the choroid plexus allow free passage of water and small molecules into the stromal space.

text 1: Active transport in the choroid plexus epithelium regulates bidirectional flux of molecules between cerebrospinal fluid and peripheral circulation.
text 2: Passive transport in the choroid plexus epithelium regulates bidirectional flux of molecules between cerebrospinal fluid and peripheral circulation.

text 1: The RNS System uses open-loop seizure detection and stimulation as proof-of-concept evidence.
text 2: The RNS System provides proof-of-concept evidence for closed-loop seizure detection and stimulation.

text 1: The vagus nerve stimulator activates automatically without patient intervention during an aura to prevent a seizure.
text 2: The vagus nerve stimulator can be activated by the patient using a hand-held magnet during an aura to prevent a seizure.

text 1: In the optogenetic approach, a virus is engineered to deliver electric shocks to neurons to reduce excitability when exposed to light.
text 2: In the optogenetic approach, a virus is engineered to express ion channels or pumps that reduce neuron excitability when exposed to light.

text 1: Unlike focal onset seizures, generalized onset seizures are not preceded by an aura or followed by postictal symptoms.
text 2: Unlike generalized onset seizures, focal onset seizures are not preceded by an aura or followed by postictal symptoms.

text 1: Focal seizures that secondarily generalize can involve both hemispheres through transcallosal pathways.
text 2: Focal seizures that secondarily generalize predominantly remain in one hemisphere and do not involve transcallosal pathways.

text 1: T-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels play a role in generalized onset seizures like typical absence seizures.
text 2: T-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels play no role in generalized onset seizures like typical absence seizures.

text 1: Ethosuximide and valproic acid block T-type channels, reducing the occurrence of typical absence seizures.
text 2: Ethosuximide and valproic acid increase T-type channel activity, promoting typical absence seizures.

text 1: Rapid generalization of focal onset seizures is more likely to occur when they begin in the limbic system.
text 2: Rapid generalization of focal onset seizures is more likely to occur when they begin in the neocortex.

text 1: Thalamocortical circuits contribute significantly to the spread of generalized onset seizures.
text 2: Thalamocortical circuits are not involved in the spread of generalized onset seizures.

text 1: Generalized onset seizures disrupt activity in both cerebral hemispheres simultaneously.
text 2: Generalized onset seizures usually disrupt activity in only one cerebral hemisphere.

text 1: Patients with typical absence seizures do not experience impaired awareness, but only exhibit minor motor symptoms.
text 2: Patients with typical absence seizures can experience impaired awareness along with minor motor symptoms.

text 1: Penfield and Jasper hypothesized that generalized seizures were not related to thalamic activity.
text 2: Penfield and Jasper hypothesized that generalized seizures could be attributed to rhythmic activity in the thalamus.

text 1: The postictal period may include symptoms such as confusion and drowsiness or even focal neurological deficits.
text 2: The postictal period is generally free of symptoms such as confusion or focal neurological deficits.

text 1: Patients with focal onset seizures followed by secondary generalization rarely experience loss of consciousness.
text 2: Patients with focal onset seizures followed by secondary generalization usually experience loss of consciousness.

text 1: Pre-ictal EEG patterns remain consistent among patients, making it easy to predict seizures.
text 2: Pre-ictal EEG patterns show great variability between patients, making it difficult to predict seizures.

text 1: The activity of many primary motor cortex neurons decreases with the amplitude of static torque generated across a single joint.
text 2: The activity of many primary motor cortex neurons increases with the amplitude of static torque generated across a single joint.

text 1: The activity of all primary motor cortex neurons varies uniformly with the direction of isometric forces.
text 2: The activity of some primary motor cortex neurons varies with the direction of isometric forces.

text 1: Reaching movements with similar hand trajectories and different arm orientations do not require changes in muscle activity or joint-centered torques.
text 2: Reaching movements with similar hand trajectories but different arm orientations require changes in joint-centered torques and muscle activity.

text 1: Muscular torques tend to be smaller for movements to the right and left compared to movements away from or toward the body.
text 2: Muscular torques tend to be larger for movements to the right and left compared to movements away from or toward the body.

text 1: Joint power is lowest for movements away from the body and slightly to the left.
text 2: Joint power is greatest for movements away from the body and slightly to the left.

text 1: Preferred directions of proximal-limb muscles tend to align with movements that require greater muscular power.
text 2: Preferred directions of proximal-limb muscles tend to align with movements that require minimal muscular power.

text 1: The distribution of preferred directions of M1 neurons does not relate to the physics of limb movement.
text 2: The distribution of preferred directions of M1 neurons parallels the bias in the physics of limb movement.

text 1: Some single M1 neurons can be correlated with specific components of muscle contraction patterns during motor tasks.
text 2: No single M1 neurons are correlated with specific components of muscle contraction patterns during motor tasks.

text 1: The final pattern of muscle activity is generated by spinal motor neurons, which integrate supraspinal inputs and interneuronal processes.
text 2: The final pattern of muscle activity is generated by M1 neurons exclusively, without additional integration from supraspinal inputs.

text 1: Voluntary motor control involves coordinated activity of many neurons throughout the motor system.
text 2: Voluntary motor control involves activity of individual neurons independently, without coordination across the motor system.

text 1: Vector notation is used to represent neuron activity in M1 during reaching movements, with preferred directions and discharge rates determining the resultant movement.
text 2: Vector notation is not capable of representing neuron activity in M1 during reaching movements or predicting resultant movements.

text 1: Population vectors from the activity of 250 M1 neurons do not provide insight into the direction of reach movements.
text 2: Population vectors from the activity of 250 M1 neurons can predict the direction of reach movements.

text 1: Instantaneous population vectors extracted from M1 neuron activity predict changes in arm trajectory during sequential time intervals.
text 2: Instantaneous population vectors fail to predict changes in arm trajectory during sequential time intervals.

text 1: Coordination of M1 neuron activity distinguishes the unique identity of different reach actions.
text 2: Coordination of M1 neuron activity fails to distinguish the unique identity of different reach actions.

text 1: M1 neurons distributed throughout the arm motor map contribute to motor control during reaching movements.
text 2: M1 neurons in the arm motor map are not involved in motor control during reaching movements.

text 1: In the visual system, feedforward projections from the primary visual cortex to secondary and tertiary visual areas originate mainly in layer V and terminate mainly in layer II of the target cortical area.
text 2: In the visual system, feedforward projections from the primary visual cortex to secondary and tertiary visual areas originate mainly in layer III and terminate mainly in layer IV of the target cortical area.

text 1: The cerebral cortex is organized into columns of cells that extend from the white matter to the surface of the cortex, forming highly specialized computational modules.
text 2: The cerebral cortex is organized into columns of cells that extend from the gray matter to the hippocampus, forming nonspecialized computational modules.

text 1: The somatosensory cortex contains several somatotopic maps, including six complete maps of the skin in Brodmann areas 3a, 4b, 1, and 2.
text 2: The somatosensory cortex contains several somatotopic maps, including four complete maps of the skin in Brodmann areas 3a, 3b, 1, and 2.

text 1: Area 2 of the somatosensory cortex may be responsible for integrated perception of two-dimensional surfaces, termed stereognosis.
text 2: Area 2 of the somatosensory cortex may be responsible for integrated perception of three-dimensional solid objects, termed stereognosis.

text 1: The corticospinal tract is also known as the pyramidal tract because its fibers form the medullary pyramids on the ventral surface of the medulla.
text 2: The corticospinal tract is also known as the pyramidal tract because its fibers form the cortical columns on the ventral surface of the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Approximately 80% of the axons in the human corticospinal tract originate in the motor cortex.
text 2: Approximately 40% of the axons in the human corticospinal tract originate in the motor cortex.

text 1: Most corticospinal fibers cross the midline at the pyramidal decussation in the cerebral peduncle.
text 2: Most corticospinal fibers cross the midline at the pyramidal decussation in the medulla.

text 1: The motor cortex outputs are influenced by the cerebellum and basal ganglia, which provide feedback for smooth execution of skilled movements.
text 2: The motor cortex outputs are influenced by the thalamus and amygdala, which provide feedback for smooth execution of skilled movements.

text 1: Ascending feedforward pathways generally originate in superficial layers of the cortex and invariably terminate in layer IV.
text 2: Ascending feedforward pathways generally originate in deep layers of the cortex and invariably terminate in layer VI.

text 1: Descending feedback pathways generally originate from superficial cortical layers and terminate in layers II and IV.
text 2: Descending feedback pathways generally originate from deep cortical layers and terminate in layers I and VI.

text 1: The primary somatosensory cortex projects to both the motor cortex in the frontal lobe and the somatosensory association area in the parietal cortex.
text 2: The primary somatosensory cortex projects to both the multimodal association cortex in the frontal lobe and the premotor cortex in the occipital region.

text 1: The somatosensory association area projects to lower-order somatosensory areas and the hippocampus.
text 2: The somatosensory association area projects to higher-order somatosensory association areas and the premotor cortex.

text 1: Unimodal association areas converge on multimodal association areas to integrate sensory modalities.
text 2: Unimodal association areas diverge from multimodal association areas to separate sensory modalities.

text 1: Neurons in a single cortical column typically have widely varying response properties, forming a global processing network.
text 2: Neurons in a single cortical column typically share similar response properties, forming a local processing network.

text 1: Columns in the cerebral cortex are roughly one-third of a millimeter in diameter.
text 2: Columns in the cerebral cortex are roughly one millimeter in diameter.

text 1: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures by the fundamental processes of inhibition and disinhibition.
text 2: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures primarily through excitatory processes.

text 1: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have low tonic firing rates, minimizing their influence on target regions.
text 2: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have high tonic firing rates, ensuring constant inhibitory control over target regions.

text 1: Focused suppression from striatal inputs enhances tonic inhibition in targeted regions of the thalamus and brain stem.
text 2: Focused suppression from striatal inputs releases targeted regions in the thalamus and brain stem from tonic inhibition.

text 1: The basal ganglia architecture has undergone significant changes during vertebrate evolution over 500 million years.
text 2: The basal ganglia architecture has remained highly conserved across vertebrate evolution for over 500 million years.

text 1: The basal ganglia are shared by all vertebrate species and solve selection problems unchanged for millions of years.
text 2: The basal ganglia are exclusive to mammals and have evolved specifically for human-centric selection problems.

text 1: In vertebrate multimodal sensory systems, selective attention resolves competing external stimuli to direct movement.
text 2: In vertebrate multimodal sensory systems, selective attention enhances multiple external stimuli simultaneously to direct movement.

text 1: The intrinsic circuits in the basal ganglia nuclei are unique to the sensorimotor territories.
text 2: The intrinsic circuits in the basal ganglia nuclei are similar across limbic, associative, and sensorimotor territories.

text 1: The phasic excitatory input signals to the striatum carry representations of behavioral options competing for expression.
text 2: The phasic excitatory input signals to the striatum suppress representations of behavioral options competing for expression.

text 1: The basal ganglia evaluate competing options based on their relative biological importance or salience.
text 2: The basal ganglia evaluate competing options based on their speed of neural transmission.

text 1: Selective disinhibition by the basal ganglia enhances distortion of the selected option’s input to motor systems.
text 2: Selective disinhibition by the basal ganglia prevents distortion of the selected option’s input to motor systems.

text 1: The basal ganglia architecture excludes competitions between sensory, motivational, cognitive, and motor systems.
text 2: The basal ganglia architecture supports competitions between sensory, motivational, cognitive, and motor systems.

text 1: Tonic inhibitory output is completely suppressed on nonselected channels within the basal ganglia network.
text 2: Tonic inhibitory output is maintained on nonselected channels within the basal ganglia network.

text 1: The return connections of the basal ganglia loops via the thalamus are often omitted in simplified diagrams for clarity.
text 2: The return connections of the basal ganglia loops via the thalamus are rarely included due to their irrelevance to functional processes.

text 1: Comparisons of mammalian basal ganglia with those of ancient vertebrates show significant divergences in structure and function.
text 2: Comparisons of mammalian basal ganglia with those of ancient vertebrates show remarkable similarities in structure and function.

text 1: The basal ganglia primarily function as systems for sensory enhancement and motor suppression.
text 2: The basal ganglia play a recurring role in action selection and reinforcement learning.

text 1: Neurons in the somatosensory cortex are the first to respond differentially to the direction of motion in higher mammals and primates.
text 2: Neurons in the primary visual cortex (area V1) are the first to respond differentially to the direction of motion in higher mammals and primates.

text 1: The frequency of the second test stimulus (f2) in the vibratory task was chosen from a range of values between 10 to 30 Hz.
text 2: The frequency of the second test stimulus (f2) in the vibratory task was chosen from a range of values between 20 to 40 Hz.

text 1: In the random dot motion discrimination task, motion strength is expressed as a percentage coherence ranging from 50% to 150%.
text 2: In the random dot motion discrimination task, motion strength is expressed as a percentage coherence ranging from 0% to 100%.

text 1: The psychometric function models the relationship between the accuracy of an animal’s choice and motion strength.
text 2: The psychometric function models the relationship between neural firing rates and motion strength.

text 1: Area MT contains a complete map of the contralateral visual field and features neurons that are direction-selective.
text 2: Area V1 contains a complete map of the contralateral visual field and features neurons that are direction-selective.

text 1: Direction-tuned neurons in the thalamus contribute noisy evidence to perceptual decisions.
text 2: Leftward and rightward direction-selective neurons contribute noisy evidence to perceptual decisions.

text 1: In flutter-vibration tasks, monkeys identify whether the first vibration frequency is higher or lower than the second frequency.
text 2: In flutter-vibration tasks, monkeys identify whether the second vibration frequency is higher or lower than the first frequency.

text 1: At 0% coherence in the random dot motion task, the dots appear to dance randomly like snowflakes with no dominant direction.
text 2: At 0% coherence in the random dot motion task, the dots appear to move consistently to the right or left.

text 1: Area V1, also known as area V5 in humans, is involved in processing motion direction and strength.
text 2: Area MT, also known as area V5 in humans, is involved in processing motion direction and strength.

text 1: The decision variable in the motion discrimination task represents the difference between firing rates of left- and right-preferring neurons.
text 2: The decision variable in the motion discrimination task represents the average firing rate of all direction-tuned neurons.

text 1: Monkeys perform the random dot motion discrimination task at nearly identical levels to humans.
text 2: Monkeys perform the random dot motion discrimination task at drastically lower levels than humans.

text 1: In the random dot motion task, difficulty is manipulated by degrading the signal-to-noise ratio.
text 2: In the random dot motion task, difficulty is manipulated by increasing the angular difference between motion directions.

text 1: Mountcastle found neurons phase-locked to flutter frequencies but did not observe neurons tuned to specific frequencies like those in area MT.
text 2: Mountcastle observed neurons phase-locked to flutter frequencies and tuned to specific frequencies like those in area MT.

text 1: During trials of the random dot motion task, monkeys are rewarded only during weak-motion trials.
text 2: During trials of the random dot motion task, monkeys are rewarded for correct answers at all levels of difficulty.

text 1: At lower coherence values, random motion introduces variability in the evidence gathered by neurons during the motion discrimination task.
text 2: At lower coherence values, directional neurons eliminate variability in the evidence gathered during the motion discrimination task.

text 1: The gluteus medius muscle in the cat responds to motion in several directions in the horizontal plane, as shown by electromyographic (EMG) activity.
text 2: The gluteus medius muscle in the cat responds exclusively to motion in one direction in the horizontal plane, as shown by electromyographic (EMG) activity.

text 1: Postural responses adapt gradually to new biomechanical conditions and are influenced by recent experience.
text 2: Postural responses immediately adapt to new biomechanical conditions and are not influenced by recent experience.

text 1: When forward sway is induced by backward motion of a narrow beam, posterior muscles of the ankle are activated to restore equilibrium using the hip strategy.
text 2: When forward sway is induced by backward motion of a narrow beam, anterior muscles of the hip and trunk are activated to restore equilibrium using the hip strategy.

text 1: The ankle strategy restores balance primarily by bending forward at the hip joints during postural sway.
text 2: The ankle strategy rotates the body primarily about the ankle joints, restoring balance during postural sway.
