text 1: Trial-to-trial changes in postural behavior occur generally at a subconscious level, involving implicit learning and updates to the body schema.
text 2: Trial-to-trial changes in postural behavior occur instantaneously, involving explicit feedback rather than implicit learning.

text 1: Muscle synergies group the activation of several muscles into fixed proportions to achieve specific postural goals.
text 2: Muscle synergies activate muscles individually to achieve specific postural goals without grouping them into fixed proportions.

text 1: Only four synergies are needed to account for the majority of activation patterns of 13 leg and trunk muscles during postural responses.
text 2: Thirteen synergies are needed to account for the activation patterns of 13 leg and trunk muscles during postural responses.

text 1: Each muscle belongs exclusively to one synergy and contributes to only one postural goal.
text 2: Each muscle belongs to more than one synergy and contributes to multiple postural goals.

text 1: Concurrent activation of synergies simplifies neural command signals while allowing flexibility and adaptability in postural control.
text 2: Concurrent activation of synergies fragments neural command signals, reducing flexibility and adaptability in postural control.

text 1: The center of mass (CoM) remains static and does not involve muscle synergies in response to postural disturbances.
text 2: The center of mass (CoM) is shifted by activating specific muscle synergies in response to postural disturbances.

text 1: Responses to postural disturbances must occur within a time limit or balance will be lost.
text 2: Responses to postural disturbances can occur at any time with no impact on balance.

text 1: Postural commands activate individual muscles rather than synergies to produce coordinated mechanical outputs.
text 2: Postural commands activate synergies rather than individual muscles to produce coordinated mechanical outputs.

text 1: Postural responses become worse with practice and do not show retention as a sign of motor learning.
text 2: Postural responses improve with practice and are retained as a sign of motor learning.

text 1: The hip strategy restores the body's center of mass by rotating the body solely about the ankle joints.
text 2: The hip strategy restores the body's center of mass by bending forward at the hip joints and counter-rotating at the ankles.

text 1: Sensory stimulation changes gradually after moving from the beam to the floor, and postural responses adjust immediately.
text 2: Sensory stimulation changes immediately after moving from the beam to the floor, but postural responses adjust gradually.

text 1: The ease with which we move, from tying our shoelaces to returning a tennis serve, masks the complexity of the control processes involved.
text 2: The complexity of the control processes involved in movement is clearly visible in tasks like tying our shoelaces and returning a tennis serve.

text 1: Motor systems produce neural commands that act directly on the skeletal system, bypassing the muscles entirely.
text 2: Motor systems produce neural commands that act on the muscles, causing them to contract and generate movement.

text 1: Voluntary movements are generated by neural circuits that span different levels of the sensory and motor hierarchies.
text 2: Voluntary movements are generated by neural circuits confined to the spinal cord.

text 1: Focal damage to different structures cannot cause any motor deficits.
text 2: Focal damage to different structures can cause distinct motor deficits.

text 1: The brain and spinal areas function independently without forming a network.
text 2: The brain and spinal areas normally work together as a network.

text 1: The variability inherent in noise limits our ability to perceive accurately and act precisely.
text 2: Noise enhances our ability to perceive accurately and act precisely.

text 1: Motor systems operate without any uncertainty about the state of the world.
text 2: Motor systems have to contend with different forms of uncertainty, such as incomplete knowledge about the state of the world.

text 1: Motor planning is unnecessary when returning an expected tennis serve.
text 2: Motor planning involves adopting an appropriate stance to return the expected serve.

text 1: The motor system increases the degrees of freedom of the musculoskeletal system by controlling individual muscles instead of synergies.
text 2: The motor system reduces the degrees of freedom of the musculoskeletal system by controlling groups of muscles, termed synergies.

text 1: No robot can manipulate a chess piece with the dexterity of a 6-year-old child.
text 2: Robots can now manipulate a chess piece with greater dexterity than a 6-year-old child.

text 1: The control of movement poses no challenges for the nervous system.
text 2: The control of movement poses challenges for the nervous system.

text 1: Prediction cannot compensate for sensorimotor delays.
text 2: Prediction can compensate for sensorimotor delays.

text 1: Feedback control uses neural signals to reinforce movements without correcting them.
text 2: Feedback control uses sensory signals to correct movements.

text 1: The amount of noise in our motor commands tends to increase with stronger commands.
text 2: The amount of noise in our motor commands decreases with stronger commands.

text 1: Skilled performance requires reducing uncertainty by anticipating events we may encounter.
text 2: Skilled performance is unaffected by uncertainty and anticipation of events.

text 1: The abducens nerve (VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
text 2: The abducens nerve (IV) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

text 1: The trochlear nerve (IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle.
text 2: The trochlear nerve (VI) innervates the superior oblique muscle.

text 1: The oculomotor nerve (VI) innervates the medial, superior, and inferior recti, and inferior oblique muscles.
text 2: The oculomotor nerve (III) innervates the medial, superior, and inferior recti, and inferior oblique muscles.

text 1: The superior oblique muscle's tendon passes through the trochlea before inserting on the globe.
text 2: The superior oblique muscle's tendon passes directly on the globe without going through any structure.

text 1: The annulus of Zinn is the common origin of the four rectus muscles.
text 2: The annulus of Zinn is the common insertion point of the four rectus muscles.

text 1: The inferior rectus and superior oblique depress the eye.
text 2: The inferior rectus and inferior oblique depress the eye.

text 1: The extraocular muscles are controlled by three cranial nerves.
text 2: The extraocular muscles are controlled by four cranial nerves.

text 1: Binocular vision prevents stereopsis, making perception of visual scenes in three dimensions impossible.
text 2: Binocular vision facilitates stereopsis, the ability to perceive a visual scene in three dimensions.

text 1: A lesion of the abducens nerve causes weakness of the lateral rectus muscle.
text 2: A lesion of the abducens nerve enhances the strength of the lateral rectus muscle.

text 1: The pupil but not the eyelid receives sympathetic innervation from the intermediolateral cell column of the ipsilateral upper thoracic spinal cord.
text 2: The pupil and eyelid receive sympathetic innervation from the intermediolateral cell column of the ipsilateral upper thoracic spinal cord.

text 1: Oculomotor nerve lesions can result in ptosis and pupillary dilation.
text 2: Oculomotor nerve lesions result only in pupillary contraction, not ptosis.

text 1: Interruption of sympathetic pathways to the eye leads to Horner syndrome.
text 2: Interruption of parasympathetic pathways to the eye leads to Horner syndrome.

text 1: Superior rectus axons cross the midline and join the contralateral oculomotor nerve.
text 2: Superior rectus axons remain on the same side and do not cross over.

text 1: Both superior rectus and superior oblique innervate respective muscles on the same side.
text 2: Both superior rectus and superior oblique innervate respective muscles on the opposite side.

text 1: Relaxation of extraocular muscles results in rotation of the eye.
text 2: Contraction of extraocular muscles results in rotation of the eye.

text 1: At all levels of depolarization, the K+ channels open more rapidly than Na+ channels.
text 2: At all levels of depolarization, the Na+ channels open more rapidly than K+ channels.

text 1: The Na+ channels open rapidly, causing an inward Na+ current.
text 2: The Na+ channels open slowly, causing an inward Na+ current.

text 1: Squid axon Na+ channels do not inactivate; they remain open as long as the membrane is depolarized.
text 2: Squid axon K+ channels do not inactivate; they remain open as long as the membrane is depolarized.

text 1: Depolarization causes Na+ channels to switch between three different states: resting, activated, or inactivated.
text 2: Depolarization causes K+ channels to switch between three different states: resting, activated, or inactivated.

text 1: Hodgkin and Huxley were able to calculate gNa and gK by multiplying measured Na+ and K+ currents by the known Na+ and K+ electrochemical driving forces.
text 2: Hodgkin and Huxley were able to calculate gNa and gK by dividing measured Na+ and K+ currents by the known Na+ and K+ electrochemical driving forces.

text 1: During prolonged depolarization, K+ channels close after opening due to the closure of an inactivation gate.
text 2: During prolonged depolarization, Na+ channels close after opening due to the closure of an inactivation gate.

text 1: The depolarization limits the duration of the action potential by inactivating Na+ channels and opening K+ channels.
text 2: The depolarization extends the duration of the action potential by inactivating Na+ channels and opening K+ channels.

text 1: Both Na+ and K+ channels close in response to depolarization.
text 2: Both Na+ and K+ channels open in response to depolarization.

text 1: The calculations of membrane conductances are done using voltage-clamp currents.
text 2: The calculations of membrane conductances are done using current-clamp currents.

text 1: The Hodgkin-Huxley model is known for its accuracy and success in describing the action potential.
text 2: The Hodgkin-Huxley model is known for its inaccuracies and failures in describing the action potential.

text 1: The inactivation of Na+ channels can be reversed only by depolarizing the membrane to its positive resting potential.
text 2: The inactivation of Na+ channels can be reversed only by repolarizing the membrane to its negative resting potential.

text 1: Voltage-gated sodium and potassium conductances are calculated from their voltages.
text 2: Voltage-gated sodium and potassium conductances are calculated from their currents.

text 1: The variables IK and INa can be calculated from records of current-clamp experiments.
text 2: The variables IK and INa can be calculated from records of voltage-clamp experiments.

text 1: Depolarization causes further depolarization by opening more Na+ channels, a regenerative process.
text 2: Depolarization causes further repolarization by closing more Na+ channels, a regenerative process.

text 1: Measurements of gNa and gK reveal two functional differences and no similarities between Na+ and K+ channels.
text 2: Measurements of gNa and gK reveal two functional similarities and two differences between Na+ and K+ channels.

text 1: The gustatory system detects four basic tastes: sweet, sour, bitter, and salty.
text 2: The gustatory system detects five basic tastes: sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami.

text 1: Chorda tympani, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves terminate in the nucleus of the solitary tract in the brain stem.
text 2: Chorda tympani, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves terminate in the thalamus in the brain stem.

text 1: The detection of five different taste modalities is mediated by different taste receptor cells, each dedicated to one modality.
text 2: The detection of five different taste modalities is mediated by the same taste receptor cell.

text 1: In contrast to sweet, umami, and bitter receptors, salty and sour tastes are detected by ion channels.
text 2: Sweet, salty, umami, and bitter receptors are all detected by ion channels.

text 1: Different GRs are found in sugar cells versus bitter cells.
text 2: The same GRs are found in sugar cells versus bitter cells.

text 1: Sweet tastants are detected by multiple receptors composed of two subunits, T1R2 and T1R3.
text 2: Sweet tastants are detected by a single type of receptor composed of two subunits, T1R2 and T1R3.

text 1: Bitter taste receptors constitute a family of approximately 10 related but diverse receptors.
text 2: Bitter taste receptors constitute a family of approximately 30 related but diverse receptors.

text 1: Odor detection in the nose is mediated by a small family of odorant receptors, numbering approximately 50 in humans.
text 2: Odor detection in the nose is mediated by a large family of odorant receptors, numbering approximately 350 in humans.

text 1: The gustatory cortex projects to a few brain areas involved in feeding only.
text 2: The gustatory cortex projects to many brain areas involved in motor control, feeding, hedonic value, learning, and memory.

text 1: Taste signals travel from taste buds through cranial nerves from gustatory sensory neurons in the geniculate, petrosal, and nodose ganglia.
text 2: Taste signals travel from taste buds through spinal nerves from gustatory sensory neurons in the geniculate, petrosal, and nodose ganglia.

text 1: In the olfactory bulb, the axons of sensory neurons expressing different receptors converge in receptor-specific glomeruli.
text 2: In the olfactory bulb, the axons of sensory neurons expressing the same receptor converge in receptor-specific glomeruli.

text 1: Activation of sugar cells drives food acceptance behavior, whereas activation of bitter cells drives food rejection.
text 2: Activation of sugar cells drives food rejection behavior, whereas activation of bitter cells drives food acceptance.

text 1: Members of the gustatory receptor gene family participate in the detection of sour and umami compounds.
text 2: Members of the gustatory receptor gene family participate in the detection of sugars and bitter compounds.

text 1: The gustatory system detects tastants primarily in taste buds on the tongue and palate epithelium.
text 2: The gustatory system detects tastants primarily in taste buds on the lips and gum epithelium.

text 1: Different odorants activate different combinations of receptors.
text 2: Different odorants activate the same combinations of receptors.

text 1: Serotonin reduces CREB-1 activity, hindering memory consolidation.
text 2: Serotonin enhances CREB-1 activity, promoting memory consolidation.

text 1: piRNA-F enhances methylation of the CREB-2 gene leading to transcriptional repression.
text 2: piRNA-F reduces methylation of the CREB-2 gene leading to transcriptional activation.

text 1: Long-term memory storage is generally thought to affect all synapses equally.
text 2: Long-term memory storage is generally thought to be synapse specific.

text 1: Long-term habituation leads to a loss of synapses, while sensitization leads to an increase.
text 2: Long-term habituation leads to an increase in synapses, while sensitization leads to a decrease.

text 1: Short-term facilitation is observed only following five pulses of serotonin.
text 2: Short-term facilitation is observed following a single pulse of serotonin.

text 1: Sensory neuron synapses with motor neurons undergo structural changes after serotonin application.
text 2: Sensory neuron synapses with motor neurons remain unchanged after serotonin application.

text 1: Long-term synaptic facilitation is synapse specific.
text 2: Long-term synaptic facilitation affects all synapses equally.

text 1: Long-term sensitization of sensory neurons halves the number of presynaptic terminals.
text 2: Long-term sensitization of sensory neurons doubles the number of presynaptic terminals.

text 1: Serotonin application results in decreased varicosities in sensory neuron axons.
text 2: Serotonin application results in increased varicosities in sensory neuron axons.

text 1: Gene products recruited during long-term memory storage may alter the strength of select synapses.
text 2: Gene products recruited during long-term memory storage always alter the strength of all synapses.

text 1: CREB-2 inhibits the action of CREB-1 in the process of memory consolidation.
text 2: CREB-2 enhances the action of CREB-1 in the process of memory consolidation.

text 1: The sensory neuron axon contacts motor neurons to reduce the neural effects of a shock.
text 2: The sensory neuron axon contacts motor neurons to mimic neural effects of a shock.

text 1: Long-term facilitation at synapses requires only electrical stimulation.
text 2: Long-term facilitation at synapses requires gene transcription and protein synthesis.

text 1: All synapses in the neuron manifest long-term facilitation regardless of serotonin signals.
text 2: Only synapses that receive the modulatory serotonin signal manifest long-term facilitation.

text 1: Activation of CREB-1 subsequently activates the transcription factor C/EBP.
text 2: Activation of CREB-1 subsequently inhibits the transcription factor C/EBP.

text 1: Notch signaling inhibits progenitor cells from differentiating into neurons.
text 2: Notch signaling promotes progenitor cells to differentiate into neurons.

text 1: Activation of Notch signaling in glial progenitor cells results in differentiation of the cells as oligodendrocytes and inhibits differentiation as astrocytes.
text 2: Activation of Notch signaling in glial progenitor cells results in differentiation of the cells as astrocytes and inhibits differentiation as oligodendrocytes.

text 1: REST/NRSF is maintained as neurons differentiate, preventing the expression of neurogenic bHLH factors and other neuronal genes.
text 2: REST/NRSF is rapidly degraded as neurons differentiate, permitting the expression of neurogenic bHLH factors and other neuronal genes.

text 1: Radial glial cells serve as the primary scaffold for radial neuronal migration.
text 2: Tangential migration serves as the primary scaffold for radial neuronal migration.

text 1: The layering of neurons in the cerebral cortex follows an inside-first, outside-last rule.
text 2: The layering of neurons in the cerebral cortex follows an outside-first, inside-last rule.

text 1: Cells that migrate from the ventricular and subventricular zones give rise to neurons that settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.
text 2: Cells that migrate from the cortical plate give rise to neurons that settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.

text 1: Interneurons enter the cortex from subcortical sites by a process called radial migration.
text 2: Interneurons enter the cortex from subcortical sites by a process called tangential migration.

text 1: In the mouse mutant reeler, the layering of neurons in the cortical plate is severely disrupted and partially inverted.
text 2: In the mouse mutant reeler, the layering of neurons in the cortical plate is correctly organized and follows the usual pattern.

text 1: Cells that exit the cell cycle at progressively later stages migrate over longer distances and settle in more superficial layers of the cortex.
text 2: Cells that exit the cell cycle at progressively later stages settle in the deepest layers of the cortex.

text 1: A microtubular lattice forms a cage around the nucleus; movement of the nucleus depends on a centrosome-like structure, termed a basal body.
text 2: A microtubular lattice forms a cage around the nucleus; movement of the nucleus does not depend on any specific structure.

text 1: Radial glial scaffolds are especially important in the development of the primate cortex.
text 2: Radial glial scaffolds are not important in the development of the primate cortex.

text 1: A single radial glial cell scaffold can support the migration of up to 30 generations of cortical neurons before differentiating into an astrocyte.
text 2: A single radial glial cell scaffold supports only one generation of cortical neurons before differentiating into an astrocyte.

text 1: The migration of neurons along glial fibers is different from the extension of axons driven by growth cones.
text 2: The migration of neurons along glial fibers is exactly the same as the extension of axons driven by growth cones.

text 1: During normal cortical development, neurons use radial glial cells as migratory scaffolds as they enter the cortical plate.
text 2: During normal cortical development, neurons use tangential glial cells as migratory scaffolds as they enter the cortical plate.

text 1: Adhesive receptors such as integrins promote neuronal extension on radial glial cells.
text 2: Adhesive receptors such as integrins inhibit neuronal extension on radial glial cells.

text 1: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) initiates locomotion by directly activating neurons in the spinal locomotor system without involvement of the medial reticular formation.
text 2: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) initiates locomotion by activating neurons in the medial reticular formation whose axons descend in the ventrolateral funiculus to the spinal locomotor system.

text 1: In a decerebrate cat, stimulating group I fibers from ankle extensors prevents initiation of the swing phase during walking.
text 2: In a decerebrate cat, stimulating group I fibers from ankle flexors prevents initiation of the swing phase during walking.

text 1: Corrective responses to a mild stimulus applied to the paw during the swing phase produce excitation of flexor motor neurons and inhibition of extensor motor neurons.
text 2: Corrective responses to a mild stimulus applied to the paw during the swing phase produce inhibition of flexor motor neurons and excitation of extensor motor neurons.

text 1: The pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) contains only glutamatergic neurons.
text 2: The pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) contains both glutamatergic and cholinergic neurons.

text 1: Glutamatergic neurons in the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) are necessary for high-speed locomotion such as gallop and bound.
text 2: Glutamatergic neurons in the cuneiform nucleus (CNF) are necessary for high-speed locomotion such as gallop and bound.

text 1: The corrective reflex during locomotion is phase-dependent, producing opposite responses in stance and swing phases.
text 2: The corrective reflex during locomotion is phase-independent, producing identical responses regardless of the phase.

text 1: Serotonergic pathways involved in locomotion have been observed in the caudal brain stem of mammals.
text 2: Serotonergic pathways involved in locomotion have been observed exclusively in spinal cord circuits in mammals.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of the mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) in the cat can change gait from slow walking to galloping.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of the mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) in the cat exclusively produces slow walking without altering gait.

text 1: The cuneiform nucleus receives input principally from structures involved in escape responses.
text 2: The cuneiform nucleus receives input principally from the basal ganglia and sensorimotor cortex.

text 1: Supraspinal structures like the cerebellum and basal ganglia regulate speed and postural balance during locomotion.
text 2: Supraspinal structures like the spinal cord regulate speed and postural balance during locomotion.

text 1: The mesencephalic locomotor region is exclusive to mammals and absent in other vertebrates.
text 2: The mesencephalic locomotor region is evolutionarily conserved across vertebrates.

text 1: Selective activation of glutamatergic neurons in the PPN supports slower exploratory locomotion such as walking and trotting.
text 2: Selective activation of glutamatergic neurons in the PPN supports faster locomotion such as galloping and bound.

text 1: Neurons in the subthalamic locomotor region bypass the PPN and CNF to initiate locomotion.
text 2: Neurons in the subthalamic locomotor region exclusively rely on connections with the PPN to initiate locomotion.

text 1: The corrective reflex in cats is largely mediated by circuits entirely contained in the spinal cord.
text 2: The corrective reflex in cats is primarily mediated by supraspinal circuits outside the spinal cord.

text 1: Neurons in the medial reticular formation relay excitatory signals to the spinal cord through both glutamatergic and serotonergic pathways.
text 2: Neurons in the medial reticular formation relay excitatory signals to the spinal cord exclusively through serotonergic pathways.

text 1: The amygdala consists of approximately 15 nuclei, but the lateral and central nuclei are especially important in fear conditioning.
text 2: The amygdala consists of approximately 12 nuclei, but the lateral and central nuclei are especially important in fear conditioning.

text 1: The medial nucleus of the amygdala receives most sensory input, while the lateral nucleus receives olfactory input.
text 2: The lateral nucleus of the amygdala receives most sensory input, while the medial nucleus receives olfactory input.

text 1: The amygdala plays a role in evaluating the emotional charge of a stimulus and can influence cognitive functions such as attention, perception, memory, and decision making.
text 2: The amygdala is solely responsible for evaluating the emotional charge of a stimulus and does not influence cognitive functions such as attention, perception, memory, and decision making.

text 1: The central nucleus of the amygdala relays signals to regions controlling motor responses, including freezing behavior.
text 2: The basal nucleus of the amygdala relays signals to regions controlling motor responses, including freezing behavior.

text 1: Research using optogenetics has shown that the prefrontal cortex, not the amygdala, plays the primary role in fear learning.
text 2: Research using optogenetics has begun to dissect the amygdala’s role in fear learning by manipulating specific neurons.

text 1: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions fail to show fear reactions to externally presented threats but can react with panic to interoceptive stimuli such as suffocation.
text 2: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions fail to show fear reactions to both externally presented threats and interoceptive stimuli such as suffocation.

text 1: Freezing behavior is mediated by connections from the central nucleus of the amygdala to the dorsal periaqueductal gray region.
text 2: Freezing behavior is mediated by connections from the central nucleus of the amygdala to the ventral periaqueductal gray region.

text 1: The medial amygdala processes unconditioned threats such as predator odors, while the lateral amygdala processes auditory threats.
text 2: The medial amygdala processes auditory threats, while the lateral amygdala processes unconditioned threats such as predator odors.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity in the amygdala underlies fear learning, with key contributions from the lateral and central nuclei.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity in the amygdala underlies fear learning, but the basal nucleus is the sole contributor to this process.

text 1: Humans can exhibit fear responses to a conditioned stimulus (CS) even without directly experiencing the unconditioned stimulus (US), as through observation or verbal instruction.
text 2: Humans cannot exhibit fear responses to a conditioned stimulus (CS) unless they directly experience the unconditioned stimulus (US).

text 1: The amygdala is not necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning, as animals with amygdala damage can still associate the CS and US.
text 2: The amygdala is necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning, as animals with amygdala damage fail to associate the CS and US.

text 1: Patients with amygdala damage often lack autonomic fear responses to external stimuli but may experience panic in response to interoceptive cues.
text 2: Patients with amygdala damage often lack autonomic fear responses to any stimuli, whether external or interoceptive.

text 1: Snakes and spiders are universally feared innate stimuli that no humans ever keep as pets.
text 2: Snakes and spiders are thought to be innate fear stimuli for some people, though others may keep them as pets without fear.

text 1: The amygdala modulates cognitive functions through projections to the cortex, including the prefrontal and sensory cortices.
text 2: The amygdala does not influence cognitive functions and lacks projections to cortical structures.

text 1: Human fear learning includes uniquely advanced mechanisms such as active pedagogy, where another person teaches someone that a stimulus is dangerous.
text 2: Human fear learning is entirely reliant on direct personal experience and lacks advanced mechanisms like active pedagogy.

text 1: Neurons in the hypothalamus receive only sensory feedback inputs and do not anticipate future homeostatic challenges.
text 2: Neurons in the hypothalamus receive top-down feedforward inputs from neurons that anticipate future homeostatic challenges.

text 1: Key regulatory neurons for body temperature are located in the arcuate nucleus.
text 2: Key regulatory neurons for body temperature are located in the median preoptic nucleus (MnPO).

text 1: The sympathetic preganglionic cell column is confined to the cranial and sacral sections of the spinal cord.
text 2: The sympathetic preganglionic cell column extends between the cervical and lumbosacral enlargements of the spinal cord.

text 1: The parasympathetic pathways arise from cranial nerve zones in the brain stem and sacral segments of the spinal cord.
text 2: The parasympathetic pathways arise from thoracic nerve zones in the spinal cord.

text 1: The sympathetic motor system regulates solely the digestive processes in the body.
text 2: The sympathetic motor system regulates systemic physiological parameters such as blood pressure and body temperature.

text 1: Preganglionic neurons synthesize and release acetylcholine, which acts on nicotinic ACh receptors on postganglionic neurons.
text 2: Preganglionic neurons synthesize and release dopamine, which acts on nicotinic ACh receptors on postganglionic neurons.

text 1: The autonomic system is divided into sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric divisions.
text 2: The autonomic system is divided into sympathetic and skeletal muscle divisions.

text 1: Effector cells controlled by autonomic neurons include smooth muscle, gland cells, and cardiac muscle.
text 2: Effector cells controlled by autonomic neurons include skeletal muscle and epithelial cells in the skin.

text 1: Similar to the somatic motor system, autonomic motor neurons are found in the central nervous system.
text 2: Unlike the somatic motor system, autonomic motor neurons are found in ganglia.

text 1: Gravity-specific hypothalamic neurons link interoceptive sensory feedback with outputs that control adaptive behaviors and physiological responses.
text 2: Modality-specific hypothalamic neurons link interoceptive sensory feedback with outputs that control adaptive behaviors and physiological responses.

text 1: The median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) does not play a role in the regulation of water balance.
text 2: The median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) is one of the sites that regulates water balance.

text 1: Langley proposed that specific chemical substances must be released by preganglionic neurons of the autonomic ganglia.
text 2: Langley proposed that autonomic ganglia operate without the need for chemical substances released by preganglionic neurons.

text 1: Thermogenesis by brown adipose tissue is largely subservient to the hypothalamus.
text 2: Thermogenesis by brown adipose tissue is independent of the hypothalamus.

text 1: Visceral motor neurons in the autonomic system are organized into direct pathways.
text 2: Visceral motor neurons in the autonomic system are organized into ganglia.

text 1: The autonomic system operates independently of the brain stem and spinal cord.
text 2: The autonomic system is also regulated by circuits in the brain stem and spinal cord.

text 1: Purkinje cells are normally inactive, and they excite their downstream targets.
text 2: Purkinje cells are normally spontaneously active, and they inhibit their downstream targets.

text 1: Studies of the cerebellum illustrate how neural circuits mediate learning through trial and error.
text 2: Studies of the cerebellum show how neural circuits mediate learning by direct supervision.

text 1: The cerebellum is a focus of intense experimental and theoretical research on learning and memory.
text 2: The cerebellum is lightly researched with little theoretical focus on learning and memory.

text 1: Granule–Purkinje cell synapses exhibit plasticity leading to learned motor responses.
text 2: Granule–Purkinje cell synapses are rigid and incapable of learning motor responses.

text 1: Purkinje cells integrate a rich diversity of signals related to both the external world and the animal's internal state.
text 2: Purkinje cells integrate signals exclusively related to the external world.

text 1: Climbing fibers provide positive reinforcement to strengthen synapses that were previously inactive.
text 2: Climbing fibers provide error signals to weaken synapses that were previously active.

text 1: Functional MRI is non-invasive and does not require surgery or ionizing radiation.
text 2: Functional MRI is invasive and requires surgery or ionizing radiation.

text 1: fMRI measures activity in isolated regions of the brain sequentially.
text 2: fMRI measures activity across the whole brain simultaneously.

text 1: Neural circuits rely exclusively on recurrent motifs to handle information from sensory streams.
text 2: Neural circuits use feedforward motifs to process information from sensory streams.

text 1: Neural coding describes how stimulus features are represented by neuronal activity.
text 2: Neural coding describes how intended actions are hidden from neuronal activity.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity supports longer-lasting changes in neural circuits underlying learning and memory.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity leads to short-term changes that are unrelated to memory.

text 1: Hebbian plasticity requires constant supervision to extract signals from inputs.
text 2: Hebbian plasticity can extract signals from a complex set of inputs without supervision.

text 1: Computer simulations have shown that learning of appropriately timed responses is impossible without external stimuli.
text 2: Computer simulations have shown that learning of appropriately timed responses can be explained by granule–Purkinje cell synapse plasticity.

text 1: Functional MRI experiments measure neurovascular activity.
text 2: Functional MRI experiments measure neurocellular activity.

text 1: Direct evidence for temporal representations in granule cells within the mammalian cerebellum has been abundantly obtained.
text 2: Direct evidence for temporal representations in granule cells within the mammalian cerebellum has not yet been obtained.

text 1: Chemical synapses dampen neuronal signals and can produce only excitatory actions in postsynaptic cells.
text 2: Chemical synapses amplify neuronal signals and can produce either excitatory or inhibitory actions in postsynaptic cells.

text 1: Electrical synapses are employed primarily for rapid and synchronous signal transmission between interconnected cells.
text 2: Electrical synapses are employed primarily for slow and asynchronous signal transmission between interconnected cells.

text 1: At chemical synapses, neurotransmitters are directly transferred through gap junctions to the postsynaptic cell.
text 2: At chemical synapses, neurotransmitters diffuse across the synaptic cleft to interact with postsynaptic receptors.

text 1: Electrical synapses involve cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells via gap-junction channels.
text 2: Electrical synapses lack cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells and operate through synaptic clefts.

text 1: The distance between pre- and postsynaptic cell membranes at electrical synapses is approximately 40 nm.
text 2: The distance between pre- and postsynaptic cell membranes at electrical synapses is approximately 4 nm.

text 1: Chemical synapses typically have a synaptic delay of at least 0.3 milliseconds and often longer.
text 2: Chemical synapses experience no synaptic delay regardless of signaling conditions.

text 1: Electrical synaptic transmission was first demonstrated in the mammalian motor cortex.
text 2: Electrical synaptic transmission was first demonstrated in the giant motor synapse of the crayfish.

text 1: Chemical synaptic transmission does not involve neurotransmitter release but instead relies on passive ion flow between neurons.
text 2: Chemical synaptic transmission involves neurotransmitter release that binds to postsynaptic receptors to initiate changes in ion channel activity.

text 1: Voltage-gated ion channels in the postsynaptic cell initiate neurotransmitter release at electrical synapses.
text 2: Voltage-gated ion channels in the presynaptic cell play a critical role in generating the ionic current at electrical synapses.

text 1: The term 'synapse' was introduced at the beginning of the 18th century by Charles Sherrington.
text 2: The term 'synapse' was introduced at the beginning of the 20th century by Charles Sherrington.

text 1: Chemical synapses allow direct cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and postsynaptic cells through special channels.
text 2: In contrast to electrical synapses, chemical synapses have a synaptic cleft between pre- and postsynaptic cells, preventing cytoplasmic continuity.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity refers to the ability of synapses to enhance or diminish their strength based on neuronal activity.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity permanently fixes synaptic strength, preventing changes based on neuronal activity.

text 1: Chemical synapses can initiate changes in the postsynaptic cell lasting from milliseconds to hours.
text 2: Chemical synapses have no lasting effect on postsynaptic cells, regardless of signal duration.

text 1: Electrical synapses are usually bidirectional, enabling current flow in both directions.
text 2: Electrical synapses are always unidirectional, allowing current flow only in one direction.

text 1: Chemical synapses prevent depolarization in the postsynaptic cell due to the lack of ion channel activity.
text 2: Chemical synapses can initiate a depolarization in the postsynaptic cell by opening ion channels upon neurotransmitter binding.

text 1: Movement planning and execution are completely segregated at the level of single neurons or neural populations in a given cortical area.
text 2: Movement planning and execution are not completely segregated at the level of single neurons or neural populations in a given cortical area.

text 1: In a reaction-time task, the monkey knows in advance in which direction to move before the target appears.
text 2: In a reaction-time task, the monkey does not know in which direction to move until the target appears.

text 1: The parietal cortex is a key brain region in sensory processing for motor action.
text 2: The parietal cortex is mainly involved in auditory processing for motor action.

text 1: The S-I and adjacent superior parietal cortex regions PE, MIP, and PEip are primarily involved in olfactory sensory information processing.
text 2: The S-I and adjacent superior parietal cortex regions PE, MIP, and PEip are a major source of proprioceptive and tactile sensory information.

text 1: Monkeys with experimental lesions in Brodmann’s area 2 and the adjacent superior parietal lobule show improved ability in reaching to and manipulating objects under proprioceptive and tactile guidance without vision.
text 2: Monkeys with experimental lesions in Brodmann’s area 2 and the adjacent superior parietal lobule show deficits in reaching to and manipulating objects under proprioceptive and tactile guidance without vision.

text 1: The posterior parietal cortex contains a single functional area that works in parallel and receives the same combination of sensory and motor inputs.
text 2: The posterior parietal cortex contains several distinct functional areas that work in parallel and receive different combinations of sensory and motor inputs.

text 1: Human subjects with lesions of the posterior parietal cortex often demonstrate no impairments in using sensory information to guide motor action.
text 2: Human subjects with lesions of the posterior parietal cortex often demonstrate specific impairments in using sensory information to guide motor action.

text 1: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) respond primarily to auditory input from extrastriate cortical areas.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) respond to visual input from extrastriate cortical areas.

text 1: Many VIP neurons respond to visual stimuli and somatosensory stimuli with receptive fields on the face or head.
text 2: Many VIP neurons respond only to olfactory stimuli with receptive fields on the face or head.

text 1: Each functional area in the parietal cortex is isolated from frontal motor regions involved in control of the same effectors.
text 2: Each functional area in the parietal cortex is connected to frontal motor regions involved in control of the same effectors.

text 1: Neurons in areas PE and PEip provide a less stable signal about the location of the reach target relative to the current position of the hand.
text 2: Neurons in areas PE and PEip provide a more stable signal about the location of the reach target relative to the current position of the hand.

text 1: The parietal reach region (PRR) corresponds solely to the lateral prefrontal cortex.
text 2: The parietal reach region (PRR) likely corresponds to the medial intraparietal cortex (MIP) and adjacent arm-control parts of the superior and inferior parietal cortex.

text 1: Many neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) shift to new spatial locations whenever the monkey changes its direction of gaze.
text 2: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) maintain a fixed spatial location despite changes in the monkey's direction of gaze.

text 1: The parietal lobe, especially PE, PEip, and MIP, receives visual sensory inputs about body posture and movement from S-I.
text 2: The parietal lobe, especially PE, PEip, and MIP, receives strong somatic sensory inputs about body posture and movement from S-I.

text 1: The ventral intraparietal area (VIP) is involved in the analysis of auditory signals and sound localization.
text 2: The ventral intraparietal area (VIP) is involved in the analysis of optic flow and visual motion.

text 1: The amygdala is implicated in both negatively valenced and positively valenced emotions through distinct populations of neurons.
text 2: The amygdala is exclusively implicated in negatively valenced emotions and does not process positively valenced stimuli.

text 1: Emotions are neurobiological states that trigger coordinated behavioral and cognitive responses due to brain activity.
text 2: Emotions are purely psychological states with no involvement of the brain's neurobiological processes.

text 1: The physiological systems engaged during emotional states include the endocrine glands, autonomic motor system, and musculoskeletal system.
text 2: The physiological systems engaged during emotional states exclude the endocrine glands and musculoskeletal system, focusing solely on the autonomic motor system.

text 1: Subjective ratings of emotions depend on culture-specific words and concepts for emotions.
text 2: Subjective ratings of emotions are universally independent of culture-specific words and concepts for emotions.

text 1: Potentiation of the startle reflex is used to assess anxiety levels in both humans and animals.
text 2: Potentiation of the startle reflex is exclusively used to assess anxiety levels in humans and has not been validated in animals.

text 1: The galvanic skin response measures parasympathetic autonomic relaxation derived from palm dryness.
text 2: The galvanic skin response measures sympathetic autonomic arousal derived from palm sweatiness.

text 1: Facial electromyography (EMG) can provide fine-grained information about emotions.
text 2: Facial electromyography (EMG) primarily measures valence and arousal, not fine-grained emotional information.

text 1: Experience sampling quantifies emotions experienced in everyday life by stopping participants during their ongoing activities.
text 2: Experience sampling quantifies emotions experienced in everyday life solely through passive observation, without active participant engagement.

text 1: Darwin’s 1872 book 'The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals' noted the correspondence between human and animal behavior.
text 2: Darwin’s 1872 book 'The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals' was solely focused on human emotional behavior, with no mention of animals.

text 1: Unconditioned stimuli require associative learning to trigger emotions, such as a painful shock or disgusting taste.
text 2: Unconditioned stimuli can trigger emotions without any prior learning, such as a painful shock or disgusting taste.

text 1: Hormonal responses to emotional states are typically slower than psychophysiological measures.
text 2: Hormonal responses to emotional states are typically faster than psychophysiological measures.

text 1: Emotional states can influence cognitive processes such as attention, memory processing, and decision making.
text 2: Emotional states are entirely separate from cognitive processes like attention, memory processing, and decision making.

text 1: Emotional responses can be updated through extinction and regulation mechanisms.
text 2: Emotional responses are static and cannot be updated through extinction or regulation mechanisms.

text 1: Animals rarely exhibit stereotyped behaviors as a consequence of emotional states, making their responses unpredictable.
text 2: Animals often exhibit stereotyped behaviors as a consequence of certain emotional states, such as freezing or attacking.

text 1: A single population of neurons in the amygdala exclusively processes either negatively or positively valenced stimuli.
text 2: Distinct populations of neurons in the amygdala process negatively valenced and positively valenced stimuli.

text 1: PER protein is highly stable and effectively represses CLOCK-dependent per transcription without degradation.
text 2: PER protein is highly unstable; most of it is degraded so quickly that it never has a chance to repress CLOCK-dependent per transcription.

text 1: Activation of cGMP signaling in young honeybees can cause them to enter the forager stage prematurely.
text 2: Activation of cAMP signaling in young honeybees can cause them to enter the forager stage prematurely.

text 1: The difference between social and solitary worms is caused by a single amino acid substitution in a single gene, npr-1.
text 2: The difference between social and solitary worms is caused by a deletion of a gene, npr-1.

text 1: Male prairie voles form long-lasting pair-bonds with females and help them raise their offspring.
text 2: Male prairie voles do not form pair-bonds with females and do not help raise their offspring.

text 1: The for gene is expressed at high levels in the brains of young nurse honeybees and at low levels in the older foraging bees.
text 2: The for gene is expressed at high levels in the brains of active foraging honeybees and at low levels in the younger nurse bees.

text 1: When PER binds to TIM, PER is protected from degradation.
text 2: When PER binds to TIM, PER is tagged for degradation.

text 1: Light activates cryptochrome, which destroys TIM protein.
text 2: Darkness activates cryptochrome, which destroys TIM protein.

text 1: Honeybees exhibit different behaviors at different stages of their life; in general, young bees are nurses, while older bees become foragers.
text 2: Honeybees exhibit the same behaviors throughout their life; both young and older bees are foragers.

text 1: Oxytocin released in the brain of female prairie voles during mating stimulates pair-bond formation.
text 2: Oxytocin released in the brain of female prairie voles during mating inhibits pair-bond formation.

text 1: During daylight, TIM protein is degraded by signaling pathways that are regulated by light.
text 2: During daylight, TIM protein accumulates unregulated by light.

text 1: Neuropeptide receptors have been implicated in the regulation of mammalian social behavior.
text 2: Neuropeptide receptors have not been implicated in the regulation of mammalian social behavior.

text 1: Light signaling pathways regulate cryptochrome and TIM protein degradation.
text 2: Light signaling pathways promote cryptochrome binding and TIM protein stabilization.

text 1: The foraging behavior difference in Drosophila melanogaster maps to multiple unrelated genes.
text 2: The foraging behavior difference in Drosophila melanogaster maps to a single protein kinase gene, for.

text 1: V1a vasopressin receptors are expressed at high levels in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.
text 2: V1a vasopressin receptors are expressed at low levels in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.

text 1: In montane voles, V1a vasopressin receptor levels are much lower in the ventral pallidum, although high in other brain regions.
text 2: In montane voles, V1a vasopressin receptor levels are much higher in the ventral pallidum than in other brain regions.

text 1: Serotonin is synthesized in a group of brain stem nuclei called the raphe nuclei, and these neurons project widely to areas including the forebrain and spinal cord.
text 2: Serotonin is synthesized exclusively in the cortex and does not project outside of the forebrain.

text 1: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) primarily metabolizes neurotransmitters only within synaptic vesicles, breaking down serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
text 2: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) metabolizes neurotransmitters in the cytoplasm, specifically breaking down serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.

text 1: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) were first approved in the 1980s and selectively inhibit SERT for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders.
text 2: The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) were first discovered in the 1950s and selectively inhibit NET for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders.

text 1: Ketamine represents a traditional antidepressant approach because it primarily acts on monoamine neurotransmission.
text 2: Ketamine represents a novel antidepressant approach because it does not exert its primary action on monoamine neurotransmission.

text 1: Cognitive therapies for depression aim to enhance automatic negative thinking to develop coping mechanisms.
text 2: Cognitive therapies for depression aim to correct excessively negative interpretations of events and interactions.

text 1: The raphe nuclei form a continuous collection of cell groups close to the midline of the brainstem and extend along its length.
text 2: The raphe nuclei are located exclusively in the forebrain and do not extend along the brainstem.

text 1: Monoamine neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine originate exclusively from cortical neurons.
text 2: Monoamine neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine originate from cells within brain stem nuclei.

text 1: Tricyclic antidepressants only block dopamine transporters and are ineffective on norepinephrine or serotonin reuptake.
text 2: Tricyclic antidepressants block the norepinephrine transporter (NET) and serotonin reuptake transporter (SERT), with some blocking both.

text 1: MAO inhibitors accelerate the breakdown of neurotransmitters like norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine, reducing their availability for release.
text 2: MAO inhibitors prevent the breakdown of neurotransmitters like norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine, increasing their availability for release.

text 1: Ketamine produces antidepressant effects slowly over several weeks and lasts indefinitely after intravenous infusion.
text 2: Ketamine has been shown to produce antidepressant effects within 2 hours, lasting approximately 7 days after intravenous infusion.

text 1: Serotonergic neurons project only to the spinal cord, excluding brain regions like the hypothalamus or hippocampus.
text 2: Serotonergic neurons project extensively to brain regions including the hypothalamus, hippocampus, amygdala, basal ganglia, and cerebral cortex.

text 1: Inhibition of MAO-A in the gut can allow bioactive amines like tyramine to enter the bloodstream and cause elevated blood pressure.
text 2: Inhibition of MAO-A in the gut prevents bioactive amines like tyramine from entering the bloodstream, lowering blood pressure.

text 1: SSRIs are widely used because of their milder side effects and greater safety in overdose compared to older antidepressant drugs.
text 2: SSRIs are rarely used due to severe side effects and high risk in overdose compared to older antidepressant drugs.

text 1: The locus ceruleus is a dopamine-producing nucleus located exclusively within the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The locus ceruleus is the largest norepinephrine-producing nucleus located beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle in the rostrolateral pons.

text 1: Monoamine neurotransmitters bind synaptic receptors after vesicular release to exert their effects or are cleared from the synapse by specific transporter proteins.
text 2: Monoamine neurotransmitters are not released from synaptic vesicles but act directly through cytoplasmic diffusion.

text 1: PMd neurons are selectively activated in monkeys when reaching for a target despite target uncertainty.
text 2: PRR neurons are selectively activated in monkeys when reaching for a target despite target uncertainty.

text 1: Dorsal premotor cortex is involved in applying rules that govern behavior based on associations.
text 2: The parietal cortex is involved in applying rules that govern behavior based on associations.

text 1: The neural activity in the dorsal premotor cortex of monkeys during movement planning can be viewed as transitions between different activation states.
text 2: The neural activity in the parietal cortex of monkeys during movement planning can be viewed as transitions between different activation states.

text 1: In the PMd, neurons that prefer potential reach movements are simultaneously activated during target uncertainty.
text 2: In the PRR, neurons that prefer potential reach movements are simultaneously activated during target uncertainty.

text 1: Neurons in premotor areas respond selectively to specific cues in monkeys trained to associate cues with movements.
text 2: Neurons in sensory areas respond selectively to specific cues in monkeys trained to associate cues with movements.

text 1: A dynamical system perspective suggests that planning-related neural activity does not initiate movement because it reflects specific network states.
text 2: A chemical process perspective suggests that planning-related neural activity does not initiate movement because it reflects specific network states.

text 1: During the planning phase, activity patterns in the PRR reflect different states in the network.
text 2: During the planning phase, activity patterns in the PMd reflect different states in the network.

text 1: Neurons in PRR encode potential reach actions during target uncertainty.
text 2: Neurons in PMd encode potential reach actions during target uncertainty.

text 1: Neurons in the PMd change activity rapidly to signal the chosen reach movement after the color cue appears.
text 2: Neurons in the PRR change activity rapidly to signal the chosen reach movement after the color cue appears.

text 1: In an instructed-delay task, the cell's activity decreases if the monkey is instructed not to move after the go cue appears.
text 2: In an instructed-delay task, the cell's activity increases if the monkey is instructed not to move after the go cue appears.

text 1: The PMd is implicated in the acquisition of new movement-related associations or rules.
text 2: The PRR is implicated in the acquisition of new movement-related associations or rules.

text 1: Cells are sorted based on their preferred movement direction in the PMd during a reach task.
text 2: Cells are sorted based on their preferred movement direction in the PRR during a reach task.

text 1: The activity of sensory cortex neurons in monkeys is evident in making decisions about response choices.
text 2: The activity of premotor cortex neurons in monkeys is evident in making decisions about response choices.

text 1: Activity patterns during planning and execution reflect different network states, including a delay period state in the PRR.
text 2: Activity patterns during planning and execution reflect different network states, including a delay period state in the PMd.

text 1: The PRR plays a role in mapping color cues to target locations in a two-target task.
text 2: The PMd plays a role in mapping color cues to target locations in a two-target task.

text 1: The vomeronasal organ (VNO) in mice is anatomically connected to the accessory olfactory bulb (AOB).
text 2: The vomeronasal organ (VNO) in mice is anatomically connected to the main olfactory bulb (MOB).

text 1: Female mice treated with testosterone exhibit male sexual behavior toward females.
text 2: Female mice treated with testosterone exhibit female mating behavior more intensely than untreated females.

text 1: High levels of DNA methylation at the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) promoter in rat pups lead to lower levels of GR expression in the hippocampus.
text 2: High levels of DNA methylation at the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) promoter in rat pups lead to increased levels of GR expression in the hippocampus.

text 1: Pups reared by high-LG mothers exhibit less anxiety-like behavior in stressful conditions compared to pups reared by low-LG mothers.
text 2: Pups reared by high-LG mothers exhibit higher anxiety-like behavior in stressful conditions compared to pups reared by low-LG mothers.

text 1: Oxytocin regulates milk let-down reflex through stimulation by suckling.
text 2: Oxytocin regulates smooth muscle contraction in the mammary gland, but not through stimulation by suckling.

text 1: Female offspring of high-LG mothers exhibit lower oxytocin receptor levels in specific brain regions compared to female offspring of low-LG mothers.
text 2: Female offspring of high-LG mothers exhibit higher oxytocin receptor levels in specific brain regions compared to female offspring of low-LG mothers.

text 1: In neonatal rodent females, testosterone directly masculinizes the brain without being converted into estrogen.
text 2: In neonatal rodent females, testosterone is converted into estrogen, which can masculinize the brain.

text 1: Testosterone plasticity contributes to changes in hypothalamic connectivity across the female estrous cycle.
text 2: Estrogen plasticity contributes to changes in hypothalamic connectivity across the female estrous cycle.

text 1: Female mice lack the neural circuitry for male sexual behavior, and its activation is precluded by their genetics.
text 2: Female mice possess the neural circuitry for male sexual behavior, but its activation is inhibited by sensory input from the VNO and lack of testosterone.

text 1: Early tactile stimulation by high-LG mothers reduces hypothalamic stress hormone release in rat pups.
text 2: Early tactile stimulation by high-LG mothers increases hypothalamic stress hormone release in rat pups.

text 1: Maternal behavior in rats can be pharmacologically reversed by modifying epigenetic marks at the GR promoter.
text 2: Maternal behavior in rats is genetically fixed and cannot be reversed by altering epigenetic marks.

text 1: Sexual dimorphic behaviors in rodents are regulated by sexually dimorphic circuits within shared neural pathways.
text 2: Sexual dimorphic behaviors in rodents are regulated by unique neural pathways found only in one sex.

text 1: Maternal behavior in rats is influenced by early-life experience rather than solely by genetic factors.
text 2: Maternal behavior in rats is solely determined by genetic factors and not influenced by early-life experience.

text 1: The estrous cycle in female rodents involves periodic hormonal-driven reconfiguration of synapses.
text 2: The estrous cycle in female rodents does not involve periodic hormonal-driven reconfiguration of synapses.

text 1: Oxytocin and vasopressin only regulate milk production and have no role in social behaviors.
text 2: Oxytocin and vasopressin regulate both maternal bonding behaviors and other social interactions via brain receptors.

text 1: The discharge rate has a greater influence on muscle force than does changes in the number of active motor units.
text 2: The discharge rate has a lesser influence on muscle force than does changes in the number of active motor units.

text 1: Monoaminergic input from the brain stem cannot adjust the gain of the motor unit pool to meet the demands of different tasks.
text 2: Monoaminergic input from the brain stem can adjust the gain of the motor unit pool to meet the demands of different tasks.

text 1: The sliding filament hypothesis of muscle contraction was proposed by A. F. Huxley and H. E. Huxley in the 1950s.
text 2: The sliding filament hypothesis of muscle contraction was proposed by A. F. Huxley and H. E. Huxley in the 1960s.

text 1: Muscle force depends on the arrangement of fibers in the muscle as well as motor neuron activity.
text 2: Muscle force depends only on the motor neuron activity and not on the arrangement of fibers in the muscle.

text 1: Sarcomeres are arranged in parallel to form a myofibril.
text 2: Sarcomeres are arranged in series to form a myofibril.

text 1: The transverse tubules, terminal cisternae, and sarcoplasmic reticulum constitute a storage system for proteins.
text 2: The transverse tubules, terminal cisternae, and sarcoplasmic reticulum constitute an activation system that transforms an action potential into the sliding of the thick and thin filaments.

text 1: During muscle activation, the width of the light band decreases while the width of the dark band remains unchanged.
text 2: During muscle activation, the width of the dark band decreases while the width of the light band remains unchanged.

text 1: The primary components of the thin filament are two helical strands of fibrous G-actin.
text 2: The primary components of the thin filament are two helical strands of fibrous F-actin.

text 1: Tropomyosin consists of two coiled strands that lie outside the F-actin helix.
text 2: Tropomyosin consists of two coiled strands that lie in the groove of the F-actin helix.

text 1: The force generated by an activated sarcomere can be explained by the cross-bridge cycle when its length does not change or decreases.
text 2: The force generated by an activated sarcomere is independent of the cross-bridge cycle.

text 1: The dendrites of motor neurons passively transmit synaptic current to the cell body in the absence of monoaminergic input.
text 2: The dendrites of motor neurons actively transmit synaptic current in the absence of monoaminergic input.

text 1: A brief inhibitory input can terminate self-sustained firing in an active motor neuron.
text 2: A brief excitatory input can terminate self-sustained firing in an active motor neuron.

text 1: Calcium is stored in the mitochondria next to transverse tubules.
text 2: Calcium is stored in the terminal cisternae next to transverse tubules.

text 1: The force that each sarcomere generates arises solely from the interaction of thick filaments.
text 2: The force that each sarcomere generates arises from the interaction of thick and thin filaments.

text 1: The excitability of the pool of motor neurons innervating a single muscle is independent of the brain stem.
text 2: The excitability of the pool of motor neurons innervating a single muscle is partly under control of the brain stem.

text 1: The initial segment of the axon is known as the trigger zone because it has the highest density of voltage-sensitive Na+ channels.
text 2: The initial segment of the axon is known as the trigger zone because it has the lowest density of voltage-sensitive Na+ channels.

text 1: The action potential does not decay as it travels along the axon to its target.
text 2: The action potential decays as it travels along the axon to its target.

text 1: Neurotransmitter molecules are contained in the neuron’s plasma membrane.
text 2: Neurotransmitter molecules are contained in synaptic vesicles.

text 1: The frequency of action potentials determines the intensity of sensation.
text 2: The amplitude of action potentials determines the intensity of sensation.

text 1: Synaptic potentials are graded either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing.
text 2: Synaptic potentials are all-or-none and always depolarizing.

text 1: Action potentials vary significantly from one nerve cell to another.
text 2: Action potentials vary only subtly from one nerve cell to another.

text 1: The output signal of a neuron is graded according to the amount of neurotransmitter released.
text 2: The output signal of a neuron is fixed regardless of the amount of neurotransmitter released.

text 1: Individual neurons, not interconnected pathways, convey information.
text 2: Interconnected neurons form anatomically and functionally distinct pathways that convey information.

text 1: Some spontaneously active nerve cells fire action potentials regularly.
text 2: Some spontaneously active nerve cells fire in regular bursts of action potentials.

text 1: The action potential is graded: stimuli below threshold can produce variable signal strengths.
text 2: The action potential is all-or-none: stimuli below threshold do not produce a signal.

text 1: An excitatory synaptic potential cannot initiate action potentials in a non-spontaneously active cell.
text 2: An excitatory synaptic potential may initiate action potentials in a non-spontaneously active cell.

text 1: All neurons use the same ion channels and transmitters, leading to uniform synaptic potential encodings.
text 2: Neurons differ in the ion channels and transmitters they use, affecting synaptic potential encodings.

text 1: Some neurons do not generate action potentials due to the lack of a conductive axon component.
text 2: All neurons generate action potentials regardless of their axon components.

text 1: The amplitude and duration of action potentials vary with the intensity of stimuli.
text 2: The amplitude and duration of action potentials remain the same regardless of the intensity of stimuli.

text 1: Neurotransmitter effects depend on the type of receptor in the postsynaptic cell, not the transmitter itself.
text 2: Neurotransmitter effects depend solely on the chemical neurotransmitter, not the receptor type.

text 1: Inhibition can establish periods of silence in spontaneously active cells.
text 2: Inhibition cannot establish periods of silence in spontaneously active cells.

text 1: The human brain is a network of more than 8 million individual nerve cells.
text 2: The human brain is a network of more than 80 billion individual nerve cells.

text 1: Neural science attempts to link the computational logic of neural circuitry to the mind.
text 2: Neural science attempts to link the computational logic of neural circuitry to genetics.

text 1: Traditional imaging techniques permit us to visualize the human brain in action.
text 2: New imaging techniques permit us to visualize the human brain in action.

text 1: The randomness of synaptic connections established during development underlies behavior.
text 2: The specificity of synaptic connections established during development underlies behavior.

text 1: Part Editors: Eric R. Kandel and Michael N. Shadlen.
text 2: Part Editors: William James and Sigmund Freud.

text 1: It is impossible to link the cellular dynamics of interconnected circuits of neurons to perceptual and motor acts in the brain.
text 2: Today, it is possible to link the cellular dynamics of interconnected circuits of neurons to perceptual and motor acts in the brain.

text 1: The focus of biology has shifted to the study of ecosystems in the first half of the 21st century.
text 2: The focus of biology has shifted to neural science in the first half of the 21st century.

text 1: Cognitive psychology and psychoanalytic theory have emphasized the diversity and complexity of human mental experience.
text 2: Cognitive psychology and psychoanalytic theory have emphasized the simplicity of human mental experience.

text 1: Our goal is to provide only the facts without principles of brain organization, function, and computation.
text 2: Our goal is to provide not simply the facts but the principles of brain organization, function, and computation.

text 1: The brain weighs only 2 kilograms.
text 2: The brain weighs only 1.5 kg.

text 1: In the first part of this book, mental functions are generalized across the entire brain.
text 2: In the first part of this book, mental functions can be localized to specific regions of the brain.

text 1: Technological advances have closed off possibilities for the scientific study of the brain.
text 2: Technological advances have opened new horizons for the scientific study of the brain.

text 1: Neural circuits construct perceptions of the external world and guide decisions.
text 2: Neural circuits have no role in constructing perceptions of the external world or guiding decisions.

text 1: The study of mind begins with the study of behavior, as proposed by Aristotle.
text 2: The study of mind begins with the study of the brain, as proposed by Hippocrates.

text 1: Genes encode proteins that play no role in the development of neural circuits.
text 2: Genes encode proteins that initially govern the development of neural circuits.

text 1: The presynaptic terminal of the neuromuscular junction is filled with a dye rhodamine-B under active conditions, showing local hotspots of intracellular Mg2+ in response to a dual presynaptic action potential.
text 2: The presynaptic terminal at the neuromuscular junction is filled with a dye fura-2 under resting conditions, showing local hotspots of intracellular Ca2+ in response to a single presynaptic action potential.

text 1: A presynaptic action potential typically produces a prolonged rise in presynaptic K+ concentration because the K+ channels open for an extended period.
text 2: A presynaptic action potential normally produces only a brief rise in presynaptic Ca2+ concentration because the Ca2+ channels open only for a short time.

text 1: Experiments revealed that a rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 μM is sufficient to induce release of some transmitter.
text 2: Experiments showed that a rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 mM is necessary to prevent the release of any transmitter.

text 1: Neurons contain three broad classes of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels: the L-type, I-type, and S-type.
text 2: Neurons contain five broad classes of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels: the L-type, P/Q-type, N-type, R-type, and T-type.

text 1: The calyx synapse comprises less than a hundred active zones that function as dependent release sites.
text 2: The calyx synapse includes almost a thousand active zones that function as independent release sites.

text 1: Once Ca2+ enters the terminal, the transmitter is gradually released with a delay of several hundred milliseconds.
text 2: Once Ca2+ enters the terminal, the transmitter is rapidly released with a delay of only a few hundred microseconds.

text 1: The synaptic delay is mainly due to the time required to close Na+ channels.
text 2: The synaptic delay is largely attributable to the time required to open Ca2+ channels.

text 1: Calcium channels are monomeric proteins whose distinct properties are determined by their pore-blocking subunit, the β1-subunit.
text 2: Calcium channels are multimeric proteins whose distinct properties are determined by their pore-forming subunit, the α1-subunit

text 1: The large presynaptic terminal of the calyx of Held in the mammalian brain stem engulfs a postsynaptic cell body.
text 2: The small post synaptic terminal of the calyx of Held in the mammalian brain stem engulfs a presynaptic cell body.

text 1: A rise in K+ concentration of less than 0.5 μM is sufficient to prevent release of some transmitter, but 5 to 15 μM K+ is required for normal release.
text 2: A rise in Ca2+ concentration of less than 1 μM is sufficient to induce release of some transmitter, but 10 to 30 μM Ca2+ is required for normal release.

text 1: In skeletal and cardiac muscle cells, sodium channels are crucial for excitation-contraction coupling.
text 2: In skeletal and cardiac muscle cells, calcium channels are important for excitation-contraction coupling.

text 1: The calyx of Held synapse specializes in rapid and reliable transmission to allow precise sound localization.
text 2: The calyx of Held synapse specializes in slow and sporadic transmission, hindering precise sound localization.

text 1: A presynaptic action potential normally produces a brief rise in presynaptic Ca2+ concentration.
text 2: A presynaptic action potential normally produces an extended rise in presynaptic Mg2+ concentration.

text 1: The α1-subunit of calcium channels is homologous to the β-subunit of voltage-gated Cl- channels.
text 2: The α1-subunit of calcium channels is homologous to the α-subunit of voltage-gated Na+ channels.

text 1: A model depicts that release is triggered by a major K+ sensor that binds two Ca2+ ions.
text 2: A model depicts that release is triggered by a major Ca2+ sensor that binds five Ca2+ ions.

text 1: The basal ganglia are important for adapting postural responses to a sudden change in initial conditions.
text 2: The basal ganglia are unimportant for adapting postural responses to a sudden change in initial conditions.

text 1: Lesions of insular cortex do not affect perception of the visual vertical.
text 2: Lesions of insular cortex can impair perception of the visual vertical.

text 1: The rostral and ventral subdivisions of the anterior cingulate cortex have extensive connections with the hippocampus, amygdala, orbital prefrontal cortex, anterior insula, and nucleus accumbens and are involved in the integration of emotion, cognition, and autonomic nervous system function.
text 2: The caudal subdivision of the anterior cingulate cortex has extensive connections with the hippocampus, amygdala, orbital prefrontal cortex, anterior insula, and nucleus accumbens and are involved in the integration of emotion, cognition, and autonomic nervous system function.

text 1: Studies of rodents have shown that new neurons within the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus can be incorporated into functional neural circuits.
text 2: Studies of rodents have shown that new neurons within the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus cannot be incorporated into functional neural circuits.

text 1: Increased hippocampal volume has been reported in cases of PTSD and in major depression.
text 2: Reduced hippocampal volume has been reported in cases of PTSD and in major depression.

text 1: Excess glucocorticoid secretion, as occurs in depression, could cause hippocampal volume loss by inhibiting neurogenesis over time.
text 2: Excess glucocorticoid secretion, as occurs in depression, enhances hippocampal volume by stimulating neurogenesis over time.

text 1: Major depressive disorder can be treated effectively with antidepressant drugs, cognitive psychotherapy, and electroconvulsive therapy.
text 2: Major depressive disorder can be treated effectively only with electroconvulsive therapy.

text 1: Current antidepressant drugs affect monoaminergic neural systems.
text 2: Current antidepressant drugs exclusively affect dopaminergic neural systems.

text 1: Induced sadness in healthy subjects decreases activity in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex.
text 2: Induced sadness in healthy subjects increases activity in the rostral anterior cingulate cortex.

text 1: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry may play a role in the symptoms of mood disorders.
text 2: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry are unrelated to the symptoms of mood disorders.

text 1: The reward circuitry comprises the dopaminergic projections from the ventral tegmental area of the midbrain to forebrain targets.
text 2: The reward circuitry comprises projections from the cerebellum to forebrain targets.

text 1: Volume reductions in patients with major depression correlate with the duration of depressive episodes.
text 2: Volume reductions in patients with major depression correlate with improved mood.

text 1: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry are not associated with symptoms of mood disorders.
text 2: Functional abnormalities of brain reward circuitry may also play a role in the symptoms of mood disorders.

text 1: The acquired loss of hippocampal volume in major depression could result from either loss of dendrites and dendritic spines or decreased cell numbers.
text 2: The acquired loss of hippocampal volume in major depression does not result from loss of dendrites and dendritic spines.

text 1: Stressful or aversive treatments inhibit the proliferation of granule cell precursors and suppress normal rates of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.
text 2: Stressful or aversive treatments enhance the proliferation of granule cell precursors and boost rates of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.

text 1: Antidepressants increase the rate of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.
text 2: Antidepressants decrease the rate of neurogenesis in the hippocampus.

text 1: Elevated cortisol levels in patients with major depression might be associated with reduced hippocampal volumes.
text 2: Elevated cortisol levels in patients with major depression might be associated with increased hippocampal volumes.

text 1: Neurons greatly outnumber glial cells—there are 2 to 10 times more neurons than glia in the vertebrate central nervous system.
text 2: Glial cells greatly outnumber neurons—there are 2 to 10 times more glia than neurons in the vertebrate central nervous system.

text 1: Interneurons comprise the most numerous functional category, subdivided into relay and local classes.
text 2: Motor neurons comprise the most numerous functional category, subdivided into relay and local classes.

text 1: A complex behavior, the knee-jerk reflex, is controlled by a circuit of sensory and motor neurons.
text 2: A simple behavior, the knee-jerk reflex, is controlled by a circuit of sensory and motor neurons.

text 1: Local interneurons have long axons and convey signals over considerable distances.
text 2: Relay or projection interneurons have long axons and convey signals over considerable distances.

text 1: Sensory neurons supply the brain with data, whereas motor neurons convert ideation into praxis.
text 2: Motor neurons supply the brain with data, whereas sensory neurons convert ideation into praxis.

text 1: Sensory neurons make only excitatory connections in the knee-jerk reflex.
