text 2: Sensory neurons make both excitatory and inhibitory connections in the knee-jerk reflex.

text 1: Feedforward inhibition in the knee-jerk reflex involves only flexor muscles.
text 2: Feedforward inhibition in the knee-jerk reflex involves both extensor and flexor muscles.

text 1: The dendrites of the retinal ganglion cells determine their type based on size and shape.
text 2: The axons of the retinal ganglion cells determine their type based on size and shape.

text 1: Glia do not form dendrites and axons.
text 2: Glia form dendrites and axons like neurons.

text 1: Divergence is common at the output stages of the nervous system.
text 2: Convergence is common at the output stages of the nervous system.

text 1: The knee-jerk reflex is a stretch reflex activated by tapping the tendon just below the patella.
text 2: The knee-jerk reflex is a flexion reflex activated by tapping the tendon just below the patella.

text 1: The sensory neurons involved in the knee-jerk reflex are pseudo-unipolar cells.
text 2: The sensory neurons involved in the knee-jerk reflex are bipolar cells.

text 1: Afferent neurons from flexor muscles excite inhibitory interneurons in the knee-jerk reflex.
text 2: Afferent neurons from extensor muscles excite inhibitory interneurons in the knee-jerk reflex.

text 1: The knee-jerk reflex is used clinically to test the integrity of the nerves.
text 2: The knee-jerk reflex is used clinically to test the elasticity of the muscles.

text 1: Local interneurons have short axons because they form connections with nearby neurons.
text 2: Local interneurons have long axons because they form connections with nearby neurons.

text 1: In the macaque monkey, V1 is located on the surface of the occipital lobe and sends axons in two pathways.
text 2: In the macaque monkey, V1 is located on the surface of the frontal lobe and sends axons in two pathways.

text 1: The dorsal or movement-guidance pathway connects the primary visual cortex directly to the temporal lobes.
text 2: The dorsal or movement-guidance pathway connects the primary visual cortex with the parietal lobe and then with the frontal lobes.

text 1: Patients with lesions of temporal areas fail to attend to objects on one side of the body, a syndrome called unilateral neglect.
text 2: Patients with lesions of parietal areas fail to attend to objects on one side of the body, a syndrome called unilateral neglect.

text 1: The inferior temporal cortex stores information about the shapes and identities of objects; damage to that region results in the inability to recognize faces (prosopagnosia).
text 2: The parietal cortex stores information about the shapes and identities of objects; damage to that region results in the inability to recognize faces (prosopagnosia).

text 1: Receptive fields with the same eccentricity are relatively large at early levels in visual processing and become progressively smaller at later levels.
text 2: Receptive fields with the same eccentricity are relatively small at early levels in visual processing and become progressively larger at later levels.

text 1: Functional specificity has been demonstrated for a number of visual areas: VO1 is implicated in object shape processing.
text 2: Functional specificity has been demonstrated for a number of visual areas: VO1 is implicated in color processing.

text 1: A ventral pathway projects through V4 into areas of the inferior temporal cortex and mediates object recognition.
text 2: A ventral pathway projects through V4 into areas of the frontal lobe and mediates object recognition.

text 1: The pulvinar in the thalamus serves as a relay between cortical areas.
text 2: The lateral geniculate nucleus in the thalamus serves as a relay between cortical areas.

text 1: The on-center cells fire when a spot of light is turned off within a circular central region.
text 2: The on-center cells fire when a spot of light is turned on within a circular central region.

text 1: The lateral occipital complex is involved in representing points in space that are the targets of eye movements or reaching.
text 2: The lateral intraparietal area is involved in representing points in space that are the targets of eye movements or reaching.

text 1: Areas in the intraparietal sulcus are involved in control of spatial attention and saccadic eye movements.
text 2: Areas in the inferior temporal cortex are involved in control of spatial attention and saccadic eye movements.

text 1: The fusiform face area (FFA) codes places.
text 2: The fusiform face area (FFA) codes faces.

text 1: Responses to only one spot of light yielded a comprehensive understanding of a cell’s receptive field.
text 2: Responses to only one spot of light yielded a limited understanding of a cell’s receptive field.

text 1: The boundaries of these maps can be used to demarcate the boundaries of auditory areas.
text 2: The boundaries of these maps can be used to demarcate the boundaries of visual areas.

text 1: The extrastriate body area (EBA) responds more strongly to objects than body parts.
text 2: The extrastriate body area (EBA) responds more strongly to body parts than objects.

text 1: Current maps usually place the primary motor cortex (M1) in Brodmann’s area 4.
text 2: Current maps usually place the primary motor cortex (M1) in Brodmann’s area 6.

text 1: Optimal feedback control emphasizes the importance of feedback signals for the planning and control of movements.
text 2: Optimal feedback control emphasizes the importance of feedforward signals for the planning and control of movements.

text 1: Experimental tasks dissociate different types of movement-related information by revealing differences in neural activity across cortical motor regions.
text 2: Experimental tasks show uniform neural activity across all cortical motor regions regardless of the movement-related information.

text 1: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes cutaneous and muscle mechanoreceptor signals.
text 2: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes visual and auditory signals.

text 1: The optimal feedback control framework divides the control of voluntary movements into two key processes: state estimation and control policy.
text 2: The optimal feedback control framework divides the control of voluntary movements into three key processes: state estimation, task selection, and control policy.

text 1: At the neuromuscular junction, EEPSP = +5 mV, EK = −10 mV, and ENa = +55 mV.
text 2: At the neuromuscular junction, EEPSP = 0 mV, EK = −100 mV, and ENa = +55 mV.

text 1: Tetrodotoxin blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channel but does not block the influx of Na+ through the nicotinic ACh receptor-channels.
text 2: Tetrodotoxin blocks the voltage-gated K+ channel but does not block the influx of Na+ through the nicotinic ACh receptor-channels.

text 1: The conductance of the ACh receptor-channel for K+ is slightly higher than for Na+.
text 2: The conductance of the ACh receptor-channel for Na+ is slightly higher than for K+.

text 1: The ACh receptors have one binding site for ACh, which must be occupied by transmitter for the channel to open efficiently.
text 2: The ACh receptors have two binding sites for ACh, both must be occupied by transmitter for the channel to open efficiently.

text 1: A minimal reaction model captures key steps of ACh receptor-channel function.
text 2: A complex reaction model captures key steps of ACh receptor-channel function.

text 1: Recent infrared spectroscopy data have provided a direct view of the large pore of the ACh receptor-channel.
text 2: Recent X-ray crystallographic data have provided a direct view of the large pore of the ACh receptor-channel.

text 1: The rapid opening of a few channels causes a large increase in the total conductance of the end-plate membrane.
text 2: The rapid opening of many channels causes a large increase in the total conductance of the end-plate membrane.

text 1: α-bungarotoxin binds tightly to the nicotinic receptors and blocks the action of ACh but does not interfere with voltage-gated Na+ channels.
text 2: α-bungarotoxin binds loosely to the nicotinic receptors and blocks the action of ACh but does not interfere with voltage-gated Na+ channels.

text 1: Heavy smokers can build up sufficient levels of nicotine to desensitize receptors in the brain.
text 2: Heavy smokers can build up insufficient levels of nicotine to desensitize receptors in the brain.

text 1: To trigger an action potential, a synaptic potential must recruit neighboring voltage-gated Na+ channels.
text 2: To trigger an action potential, a synaptic potential must recruit neighboring voltage-gated K+ channels.

text 1: The end-plate potential resulting from the opening of acetylcholine receptor-channels opens voltage-gated sodium channels.
text 2: The end-plate potential resulting from the opening of acetylcholine receptor-channels opens voltage-gated potassium channels.

text 1: The mature nicotinic ACh receptor is a membrane glycoprotein formed from three subunits.
text 2: The mature nicotinic ACh receptor is a membrane glycoprotein formed from five subunits.

text 1: One molecule of ACh must bind at each of the two sites for the channel to open efficiently.
text 2: Two molecules of ACh must bind at each of the two sites for the channel to open efficiently.

text 1: Two types of ion channels generate the end-plate potential by allowing both Na+ and K+ to pass with nearly equal permeability.
text 2: A single type of ion channel, the ACh receptor-channel, generates the end-plate potential by allowing both Na+ and K+ to pass with nearly equal permeability.

text 1: The action potential is generated by simultaneous activation of three distinct classes of voltage-gated channels.
text 2: The action potential is generated by sequential activation of two distinct classes of voltage-gated channels.

text 1: Feedback control systems are known as feedback or closed-loop control because the sensorimotor loop is complete.
text 2: Feedback control systems are known as open-loop control because the sensorimotor loop is incomplete.

text 1: If feedback delay increases, the control system may start to oscillate and eventually become unstable.
text 2: If feedback delay decreases, the control system may start to oscillate and eventually become unstable.

text 1: Internal models can answer how can we perceive body temperature and predict weather conditions.
text 2: Internal models can answer how can we generate motor commands and predict their consequences.

text 1: The simplest form of feedback control occurs when the error is below a certain threshold.
text 2: The simplest form of feedback control occurs when the error exceeds a certain threshold.

text 1: Smooth pursuit eye movement uses feedforward to maximize the velocity error on the retina.
text 2: Smooth pursuit eye movement uses feedback to minimize the velocity error on the retina.

text 1: Skilled motor performance requires both control and prediction.
text 2: Skilled motor performance requires control but not prediction.

text 1: Internal sensorimotor models only represent the internal state of the body.
text 2: Internal sensorimotor models represent relationships of the body and external world.

text 1: Feedback control is immune to feedback delays.
text 2: Feedback control can be sensitive to feedback delays.

text 1: Internal models force an organism to act out consequences to understand them.
text 2: Internal models allow an organism to contemplate consequences without committing to actions.

text 1: State estimation cannot be improved by combining sensory modalities.
text 2: State estimation can be improved by combining multiple sensory modalities.

text 1: Prediction and control map onto forward and inverse models.
text 2: Prediction and control are unrelated to forward and inverse models.

text 1: The vestibulo-ocular reflex offers precise fixation due to feedforward control.
text 2: The vestibulo-ocular reflex offers precise fixation due to feedback control.

text 1: Sophisticated computation is required to estimate current body states accurately.
text 2: Estimation of body states is simple and requires no computation.

text 1: Estimating the body’s state uses internal models of sensorimotor transformations.
text 2: Estimating the body’s state does not use any form of internal models.

text 1: Feedback control is insensitive to noise and delays.
text 2: Feedback control is robust to noise but sensitive to delays.

text 1: A single motor neuron may be the target of as many as 10,000 different presynaptic terminals.
text 2: A single motor neuron may be the target of only 100 different presynaptic terminals.

text 1: The reversal potential for Cl− is typically more positive than the resting potential, leading to hyperpolarization.
text 2: The reversal potential for Cl− is typically more negative than the resting potential, leading to hyperpolarization.

text 1: GABAB responses turn on more slowly and persist for a longer time compared with GABAA responses.
text 2: GABAB responses turn on more quickly and persist for a shorter time compared with GABAA responses.

text 1: 5-HT3 receptor-channels are impermeable to monovalent cations and have a reversal potential far from 0 mV.
text 2: 5-HT3 receptor-channels are permeable to monovalent cations and have a reversal potential near 0 mV.

text 1: EPSPs produced by motor neurons are often 10 to 12 mV in amplitude.
text 2: EPSPs produced by motor neurons are often only 0.2 to 0.4 mV in amplitude.

text 1: P2X receptor-channels are impermeable to Ca2+, with a reversal potential near 0 mV.
text 2: P2X receptor-channels are permeable to both monovalent cations and Ca2+, with a reversal potential near 0 mV.

text 1: Neuronal integration reflects the task that confronts the nervous system as a whole.
text 2: Neuronal integration is unrelated to the task that confronts the nervous system as a whole.

text 1: In some neurons, the resting potential is substantially different from ECl, making the electrochemical driving force on Cl− large.
text 2: In some neurons, the resting potential is approximately equal to ECl, making the electrochemical driving force on Cl− nearly zero.

text 1: The opening of Cl− channels results in a positive current corresponding to an influx of Cl− ions.
text 2: The opening of Cl− channels results in a negative current corresponding to an influx of Cl− ions.

text 1: Opening Cl− channels in neurons can result in amplification or enhancing effects.
text 2: Opening Cl− channels in neurons can result in short-circuiting or shunting effects.

text 1: Some central neurons have a resting potential nearly equal to the Cl− reversal potential.
text 2: All central neurons have a resting potential much more positive than the Cl− reversal potential.

text 1: Excitatory inputs added in neurons result in division.
text 2: Excitatory inputs added in neurons result in summation.

text 1: Cl− efflux frequently leads to hyperpolarizing responses under all conditions.
text 2: Cl− efflux can lead to depolarizing responses under certain conditions.

text 1: The charge carrier in Cl− channel opening is a positively charged Cl− ion.
text 2: The charge carrier in Cl− channel opening is a negatively charged Cl− ion.

text 1: Activation of GABAA receptors can cause depolarization in newborn animals.
text 2: Activation of GABAA receptors typically causes hyperpolarization in newborn animals.

text 1: During transport of glutamate, one negatively charged molecule of the transmitter is imported with three Na+ ions and one proton in exchange for the export of two K+, leading to a net influx of three positive charges.
text 2: During transport of glutamate, one negatively charged molecule of the transmitter is imported with three Na+ ions and one proton in exchange for the export of one K+, leading to a net influx of two positive charges.

text 1: The psychostimulatory effects of cocaine result from its action to prevent reuptake of dopamine, thereby increasing its extracellular levels.
text 2: The psychostimulatory effects of cocaine result from its action to enhance the uptake of dopamine, thereby reducing its extracellular levels.

text 1: Synaptic vesicles in the periphery are highly concentrated in nerve endings and, in the brain, tend to be at varicosities along the axon at presynaptic sites.
text 2: Synaptic vesicles in the periphery are scarce in nerve endings and, in the brain, never tend to be at varicosities along the axon at presynaptic sites.

text 1: The enzymes that regulate transmitter biosynthesis are under loose regulation and cannot produce homeostatic changes in the levels and activity of these enzymes.
text 2: The enzymes that regulate transmitter biosynthesis are under tight regulatory control and can produce homeostatic changes in the levels and activity of these enzymes.

text 1: Glutamate transport requires the countertransport of K+ driven by the electrochemical potential provided by the Na+ gradient.
text 2: Glutamate transport requires the cotransport of Cl− driven by the electrochemical potential provided by the Na+ gradient.

text 1: The co-release of several neuroactive substances onto appropriate postsynaptic receptors limits the diversity of information to be transferred in a single synaptic action.
text 2: The co-release of several neuroactive substances onto appropriate postsynaptic receptors permits great diversity of information to be transferred in a single synaptic action.

text 1: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release through DAT occurs independently of phosphorylation of its N-terminus.
text 2: Amphetamine-induced dopamine release through DAT requires phosphorylation of its N-terminus.

text 1: Precise mechanisms for terminating transmitter actions are not important compared to transmitting synthesis and release.
text 2: Precise mechanisms for terminating transmitter actions are nearly as important as transmitting synthesis and release.

text 1: The normal physiological role of the phosphorylation of DAT's N-terminus remains a mystery.
text 2: The normal physiological role of the phosphorylation of DAT's N-terminus is fully understood.

text 1: The NSS proteins can run backward, allowing them to generate transmitter efflux and are best characterized for dopamine.
text 2: The NSS proteins run strictly forward, which restricts their ability to generate transmitter efflux for dopamine.

text 1: Acetylcholine is rapidly hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase to choline and acetate.
text 2: Acetylcholine is slowly converted by acetyltransferase to acetyl-CoA and acetate.

text 1: Computational studies suggest phosphorylation-regulated interactions of DAT's N-terminus with acidic lipids play a role in modulating transporter function.
text 2: Experimental studies show phosphorylated interactions of DAT's C-terminus with neutral lipids play a role in modulating transporter function.

text 1: Small-molecule transmitters are taken up and highly concentrated in vesicles, protected from degradative enzymes in the cytoplasm.
text 2: Small-molecule transmitters are dispersed loosely in the cytoplasm and vulnerable to degradative enzymes.

text 1: All molecules released by a neuron are chemical messengers regardless of receptor binding and functional initiation.
text 2: Not all molecules released by a neuron are chemical messengers—only those that bind to appropriate receptors and initiate functional changes are considered neurotransmitters.

text 1: The electrochemical driving force is never sufficient for NSS transporters to carry transmitters into the cell, resulting in the decrease of cytoplasmic transmitter concentration.
text 2: The electrochemical driving force is often sufficient for NSS transporters to carry transmitters into the cell, thereby increasing the cytoplasmic transmitter concentration.

text 1: The deepest dendrites of J-RGCs are represented in blue in the transgenic labeling of the mouse retina.
text 2: The deepest dendrites of J-RGCs are represented in red in the transgenic labeling of the mouse retina.

text 1: The history of developmental neurobiology excludes Santiago Ramón y Cajal's anatomical studies on the nervous system's structure.
text 2: The history of developmental neurobiology includes Santiago Ramón y Cajal's anatomical studies on the nervous system's structure.

text 1: Transcription factors do not play a role in controlling gene expression during neural development.
text 2: Some molecules that control neural development are transcription factors that regulate gene expression.

text 1: Genetic programs governing body plan and neural connectivity are conserved throughout phylogeny.
text 2: Genetic programs governing body plan and neural connectivity are not conserved throughout phylogeny.

text 1: Axons of many neuronal types must often navigate long distances during neural development.
text 2: Axons of many neuronal types only travel short distances during neural development.

text 1: The experience-dependent remodeling of the brain is minimal and short-lived in humans.
text 2: The experience-dependent remodeling of the brain is especially prominent and prolonged in humans.

text 1: Santiago Ramón y Cajal used electron microscopy to deduce developmental principles of neurobiology.
text 2: Santiago Ramón y Cajal deduced many developmental principles of neurobiology using light microscopic analysis of fixed tissue.

text 1: Neuronal wiring includes the migration of somata, axon guidance, and synaptic connection formation.
text 2: Neuronal wiring exclusively involves synaptic connection formation.

text 1: The first epoch of neural development involves the generation and differentiation of neurons and glia.
text 2: The first epoch of neural development primarily involves the establishment of synaptic connections.

text 1: Transcription factors, which are cell-autonomous factors, regulate gene expression during neural development.
text 2: Transcription factors, which are cell non-autonomous factors, regulate gene expression during neural development.

text 1: Cell non-autonomous factors do not involve cell surface or secreted molecules.
text 2: Cell non-autonomous factors include cell surface and secreted molecules that arise from other cells.

text 1: Neurological diseases have no connection to neural development studies.
text 2: The etiology of some neurological diseases is being elucidated through neural development studies.

text 1: Butterflies and beetles are the primary organisms used to study neural development.
text 2: Fruit flies and nematode worms are genetically accessible organisms used to study neural development.

text 1: The nervous system's plasticity is evident during early life and can be recruited in adults.
text 2: The nervous system's plasticity is purely a factor of early life and cannot be recruited in adults.

text 1: Developmental neurobiology has progressed significantly with advances in methods like electrophysiology and molecular biology.
text 2: Developmental neurobiology has remained unchanged due to a lack of advancements in methods.

text 1: The neocortex receives inputs exclusively from cortical regions on both sides of the brain.
text 2: The neocortex receives inputs from the thalamus, other cortical regions on both sides of the brain, and other subcortical structures.

text 1: Layer IV in the primary visual cortex is sparsely populated by neurons, making it less complex and not divided into sublayers.
text 2: Layer IV in the primary visual cortex is so heavily populated by neurons and so complex that it is divided into three sublayers.

text 1: Areas with a prominent layer IV are called granular cortex.
text 2: Areas with a prominent layer IV are called agranular cortex.

text 1: Layer V, the internal pyramidal cell layer, contains mainly pyramidally shaped cells that are typically smaller than those in layer III.
text 2: Layer V, the internal pyramidal cell layer, contains mainly pyramidally shaped cells that are typically larger than those in layer III.

text 1: Layer VI is called the monomorphic or single-form layer.
text 2: Layer VI is called the polymorphic or multiform layer.

text 1: Korbinian Brodmann divided the cerebral cortex into 30 regions based on cytoarchitectonic differences.
text 2: Korbinian Brodmann divided the cerebral cortex into 47 regions based on cytoarchitectonic differences.

text 1: The neocortex's organization reduces its computational efficiency.
text 2: The neocortex's organization increases its computational efficiency.

text 1: The Golgi stain reveals the pattern of myelinated fibers.
text 2: The Golgi stain reveals a subset of neuronal cell bodies, axons, and dendritic trees.

text 1: Approximately one-third of the neocortex is along the deep wrinkles of the cortex, termed sulci.
text 2: Approximately two-thirds of the neocortex is along the deep wrinkles of the cortex, termed sulci.

text 1: Layer IV is primarily responsible for processing motor output.
text 2: Layer IV is the main recipient of sensory input from the thalamus.

text 1: The neurons located deeper in layer III are typically smaller than those located more superficially.
text 2: The neurons located deeper in layer III are typically larger than those located more superficially.

text 1: The thickness of individual layers and details of their functional organization are uniform throughout the cortex.
text 2: The thickness of individual layers and details of their functional organization vary throughout the cortex.

text 1: Layer I, the molecular layer, contains primarily axons and lacks dendrites.
text 2: Layer I, the molecular layer, is occupied by the dendrites of cells located in deeper layers and axons that travel through this layer.

text 1: The external granular cell layer is one of two layers that contain small spherical neurons.
text 2: The external pyramidal cell layer exclusively contains small spherical neurons.

text 1: Corticocortical connections arise primarily from neurons in layers II and III.
text 2: Corticocortical connections arise primarily from neurons in layers IV and V.

text 1: Synaptotagmin mediates K+-dependent transmitter release by forming a protein complex that favors vesicle fusion.
text 2: Synaptotagmin mediates Ca2+-dependent transmitter release by forming a protein complex that favors vesicle fusion.

text 1: Vesicles are tethered to filamentous proteins of the active zone.
text 2: Vesicles are untethered in the active zone, floating freely.

text 1: Zippering of the synaptotagmin-complexin-SNARE complex inhibits vesicle fusion.
text 2: Zippering of the synaptotagmin-complexin-SNARE complex mediates vesicle fusion.

text 1: Synaptic depression refers to an increase in the size of the postsynaptic response to repeated stimulation.
text 2: Synaptic depression refers to a decrease in the size of the postsynaptic response to repeated stimulation.

text 1: During tetanic stimulation, so much Ca2+ flows into the axon terminals that Ca2+ buffering and clearance systems can become saturated.
text 2: During tetanic stimulation, so little Ca2+ flows into the axon terminals that they deplete Ca2+ buffering systems.

text 1: Low-frequency stimulation is called tetanic stimulation and can cause dramatic changes in synaptic strength.
text 2: High-frequency stimulation is called tetanic stimulation and can cause dramatic changes in synaptic strength.

text 1: The active zone releases neurotransmitters without regulating docking and priming of synaptic vesicles.
text 2: The active zone coordinates and regulates the docking and priming of synaptic vesicles.

text 1: RIM and RIM-BP mediate the recruitment of K+ channels to the active zone.
text 2: RIM and RIM-BP mediate the recruitment of Ca2+ channels to the active zone.

text 1: Synaptic facilitation is the reduction of transmission with repeated stimulation.
text 2: Synaptic facilitation is the enhancement of transmission with repeated stimulation.

text 1: Munc13 and RIM are used to counteract vesicle depletion during high-frequency stimulation.
text 2: Munc13 and RIM are used to promote vesicle depletion during high-frequency stimulation.

text 1: Phosphorylation of RIM by cAMP-dependent protein kinase inhibits transmitter release.
text 2: Phosphorylation of RIM by cAMP-dependent protein kinase enhances transmitter release.

text 1: Synaptic vesicle binding to RIM and Munc13 is unnecessary for exocytosis.
text 2: Synaptic vesicle binding to RIM and Munc13 is essential for priming vesicles for exocytosis.

text 1: Residual Ca2+ diminishes synaptic transmission by deactivating Ca2+-dependent enzymes.
text 2: Residual Ca2+ enhances synaptic transmission by activating Ca2+-dependent enzymes.

text 1: Synaptic plasticity stabilizes synaptic effectiveness, preventing changes.
text 2: Synaptic plasticity can dramatically and rapidly modulate synaptic effectiveness.

text 1: Axosomatic synaptic actions selectively control individual terminals of the axon.
text 2: Axosomatic synaptic actions affect all branches of the postsynaptic neuron’s axon.

text 1: Long-term potentiation can last for many hours or days.
text 2: Long-term potentiation can last for a few seconds.

text 1: Electrical synaptic transmission is slow because it results from indirect passage of current between cells.
text 2: Electrical synaptic transmission is rapid because it results from the direct passage of current between cells.

text 1: The tail-flip response of goldfish is mediated by a giant neuron in the brain stem known as the Mauthner cell.
text 2: The tail-flip response of goldfish is mediated by a small neuron in the spinal cord known as the Mauthner cell.

text 1: Gap-junction channels conduct only organic compounds and proteins, excluding inorganic cations and anions.
text 2: Gap-junction channels conduct a variety of inorganic cations and anions, including Ca2+, and even moderate-sized organic compounds.

text 1: Gap junctions are formed between glial cells as well as between neurons.
text 2: Gap junctions are only formed between neurons and are not found in glial cells.

text 1: Chemical synapses cannot amplify signals and rely on direct electrical transmission.
text 2: Chemical synapses can amplify signals due to the release of neurotransmitter from synaptic vesicles.

text 1: In chemical synaptic transmission, transmitter is released from synaptic boutons that contain 100 to 200 synaptic vesicles.
text 2: In chemical synaptic transmission, transmitter is released from axon terminals that contain only 2 to 5 synaptic vesicles.

text 1: A neurotransmitter binds to receptors in the postsynaptic membrane, leading to the opening or closing of ion channels.
text 2: A neurotransmitter binds to receptors in the postsynaptic membrane, leading to the permanent closure of ion channels.

text 1: Inherited mutations in connexin can disrupt the function of gap junction channels and cause congenital deafness.
text 2: Inherited mutations in connexin have no impact on the function of gap junction channels in hearing.

text 1: Chemical synaptic transmission has a property of amplification, allowing one synaptic vesicle to open thousands of ion channels.
text 2: Chemical synaptic transmission lacks amplification, with each synaptic vesicle opening only one ion channel.

text 1: Gap junctions in the mammalian brain disrupt the generation of synchronous 40- to 100-Hz gamma oscillations.
text 2: Gap junctions in the mammalian brain help generate synchronous 40- to 100-Hz gamma oscillations.

text 1: Electrical synapses allow rapid and synchronous firing of interconnected cells.
text 2: Electrical synapses transmit metabolic signals between cells through large-diameter pore channels.

text 1: Electrical stimulation of neuronal pathways can trigger a rise in intracellular Ca2+ in astrocytes.
text 2: Electrical stimulation of neuronal pathways completely blocks intracellular signaling in astrocytes.

text 1: The synaptic cleft at chemical synapses is usually slightly wider (20–40 nm) than the nonsynaptic intercellular space.
text 2: The synaptic cleft at chemical synapses is usually narrower than the nonsynaptic intercellular space.

text 1: At chemical synapses, there is complete structural continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons.
text 2: At chemical synapses, there is no structural continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons.

text 1: Electrically coupled cells always fire independently regardless of their thresholds.
text 2: Electrically coupled cells fire synchronously once their high threshold is surpassed.

text 1: The stretch reflex acts to promote the lengthening of a muscle.
text 2: The stretch reflex acts to resist the lengthening of a muscle.

text 1: Charles Sherrington recognized the importance of sensory information in regulating movements in 1906.
text 2: Charles Sherrington recognized the importance of sensory information in regulating movements in 1925.

text 1: Minimal damage to glutamatergic neurons in the parabrachial and pedunculopontine nuclei can cause a prolonged coma.
text 2: Extensive damage to glutamatergic neurons in the parabrachial and pedunculopontine nuclei can cause a prolonged coma.

text 1: Ablation of any one of the monoaminergic cell groups causes a profound effect on the waking state.
text 2: Ablation of any one of the monoaminergic cell groups has little effect on the waking state.

text 1: Thalamic relay neurons fire single spikes related to incoming sensory stimuli during wakefulness.
text 2: Thalamic relay neurons fire in rhythmic bursts related to incoming sensory stimuli during wakefulness.

text 1: Both noradrenergic and serotonergic neurons innervate the parabrachial complex.
text 2: Both noradrenergic and serotonergic neurons innervate the cerebellum.

text 1: Antihistamines cause drowsiness.
text 2: Antihistamines enhance alertness.

text 1: The firing pattern of thalamic and cortical neurons changes from single-spike mode to burst mode when the cells are depolarized by acetylcholine.
text 2: The firing pattern of thalamic and cortical neurons changes from burst mode to single-spike mode when the cells are depolarized by acetylcholine.

text 1: Parabrachial, noradrenergic, serotonergic, histaminergic, and cholinergic inputs modulate the cerebellum's ability to transmit sensory information to the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Parabrachial, noradrenergic, serotonergic, histaminergic, and cholinergic inputs modulate the thalamus's ability to transmit sensory information to the cerebral cortex.

text 1: Nicotine is a powerful depressant.
text 2: Nicotine is a powerful stimulant.

text 1: A large portion of all central nervous system–active drugs act on monoaminergic pathways.
text 2: A large portion of all central nervous system–active drugs act on purinergic pathways.

text 1: Patients with Parkinson disease lose noradrenergic neurons in the locus ceruleus and tend to be abnormally sleepy during the day.
text 2: Patients with Parkinson disease gain noradrenergic neurons in the locus ceruleus and tend to be alert during the day.

text 1: Dopamine reuptake blockers like amphetamines induce sleep.
text 2: Dopamine reuptake blockers like amphetamines induce arousal.

text 1: Monoaminergic neurons hinder the ascending arousal system by silencing cortical activity.
text 2: Monoaminergic neurons participate in the ascending arousal system by regulating cortical activity.

text 1: The thalamic–cerebellar–midbrain–cortical pathway is essential to maintaining a waking state.
text 2: The parabrachial–pedunculopontine–basal forebrain–cortical pathway is essential to maintaining a waking state.

text 1: Monoaminergic pathways stabilize cellular properties of postsynaptic neurons in the thalamus and cerebral cortex.
text 2: Monoaminergic pathways modulate specific cellular properties of postsynaptic neurons in the thalamus and cerebral cortex.

text 1: Both acetylcholine and monoamines convert the firing patterns of cortical and thalamic neurons from burst mode to single-spike mode.
text 2: Both acetylcholine and monoamines convert the firing patterns of cortical and thalamic neurons from single-spike mode to burst mode.

text 1: In male rodents, the spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) promotes the survival of target muscles by expressing the androgen receptor and responding to testosterone.
text 2: In female rodents, the spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) promotes the survival of target muscles by expressing the androgen receptor and responding to testosterone.

text 1: Zebra finches exhibit sexual dimorphism in the song circuit, with larger regions in female songbirds contributing more neurons to song production.
text 2: Zebra finches exhibit sexual dimorphism in the song circuit, with larger regions in male songbirds contributing more neurons to song production.

text 1: The female-specific perinatal surge of testosterone promotes the survival of neurons in the SDN-POA and BNST in male rodents.
text 2: The male-specific perinatal surge of testosterone promotes the survival of neurons in the SDN-POA and BNST in male rodents.

text 1: Removal of the olfactory bulb abolishes mating and aggression in mice, indicating an essential role for olfactory stimulation.
text 2: Enhancement of the olfactory bulb promotes mating and aggression in mice, indicating an essential role for olfactory stimulation.

text 1: Estrogen produced from testosterone aromatization in the male rodent brain promotes neuron survival via activation of estrogen receptors.
text 2: Estrogen produced from testosterone aromatization in the female rodent brain promotes neuron survival via activation of estrogen receptors.

text 1: Female-specific neurons survive due to testosterone aromatization into estrogen in the SDN-POA and BNST.
text 2: Male-specific neurons survive due to testosterone aromatization into estrogen in the SDN-POA and BNST.

text 1: Sensory neurons in the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) detect volatile odors, whereas the vomeronasal organ (VNO) detects nonvolatile cues.
text 2: Sensory neurons in the vomeronasal organ (VNO) detect volatile odors, whereas the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) detects nonvolatile cues.

text 1: Pheromone detection in the vomeronasal organ (VNO) is crucial for sex discrimination and mating behavior in mice.
text 2: Pheromone detection in the main olfactory epithelium (MOE) is crucial for sex discrimination and mating behavior in mice.

text 1: Trpc2 is essential for pheromone signaling in main olfactory epithelium (MOE) neurons, not expressed in VNO neurons.
text 2: Trpc2 is essential for pheromone signaling in vomeronasal organ (VNO) neurons, not expressed in MOE neurons.

text 1: In zebra finches, the female high vocal center (HVC) is larger in volume and contains more neurons than the comparable regions in the male.
text 2: In zebra finches, the male high vocal center (HVC) is larger in volume and contains more neurons than the comparable regions in the female.

text 1: The ability of brain testosterone to promote neuron survival is exerted directly without aromatization into estrogen.
text 2: The ability of brain testosterone to promote neuron survival is exerted via aromatization into estrogen.

text 1: In newborn males, the small amount of estrogen present is easily sequestered by binding to α-fetoprotein.
text 2: In newborn females, the small amount of estrogen present is easily sequestered by binding to α-fetoprotein.

text 1: Male mice lacking α-fetoprotein exhibit female-typical behaviors and reduced male-typical sexual receptivity.
text 2: Female mice lacking α-fetoprotein exhibit male-typical behaviors and reduced female-typical sexual receptivity.

text 1: Genetically engineered enhancement of pheromone responsiveness in MOE or VNO reveals a simple role in mouse mating behavior.
text 2: Genetically engineered disruption of pheromone responsiveness in MOE or VNO reveals a complex role in mouse mating behavior.

text 1: The lateral magnocellular nucleus of the anterior neostriatum (LMAN) is larger in volume in male zebra finches than in females.
text 2: The lateral magnocellular nucleus of the anterior neostriatum (LMAN) is larger in volume in female zebra finches than in males.

text 1: Structural magnetic resonance imaging depicts the near-complete removal of the left occipital cortex in a patient, M.S., who suffered pharmacologically intractable epilepsy with a right occipital cortical focus.
text 2: Structural magnetic resonance imaging depicts the near-complete removal of the right occipital cortex in a patient, M.S., who suffered pharmacologically intractable epilepsy with a right occipital cortical focus.

text 1: Font-specific priming is intact in amnesic patients (AMN) and their controls as well as in the controls for patient M.S., but not in M.S. himself.
text 2: Font-specific priming is intact in amnesic patients (AMN) and their controls as well as in patient M.S. himself, but not in the controls for M.S.

text 1: Implicit memory refers to forms of knowledge that guide behavior with full conscious awareness.
text 2: Implicit memory refers to forms of knowledge that guide behavior without conscious awareness.

text 1: Damage to unimodal sensory regions of cortex enhances modality-specific perceptual priming.
text 2: Damage to unimodal sensory regions of cortex impairs modality-specific perceptual priming.

text 1: The patient M.S. has normal explicit memory, even for visual cues, but lacks implicit memory for specific properties of visually presented words.
text 2: The patient M.S. lacks normal explicit memory, even for visual cues, but has implicit memory for specific properties of visually presented words.

text 1: H.M. was unable to acquire new visuomotor skills, like the mirror-tracing task.
text 2: H.M. was able to acquire new visuomotor skills, like the mirror-tracing task.

text 1: Statistical learning is typically measured by a slower reaction time to repeated compared to nonrepeated sequences.
text 2: Statistical learning is typically measured by a faster reaction time to repeated compared to nonrepeated sequences.

text 1: Functional imaging of healthy individuals during sensorimotor learning shows a decrease in the activity of the basal ganglia and cerebellum and their connectivity with cortical regions.
text 2: Functional imaging of healthy individuals during sensorimotor learning shows changes in the activity of the basal ganglia and cerebellum and their connectivity with cortical regions.

text 1: Patients with cerebellar lesions also have difficulties acquiring some motor skills.
text 2: Patients with cerebellar lesions have no difficulties acquiring any motor skills.

text 1: Incremental learning of stimulus-reward associations depends on the striatum.
text 2: Incremental learning of stimulus-reward associations does not depend on the striatum.

text 1: fMRI studies show lack of functional connectivity between the hippocampus and the striatum in support of learning across a variety of tasks.
text 2: fMRI studies show functional connectivity between the hippocampus and the striatum in support of learning across a variety of tasks.

text 1: Habituation is an increased response that occurs when a benign stimulus is presented repeatedly.
text 2: Habituation is a decrease in a response that occurs when a benign stimulus is presented repeatedly.

text 1: Sensitization is a reduced response to a wide variety of stimuli after the presentation of an intense or noxious stimulus.
text 2: Sensitization is an enhanced response to a wide variety of stimuli after the presentation of an intense or noxious stimulus.

text 1: Learning of sensorimotor skills depends exclusively on the hippocampus and does not vary with the specific associations being learned.
text 2: Learning of sensorimotor skills depends on numerous brain regions that vary with the specific associations being learned.

text 1: Nonassociative learning results only when a subject is exposed to multiple types of stimuli.
text 2: Nonassociative learning results when a subject is exposed once or repeatedly to a single type of stimulus.

text 1: The human brain is less capable of carrying out actions than current computers.
text 2: The human brain carries out actions in ways no current computer can begin to approach.

text 1: The brain is hierarchically organized such that information processed at one level is passed to higher-level circuits for more complex and refined processing.
text 2: The brain processes information in a scattered manner with no specific order of complexity.

text 1: The somatosensory system is the least understood system and does not illustrate the interaction of sensory processing circuits.
text 2: The somatosensory system is particularly well understood and helps illustrate the interaction of sensory processing circuits at several levels.

text 1: Voluntary movement is mediated by indirect connections between the cortex and pancreas.
text 2: Voluntary movement is mediated by direct connections between the cortex and spinal cord.

text 1: The hippocampal formation is interconnected with the highest-level polysensory cortical regions.
text 2: The hippocampal formation is isolated from all polysensory cortical regions.

text 1: Explicit memory depends on circuits in the hippocampus.
text 2: Explicit memory depends solely on circuits in the spinal cord.

text 1: Sensory information processing culminates in the cerebral cortex.
text 2: Sensory information processing culminates in the cerebellum.

text 1: The thalamus is unrelated to sensory processing and acts only as a motor control center.
text 2: The thalamus is an essential link between sensory receptors and the cerebral cortex.

text 1: The peripheral nervous system is integrated seamlessly within the central nervous system.
text 2: The peripheral nervous system is anatomically distinct from the central nervous system.

text 1: Complex behaviors can be carried out by a single neuron acting independently.
text 2: Complex behaviors require the integrated action of several nuclei and cortical regions.

text 1: Within the spinal cord, simple reflex circuits only process pain information and have no output.
text 2: Within the spinal cord, simple reflex circuits receive sensory information from stretch receptors and send output to various muscle groups.

text 1: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal pathway is the major afferent pathway for somatosensory information.
text 2: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal pathway is primarily involved in motor control.

text 1: Information in the brain is processed randomly and lacks any hierarchy.
text 2: Information is processed in the brain in a hierarchical fashion.

text 1: For complex behavioral functions, different stages of information processing are carried out in networks in different regions of the nervous system.
text 2: Complex behavioral functions are processed only in one central region of the nervous system.

text 1: The somatic sensory cortex is located in the frontal gyrus.
text 2: The somatic sensory cortex is located in the postcentral gyrus.

text 1: The caudate nucleus, which in turn is excited by the frontal eye fields, inhibits the substantia nigra.
text 2: The caudate nucleus excites the frontal eye fields and inhibits the substantia nigra.

text 1: A lesion of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus causes hypometric ipsiversive saccades.
text 2: Damage to the oculomotor vermis disinhibits the fastigial nucleus and causes hypometric ipsiversive saccades.

text 1: The superior colliculus integrates visual and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.
text 2: The superior colliculus integrates auditory and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.

text 1: The pontine and mesencephalic burst circuits provide the motor signals necessary to drive the extraocular muscles for saccades.
text 2: The pontine and mesencephalic burst circuits provide sensory signals necessary to drive the extraocular muscles for saccades.

text 1: A lesion of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus causes ipsiversive saccades to overshoot their targets (hypermetric saccades), and contraversive saccades undershoot their targets (hypometric saccades).
text 2: Damage to the fastigial nucleus results in hypermetric contraversive saccades and hypometric ipsiversive saccades.

text 1: Neurons in the superior colliculus are organized in a retinotopic map.
text 2: Neurons in the superior colliculus are arranged in a tonotopic map.

text 1: The superior colliculus is controlled solely by the frontal eye field of the cerebral cortex.
text 2: The superior colliculus is controlled by two regions of the cerebral cortex that have overlapping but distinct functions: the lateral intraparietal area and the frontal eye field.

text 1: In monkeys, sensory activity in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus directly leads to motor output.
text 2: Activity in the superficial and intermediate layers of the superior colliculus can occur independently: sensory activity in the superficial layers does not always lead to motor output.

text 1: The substantia nigra excites neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus during a saccade.
text 2: A neuron in the substantia nigra pars reticulata inhibits neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus.

text 1: Neurons in the superior colliculus superficial layers respond to visual stimuli.
text 2: Neurons in the superior colliculus superficial layers respond specifically to auditory stimuli.

text 1: A large population of cells is thus active before each saccade, and eye movement is encoded by the entire ensemble of these broadly tuned cells.
text 2: A large population of cells in the superior colliculus is active before each auditory movement.

text 1: Neurons in the rostral superior colliculus discharge strongly during passive visual fixation.
text 2: Neurons in the rostral superior colliculus discharge strongly during active visual fixation.

text 1: The frontal eye fields release the superior colliculus from suppression through direct inhibition of the substantia nigra.
text 2: The frontal eye fields directly excite the colliculus and indirectly release it from suppression by the substantia nigra by exciting the caudate nucleus, which inhibits the substantia nigra.

text 1: Neurons in the intermediate layers of the superior colliculus project directly to the visual cortex.
text 2: Neurons in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus do not provide a large projection directly to the intermediate layers.

text 1: Lesions of a small part of the superior colliculus have no effect on saccades.
text 2: Lesions of a small part of the colliculus affect the latency, accuracy, and velocity of saccades.

text 1: Growth cones have three main compartments: filopodia, lamellipodia, and a central core.
text 2: Growth cones have four main compartments: filopodia, lamellipodia, a central core, and dendrites.

text 1: Filopodia on growth cones are actin-rich structures that are highly motile and help in sensing environmental signals.
text 2: Filopodia on growth cones are tubulin-rich structures that are static and do not participate in sensing environmental signals.

text 1: Ramón y Cajal discovered the growth cone and had key insights about its role in axonal pathfinding.
text 2: Ramón y Cajal discovered dendrites and had key insights about their role in neuronal communication.

text 1: The movement of actin along myosin in filopodia is similar to the contraction mechanism of skeletal muscle fibers.
text 2: The movement of actin along tubulin in filopodia is similar to the contraction mechanism of skeletal muscle fibers.

text 1: Calcium concentration in growth cones affects cytoskeleton organization and modulates motility.
text 2: Potassium concentration in growth cones affects cytoskeleton organization and modulates motility.

text 1: Filopodia length permits them to sample environments far in advance of the central core of the growth cone.
text 2: Filopodia length limits them to environments close to the central core of the growth cone.

text 1: Growth cones are only sensory structures and do not play a role in axon elongation.
text 2: Growth cones are both sensory and motor structures that drive axon elongation.

text 1: Integrin receptors in growth cones influence motility by coupling to tubulin.
text 2: Integrin receptors in growth cones influence motility by coupling to actin.

text 1: Filopodia are sheet-like, tubulin-rich structures that are static.
text 2: Filopodia are rod-like, actin-rich, membrane-limited structures that are highly motile.

text 1: Growth cone motility is optimal within a narrow range of calcium concentrations, known as a set point.
text 2: Growth cone motility is optimal within a narrow range of potassium concentrations, known as a set point.

text 1: Growth cones transduce positive and negative cues into signals that regulate the cytoskeleton.
text 2: Growth cones transduce positive and negative cues into signals that regulate mitochondrial activity.

text 1: Application of growth factors to one side of an embryonic neuron growth cone leads it to turn toward the source.
text 2: Application of growth factors to one side of an embryonic neuron growth cone leads it to turn away from the source.

text 1: Growth cones contain the machinery for protein synthesis, including a subset of messenger RNAs.
text 2: Growth cones do not contain machinery for protein synthesis and depend entirely on the cell body.

text 1: Ramón y Cajal envisioned dendritic spines to be 'endowed with exquisite chemical sensitivity.'
text 2: Ramón y Cajal envisioned growth cones to be 'endowed with exquisite chemical sensitivity.'

text 1: Cyclic nucleotides modulate the activity of enzymes such as protein kinases.
text 2: Cyclic nucleotides modulate the activity of enzymes such as lactase.

text 1: The retina transforms light patterns projected onto photoreceptors into neural signals that are conveyed through the optic nerve to specialized visual centers in the brain.
text 2: The retina transforms sound patterns projected onto photoreceptors into neural signals that are conveyed through the optic nerve to specialized visual centers in the brain.

text 1: Rod photoreceptors are efficient collectors of light and serve nocturnal vision.
text 2: Cone photoreceptors are efficient collectors of light and serve nocturnal vision.

text 1: Through lateral networks, light in the receptive-field center of a ganglion cell counteracts the effect of light in the surround.
text 2: Through lateral networks, light in the receptive-field surround of a ganglion cell counteracts the effect of light in the center.

text 1: Rods synapse onto bipolar cells that in turn excite ganglion cells.
text 2: Cones synapse onto bipolar cells that in turn excite ganglion cells.

text 1: The visual system follows Weber’s law approximately.
text 2: The visual system follows Weber’s law precisely.

text 1: Dopamine released by specialized amacrine cells is an important regulator of changes in receptive-field properties in the retina.
text 2: Light released by specialized amacrine cells is an important regulator of changes in receptive-field properties in the retina.

text 1: Cone bipolar cells begin to adapt at somewhat higher light intensities, changing their responsiveness depending on the average light level.
text 2: Rod bipolar cells begin to adapt at somewhat higher light intensities, changing their responsiveness depending on the average light level.

text 1: When illumination is continuous, the Ca2+ concentration remains low, and reactions are in a steady state that lowers the gain and accelerates the response to light.
text 2: When illumination is continuous, the Ca2+ concentration remains high, and reactions are in a steady state that lowers the gain and accelerates the response to light.

text 1: The firing rates of optic nerve fibers can vary effectively over only two orders of magnitude.
text 2: The firing rates of optic nerve fibers can vary effectively over three orders of magnitude.

text 1: Cone cells connect to specialized cone bipolar cells whose signals are conveyed through amacrine cells to the rod bipolar cells.
text 2: Rod cells connect to specialized rod bipolar cells whose signals are conveyed through amacrine cells to the cone bipolar cells.

text 1: Light adaptation results principally from gain changes within the cones as ambient light increases further.
text 2: Light adaptation results principally from gain changes within the rods as ambient light increases further.

text 1: Ganglion cells have a broad receptive field structure that doesn't change as light dims.
text 2: Ganglion cells have a sharp center-surround structure in their receptive fields, but this structure changes as light dims.

text 1: The transduction of sound stimuli begins in the outer segment of the photoreceptor cell when a pigment molecule absorbs a photon.
text 2: The transduction of light stimuli begins in the outer segment of the photoreceptor cell when a pigment molecule absorbs a photon.

text 1: Horizontal connections are primarily inhibitory in the excitatory pathways.
text 2: Horizontal connections are primarily excitatory in the excitatory pathways.

text 1: Sensitivity decreases more steeply with increasing background intensity.
text 2: Sensitivity decreases somewhat less steeply with increasing background intensity.

text 1: The distal segment of the axon experiences degeneration through a process called Wallerian degeneration, which is actively regulated.
text 2: The proximal segment of the axon experiences degeneration through a process called Wallerian degeneration, which is actively regulated.

text 1: In Wlds mutant mice, the proximal portion of severed axons persists much longer compared to normal mice, suggesting an actively regulated response to axotomy.
text 2: In Wlds mutant mice, the distal portion of severed axons persists much longer compared to normal mice, suggesting an actively regulated response to axotomy.

text 1: Axotomy divides the axon into a distal segment that remains attached to the cell body and a proximal segment that loses attachment.
text 2: Axotomy divides the axon into a proximal segment that remains attached to the cell body and a distal segment that loses attachment.

text 1: Santiago Ramón y Cajal believed that in the injured central nervous system, nothing may be regenerated.
text 2: Santiago Ramón y Cajal believed that in the injured central nervous system, everything may be regenerated.

text 1: NMNAT1 is confined to the axon in normal conditions, but mislocalizes to the nucleus in Wlds mutant mice.
text 2: NMNAT1 is confined to the nucleus in normal conditions, but mislocalizes to the axon in Wlds mutant mice.

text 1: Chromatolysis involves swelling of the cell body and movement of the nucleus to an eccentric position.
text 2: Chromatolysis involves shrinking of the cell body and movement of the nucleus to a central position.

text 1: Evidence has accumulated that neurogenesis occurs in certain regions of the adult mammalian brain.
text 2: Evidence has accumulated that neurogenesis does not occur in any regions of the adult mammalian brain.

text 1: Following axotomy, calcium levels rise within the axon, activating proteases which initiate cytoskeletal disassembly.
text 2: Following axotomy, calcium levels decrease within the axon, activating proteases which initiate cytoskeletal disassembly.

text 1: In Wlds mutant mice, a mutant form of NMNAT1 forms, which can substitute for NMNAT2 to prolong axonal survival.
text 2: In Wlds mutant mice, a mutant form of NMNAT2 forms, which can substitute for NMNAT1 to prolong axonal survival.

text 1: Axon degeneration in Wlds mutant mice is accelerated compared to wild type mice due to mislocalization of the mutant protein.
text 2: Axon degeneration in Wlds mutant mice is delayed compared to wild type mice due to mislocalization of the mutant protein.

text 1: Wallerian degeneration was first described by Augustus Waller in 1950.
text 2: Wallerian degeneration was first described by Augustus Waller in 1850.

text 1: The proximal stump of the axon undergoes degeneration due to the loss of attachment from the cell body and dwindling energy supplies.
text 2: The distal stump of the axon undergoes degeneration due to the loss of attachment from the cell body and dwindling energy supplies.

text 1: SARM1 activation leads to synthesis of NAD, preventing axon degeneration.
text 2: SARM1 activation leads to degradation of NAD, promoting axon degeneration.

text 1: NMNAT2 normally present in neurons generates NAD and inhibits SARM1 to maintain energy metabolism.
text 2: NMNAT2 normally present in axons generates NAD and inhibits SARM1 to maintain energy metabolism.

text 1: The ability to form new neurons in the adult brain was a central dogma of neuroscience for most of the last century.
text 2: The inability to form new neurons in the adult brain was a central dogma of neuroscience for most of the last century.

text 1: In English, adjectives typically follow the noun.
text 2: In English, adjectives typically precede the noun.

text 1: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 10,000 words.
text 2: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 1,000 words.

text 1: Infants ‘coo’ with vowel-like sounds at 3 months of age.
text 2: Infants ‘coo’ with vowel-like sounds at 6 months of age.

text 1: The combination /zb/ is allowed in English but not in Polish.
text 2: The combination /zb/ is not allowed in English but is common in Polish.

text 1: Between 36 and 48 months, children respond to grammatical sentences in an adult-like way.
text 2: Between 36 and 48 months, children cannot respond to grammatical sentences.

text 1: Chinese toddlers’ utterances reflect the pitch, rhythm, and phonetic structure of Mandarin.
text 2: Chinese toddlers’ utterances reflect the pitch and rhythm of English.

text 1: Japanese speakers often use the /r/ and /l/ sounds interchangeably when producing words.
text 2: Japanese speakers distinctly differentiate between the /r/ and /l/ sounds when producing words.

text 1: Infants are sensitive to the statistical properties of the language they hear.
text 2: Infants are insensitive to the statistical properties of the language they hear.

text 1: Adults find it difficult to discern phonetic units in languages they are not fluent in.
text 2: Adults easily discern phonetic units in languages they are not fluent in.

text 1: The behavioral psychologist B. F. Skinner proposed that language was acquired through learning.
text 2: The behavioral psychologist B. F. Skinner proposed that language was innate and not reliant on learning.

text 1: The nativist Noam Chomsky argued that traditional reinforcement learning has little to do with language acquisition.
text 2: The nativist Noam Chomsky argued that traditional reinforcement learning is crucial to language acquisition.

text 1: Speech perception becomes language-specific before speech production.
text 2: Speech production becomes language-specific before speech perception.

text 1: Categorical perception occurs in both humans and nonhuman mammals.
text 2: Categorical perception occurs only in humans, not in nonhuman mammals.

text 1: Infants begin to produce babbling using consonant–vowel combinations at about 3 months of age.
text 2: Infants begin to produce babbling using consonant–vowel combinations at about 7 months of age.

text 1: The order of words within larger elements differs between languages like English and Japanese.
text 2: The order of words within larger elements is identical between languages like English and Japanese.

text 1: Neurotrophins interact with Trk receptors but cannot bind to the low-affinity neurotrophin receptor p75, which contributes to neuronal survival.
text 2: Neurotrophins interact with Trk receptors and can bind to the low-affinity neurotrophin receptor p75, which contributes to neuronal survival.

text 1: Binding of proneurotrophins to the p75/sortilin complex promotes neuronal survival by suppressing caspase activity.
text 2: Binding of proneurotrophins to the p75/sortilin complex promotes neuronal death by activating caspases.

text 1: The retrograde transport of neurotrophin-Trk receptor complexes occurs through signaling endosomes to deactivate neuronal survival pathways.
text 2: The retrograde transport of neurotrophin-Trk receptor complexes occurs through signaling endosomes to activate neuronal survival pathways.

text 1: The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes members that either promote or inhibit cell death in mammals.
text 2: The Bcl-2 family of proteins exclusively promotes cell death in mammals.

text 1: Caspase activation leads to apoptosis, involving chromatin condensation and DNA fragmentation.
text 2: Caspase activation leads to apoptosis, preventing chromatin condensation and DNA fragmentation.

text 1: Apoptosis differs from necrosis because apoptosis involves activation of a programmed cell death pathway.
text 2: Apoptosis is identical to necrosis, as both involve acute traumatic injury to cells.

text 1: Withdrawal of neurotrophic factors leads to enhanced metabolism and neuronal survival.
text 2: Withdrawal of neurotrophic factors leads to apoptosis by derepressing the latent cell death pathway.

text 1: Ced-9 protein in Caenorhabditis elegans inhibits cell death by antagonizing Ced-3 and Ced-4 activities.
text 2: Ced-9 protein in Caenorhabditis elegans promotes cell death by enhancing Ced-3 and Ced-4 activities.

text 1: The mammalian apoptotic cell death pathway is completely different from the pathway observed in Caenorhabditis elegans.
text 2: The mammalian apoptotic cell death pathway resembles the pathway observed in Caenorhabditis elegans.

text 1: Neurotrophic factors suppress caspase activation and cell death through the PI3 kinase pathway.
text 2: Neurotrophic factors enhance caspase activation and cell death through the PI3 kinase pathway.

text 1: Motor neuron survival is independent of neurotrophins, GDNF, and interleukin-6–like proteins.
text 2: Motor neuron survival depends on exposure to neurotrophins, GDNF, and interleukin-6–like proteins.

text 1: Chromatin condensation does not occur in cells undergoing apoptosis.
text 2: Chromatin condensation is one of the hallmark features of cells undergoing apoptosis.

text 1: Ced-3 encodes a kinase in Caenorhabditis elegans completely unrelated to mammalian caspases.
text 2: Ced-3 encodes a cysteine protease in Caenorhabditis elegans that is related to mammalian caspases.

text 1: In apoptosis, cytochrome c enhances mitochondrial function instead of activating caspases.
text 2: In apoptosis, cytochrome c is released from the mitochondrial intermembrane space to activate caspases.

text 1: The mammalian protein Apaf-1 is unrelated to Ced-4 in Caenorhabditis elegans.
text 2: The mammalian protein Apaf-1 is functionally related to Ced-4 in Caenorhabditis elegans.
